taciturn, this worthy signor. Be it understood we are speaking of	183.70302171308828
Athos. During the five or six years that he had lived in the strictest	214.67932211314513
intimacy with his companions, Porthos and Aramis, they could remember	200.58994641893253
having often seen him smile, but had never heard him laugh. His words	254.77463421866554
were brief and expressive, conveying all that was meant, and no more;	251.2650178485585
no embellishments, no embroidery, no arabesques. His conversation was a	245.58828244006972
matter of fact, without a single romance.	194.9350787764265
Although Athos was scarcely thirty years old, and was of great personal	364.25292146513186
beauty and intelligence of mind, no one knew whether he had ever had a	338.47782469601907
mistress. He never spoke of women. He certainly did not prevent others	333.2875201732925
from speaking of them before him, although it was easy to perceive that	290.37439047554847
this kind of conversation, in which he only mingled by bitter words and	334.669260786382
misanthropic remarks, was very disagreeable to him. His reserve, his	331.0102924417808
roughness, and his silence made almost an old man of him. He had, then,	217.5455911783203
in order not to disturb his habits, accustomed Grimaud to obey him upon	355.5956710119498
a simple gesture or upon a simple movement of his lips. He never spoke	265.6056843224353
to him, except under the most extraordinary occasions.	196.55517126976167
Sometimes, Grimaud, who feared his master as he did fire, while	194.42276637021598
entertaining a strong attachment to his person and a great veneration	226.01174241236276
for his talents, believed he perfectly understood what he wanted, flew	303.97969952001796
to execute the order received, and did precisely the contrary. Athos	300.54641355669787
then shrugged his shoulders, and, without putting himself in a passion,	257.7548600729375
thrashed Grimaud. On these days he spoke a little.	273.9267350929264
Porthos, as we have seen, had a character exactly opposite to that of	303.0003022013427
Athos. He not only talked much, but he talked loudly, little caring, we	179.02117896535879
must render him that justice, whether anybody listened to him or not.	309.4023941666304
He talked for the pleasure of talking and for the pleasure of hearing	266.17016865066876
himself talk. He spoke upon all subjects except the sciences, alleging	201.4230646703535
in this respect the inveterate hatred he had borne to scholars from his	188.82287611884246
childhood. He had not so noble an air as Athos, and the commencement of	238.7876216447185
their intimacy often rendered him unjust toward that gentleman, whom he	279.9790860165253
endeavored to eclipse by his splendid dress. But with his simple	364.98341143783443
Musketeer’s uniform and nothing but the manner in which he threw back	220.44927673422836
his head and advanced his foot, Athos instantly took the place which	317.03097486723925
was his due and consigned the ostentatious Porthos to the second rank.	228.25518071498217
Porthos consoled himself by filling the antechamber of M. de Tréville	303.81757079633684
and the guardroom of the Louvre with the accounts of his love scrapes,	364.7317468262179
after having passed from professional ladies to military ladies, from	298.5557911898972
the lawyer’s dame to the baroness, there was question of nothing less	325.0512044724967
with Porthos than a foreign princess, who was enormously fond of him.	323.21508009607487
An old proverb says, “Like master, like man.” Let us pass, then, from	244.12271715410645
the valet of Athos to the valet of Porthos, from Grimaud to Mousqueton.	336.2876220064679
Mousqueton was a Norman, whose pacific name of Boniface his master had	304.77449407647157
changed into the infinitely more sonorous name of Mousqueton. He had	331.7264975736233
entered the service of Porthos upon condition that he should only be	260.1847457743108
clothed and lodged, though in a handsome manner; but he claimed two	224.4163235881881
hours a day to himself, consecrated to an employment which would	335.4129650369914
provide for his other wants. Porthos agreed to the bargain; the thing	184.6858733061916
suited him wonderfully well. He had doublets cut out of his old clothes	217.31324127760138
and cast-off cloaks for Mousqueton, and thanks to a very intelligent	285.6712542948138
tailor, who made his clothes look as good as new by turning them, and	171.10812287667946
whose wife was suspected of wishing to make Porthos descend from his	324.64162586677753
aristocratic habits, Mousqueton made a very good figure when attending	174.57683825199308
on his master.	265.27119135830145
As for Aramis, of whom we believe we have sufficiently explained the	342.37868770200544
character—a character which, like that of his companions, we shall be	180.0434044051316
able to follow in its development—his lackey was called Bazin. Thanks	328.8025941583311
to the hopes which his master entertained of someday entering into	269.92174768373434
orders, he was always clothed in black, as became the servant of a	202.24906813393943
churchman. He was a Berrichon, thirty-five or forty years old, mild,	244.40100185425504
peaceable, sleek, employing the leisure his master left him in the	225.73518700390824
perusal of pious works, providing rigorously for two a dinner of few	330.77764998932616
dishes, but excellent. For the rest, he was dumb, blind, and deaf, and	195.88807821330226
of unimpeachable fidelity.	326.31521854532366
And now that we are acquainted, superficially at least, with the	181.57120103850394
masters and the valets, let us pass on to the dwellings occupied by	286.914349678352
each of them.	308.5050852451981
Athos dwelt in the Rue Férou, within two steps of the Luxembourg. His	245.98473784524276
apartment consisted of two small chambers, very nicely fitted up, in a	328.37138803050686
furnished house, the hostess of which, still young and still really	209.68440439090932
handsome, cast tender glances uselessly at him. Some fragments of past	364.7350492949295
splendor appeared here and there upon the walls of this modest lodging;	307.55419652579894
a sword, for example, richly embossed, which belonged by its make to	169.81576667908948
the times of Francis I, the hilt of which alone, encrusted with	249.63982895636462
precious stones, might be worth two hundred pistoles, and which,	251.40645849573303
nevertheless, in his moments of greatest distress Athos had never	331.3369044519111
pledged or offered for sale. It had long been an object of ambition for	171.3294980379886
Porthos. Porthos would have given ten years of his life to possess this	309.86862239873244
sword.	305.6292941750953
One day, when he had an appointment with a duchess, he endeavored even	203.4773976831088
to borrow it of Athos. Athos, without saying anything, emptied his	166.51136298353902
pockets, got together all his jewels, purses, aiguillettes, and gold	250.77426735333057
chains, and offered them all to Porthos; but as to the sword, he said	232.8027346459145
it was sealed to its place and should never quit it until its master	220.63966028242777
should himself quit his lodgings. In addition to the sword, there was a	342.1696458590763
portrait representing a nobleman of the time of Henry III., dressed with	217.70380803152358
the greatest elegance, and who wore the Order of the Holy Ghost; and	190.16267033745632
this portrait had certain resemblances of lines with Athos, certain	170.5863139178819
family likenesses which indicated that this great noble, a knight of	174.40117180622173
the Order of the King, was his ancestor.	307.1354083978015
Besides these, a casket of magnificent goldwork, with the same arms as	258.70765565068007
the sword and the portrait, formed a middle ornament to the	267.4820664616967
mantelpiece, and assorted badly with the rest of the furniture. Athos	327.0348252566873
always carried the key of this coffer about him; but he one day opened	356.6912856040685
it before Porthos, and Porthos was convinced that this coffer contained	268.48016305108416
nothing but letters and papers—love letters and family papers, no	336.48346266075737
doubt.	330.9641309673269
Porthos lived in an apartment, large in size and of very sumptuous	292.10909583248434
appearance, in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier. Every time he passed with a	361.0888095008198
friend before his windows, at one of which Mousqueton was sure to be	219.48538684103985
placed in full livery, Porthos raised his head and his hand, and said,	210.6751611618224
“That is my abode!” But he was never to be found at home; he never	309.7012570302224
invited anybody to go up with him, and no one could form an idea of	251.90634148822494
what his sumptuous apartment contained in the shape of real riches.	323.41673064076144
As to Aramis, he dwelt in a little lodging composed of a boudoir, an	311.85575127834215
eating room, and a bedroom, which room, situated, as the others were,	275.47596975356396
on the ground floor, looked out upon a little fresh green garden, shady	240.81352079143426
and impenetrable to the eyes of his neighbors.	167.1334279363536
With regard to D’Artagnan, we know how he was lodged, and we have	238.96059199981016
already made acquaintance with his lackey, Master Planchet.	259.97559560487105
D’Artagnan, who was by nature very curious—as people generally are who	203.17332798568404
possess the genius of intrigue—did all he could to make out who Athos,	168.55447919063366
Porthos, and Aramis really were (for under these pseudonyms each of	194.8694594239211
these young men concealed his family name)—Athos in particular, who, a	284.84662761904093
league away, savored of nobility. He addressed himself then to Porthos	206.32135487118637
to gain information respecting Athos and Aramis, and to Aramis in order	178.75399755917078
to learn something of Porthos.	176.37945254894214
Unfortunately Porthos knew nothing of the life of his silent companion	296.09063270587325
but what revealed itself. It was said Athos had met with great crosses	208.42009749780038
in love, and that a frightful treachery had forever poisoned the life	187.49649734105185
of this gallant man. What could this treachery be? All the world was	231.32140882142875
ignorant of it.	186.84550755934984
As to Porthos, except his real name (as was the case with those of his	283.25619560420597
two comrades), his life was very easily known. Vain and indiscreet, it	212.11986759960362
was as easy to see through him as through a crystal. The only thing to	304.8132391160899
mislead the investigator would have been belief in all the good things	181.75143183473557
he said of himself.	195.62420804181994
With respect to Aramis, though having the air of having nothing secret	289.36767143536554
about him, he was a young fellow made up of mysteries, answering little	319.6833491603852
to questions put to him about others, and having learned from him the	202.66860481079658
report which prevailed concerning the success of the Musketeer with a	238.0457014723179
princess, wished to gain a little insight into the amorous adventures	290.6288479292541
of his interlocutor. “And you, my dear companion,” said he, “you speak	182.7475850463813
of the baronesses, countesses, and princesses of others?”	277.96608942839816
“_Pardieu!_ I spoke of them because Porthos talked of them himself,	186.53383539380096
because he had paraded all these fine things before me. But be assured,	338.43293524895716
my dear Monsieur d’Artagnan, that if I had obtained them from any other	178.83511330887697
source, or if they had been confided to me, there exists no confessor	349.20033903314356
more discreet than myself.”	207.83727701785088
“Oh, I don’t doubt that,” replied D’Artagnan; “but it seems to me that	212.20364678196134
you are tolerably familiar with coats of arms—a certain embroidered	231.6698728678902
handkerchief, for instance, to which I owe the honor of your	304.95063523891645
acquaintance?”	347.24430706117096
This time Aramis was not angry, but assumed the most modest air and	318.44766882870226
replied in a friendly tone, “My dear friend, do not forget that I wish	329.2106123850515
to belong to the Church, and that I avoid all mundane opportunities.	280.9331944480747
The handkerchief you saw had not been given to me, but it had been	309.5402647166027
forgotten and left at my house by one of my friends. I was obliged to	262.2139436496127
pick it up in order not to compromise him and the lady he loves. As for	333.31867986535576
myself, I neither have, nor desire to have, a mistress, following in	314.8201923684944
that respect the very judicious example of Athos, who has none any more	365.93550013384186
than I have.”	187.42049708328025
“But what the devil! You are not a priest, you are a Musketeer!”	247.04884667050624
“A Musketeer for a time, my friend, as the cardinal says, a Musketeer	191.73836994531172
against my will, but a churchman at heart, believe me. Athos and	353.6530298746826
Porthos dragged me into this to occupy me. I had, at the moment of	284.5078224431161
being ordained, a little difficulty with—But that would not interest	317.44325883861796
you, and I am taking up your valuable time.”	220.26291336177133
“Not at all; it interests me very much,” cried D’Artagnan; “and at this	298.08428809439755
moment I have absolutely nothing to do.”	320.27295475507304
“Yes, but I have my breviary to repeat,” answered Aramis; “then some	251.9619680128916
verses to compose, which Madame d’Aiguillon begged of me. Then I must	325.4468195534887
go to the Rue St. Honoré in order to purchase some rouge for Madame de	182.74201313741275
Chevreuse. So you see, my dear friend, that if you are not in a hurry,	301.28635699445323
I am very much in a hurry.”	247.8308222780095
Aramis held out his hand in a cordial manner to his young companion,	242.44222282011526
and took leave of him.	187.59680870699344
Notwithstanding all the pains he took, D’Artagnan was unable to learn	294.2464639349634
any more concerning his three new-made friends. He formed, therefore,	229.92753472964068
the resolution of believing for the present all that was said of their	308.57169862765375
past, hoping for more certain and extended revelations in the future.	258.09222907097615
In the meanwhile, he looked upon Athos as an Achilles, Porthos as an	185.07988477160384
Ajax, and Aramis as a Joseph.	231.29632570878357
As to the rest, the life of the four young friends was joyous enough.	324.6749180201127
Athos played, and that as a rule unfortunately. Nevertheless, he never	227.11095424416567
borrowed a sou of his companions, although his purse was ever at their	354.56836322257243
service; and when he had played upon honor, he always awakened his	351.89383869769483
creditor by six o’clock the next morning to pay the debt of the	289.00629246377036
preceding evening.	294.0475671408892
Porthos had his fits. On the days when he won he was insolent and	244.31778358926277
ostentatious; if he lost, he disappeared completely for several days,	252.72894623517243
after which he reappeared with a pale face and thinner person, but with	354.1027147492672
money in his purse.	309.200382993509
As to Aramis, he never played. He was the worst Musketeer and the most	323.79436299184147
unconvivial companion imaginable. He had always something or other to	249.8474515006103
do. Sometimes in the midst of dinner, when everyone, under the	261.18899162389084
attraction of wine and in the warmth of conversation, believed they had	223.7164677422783
two or three hours longer to enjoy themselves at table, Aramis looked	181.06124705611572
at his watch, arose with a bland smile, and took leave of the company,	322.8752382522557
to go, as he said, to consult a casuist with whom he had an	216.6268053721472
appointment. At other times he would return home to write a treatise,	326.9746758903376
and requested his friends not to disturb him.	186.45254497182563
At this Athos would smile, with his charming, melancholy smile, which	292.4122667728319
so became his noble countenance, and Porthos would drink, swearing that	234.30794010638832
Aramis would never be anything but a village _curé_.	184.8904409698224
Planchet, D’Artagnan’s valet, supported his good fortune nobly. He	208.30397314494357
received thirty sous per day, and for a month he returned to his	171.8314869970071
lodgings gay as a chaffinch, and affable toward his master. When the	188.34635712578122
wind of adversity began to blow upon the housekeeping of the Rue des	191.46449764774044
Fossoyeurs—that is to say, when the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII.	261.2795254031613
were consumed or nearly so—he commenced complaints which Athos thought	210.80284050771596
nauseous, Porthos indecent, and Aramis ridiculous. Athos counseled	260.8859459094484
D’Artagnan to dismiss the fellow; Porthos was of the opinion that he	242.75741481732334
should give him a good thrashing first; and Aramis contended that a	333.82563559688236
master should never attend to anything but the civilities paid to him.	171.14617032776755
“This is all very easy for you to say,” replied D’Artagnan, “for you,	183.26833108287084
Athos, who live like a dumb man with Grimaud, who forbid him to speak,	252.19434988948603
and consequently never exchange ill words with him; for you, Porthos,	235.97106976186637
who carry matters in such a magnificent style, and are a god to your	224.95158683038952
valet, Mousqueton; and for you, Aramis, who, always abstracted by your	271.5555495131118
theological studies, inspire your servant, Bazin, a mild, religious	288.7690467598884
man, with a profound respect; but for me, who am without any settled	228.55699683455032
means and without resources—for me, who am neither a Musketeer nor even	229.0706642985632
a Guardsman, what am I to do to inspire either the affection, the	333.59397733184926
terror, or the respect in Planchet?”	177.79169151393978
“This is serious,” answered the three friends; “it is a family affair.	262.053720741157
It is with valets as with wives, they must be placed at once upon the	268.27076698893757
footing in which you wish them to remain. Reflect upon it.”	185.92471465197815
D’Artagnan did reflect, and resolved to thrash Planchet provisionally;	340.715842463931
which he did with the conscientiousness that D’Artagnan carried into	361.1712184857167
everything. After having well beaten him, he forbade him to leave his	170.2122134354317
service without his permission. “For,” added he, “the future cannot	357.40204072887735
fail to mend; I inevitably look for better times. Your fortune is	345.4883135623967
therefore made if you remain with me, and I am too good a master to	254.66995939633534
allow you to miss such a chance by granting you the dismissal you	239.30940967356784
require.”	261.2097314082907
This manner of acting roused much respect for D’Artagnan’s policy among	167.5242091756025
the Musketeers. Planchet was equally seized with admiration, and said	219.88188957250375
no more about going away.	234.5361658022914
The life of the four young men had become fraternal. D’Artagnan, who	240.9171908027356
had no settled habits of his own, as he came from his province into the	172.6709162607919
midst of a world quite new to him, fell easily into the habits of his	363.45665386771265
friends.	234.57137665262724
They rose about eight o’clock in the winter, about six in summer, and	256.0275770900697
went to take the countersign and see how things went on at M. de	333.81584425749145
Tréville’s. D’Artagnan, although he was not a Musketeer, performed the	172.66236631798486
duty of one with remarkable punctuality. He went on guard because he	185.63915047973694
always kept company with whoever of his friends was on duty. He was	194.4057038173069
well known at the Hôtel of the Musketeers, where everyone considered	183.48984857675936
him a good comrade. M. de Tréville, who had appreciated him at the	275.5431861246941
first glance and who bore him a real affection, never ceased	309.91544210158116
recommending him to the king.	193.10787502513375
On their side, the three Musketeers were much attached to their young	181.46394753092787
comrade. The friendship which united these four men, and the need they	302.2037219700518
felt of seeing another three or four times a day, whether for dueling,	272.2952461424381
business, or pleasure, caused them to be continually running after one	294.9070346386655
another like shadows; and the Inseparables were constantly to be met	249.3319760791592
with seeking one another, from the Luxembourg to the Place St. Sulpice,	181.04090265121107
or from the Rue du Vieux-Colombier to the Luxembourg.	355.43360109500395
In the meanwhile the promises of M. de Tréville went on prosperously.	266.8407758175025
One fine morning the king commanded M. de Chevalier Dessessart to admit	346.2366552174134
D’Artagnan as a cadet in his company of Guards. D’Artagnan, with a	204.538088679659
sigh, donned his uniform, which he would have exchanged for that of a	206.23914742592885
Musketeer at the expense of ten years of his existence. But M. de	246.41805345597857
Tréville promised this favor after a novitiate of two years—a novitiate	204.75806938348802
which might besides be abridged if an opportunity should present itself	296.3348048485982
for D’Artagnan to render the king any signal service, or to distinguish	275.74022144820856
himself by some brilliant action. Upon this promise D’Artagnan	215.078746057818
withdrew, and the next day he began service.	244.05333636711094
Then it became the turn of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis to mount guard	171.30120706863582
with D’Artagnan when he was on duty. The company of M. le Chevalier	195.79149348171347
Dessessart thus received four instead of one when it admitted	198.34798613212013
D’Artagnan.	177.876368450339
Chapter VIII.	232.60162826308346
CONCERNING A COURT INTRIGUE	310.2291021759851
In the meantime, the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII., like all other	351.476920739938
things of this world, after having had a beginning had an end, and	263.39116251854585
after this end our four companions began to be somewhat embarrassed. At	171.58614837734936
first, Athos supported the association for a time with his own means.	183.50391122275525
Porthos succeeded him; and thanks to one of those disappearances to	293.13000135781385
which he was accustomed, he was able to provide for the wants of all	261.1722312407635
for a fortnight. At last it became Aramis’s turn, who performed it with	293.76353841482455
a good grace and who succeeded—as he said, by selling some theological	332.32270504061034
books—in procuring a few pistoles.	221.8877661505789
Then, as they had been accustomed to do, they had recourse to M. de	217.63532569092354
Tréville, who made some advances on their pay; but these advances could	243.66480523486396
not go far with three Musketeers who were already much in arrears and a	185.35911557092328
Guardsman who as yet had no pay at all.	169.36290442951503
At length when they found they were likely to be really in want, they	279.068499869812
got together, as a last effort, eight or ten pistoles, with which	169.12456208084538
Porthos went to the gaming table. Unfortunately he was in a bad vein;	338.0138658886133
he lost all, together with twenty-five pistoles for which he had given	168.0910969590336
his word.	276.8864520814174
Then the inconvenience became distress. The hungry friends, followed by	242.34158698700685
their lackeys, were seen haunting the quays and Guard rooms, picking up	213.01494492044347
among their friends abroad all the dinners they could meet with; for	260.61910220849546
according to the advice of Aramis, it was prudent to sow repasts right	296.90893291930763
and left in prosperity, in order to reap a few in time of need.	353.6186262522724
Athos was invited four times, and each time took his friends and their	293.247419012255
lackeys with him. Porthos had six occasions, and contrived in the same	290.09134178760127
manner that his friends should partake of them; Aramis had eight of	276.6474306858763
them. He was a man, as must have been already perceived, who made but	251.97668375284715
little noise, and yet was much sought after.	226.21989739056934
As to D’Artagnan, who as yet knew nobody in the capital, he only found	218.32944199075155
one chocolate breakfast at the house of a priest of his own province,	298.6619349992159
and one dinner at the house of a cornet of the Guards. He took his army	301.1608689886811
to the priest’s, where they devoured as much provision as would have	290.1772267144232
lasted him for two months, and to the cornet’s, who performed wonders;	241.29890447943097
but as Planchet said, “People do not eat at once for all time, even	179.74691436363966
when they eat a good deal.”	293.2875746742511
D’Artagnan thus felt himself humiliated in having only procured one	186.26490297360775
meal and a half for his companions—as the breakfast at the priest’s	342.1706771701065
could only be counted as half a repast—in return for the feasts which	303.0346510543685
Athos, Porthos, and Aramis had procured him. He fancied himself a	271.61685239819934
burden to the society, forgetting in his perfectly juvenile good faith	232.15777173922214
that he had fed this society for a month; and he set his mind actively	191.69981362380543
to work. He reflected that this coalition of four young, brave,	215.34585736424623
enterprising, and active men ought to have some other object than	248.83126522906633
swaggering walks, fencing lessons, and practical jokes, more or less	247.59794987461152
witty.	197.46971786182618
In fact, four men such as they were—four men devoted to one another,	236.3703252864259
from their purses to their lives; four men always supporting one	354.2992973158597
another, never yielding, executing singly or together the resolutions	330.95165751433126
formed in common; four arms threatening the four cardinal points, or	178.81942594489652
turning toward a single point—must inevitably, either subterraneously,	333.6799643496024
in open day, by mining, in the trench, by cunning, or by force, open	317.80132978169513
themselves a way toward the object they wished to attain, however well	239.32998048929346
it might be defended, or however distant it may seem. The only thing	223.68356709502888
that astonished D’Artagnan was that his friends had never thought of	183.20858092071745
this.	231.44092435643995
He was thinking by himself, and even seriously racking his brain to	306.45639396835645
find a direction for this single force four times multiplied, with	354.25429425231613
which he did not doubt, as with the lever for which Archimedes sought,	188.31408889734394
they should succeed in moving the world, when someone tapped gently at	324.31933235966875
his door. D’Artagnan awakened Planchet and ordered him to open it.	286.11401242800804
From this phrase, “D’Artagnan awakened Planchet,” the reader must not	176.51663018924472
suppose it was night, or that day was hardly come. No, it had just	268.26031782656594
struck four. Planchet, two hours before, had asked his master for some	193.75750938508335
dinner, and he had answered him with the proverb, “He who sleeps,	289.87745703541873
dines.” And Planchet dined by sleeping.	280.7868597726188
A man was introduced of simple mien, who had the appearance of a	167.49993190183002
tradesman. Planchet, by way of dessert, would have liked to hear the	236.3544550574175
conversation; but the citizen declared to D’Artagnan that, what he had	348.5405463960501
to say being important and confidential, he desired to be left alone	174.10330984964395
with him.	300.55713668599583
D’Artagnan dismissed Planchet, and requested his visitor to be seated.	179.03577119079858
There was a moment of silence, during which the two men looked at each	223.61320336862593
other, as if to make a preliminary acquaintance, after which D’Artagnan	176.57471655426642
bowed, as a sign that he listened.	253.5971294021702
“I have heard Monsieur d’Artagnan spoken of as a very brave young man,”	345.2215754685029
said the citizen; “and this reputation which he justly enjoys had	297.45115644856094
decided me to confide a secret to him.”	206.92063954032525
“Speak, monsieur, speak,” said D’Artagnan, who instinctively scented	265.34412793784315
something advantageous.	239.33031755491373
The citizen made a fresh pause and continued, “I have a wife who is	254.65889711154642
seamstress to the queen, monsieur, and who is not deficient in either	167.25100201420543
virtue or beauty. I was induced to marry her about three years ago,	174.52185049726077
although she had but very little dowry, because Monsieur Laporte, the	316.8274867771871
queen’s cloak bearer, is her godfather, and befriends her.”	364.79168092807754
“Well, monsieur?” asked D’Artagnan.	249.9572531024357
“Well!” resumed the citizen, “well, monsieur, my wife was abducted	183.86073771191207
yesterday morning, as she was coming out of her workroom.”	169.66017419010583
“And by whom was your wife abducted?”	231.1523340317321
“I know nothing surely, monsieur, but I suspect someone.”	336.1929049280352
“And who is the person whom you suspect?”	293.34023751373877
“A man who has pursued her a long time.”	317.3770111909764
“The devil!”	192.2782604499735
“But allow me to tell you, monsieur,” continued the citizen, “that I am	251.59132780228657
convinced that there is less love than politics in all this.”	285.24254940273244
“Less love than politics,” replied D’Artagnan, with a reflective air;	220.74576279842046
“and what do you suspect?”	206.9922390617048
“I do not know whether I ought to tell you what I suspect.”	221.8338681404109
“Monsieur, I beg you to observe that I ask you absolutely nothing. It	320.4823460227561
is you who have come to me. It is you who have told me that you had a	240.78351157138906
secret to confide in me. Act, then, as you think proper; there is still	282.94099885331514
time to withdraw.”	320.5494045043068
“No, monsieur, no; you appear to be an honest young man, and I will	341.9876262844606
have confidence in you. I believe, then, that it is not on account of	233.07494237186904
any intrigues of her own that my wife has been arrested, but because of	330.89510051081083
those of a lady much greater than herself.”	354.9784708385563
“Ah, ah! Can it be on account of the amours of Madame de Bois-Tracy?”	338.633577205391
said D’Artagnan, wishing to have the air, in the eyes of the citizen,	223.60607143401893
of being posted as to court affairs.	313.24594047210144
“Higher, monsieur, higher.”	353.4513999672018
“Of Madame d’Aiguillon?”	305.344480916002
“Still higher.”	318.64240466633674
“Of Madame de Chevreuse?”	188.8358555844281
“Higher, much higher.”	210.12335170581142
“Of the—” D’Artagnan checked himself.	358.98708270018926
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the terrified citizen, in a tone so low that	328.2110158677258
he was scarcely audible.	320.7318650867046
“And with whom?”	208.0073501682928
“With whom can it be, if not the Duke of—”	312.38296486865795
“The Duke of—”	350.8245686506776
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the citizen, giving a still fainter intonation	185.95581404866275
to his voice.	270.56876328772506
“But how do you know all this?”	223.11833961487162
“How do I know it?”	217.720424973713
“Yes, how do you know it? No half-confidence, or—you understand!”	332.10325424049927
“I know it from my wife, monsieur—from my wife herself.”	285.82068392595414
“Who learns it from whom?”	227.32895496176516
“From Monsieur Laporte. Did I not tell you that she was the goddaughter	282.1694456956341
of Monsieur Laporte, the confidential man of the queen? Well, Monsieur	294.52493577776994
Laporte placed her near her Majesty in order that our poor queen might	328.90332047748734
at least have someone in whom she could place confidence, abandoned as	248.17361620321287
she is by the king, watched as she is by the cardinal, betrayed as she	362.3252925882143
is by everybody.”	313.1925507963292
“Ah, ah! It begins to develop itself,” said D’Artagnan.	272.69658906826623
“Now, my wife came home four days ago, monsieur. One of her conditions	339.66761815634874
was that she should come and see me twice a week; for, as I had the	332.3948216573825
honor to tell you, my wife loves me dearly—my wife, then, came and	172.66580847442057
confided to me that the queen at that very moment entertained great	205.87847411018544
fears.”	302.9905305471009
“Truly!”	182.5681742974433
“Yes. The cardinal, as it appears, pursues her and persecutes her more	250.7164474042824
than ever. He cannot pardon her the history of the Saraband. You know	349.7218914996181
the history of the Saraband?”	275.1877178960684
“_Pardieu!_ Know it!” replied D’Artagnan, who knew nothing about it,	320.13824171221506
but who wished to appear to know everything that was going on.	304.1650760832929
“So that now it is no longer hatred, but vengeance.”	278.791535267715
“Indeed!”	315.3500782468141
“And the queen believes—”	182.82004848994302
“Well, what does the queen believe?”	297.81179313229484
“She believes that someone has written to the Duke of Buckingham in her	174.74345790022986
name.”	170.0344773821622
“In the queen’s name?”	189.2455939622206
“Yes, to make him come to Paris; and when once come to Paris, to draw	365.07802130339905
him into some snare.”	285.65056124266675
“The devil! But your wife, monsieur, what has she to do with all this?”	311.1977014366539
“Her devotion to the queen is known; and they wish either to remove her	209.53474878436833
from her mistress, or to intimidate her, in order to obtain her	241.3526962274945
Majesty’s secrets, or to seduce her and make use of her as a spy.”	356.38847271215104
“That is likely,” said D’Artagnan; “but the man who has abducted her—do	234.5655895507314
you know him?”	244.02858776979545
“I have told you that I believe I know him.”	247.5742920464494
“His name?”	203.75210660073202
“I do not know that; what I do know is that he is a creature of the	242.4271972404934
cardinal, his evil genius.”	288.3616382847955
“But you have seen him?”	201.69085254520587
“Yes, my wife pointed him out to me one day.”	302.16738855455145
“Has he anything remarkable about him by which one may recognize him?”	256.3517095733325
“Oh, certainly; he is a noble of very lofty carriage, black hair,	255.23742731495946
swarthy complexion, piercing eye, white teeth, and has a scar on his	209.50480098622864
temple.”	362.65378248275977
“A scar on his temple!” cried D’Artagnan; “and with that, white teeth,	279.7586970848526
a piercing eye, dark complexion, black hair, and haughty carriage—why,	292.61945691261326
that’s my man of Meung.”	360.1015724533303
“He is your man, do you say?”	321.26415489427916
“Yes, yes; but that has nothing to do with it. No, I am wrong. On the	250.10620987156068
contrary, that simplifies the matter greatly. If your man is mine, with	267.6037935327681
one blow I shall obtain two revenges, that’s all; but where to find	189.14430307491472
this man?”	305.01655620649944
“I know not.”	265.8126294126816
“Have you no information as to his abiding place?”	302.86725153314194
“None. One day, as I was conveying my wife back to the Louvre, he was	259.45982566022974
coming out as she was going in, and she showed him to me.”	210.95267014982056
“The devil! The devil!” murmured D’Artagnan; “all this is vague enough.	313.44334851848714
From whom have you learned of the abduction of your wife?”	225.6577002767383
“From Monsieur Laporte.”	196.26907949386143
“Did he give you any details?”	307.1861686891798
“He knew none himself.”	248.65511628151458
“And you have learned nothing from any other quarter?”	213.0918599994363
“Yes, I have received—”	304.644611484964
“What?”	335.38763332504027
“I fear I am committing a great imprudence.”	265.6160431550305
“You always come back to that; but I must make you see this time that	361.94836209669995
it is too late to retreat.”	333.2933732027524
“I do not retreat, _mordieu!_” cried the citizen, swearing in order to	353.5023548101229
rouse his courage. “Besides, by the faith of Bonacieux—”	282.79763693254074
“You call yourself Bonacieux?” interrupted D’Artagnan.	353.2610912089723
“Yes, that is my name.”	341.85356157023676
“You said, then, by the word of Bonacieux. Pardon me for interrupting	343.13839762883435
you, but it appears to me that that name is familiar to me.”	334.6367357197953
“Possibly, monsieur. I am your landlord.”	172.6714683532555
“Ah, ah!” said D’Artagnan, half rising and bowing; “you are my	299.4770977643915
landlord?”	269.0780118478638
“Yes, monsieur, yes. And as it is three months since you have been	259.27990675035744
here, and though, distracted as you must be in your important	345.43701729613895
occupations, you have forgotten to pay me my rent—as, I say, I have not	171.98365875219758
tormented you a single instant, I thought you would appreciate my	320.79598611939866
delicacy.”	316.6763337092193
“How can it be otherwise, my dear Bonacieux?” replied D’Artagnan;	220.47240909820502
“trust me, I am fully grateful for such unparalleled conduct, and if,	220.03893683106656
as I told you, I can be of any service to you—”	360.41930089493417
“I believe you, monsieur, I believe you; and as I was about to say, by	246.08465770907358
the word of Bonacieux, I have confidence in you.”	210.61670185860737
“Finish, then, what you were about to say.”	273.2609800754966
The citizen took a paper from his pocket, and presented it to	288.4163780282656
D’Artagnan.	208.19329511089353
“A letter?” said the young man.	261.90839675528275
“Which I received this morning.”	229.11008685916786
D’Artagnan opened it, and as the day was beginning to decline, he	342.95024386507225
approached the window to read it. The citizen followed him.	212.65264857895505
“‘Do not seek your wife,’” read D’Artagnan; “‘she will be restored to	279.89714944940175
you when there is no longer occasion for her. If you make a single step	332.2791407116662
to find her you are lost.’	253.6110936759162
“That’s pretty positive,” continued D’Artagnan; “but after all, it is	214.09110260245896
but a menace.”	285.6251903808756
“Yes; but that menace terrifies me. I am not a fighting man at all,	196.16917781234787
monsieur, and I am afraid of the Bastille.”	282.9622036963436
“Hum!” said D’Artagnan. “I have no greater regard for the Bastille than	169.4396292613755
you. If it were nothing but a sword thrust, why then—”	324.420031509816
“I have counted upon you on this occasion, monsieur.”	362.5832302698222
“Yes?”	335.9472024810609
“Seeing you constantly surrounded by Musketeers of a very superb	180.56146328607352
appearance, and knowing that these Musketeers belong to Monsieur de	181.8607543158809
Tréville, and were consequently enemies of the cardinal, I thought that	243.7402708589711
you and your friends, while rendering justice to your poor queen, would	206.1935739855727
be pleased to play his Eminence an ill turn.”	288.86692418110124
“Without doubt.”	312.62241482419506
“And then I have thought that considering three months’ lodging, about	319.67001939791436
which I have said nothing—”	311.1120370157878
“Yes, yes; you have already given me that reason, and I find it	206.05562610374216
excellent.”	258.15001477422345
“Reckoning still further, that as long as you do me the honor to remain	203.01423785239868
in my house I shall never speak to you about rent—”	269.89717155551983
“Very kind!”	242.73793401164835
“And adding to this, if there be need of it, meaning to offer you fifty	350.1216049850211
pistoles, if, against all probability, you should be short at the	296.3123008916302
present moment.”	284.1777197757133
“Admirable! You are rich then, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux?”	275.87485927038085
“I am comfortably off, monsieur, that’s all; I have scraped together	362.1308242033298
some such things as an income of two or three thousand crowns in the	340.11820850874136
haberdashery business, but more particularly in venturing some funds in	345.08913032842014
the last voyage of the celebrated navigator Jean Moquet; so that you	207.71198366897522
understand, monsieur—But!—” cried the citizen.	184.86750379604848
“What!” demanded D’Artagnan.	174.34994931788867
“Whom do I see yonder?”	276.78955377010294
“Where?”	230.03836223798874
“In the street, facing your window, in the embrasure of that door—a man	249.6875844830568
wrapped in a cloak.”	191.84183323319334
“It is he!” cried D’Artagnan and the citizen at the same time, each	349.3127904548751
having recognized his man.	347.9725376649702
“Ah, this time,” cried D’Artagnan, springing to his sword, “this time	341.2924082101657
he will not escape me!”	242.9677377509894
Drawing his sword from its scabbard, he rushed out of the apartment. On	226.75626675886713
the staircase he met Athos and Porthos, who were coming to see him.	305.8173464976541
They separated, and D’Artagnan rushed between them like a dart.	261.02985438028463
“Pah! Where are you going?” cried the two Musketeers in a breath.	310.6947354891405
“The man of Meung!” replied D’Artagnan, and disappeared.	206.5464524336254
D’Artagnan had more than once related to his friends his adventure with	358.7415822408443
the stranger, as well as the apparition of the beautiful foreigner, to	326.87395859297243
whom this man had confided some important missive.	230.27952078009451
The opinion of Athos was that D’Artagnan had lost his letter in the	237.8775330318319
skirmish. A gentleman, in his opinion—and according to D’Artagnan’s	362.7240793050737
portrait of him, the stranger must be a gentleman—would be incapable of	251.24317457475377
the baseness of stealing a letter.	178.23628179059605
Porthos saw nothing in all this but a love meeting, given by a lady to	251.11884969462932
a cavalier, or by a cavalier to a lady, which had been disturbed by the	166.90131847528593
presence of D’Artagnan and his yellow horse.	271.80997295637377
Aramis said that as these sorts of affairs were mysterious, it was	363.56507665563015
better not to fathom them.	225.02777957691512
They understood, then, from the few words which escaped from	258.41240483887873
D’Artagnan, what affair was in hand, and as they thought that	326.99496456619806
overtaking his man, or losing sight of him, D’Artagnan would return to	246.77522208999437
his rooms, they kept on their way.	273.68906693716804
When they entered D’Artagnan’s chamber, it was empty; the landlord,	180.43440207675295
dreading the consequences of the encounter which was doubtless about to	193.045829723748
take place between the young man and the stranger, had, consistent with	264.1423467212702
the character he had given himself, judged it prudent to decamp.	232.395904214709
Chapter IX.	257.1926818893311
D’ARTAGNAN SHOWS HIMSELF	308.3500582730695
As Athos and Porthos had foreseen, at the expiration of a half hour,	231.42612594066068
D’Artagnan returned. He had again missed his man, who had disappeared	272.7394376993378
as if by enchantment. D’Artagnan had run, sword in hand, through all	283.2392781062854
the neighboring streets, but had found nobody resembling the man he	205.73292211793262
sought for. Then he came back to the point where, perhaps, he ought to	296.1064636085073
have begun, and that was to knock at the door against which the	255.5506486308017
stranger had leaned; but this proved useless—for though he knocked ten	197.10052279015508
or twelve times in succession, no one answered, and some of the	345.88983683208346
neighbors, who put their noses out of their windows or were brought to	317.43107904698536
their doors by the noise, had assured him that that house, all the	338.665223825084
openings of which were tightly closed, had not been inhabited for six	355.04167211445554
months.	324.7017065107501
While D’Artagnan was running through the streets and knocking at doors,	238.30083403565658
Aramis had joined his companions; so that on returning home D’Artagnan	324.3257887532192
found the reunion complete.	221.38171136665724
“Well!” cried the three Musketeers all together, on seeing D’Artagnan	205.4354474992411
enter with his brow covered with perspiration and his countenance upset	348.3366232953864
with anger.	311.8309548068832
“Well!” cried he, throwing his sword upon the bed, “this man must be	322.9237310759604
the devil in person; he has disappeared like a phantom, like a shade,	267.0552160063718
like a specter.”	176.52036875630054
“Do you believe in apparitions?” asked Athos of Porthos.	166.56258691137117
“I never believe in anything I have not seen, and as I never have seen	270.3872606425002
apparitions, I don’t believe in them.”	329.5606573541211
“The Bible,” said Aramis, “makes our belief in them a law; the ghost of	313.78889334039764
Samuel appeared to Saul, and it is an article of faith that I should be	232.39403271524296
very sorry to see any doubt thrown upon, Porthos.”	263.2392326179503
“At all events, man or devil, body or shadow, illusion or reality, this	277.58700901188206
man is born for my damnation; for his flight has caused us to miss a	223.8334948234585
glorious affair, gentlemen—an affair by which there were a hundred	243.51373976423497
pistoles, and perhaps more, to be gained.”	211.8794507612899
“How is that?” cried Porthos and Aramis in a breath.	316.0522276047857
As to Athos, faithful to his system of reticence, he contented himself	255.04584869276493
with interrogating D’Artagnan by a look.	211.04156786503694
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan to his domestic, who just then insinuated	187.75004624184902
his head through the half-open door in order to catch some fragments of	344.5402425143784
the conversation, “go down to my landlord, Monsieur Bonacieux, and ask	291.1310708990215
him to send me half a dozen bottles of Beaugency wine; I prefer that.”	263.0443930495768
“Ah, ah! You have credit with your landlord, then?” asked Porthos.	174.4337500338309
“Yes,” replied D’Artagnan, “from this very day; and mind, if the wine	360.7917928154436
is bad, we will send him to find better.”	273.2652240916228
“We must use, and not abuse,” said Aramis, sententiously.	186.40669811459423
“I always said that D’Artagnan had the longest head of the four,” said	330.849458745583
Athos, who, having uttered his opinion, to which D’Artagnan replied	175.64555405878647
with a bow, immediately resumed his accustomed silence.	166.295725078378
“But come, what is this about?” asked Porthos.	263.3661938287094
“Yes,” said Aramis, “impart it to us, my dear friend, unless the honor	305.9957935532117
of any lady be hazarded by this confidence; in that case you would do	304.4552879395868
better to keep it to yourself.”	340.436934777608
“Be satisfied,” replied D’Artagnan; “the honor of no one will have	341.91802664508714
cause to complain of what I have to tell.”	328.52713296609716
He then related to his friends, word for word, all that had passed	248.83437862727104
between him and his host, and how the man who had abducted the wife of	304.48915624062016
his worthy landlord was the same with whom he had had the difference at	217.09300057428024
the hostelry of the Jolly Miller.	223.21620847031403
“Your affair is not bad,” said Athos, after having tasted like a	199.26492129602047
connoisseur and indicated by a nod of his head that he thought the wine	295.4194911981318
good; “and one may draw fifty or sixty pistoles from this good man.	319.7568595712048
Then there only remains to ascertain whether these fifty or sixty	295.8784317719949
pistoles are worth the risk of four heads.”	194.4390732570792
“But observe,” cried D’Artagnan, “that there is a woman in the affair—a	243.21234832446135
woman carried off, a woman who is doubtless threatened, tortured	349.25930235518274
perhaps, and all because she is faithful to her mistress.”	184.05710608480086
“Beware, D’Artagnan, beware,” said Aramis. “You grow a little too warm,	263.84617351380564
in my opinion, about the fate of Madame Bonacieux. Woman was created	305.97634248348527
for our destruction, and it is from her we inherit all our miseries.”	261.03819556124597
At this speech of Aramis, the brow of Athos became clouded and he bit	188.41253243439968
his lips.	277.72307725095516
“It is not Madame Bonacieux about whom I am anxious,” cried D’Artagnan,	279.77663558163493
“but the queen, whom the king abandons, whom the cardinal persecutes,	271.7282787774251
and who sees the heads of all her friends fall, one after the other.”	306.7566572545228
“Why does she love what we hate most in the world, the Spaniards and	327.0729953359363
the English?”	252.36619333740128
“Spain is her country,” replied D’Artagnan; “and it is very natural	193.84821283280317
that she should love the Spanish, who are the children of the same soil	251.2275119628261
as herself. As to the second reproach, I have heard it said that she	283.395160511703
does not love the English, but an Englishman.”	357.1118638144105
“Well, and by my faith,” said Athos, “it must be acknowledged that this	223.33764633621124
Englishman is worthy of being loved. I never saw a man with a nobler	301.1372130814231
air than his.”	275.20092491161336
“Without reckoning that he dresses as nobody else can,” said Porthos.	205.41096085811907
“I was at the Louvre on the day when he scattered his pearls; and,	180.2535186890242
_pardieu_, I picked up two that I sold for ten pistoles each. Do you	328.2944636887736
know him, Aramis?”	175.5794233925794
“As well as you do, gentlemen; for I was among those who seized him in	247.2148287765525
the garden at Amiens, into which Monsieur Putange, the queen’s equerry,	200.7178637660842
introduced me. I was at school at the time, and the adventure appeared	359.33510931458767
to me to be cruel for the king.”	318.4307679488913
“Which would not prevent me,” said D’Artagnan, “if I knew where the	357.48131251883194
Duke of Buckingham was, from taking him by the hand and conducting him	202.69795603822553
to the queen, were it only to enrage the cardinal, and if we could find	271.51373091702567
means to play him a sharp turn, I vow that I would voluntarily risk my	180.70904089005717
head in doing it.”	185.1097878215831
“And did the mercer*,” rejoined Athos, “tell you, D’Artagnan, that the	220.51509174930044
queen thought that Buckingham had been brought over by a forged	353.50391730008295
letter?”	211.13833730356268
* Haberdasher	289.8255564671183
“She is afraid so.”	247.53609318478172
“Wait a minute, then,” said Aramis.	223.63306829080574
“What for?” demanded Porthos.	277.2557881636965
“Go on, while I endeavor to recall circumstances.”	298.25680373539126
“And now I am convinced,” said D’Artagnan, “that this abduction of the	337.8198864519595
queen’s woman is connected with the events of which we are speaking,	171.82401918457467
and perhaps with the presence of Buckingham in Paris.”	179.5698027386985
“The Gascon is full of ideas,” said Porthos, with admiration.	241.2854238008082
“I like to hear him talk,” said Athos; “his dialect amuses me.”	184.69060967480112
“Gentlemen,” cried Aramis, “listen to this.”	302.79557151189704
“Listen to Aramis,” said his three friends.	297.3708058023701
“Yesterday I was at the house of a doctor of theology, whom I sometimes	197.76993241347793
consult about my studies.”	276.6585733592307
Athos smiled.	214.9420610162595
“He resides in a quiet quarter,” continued Aramis; “his tastes and his	291.64537177120195
profession require it. Now, at the moment when I left his house—”	228.02991257749625
Here Aramis paused.	246.6940662806889
“Well,” cried his auditors; “at the moment you left his house?”	310.3240408451229
Aramis appeared to make a strong inward effort, like a man who, in the	293.21285719418677
full relation of a falsehood, finds himself stopped by some unforeseen	335.2804266524348
obstacle; but the eyes of his three companions were fixed upon him,	329.6486772813026
their ears were wide open, and there were no means of retreat.	208.91364035739926
“This doctor has a niece,” continued Aramis.	315.2982128380461
“Ah, he has a niece!” interrupted Porthos.	249.83305882529913
“A very respectable lady,” said Aramis.	361.8857393007755
The three friends burst into laughter.	193.07473898944383
“Ah, if you laugh, if you doubt me,” replied Aramis, “you shall know	236.24391988435497
nothing.”	317.1166883648966
“We believe like Mohammedans, and are as mute as tombstones,” said	352.4989869939237
Athos.	172.5807522749642
“I will continue, then,” resumed Aramis. “This niece comes sometimes to	362.90509454865816
see her uncle; and by chance was there yesterday at the same time that	248.79733972196254
I was, and it was my duty to offer to conduct her to her carriage.”	189.79502764190937
“Ah! She has a carriage, then, this niece of the doctor?” interrupted	306.6815625048815
Porthos, one of whose faults was a great looseness of tongue. “A nice	176.03062541273135
acquaintance, my friend!”	316.9080395759401
“Porthos,” replied Aramis, “I have had the occasion to observe to you	294.8018140396298
more than once that you are very indiscreet; and that is injurious to	286.3955928416584
you among the women.”	312.8116287164172
“Gentlemen, gentlemen,” cried D’Artagnan, who began to get a glimpse of	288.58357356026806
the result of the adventure, “the thing is serious. Let us try not to	189.2323675881545
jest, if we can. Go on Aramis, go on.”	190.41269025460377
“All at once, a tall, dark gentleman—just like yours, D’Artagnan.”	211.95446090265534
“The same, perhaps,” said he.	252.7137287695549
“Possibly,” continued Aramis, “came toward me, accompanied by five or	334.6172230299899
six men who followed about ten paces behind him; and in the politest	297.29491846974787
tone, ‘Monsieur Duke,’ said he to me, ‘and you madame,’ continued he,	256.2647102610189
addressing the lady on my arm—”	365.4485426637646
“The doctor’s niece?”	311.4969243491263
“Hold your tongue, Porthos,” said Athos; “you are insupportable.”	324.5952971801684
“‘—will you enter this carriage, and that without offering the least	207.32811359495943
resistance, without making the least noise?’”	178.58242723590607
“He took you for Buckingham!” cried D’Artagnan.	365.05150858087404
“I believe so,” replied Aramis.	212.9138941727512
“But the lady?” asked Porthos.	248.42676321271793
“He took her for the queen!” said D’Artagnan.	244.88333492961897
“Just so,” replied Aramis.	352.8788485576721
“The Gascon is the devil!” cried Athos; “nothing escapes him.”	200.37506194000997
“The fact is,” said Porthos, “Aramis is of the same height, and	283.85591869931045
something of the shape of the duke; but it nevertheless appears to me	264.0572767506485
that the dress of a Musketeer—”	282.82191614687866
“I wore an enormous cloak,” said Aramis.	225.5673439434645
“In the month of July? The devil!” said Porthos. “Is the doctor afraid	343.2008446032278
that you may be recognized?”	289.0629700320312
“I can comprehend that the spy may have been deceived by the person;	277.0275775511667
but the face—”	289.1396829560184
“I had a large hat,” said Aramis.	261.7205752095143
“Oh, good lord,” cried Porthos, “what precautions for the study of	329.599537326204
theology!”	226.13477079880244
“Gentlemen, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “do not let us lose our time	193.52580372897953
in jesting. Let us separate, and let us seek the mercer’s wife—that is	260.57704945713556
the key of the intrigue.”	342.38039441750533
“A woman of such inferior condition! Can you believe so?” said Porthos,	262.4019073433078
protruding his lips with contempt.	307.7385695520179
“She is goddaughter to Laporte, the confidential valet of the queen.	180.12951934084248
Have I not told you so, gentlemen? Besides, it has perhaps been her	308.80356088884935
Majesty’s calculation to seek on this occasion for support so lowly.	360.29746566625965
High heads expose themselves from afar, and the cardinal is	189.27431642113893
longsighted.”	215.9724090028744
“Well,” said Porthos, “in the first place make a bargain with the	359.1688638643101
mercer, and a good bargain.”	335.88813632899985
“That’s useless,” said D’Artagnan; “for I believe if he does not pay	184.43250589953408
us, we shall be well enough paid by another party.”	233.0730163047685
At this moment a sudden noise of footsteps was heard upon the stairs;	196.01798080659364
the door was thrown violently open, and the unfortunate mercer rushed	311.56407034824133
into the chamber in which the council was held.	315.4353306480429
“Save me, gentlemen, for the love of heaven, save me!” cried he. “There	184.4195761462094
are four men come to arrest me. Save me! Save me!”	337.6478552782064
Porthos and Aramis arose.	303.84001761227734
“A moment,” cried D’Artagnan, making them a sign to replace in the	243.49514376474602
scabbard their half-drawn swords. “It is not courage that is needed; it	268.16404599718624
is prudence.”	204.99631379662782
“And yet,” cried Porthos, “we will not leave—”	354.27611377347034
“You will leave D’Artagnan to act as he thinks proper,” said Athos. “He	216.08132243236895
has, I repeat, the longest head of the four, and for my part I declare	235.4097174066612
that I will obey him. Do as you think best, D’Artagnan.”	236.9468346009547
At this moment the four Guards appeared at the door of the antechamber,	334.51355659820206
but seeing four Musketeers standing, and their swords by their sides,	328.01547373108707
they hesitated about going farther.	287.94043565694096
“Come in, gentlemen, come in,” called D’Artagnan; “you are here in my	322.10501780471316
apartment, and we are all faithful servants of the king and cardinal.”	290.758914250982
“Then, gentlemen, you will not oppose our executing the orders we have	199.51877993891793
received?” asked one who appeared to be the leader of the party.	267.7724799574202
“On the contrary, gentlemen, we would assist you if it were necessary.”	299.16225697625754
“What does he say?” grumbled Porthos.	251.38977598747675
“You are a simpleton,” said Athos. “Silence!”	332.01207945449613
“But you promised me—” whispered the poor mercer.	315.57632098118154
“We can only save you by being free ourselves,” replied D’Artagnan, in	217.98380639068358
a rapid, low tone; “and if we appear inclined to defend you, they will	284.033505891995
arrest us with you.”	295.7709879449168
“It seems, nevertheless—”	187.45812863458005
“Come, gentlemen, come!” said D’Artagnan, aloud; “I have no motive for	270.009750007952
defending Monsieur. I saw him today for the first time, and he can tell	167.88714728395232
you on what occasion; he came to demand the rent of my lodging. Is that	167.63460047344356
not true, Monsieur Bonacieux? Answer!”	316.96817927307524
“That is the very truth,” cried the mercer; “but Monsieur does not tell	316.6584775212986
you—”	266.3560525142551
“Silence, with respect to me, silence, with respect to my friends;	202.60403304096894
silence about the queen, above all, or you will ruin everybody without	364.6410335488198
saving yourself! Come, come, gentlemen, remove the fellow.” And	332.5607154725098
D’Artagnan pushed the half-stupefied mercer among the Guards, saying to	349.90458336740744
him, “You are a shabby old fellow, my dear. You come to demand money of	332.2981536414718
me—of a Musketeer! To prison with him! Gentlemen, once more, take him	166.79364863057657
to prison, and keep him under key as long as possible; that will give	242.84079788453624
me time to pay him.”	258.1880194284681
The officers were full of thanks, and took away their prey. As they	221.64713083270303
were going down D’Artagnan laid his hand on the shoulder of their	354.74052891907013
leader.	316.7242671046953
“May I not drink to your health, and you to mine?” said D’Artagnan,	365.1138506033168
filling two glasses with the Beaugency wine which he had obtained from	262.4938501725777
the liberality of M. Bonacieux.	338.3846871309966
“That will do me great honor,” said the leader of the posse, “and I	339.37288305617363
accept thankfully.”	232.44214393026704
“Then to yours, monsieur—what is your name?”	308.43659339506485
“Boisrenard.”	347.6506337960386
“Monsieur Boisrenard.”	349.8932602544878
“To yours, my gentlemen! What is your name, in your turn, if you	364.10986578059146
please?”	233.25936890661126
“D’Artagnan.”	336.966207252314
“To yours, monsieur.”	282.139488454419
“And above all others,” cried D’Artagnan, as if carried away by his	314.37378083976773
enthusiasm, “to that of the king and the cardinal.”	297.7370022424501
The leader of the posse would perhaps have doubted the sincerity of	288.88239064699087
D’Artagnan if the wine had been bad; but the wine was good, and he was	330.27014066435663
convinced.	221.8183515586326
“What diabolical villainy you have performed here,” said Porthos, when	203.05029038068267
the officer had rejoined his companions and the four friends found	327.0575394728687
themselves alone. “Shame, shame, for four Musketeers to allow an	286.80994389837747
unfortunate fellow who cried for help to be arrested in their midst!	249.17884216658476
And a gentleman to hobnob with a bailiff!”	287.28849820281533
“Porthos,” said Aramis, “Athos has already told you that you are a	321.81767796314364
simpleton, and I am quite of his opinion. D’Artagnan, you are a great	274.313094063799
man; and when you occupy Monsieur de Tréville’s place, I will come and	173.10838951416514
ask your influence to secure me an abbey.”	321.0011532839976
“Well, I am in a maze,” said Porthos; “do _you_ approve of what	279.4250681491199
D’Artagnan has done?”	169.4412770166365
“_Parbleu!_ Indeed I do,” said Athos; “I not only approve of what he	292.93185852059355
has done, but I congratulate him upon it.”	352.0916481665409
“And now, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, without stopping to explain his	359.66381472635703
conduct to Porthos, “All for one, one for all—that is our motto, is it	346.6875768829969
not?”	314.890931257088
“And yet—” said Porthos.	251.45271465353792
“Hold out your hand and swear!” cried Athos and Aramis at once.	292.64194597932794
Overcome by example, grumbling to himself, nevertheless, Porthos	232.67449920796207
stretched out his hand, and the four friends repeated with one voice	210.88835082361757
the formula dictated by D’Artagnan:	239.12795335737843
“All for one, one for all.”	293.04396734118797
“That’s well! Now let us everyone retire to his own home,” said	184.47184842576434
D’Artagnan, as if he had done nothing but command all his life; “and	296.06415976453377
attention! For from this moment we are at feud with the cardinal.”	283.47361957119557
Chapter X.	246.9470663135916
A MOUSETRAP IN THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY	345.330963913112
The invention of the mousetrap does not date from our days; as soon as	219.6742119117296
societies, in forming, had invented any kind of police, that police	274.0284166178019
invented mousetraps.	343.7311988819132
As perhaps our readers are not familiar with the slang of the Rue de	301.73926941749505
Jerusalem, and as it is fifteen years since we applied this word for	218.9374567240173
the first time to this thing, allow us to explain to them what is a	298.85230750807193
mousetrap.	224.3107607298515
When in a house, of whatever kind it may be, an individual suspected of	206.46470508236396
any crime is arrested, the arrest is held secret. Four or five men are	185.64372580414314
placed in ambuscade in the first room. The door is opened to all who	218.04386231334394
knock. It is closed after them, and they are arrested; so that at the	311.01713130765205
end of two or three days they have in their power almost all the	304.5200633014982
_habitués_ of the establishment. And that is a mousetrap.	249.3808794334517
The apartment of M. Bonacieux, then, became a mousetrap; and whoever	263.4525945396395
appeared there was taken and interrogated by the cardinal’s people. It	190.28046240426926
must be observed that as a separate passage led to the first floor, in	290.113618825902
which D’Artagnan lodged, those who called on him were exempted from	360.94003813802345
this detention.	246.93132871461822
Besides, nobody came thither but the three Musketeers; they had all	307.08844435326307
been engaged in earnest search and inquiries, but had discovered	355.7750863695601
nothing. Athos had even gone so far as to question M. de Tréville—a	205.83263829285107
thing which, considering the habitual reticence of the worthy	205.8964818402291
Musketeer, had very much astonished his captain. But M. de Tréville	282.4130868062374
knew nothing, except that the last time he had seen the cardinal, the	175.55502245293064
king, and the queen, the cardinal looked very thoughtful, the king	186.0662521395702
uneasy, and the redness of the queen’s eyes donated that she had been	226.12363698619654
sleepless or tearful. But this last circumstance was not striking, as	188.22419277654615
the queen since her marriage had slept badly and wept much.	234.39118756165715
M. de Tréville requested Athos, whatever might happen, to be observant	181.06141499205805
of his duty to the king, but particularly to the queen, begging him to	199.61463065888177
convey his desires to his comrades.	212.30698540551322
As to D’Artagnan, he did not budge from his apartment. He converted his	274.39339694323974
chamber into an observatory. From his windows he saw all the visitors	287.8372191289268
who were caught. Then, having removed a plank from his floor, and	247.57827973874458
nothing remaining but a simple ceiling between him and the room	247.1199213344293
beneath, in which the interrogatories were made, he heard all that	248.4887737206271
passed between the inquisitors and the accused.	313.3180045616258
The interrogatories, preceded by a minute search operated upon the	292.1351740144229
persons arrested, were almost always framed thus: “Has Madame Bonacieux	216.4531392499033
sent anything to you for her husband, or any other person? Has Monsieur	289.8925825936667
Bonacieux sent anything to you for his wife, or for any other person?	251.91266228288407
Has either of them confided anything to you by word of mouth?”	272.0481759227033
“If they knew anything, they would not question people in this manner,”	249.47290950556936
said D’Artagnan to himself. “Now, what is it they want to know? Why,	212.81150810073132
they want to know if the Duke of Buckingham is in Paris, and if he has	287.58586706597805
had, or is likely to have, an interview with the queen.”	295.04760183146254
D’Artagnan held onto this idea, which, from what he had heard, was not	192.04861847661599
wanting in probability.	279.0395452279596
In the meantime, the mousetrap continued in operation, and likewise	208.55236141107662
D’Artagnan’s vigilance.	210.44573369030851
On the evening of the day after the arrest of poor Bonacieux, as Athos	281.23042362026996
had just left D’Artagnan to report at M. de Tréville’s, as nine o’clock	263.1212414450622
had just struck, and as Planchet, who had not yet made the bed, was	333.54132469025694
beginning his task, a knocking was heard at the street door. The door	353.73378976772966
was instantly opened and shut; someone was taken in the mousetrap.	287.61956803783113
D’Artagnan flew to his hole, laid himself down on the floor at full	189.58001066707507
length, and listened.	219.72987357823632
Cries were soon heard, and then moans, which someone appeared to be	167.76070971893273
endeavoring to stifle. There were no questions.	234.23543142849462
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan to himself. “It seems like a woman! They	248.9742580410939
search her; she resists; they use force—the scoundrels!”	191.62659394229775
In spite of his prudence, D’Artagnan restrained himself with great	320.6559029695429
difficulty from taking a part in the scene that was going on below.	276.5465203037593
“But I tell you that I am the mistress of the house, gentlemen! I tell	235.56999818408508
you I am Madame Bonacieux; I tell you I belong to the queen!” cried the	187.43683206769262
unfortunate woman.	271.85725607240647
“Madame Bonacieux!” murmured D’Artagnan. “Can I be so lucky as to find	291.2091430173879
what everybody is seeking for?”	272.88790019531984
The voice became more and more indistinct; a tumultuous movement shook	248.5877042827725
the partition. The victim resisted as much as a woman could resist four	271.9162450946061
men.	253.68470778956777
“Pardon, gentlemen—par—” murmured the voice, which could now only be	249.20597965076496
heard in inarticulate sounds.	259.41549527574267
“They are binding her; they are going to drag her away,” cried	264.0324988899212
D’Artagnan to himself, springing up from the floor. “My sword! Good, it	173.33653610576525
is by my side! Planchet!”	329.8464333952912
“Monsieur.”	305.20887771606874
“Run and seek Athos, Porthos and Aramis. One of the three will	338.87243379572146
certainly be at home, perhaps all three. Tell them to take arms, to	166.7363927342868
come here, and to run! Ah, I remember, Athos is at Monsieur de	189.70920560099879
Tréville’s.”	170.11093113859005
“But where are you going, monsieur, where are you going?”	275.28456191691333
“I am going down by the window, in order to be there the sooner,” cried	266.4199462582699
D’Artagnan. “You put back the boards, sweep the floor, go out at the	248.89356840197905
door, and run as I told you.”	219.4949944903038
“Oh, monsieur! Monsieur! You will kill yourself,” cried Planchet.	285.3945157545638
“Hold your tongue, stupid fellow,” said D’Artagnan; and laying hold of	281.60697595845426
the casement, he let himself gently down from the first story, which	324.12071005403817
fortunately was not very elevated, without doing himself the slightest	319.0534762231132
injury.	199.73703563536202
He then went straight to the door and knocked, murmuring, “I will go	333.83924603376124
myself and be caught in the mousetrap, but woe be to the cats that	340.324199660155
shall pounce upon such a mouse!”	263.55379229369555
The knocker had scarcely sounded under the hand of the young man before	340.5959495061153
the tumult ceased, steps approached, the door was opened, and	359.85079659996524
D’Artagnan, sword in hand, rushed into the rooms of M. Bonacieux, the	343.39143807345107
door of which, doubtless acted upon by a spring, closed after him.	245.09072149214617
Then those who dwelt in Bonacieux’s unfortunate house, together with	214.95600055586613
the nearest neighbors, heard loud cries, stamping of feet, clashing of	218.5393550648078
swords, and breaking of furniture. A moment after, those who, surprised	349.86852416326514
by this tumult, had gone to their windows to learn the cause of it, saw	293.793177366643
the door open, and four men, clothed in black, not _come_ out of it,	221.1468957856667
but _fly_, like so many frightened crows, leaving on the ground and on	198.04257244130812
the corners of the furniture, feathers from their wings; that is to	216.67863666731776
say, patches of their clothes and fragments of their cloaks.	235.20803744229318
D’Artagnan was conqueror—without much effort, it must be confessed, for	338.3563248338403
only one of the officers was armed, and even he defended himself for	253.4365007432977
form’s sake. It is true that the three others had endeavored to knock	293.6799378764166
the young man down with chairs, stools, and crockery; but two or three	205.59136772741368
scratches made by the Gascon’s blade terrified them. Ten minutes	167.1782931774053
sufficed for their defeat, and D’Artagnan remained master of the field	274.8403615241434
of battle.	225.98832419833752
The neighbors who had opened their windows, with the coolness peculiar	330.5159693639931
to the inhabitants of Paris in these times of perpetual riots and	236.28215042870147
disturbances, closed them again as soon as they saw the four men in	359.8676096600622
black flee—their instinct telling them that for the time all was over.	296.90780104593773
Besides, it began to grow late, and then, as today, people went to bed	220.7356816303008
early in the quarter of the Luxembourg.	197.84155655411172
On being left alone with Mme. Bonacieux, D’Artagnan turned toward her;	334.8590454193459
the poor woman reclined where she had been left, half-fainting upon an	259.10938624604114
armchair. D’Artagnan examined her with a rapid glance.	224.6689961202478
She was a charming woman of twenty-five or twenty-six years, with dark	311.0611949645514
hair, blue eyes, and a nose slightly turned up, admirable teeth, and a	271.2548716796525
complexion marbled with rose and opal. There, however, ended the signs	220.8597356574626
which might have confounded her with a lady of rank. The hands were	190.1692116575328
white, but without delicacy; the feet did not bespeak the woman of	273.4362975277887
quality. Happily, D’Artagnan was not yet acquainted with such niceties.	218.2735648399121
While D’Artagnan was examining Mme. Bonacieux, and was, as we have	300.32027767955225
said, close to her, he saw on the ground a fine cambric handkerchief,	290.5094385484873
which he picked up, as was his habit, and at the corner of which he	316.0395193296522
recognized the same cipher he had seen on the handkerchief which had	240.07804255820503
nearly caused him and Aramis to cut each other’s throat.	232.61856175771194
From that time, D’Artagnan had been cautious with respect to	175.02501286152537
handkerchiefs with arms on them, and he therefore placed in the pocket	212.64777913497448
of Mme. Bonacieux the one he had just picked up.	269.3977980653628
At that moment Mme. Bonacieux recovered her senses. She opened her	304.2971862685921
eyes, looked around her with terror, saw that the apartment was empty	255.168051969555
and that she was alone with her liberator. She extended her hands to	251.5729252197542
him with a smile. Mme. Bonacieux had the sweetest smile in the world.	254.9904116152002
“Ah, monsieur!” said she, “you have saved me; permit me to thank you.”	270.24116155558653
“Madame,” said D’Artagnan, “I have only done what every gentleman would	205.78621979162747
have done in my place; you owe me no thanks.”	210.77660235521634
“Oh, yes, monsieur, oh, yes; and I hope to prove to you that you have	181.52057105398353
not served an ingrate. But what could these men, whom I at first took	202.81711796854998
for robbers, want with me, and why is Monsieur Bonacieux not here?”	325.1704949589979
“Madame, those men were more dangerous than any robbers could have	243.55615528070447
been, for they are the agents of the cardinal; and as to your husband,	245.8681483701545
Monsieur Bonacieux, he is not here because he was yesterday evening	282.66303163086025
conducted to the Bastille.”	211.73590762577604
“My husband in the Bastille!” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Oh, my God! What	262.14542706327546
has he done? Poor dear man, he is innocence itself!”	291.8259393740121
And something like a faint smile lighted the still-terrified features	296.20098856695836
of the young woman.	231.5141355938052
“What has he done, madame?” said D’Artagnan. “I believe that his only	287.4696210779547
crime is to have at the same time the good fortune and the misfortune	203.13082456987055
to be your husband.”	195.24735506103323
“But, monsieur, you know then—”	279.7939290448878
“I know that you have been abducted, madame.”	329.2219824625172
“And by whom? Do you know him? Oh, if you know him, tell me!”	246.15094543995457
“By a man of from forty to forty-five years, with black hair, a dark	204.8160568000499
complexion, and a scar on his left temple.”	263.6589591349035
“That is he, that is he; but his name?”	344.52702454968954
“Ah, his name? I do not know that.”	282.7501400342908
“And did my husband know I had been carried off?”	261.7038197536426
“He was informed of it by a letter, written to him by the abductor	265.1321327365313
himself.”	167.02358389247755
“And does he suspect,” said Mme. Bonacieux, with some embarrassment,	218.84666986491231
“the cause of this event?”	225.22934737639332
“He attributed it, I believe, to a political cause.”	196.1180819075353
“I doubted from the first; and now I think entirely as he does. Then my	235.95594971996144
dear Monsieur Bonacieux has not suspected me a single instant?”	184.54412651240372
“So far from it, madame, he was too proud of your prudence, and above	207.06308143669042
all, of your love.”	237.97049035000788
A second smile, almost imperceptible, stole over the rosy lips of the	289.2533976822417
pretty young woman.	310.9888767569554
“But,” continued D’Artagnan, “how did you escape?”	238.41955938739085
“I took advantage of a moment when they left me alone; and as I had	239.99746171553994
known since morning the reason of my abduction, with the help of the	197.39841899532732
sheets I let myself down from the window. Then, as I believed my	238.7013165627715
husband would be at home, I hastened hither.”	289.18287478109335
“To place yourself under his protection?”	245.11904543403483
“Oh, no, poor dear man! I knew very well that he was incapable of	174.1149886223519
defending me; but as he could serve us in other ways, I wished to	167.3682039624234
inform him.”	331.1918960720768
“Of what?”	222.62225148052107
“Oh, that is not my secret; I must not, therefore, tell you.”	223.1812263221167
“Besides,” said D’Artagnan, “pardon me, madame, if, guardsman as I am,	240.1437785295289
I remind you of prudence—besides, I believe we are not here in a very	317.89116817723027
proper place for imparting confidences. The men I have put to flight	228.5711152613521
will return reinforced; if they find us here, we are lost. I have sent	244.27914754606837
for three of my friends, but who knows whether they were at home?”	242.3569569405397
“Yes, yes! You are right,” cried the affrighted Mme. Bonacieux; “let us	300.24454298580343
fly! Let us save ourselves.”	283.0515112192111
At these words she passed her arm under that of D’Artagnan, and urged	259.667165965172
him forward eagerly.	330.7056749365774
“But whither shall we fly—whither escape?”	329.07250765789877
“Let us first withdraw from this house; afterward we shall see.”	250.30653323322406
The young woman and the young man, without taking the trouble to shut	296.10309415916925
the door after them, descended the Rue des Fossoyeurs rapidly, turned	365.3411690224993
into the Rue des Fossés-Monsieur-le-Prince, and did not stop till they	264.560407579187
came to the Place St. Sulpice.	274.1209478423982
“And now what are we to do, and where do you wish me to conduct you?”	312.51947812799165
asked D’Artagnan.	364.931176840866
“I am at quite a loss how to answer you, I admit,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	238.8822080205167
“My intention was to inform Monsieur Laporte, through my husband, in	328.15542818644093
order that Monsieur Laporte might tell us precisely what had taken	211.61202878933773
place at the Louvre in the last three days, and whether there is any	228.89171957598677
danger in presenting myself there.”	244.48781304455798
“But I,” said D’Artagnan, “can go and inform Monsieur Laporte.”	318.2489870004384
“No doubt you could, only there is one misfortune, and that is that	332.1549157013172
Monsieur Bonacieux is known at the Louvre, and would be allowed to	352.16314948299885
pass; whereas you are not known there, and the gate would be closed	240.94975039873518
against you.”	353.31163551830724
“Ah, bah!” said D’Artagnan; “you have at some wicket of the Louvre a	214.90381413646978
_concierge_ who is devoted to you, and who, thanks to a password,	205.25262580782916
would—”	348.0071155974557
Mme. Bonacieux looked earnestly at the young man.	193.1453307464526
“And if I give you this password,” said she, “would you forget it as	274.3443918904406
soon as you used it?”	252.79143212413896
“By my honor, by the faith of a gentleman!” said D’Artagnan, with an	222.50413548619758
accent so truthful that no one could mistake it.	308.0584743788992
“Then I believe you. You appear to be a brave young man; besides, your	324.3909791548868
fortune may perhaps be the result of your devotedness.”	254.0492496577371
“I will do, without a promise and voluntarily, all that I can do to	183.39584529324694
serve the king and be agreeable to the queen. Dispose of me, then, as a	315.924981357917
friend.”	352.41081627299764
“But I—where shall I go meanwhile?”	206.9150031702139
“Is there nobody from whose house Monsieur Laporte can come and fetch	223.61497090398146
you?”	312.0570025560514
