“No, I can trust nobody.”	335.67659907245263
“Stop,” said D’Artagnan; “we are near Athos’s door. Yes, here it is.”	192.54027826555156
“Who is this Athos?”	318.78591170963756
“One of my friends.”	236.01156345164028
“But if he should be at home and see me?”	170.2260127547723
“He is not at home, and I will carry away the key, after having placed	323.35286360832606
you in his apartment.”	244.82358404054372
“But if he should return?”	192.04968125836737
“Oh, he won’t return; and if he should, he will be told that I have	173.14014209358092
brought a woman with me, and that woman is in his apartment.”	186.81983263981576
“But that will compromise me sadly, you know.”	223.99419538854875
“Of what consequence? Nobody knows you. Besides, we are in a situation	224.89957322485895
to overlook ceremony.”	340.7847671905636
“Come, then, let us go to your friend’s house. Where does he live?”	311.21391702178397
“Rue Férou, two steps from here.”	359.8349218905922
“Let us go!”	330.285417679337
Both resumed their way. As D’Artagnan had foreseen, Athos was not	217.46743677771764
within. He took the key, which was customarily given him as one of the	176.65701621064892
family, ascended the stairs, and introduced Mme. Bonacieux into the	294.0614800161999
little apartment of which we have given a description.	358.80609802352217
“You are at home,” said he. “Remain here, fasten the door inside, and	336.6820303818907
open it to nobody unless you hear three taps like this;” and he tapped	194.70492873751542
thrice—two taps close together and pretty hard, the other after an	318.4667825982761
interval, and lighter.	275.88437626585
“That is well,” said Mme. Bonacieux. “Now, in my turn, let me give you	284.5511401011693
my instructions.”	318.88184814326473
“I am all attention.”	246.873576922317
“Present yourself at the wicket of the Louvre, on the side of the Rue	255.9890286775256
de l’Echelle, and ask for Germain.”	252.608331807391
“Well, and then?”	335.98787425845796
“He will ask you what you want, and you will answer by these two words,	357.67306711395076
‘Tours’ and ‘Bruxelles.’ He will at once put himself at your orders.”	303.31670453302866
“And what shall I command him?”	303.0939657601946
“To go and fetch Monsieur Laporte, the queen’s _valet de chambre_.”	295.2494536745328
“And when he shall have informed him, and Monsieur Laporte is come?”	322.7706466784236
“You will send him to me.”	204.92716180362783
“That is well; but where and how shall I see you again?”	294.08105247554136
“Do you wish to see me again?”	242.54139131723701
“Certainly.”	182.44430789700922
“Well, let that care be mine, and be at ease.”	310.9912907942631
“I depend upon your word.”	339.77591562873215
“You may.”	314.44435105091554
D’Artagnan bowed to Mme. Bonacieux, darting at her the most loving	285.36992321372674
glance that he could possibly concentrate upon her charming little	259.3626959892532
person; and while he descended the stairs, he heard the door closed and	350.2111738363621
double-locked. In two bounds he was at the Louvre; as he entered the	246.52034146063522
wicket of L’Echelle, ten o’clock struck. All the events we have	185.6007788561871
described had taken place within a half hour.	323.4052009294422
Everything fell out as Mme. Bonacieux prophesied. On hearing the	269.6228840199474
password, Germain bowed. In a few minutes, Laporte was at the lodge; in	313.3367237717117
two words D’Artagnan informed him where Mme. Bonacieux was. Laporte	300.6960275718874
assured himself, by having it twice repeated, of the accurate address,	256.7840076398161
and set off at a run. Hardly, however, had he taken ten steps before he	216.7917063392746
returned.	365.5488937755458
“Young man,” said he to D’Artagnan, “a suggestion.”	220.48740489756446
“What?”	182.2984885965915
“You may get into trouble by what has taken place.”	179.43339026976088
“You believe so?”	315.3709909123237
“Yes. Have you any friend whose clock is too slow?”	209.03063181936844
“Well?”	229.0998835350628
“Go and call upon him, in order that he may give evidence of your	271.47893708666805
having been with him at half past nine. In a court of justice that is	248.89739576135457
called an alibi.”	302.77534106951396
D’Artagnan found his advice prudent. He took to his heels, and was soon	332.96799263356945
at M. de Tréville’s; but instead of going into the saloon with the rest	173.48870012971437
of the crowd, he asked to be introduced to M. de Tréville’s office. As	236.06134103653213
D’Artagnan so constantly frequented the hôtel, no difficulty was made	168.44305267265545
in complying with his request, and a servant went to inform M. de	332.1898825279194
Tréville that his young compatriot, having something important to	319.2032233493375
communicate, solicited a private audience. Five minutes after, M. de	309.38119886784847
Tréville was asking D’Artagnan what he could do to serve him, and what	209.99796512510875
caused his visit at so late an hour.	178.49578511090078
“Pardon me, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, who had profited by the moment	238.519865026503
he had been left alone to put back M. de Tréville’s clock	357.19146188741206
three-quarters of an hour, “but I thought, as it was yet only	347.2834305291358
twenty-five minutes past nine, it was not too late to wait upon you.”	170.1996061640687
“Twenty-five minutes past nine!” cried M. de Tréville, looking at the	187.67398038769966
clock; “why, that’s impossible!”	311.6156947596792
“Look, rather, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, “the clock shows it.”	204.87209467591774
“That’s true,” said M. de Tréville; “I believed it later. But what can	317.80283421426043
I do for you?”	199.51700999861967
Then D’Artagnan told M. de Tréville a long history about the queen. He	298.72639021393604
expressed to him the fears he entertained with respect to her Majesty;	175.7881741851311
he related to him what he had heard of the projects of the cardinal	240.8005366522884
with regard to Buckingham, and all with a tranquillity and candor of	170.03513448481593
which M. de Tréville was the more the dupe, from having himself, as we	243.59326125715552
have said, observed something fresh between the cardinal, the king, and	333.54127539840727
the queen.	305.7667642356499
As ten o’clock was striking, D’Artagnan left M. de Tréville, who	347.8687252055528
thanked him for his information, recommended him to have the service of	278.3386187326959
the king and queen always at heart, and returned to the saloon; but at	308.1881335174776
the foot of the stairs, D’Artagnan remembered he had forgotten his	286.97328741834815
cane. He consequently sprang up again, re-entered the office, with a	184.38459405324826
turn of his finger set the clock right again, that it might not be	297.23188901137837
perceived the next day that it had been put wrong, and certain from	235.00443823804522
that time that he had a witness to prove his alibi, he ran downstairs	344.2675565436721
and soon found himself in the street.	326.3648275666051
Chapter XI.	260.35977118329
IN WHICH THE PLOT THICKENS	285.84303644988375
His visit to M. de Tréville being paid, the pensive D’Artagnan took the	308.4979919990407
longest way homeward.	167.37763645558888
On what was D’Artagnan thinking, that he strayed thus from his path,	210.0171473157174
gazing at the stars of heaven, and sometimes sighing, sometimes	200.800727829442
smiling?	210.14513901261896
He was thinking of Mme. Bonacieux. For an apprentice Musketeer the	183.96413490331895
young woman was almost an ideal of love. Pretty, mysterious, initiated	193.84055528757267
in almost all the secrets of the court, which reflected such a charming	195.33113237470275
gravity over her pleasing features, it might be surmised that she was	288.3758562101759
not wholly unmoved; and this is an irresistible charm to novices in	314.8368409381751
love. Moreover, D’Artagnan had delivered her from the hands of the	328.8561549608716
demons who wished to search and ill treat her; and this important	337.4400980381283
service had established between them one of those sentiments of	288.72081430032074
gratitude which so easily assume a more tender character.	265.92177683928526
D’Artagnan already fancied himself, so rapid is the flight of our	233.56209475773076
dreams upon the wings of imagination, accosted by a messenger from the	260.02710983653327
young woman, who brought him some billet appointing a meeting, a gold	354.28138097465364
chain, or a diamond. We have observed that young cavaliers received	166.96717089642107
presents from their king without shame. Let us add that in these times	325.4861308098036
of lax morality they had no more delicacy with respect to the	287.4507081487882
mistresses; and that the latter almost always left them valuable and	245.18906185044045
durable remembrances, as if they essayed to conquer the fragility of	321.6127468288931
their sentiments by the solidity of their gifts.	180.11117301217513
Without a blush, men made their way in the world by the means of women	357.40585356195663
blushing. Such as were only beautiful gave their beauty, whence,	295.41736194365274
without doubt, comes the proverb, “The most beautiful girl in the world	230.02091759063057
can only give what she has.” Such as were rich gave in addition a part	212.68590243093897
of their money; and a vast number of heroes of that gallant period may	220.8260886999388
be cited who would neither have won their spurs in the first place, nor	220.3043456231972
their battles afterward, without the purse, more or less furnished,	240.54026180094144
which their mistress fastened to the saddle bow.	245.47194556808654
D’Artagnan owned nothing. Provincial diffidence, that slight varnish,	203.1007730698068
the ephemeral flower, that down of the peach, had evaporated to the	240.92918784819273
winds through the little orthodox counsels which the three Musketeers	193.95337945874348
gave their friend. D’Artagnan, following the strange custom of the	306.5398295914716
times, considered himself at Paris as on a campaign, neither more nor	172.9144508052554
less than if he had been in Flanders—Spain yonder, woman here. In each	289.3036653202898
there was an enemy to contend with, and contributions to be levied.	282.40883925428983
But, we must say, at the present moment D’Artagnan was ruled by a	344.34563374958987
feeling much more noble and disinterested. The mercer had said that he	167.08461554493707
was rich; the young man might easily guess that with so weak a man as	365.7592033404914
M. Bonacieux; and interest was almost foreign to this commencement of	258.39539400322724
love, which had been the consequence of it. We say _almost_, for the	182.0275106518564
idea that a young, handsome, kind, and witty woman is at the same time	237.97858782467534
rich takes nothing from the beginning of love, but on the contrary	358.3907633919165
strengthens it.	339.9515770668808
There are in affluence a crowd of aristocratic cares and caprices which	275.41608890754156
are highly becoming to beauty. A fine and white stocking, a silken	246.93082160092212
robe, a lace kerchief, a pretty slipper on the foot, a tasty ribbon on	247.73634007793547
the head do not make an ugly woman pretty, but they make a pretty woman	174.19056664917903
beautiful, without reckoning the hands, which gain by all this; the	349.2367954553506
hands, among women particularly, to be beautiful must be idle.	348.23871206289255
Then D’Artagnan, as the reader, from whom we have not concealed the	237.70812900818964
state of his fortune, very well knows—D’Artagnan was not a millionaire;	198.0760411136426
he hoped to become one someday, but the time which in his own mind he	289.9877235680704
fixed upon for this happy change was still far distant. In the	204.36042818302855
meanwhile, how disheartening to see the woman one loves long for those	316.0889077214214
thousands of nothings which constitute a woman’s happiness, and be	166.24813856431416
unable to give her those thousands of nothings. At least, when the	255.72568784278013
woman is rich and the lover is not, that which he cannot offer she	257.212415111939
offers to herself; and although it is generally with her husband’s	328.71270989514403
money that she procures herself this indulgence, the gratitude for it	318.87168759008256
seldom reverts to him.	181.47714716812104
Then D’Artagnan, disposed to become the most tender of lovers, was at	219.64905221965375
the same time a very devoted friend. In the midst of his amorous	238.64352631778897
projects for the mercer’s wife, he did not forget his friends. The	253.15516671751772
pretty Mme. Bonacieux was just the woman to walk with in the Plain St.	292.3695343613369
Denis or in the fair of St. Germain, in company with Athos, Porthos,	193.37268912526994
and Aramis, to whom D’Artagnan had often remarked this. Then one could	335.75223070718715
enjoy charming little dinners, where one touches on one side the hand	361.13196036735906
of a friend, and on the other the foot of a mistress. Besides, on	242.9011246984906
pressing occasions, in extreme difficulties, D’Artagnan would become	283.8459299603811
the preserver of his friends.	275.23174159057726
And M. Bonacieux, whom D’Artagnan had pushed into the hands of the	268.62434318105807
officers, denying him aloud although he had promised in a whisper to	330.3623722362187
save him? We are compelled to admit to our readers that D’Artagnan	257.48668218693206
thought nothing about him in any way; or that if he did think of him,	323.507192855707
it was only to say to himself that he was very well where he was,	211.9810712372676
wherever it might be. Love is the most selfish of all the passions.	293.9421028873865
Let our readers reassure themselves. If D’Artagnan forgets his host, or	186.5777072077758
appears to forget him, under the pretense of not knowing where he has	361.64086448140483
been carried, we will not forget him, and we know where he is. But for	200.96799794009388
the moment, let us do as did the amorous Gascon; we will see after the	260.6859426615244
worthy mercer later.	202.8763164504001
D’Artagnan, reflecting on his future amours, addressing himself to the	235.37058783170028
beautiful night, and smiling at the stars, ascended the Rue	291.0106690054712
Cherish-Midi, or Chase-Midi, as it was then called. As he found himself	183.63287029590336
in the quarter in which Aramis lived, he took it into his head to pay	177.86706570919088
his friend a visit in order to explain the motives which had led him to	330.1366017442516
send Planchet with a request that he would come instantly to the	329.4967107003762
mousetrap. Now, if Aramis had been at home when Planchet came to his	235.65636288056336
abode, he had doubtless hastened to the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and finding	238.44507530056413
nobody there but his other two companions perhaps, they would not be	318.7412108530291
able to conceive what all this meant. This mystery required an	315.325632267252
explanation; at least, so D’Artagnan declared to himself.	243.34218170357093
He likewise thought this was an opportunity for talking about pretty	252.72205152284334
little Mme. Bonacieux, of whom his head, if not his heart, was already	295.2675081712692
full. We must never look for discretion in first love. First love is	324.9059303204152
accompanied by such excessive joy that unless the joy be allowed to	363.6246580320938
overflow, it will stifle you.	277.2849583936379
Paris for two hours past had been dark, and seemed a desert. Eleven	224.28997727300543
o’clock sounded from all the clocks of the Faubourg St. Germain. It was	208.8288444369498
delightful weather. D’Artagnan was passing along a lane on the spot	293.6466839169991
where the Rue d’Assas is now situated, breathing the balmy emanations	204.7419413604329
which were borne upon the wind from the Rue de Vaugirard, and which	220.30926341292647
arose from the gardens refreshed by the dews of evening and the breeze	178.4821084486515
of night. From a distance resounded, deadened, however, by good	340.50494485613535
shutters, the songs of the tipplers, enjoying themselves in the	287.0763561161535
cabarets scattered along the plain. Arrived at the end of the lane,	235.72163592146575
D’Artagnan turned to the left. The house in which Aramis dwelt was	237.7932608642286
situated between the Rue Cassette and the Rue Servandoni.	260.1943197422252
D’Artagnan had just passed the Rue Cassette, and already perceived the	199.55249156090437
door of his friend’s house, shaded by a mass of sycamores and clematis	227.06809705297144
which formed a vast arch opposite the front of it, when he perceived	291.4631583266906
something like a shadow issuing from the Rue Servandoni. This something	170.47550887252254
was enveloped in a cloak, and D’Artagnan at first believed it was a	351.05190973383355
man; but by the smallness of the form, the hesitation of the walk, and	180.72570562819305
the indecision of the step, he soon discovered that it was a woman.	252.58114955498678
Further, this woman, as if not certain of the house she was seeking,	267.31786113402507
lifted up her eyes to look around her, stopped, went backward, and then	275.7795840476585
returned again. D’Artagnan was perplexed.	236.7518496689389
“Shall I go and offer her my services?” thought he. “By her step she	230.26863634773792
must be young; perhaps she is pretty. Oh, yes! But a woman who wanders	174.97017798468627
in the streets at this hour only ventures out to meet her lover. If I	281.74437877797584
should disturb a rendezvous, that would not be the best means of	265.6891382201777
commencing an acquaintance.”	342.34398683051984
Meantime the young woman continued to advance, counting the houses and	358.6379614625281
windows. This was neither long nor difficult. There were but three	186.9949532555534
hôtels in this part of the street; and only two windows looking toward	282.49473082382934
the road, one of which was in a pavilion parallel to that which Aramis	296.66307156289747
occupied, the other belonging to Aramis himself.	204.9660078829944
“_Pardieu!_” said D’Artagnan to himself, to whose mind the niece of the	357.7157377127255
theologian reverted, “_pardieu_, it would be droll if this belated dove	302.03889863881557
should be in search of our friend’s house. But on my soul, it looks so.	307.05335452791394
Ah, my dear Aramis, this time I shall find you out.” And D’Artagnan,	228.6759090866148
making himself as small as he could, concealed himself in the darkest	207.16910886748065
side of the street near a stone bench placed at the back of a niche.	356.25837515729154
The young woman continued to advance; and in addition to the lightness	282.23775717814385
of her step, which had betrayed her, she emitted a little cough which	185.14033058177006
denoted a sweet voice. D’Artagnan believed this cough to be a signal.	240.604833533982
Nevertheless, whether the cough had been answered by a similar signal	344.121604407669
which had fixed the irresolution of the nocturnal seeker, or whether	190.16863921649139
without this aid she saw that she had arrived at the end of her	194.22664879540318
journey, she resolutely drew near to Aramis’s shutter, and tapped, at	247.91128560179192
three equal intervals, with her bent finger.	233.75424488210513
“This is all very fine, dear Aramis,” murmured D’Artagnan. “Ah,	316.6209054677962
Monsieur Hypocrite, I understand how you study theology.”	229.7362473522191
The three blows were scarcely struck, when the inside blind was opened	258.0852473837962
and a light appeared through the panes of the outside shutter.	237.9888586502746
“Ah, ah!” said the listener, “not through doors, but through windows!	227.161711741619
Ah, this visit was expected. We shall see the windows open, and the	335.4144190340405
lady enter by escalade. Very pretty!”	340.56590157439337
But to the great astonishment of D’Artagnan, the shutter remained	170.1760829960159
closed. Still more, the light which had shone for an instant	181.65865323182243
disappeared, and all was again in obscurity.	260.5737971824508
D’Artagnan thought this could not last long, and continued to look with	339.8140270347284
all his eyes and listen with all his ears.	301.58064937052893
He was right; at the end of some seconds two sharp taps were heard	310.39721423553965
inside. The young woman in the street replied by a single tap, and the	226.353646676412
shutter was opened a little way.	330.495092882667
It may be judged whether D’Artagnan looked or listened with avidity.	343.09194355536
Unfortunately the light had been removed into another chamber; but the	170.62664150651776
eyes of the young man were accustomed to the night. Besides, the eyes	233.3550187537732
of the Gascons have, as it is asserted, like those of cats, the faculty	166.35477020852446
of seeing in the dark.	222.14729373886445
D’Artagnan then saw that the young woman took from her pocket a white	169.93601503677095
object, which she unfolded quickly, and which took the form of a	242.36544806246886
handkerchief. She made her interlocutor observe the corner of this	209.2817058804089
unfolded object.	170.04420019270555
This immediately recalled to D’Artagnan’s mind the handkerchief which	343.66733273861405
he had found at the feet of Mme. Bonacieux, which had reminded him of	275.660117410256
that which he had dragged from under the feet of Aramis.	311.65027056070784
“What the devil could that handkerchief signify?”	288.4967304401237
Placed where he was, D’Artagnan could not perceive the face of Aramis.	351.69727110738563
We say Aramis, because the young man entertained no doubt that it was	289.8828919242808
his friend who held this dialogue from the interior with the lady of	241.48203688134774
the exterior. Curiosity prevailed over prudence; and profiting by the	287.9050490463416
preoccupation into which the sight of the handkerchief appeared to have	236.21974287818207
plunged the two personages now on the scene, he stole from his hiding	363.1310948701641
place, and quick as lightning, but stepping with utmost caution, he ran	254.7712637944315
and placed himself close to the angle of the wall, from which his eye	353.9755933828431
could pierce the interior of Aramis’s room.	259.70292086381096
Upon gaining this advantage D’Artagnan was near uttering a cry of	297.9118032272744
surprise; it was not Aramis who was conversing with the nocturnal	267.6213285179508
visitor, it was a woman! D’Artagnan, however, could only see enough to	243.30053133206943
recognize the form of her vestments, not enough to distinguish her	179.17472425677218
features.	274.99809487367685
At the same instant the woman inside drew a second handkerchief from	210.5220107141299
her pocket, and exchanged it for that which had just been shown to her.	175.92568258667518
Then some words were spoken by the two women. At length the shutter	219.77551921978022
closed. The woman who was outside the window turned round, and passed	173.9811054934726
within four steps of D’Artagnan, pulling down the hood of her mantle;	339.36705994890934
but the precaution was too late, D’Artagnan had already recognized Mme.	296.84407003499064
Bonacieux.	361.47156525923515
Mme. Bonacieux! The suspicion that it was she had crossed the mind of	219.60583817282952
D’Artagnan when she drew the handkerchief from her pocket; but what	212.38138727028004
probability was there that Mme. Bonacieux, who had sent for M. Laporte	184.57352256292657
in order to be reconducted to the Louvre, should be running about the	177.80611270248087
streets of Paris at half past eleven at night, at the risk of being	284.4298788835796
abducted a second time?	302.3753711942711
This must be, then, an affair of importance; and what is the most	330.16644645363476
important affair to a woman of twenty-five! Love.	285.42359046864965
But was it on her own account, or on account of another, that she	345.8296283939177
exposed herself to such hazards? This was a question the young man	328.7430769431006
asked himself, whom the demon of jealousy already gnawed, being in	233.8180166939889
heart neither more nor less than an accepted lover.	317.03917731103377
There was a very simple means of satisfying himself whither Mme.	342.3648542525791
Bonacieux was going; that was to follow her. This method was so simple	167.1580379914305
that D’Artagnan employed it quite naturally and instinctively.	212.04690005242077
But at the sight of the young man, who detached himself from the wall	322.8654357084365
like a statue walking from its niche, and at the noise of the steps	205.628035116238
which she heard resound behind her, Mme. Bonacieux uttered a little cry	200.3940002746891
and fled.	216.74115277046138
D’Artagnan ran after her. It was not difficult for him to overtake a	321.3344660198642
woman embarrassed with her cloak. He came up with her before she had	294.5596374264768
traversed a third of the street. The unfortunate woman was exhausted,	214.48615069988034
not by fatigue, but by terror, and when D’Artagnan placed his hand upon	233.56588863584656
her shoulder, she sank upon one knee, crying in a choking voice, “Kill	247.96075962809334
me, if you please, you shall know nothing!”	360.09738742632896
D’Artagnan raised her by passing his arm round her waist; but as he	230.69600532539857
felt by her weight she was on the point of fainting, he made haste to	293.0519267037188
reassure her by protestations of devotedness. These protestations were	243.52893893088384
nothing for Mme. Bonacieux, for such protestations may be made with the	327.3150036226313
worst intentions in the world; but the voice was all. Mme. Bonacieux	309.3921811409732
thought she recognized the sound of that voice; she reopened her eyes,	339.1232647357119
cast a quick glance upon the man who had terrified her so, and at once	272.9726947705716
perceiving it was D’Artagnan, she uttered a cry of joy, “Oh, it is you,	297.16689736995534
it is you! Thank God, thank God!”	247.1359715798385
“Yes, it is I,” said D’Artagnan, “it is I, whom God has sent to watch	230.189166873982
over you.”	177.728782460103
“Was it with that intention you followed me?” asked the young woman,	363.605647136283
with a coquettish smile, whose somewhat bantering character resumed its	346.54135123764854
influence, and with whom all fear had disappeared from the moment in	299.56172868688805
which she recognized a friend in one she had taken for an enemy.	345.88853837677993
“No,” said D’Artagnan; “no, I confess it. It was chance that threw me	365.3077600580277
in your way; I saw a woman knocking at the window of one of my	198.46890187979102
friends.”	190.81868238489264
“One of your friends?” interrupted Mme. Bonacieux.	179.46845327972827
“Without doubt; Aramis is one of my best friends.”	328.49934464512626
“Aramis! Who is he?”	187.45284780086814
“Come, come, you won’t tell me you don’t know Aramis?”	242.51240832425694
“This is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced.”	324.85685718817786
“It is the first time, then, that you ever went to that house?”	283.21684975706717
“Undoubtedly.”	273.2597535637475
“And you did not know that it was inhabited by a young man?”	307.69815509383716
“No.”	205.71211286712696
“By a Musketeer?”	326.97000052210205
“No, indeed!”	214.12071697080938
“It was not he, then, you came to seek?”	282.72401757598493
“Not the least in the world. Besides, you must have seen that the	175.59746421570233
person to whom I spoke was a woman.”	292.3375379357842
“That is true; but this woman is a friend of Aramis—”	205.54063044558995
“I know nothing of that.”	319.9519130487464
“—since she lodges with him.”	329.7572860386274
“That does not concern me.”	253.9359988101689
“But who is she?”	344.56052713005647
“Oh, that is not my secret.”	245.14575911154458
“My dear Madame Bonacieux, you are charming; but at the same time you	350.7448166306739
are one of the most mysterious women.”	186.14386127707417
“Do I lose by that?”	280.3840710999206
“No; you are, on the contrary, adorable.”	352.8095451786814
“Give me your arm, then.”	287.57245724071277
“Most willingly. And now?”	296.9804992361916
“Now escort me.”	181.19100544613195
“Where?”	302.63929695023796
“Where I am going.”	362.7303799149485
“But where are you going?”	177.87803019394502
“You will see, because you will leave me at the door.”	320.6368967659211
“Shall I wait for you?”	194.2882109679477
“That will be useless.”	213.55239558704426
“You will return alone, then?”	229.55883912313095
“Perhaps yes, perhaps no.”	265.55367849307373
“But will the person who shall accompany you afterward be a man or a	299.05381891441385
woman?”	203.77712231564985
“I don’t know yet.”	181.69639335896994
“But I will know it!”	362.44469740848245
“How so?”	178.898517258236
“I will wait until you come out.”	179.53064776153218
“In that case, adieu.”	357.3988823190586
“Why so?”	227.61673232902237
“I do not want you.”	207.40814425565227
“But you have claimed—”	358.6724762408003
“The aid of a gentleman, not the watchfulness of a spy.”	314.62897268150255
“The word is rather hard.”	243.45028311692954
“How are they called who follow others in spite of them?”	209.11004938990152
“They are indiscreet.”	257.6476708193643
“The word is too mild.”	327.39273192295445
“Well, madame, I perceive I must do as you wish.”	358.6335914189982
“Why did you deprive yourself of the merit of doing so at once?”	200.92023098914729
“Is there no merit in repentance?”	173.842709265214
“And do you really repent?”	274.78878707918
“I know nothing about it myself. But what I know is that I promise to	229.4516106022037
do all you wish if you allow me to accompany you where you are going.”	245.84826922911026
“And you will leave me then?”	338.11883956868223
“Yes.”	246.03987746073796
“Without waiting for my coming out again?”	277.34572393141946
“Yes.”	178.11570624994914
“Word of honor?”	353.6647347491386
“By the faith of a gentleman. Take my arm, and let us go.”	324.86573168726545
D’Artagnan offered his arm to Mme. Bonacieux, who willingly took it,	217.76038936948774
half laughing, half trembling, and both gained the top of Rue de la	278.36094189158325
Harpe. Arriving there, the young woman seemed to hesitate, as she had	350.52608011272525
before done in the Rue Vaugirard. She seemed, however, by certain	188.43840984405813
signs, to recognize a door, and approaching that door, “And now,	324.7707785140851
monsieur,” said she, “it is here I have business; a thousand thanks for	296.78546529418134
your honorable company, which has saved me from all the dangers to	280.43941517369393
which, alone, I was exposed. But the moment is come to keep your word;	324.5122260203177
I have reached my destination.”	232.645683372024
“And you will have nothing to fear on your return?”	274.1656498734895
“I shall have nothing to fear but robbers.”	306.27361276677607
“And that is nothing?”	247.31809191278137
“What could they take from me? I have not a penny about me.”	190.48924732930365
“You forget that beautiful handkerchief with the coat of arms.”	270.4474680287549
“Which?”	337.16532194846616
“That which I found at your feet, and replaced in your pocket.”	283.6682855965049
“Hold your tongue, imprudent man! Do you wish to destroy me?”	332.4249326223221
“You see very plainly that there is still danger for you, since a	360.0576090980081
single word makes you tremble; and you confess that if that word were	279.1555991803848
heard you would be ruined. Come, come, madame!” cried D’Artagnan,	308.98787976413297
seizing her hands, and surveying her with an ardent glance, “come, be	241.02323557329447
more generous. Confide in me. Have you not read in my eyes that there	363.1810375785734
is nothing but devotion and sympathy in my heart?”	245.46218149733724
“Yes,” replied Mme. Bonacieux; “therefore, ask my own secrets, and I	189.5406648305037
will reveal them to you; but those of others—that is quite another	227.72642027773395
thing.”	241.88289613983534
“Very well,” said D’Artagnan, “I shall discover them; as these secrets	247.3907721343268
may have an influence over your life, these secrets must become mine.”	221.27858651894695
“Beware of what you do!” cried the young woman, in a manner so serious	246.22089597601763
as to make D’Artagnan start in spite of himself. “Oh, meddle in nothing	302.6942356323217
which concerns me. Do not seek to assist me in that which I am	285.85638037676017
accomplishing. This I ask of you in the name of the interest with which	178.62286492992405
I inspire you, in the name of the service you have rendered me and	174.05368532922478
which I never shall forget while I have life. Rather, place faith in	172.5790848962735
what I tell you. Have no more concern about me; I exist no longer for	335.8105421025597
you, any more than if you had never seen me.”	346.6831890502043
“Must Aramis do as much as I, madame?” said D’Artagnan, deeply piqued.	318.321543925542
“This is the second or third time, monsieur, that you have repeated	238.29634534485425
that name, and yet I have told you that I do not know him.”	295.55154386446077
“You do not know the man at whose shutter you have just knocked?	234.15078027858573
Indeed, madame, you believe me too credulous!”	201.17772387318263
“Confess that it is for the sake of making me talk that you invent this	180.49471081495173
story and create this personage.”	198.2171503518778
“I invent nothing, madame; I create nothing. I only speak that exact	177.48087934572254
truth.”	332.89939859604385
“And you say that one of your friends lives in that house?”	309.1386585907728
“I say so, and I repeat it for the third time; that house is one	362.86181079088703
inhabited by my friend, and that friend is Aramis.”	196.60310520688463
“All this will be cleared up at a later period,” murmured the young	219.19752124874333
woman; “no, monsieur, be silent.”	178.44495404468495
“If you could see my heart,” said D’Artagnan, “you would there read so	188.14590795706155
much curiosity that you would pity me and so much love that you would	283.3192163425465
instantly satisfy my curiosity. We have nothing to fear from those who	335.6984929230671
love us.”	362.71949048589465
“You speak very suddenly of love, monsieur,” said the young woman,	310.46887715352136
shaking her head.	236.81964549481958
“That is because love has come suddenly upon me, and for the first	308.20645856329077
time; and because I am only twenty.”	293.1114084828691
The young woman looked at him furtively.	197.1928043487268
“Listen; I am already upon the scent,” resumed D’Artagnan. “About three	180.20435206199448
months ago I was near having a duel with Aramis concerning a	233.26643674549754
handkerchief resembling the one you showed to the woman in his	272.0045615524159
house—for a handkerchief marked in the same manner, I am sure.”	211.48419387436516
“Monsieur,” said the young woman, “you weary me very much, I assure	195.57951551819167
you, with your questions.”	326.5828809383554
“But you, madame, prudent as you are, think, if you were to be arrested	343.44957422949875
with that handkerchief, and that handkerchief were to be seized, would	330.8336691648492
you not be compromised?”	243.70810218395462
“In what way? The initials are only mine—C. B., Constance Bonacieux.”	301.22926781012364
“Or Camille de Bois-Tracy.”	262.3562090646617
“Silence, monsieur! Once again, silence! Ah, since the dangers I incur	312.26369631934665
on my own account cannot stop you, think of those you may yourself	216.60719249274482
run!”	275.53104639813324
“Me?”	308.59123107237315
“Yes; there is peril of imprisonment, risk of life in knowing me.”	265.52256709801964
“Then I will not leave you.”	216.28515759684777
“Monsieur!” said the young woman, supplicating him and clasping her	270.76507988703713
hands together, “monsieur, in the name of heaven, by the honor of a	166.64912170656453
soldier, by the courtesy of a gentleman, depart! There, there midnight	344.847008421566
sounds! That is the hour when I am expected.”	181.60917776522555
“Madame,” said the young man, bowing; “I can refuse nothing asked of me	290.26640311199833
thus. Be content; I will depart.”	327.90684311405926
“But you will not follow me; you will not watch me?”	257.4732161152036
“I will return home instantly.”	232.33130040407093
“Ah, I was quite sure you were a good and brave young man,” said Mme.	218.5240767308465
Bonacieux, holding out her hand to him, and placing the other upon the	255.52332006966043
knocker of a little door almost hidden in the wall.	203.11935095701932
D’Artagnan seized the hand held out to him, and kissed it ardently.	352.09216896745386
“Ah! I wish I had never seen you!” cried D’Artagnan, with that	213.79008915829158
ingenuous roughness which women often prefer to the affectations of	348.50843677867135
politeness, because it betrays the depths of the thought and proves	364.23155264896815
that feeling prevails over reason.	265.38343926615613
“Well!” resumed Mme. Bonacieux, in a voice almost caressing, and	292.48612543310196
pressing the hand of D’Artagnan, who had not relinquished hers, “well:	290.33356313084033
I will not say as much as you do; what is lost for today may not be	343.3059321351584
lost forever. Who knows, when I shall be at liberty, that I may not	225.4758989461343
satisfy your curiosity?”	341.8525214689793
“And will you make the same promise to my love?” cried D’Artagnan,	364.6190375075355
beside himself with joy.	198.95424969528014
“Oh, as to that, I do not engage myself. That depends upon the	304.72132266641825
sentiments with which you may inspire me.”	257.2799044263746
“Then today, madame—”	298.3757187090988
“Oh, today, I am no further than gratitude.”	177.75089485928683
“Ah! You are too charming,” said D’Artagnan, sorrowfully; “and you	271.6640885912299
abuse my love.”	312.67376072205894
“No, I use your generosity, that’s all. But be of good cheer; with	348.4422873758833
certain people, everything comes round.”	239.03842048209268
“Oh, you render me the happiest of men! Do not forget this evening—do	249.08158113250468
not forget that promise.”	273.33926959796804
“Be satisfied. In the proper time and place I will remember everything.	170.09932814592727
Now then, go, go, in the name of heaven! I was expected at sharp	292.4632709582903
midnight, and I am late.”	298.18732712699136
“By five minutes.”	246.65633872496431
“Yes; but in certain circumstances five minutes are five ages.”	217.98037619211473
“When one loves.”	263.5025445699944
“Well! And who told you I had no affair with a lover?”	326.8559439756253
“It is a man, then, who expects you?” cried D’Artagnan. “A man!”	170.0401025858186
“The discussion is going to begin again!” said Mme. Bonacieux, with a	241.79588897920277
half-smile which was not exempt from a tinge of impatience.	310.2265033511595
“No, no; I go, I depart! I believe in you, and I would have all the	225.39564056503437
merit of my devotion, even if that devotion were stupidity. Adieu,	228.40607964731836
madame, adieu!”	291.39663070059703
And as if he only felt strength to detach himself by a violent effort	195.15976018313407
from the hand he held, he sprang away, running, while Mme. Bonacieux	293.5985391503593
knocked, as at the shutter, three light and regular taps. When he had	352.6785589315433
gained the angle of the street, he turned. The door had been opened,	287.7359270629146
and shut again; the mercer’s pretty wife had disappeared.	295.3903902840764
D’Artagnan pursued his way. He had given his word not to watch Mme.	175.51915430849576
Bonacieux, and if his life had depended upon the spot to which she was	340.38372638706926
going or upon the person who should accompany her, D’Artagnan would	358.5715256170058
have returned home, since he had so promised. Five minutes later he was	215.46480048400218
in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.	279.3503945928612
“Poor Athos!” said he; “he will never guess what all this means. He	308.8665186836478
will have fallen asleep waiting for me, or else he will have returned	292.10757752291295
home, where he will have learned that a woman had been there. A woman	251.71960402715362
with Athos! After all,” continued D’Artagnan, “there was certainly one	176.09696684625624
with Aramis. All this is very strange; and I am curious to know how it	218.04212339367982
will end.”	204.22649364706285
“Badly, monsieur, badly!” replied a voice which the young man	201.88635297439052
recognized as that of Planchet; for, soliloquizing aloud, as very	210.878341093816
preoccupied people do, he had entered the alley, at the end of which	258.05743741126025
were the stairs which led to his chamber.	222.50836130699372
“How, badly? What do you mean by that, you idiot?” asked D’Artagnan.	317.4410488728709
“What has happened?”	292.1622276301747
“All sorts of misfortunes.”	177.87984169921245
“What?”	262.24033503175013
“In the first place, Monsieur Athos is arrested.”	175.7986483688328
“Arrested! Athos arrested! What for?”	361.44827055550695
“He was found in your lodging; they took him for you.”	303.1765588286088
“And by whom was he arrested?”	314.08824300889114
“By Guards brought by the men in black whom you put to flight.”	172.22432575097213
“Why did he not tell them his name? Why did he not tell them he knew	198.85888838699935
nothing about this affair?”	177.2999530834813
“He took care not to do so, monsieur; on the contrary, he came up to me	332.7807292769237
and said, ‘It is your master that needs his liberty at this moment and	200.67882511994372
not I, since he knows everything and I know nothing. They will believe	325.46068403499305
he is arrested, and that will give him time; in three days I will tell	364.1668988122394
them who I am, and they cannot fail to let me go.’”	263.9285688679156
“Bravo, Athos! Noble heart!” murmured D’Artagnan. “I know him well	204.26347415059686
there! And what did the officers do?”	215.99963443737948
“Four conveyed him away, I don’t know where—to the Bastille or Fort	342.04889028699745
l’Evêque. Two remained with the men in black, who rummaged every place	354.69763896518407
and took all the papers. The last two mounted guard at the door during	241.87956559336135
this examination; then, when all was over, they went away, leaving the	207.46721602400788
house empty and exposed.”	168.76287035867242
“And Porthos and Aramis?”	297.8541584070383
“I could not find them; they did not come.”	232.34003192835831
“But they may come any moment, for you left word that I awaited them?”	273.9413238082635
“Yes, monsieur.”	242.28559328569713
“Well, don’t budge, then; if they come, tell them what has happened.	229.50679998244982
Let them wait for me at the Pomme-de-Pin. Here it would be dangerous;	255.24875807344438
the house may be watched. I will run to Monsieur de Tréville to tell	202.82441201287006
them all this, and will meet them there.”	290.0645799677799
“Very well, monsieur,” said Planchet.	179.02397617702374
“But you will remain; you are not afraid?” said D’Artagnan, coming back	293.0043275545386
to recommend courage to his lackey.	349.8818698250042
“Be easy, monsieur,” said Planchet; “you do not know me yet. I am brave	222.86234278289515
when I set about it. It is all in beginning. Besides, I am a Picard.”	242.93777335287993
“Then it is understood,” said D’Artagnan; “you would rather be killed	281.60217737523976
than desert your post?”	326.88716206999084
“Yes, monsieur; and there is nothing I would not do to prove to	192.48454155504328
Monsieur that I am attached to him.”	225.67050956305474
“Good!” said D’Artagnan to himself. “It appears that the method I have	356.8346027990169
adopted with this boy is decidedly the best. I shall use it again upon	256.44109938881627
occasion.”	252.78187738213586
And with all the swiftness of his legs, already a little fatigued,	187.72608889077324
however, with the perambulations of the day, D’Artagnan directed his	262.5775778434784
course toward M. de Tréville’s.	250.00612337869183
M. de Tréville was not at his hôtel. His company was on guard at the	212.6521197499135
Louvre; he was at the Louvre with his company.	193.03890701044264
It was necessary to reach M. de Tréville; it was important that he	265.51084183521846
should be informed of what was passing. D’Artagnan resolved to try and	281.7725397599369
enter the Louvre. His costume of Guardsman in the company of M.	363.156823773994
Dessessart ought to be his passport.	308.8522107822942
He therefore went down the Rue des Petits Augustins, and came up to the	363.0200085385136
quay, in order to take the New Bridge. He had at first an idea of	221.15628660959084
crossing by the ferry; but on gaining the riverside, he had	343.22404767795354
mechanically put his hand into his pocket, and perceived that he had	226.0639728954042
not wherewithal to pay his passage.	211.4652896461777
As he gained the top of the Rue Guénegaud, he saw two persons coming	271.95419354934114
out of the Rue Dauphine whose appearance very much struck him. Of the	190.71536066779697
two persons who composed this group, one was a man and the other a	344.4186975298159
woman. The woman had the outline of Mme. Bonacieux; the man resembled	205.55054205624683
Aramis so much as to be mistaken for him.	245.57122198823072
Besides, the woman wore that black mantle which D’Artagnan could still	358.60658907447095
see outlined on the shutter of the Rue de Vaugirard and on the door of	335.05192260818086
the Rue de la Harpe; still further, the man wore the uniform of a	335.7165491594516
Musketeer.	362.18631679480393
The woman’s hood was pulled down, and the man held a handkerchief to	238.17511400961203
his face. Both, as this double precaution indicated, had an interest in	175.55336910100272
not being recognized.	230.02916915255258
They took the bridge. That was D’Artagnan’s road, as he was going to	251.5664823733419
the Louvre. D’Artagnan followed them.	237.42486021958916
He had not gone twenty steps before he became convinced that the woman	274.35490257449817
was really Mme. Bonacieux and that the man was Aramis.	182.9753401648851
He felt at that instant all the suspicions of jealousy agitating his	302.54391976716425
heart. He felt himself doubly betrayed, by his friend and by her whom	255.5053107483257
he already loved like a mistress. Mme. Bonacieux had declared to him,	197.9512864793671
by all the gods, that she did not know Aramis; and a quarter of an hour	175.00952540739547
after having made this assertion, he found her hanging on the arm of	232.95787787923524
Aramis.	237.84827137709615
D’Artagnan did not reflect that he had only known the mercer’s pretty	336.96291003183126
wife for three hours; that she owed him nothing but a little gratitude	216.19910997178084
for having delivered her from the men in black, who wished to carry her	354.15949616965224
off, and that she had promised him nothing. He considered himself an	356.16603118797116
outraged, betrayed, and ridiculed lover. Blood and anger mounted to his	220.1637947580853
face; he was resolved to unravel the mystery.	179.85839931239036
The young man and young woman perceived they were watched, and	272.9042001999043
redoubled their speed. D’Artagnan determined upon his course. He passed	280.78260620454967
them, then returned so as to meet them exactly before the Samaritaine,	187.97065336544057
which was illuminated by a lamp which threw its light over all that	357.0427608245096
part of the bridge.	237.43404280016455
D’Artagnan stopped before them, and they stopped before him.	351.6777785563754
“What do you want, monsieur?” demanded the Musketeer, recoiling a step,	358.55674226782446
and with a foreign accent, which proved to D’Artagnan that he was	257.94548720203977
deceived in one of his conjectures.	190.39667916893015
“It is not Aramis!” cried he.	210.50185087631286
“No, monsieur, it is not Aramis; and by your exclamation I perceive you	288.9470768893049
have mistaken me for another, and pardon you.”	247.27642772518786
“You pardon me?” cried D’Artagnan.	179.07016513497808
“Yes,” replied the stranger. “Allow me, then, to pass on, since it is	181.19897584438897
not with me you have anything to do.”	317.3902944016444
“You are right, monsieur, it is not with you that I have anything to	216.2926024726907
do; it is with Madame.”	307.8788806973224
“With Madame! You do not know her,” replied the stranger.	325.7373039433694
“You are deceived, monsieur; I know her very well.”	214.85860122983462
“Ah,” said Mme. Bonacieux; in a tone of reproach, “ah, monsieur, I had	169.29718297680049
your promise as a soldier and your word as a gentleman. I hoped to be	179.09691750952595
able to rely upon that.”	205.40452015637646
“And I, madame!” said D’Artagnan, embarrassed; “you promised me—”	361.71124561022975
“Take my arm, madame,” said the stranger, “and let us continue our	221.45364876316484
way.”	364.52094992156054
D’Artagnan, however, stupefied, cast down, annihilated by all that	323.1521511804924
happened, stood, with crossed arms, before the Musketeer and Mme.	179.8972029164051
Bonacieux.	322.3399865760912
The Musketeer advanced two steps, and pushed D’Artagnan aside with his	340.25840456486674
hand. D’Artagnan made a spring backward and drew his sword. At the same	332.36053381879697
time, and with the rapidity of lightning, the stranger drew his.	319.6557258547221
“In the name of heaven, my Lord!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, throwing	187.8963647477978
herself between the combatants and seizing the swords with her hands.	248.25241452817812
“My Lord!” cried D’Artagnan, enlightened by a sudden idea, “my Lord!	190.97291901691355
Pardon me, monsieur, but you are not—”	342.85085266099344
“My Lord the Duke of Buckingham,” said Mme. Bonacieux, in an undertone;	179.0500050531414
“and now you may ruin us all.”	312.81436762295493
“My Lord, Madame, I ask a hundred pardons! But I love her, my Lord, and	344.52663141072674
was jealous. You know what it is to love, my Lord. Pardon me, and then	305.33749068664895
tell me how I can risk my life to serve your Grace?”	330.56696245011426
“You are a brave young man,” said Buckingham, holding out his hand to	266.866594655904
D’Artagnan, who pressed it respectfully. “You offer me your services;	332.088456006805
with the same frankness I accept them. Follow us at a distance of	309.2390206392554
twenty paces, as far as the Louvre, and if anyone watches us, slay	294.6944848527597
him!”	276.43974228794315
D’Artagnan placed his naked sword under his arm, allowed the duke and	249.32881386706086
Mme. Bonacieux to take twenty steps ahead, and then followed them,	296.3158055465916
ready to execute the instructions of the noble and elegant minister of	304.95393190982867
Charles I.	227.12906443380245
Fortunately, he had no opportunity to give the duke this proof of his	325.74692821824834
devotion, and the young woman and the handsome Musketeer entered the	189.00798362821848
Louvre by the wicket of the Echelle without any interference.	359.76208492142734
As for D’Artagnan, he immediately repaired to the cabaret of the	234.8316278087533
Pomme-de-Pin, where he found Porthos and Aramis awaiting him. Without	317.1641014492327
giving them any explanation of the alarm and inconvenience he had	248.859966634052
caused them, he told them that he had terminated the affair alone in	200.42706018927106
which he had for a moment believed he should need their assistance.	302.3478257160107
Meanwhile, carried away as we are by our narrative, we must leave our	317.6593495319852
three friends to themselves, and follow the Duke of Buckingham and his	348.782686033964
guide through the labyrinths of the Louvre.	224.93207567757054
Chapter XII.	346.4881206932096
GEORGE VILLIERS, DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM	325.3418078552331
Mme. Bonacieux and the duke entered the Louvre without difficulty. Mme.	268.35470687925493
Bonacieux was known to belong to the queen; the duke wore the uniform	285.451306205928
of the Musketeers of M. de Tréville, who, as we have said, were that	174.5176649125172
evening on guard. Besides, Germain was in the interests of the queen;	181.16051687885016
and if anything should happen, Mme. Bonacieux would be accused of	342.9083616883003
having introduced her lover into the Louvre, that was all. She took the	177.6932431531566
risk upon herself. Her reputation would be lost, it is true; but of	186.84660628404805
what value in the world was the reputation of the little wife of a	232.24899336128098
mercer?	280.2828666681047
Once within the interior of the court, the duke and the young woman	324.53575096328484
followed the wall for the space of about twenty-five steps. This space	347.1266128939025
passed, Mme. Bonacieux pushed a little servants’ door, open by day but	328.4705951455859
generally closed at night. The door yielded. Both entered, and found	358.7632287983429
themselves in darkness; but Mme. Bonacieux was acquainted with all the	173.2096106372122
turnings and windings of this part of the Louvre, appropriated for the	269.65099730746505
people of the household. She closed the door after her, took the duke	356.4850476445591
by the hand, and after a few experimental steps, grasped a balustrade,	196.53913914184287
put her foot upon the bottom step, and began to ascend the staircase.	289.2072307828638
The duke counted two stories. She then turned to the right, followed	341.772122831885
the course of a long corridor, descended a flight, went a few steps	316.10223593555014
farther, introduced a key into a lock, opened a door, and pushed the	235.37853457686555
duke into an apartment lighted only by a lamp, saying, “Remain here, my	198.42662321949587
Lord Duke; someone will come.” She then went out by the same door,	346.64535825570294
which she locked, so that the duke found himself literally a prisoner.	288.06358966587476
Nevertheless, isolated as he was, we must say that the Duke of	296.8945945794301
Buckingham did not experience an instant of fear. One of the salient	356.47683359553537
points of his character was the search for adventures and a love of	262.9347663131895
romance. Brave, rash, and enterprising, this was not the first time he	215.8034205573113
had risked his life in such attempts. He had learned that the pretended	326.6052097763942
message from Anne of Austria, upon the faith of which he had come to	318.21590519884194
Paris, was a snare; but instead of regaining England, he had, abusing	220.01023953662704
the position in which he had been placed, declared to the queen that he	357.2130762365981
would not depart without seeing her. The queen had at first positively	269.8612730311
refused; but at length became afraid that the duke, if exasperated,	250.05512035978774
would commit some folly. She had already decided upon seeing him and	263.17923866500735
urging his immediate departure, when, on the very evening of coming to	174.12301045645515
this decision, Mme. Bonacieux, who was charged with going to fetch the	316.28036572890807
duke and conducting him to the Louvre, was abducted. For two days no	296.2241357228596
one knew what had become of her, and everything remained in suspense;	310.78230886401366
but once free, and placed in communication with Laporte, matters	269.67318520195454
resumed their course, and she accomplished the perilous enterprise	219.37225275714542
which, but for her arrest, would have been executed three days earlier.	298.25455546420903
Buckingham, left alone, walked toward a mirror. His Musketeer’s uniform	255.04693259756846
became him marvelously.	246.8136864873705
At thirty-five, which was then his age, he passed, with just title, for	287.2904612418847
the handsomest gentleman and the most elegant cavalier of France or	312.749677814813
England.	191.26336676102034
The favorite of two kings, immensely rich, all-powerful in a kingdom	207.47282495239966
which he disordered at his fancy and calmed again at his caprice,	242.29264582681697
George Villiers, Duke of Buckingham, had lived one of those fabulous	226.99070562830985
existences which survive, in the course of centuries, to astonish	344.45196345580905
posterity.	359.1368807553613
Sure of himself, convinced of his own power, certain that the laws	328.97424055278077
which rule other men could not reach him, he went straight to the	327.9394703577584
object he aimed at, even were this object so elevated and so dazzling	330.89192205057043
that it would have been madness for any other even to have contemplated	299.15367313694065
it. It was thus he had succeeded in approaching several times the	219.85542362539445
beautiful and proud Anne of Austria, and in making himself loved by	263.28368559552376
dazzling her.	315.7747673858292
George Villiers placed himself before the glass, as we have said,	320.9665172378271
restored the undulations to his beautiful hair, which the weight of his	247.9377752284004
hat had disordered, twisted his mustache, and, his heart swelling with	205.66463283678434
joy, happy and proud at being near the moment he had so long sighed	294.7393509950342
for, he smiled upon himself with pride and hope.	296.5698460927256
At this moment a door concealed in the tapestry opened, and a woman	214.14643173642634
appeared. Buckingham saw this apparition in the glass; he uttered a	249.09078035676146
cry. It was the queen!	338.40394208175326
Anne of Austria was then twenty-six or twenty-seven years of age; that	326.08439181389997
is to say, she was in the full splendor of her beauty.	346.3298872850754
Her carriage was that of a queen or a goddess; her eyes, which cast the	217.56790091731224
brilliancy of emeralds, were perfectly beautiful, and yet were at the	337.6108167217799
same time full of sweetness and majesty.	239.31641716000783
Her mouth was small and rosy; and although her underlip, like that of	213.73607656373838
all princes of the House of Austria, protruded slightly beyond the	356.2424337526374
other, it was eminently lovely in its smile, but as profoundly	174.15163281690727
disdainful in its contempt.	273.4376126732385
Her skin was admired for its velvety softness; her hands and arms were	329.32656300084966
of surpassing beauty, all the poets of the time singing them as	293.9729383542179
incomparable.	336.72117389719006
Lastly, her hair, which, from being light in her youth, had become	213.48773535203028
chestnut, and which she wore curled very plainly, and with much powder,	197.01149166464097
admirably set off her face, in which the most rigid critic could only	195.37293401088218
have desired a little less rouge, and the most fastidious sculptor a	347.74796983589533
little more fineness in the nose.	339.25560187518084
Buckingham remained for a moment dazzled. Never had Anne of Austria	328.7571700631711
appeared to him so beautiful, amid balls, fêtes, or carousals, as she	218.57970130560898
appeared to him at this moment, dressed in a simple robe of white	285.5617570721978
satin, and accompanied by Donna Estafania—the only one of her Spanish	197.0195013062217
women who had not been driven from her by the jealousy of the king or	176.91352517055216
by the persecutions of Richelieu.	188.9558105205856
Anne of Austria took two steps forward. Buckingham threw himself at her	226.7610887052356
feet, and before the queen could prevent him, kissed the hem of her	339.3406027703527
robe.	184.31228337164376
“Duke, you already know that it is not I who caused you to be written	196.14976980618655
to.”	324.1674173351694
“Yes, yes, madame! Yes, your Majesty!” cried the duke. “I know that I	195.20634685667096
must have been mad, senseless, to believe that snow would become	262.0357833671517
animated or marble warm; but what then! They who love believe easily in	278.9895015562742
love. Besides, I have lost nothing by this journey because I see you.”	183.73588073592978
“Yes,” replied Anne, “but you know why and how I see you; because,	252.11435239368816
insensible to all my sufferings, you persist in remaining in a city	263.7764326493136
where, by remaining, you run the risk of your life, and make me run the	342.6872721077991
risk of my honor. I see you to tell you that everything separates	244.28708751244005
us—the depths of the sea, the enmity of kingdoms, the sanctity of vows.	211.12563265770382
It is sacrilege to struggle against so many things, my Lord. In short,	284.642764536835
I see you to tell you that we must never see each other again.”	217.19220471876102
“Speak on, madame, speak on, Queen,” said Buckingham; “the sweetness of	313.0233141768008
your voice covers the harshness of your words. You talk of sacrilege!	350.93908897490246
Why, the sacrilege is the separation of two hearts formed by God for	247.04609459597563
each other.”	207.5741968624162
“My Lord,” cried the queen, “you forget that I have never said that I	312.1508627444545
love you.”	181.13696191577924
“But you have never told me that you did not love me; and truly, to	195.7110627300865
speak such words to me would be, on the part of your Majesty, too great	260.85797173036735
an ingratitude. For tell me, where can you find a love like mine—a love	306.3036018874203
which neither time, nor absence, nor despair can extinguish, a love	260.4903309437258
which contents itself with a lost ribbon, a stray look, or a chance	224.26387946230298
word? It is now three years, madame, since I saw you for the first	234.1071405859777
time, and during those three years I have loved you thus. Shall I tell	187.91488217661274
you each ornament of your toilet? Mark! I see you now. You were seated	306.8735957829731
upon cushions in the Spanish fashion; you wore a robe of green satin	303.7706949852257
embroidered with gold and silver, hanging sleeves knotted upon your	258.69051587894955
beautiful arms—those lovely arms—with large diamonds. You wore a close	187.05576480938453
ruff, a small cap upon your head of the same color as your robe, and in	265.4534280418311
that cap a heron’s feather. Hold! Hold! I shut my eyes, and I can see	248.67346895480838
you as you then were; I open them again, and I see what you are now—a	214.24931929544962
hundred times more beautiful!”	257.71940035700345
“What folly,” murmured Anne of Austria, who had not the courage to find	186.5485194374926
fault with the duke for having so well preserved her portrait in his	232.96458375251535
heart, “what folly to feed a useless passion with such remembrances!”	219.26119534169777
“And upon what then must I live? I have nothing but memory. It is my	222.47698340815353
happiness, my treasure, my hope. Every time I see you is a fresh	322.7378275830133
diamond which I enclose in the casket of my heart. This is the fourth	325.77709315788735
which you have let fall and I have picked up; for in three years,	187.8420584781211
madame, I have only seen you four times—the first, which I have	282.89053173411935
described to you; the second, at the mansion of Madame de Chevreuse;	195.94401274966478
the third, in the gardens of Amiens.”	334.13561533334735
“Duke,” said the queen, blushing, “never speak of that evening.”	234.2865954082783
“Oh, let us speak of it; on the contrary, let us speak of it! That is	323.71075039078926
the most happy and brilliant evening of my life! You remember what a	186.36918799501944
beautiful night it was? How soft and perfumed was the air; how lovely	235.04734613226066
the blue heavens and star-enameled sky! Ah, then, madame, I was able	200.59494567729678
for one instant to be alone with you. Then you were about to tell me	325.2708193917914
all—the isolation of your life, the griefs of your heart. You leaned	215.63385459933954
upon my arm—upon this, madame! I felt, in bending my head toward you,	199.26128219228292
your beautiful hair touch my cheek; and every time that it touched me I	260.46748365273027
trembled from head to foot. Oh, Queen! Queen! You do not know what	248.40772271435262
felicity from heaven, what joys from paradise, are comprised in a	347.0658416222898
moment like that. Take my wealth, my fortune, my glory, all the days I	305.29535285100656
have to live, for such an instant, for a night like that. For that	323.16677945160757
night, madame, that night you loved me, I will swear it.”	204.89949935000521
“My Lord, yes; it is possible that the influence of the place, the	194.61511998462439
charm of the beautiful evening, the fascination of your look—the	334.400977524964
thousand circumstances, in short, which sometimes unite to destroy a	329.5338191416026
woman—were grouped around me on that fatal evening; but, my Lord, you	355.70341291949285
saw the queen come to the aid of the woman who faltered. At the first	343.39873586068893
word you dared to utter, at the first freedom to which I had to reply,	251.3739728084595
I called for help.”	265.43561658815895
“Yes, yes, that is true. And any other love but mine would have sunk	273.9067181245379
beneath this ordeal; but my love came out from it more ardent and more	220.5441172700629
eternal. You believed that you would fly from me by returning to Paris;	209.52243876897802
you believed that I would not dare to quit the treasure over which my	210.58719705088401
master had charged me to watch. What to me were all the treasures in	280.20641072943675
the world, or all the kings of the earth! Eight days after, I was back	296.264799298365
again, madame. That time you had nothing to say to me; I had risked my	219.82689914071344
life and favor to see you but for a second. I did not even touch your	341.67023050785804
hand, and you pardoned me on seeing me so submissive and so repentant.”	305.01641994086424
“Yes, but calumny seized upon all those follies in which I took no	331.4277868640104
part, as you well know, my Lord. The king, excited by the cardinal,	330.0301769780341
made a terrible clamor. Madame de Vernet was driven from me, Putange	268.1441129068315
was exiled, Madame de Chevreuse fell into disgrace, and when you wished	230.47404197435287
to come back as ambassador to France, the king himself—remember, my	297.82788046737187
lord—the king himself opposed it.”	224.01567864959358
“Yes, and France is about to pay for her king’s refusal with a war. I	355.4838824088624
am not allowed to see you, madame, but you shall every day hear of me.	296.08596802890827
What object, think you, have this expedition to Ré and this league with	350.69896722471697
the Protestants of La Rochelle which I am projecting? The pleasure of	291.1591833790226
seeing you. I have no hope of penetrating, sword in hand, to Paris, I	187.57681548005118
know that well. But this war may bring round a peace; this peace will	227.39174054876048
require a negotiator; that negotiator will be me. They will not dare to	329.18487538372096
refuse me then; and I will return to Paris, and will see you again, and	343.3072940322062
will be happy for an instant. Thousands of men, it is true, will have	232.30678340564623
to pay for my happiness with their lives; but what is that to me,	266.5505178372293
provided I see you again! All this is perhaps folly—perhaps insanity;	172.7494051307002
but tell me what woman has a lover more truly in love; what queen a	238.68957867558692
servant more ardent?”	277.2192424691214
“My Lord, my Lord, you invoke in your defense things which accuse you	209.32798206580543
more strongly. All these proofs of love which you would give me are	175.293394802947
almost crimes.”	359.9474744484387
“Because you do not love me, madame! If you loved me, you would view	194.68897627240332
all this otherwise. If you loved me, oh, if you loved me, that would be	260.04445681791185
too great happiness, and I should run mad. Ah, Madame de Chevreuse was	282.0718711091652
less cruel than you. Holland loved her, and she responded to his love.”	238.08727433720895
“Madame de Chevreuse was not queen,” murmured Anne of Austria,	181.40209389371557
overcome, in spite of herself, by the expression of so profound a	190.7539232938262
passion.	326.25612338623677
“You would love me, then, if you were not queen! Madame, say that you	246.52150583981785
would love me then! I can believe that it is the dignity of your rank	223.65842551677906
alone which makes you cruel to me; I can believe that, had you been	278.9907814499633
Madame de Chevreuse, poor Buckingham might have hoped. Thanks for those	332.35962621192914
sweet words! Oh, my beautiful sovereign, a hundred times, thanks!”	321.0404962289681
“Oh, my Lord! You have ill understood, wrongly interpreted; I did not	178.73437100435325
mean to say—”	286.70820592948985
“Silence, silence!” cried the duke. “If I am happy in an error, do not	343.52412718904486
have the cruelty to lift me from it. You have told me yourself, madame,	299.1088952042106
that I have been drawn into a snare; I, perhaps, may leave my life in	184.647951590623
it—for, although it may be strange, I have for some time had a	353.90705178526053
presentiment that I should shortly die.” And the duke smiled, with a	314.4799317297112
smile at once sad and charming.	343.077782236303
“Oh, my God!” cried Anne of Austria, with an accent of terror which	181.74543778038532
proved how much greater an interest she took in the duke than she	278.0803179276737
ventured to tell.	231.17767992452798
“I do not tell you this, madame, to terrify you; no, it is even	360.2430786954817
ridiculous for me to name it to you, and, believe me, I take no heed of	222.34812279813912
such dreams. But the words you have just spoken, the hope you have	215.23801002888
almost given me, will have richly paid all—were it my life.”	166.54152685904876
“Oh, but I,” said Anne, “I also, duke, have had presentiments; I also	311.5612840621701
have had dreams. I dreamed that I saw you lying bleeding, wounded.”	360.05568549808254
“In the left side, was it not, and with a knife?” interrupted	264.3567331413301
Buckingham.	260.60365193912105
“Yes, it was so, my Lord, it was so—in the left side, and with a knife.	302.3187234759367
Who can possibly have told you I had had that dream? I have imparted it	360.08099678691156
to no one but my God, and that in my prayers.”	329.02814614370817
“I ask for no more. You love me, madame; it is enough.”	187.48071137317783
“I love you, I?”	358.9364320027495
“Yes, yes. Would God send the same dreams to you as to me if you did	172.9889533359559
not love me? Should we have the same presentiments if our existences	227.08862591023146
did not touch at the heart? You love me, my beautiful queen, and you	308.6624618927799
will weep for me?”	242.68064408837895
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Anne of Austria, “this is more than I can	274.9134578925647
bear. In the name of heaven, Duke, leave me, go! I do not know whether	322.2512342431478
I love you or love you not; but what I know is that I will not be	342.26814589838204
perjured. Take pity on me, then, and go! Oh, if you are struck in	352.12879964045715
France, if you die in France, if I could imagine that your love for me	249.5976100492863
was the cause of your death, I could not console myself; I should run	235.26920117565132
mad. Depart then, depart, I implore you!”	359.6019171899147
“Oh, how beautiful you are thus! Oh, how I love you!” said Buckingham.	182.4664449809898
“Go, go, I implore you, and return hereafter! Come back as ambassador,	166.12081661110912
come back as minister, come back surrounded with guards who will defend	282.61674991511086
you, with servants who will watch over you, and then I shall no longer	352.24908647319194
fear for your days, and I shall be happy in seeing you.”	329.1130713203489
“Oh, is this true what you say?”	225.21386328665665
“Yes.”	331.5163080787454
“Oh, then, some pledge of your indulgence, some object which came from	275.5332881905246
you, and may remind me that I have not been dreaming; something you	289.1304170409099
have worn, and that I may wear in my turn—a ring, a necklace, a chain.”	345.54057084907856
“Will you depart—will you depart, if I give you that you demand?”	318.32333018488674
“Yes.”	296.7491717900812
“This very instant?”	264.8705754584388
“Yes.”	349.06910073460006
“You will leave France, you will return to England?”	207.55909394450762
“I will, I swear to you.”	283.9937816381371
“Wait, then, wait.”	273.3526664039333
Anne of Austria re-entered her apartment, and came out again almost	302.2382866086873
immediately, holding a rosewood casket in her hand, with her cipher	208.03408994840052
encrusted with gold.	185.532438310195
“Here, my Lord, here,” said she, “keep this in memory of me.”	280.57803892939967
Buckingham took the casket, and fell a second time on his knees.	341.2975809534304
“You have promised me to go,” said the queen.	294.123752986441
“And I keep my word. Your hand, madame, your hand, and I depart!”	252.26471502520022
Anne of Austria stretched forth her hand, closing her eyes, and leaning	344.15908340865155
with the other upon Estafania, for she felt that her strength was about	250.6254941718792
to fail her.	330.84732176808353
Buckingham pressed his lips passionately to that beautiful hand, and	199.80839829688722
then rising, said, “Within six months, if I am not dead, I shall have	311.7995736792736
seen you again, madame—even if I have to overturn the world.” And	261.6214001605547
faithful to the promise he had made, he rushed out of the apartment.	275.43165341743816
In the corridor he met Mme. Bonacieux, who waited for him, and who,	277.2077927807238
with the same precautions and the same good luck, conducted him out of	300.34702513852983
the Louvre.	243.95688311478182
Chapter XIII.	204.49739461131782
MONSIEUR BONACIEUX	203.2433968345563
There was in all this, as may have been observed, one personage	365.078333172664
concerned, of whom, notwithstanding his precarious position, we have	324.3268104660589
appeared to take but very little notice. This personage was M.	302.52738720884827
Bonacieux, the respectable martyr of the political and amorous	227.7575450555647
intrigues which entangled themselves so nicely together at this gallant	227.18610538159135
and chivalric period.	358.4922768560682
Fortunately, the reader may remember, or may not remember—fortunately	359.6360816092426
we have promised not to lose sight of him.	289.6161894277149
The officers who arrested him conducted him straight to the Bastille,	274.3716612277542
where he passed trembling before a party of soldiers who were loading	351.49920497590267
their muskets. Thence, introduced into a half-subterranean gallery, he	271.6650912169898
became, on the part of those who had brought him, the object of the	343.37624113444235
grossest insults and the harshest treatment. The officers perceived	324.9897085960961
that they had not to deal with a gentleman, and they treated him like a	230.11216498375092
very peasant.	169.25226965881274
At the end of half an hour or thereabouts, a clerk came to put an end	263.5919934978527
to his tortures, but not to his anxiety, by giving the order to conduct	323.1266336734858
M. Bonacieux to the Chamber of Examination. Ordinarily, prisoners were	360.96139862461666
interrogated in their cells; but they did not do so with M. Bonacieux.	212.90447042004152
Two guards attended the mercer who made him traverse a court and enter	347.29933335170995
a corridor in which were three sentinels, opened a door and pushed him	332.1622474711923
unceremoniously into a low room, where the only furniture was a table,	178.2338647573835
a chair, and a commissary. The commissary was seated in the chair, and	213.28028805141864
was writing at the table.	334.68235079184484
The two guards led the prisoner toward the table, and upon a sign from	193.06112409902022
the commissary drew back so far as to be unable to hear anything.	260.12209643009504
The commissary, who had till this time held his head down over his	298.40148082394774
papers, looked up to see what sort of person he had to do with. This	332.3892882258581
commissary was a man of very repulsive mien, with a pointed nose, with	227.46584697226098
yellow and salient cheek bones, with eyes small but keen and	243.02691487194076
penetrating, and an expression of countenance resembling at once the	220.5572239405832
polecat and the fox. His head, supported by a long and flexible neck,	262.814490633579
issued from his large black robe, balancing itself with a motion very	222.7603982755868
much like that of the tortoise thrusting his head out of his shell. He	256.6110573736271
began by asking M. Bonacieux his name, age, condition, and abode.	216.40967849585792
The accused replied that his name was Jacques Michel Bonacieux, that he	246.97557323956642
was fifty-one years old, a retired mercer, and lived Rue des	342.0975041655506
Fossoyeurs, No. 14.	206.48037465258835
The commissary then, instead of continuing to interrogate him, made him	323.2145474750958
a long speech upon the danger there is for an obscure citizen to meddle	182.9664630820161
with public matters. He complicated this exordium by an exposition in	173.01206264973183
which he painted the power and the deeds of the cardinal, that	214.0101060651291
incomparable minister, that conqueror of past ministers, that example	313.704136419206
for ministers to come—deeds and power which none could thwart with	258.2837692116936
impunity.	300.8373040169295
After this second part of his discourse, fixing his hawk’s eye upon	306.92238776102977
poor Bonacieux, he bade him reflect upon the gravity of his situation.	175.2383702803079
The reflections of the mercer were already made; he cursed the instant	205.10694279305125
when M. Laporte formed the idea of marrying him to his goddaughter, and	344.8234407025255
particularly the moment when that goddaughter had been received as Lady	254.52435241379277
of the Linen to her Majesty.	214.47278248140356
At bottom the character of M. Bonacieux was one of profound selfishness	308.2023036449419
mixed with sordid avarice, the whole seasoned with extreme cowardice.	353.6176237959089
The love with which his young wife had inspired him was a secondary	296.84016478161755
sentiment, and was not strong enough to contend with the primitive	189.6947380370874
feelings we have just enumerated. Bonacieux indeed reflected on what	253.52396594690322
had just been said to him.	253.71182955076574
“But, Monsieur Commissary,” said he, calmly, “believe that I know and	284.4696474819483
appreciate, more than anybody, the merit of the incomparable eminence	260.45258053649326
by whom we have the honor to be governed.”	359.71823253275335
“Indeed?” asked the commissary, with an air of doubt. “If that is	337.87558511921634
really so, how came you in the Bastille?”	167.7896791590737
“How I came there, or rather why I am there,” replied Bonacieux, “that	273.5714039724318
is entirely impossible for me to tell you, because I don’t know myself;	323.91195668524165
but to a certainty it is not for having, knowingly at least, disobliged	174.65782594372044
Monsieur the Cardinal.”	300.33855080171804
“You must, nevertheless, have committed a crime, since you are here and	352.6118998780591
are accused of high treason.”	257.30327723201293
“Of high treason!” cried Bonacieux, terrified; “of high treason! How is	248.75745375861186
it possible for a poor mercer, who detests Huguenots and who abhors	186.64988350012592
Spaniards, to be accused of high treason? Consider, monsieur, the thing	220.6356214758714
is absolutely impossible.”	289.5012303905495
“Monsieur Bonacieux,” said the commissary, looking at the accused as if	299.8961941529538
his little eyes had the faculty of reading to the very depths of	168.18219682959668
hearts, “you have a wife?”	287.89345498823144
“Yes, monsieur,” replied the mercer, in a tremble, feeling that it was	289.5531387304509
at this point affairs were likely to become perplexing; “that is to	230.37926779794768
say, I _had_ one.”	302.7791041480418
“What, you ‘_had_ one’? What have you done with her, then, if you have	182.37490909264878
her no longer?”	302.9147917122649
“They have abducted her, monsieur.”	277.92710422225366
“They have abducted her? Ah!”	281.29590387366005
Bonacieux inferred from this “Ah” that the affair grew more and more	263.2439281181712
intricate.	305.55623646673143
“They have abducted her,” added the commissary; “and do you know the	181.30190842078903
man who has committed this deed?”	271.9200425813576
“I think I know him.”	310.20994100377254
“Who is he?”	360.2116172765603
“Remember that I affirm nothing, Monsieur the Commissary, and that I	209.22125546881344
only suspect.”	230.70560325750233
“Whom do you suspect? Come, answer freely.”	267.68087802499906
