M. Bonacieux was in the greatest perplexity possible. Had he better	325.82687182656036
deny everything or tell everything? By denying all, it might be	174.6664004819164
suspected that he must know too much to avow; by confessing all he	167.10955092555574
might prove his good will. He decided, then, to tell all.	342.89202567253153
“I suspect,” said he, “a tall, dark man, of lofty carriage, who has the	212.620955322001
air of a great lord. He has followed us several times, as I think, when	247.65043818726778
I have waited for my wife at the wicket of the Louvre to escort her	214.2572670182109
home.”	218.79824065872242
The commissary now appeared to experience a little uneasiness.	181.0521989047086
“And his name?” said he.	302.8697229264543
“Oh, as to his name, I know nothing about it; but if I were ever to	232.71811719944023
meet him, I should recognize him in an instant, I will answer for it,	256.1972451355699
were he among a thousand persons.”	240.57358272073827
The face of the commissary grew still darker.	274.4619459823772
“You should recognize him among a thousand, say you?” continued he.	292.0794044312122
“That is to say,” cried Bonacieux, who saw he had taken a false step,	340.282395462007
“that is to say—”	262.91900596277674
“You have answered that you should recognize him,” said the commissary.	254.96579488666794
“That is all very well, and enough for today; before we proceed	249.6799616396941
further, someone must be informed that you know the ravisher of your	306.5034381796598
wife.”	240.129944252522
“But I have not told you that I know him!” cried Bonacieux, in despair.	246.94679756742443
“I told you, on the contrary—”	238.64403531873336
“Take away the prisoner,” said the commissary to the two guards.	174.25088768439878
“Where must we place him?” demanded the chief.	352.895770125043
“In a dungeon.”	217.84622157891027
“Which?”	336.1895574229762
“Good Lord! In the first one handy, provided it is safe,” said the	173.08563616685035
commissary, with an indifference which penetrated poor Bonacieux with	336.92557362979903
horror.	281.0813664415123
“Alas, alas!” said he to himself, “misfortune is over my head; my wife	323.16093243135094
must have committed some frightful crime. They believe me her	203.55543531504722
accomplice, and will punish me with her. She must have spoken; she must	236.238936686915
have confessed everything—a woman is so weak! A dungeon! The first he	274.87794086017175
comes to! That’s it! A night is soon passed; and tomorrow to the wheel,	217.92924735827472
to the gallows! Oh, my God, my God, have pity on me!”	255.009380595216
Without listening the least in the world to the lamentations of M.	195.43796153520236
Bonacieux—lamentations to which, besides, they must have been pretty	212.2633324930377
well accustomed—the two guards took the prisoner each by an arm, and	345.9623889239142
led him away, while the commissary wrote a letter in haste and	275.16381755439295
dispatched it by an officer in waiting.	175.03410562761974
Bonacieux could not close his eyes; not because his dungeon was so very	232.19617092617182
disagreeable, but because his uneasiness was so great. He sat all night	189.6235260661544
on his stool, starting at the least noise; and when the first rays of	314.7121454505771
the sun penetrated into his chamber, the dawn itself appeared to him to	331.04316618586756
have taken funereal tints.	174.1779502006202
All at once he heard his bolts drawn, and made a terrified bound. He	209.11613829687374
believed they were come to conduct him to the scaffold; so that when he	353.2492614531615
saw merely and simply, instead of the executioner he expected, only his	255.52817757249704
commissary of the preceding evening, attended by his clerk, he was	174.90580481227744
ready to embrace them both.	338.76804410257375
“Your affair has become more complicated since yesterday evening, my	175.11448375003414
good man, and I advise you to tell the whole truth; for your repentance	166.7734886568982
alone can remove the anger of the cardinal.”	335.8100664194467
“Why, I am ready to tell everything,” cried Bonacieux, “at least, all	306.005814152221
that I know. Interrogate me, I entreat you!”	168.01285574323745
“Where is your wife, in the first place?”	170.61139773364147
“Why, did not I tell you she had been stolen from me?”	271.086024696247
“Yes, but yesterday at five o’clock in the afternoon, thanks to you,	293.9749489876368
she escaped.”	201.1355556170743
“My wife escaped!” cried Bonacieux. “Oh, unfortunate creature!	262.74404346772974
Monsieur, if she has escaped, it is not my fault, I swear.”	285.8924457528709
“What business had you, then, to go into the chamber of Monsieur	332.2650297337574
d’Artagnan, your neighbor, with whom you had a long conference during	337.8745361875512
the day?”	184.84965987293208
“Ah, yes, Monsieur Commissary; yes, that is true, and I confess that I	283.8310035345205
was in the wrong. I did go to Monsieur d’Artagnan’s.”	343.70681523681776
“What was the aim of that visit?”	253.36483862284814
“To beg him to assist me in finding my wife. I believed I had a right	254.21314975932881
to endeavor to find her. I was deceived, as it appears, and I ask your	343.3711302410505
pardon.”	233.84076190637518
“And what did Monsieur d’Artagnan reply?”	322.9244518888895
“Monsieur d’Artagnan promised me his assistance; but I soon found out	200.96424679611073
that he was betraying me.”	258.6844429935644
“You impose upon justice. Monsieur d’Artagnan made a compact with you;	287.5521490973861
and in virtue of that compact put to flight the police who had arrested	249.69582604850456
your wife, and has placed her beyond reach.”	260.01938572959006
“M. d’Artagnan has abducted my wife! Come now, what are you telling	308.56140755504003
me?”	210.71300957112183
“Fortunately, Monsieur d’Artagnan is in our hands, and you shall be	200.41779774824522
confronted with him.”	270.5024177311129
“By my faith, I ask no better,” cried Bonacieux; “I shall not be sorry	228.92907435777633
to see the face of an acquaintance.”	288.5469731488799
“Bring in the Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said the commissary to the guards.	239.67526376322974
The two guards led in Athos.	299.47641017806995
“Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said the commissary, addressing Athos, “declare	342.48186332842255
all that passed yesterday between you and Monsieur.”	246.66827747969637
“But,” cried Bonacieux, “this is not Monsieur d’Artagnan whom you show	237.7420713696182
me.”	291.3929843630849
“What! Not Monsieur d’Artagnan?” exclaimed the commissary.	255.81602545091152
“Not the least in the world,” replied Bonacieux.	331.44068672646705
“What is this gentleman’s name?” asked the commissary.	302.4376143644605
“I cannot tell you; I don’t know him.”	248.07804957419899
“How! You don’t know him?”	365.69500875503655
“No.”	280.84879448079573
“Did you never see him?”	194.81194999234154
“Yes, I have seen him, but I don’t know what he calls himself.”	210.60076059785357
“Your name?” replied the commissary.	213.54090721075232
“Athos,” replied the Musketeer.	264.08629603388755
“But that is not a man’s name; that is the name of a mountain,” cried	273.89538234048524
the poor questioner, who began to lose his head.	332.6096222111429
“That is my name,” said Athos, quietly.	258.8229211090441
“But you said that your name was D’Artagnan.”	361.20138942418646
“Who, I?”	302.8139064100262
“Yes, you.”	291.2534000604696
“Somebody said to me, ‘You are Monsieur d’Artagnan?’ I answered, ‘You	361.8602679846067
think so?’ My guards exclaimed that they were sure of it. I did not	214.64091974711897
wish to contradict them; besides, I might be deceived.”	316.2215160500997
“Monsieur, you insult the majesty of justice.”	287.62691898192236
“Not at all,” said Athos, calmly.	250.57527443597178
“You are Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	175.8312911882619
“You see, monsieur, that you say it again.”	184.47570892650367
“But I tell you, Monsieur Commissary,” cried Bonacieux, in his turn,	286.93961944509033
“there is not the least doubt about the matter. Monsieur d’Artagnan is	260.6782447573637
my tenant, although he does not pay me my rent—and even better on that	279.1884190687579
account ought I to know him. Monsieur d’Artagnan is a young man,	224.96964883671032
scarcely nineteen or twenty, and this gentleman must be thirty at	195.71404333458722
least. Monsieur d’Artagnan is in Monsieur Dessessart’s Guards, and this	237.87610605748807
gentleman is in the company of Monsieur de Tréville’s Musketeers. Look	233.56879379765098
at his uniform, Monsieur Commissary, look at his uniform!”	191.14618403964425
“That’s true,” murmured the commissary; “_pardieu_, that’s true.”	247.66954911889815
At this moment the door was opened quickly, and a messenger, introduced	308.5870974501228
by one of the gatekeepers of the Bastille, gave a letter to the	228.70139481068736
commissary.	168.23407804734757
“Oh, unhappy woman!” cried the commissary.	214.39765773580302
“How? What do you say? Of whom do you speak? It is not of my wife, I	167.92401232837656
hope!”	354.4895000451713
“On the contrary, it is of her. Yours is a pretty business.”	225.3414723909757
“But,” said the agitated mercer, “do me the pleasure, monsieur, to tell	220.9521262099079
me how my own proper affair can become worse by anything my wife does	361.9671642717765
while I am in prison?”	365.7092556080647
“Because that which she does is part of a plan concerted between you—of	235.53970044520406
an infernal plan.”	301.2968548764306
“I swear to you, Monsieur Commissary, that you are in the profoundest	302.1390476530539
error, that I know nothing in the world about what my wife had to do,	190.16760296937372
that I am entirely a stranger to what she has done; and that if she has	208.85473368744596
committed any follies, I renounce her, I abjure her, I curse her!”	259.8947816133268
“Bah!” said Athos to the commissary, “if you have no more need of me,	310.63578527916894
send me somewhere. Your Monsieur Bonacieux is very tiresome.”	225.8052001211943
The commissary designated by the same gesture Athos and Bonacieux, “Let	226.52384910196992
them be guarded more closely than ever.”	231.6570744654454
“And yet,” said Athos, with his habitual calmness, “if it be Monsieur	240.35912233340804
d’Artagnan who is concerned in this matter, I do not perceive how I can	258.6124069715932
take his place.”	183.8983569080652
“Do as I bade you,” cried the commissary, “and preserve absolute	303.0807431413919
secrecy. You understand!”	290.83329371019107
Athos shrugged his shoulders, and followed his guards silently, while	307.1974919137437
M. Bonacieux uttered lamentations enough to break the heart of a tiger.	197.30712730639445
They locked the mercer in the same dungeon where he had passed the	219.64606768335906
night, and left him to himself during the day. Bonacieux wept all day,	342.45340806746844
like a true mercer, not being at all a military man, as he himself	261.8527116086486
informed us. In the evening, about nine o’clock, at the moment he had	230.10351008178128
made up his mind to go to bed, he heard steps in his corridor. These	285.12662016386236
steps drew near to his dungeon, the door was thrown open, and the	190.0902396215444
guards appeared.	299.28218943243223
“Follow me,” said an officer, who came up behind the guards.	289.4681810715975
“Follow you!” cried Bonacieux, “follow you at this hour! Where, my	363.49376460742536
God?”	211.97971106722707
“Where we have orders to lead you.”	194.22507748390956
“But that is not an answer.”	284.8581344656279
“It is, nevertheless, the only one we can give.”	359.0377685801925
“Ah, my God, my God!” murmured the poor mercer, “now, indeed, I am	241.48706604606568
lost!” And he followed the guards who came for him, mechanically and	175.81886937358087
without resistance.	320.1395689274161
He passed along the same corridor as before, crossed one court, then a	326.6273682156773
second side of a building; at length, at the gate of the entrance court	318.77327343612023
he found a carriage surrounded by four guards on horseback. They made	343.92289664789854
him enter this carriage, the officer placed himself by his side, the	258.4861848308533
door was locked, and they were left in a rolling prison. The carriage	258.930685069149
was put in motion as slowly as a funeral car. Through the closely	344.8562215502494
fastened windows the prisoner could perceive the houses and the	355.49239090918775
pavement, that was all; but, true Parisian as he was, Bonacieux could	302.3830907474886
recognize every street by the milestones, the signs, and the lamps. At	183.0494985142832
the moment of arriving at St. Paul—the spot where such as were	247.31541147955951
condemned at the Bastille were executed—he was near fainting and	275.77233591767026
crossed himself twice. He thought the carriage was about to stop there.	285.42503739371807
The carriage, however, passed on.	356.56593459753594
Farther on, a still greater terror seized him on passing by the	343.9508007054218
cemetery of St. Jean, where state criminals were buried. One thing,	193.47374946730875
however, reassured him; he remembered that before they were buried	208.3500539269213
their heads were generally cut off, and he felt that his head was still	327.406607550592
on his shoulders. But when he saw the carriage take the way to La	194.84831308843889
Grêve, when he perceived the pointed roof of the Hôtel de Ville, and	270.76628842567266
the carriage passed under the arcade, he believed it was over with him.	318.3741799056686
He wished to confess to the officer, and upon his refusal, uttered such	350.7472296187299
pitiable cries that the officer told him that if he continued to deafen	320.20786881204526
him thus, he should put a gag in his mouth.	319.8552946116652
This measure somewhat reassured Bonacieux. If they meant to execute him	334.4205937911483
at La Grêve, it could scarcely be worth while to gag him, as they had	180.43867498974365
nearly reached the place of execution. Indeed, the carriage crossed the	364.5816299662964
fatal spot without stopping. There remained, then, no other place to	166.52636894077577
fear but the Traitor’s Cross; the carriage was taking the direct road	350.5228992839387
to it.	199.06789346152485
This time there was no longer any doubt; it was at the Traitor’s Cross	168.4424098484327
that lesser criminals were executed. Bonacieux had flattered himself in	333.32104303811246
believing himself worthy of St. Paul or of the Place de Grêve; it was	226.60263269398374
at the Traitor’s Cross that his journey and his destiny were about to	180.50964273606309
end! He could not yet see that dreadful cross, but he felt somehow as	213.02188716687766
if it were coming to meet him. When he was within twenty paces of it,	279.5174669131306
he heard a noise of people and the carriage stopped. This was more than	221.6511388176552
poor Bonacieux could endure, depressed as he was by the successive	168.95548428492097
emotions which he had experienced; he uttered a feeble groan which	193.430736796266
might have been taken for the last sigh of a dying man, and fainted.	277.48087639667733
Chapter XIV.	276.1532515544932
THE MAN OF MEUNG	250.75659370791485
The crowd was caused, not by the expectation of a man to be hanged, but	354.49875017763816
by the contemplation of a man who was hanged.	191.30760580340524
The carriage, which had been stopped for a minute, resumed its way,	272.7459088962173
passed through the crowd, threaded the Rue St. Honoré, turned into the	272.77067850436896
Rue des Bons Enfants, and stopped before a low door.	241.35442165152384
The door opened; two guards received Bonacieux in their arms from the	197.6462718112935
officer who supported him. They carried him through an alley, up a	252.34888448616098
flight of stairs, and deposited him in an antechamber.	227.8732636544513
All these movements had been effected mechanically, as far as he was	207.7427775771781
concerned. He had walked as one walks in a dream; he had a glimpse of	266.6894702773924
objects as through a fog. His ears had perceived sounds without	350.3941052460906
comprehending them; he might have been executed at that moment without	177.22386530885458
his making a single gesture in his own defense or uttering a cry to	293.22601655976143
implore mercy.	337.8395682112151
He remained on the bench, with his back leaning against the wall and	307.58494419909493
his hands hanging down, exactly on the spot where the guards placed	202.40705111181128
him.	167.1241477911123
On looking around him, however, as he could perceive no threatening	213.50687467906232
object, as nothing indicated that he ran any real danger, as the bench	293.2503846462929
was comfortably covered with a well-stuffed cushion, as the wall was	210.66588590469345
ornamented with a beautiful Cordova leather, and as large red damask	203.35022875232957
curtains, fastened back by gold clasps, floated before the window, he	220.72372110892746
perceived by degrees that his fear was exaggerated, and he began to	284.9385217907088
turn his head to the right and the left, upward and downward.	213.63985296564815
At this movement, which nobody opposed, he resumed a little courage,	297.4420243646649
and ventured to draw up one leg and then the other. At length, with the	235.4406220908886
help of his two hands he lifted himself from the bench, and found	316.97649051342637
himself on his feet.	342.2133006891346
At this moment an officer with a pleasant face opened a door, continued	284.64267700569695
to exchange some words with a person in the next chamber and then came	242.28553979004008
up to the prisoner. “Is your name Bonacieux?” said he.	204.43501062593663
“Yes, Monsieur Officer,” stammered the mercer, more dead than alive,	346.8476922671583
“at your service.”	301.23426270885193
“Come in,” said the officer.	274.92194317618254
And he moved out of the way to let the mercer pass. The latter obeyed	219.7204929164591
without reply, and entered the chamber, where he appeared to be	260.7398558379251
expected.	218.3040741095566
It was a large cabinet, close and stifling, with the walls furnished	243.38426055374077
with arms offensive and defensive, and in which there was already a	314.1097441185156
fire, although it was scarcely the end of the month of September. A	300.98930044643134
square table, covered with books and papers, upon which was unrolled an	307.8777541365978
immense plan of the city of La Rochelle, occupied the center of the	308.2664446764896
room.	319.99988735050596
Standing before the chimney was a man of middle height, of a haughty,	268.11197705363304
proud mien; with piercing eyes, a large brow, and a thin face, which	178.94197080371634
was made still longer by a _royal_ (or _imperial_, as it is now	192.227684323267
called), surmounted by a pair of mustaches. Although this man was	358.90390454714236
scarcely thirty-six or thirty-seven years of age, hair, mustaches, and	210.72076364471326
royal, all began to be gray. This man, except a sword, had all the	206.89532376453946
appearance of a soldier; and his buff boots, still slightly covered	263.37345238649874
with dust, indicated that he had been on horseback in the course of the	252.35758025288908
day.	221.94378608330874
This man was Armand Jean Duplessis, Cardinal de Richelieu; not such as	297.14032147651227
he is now represented—broken down like an old man, suffering like a	218.54786386109095
martyr, his body bent, his voice failing, buried in a large armchair as	190.043760936185
in an anticipated tomb; no longer living but by the strength of his	360.23132948182797
genius, and no longer maintaining the struggle with Europe but by the	202.23200276814845
eternal application of his thoughts—but such as he really was at this	244.63339380788597
period; that is to say, an active and gallant cavalier, already weak of	324.6674544979314
body, but sustained by that moral power which made of him one of the	259.2366949765611
most extraordinary men that ever lived, preparing, after having	308.46278288468704
supported the Duc de Nevers in his duchy of Mantua, after having taken	304.12284722356924
Nîmes, Castres, and Uzes, to drive the English from the Isle of Ré and	330.2628615418806
lay siege to La Rochelle.	231.28620297968698
At first sight, nothing denoted the cardinal; and it was impossible for	217.19879363895149
those who did not know his face to guess in whose presence they were.	258.6611007886455
The poor mercer remained standing at the door, while the eyes of the	223.01123601660146
personage we have just described were fixed upon him, and appeared to	278.6590113210148
wish to penetrate even into the depths of the past.	353.5684803643671
“Is this that Bonacieux?” asked he, after a moment of silence.	333.47521601010124
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the officer.	236.79028289407785
“That’s well. Give me those papers, and leave us.”	208.1159126170945
The officer took from the table the papers pointed out, gave them to	229.42833185417774
him who asked for them, bowed to the ground, and retired.	284.10110390658116
Bonacieux recognized in these papers his interrogatories of the	215.0715408786601
Bastille. From time to time the man by the chimney raised his eyes from	348.0060619919309
the writings, and plunged them like poniards into the heart of the poor	246.77882185427984
mercer.	221.19701030181153
At the end of ten minutes of reading and ten seconds of examination,	344.55695998200446
the cardinal was satisfied.	251.764410423008
“That head has never conspired,” murmured he, “but it matters not; we	221.36953314802213
will see.”	275.786041752419
“You are accused of high treason,” said the cardinal, slowly.	201.35599474409108
“So I have been told already, monseigneur,” cried Bonacieux, giving his	238.22864232369375
interrogator the title he had heard the officer give him, “but I swear	307.75763909585083
to you that I know nothing about it.”	250.03833325816979
The cardinal repressed a smile.	198.69051267969715
“You have conspired with your wife, with Madame de Chevreuse, and with	273.74109697706484
my Lord Duke of Buckingham.”	357.52877076832533
“Indeed, monseigneur,” responded the mercer, “I have heard her	231.40764678935895
pronounce all those names.”	290.65936079021185
“And on what occasion?”	287.57003810532194
“She said that the Cardinal de Richelieu had drawn the Duke of	235.4973829994679
Buckingham to Paris to ruin him and to ruin the queen.”	206.2020910266795
“She said that?” cried the cardinal, with violence.	203.4372078393551
“Yes, monseigneur, but I told her she was wrong to talk about such	259.50011885727935
things; and that his Eminence was incapable—”	193.7276943295433
“Hold your tongue! You are stupid,” replied the cardinal.	338.02446846805015
“That’s exactly what my wife said, monseigneur.”	270.8721159212148
“Do you know who carried off your wife?”	190.84413916877546
“No, monseigneur.”	220.0989091812272
“You have suspicions, nevertheless?”	196.8970327678225
“Yes, monseigneur; but these suspicions appeared to be disagreeable to	293.11025870751024
Monsieur the Commissary, and I no longer have them.”	220.0997065545946
“Your wife has escaped. Did you know that?”	312.84661049087714
“No, monseigneur. I learned it since I have been in prison, and that	210.88642248692022
from the conversation of Monsieur the Commissary—an amiable man.”	299.64042695717046
The cardinal repressed another smile.	339.4347872683018
“Then you are ignorant of what has become of your wife since her	175.26347765132516
flight.”	239.70859037788654
“Absolutely, monseigneur; but she has most likely returned to the	310.46629363021447
Louvre.”	252.43918959358385
“At one o’clock this morning she had not returned.”	356.6200435523058
“My God! What can have become of her, then?”	258.12727922726367
“We shall know, be assured. Nothing is concealed from the cardinal; the	275.50830981661204
cardinal knows everything.”	203.42723263675393
“In that case, monseigneur, do you believe the cardinal will be so kind	338.50578553672506
as to tell me what has become of my wife?”	282.499954565857
“Perhaps he may; but you must, in the first place, reveal to the	365.85164954544155
cardinal all you know of your wife’s relations with Madame de	308.479422122411
Chevreuse.”	286.30418239083133
“But, monseigneur, I know nothing about them; I have never seen her.”	278.90032288848977
“When you went to fetch your wife from the Louvre, did you always	204.51960464219516
return directly home?”	285.52247339836026
“Scarcely ever; she had business to transact with linen drapers, to	187.16640708326497
whose houses I conducted her.”	276.7266547340371
“And how many were there of these linen drapers?”	304.1740442974368
“Two, monseigneur.”	347.03610577263146
“And where did they live?”	324.173204989708
“One in Rue de Vaugirard, the other Rue de la Harpe.”	349.29865776680197
“Did you go into these houses with her?”	234.64024703855102
“Never, monseigneur; I waited at the door.”	186.052399623638
“And what excuse did she give you for entering all alone?”	354.2811936407967
“She gave me none; she told me to wait, and I waited.”	309.2627382715992
“You are a very complacent husband, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux,” said	181.95893120480721
the cardinal.	199.333821727888
“He calls me his dear Monsieur,” said the mercer to himself. “_Peste!_	180.0246572614902
Matters are going all right.”	184.7093171695506
“Should you know those doors again?”	309.5023198806225
“Yes.”	353.7670247636367
“Do you know the numbers?”	181.2890673805877
“Yes.”	289.3990731988913
“What are they?”	181.66294910133263
“No. 25 in the Rue de Vaugirard; 75 in the Rue de la Harpe.”	251.91311050595849
“That’s well,” said the cardinal.	313.360995905138
At these words he took up a silver bell, and rang it; the officer	270.3926316920749
entered.	365.66355868625806
“Go,” said he, in a subdued voice, “and find Rochefort. Tell him to	321.42745095466944
come to me immediately, if he has returned.”	259.32965615566064
“The count is here,” said the officer, “and requests to speak with your	359.6964283739676
Eminence instantly.”	229.9912610892928
“Let him come in, then!” said the cardinal, quickly.	362.6295948974762
The officer sprang out of the apartment with that alacrity which all	252.6221135831519
the servants of the cardinal displayed in obeying him.	244.50849670871332
“To your Eminence!” murmured Bonacieux, rolling his eyes round in	331.18013384420146
astonishment.	267.80073081287355
Five seconds has scarcely elapsed after the disappearance of the	223.7805675836713
officer, when the door opened, and a new personage entered.	206.82910373695853
“It is he!” cried Bonacieux.	216.90945245351077
“He! What he?” asked the cardinal.	177.0826920557562
“The man who abducted my wife.”	250.88169189005342
The cardinal rang a second time. The officer reappeared.	282.4633296923636
“Place this man in the care of his guards again, and let him wait till	231.03730039292623
I send for him.”	320.79662191726874
“No, monseigneur, no, it is not he!” cried Bonacieux; “no, I was	297.7461823682571
deceived. This is quite another man, and does not resemble him at all.	299.32718394051335
Monsieur is, I am sure, an honest man.”	206.96579088878434
“Take away that fool!” said the cardinal.	223.18395560931907
The officer took Bonacieux by the arm, and led him into the	206.55099104574887
antechamber, where he found his two guards.	217.04472518023982
The newly introduced personage followed Bonacieux impatiently with his	266.3484265472947
eyes till he had gone out; and the moment the door closed, “They have	235.55509355489528
seen each other;” said he, approaching the cardinal eagerly.	171.202707813635
“Who?” asked his Eminence.	170.9940931120374
“He and she.”	247.47837479793293
“The queen and the duke?” cried Richelieu.	227.64021893611942
“Yes.”	181.80651079243995
“Where?”	214.24533595942626
“At the Louvre.”	235.8077561498543
“Are you sure of it?”	200.28083548811853
“Perfectly sure.”	338.95979621327155
“Who told you of it?”	365.66738424565864
“Madame de Lannoy, who is devoted to your Eminence, as you know.”	259.758208108307
“Why did she not let me know sooner?”	345.874721010857
“Whether by chance or mistrust, the queen made Madame de Surgis sleep	174.64814890853697
in her chamber, and detained her all day.”	272.69990462266605
“Well, we are beaten! Now let us try to take our revenge.”	240.59463297025957
“I will assist you with all my heart, monseigneur; be assured of that.”	287.2806955179988
“How did it come about?”	167.3607888527211
“At half past twelve the queen was with her women—”	267.3828163447539
“Where?”	282.11781531099115
“In her bedchamber—”	285.0419886883959
“Go on.”	287.53648937948964
“When someone came and brought her a handkerchief from her laundress.”	187.17791046520838
“And then?”	295.84800819259834
“The queen immediately exhibited strong emotion; and despite the rouge	321.3756971025715
with which her face was covered evidently turned pale—”	236.50173305026965
“And then, and then?”	242.27083238493123
“She then arose, and with altered voice, ‘Ladies,’ said she, ‘wait for	337.337841816068
me ten minutes, I shall soon return.’ She then opened the door of her	344.6671319001065
alcove, and went out.”	258.86427423758033
“Why did not Madame de Lannoy come and inform you instantly?”	208.0006049661988
“Nothing was certain; besides, her Majesty had said, ‘Ladies, wait for	267.16060309068723
me,’ and she did not dare to disobey the queen.”	322.01632439179946
“How long did the queen remain out of the chamber?”	316.75863605775436
“Three-quarters of an hour.”	178.8852444158299
“None of her women accompanied her?”	348.8241606923193
“Only Donna Estafania.”	352.96580662965755
“Did she afterward return?”	190.88866703164862
“Yes; but only to take a little rosewood casket, with her cipher upon	287.64496371467703
it, and went out again immediately.”	198.3845047048862
“And when she finally returned, did she bring that casket with her?”	266.70319178262315
“No.”	302.557884014882
“Does Madame de Lannoy know what was in that casket?”	280.3036249974626
“Yes; the diamond studs which his Majesty gave the queen.”	224.88594741025534
“And she came back without this casket?”	255.2215275349159
“Yes.”	324.91275492365855
“Madame de Lannoy, then, is of opinion that she gave them to	192.01552691184793
Buckingham?”	361.67241958577495
“She is sure of it.”	347.61904035201314
“How can she be so?”	180.6085416073872
“In the course of the day Madame de Lannoy, in her quality of	230.7742584109618
tire-woman of the queen, looked for this casket, appeared uneasy at not	269.5286454405705
finding it, and at length asked information of the queen.”	220.4474430689229
“And then the queen?”	231.73284029183918
“The queen became exceedingly red, and replied that having in the	218.4514643541724
evening broken one of those studs, she had sent it to her goldsmith to	200.10970358358597
be repaired.”	181.84037080496606
“He must be called upon, and so ascertain if the thing be true or not.”	214.94957384369968
“I have just been with him.”	191.71603337777537
“And the goldsmith?”	175.1396364077381
“The goldsmith has heard nothing of it.”	261.98432726179016
“Well, well! Rochefort, all is not lost; and perhaps—perhaps everything	173.91500138109785
is for the best.”	322.02966692304955
“The fact is that I do not doubt your Eminence’s genius—”	169.9349707539909
“Will repair the blunders of his agent—is that it?”	321.3503004885491
“That is exactly what I was going to say, if your Eminence had let me	365.2056845848292
finish my sentence.”	351.25855197255055
“Meanwhile, do you know where the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of	245.89244854303757
Buckingham are now concealed?”	234.4417473619942
“No, monseigneur; my people could tell me nothing on that head.”	302.8895689748675
“But I know.”	330.38517540073934
“You, monseigneur?”	214.41254924986995
“Yes; or at least I guess. They were, one in the Rue de Vaugirard, No.	231.0792371483617
25; the other in the Rue de la Harpe, No. 75.”	317.4704633880521
“Does your Eminence command that they both be instantly arrested?”	246.07463407578803
“It will be too late; they will be gone.”	194.19068593768213
“But still, we can make sure that they are so.”	314.06647976791817
“Take ten men of my Guardsmen, and search the two houses thoroughly.”	310.5152792128436
“Instantly, monseigneur.” And Rochefort went hastily out of the	353.7136763432526
apartment.	230.58696997913853
The cardinal, being left alone, reflected for an instant and then rang	269.3202849363881
the bell a third time. The same officer appeared.	201.5648394943927
“Bring the prisoner in again,” said the cardinal.	193.62357822031416
M. Bonacieux was introduced afresh, and upon a sign from the cardinal,	313.2653834052003
the officer retired.	307.35964357177454
“You have deceived me!” said the cardinal, sternly.	344.0371688208413
“I,” cried Bonacieux, “I deceive your Eminence!”	220.56945878347858
“Your wife, in going to Rue de Vaugirard and Rue de la Harpe, did not	241.89497128909343
go to find linen drapers.”	226.26127121944882
“Then why did she go, just God?”	291.7544929463037
“She went to meet the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of	199.2370862898544
Buckingham.”	233.01867198478044
“Yes,” cried Bonacieux, recalling all his remembrances of the	213.02391689722157
circumstances, “yes, that’s it. Your Eminence is right. I told my wife	296.60352506000186
several times that it was surprising that linen drapers should live in	290.8635484726021
such houses as those, in houses that had no signs; but she always	242.72103212159922
laughed at me. Ah, monseigneur!” continued Bonacieux, throwing himself	279.1102146409652
at his Eminence’s feet, “ah, how truly you are the cardinal, the great	349.9166891692936
cardinal, the man of genius whom all the world reveres!”	183.11813768263488
The cardinal, however contemptible might be the triumph gained over so	243.43424197584545
vulgar a being as Bonacieux, did not the less enjoy it for an instant;	329.98414950958545
then, almost immediately, as if a fresh thought has occurred, a smile	265.21799405115996
played upon his lips, and he said, offering his hand to the mercer,	185.055995431604
“Rise, my friend, you are a worthy man.”	284.14364817853277
“The cardinal has touched me with his hand! I have touched the hand of	273.5173758447423
the great man!” cried Bonacieux. “The great man has called me his	178.26608747743015
friend!”	302.53602470717857
“Yes, my friend, yes,” said the cardinal, with that paternal tone which	187.49139011776398
he sometimes knew how to assume, but which deceived none who knew him;	277.3772962517651
“and as you have been unjustly suspected, well, you must be	361.09820969884214
indemnified. Here, take this purse of a hundred pistoles, and pardon	308.8710644371443
me.”	247.0424552526307
“I pardon you, monseigneur!” said Bonacieux, hesitating to take the	292.9028797082641
purse, fearing, doubtless, that this pretended gift was but a	172.1765349896358
pleasantry. “But you are able to have me arrested, you are able to have	261.3691512775524
me tortured, you are able to have me hanged; you are the master, and I	203.71412389183502
could not have the least word to say. Pardon you, monseigneur! You	280.980326884559
cannot mean that!”	214.64404135120392
“Ah, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, you are generous in this matter. I see	330.7587643010033
it and I thank you for it. Thus, then, you will take this bag, and you	234.56966697501545
will go away without being too malcontent.”	190.18187808613948
“I go away enchanted.”	304.4451358225156
“Farewell, then, or rather, _au revoir_, for I hope we shall meet	217.08218690360468
again.”	218.44187957089707
“Whenever Monseigneur wishes, I am always at at his Eminence’s orders.”	255.79932483179502
“That will be frequently, I assure you, for I have found something	272.0511173514942
extremely agreeable in your conversation.”	296.86751902243475
“Oh! Monseigneur!”	299.59153518694734
“_Au revoir_, Monsieur Bonacieux, _au revoir!_”	352.2632944196041
And the cardinal made him a sign with his hand, to which Bonacieux	344.8084021504386
replied by bowing to the ground. He then went out backward, and when he	233.83230834496607
was in the antechamber the cardinal heard him, in his enthusiasm,	348.4496336558442
crying aloud, “Long life to the Monseigneur! Long life to his Eminence!	353.44606096178074
Long life to the great cardinal!” The cardinal listened with a smile to	300.28686289690313
this vociferous manifestation of the feelings of M. Bonacieux; and	278.57866907819607
then, when Bonacieux’s cries were no longer audible, “Good!” said he,	200.90683020779142
“that man would henceforward lay down his life for me.” And the	351.38991316195177
cardinal began to examine with the greatest attention the map of La	286.8786825819826
Rochelle, which, as we have said, lay open on the desk, tracing with a	330.0646695020402
pencil the line in which the famous dyke was to pass which, eighteen	189.42727323711486
months later, shut up the port of the besieged city. As he was in the	179.5726704826512
deepest of his strategic meditations, the door opened, and Rochefort	197.14025676349377
returned.	356.0279948584588
“Well?” said the cardinal, eagerly, rising with a promptitude which	303.6122548275416
proved the degree of importance he attached to the commission with	173.14728281020928
which he had charged the count.	191.68842834377637
“Well,” said the latter, “a young woman of about twenty-six or	195.01923362453908
twenty-eight years of age, and a man of from thirty-five to forty, have	174.42196873583478
indeed lodged at the two houses pointed out by your Eminence; but the	327.05952211082484
woman left last night, and the man this morning.”	205.76723598154544
“It was they!” cried the cardinal, looking at the clock; “and now it is	182.58325790176823
too late to have them pursued. The duchess is at Tours, and the duke at	178.17410689180144
Boulogne. It is in London they must be found.”	214.60520502447494
“What are your Eminence’s orders?”	225.32070681946925
“Not a word of what has passed. Let the queen remain in perfect	232.35114374416838
security; let her be ignorant that we know her secret. Let her believe	244.5448450826256
that we are in search of some conspiracy or other. Send me the keeper	294.6237735938034
of the seals, Séguier.”	205.88851114298996
“And that man, what has your Eminence done with him?”	171.20280818025904
“What man?” asked the cardinal.	365.6174053059839
“That Bonacieux.”	197.31259133412533
“I have done with him all that could be done. I have made him a spy	281.4930098212945
upon his wife.”	210.6854795522953
The Comte de Rochefort bowed like a man who acknowledges the	308.3163471370109
superiority of the master as great, and retired.	207.90722557491554
Left alone, the cardinal seated himself again and wrote a letter, which	174.2354081645936
he secured with his special seal. Then he rang. The officer entered for	258.8399822557627
the fourth time.	201.33130650223745
“Tell Vitray to come to me,” said he, “and tell him to get ready for a	334.87610449077147
journey.”	308.1385474428716
An instant after, the man he asked for was before him, booted and	226.57332939801228
spurred.	357.13067798048917
“Vitray,” said he, “you will go with all speed to London. You must not	186.1450068462755
stop an instant on the way. You will deliver this letter to Milady.	241.39574817649532
Here is an order for two hundred pistoles; call upon my treasurer and	179.87161188024854
get the money. You shall have as much again if you are back within six	353.72404109393585
days, and have executed your commission well.”	309.10179471373
The messenger, without replying a single word, bowed, took the letter,	309.99647182546084
with the order for the two hundred pistoles, and retired.	299.70237011370034
Here is what the letter contained:	183.87818965397113
MILADY, Be at the first ball at which the Duke of Buckingham shall be	297.87550795319123
present. He will wear on his doublet twelve diamond studs; get as near	252.54979082355948
to him as you can, and cut off two.	336.4722169942464
As soon as these studs shall be in your possession, inform me.	347.6642252307967
Chapter XV.	338.636038091399
MEN OF THE ROBE AND MEN OF THE SWORD	207.40300499847595
On the day after these events had taken place, Athos not having	327.34315462268745
reappeared, M. de Tréville was informed by D’Artagnan and Porthos of	258.41810400013173
the circumstance. As to Aramis, he had asked for leave of absence for	297.0165181835056
five days, and was gone, it was said, to Rouen on family business.	221.83229561657032
M. de Tréville was the father of his soldiers. The lowest or the least	257.61832159185235
known of them, as soon as he assumed the uniform of the company, was as	282.81494261260343
sure of his aid and support as if he had been his own brother.	212.6411712986657
He repaired, then, instantly to the office of the	266.7833816554086
_lieutenant-criminel_. The officer who commanded the post of the Red	318.06070963178803
Cross was sent for, and by successive inquiries they learned that Athos	343.70651134979744
was then lodged in Fort l’Evêque.	289.47000524537225
Athos had passed through all the examinations we have seen Bonacieux	212.4269723808176
undergo.	204.54537121164492
We were present at the scene in which the two captives were confronted	236.12555434541815
with each other. Athos, who had till that time said nothing for fear	218.42203335442457
that D’Artagnan, interrupted in his turn, should not have the time	320.70489069617986
necessary, from this moment declared that his name was Athos, and not	260.12347339054077
D’Artagnan. He added that he did not know either M. or Mme. Bonacieux;	359.0130851450243
that he had never spoken to the one or the other; that he had come, at	243.58022757036218
about ten o’clock in the evening, to pay a visit to his friend M.	262.3035228423498
d’Artagnan, but that till that hour he had been at M. de Tréville’s,	225.09142852955884
where he had dined. “Twenty witnesses,” added he, “could attest the	286.1721057686715
fact”; and he named several distinguished gentlemen, and among them was	307.123519657893
M. le Duc de la Trémouille.	314.32371074906484
The second commissary was as much bewildered as the first had been by	329.41977901306205
the simple and firm declaration of the Musketeer, upon whom he was	307.75331768938986
anxious to take the revenge which men of the robe like at all times to	319.29957313253425
gain over men of the sword; but the name of M. de Tréville, and that of	237.93214585853673
M. de la Trémouille, commanded a little reflection.	348.82817668685175
Athos was then sent to the cardinal; but unfortunately the cardinal was	274.6573226140643
at the Louvre with the king.	270.45756778207897
It was precisely at this moment that M. de Tréville, on leaving the	219.60879841285578
residence of the _lieutenant-criminel_ and the governor of Fort	321.64191675288413
l’Evêque without being able to find Athos, arrived at the palace.	310.4312003160162
As captain of the Musketeers, M. de Tréville had the right of entry at	341.2829970533646
all times.	234.08790375548818
It is well known how violent the king’s prejudices were against the	203.40244875167087
queen, and how carefully these prejudices were kept up by the cardinal,	364.4387640341786
who in affairs of intrigue mistrusted women infinitely more than men.	316.0568700468659
One of the grand causes of this prejudice was the friendship of Anne of	299.02945166176994
Austria for Mme. de Chevreuse. These two women gave him more uneasiness	221.66277590337015
than the war with Spain, the quarrel with England, or the embarrassment	177.56226451444635
of the finances. In his eyes and to his conviction, Mme. de Chevreuse	362.1394285719533
not only served the queen in her political intrigues, but, what	353.2728897907815
tormented him still more, in her amorous intrigues.	244.9934321929343
At the first word the cardinal spoke of Mme. de Chevreuse—who, though	339.57567481159566
exiled to Tours and believed to be in that city, had come to Paris,	355.0317750330688
remained there five days, and outwitted the police—the king flew into a	250.3670890827477
furious passion. Capricious and unfaithful, the king wished to be	253.20440492064523
called Louis the Just and Louis the Chaste. Posterity will find a	265.6733997722429
difficulty in understanding this character, which history explains only	350.0827018208146
by facts and never by reason.	231.65525212794765
But when the cardinal added that not only Mme. de Chevreuse had been in	328.3862172587588
Paris, but still further, that the queen had renewed with her one of	295.1325564813604
those mysterious correspondences which at that time was named a	266.212810556039
_cabal;_ when he affirmed that he, the cardinal, was about to unravel	242.57971451629612
the most closely twisted thread of this intrigue; that at the moment of	339.9470465267439
arresting in the very act, with all the proofs about her, the queen’s	288.5832245317699
emissary to the exiled duchess, a Musketeer had dared to interrupt the	247.7104085091454
course of justice violently, by falling sword in hand upon the honest	222.08220479201947
men of the law, charged with investigating impartially the whole affair	301.1090655587956
in order to place it before the eyes of the king—Louis XIII. could not	257.52867797193306
contain himself, and he made a step toward the queen’s apartment with	195.82117996598768
that pale and mute indignation which, when it broke out, led this	361.46914787969047
prince to the commission of the most pitiless cruelty. And yet, in all	342.6834385076146
this, the cardinal had not yet said a word about the Duke of	353.5843731123715
Buckingham.	345.4692550115201
At this instant M. de Tréville entered, cool, polite, and in	337.01512111237514
irreproachable costume.	204.44192936884875
Informed of what had passed by the presence of the cardinal and the	360.83008086568304
alteration in the king’s countenance, M. de Tréville felt himself	349.4722903993004
something like Samson before the Philistines.	308.29783150613184
Louis XIII. had already placed his hand on the knob of the door; at the	312.77099295625356
noise of M. de Tréville’s entrance he turned round. “You arrive in good	269.7953046955996
time, monsieur,” said the king, who, when his passions were raised to a	202.04283028814515
certain point, could not dissemble; “I have learned some fine things	179.0008139478369
concerning your Musketeers.”	270.2546244191532
“And I,” said Tréville, coldly, “I have some pretty things to tell your	333.14169974666174
Majesty concerning these gownsmen.”	335.07557498323376
“What?” said the king, with hauteur.	309.6053799655535
“I have the honor to inform your Majesty,” continued M. de Tréville, in	166.24601856586045
the same tone, “that a party of _procureurs_, commissaries, and men of	193.18317789488583
the police—very estimable people, but very inveterate, as it appears,	282.32894428354655
against the uniform—have taken upon themselves to arrest in a house, to	252.99348402582277
lead away through the open street, and throw into Fort l’Evêque, all	348.5871368797997
upon an order which they have refused to show me, one of my, or rather	206.72289906202573
your Musketeers, sire, of irreproachable conduct, of an almost	230.24411657989717
illustrious reputation, and whom your Majesty knows favorably, Monsieur	181.7644525648116
Athos.”	250.04125303326128
“Athos,” said the king, mechanically; “yes, certainly I know that	361.3715855111268
name.”	256.8885802016666
“Let your Majesty remember,” said Tréville, “that Monsieur Athos is the	225.6678585531784
Musketeer who, in the annoying duel which you are acquainted with, had	207.4969274053638
the misfortune to wound Monsieur de Cahusac so seriously. _A propos_,	223.9214491276797
monseigneur,” continued Tréville, addressing the cardinal, “Monsieur de	251.63095015770278
Cahusac is quite recovered, is he not?”	260.780956454078
“Thank you,” said the cardinal, biting his lips with anger.	341.5999197377648
“Athos, then, went to pay a visit to one of his friends absent at the	350.877433212843
time,” continued Tréville, “to a young Béarnais, a cadet in his	281.47505542790833
Majesty’s Guards, the company of Monsieur Dessessart, but scarcely had	216.38268348708334
he arrived at his friend’s and taken up a book, while waiting his	279.3298048169826
return, when a mixed crowd of bailiffs and soldiers came and laid siege	261.4999861059771
to the house, broke open several doors—”	205.22806988858645
The cardinal made the king a sign, which signified, “That was on	335.37145411896
account of the affair about which I spoke to you.”	344.95553330909604
“We all know that,” interrupted the king; “for all that was done for	350.78377720489686
our service.”	228.36543784643223
“Then,” said Tréville, “it was also for your Majesty’s service that one	263.44839800719916
of my Musketeers, who was innocent, has been seized, that he has been	297.4727113303438
placed between two guards like a malefactor, and that this gallant man,	296.12223368230923
who has ten times shed his blood in your Majesty’s service and is ready	192.99847850231077
to shed it again, has been paraded through the midst of an insolent	197.09034971062326
populace?”	333.67839166959317
“Bah!” said the king, who began to be shaken, “was it so managed?”	195.30197188809413
“Monsieur de Tréville,” said the cardinal, with the greatest phlegm,	354.3906485009703
“does not tell your Majesty that this innocent Musketeer, this gallant	205.85009976809903
man, had only an hour before attacked, sword in hand, four commissaries	288.0161461665474
of inquiry, who were delegated by myself to examine into an affair of	202.92248833491212
the highest importance.”	184.56478204317085
“I defy your Eminence to prove it,” cried Tréville, with his Gascon	299.3090962558323
freedom and military frankness; “for one hour before, Monsieur Athos,	259.41390156852424
who, I will confide it to your Majesty, is really a man of the highest	264.8230275531101
quality, did me the honor after having dined with me to be conversing	353.843439054002
in the saloon of my hôtel, with the Duc de la Trémouille and the Comte	325.3060259417339
de Châlus, who happened to be there.”	260.23715260558976
The king looked at the cardinal.	363.28868528417433
“A written examination attests it,” said the cardinal, replying aloud	313.2421837936133
to the mute interrogation of his Majesty; “and the ill-treated people	202.59658558681707
have drawn up the following, which I have the honor to present to your	348.81639086689535
Majesty.”	198.48707144612115
“And is the written report of the gownsmen to be placed in comparison	247.6100284347075
with the word of honor of a swordsman?” replied Tréville haughtily.	237.12340368035748
“Come, come, Tréville, hold your tongue,” said the king.	205.85276793538205
“If his Eminence entertains any suspicion against one of my	363.21047687704163
Musketeers,” said Tréville, “the justice of Monsieur the Cardinal is so	253.8791290548254
well known that I demand an inquiry.”	205.06369435761206
“In the house in which the judicial inquiry was made,” continued the	210.39313691425806
impassive cardinal, “there lodges, I believe, a young Béarnais, a	247.03191640994334
friend of the Musketeer.”	243.19144757666305
“Your Eminence means Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	237.9121642357415
“I mean a young man whom you patronize, Monsieur de Tréville.”	188.81486912425362
“Yes, your Eminence, it is the same.”	321.22315372306235
“Do you not suspect this young man of having given bad counsel?”	191.00220385244188
“To Athos, to a man double his age?” interrupted Tréville. “No,	211.31592880718338
monseigneur. Besides, D’Artagnan passed the evening with me.”	207.48668654994916
“Well,” said the cardinal, “everybody seems to have passed the evening	258.8292525892822
with you.”	170.84899906341894
“Does your Eminence doubt my word?” said Tréville, with a brow flushed	237.04720988845452
with anger.	274.12199381616347
“No, God forbid,” said the cardinal; “only, at what hour was he with	244.19452600250048
you?”	218.40739585568397
“Oh, as to that I can speak positively, your Eminence; for as he came	324.5954118423622
in I remarked that it was but half past nine by the clock, although I	211.09814211545134
had believed it to be later.”	290.54152066532856
“At what hour did he leave your hôtel?”	170.7573227497798
“At half past ten—an hour after the event.”	209.08844908144192
“Well,” replied the cardinal, who could not for an instant suspect the	280.4250059913411
loyalty of Tréville, and who felt that the victory was escaping him,	285.6674837413813
“well, but Athos _was_ taken in the house in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.”	341.5897972743098
“Is one friend forbidden to visit another, or a Musketeer of my company	202.03806203259836
to fraternize with a Guard of Dessessart’s company?”	247.30467321724518
“Yes, when the house where he fraternizes is suspected.”	268.45648891302153
“That house is suspected, Tréville,” said the king; “perhaps you did	338.03130008446493
not know it?”	344.7974872939467
“Indeed, sire, I did not. The house may be suspected; but I deny that	330.8041071839385
it is so in the part of it inhabited by Monsieur d’Artagnan, for I can	188.80569457342497
affirm, sire, if I can believe what he says, that there does not exist	339.1181930396756
a more devoted servant of your Majesty, or a more profound admirer of	226.4628851584621
Monsieur the Cardinal.”	168.0561882624633
“Was it not this D’Artagnan who wounded Jussac one day, in that	175.3133262567975
unfortunate encounter which took place near the Convent of the	300.76368898322426
Carmes-Déchaussés?” asked the king, looking at the cardinal, who	267.8463646971518
colored with vexation.	209.44557102117406
“And the next day, Bernajoux. Yes, sire, yes, it is the same; and your	250.30158040531566
Majesty has a good memory.”	270.22989711643777
“Come, how shall we decide?” said the king.	353.7485641399402
“That concerns your Majesty more than me,” said the cardinal. “I should	307.4914939851095
affirm the culpability.”	270.122152457746
“And I deny it,” said Tréville. “But his Majesty has judges, and these	353.6207867425758
judges will decide.”	282.91213806006385
“That is best,” said the king. “Send the case before the judges; it is	284.0356301629956
their business to judge, and they shall judge.”	286.7665441296444
“Only,” replied Tréville, “it is a sad thing that in the unfortunate	212.37899771073995
times in which we live, the purest life, the most incontestable virtue,	287.81062662862496
cannot exempt a man from infamy and persecution. The army, I will	314.3149722052371
answer for it, will be but little pleased at being exposed to rigorous	311.67140761466794
treatment on account of police affairs.”	261.67422365684115
The expression was imprudent; but M. de Tréville launched it with	340.52000035977045
knowledge of his cause. He was desirous of an explosion, because in	300.60871769008463
that case the mine throws forth fire, and fire enlightens.	263.59032122867006
“Police affairs!” cried the king, taking up Tréville’s words, “police	187.39524476595417
affairs! And what do you know about them, Monsieur? Meddle with your	267.017888237412
Musketeers, and do not annoy me in this way. It appears, according to	190.2800223060912
your account, that if by mischance a Musketeer is arrested, France is	226.3596524259329
in danger. What a noise about a Musketeer! I would arrest ten of them,	340.5683521614966
_ventrebleu_, a hundred, even, all the company, and I would not allow a	218.48253569989612
whisper.”	246.2604101594934
“From the moment they are suspected by your Majesty,” said Tréville,	228.3338088319622
“the Musketeers are guilty; therefore, you see me prepared to surrender	180.3408641349992
my sword—for after having accused my soldiers, there can be no doubt	244.0508861720176
that Monsieur the Cardinal will end by accusing me. It is best to	347.449713714296
constitute myself at once a prisoner with Athos, who is already	306.6337203087961
arrested, and with D’Artagnan, who most probably will be.”	245.76213791182897
“Gascon-headed man, will you have done?” said the king.	204.3471594831068
“Sire,” replied Tréville, without lowering his voice in the least,	182.43952084202112
“either order my Musketeer to be restored to me, or let him be tried.”	187.97826138034688
“He shall be tried,” said the cardinal.	307.56337036770526
“Well, so much the better; for in that case I shall demand of his	201.7275684005804
Majesty permission to plead for him.”	330.05199025978027
The king feared an outbreak.	188.9630570395617
“If his Eminence,” said he, “did not have personal motives—”	270.1777009734679
The cardinal saw what the king was about to say and interrupted him:	326.5440670933224
“Pardon me,” said he; “but the instant your Majesty considers me a	305.57356568606156
prejudiced judge, I withdraw.”	262.79827060169976
“Come,” said the king, “will you swear, by my father, that Athos was at	275.54804556304816
your residence during the event and that he took no part in it?”	207.98859279060238
“By your glorious father, and by yourself, whom I love and venerate	173.58686817676252
above all the world, I swear it.”	248.14353701032664
“Be so kind as to reflect, sire,” said the cardinal. “If we release the	351.3912122594942
prisoner thus, we shall never know the truth.”	248.28636011873368
“Athos may always be found,” replied Tréville, “ready to answer, when	188.72492600341107
it shall please the gownsmen to interrogate him. He will not desert,	271.27448648304414
Monsieur the Cardinal, be assured of that; I will answer for him.”	224.76624327167232
“No, he will not desert,” said the king; “he can always be found, as	320.04205373471757
Tréville says. Besides,” added he, lowering his voice and looking with	169.41123618329203
a suppliant air at the cardinal, “let us give them apparent security;	225.55910001831253
that is policy.”	320.94686439217554
This policy of Louis XIII. made Richelieu smile.	345.7265662069045
“Order it as you please, sire; you possess the right of pardon.”	339.5665543503418
“The right of pardoning only applies to the guilty,” said Tréville, who	345.0110057696379
was determined to have the last word, “and my Musketeer is innocent. It	333.60240194899995
is not mercy, then, that you are about to accord, sire, it is justice.”	297.03710089754526
“And he is in the Fort l’Evêque?” said the king.	168.12717855498465
“Yes, sire, in solitary confinement, in a dungeon, like the lowest	289.0167722912777
criminal.”	272.57184263301144
“The devil!” murmured the king; “what must be done?”	175.55262359926786
“Sign an order for his release, and all will be said,” replied the	216.06099735350165
cardinal. “I believe with your Majesty that Monsieur de Tréville’s	283.9969985223607
guarantee is more than sufficient.”	276.8227299199084
Tréville bowed very respectfully, with a joy that was not unmixed with	207.70275126327425
fear; he would have preferred an obstinate resistance on the part of	182.5243520192688
the cardinal to this sudden yielding.	200.5041364310245
The king signed the order for release, and Tréville carried it away	344.57188826905224
without delay. As he was about to leave the presence, the cardinal gave	210.81764123095388
him a friendly smile, and said, “A perfect harmony reigns, sire,	230.8628822359438
between the leaders and the soldiers of your Musketeers, which must be	364.56552202988166
profitable for the service and honorable to all.”	312.1149959149833
“He will play me some dog’s trick or other, and that immediately,” said	357.86300372752095
Tréville. “One has never the last word with such a man. But let us be	306.24925313478866
quick—the king may change his mind in an hour; and at all events it is	357.8230760293301
more difficult to replace a man in the Fort l’Evêque or the Bastille	316.1766805572205
who has got out, than to keep a prisoner there who is in.”	278.1009065697393
M. de Tréville made his entrance triumphantly into the Fort l’Evêque,	175.06850943009252
whence he delivered the Musketeer, whose peaceful indifference had not	341.14063324484584
for a moment abandoned him.	254.00733400602488
The first time he saw D’Artagnan, “You have come off well,” said he to	226.47434242105425
him; “there is your Jussac thrust paid for. There still remains that of	357.2210726800537
Bernajoux, but you must not be too confident.”	241.28897879286683
As to the rest, M. de Tréville had good reason to mistrust the cardinal	240.30457928676395
and to think that all was not over, for scarcely had the captain of the	344.3193603959862
Musketeers closed the door after him, than his Eminence said to the	361.6773878550319
king, “Now that we are at length by ourselves, we will, if your Majesty	331.5059549006189
pleases, converse seriously. Sire, Buckingham has been in Paris five	183.36505526282565
days, and only left this morning.”	345.27778105635673
Chapter XVI.	322.75956114152405
IN WHICH M. SÉGUIER, KEEPER OF THE SEALS, LOOKS MORE THAN ONCE FOR THE	186.56205430589196
BELL	204.4143853122689
It is impossible to form an idea of the impression these few words made	203.90033241295166
upon Louis XIII. He grew pale and red alternately; and the cardinal saw	262.7940894592062
at once that he had recovered by a single blow all the ground he had	220.46375992931814
lost.	205.32793674516262
“Buckingham in Paris!” cried he, “and why does he come?”	276.49971413096677
“To conspire, no doubt, with your enemies, the Huguenots and the	322.59766435118075
Spaniards.”	327.72869379040145
“No, _pardieu_, no! To conspire against my honor with Madame de	186.03765897498366
Chevreuse, Madame de Longueville, and the Condés.”	253.26207472304253
“Oh, sire, what an idea! The queen is too virtuous; and besides, loves	338.0980240946215
your Majesty too well.”	324.60327198547213
“Woman is weak, Monsieur Cardinal,” said the king; “and as to loving me	298.05652913501797
much, I have my own opinion as to that love.”	250.74050990949897
“I not the less maintain,” said the cardinal, “that the Duke of	208.34069583516649
Buckingham came to Paris for a project wholly political.”	260.53783646454167
“And I am sure that he came for quite another purpose, Monsieur	259.40707268746536
Cardinal; but if the queen be guilty, let her tremble!”	305.39431954449606
“Indeed,” said the cardinal, “whatever repugnance I may have to	192.9599341781381
directing my mind to such a treason, your Majesty compels me to think	338.57529839004536
of it. Madame de Lannoy, whom, according to your Majesty’s command, I	363.478704248418
have frequently interrogated, told me this morning that the night	354.99207429460034
before last her Majesty sat up very late, that this morning she wept	269.81089051743476
much, and that she was writing all day.”	262.5199650434803
“That’s it!” cried the king; “to him, no doubt. Cardinal, I must have	296.2351372971578
the queen’s papers.”	229.19382747906414
“But how to take them, sire? It seems to me that it is neither your	224.11730159348832
Majesty nor myself who can charge himself with such a mission.”	309.2977502444261
“How did they act with regard to the Maréchale d’Ancre?” cried the	347.2202906044382
king, in the highest state of choler; “first her closets were	352.1009454276208
thoroughly searched, and then she herself.”	280.774059380628
“The Maréchale d’Ancre was no more than the Maréchale d’Ancre. A	188.01254278531405
Florentine adventurer, sire, and that was all; while the august spouse	187.79608082790847
of your Majesty is Anne of Austria, Queen of France—that is to say, one	219.32152221731997
of the greatest princesses in the world.”	244.76457110909593
“She is not the less guilty, Monsieur Duke! The more she has forgotten	298.77256462297385
the high position in which she was placed, the more degrading is her	187.4473778635371
fall. Besides, I long ago determined to put an end to all these petty	232.22550587647464
intrigues of policy and love. She has near her a certain Laporte.”	307.21484999822053
“Who, I believe, is the mainspring of all this, I confess,” said the	304.9929788261078
cardinal.	192.01339447429717
“You think then, as I do, that she deceives me?” said the king.	271.1216479788147
“I believe, and I repeat it to your Majesty, that the queen conspires	292.57140974872806
against the power of the king, but I have not said against his honor.”	187.36488521440762
“And I—I tell you against both. I tell you the queen does not love me;	320.71286218643775
I tell you she loves another; I tell you she loves that infamous	277.56069590326683
Buckingham! Why did you not have him arrested while in Paris?”	194.00640395596244
“Arrest the Duke! Arrest the prime minister of King Charles I.! Think	194.05710297763443
of it, sire! What a scandal! And if the suspicions of your Majesty,	234.037470762037
which I still continue to doubt, should prove to have any foundation,	337.7156853431595
what a terrible disclosure, what a fearful scandal!”	279.3649948319607
“But as he exposed himself like a vagabond or a thief, he should have	225.6753301926617
been—”	230.9349261884154
Louis XIII. stopped, terrified at what he was about to say, while	182.571365623919
Richelieu, stretching out his neck, waited uselessly for the word which	232.01061873901438
had died on the lips of the king.	321.3545195222961
“He should have been—?”	287.12143621997757
“Nothing,” said the king, “nothing. But all the time he was in Paris,	268.1140277619369
you, of course, did not lose sight of him?”	345.9626473823121
“No, sire.”	294.70098189189935
“Where did he lodge?”	215.69173045252717
“Rue de la Harpe. No. 75.”	239.48127869399917
“Where is that?”	296.40691262823276
“By the side of the Luxembourg.”	348.83768214019324
“And you are certain that the queen and he did not see each other?”	300.8871092461842
“I believe the queen to have too high a sense of her duty, sire.”	244.649442856535
“But they have corresponded; it is to him that the queen has been	353.4328230168328
writing all the day. Monsieur Duke, I must have those letters!”	344.3525270944814
“Sire, notwithstanding—”	254.3490901928931
“Monsieur Duke, at whatever price it may be, I will have them.”	192.13000881439848
“I would, however, beg your Majesty to observe—”	175.0682284798949
“Do you, then, also join in betraying me, Monsieur Cardinal, by thus	166.8350468622425
always opposing my will? Are you also in accord with Spain and England,	353.0018180266485
with Madame de Chevreuse and the queen?”	295.8136971638721
“Sire,” replied the cardinal, sighing, “I believed myself secure from	227.3602086898642
such a suspicion.”	307.4578615714149
“Monsieur Cardinal, you have heard me; I will have those letters.”	322.1250144929528
“There is but one way.”	168.1294664708384
“What is that?”	197.52231954952597
“That would be to charge Monsieur de Séguier, the keeper of the seals,	241.08963469013213
with this mission. The matter enters completely into the duties of the	322.2893143291993
post.”	233.27647717504908
“Let him be sent for instantly.”	252.1727741897863
“He is most likely at my hôtel. I requested him to call, and when I	329.183584862175
came to the Louvre I left orders if he came, to desire him to wait.”	228.8403150712844
“Let him be sent for instantly.”	305.7344066485426
“Your Majesty’s orders shall be executed; but—”	244.82284485857986
“But what?”	259.0941412488308
“But the queen will perhaps refuse to obey.”	345.38261887493024
“My orders?”	217.3229801196979
“Yes, if she is ignorant that these orders come from the king.”	279.02151399178797
“Well, that she may have no doubt on that head, I will go and inform	230.0967201978873
her myself.”	173.6646098050891
“Your Majesty will not forget that I have done everything in my power	167.15577881866707
to prevent a rupture.”	261.7751222472665
“Yes, Duke, yes, I know you are very indulgent toward the queen, too	170.20807772894133
indulgent, perhaps; we shall have occasion, I warn you, at some future	357.74879616937926
period to speak of that.”	184.17639034421381
“Whenever it shall please your Majesty; but I shall be always happy and	232.85125513442586
proud, sire, to sacrifice myself to the harmony which I desire to see	286.6551207024127
reign between you and the Queen of France.”	250.19938937286267
“Very well, Cardinal, very well; but, meantime, send for Monsieur the	199.99634512782896
Keeper of the Seals. I will go to the queen.”	240.75042899033014
And Louis XIII., opening the door of communication, passed into the	246.59441569418095
corridor which led from his apartments to those of Anne of Austria.	190.59243520014414
The queen was in the midst of her women—Mme. de Guitaut, Mme. de Sable,	228.28354801708724
Mme. de Montbazon, and Mme. de Guémené. In a corner was the Spanish	323.49052172414326
companion, Donna Estafania, who had followed her from Madrid. Mme.	265.65665534311285
Guémené was reading aloud, and everybody was listening to her with	221.10174639504532
attention with the exception of the queen, who had, on the contrary,	172.7549460725479
desired this reading in order that she might be able, while feigning to	280.2984810105685
listen, to pursue the thread of her own thoughts.	310.59144354851435
These thoughts, gilded as they were by a last reflection of love, were	320.13064019244143
not the less sad. Anne of Austria, deprived of the confidence of her	231.20416617676847
husband, pursued by the hatred of the cardinal, who could not pardon	352.86192996807813
her for having repulsed a more tender feeling, having before her eyes	279.2135098068097
the example of the queen-mother whom that hatred had tormented all her	343.57609937451764
life—though Marie de Médicis, if the memoirs of the time are to be	218.0211937167575
believed, had begun by according to the cardinal that sentiment which	223.4014706952659
Anne of Austria always refused him—Anne of Austria had seen her most	207.09269321094365
devoted servants fall around her, her most intimate confidants, her	273.0611671996165
dearest favorites. Like those unfortunate persons endowed with a fatal	339.51160221401585
gift, she brought misfortune upon everything she touched. Her	332.48460152248987
friendship was a fatal sign which called down persecution. Mme. de	236.17397095546522
Chevreuse and Mme. de Bernet were exiled, and Laporte did not conceal	228.97335325930743
from his mistress that he expected to be arrested every instant.	183.63919883318616
It was at the moment when she was plunged in the deepest and darkest of	323.0538239387723
these reflections that the door of the chamber opened, and the king	175.19833318863
entered.	172.0218420915526
The reader hushed herself instantly. All the ladies rose, and there was	269.6054204133489
a profound silence. As to the king, he made no demonstration of	230.54485020313285
politeness, only stopping before the queen. “Madame,” said he, “you are	215.60798699533854
about to receive a visit from the chancellor, who will communicate	291.4208311183652
certain matters to you with which I have charged him.”	280.59523671128534
The unfortunate queen, who was constantly threatened with divorce,	351.29851130924067
exile, and trial even, turned pale under her rouge, and could not	315.9129016731724
refrain from saying, “But why this visit, sire? What can the chancellor	335.76339232020916
have to say to me that your Majesty could not say yourself?”	175.60511611417311
The king turned upon his heel without reply, and almost at the same	216.5392189949149
instant the captain of the Guards, M. de Guitant, announced the visit	215.04002921619616
of the chancellor.	292.70413419020963
When the chancellor appeared, the king had already gone out by another	259.7179886959507
door.	170.22351599604548
The chancellor entered, half smiling, half blushing. As we shall	274.3222705621024
probably meet with him again in the course of our history, it may be	275.9516433224365
well for our readers to be made at once acquainted with him.	359.18620797858796
This chancellor was a pleasant man. He was Des Roches le Masle, canon	178.43984154524534
of Notre Dame, who had formerly been valet of a bishop, who introduced	273.96476283223893
him to his Eminence as a perfectly devout man. The cardinal trusted	212.82786834542708
him, and therein found his advantage.	353.27449183308147
There are many stories related of him, and among them this. After a	320.4532764966848
wild youth, he had retired into a convent, there to expiate, at least	225.23654642392341
for some time, the follies of adolescence. On entering this holy place,	288.2673875256368
the poor penitent was unable to shut the door so close as to prevent	305.51036000224883
the passions he fled from entering with him. He was incessantly	216.86591474175663
attacked by them, and the superior, to whom he had confided this	292.3177046287284
misfortune, wishing as much as in him lay to free him from them, had	299.6598271099564
advised him, in order to conjure away the tempting demon, to have	184.67709626498026
recourse to the bell rope, and ring with all his might. At the	242.02711476087845
denunciating sound, the monks would be rendered aware that temptation	344.3980089223521
was besieging a brother, and all the community would go to prayers.	343.2037502973319
This advice appeared good to the future chancellor. He conjured the	178.0175918453023
evil spirit with abundance of prayers offered up by the monks. But the	282.99297864017547
devil does not suffer himself to be easily dispossessed from a place in	246.36140167929454
which he has fixed his garrison. In proportion as they redoubled the	223.20898618379383
exorcisms he redoubled the temptations; so that day and night the bell	337.12634923704525
was ringing full swing, announcing the extreme desire for mortification	215.77183329885207
which the penitent experienced.	364.18706692789436
The monks had no longer an instant of repose. By day they did nothing	243.60809284525664
but ascend and descend the steps which led to the chapel; at night, in	283.64465417050735
addition to complines and matins, they were further obliged to leap	256.48624879689675
twenty times out of their beds and prostrate themselves on the floor of	360.73211670189767
their cells.	311.2122484238791
It is not known whether it was the devil who gave way, or the monks who	200.34930063928277
grew tired; but within three months the penitent reappeared in the	355.30088922560014
world with the reputation of being the most terrible _possessed_ that	344.75352232940975
ever existed.	320.93213816602656
On leaving the convent he entered into the magistracy, became president	179.05649916865423
on the place of his uncle, embraced the cardinal’s party, which did not	253.4272015269566
prove want of sagacity, became chancellor, served his Eminence with	191.33121440018732
zeal in his hatred against the queen-mother and his vengeance against	176.10899699127435
Anne of Austria, stimulated the judges in the affair of Calais,	330.3133257182112
encouraged the attempts of M. de Laffemas, chief gamekeeper of France;	166.1732491918606
then, at length, invested with the entire confidence of the cardinal—a	189.34999706477225
confidence which he had so well earned—he received the singular	248.57483759765594
commission for the execution of which he presented himself in the	243.72234443287329
queen’s apartments.	168.55922075779029
The queen was still standing when he entered; but scarcely had she	225.28732686306776
perceived him then she reseated herself in her armchair, and made a	332.5442713208254
sign to her women to resume their cushions and stools, and with an air	208.54805794150954
of supreme hauteur, said, “What do you desire, monsieur, and with what	216.14483327827884
object do you present yourself here?”	348.6083059794038
“To make, madame, in the name of the king, and without prejudice to the	210.6597557109141
respect which I have the honor to owe to your Majesty a close	363.6787274850401
examination into all your papers.”	340.1433112382939
“How, monsieur, an investigation of my papers—mine! Truly, this is an	358.7705141104549
indignity!”	177.28049983530929
“Be kind enough to pardon me, madame; but in this circumstance I am but	263.64621763066987
the instrument which the king employs. Has not his Majesty just left	259.7004960200682
you, and has he not himself asked you to prepare for this visit?”	256.5067299723934
“Search, then, monsieur! I am a criminal, as it appears. Estafania,	238.47171622792888
give up the keys of my drawers and my desks.”	362.5239276249363
For form’s sake the chancellor paid a visit to the pieces of furniture	260.278089676028
named; but he well knew that it was not in a piece of furniture that	336.0446525120245
the queen would place the important letter she had written that day.	230.29339771542283
When the chancellor had opened and shut twenty times the drawers of the	304.21917596643846
secretaries, it became necessary, whatever hesitation he might	214.098702251278
experience—it became necessary, I say, to come to the conclusion of the	228.93318995190373
affair; that is to say, to search the queen herself. The chancellor	250.7975400408494
advanced, therefore, toward Anne of Austria, and said with a very	282.4331868237804
perplexed and embarrassed air, “And now it remains for me to make the	278.78378195986124
principal examination.”	264.2676802463801
“What is that?” asked the queen, who did not understand, or rather was	218.89693204167395
not willing to understand.	295.62569353622166
“His majesty is certain that a letter has been written by you during	228.50470541653533
the day; he knows that it has not yet been sent to its address. This	185.65926203245888
letter is not in your table nor in your secretary; and yet this letter	299.0168487866924
must be somewhere.”	208.5723681574728
“Would you dare to lift your hand to your queen?” said Anne of Austria,	298.4087572201644
drawing herself up to her full height, and fixing her eyes upon the	229.64285734992907
chancellor with an expression almost threatening.	244.60841658531643
“I am a faithful subject of the king, madame, and all that his Majesty	225.5508850853337
commands I shall do.”	250.5889835233705
“Well, it is true!” said Anne of Austria; “and the spies of the	234.06101363841626
cardinal have served him faithfully. I have written a letter today;	215.43036489913055
that letter is not yet gone. The letter is here.” And the queen laid	173.5450508421695
her beautiful hand on her bosom.	271.34871094880907
“Then give me that letter, madame,” said the chancellor.	182.8321596978165
“I will give it to none but the king, monsieur,” said Anne.	364.6661780884573
“If the king had desired that the letter should be given to him,	327.6950242440886
madame, he would have demanded it of you himself. But I repeat to you,	259.4556722841535
I am charged with reclaiming it; and if you do not give it up—”	283.7074168104893
“Well?”	183.52799467691392
“He has, then, charged me to take it from you.”	301.81399907067055
“How! What do you say?”	182.36957766724018
“That my orders go far, madame; and that I am authorized to seek for	197.77240141220773
the suspected paper, even on the person of your Majesty.”	340.910789537431
“What horror!” cried the queen.	342.31799005075555
“Be kind enough, then, madame, to act more compliantly.”	184.80783039317043
“The conduct is infamously violent! Do you know that, monsieur?”	262.12003549624455
“The king commands it, madame; excuse me.”	297.22194807798985
“I will not suffer it! No, no, I would rather die!” cried the queen, in	257.1921241651552
whom the imperious blood of Spain and Austria began to rise.	336.3933062938907
The chancellor made a profound reverence. Then, with the intention	221.30080976689666
quite patent of not drawing back a foot from the accomplishment of the	212.86043608924763
commission with which he was charged, and as the attendant of an	331.5776421582921
executioner might have done in the chamber of torture, he approached	358.3829414196898
Anne of Austria, from whose eyes at the same instant sprang tears of	289.5163809152638
rage.	249.83223012750696
The queen was, as we have said, of great beauty. The commission might	183.14678923810916
