well be called delicate; and the king had reached, in his jealousy of	217.42698800863997
Buckingham, the point of not being jealous of anyone else.	295.8364004569586
Without doubt the chancellor Séguier looked about at that moment for	261.13318686322106
the rope of the famous bell; but not finding it he summoned his	323.80692348027424
resolution, and stretched forth his hands toward the place where the	178.24760129272508
queen had acknowledged the paper was to be found.	253.18962305020176
Anne of Austria took one step backward, became so pale that it might be	260.55840266193457
said she was dying, and leaning with her left hand upon a table behind	332.11759964605335
her to keep herself from falling, she with her right hand drew the	213.51081395487898
paper from her bosom and held it out to the keeper of the seals.	194.60540660224964
“There, monsieur, there is that letter!” cried the queen, with a broken	296.15902024373963
and trembling voice; “take it, and deliver me from your odious	215.1082934927278
presence.”	313.2483913025857
The chancellor, who, on his part, trembled with an emotion easily to be	331.1050647455362
conceived, took the letter, bowed to the ground, and retired. The door	236.23426981781122
was scarcely closed upon him, when the queen sank, half fainting, into	197.9151839402965
the arms of her women.	237.42984762460858
The chancellor carried the letter to the king without having read a	295.1290827496256
single word of it. The king took it with a trembling hand, looked for	334.70417540234837
the address, which was wanting, became very pale, opened it slowly,	337.4385607732695
then seeing by the first words that it was addressed to the King of	180.4462025428367
Spain, he read it rapidly.	291.70423273213675
It was nothing but a plan of attack against the cardinal. The queen	352.7106633714867
pressed her brother and the Emperor of Austria to appear to be wounded,	169.391947376104
as they really were, by the policy of Richelieu—the eternal object of	345.3271106074865
which was the abasement of the house of Austria—to declare war against	325.86842486954373
France, and as a condition of peace, to insist upon the dismissal of	203.1448887209599
the cardinal; but as to love, there was not a single word about it in	321.7973225395839
all the letter.	323.1619625568434
The king, quite delighted, inquired if the cardinal was still at the	306.3893995594605
Louvre; he was told that his Eminence awaited the orders of his Majesty	183.77850401835155
in the business cabinet.	184.27537905549698
The king went straight to him.	342.6005489205492
“There, Duke,” said he, “you were right and I was wrong. The whole	298.66643186643194
intrigue is political, and there is not the least question of love in	285.18881550039083
this letter; but, on the other hand, there is abundant question of	296.3810510064361
you.”	270.0366901117089
The cardinal took the letter, and read it with the greatest attention;	202.5745805172285
then, when he had arrived at the end of it, he read it a second time.	359.0902459281421
“Well, your Majesty,” said he, “you see how far my enemies go; they	174.5496396263075
menace you with two wars if you do not dismiss me. In your place, in	297.214016841352
truth, sire, I should yield to such powerful instance; and on my part,	202.81746612654845
it would be a real happiness to withdraw from public affairs.”	245.76807337837633
“What say you, Duke?”	171.32300905149597
“I say, sire, that my health is sinking under these excessive struggles	292.3802670525964
and these never-ending labors. I say that according to all probability	182.54870299017352
I shall not be able to undergo the fatigues of the siege of La	348.54949003518954
Rochelle, and that it would be far better that you should appoint there	175.31503330274606
either Monsieur de Condé, Monsieur de Bassopierre, or some valiant	221.38298712605692
gentleman whose business is war, and not me, who am a churchman, and	180.64706693551747
who am constantly turned aside for my real vocation to look after	287.90698224859324
matters for which I have no aptitude. You would be the happier for it	243.51173562930998
at home, sire, and I do not doubt you would be the greater for it	223.51890572696857
abroad.”	197.9303798357914
“Monsieur Duke,” said the king, “I understand you. Be satisfied, all	282.2253487903944
who are named in that letter shall be punished as they deserve, even	174.9822770219246
the queen herself.”	166.72712667527722
“What do you say, sire? God forbid that the queen should suffer the	254.31998576799978
least inconvenience or uneasiness on my account! She has always	222.95502603454446
believed me, sire, to be her enemy; although your Majesty can bear	344.7019563635423
witness that I have always taken her part warmly, even against you. Oh,	201.1926001054705
if she betrayed your Majesty on the side of your honor, it would be	295.0388106182273
quite another thing, and I should be the first to say, ‘No grace,	172.19519588423128
sire—no grace for the guilty!’ Happily, there is nothing of the kind,	173.82442189195572
and your Majesty has just acquired a new proof of it.”	221.92493328391188
“That is true, Monsieur Cardinal,” said the king, “and you were right,	294.2113020294148
as you always are; but the queen, not the less, deserves all my anger.”	264.39003187699996
“It is you, sire, who have now incurred hers. And even if she were to	353.9409186020047
be seriously offended, I could well understand it; your Majesty has	201.14562628171714
treated her with a severity—”	349.6154372173479
“It is thus I will always treat my enemies and yours, Duke, however	331.86511328637357
high they may be placed, and whatever peril I may incur in acting	333.78395573245894
severely toward them.”	305.1969106820251
“The queen is my enemy, but is not yours, sire; on the contrary, she is	233.11563799415245
a devoted, submissive, and irreproachable wife. Allow me, then, sire,	330.6641363331967
to intercede for her with your Majesty.”	209.71642549506075
“Let her humble herself, then, and come to me first.”	214.15782339440824
“On the contrary, sire, set the example. You have committed the first	271.67020330707925
wrong, since it was you who suspected the queen.”	351.9114726569993
“What! I make the first advances?” said the king. “Never!”	250.89015774502218
“Sire, I entreat you to do so.”	260.4773198182629
“Besides, in what manner can I make advances first?”	203.3383070771996
“By doing a thing which you know will be agreeable to her.”	303.6450727571643
“What is that?”	206.51184971541653
“Give a ball; you know how much the queen loves dancing. I will answer	252.30980392115305
for it, her resentment will not hold out against such an attention.”	222.14839309406085
“Monsieur Cardinal, you know that I do not like worldly pleasures.”	188.57111063628662
“The queen will only be the more grateful to you, as she knows your	168.90631452279183
antipathy for that amusement; besides, it will be an opportunity for	175.3971490099852
her to wear those beautiful diamonds which you gave her recently on her	206.4563344664127
birthday and with which she has since had no occasion to adorn	315.59362712079843
herself.”	188.8575997896798
“We shall see, Monsieur Cardinal, we shall see,” said the king, who, in	256.5914632534333
his joy at finding the queen guilty of a crime which he cared little	169.7552725305025
about, and innocent of a fault of which he had great dread, was ready	211.07727405320287
to make up all differences with her, “we shall see, but upon my honor,	241.42806682564822
you are too indulgent toward her.”	189.01184206543448
“Sire,” said the cardinal, “leave severity to your ministers. Clemency	319.3476200290821
is a royal virtue; employ it, and you will find that you derive	358.2641837688149
advantage therein.”	186.3840629389746
Thereupon the cardinal, hearing the clock strike eleven, bowed low,	206.06380864749707
asking permission of the king to retire, and supplicating him to come	185.79420016353748
to a good understanding with the queen.	227.379768276427
Anne of Austria, who, in consequence of the seizure of her letter,	274.8901726072414
expected reproaches, was much astonished the next day to see the king	273.68820110396723
make some attempts at reconciliation with her. Her first movement was	205.6468849828041
repellent. Her womanly pride and her queenly dignity had both been so	253.6029773793813
cruelly offended that she could not come round at the first advance;	232.7690485350064
but, overpersuaded by the advice of her women, she at last had the	213.7047785101921
appearance of beginning to forget. The king took advantage of this	197.03733985431435
favorable moment to tell her that he had the intention of shortly	352.1315266639925
giving a fête.	354.39522955161465
A fête was so rare a thing for poor Anne of Austria that at this	176.06925763487166
announcement, as the cardinal had predicted, the last trace of her	288.834329467322
resentment disappeared, if not from her heart, at least from her	229.72708623428844
countenance. She asked upon what day this fête would take place, but	239.44406610448797
the king replied that he must consult the cardinal upon that head.	285.22453598461436
Indeed, every day the king asked the cardinal when this fête should	341.00337342064364
take place; and every day the cardinal, under some pretext, deferred	202.290988614145
fixing it. Ten days passed away thus.	201.85674157571023
On the eighth day after the scene we have described, the cardinal	248.52824137129346
received a letter with the London stamp which only contained these	257.730978661661
lines: “I have them; but I am unable to leave London for want of money.	364.42200636187795
Send me five hundred pistoles, and four or five days after I have	229.58887437740998
received them I shall be in Paris.”	304.17533470687926
On the same day the cardinal received this letter the king put his	200.8033477491478
customary question to him.	227.16807166514678
Richelieu counted on his fingers, and said to himself, “She will	231.88694485217815
arrive, she says, four or five days after having received the money. It	304.77988633496136
will require four or five days for the transmission of the money, four	312.97147569395474
or five days for her to return; that makes ten days. Now, allowing for	329.5870344556711
contrary winds, accidents, and a woman’s weakness, there are twelve	221.75683403479965
days.”	196.3454038161401
“Well, Monsieur Duke,” said the king, “have you made your	284.2972814758132
calculations?”	216.7139953030878
“Yes, sire. Today is the twentieth of September. The aldermen of the	296.02240499306424
city give a fête on the third of October. That will fall in wonderfully	229.3702087398187
well; you will not appear to have gone out of your way to please the	298.6658903740853
queen.”	300.0993704191379
Then the cardinal added, “_A propos_, sire, do not forget to tell her	182.12802431547
Majesty the evening before the fête that you should like to see how her	360.48899511461434
diamond studs become her.”	225.59866531045833
Chapter XVII.	313.796344179034
BONACIEUX AT HOME	268.8140369954216
It was the second time the cardinal had mentioned these diamond studs	212.7532144159297
to the king. Louis XIII. was struck with this insistence, and began to	322.56370134608926
fancy that this recommendation concealed some mystery.	298.57625700578956
More than once the king had been humiliated by the cardinal, whose	201.6655686673033
police, without having yet attained the perfection of the modern	319.40648472996656
police, were excellent, being better informed than himself, even upon	218.02083777143818
what was going on in his own household. He hoped, then, in a	292.8108087768344
conversation with Anne of Austria, to obtain some information from that	260.6663456643636
conversation, and afterward to come upon his Eminence with some secret	260.6800575867867
which the cardinal either knew or did not know, but which, in either	347.19006116742037
case, would raise him infinitely in the eyes of his minister.	264.2318688161443
He went then to the queen, and according to custom accosted her with	259.90557592787127
fresh menaces against those who surrounded her. Anne of Austria lowered	326.5585544967364
her head, allowed the torrent to flow on without replying, hoping that	281.78501609210986
it would cease of itself; but this was not what Louis XIII. meant. Louis	266.17487040243225
XIII. wanted a discussion from which some light or other might break,	224.30985487391166
convinced as he was that the cardinal had some afterthought and was	332.99516657938614
preparing for him one of those terrible surprises which his Eminence	226.81744984028316
was so skillful in getting up. He arrived at this end by his	264.39148299611884
persistence in accusation.	357.1532294887845
“But,” cried Anne of Austria, tired of these vague attacks, “but, sire,	189.7565064199484
you do not tell me all that you have in your heart. What have I done,	324.03913575151967
then? Let me know what crime I have committed. It is impossible that	321.71782496434014
your Majesty can make all this ado about a letter written to my	331.09148287954446
brother.”	214.56013370592146
The king, attacked in a manner so direct, did not know what to answer;	337.08268341890755
and he thought that this was the moment for expressing the desire which	211.4093036324244
he was not going to have made until the evening before the fête.	200.33341523352615
“Madame,” said he, with dignity, “there will shortly be a ball at the	312.45128975145127
Hôtel de Ville. I wish, in order to honor our worthy aldermen, you	207.11063204657034
should appear in ceremonial costume, and above all, ornamented with the	170.4967401982128
diamond studs which I gave you on your birthday. That is my answer.”	319.678931335279
The answer was terrible. Anne of Austria believed that Louis XIII. knew	230.6525107435653
all, and that the cardinal had persuaded him to employ this long	195.4160710414556
dissimulation of seven or eight days, which, likewise, was	289.6951608178872
characteristic. She became excessively pale, leaned her beautiful hand	287.462408996055
upon a _console_, which hand appeared then like one of wax, and looking	206.11757450634173
at the king with terror in her eyes, she was unable to reply by a	181.3161887675899
single syllable.	177.60065219967882
“You hear, madame,” said the king, who enjoyed the embarrassment to its	239.62511232121926
full extent, but without guessing the cause. “You hear, madame?”	196.58200435049412
“Yes, sire, I hear,” stammered the queen.	208.27405836618632
“You will appear at this ball?”	299.2220089477989
“Yes.”	248.05465987384457
“With those studs?”	344.22796512031823
“Yes.”	331.6939445408955
The queen’s paleness, if possible, increased; the king perceived it,	298.7312679605735
and enjoyed it with that cold cruelty which was one of the worst sides	323.6443752594421
of his character.	262.2597261163644
“Then that is agreed,” said the king, “and that is all I had to say to	252.04104853673516
you.”	305.2572855800605
“But on what day will this ball take place?” asked Anne of Austria.	358.8421684625574
Louis XIII. felt instinctively that he ought not to reply to this	245.04568406635332
question, the queen having put it in an almost dying voice.	353.45601012887494
“Oh, very shortly, madame,” said he; “but I do not precisely recollect	268.55400481460276
the date of the day. I will ask the cardinal.”	206.8514094566182
“It was the cardinal, then, who informed you of this fête?”	276.3011803635093
“Yes, madame,” replied the astonished king; “but why do you ask that?”	341.88448001134134
“It was he who told you to invite me to appear with these studs?”	270.53811444801596
“That is to say, madame—”	189.9758418472886
“It was he, sire, it was he!”	282.2090041951485
“Well, and what does it signify whether it was he or I? Is there any	309.7784728237399
crime in this request?”	230.7814702559548
“No, sire.”	184.71944250378488
“Then you will appear?”	359.3223243040085
“Yes, sire.”	262.12671954280364
“That is well,” said the king, retiring, “that is well; I count upon	339.01764434950843
it.”	344.75545027463266
The queen made a curtsy, less from etiquette than because her knees	252.39316292557498
were sinking under her. The king went away enchanted.	215.2477485082988
“I am lost,” murmured the queen, “lost!—for the cardinal knows all, and	209.13093152941786
it is he who urges on the king, who as yet knows nothing but will soon	277.25635330901815
know everything. I am lost! My God, my God, my God!”	294.6512608409685
She knelt upon a cushion and prayed, with her head buried between her	277.2912474048182
palpitating arms.	232.90813508254973
In fact, her position was terrible. Buckingham had returned to London;	265.9990678640891
Mme. de Chevreuse was at Tours. More closely watched than ever, the	309.9574275918798
queen felt certain, without knowing how to tell which, that one of her	197.2370780796187
women had betrayed her. Laporte could not leave the Louvre; she had not	340.28407077206805
a soul in the world in whom she could confide. Thus, while	361.3899326985504
contemplating the misfortune which threatened her and the abandonment	247.02571305186092
in which she was left, she broke out into sobs and tears.	243.9905089672235
“Can I be of service to your Majesty?” said all at once a voice full of	282.33142386297004
sweetness and pity.	346.08072074597607
The queen turned sharply round, for there could be no deception in the	204.40161764509713
expression of that voice; it was a friend who spoke thus.	184.81796726544997
In fact, at one of the doors which opened into the queen’s apartment	279.2124914068842
appeared the pretty Mme. Bonacieux. She had been engaged in arranging	310.89828989125533
the dresses and linen in a closet when the king entered; she could not	267.2299506756565
get out and had heard all.	249.39293357454005
The queen uttered a piercing cry at finding herself surprised—for in	348.04376497359397
her trouble she did not at first recognize the young woman who had been	327.5491456892578
given to her by Laporte.	251.24158083137655
“Oh, fear nothing, madame!” said the young woman, clasping her hands	276.4206636707974
and weeping herself at the queen’s sorrows; “I am your Majesty’s, body	172.89824690601566
and soul, and however far I may be from you, however inferior may be my	230.14970643003483
position, I believe I have discovered a means of extricating your	196.9745600669281
Majesty from your trouble.”	200.66451578220514
“You, oh, heaven, you!” cried the queen; “but look me in the face. I am	172.98162684658217
betrayed on all sides. Can I trust in you?”	170.62597589084763
“Oh, madame!” cried the young woman, falling on her knees; “upon my	169.2985390397681
soul, I am ready to die for your Majesty!”	213.44822650702872
This expression sprang from the very bottom of the heart, and, like the	361.686130644806
first, there was no mistaking it.	274.59645171396176
“Yes,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “yes, there are traitors here; but by	277.2042713353807
the holy name of the Virgin, I swear that no one is more devoted to	364.54336392929224
your Majesty than I am. Those studs which the king speaks of, you gave	262.5511391373854
them to the Duke of Buckingham, did you not? Those studs were enclosed	296.73404353570925
in a little rosewood box which he held under his arm? Am I deceived? Is	333.8166247512646
it not so, madame?”	338.31107289297745
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured the queen, whose teeth chattered with	333.11521288650033
fright.	278.23390787396204
“Well, those studs,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “we must have them back	347.59244114817545
again.”	351.51987539907236
“Yes, without doubt, it is necessary,” cried the queen; “but how am I	325.46772469308314
to act? How can it be effected?”	207.19412674974004
“Someone must be sent to the duke.”	255.38194670107194
“But who, who? In whom can I trust?”	167.92279724325172
“Place confidence in me, madame; do me that honor, my queen, and I will	171.54321028152572
find a messenger.”	220.90482493644907
“But I must write.”	317.87021501719244
“Oh, yes; that is indispensable. Two words from the hand of your	323.82733339787205
Majesty and your private seal.”	329.24921130027565
“But these two words would bring about my condemnation, divorce,	329.40666615103635
exile!”	235.7590409190261
“Yes, if they fell into infamous hands. But I will answer for these two	173.36820041652507
words being delivered to their address.”	258.03257467543636
“Oh, my God! I must then place my life, my honor, my reputation, in	299.1859315071931
your hands?”	350.3395604564739
“Yes, yes, madame, you must; and I will save them all.”	257.17266938079126
“But how? Tell me at least the means.”	344.87842646647596
“My husband had been at liberty these two or three days. I have not yet	298.40090085532734
had time to see him again. He is a worthy, honest man who entertains	331.90833011164375
neither love nor hatred for anybody. He will do anything I wish. He	306.8621636965981
will set out upon receiving an order from me, without knowing what he	319.1964340277566
carries, and he will carry your Majesty’s letter, without even knowing	242.8510546924049
it is from your Majesty, to the address which is on it.”	196.63518182646698
The queen took the two hands of the young woman with a burst of	218.15397058672863
emotion, gazed at her as if to read her very heart, and, seeing nothing	225.5109952426546
but sincerity in her beautiful eyes, embraced her tenderly.	261.0530174937931
“Do that,” cried she, “and you will have saved my life, you will have	223.40589163127945
saved my honor!”	312.6533260975144
“Do not exaggerate the service I have the happiness to render your	360.9484057996388
Majesty. I have nothing to save for your Majesty; you are only the	222.10888029264967
victim of perfidious plots.”	303.809967038226
“That is true, that is true, my child,” said the queen, “you are	252.5625173278275
right.”	283.1871696633409
“Give me then, that letter, madame; time presses.”	282.4463663361857
The queen ran to a little table, on which were ink, paper, and pens.	323.60929953767123
She wrote two lines, sealed the letter with her private seal, and gave	351.5589073432892
it to Mme. Bonacieux.	182.86228877647275
“And now,” said the queen, “we are forgetting one very necessary	184.04043629962305
thing.”	322.724047242713
“What is that, madame?”	230.55684671573331
“Money.”	169.03248795918975
Mme. Bonacieux blushed.	348.7013647298548
“Yes, that is true,” said she, “and I will confess to your Majesty that	245.90059058168185
my husband—”	228.3655943417662
“Your husband has none. Is that what you would say?”	257.09233261412237
“He has some, but he is very avaricious; that is his fault.	279.69502644896727
Nevertheless, let not your Majesty be uneasy, we will find means.”	276.60557390137694
“And I have none, either,” said the queen. Those who have read the	234.90057189121381
_Memoirs_ of Mme. de Motteville will not be astonished at this reply.	342.8991816072132
“But wait a minute.”	237.46698493315267
Anne of Austria ran to her jewel case.	291.8180294730554
“Here,” said she, “here is a ring of great value, as I have been	192.9270561075688
assured. It came from my brother, the King of Spain. It is mine, and I	261.4043108053445
am at liberty to dispose of it. Take this ring; raise money with it,	171.3165306018374
and let your husband set out.”	242.04306243254257
“In an hour you shall be obeyed.”	286.07742765925127
“You see the address,” said the queen, speaking so low that Mme.	308.8869923174235
Bonacieux could hardly hear what she said, “To my Lord Duke of	309.241433807808
Buckingham, London.”	199.56564760430504
“The letter shall be given to himself.”	222.17011421821576
“Generous girl!” cried Anne of Austria.	350.1967747756223
Mme. Bonacieux kissed the hands of the queen, concealed the paper in	173.0213800948144
the bosom of her dress, and disappeared with the lightness of a bird.	357.5627193735056
Ten minutes afterward she was at home. As she told the queen, she had	288.5293079480407
not seen her husband since his liberation; she was ignorant of the	315.2233963080098
change that had taken place in him with respect to the cardinal—a	220.1361776953143
change which had since been strengthened by two or three visits from	266.16178736037836
the Comte de Rochefort, who had become the best friend of Bonacieux,	344.8363263251051
and had persuaded him, without much trouble, that no culpable	294.1843370757282
sentiments had prompted the abduction of his wife, but that it was only	341.91505999929996
a political precaution.	192.20508145142858
She found M. Bonacieux alone; the poor man was recovering with	270.3996386895313
difficulty the order in his house, in which he had found most of the	289.47422448787495
furniture broken and the closets nearly emptied—justice not being one	273.7147487965258
of the three things which King Solomon names as leaving no traces of	309.8952467866652
their passage. As to the servant, she had run away at the moment of her	326.51854227525246
master’s arrest. Terror had had such an effect upon the poor girl that	178.912989669765
she had never ceased walking from Paris till she reached Burgundy, her	328.3169870618983
native place.	222.3357950493723
The worthy mercer had, immediately upon re-entering his house, informed	268.96171956250845
his wife of his happy return, and his wife had replied by	312.2365813407921
congratulating him, and telling him that the first moment she could	320.0652338542202
steal from her duties should be devoted to paying him a visit.	301.2472911982145
This first moment had been delayed five days, which, under any other	166.75149899507204
circumstances, might have appeared rather long to M. Bonacieux; but he	282.97936824749684
had, in the visit he had made to the cardinal and in the visits	250.7211556502782
Rochefort had made him, ample subjects for reflection, and as everybody	311.3860753344258
knows, nothing makes time pass more quickly than reflection.	221.00217827557145
This was the more so because Bonacieux’s reflections were all	343.8721543753259
rose-colored. Rochefort called him his friend, his dear Bonacieux, and	213.9702122883109
never ceased telling him that the cardinal had a great respect for him.	235.64485992904474
The mercer fancied himself already on the high road to honors and	312.0104205482187
fortune.	294.8707663174815
On her side Mme. Bonacieux had also reflected; but, it must be	194.29708758018756
admitted, upon something widely different from ambition. In spite of	300.0403351110108
herself her thoughts constantly reverted to that handsome young man who	246.80672232544907
was so brave and appeared to be so much in love. Married at eighteen to	324.3726570770656
M. Bonacieux, having always lived among her husband’s friends—people	274.7008088478061
little capable of inspiring any sentiment whatever in a young woman	323.24165749078645
whose heart was above her position—Mme. Bonacieux had remained	314.030198770253
insensible to vulgar seductions; but at this period the title of	225.30368429007075
gentleman had great influence with the citizen class, and D’Artagnan	173.34841315813085
was a gentleman. Besides, he wore the uniform of the Guards, which,	292.5515972817992
next to that of the Musketeers, was most admired by the ladies. He was,	356.1215254328272
we repeat, handsome, young, and bold; he spoke of love like a man who	281.9438284547
did love and was anxious to be loved in return. There was certainly	236.76401454440963
enough in all this to turn a head only twenty-three years old, and Mme.	294.8125291949965
Bonacieux had just attained that happy period of life.	167.33229973685053
The couple, then, although they had not seen each other for eight days,	174.41801801917367
and during that time serious events had taken place in which both were	342.4436739392113
concerned, accosted each other with a degree of preoccupation.	171.9155563231584
Nevertheless, Bonacieux manifested real joy, and advanced toward his	171.9166157282829
wife with open arms. Madame Bonacieux presented her cheek to him.	328.90568913407634
“Let us talk a little,” said she.	318.37138797052734
“How!” said Bonacieux, astonished.	288.67891525306766
“Yes, I have something of the highest importance to tell you.”	252.1644160605656
“True,” said he, “and I have some questions sufficiently serious to put	228.01162479988153
to you. Describe to me your abduction, I pray you.”	267.59974796108287
“Oh, that’s of no consequence just now,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	331.89776148832215
“And what does it concern, then—my captivity?”	264.4193353288283
“I heard of it the day it happened; but as you were not guilty of any	358.47971732097454
crime, as you were not guilty of any intrigue, as you, in short, knew	328.3864839770364
nothing that could compromise yourself or anybody else, I attached no	233.425994359992
more importance to that event than it merited.”	256.2808387286004
“You speak very much at your ease, madame,” said Bonacieux, hurt at the	346.66279195278764
little interest his wife showed in him. “Do you know that I was plunged	182.677787779115
during a day and night in a dungeon of the Bastille?”	235.5686368091482
“Oh, a day and night soon pass away. Let us return to the object that	364.1026211727058
brings me here.”	332.6434778432879
“What, that which brings you home to me? Is it not the desire of seeing	254.37147597936973
a husband again from whom you have been separated for a week?” asked	291.56781941332605
the mercer, piqued to the quick.	197.28824585162755
“Yes, that first, and other things afterward.”	271.2486763891309
“Speak.”	270.4271990409313
“It is a thing of the highest interest, and upon which our future	261.32597384874737
fortune perhaps depends.”	236.85824647003867
“The complexion of our fortune has changed very much since I saw you,	171.0229817464088
Madame Bonacieux, and I should not be astonished if in the course of a	326.981571452148
few months it were to excite the envy of many folks.”	203.87404308810062
“Yes, particularly if you follow the instructions I am about to give	297.3585352758075
you.”	196.4109247071681
“Me?”	324.9623055492476
“Yes, you. There is good and holy action to be performed, monsieur, and	181.83045837992674
much money to be gained at the same time.”	192.74992717160086
Mme. Bonacieux knew that in talking of money to her husband, she took	246.02567892179687
him on his weak side. But a man, were he even a mercer, when he had	167.51316383154773
talked for ten minutes with Cardinal Richelieu, is no longer the same	249.08669962933652
man.	174.1918571331588
“Much money to be gained?” said Bonacieux, protruding his lip.	185.6067749124285
“Yes, much.”	315.7923522931352
“About how much?”	252.61158866428974
“A thousand pistoles, perhaps.”	245.6210417029585
“What you demand of me is serious, then?”	334.55988867653264
“It is indeed.”	172.01224836205049
“What must be done?”	260.71517102574427
“You must go away immediately. I will give you a paper which you must	255.07957885557585
not part with on any account, and which you will deliver into the	283.9649528929499
proper hands.”	336.50961564507253
“And whither am I to go?”	290.41450806517514
“To London.”	185.56340716797556
“I go to London? Go to! You jest! I have no business in London.”	245.37250822883055
“But others wish that you should go there.”	328.4505213091894
“But who are those others? I warn you that I will never again work in	318.7349106814886
the dark, and that I will know not only to what I expose myself, but	195.1979224538279
for whom I expose myself.”	260.47737165881534
“An illustrious person sends you; an illustrious person awaits you. The	225.45396463280127
recompense will exceed your expectations; that is all I promise you.”	296.3964289885074
“More intrigues! Nothing but intrigues! Thank you, madame, I am aware	198.08897360665844
of them now; Monsieur Cardinal has enlightened me on that head.”	307.99633066865476
“The cardinal?” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Have you seen the cardinal?”	346.151988130994
“He sent for me,” answered the mercer, proudly.	189.70077955418282
“And you responded to his bidding, you imprudent man?”	257.709635880791
“Well, I can’t say I had much choice of going or not going, for I was	259.5579988693885
taken to him between two guards. It is true also, that as I did not	228.5355632207366
then know his Eminence, if I had been able to dispense with the visit,	231.73111587794057
I should have been enchanted.”	313.69627069132184
“He ill-treated you, then; he threatened you?”	210.73847101236805
“He gave me his hand, and called me his friend. His friend! Do you hear	188.42901184443997
that, madame? I am the friend of the great cardinal!”	322.9920090178124
“Of the great cardinal!”	278.3238216721766
“Perhaps you would contest his right to that title, madame?”	196.6514071316103
“I would contest nothing; but I tell you that the favor of a minister	334.2368977994415
is ephemeral, and that a man must be mad to attach himself to a	207.35354563704186
minister. There are powers above his which do not depend upon a man or	262.8503377655344
the issue of an event; it is to these powers we should rally.”	350.71970457983093
“I am sorry for it, madame, but I acknowledge no other power but that	313.72932983494854
of the great man whom I have the honor to serve.”	178.9108995836561
“You serve the cardinal?”	360.8368383860886
“Yes, madame; and as his servant, I will not allow you to be concerned	254.55325210716666
in plots against the safety of the state, or to serve the intrigues of	243.3931781952552
a woman who is not French and who has a Spanish heart. Fortunately we	343.54071580337256
have the great cardinal; his vigilant eye watches over and penetrates	310.6919721879544
to the bottom of the heart.”	196.47425327534916
Bonacieux was repeating, word for word, a sentence which he had heard	365.51004911186874
from the Comte de Rochefort; but the poor wife, who had reckoned on her	201.92745742096176
husband, and who, in that hope, had answered for him to the queen, did	299.37585597782794
not tremble the less, both at the danger into which she had nearly cast	354.22044913184993
herself and at the helpless state to which she was reduced.	342.1576003865624
Nevertheless, knowing the weakness of her husband, and more	283.30371550648897
particularly his cupidity, she did not despair of bringing him round to	169.4278131909173
her purpose.	219.66570174659924
“Ah, you are a cardinalist, then, monsieur, are you?” cried she; “and	281.76365736940056
you serve the party of those who maltreat your wife and insult your	363.58532642177227
queen?”	216.0036192796469
“Private interests are as nothing before the interests of all. I am for	191.17532004325435
those who save the state,” said Bonacieux, emphatically.	182.53900241894755
“And what do you know about the state you talk of?” said Mme.	264.0965828220043
Bonacieux, shrugging her shoulders. “Be satisfied with being a plain,	338.32257990796694
straightforward citizen, and turn to that side which offers the most	327.56719373920583
advantages.”	207.6551231387389
“Eh, eh!” said Bonacieux, slapping a plump, round bag, which returned	332.92353798112435
of sound a money; “what do you think of this, Madame Preacher?”	260.59291183515654
“Whence comes that money?”	229.9956828755076
“You do not guess?”	166.63823679428882
“From the cardinal?”	181.049945996053
“From him, and from my friend the Comte de Rochefort.”	317.83542558979815
“The Comte de Rochefort! Why, it was he who carried me off!”	281.25432243707724
“That may be, madame!”	323.88774299477325
“And you receive silver from that man?”	185.98539129387473
“Have you not said that that abduction was entirely political?”	263.0509564890634
“Yes; but that abduction had for its object the betrayal of my	358.9580013659802
mistress, to draw from me by torture confessions that might compromise	337.8344290259545
the honor, and perhaps the life, of my august mistress.”	254.42700847013947
“Madame,” replied Bonacieux, “your august mistress is a perfidious	317.40730136698505
Spaniard, and what the cardinal does is well done.”	286.748905099328
“Monsieur,” said the young woman, “I know you to be cowardly,	228.2713596684528
avaricious, and foolish, but I never till now believed you infamous!”	312.41498409902624
“Madame,” said Bonacieux, who had never seen his wife in a passion, and	266.0450995026939
who recoiled before this conjugal anger, “madame, what do you say?”	341.5715258796437
“I say you are a miserable creature!” continued Mme. Bonacieux, who saw	297.46415875205685
she was regaining some little influence over her husband. “You meddle	356.4199963753583
with politics, do you—and still more, with cardinalist politics? Why,	258.702186726391
you sell yourself, body and soul, to the demon, the devil, for money!”	248.11879960208574
“No, to the cardinal.”	187.37510715041944
“It’s the same thing,” cried the young woman. “Who calls Richelieu	322.6201892687591
calls Satan.”	270.67749308369304
“Hold your tongue, hold your tongue, madame! You may be overheard.”	260.6210664664294
“Yes, you are right; I should be ashamed for anyone to know your	288.1855018508104
baseness.”	340.43678671798136
“But what do you require of me, then? Let us see.”	324.47182288847443
“I have told you. You must depart instantly, monsieur. You must	173.89226884846525
accomplish loyally the commission with which I deign to charge you, and	216.49779502265994
on that condition I pardon everything, I forget everything; and what is	271.5223064800257
more,” and she held out her hand to him, “I restore my love.”	193.71003991510526
Bonacieux was cowardly and avaricious, but he loved his wife. He was	285.10383912172773
softened. A man of fifty cannot long bear malice with a wife of	341.25425312361176
twenty-three. Mme. Bonacieux saw that he hesitated.	316.3579327014928
“Come! Have you decided?” said she.	229.90882147809398
“But, my dear love, reflect a little upon what you require of me.	269.8736920758023
London is far from Paris, very far, and perhaps the commission with	170.02043240984395
which you charge me is not without dangers?”	300.1100746423374
“What matters it, if you avoid them?”	199.03146847657703
“Hold, Madame Bonacieux,” said the mercer, “hold! I positively refuse;	166.48268006462172
intrigues terrify me. I have seen the Bastille. My! Whew! That’s a	248.1920244757547
frightful place, that Bastille! Only to think of it makes my flesh	322.9392358586672
crawl. They threatened me with torture. Do you know what torture is?	359.673599827428
Wooden points that they stick in between your legs till your bones	341.8227312157844
stick out! No, positively I will not go. And, _morbleu_, why do you not	214.2354925427154
go yourself? For in truth, I think I have hitherto been deceived in	288.10989898242894
you. I really believe you are a man, and a violent one, too.”	190.92796621266567
“And you, you are a woman—a miserable woman, stupid and brutal. You are	340.61365479682826
afraid, are you? Well, if you do not go this very instant, I will have	197.72023061362032
you arrested by the queen’s orders, and I will have you placed in the	336.21499609436194
Bastille which you dread so much.”	235.21623860314838
Bonacieux fell into a profound reflection. He weighed the two angers in	222.41851399925596
his brain—that of the cardinal and that of the queen; that of the	236.193175606845
cardinal predominated enormously.	170.32905546189417
“Have me arrested on the part of the queen,” said he, “and I—I will	305.78008358070247
appeal to his Eminence.”	236.94042288407593
At once Mme. Bonacieux saw that she had gone too far, and she was	237.17986835974034
terrified at having communicated so much. She for a moment contemplated	175.5185616542451
with fright that stupid countenance, impressed with the invincible	206.17188790760304
resolution of a fool that is overcome by fear.	198.99850484662517
“Well, be it so!” said she. “Perhaps, when all is considered, you are	313.1973054741022
right. In the long run, a man knows more about politics than a woman,	193.3056214704493
particularly such as, like you, Monsieur Bonacieux, have conversed with	305.02680844524605
the cardinal. And yet it is very hard,” added she, “that a man upon	204.0170354299875
whose affection I thought I might depend, treats me thus unkindly and	251.9046613558171
will not comply with any of my fancies.”	269.56356639204125
“That is because your fancies go too far,” replied the triumphant	206.5702492703501
Bonacieux, “and I mistrust them.”	345.4070571860077
“Well, I will give it up, then,” said the young woman, sighing. “It is	293.24907451551275
well as it is; say no more about it.”	333.26409950887125
“At least you should tell me what I should have to do in London,”	252.56442849598469
replied Bonacieux, who remembered a little too late that Rochefort had	265.6196477056143
desired him to endeavor to obtain his wife’s secrets.	359.77626294540227
“It is of no use for you to know anything about it,” said the young	346.2554062838342
woman, whom an instinctive mistrust now impelled to draw back. “It was	340.2815894703584
about one of those purchases that interest women—a purchase by which	170.27364038181406
much might have been gained.”	252.02901030635007
But the more the young woman excused herself, the more important	217.92857877119246
Bonacieux thought the secret which she declined to confide to him. He	336.3226068619888
resolved then to hasten immediately to the residence of the Comte de	166.5318419748045
Rochefort, and tell him that the queen was seeking for a messenger to	224.4670613777817
send to London.	274.41255548070717
“Pardon me for quitting you, my dear Madame Bonacieux,” said he; “but,	192.85289081821335
not knowing you would come to see me, I had made an engagement with a	341.6342659882115
friend. I shall soon return; and if you will wait only a few minutes	171.3108545508288
for me, as soon as I have concluded my business with that friend, as it	209.0796494373445
is growing late, I will come back and reconduct you to the Louvre.”	360.88792091643654
“Thank you, monsieur, you are not brave enough to be of any use to me	316.78088545893775
whatever,” replied Mme. Bonacieux. “I shall return very safely to the	341.95343508879006
Louvre all alone.”	314.71594235132966
“As you please, Madame Bonacieux,” said the ex-mercer. “Shall I see you	328.1809527969495
again soon?”	222.69456852247683
“Next week I hope my duties will afford me a little liberty, and I will	258.6235039613934
take advantage of it to come and put things in order here, as they must	310.3486769881607
necessarily be much deranged.”	259.40113048676494
“Very well; I shall expect you. You are not angry with me?”	209.36776415181114
“Not the least in the world.”	292.79152387923347
“Till then, then?”	336.39786771801766
“Till then.”	247.8372140781904
Bonacieux kissed his wife’s hand, and set off at a quick pace.	176.59197579908798
“Well,” said Mme. Bonacieux, when her husband had shut the street door	313.2164450918118
and she found herself alone; “that imbecile lacked but one thing: to	269.4878262383192
become a cardinalist. And I, who have answered for him to the queen—I,	251.3309082208265
who have promised my poor mistress—ah, my God, my God! She will take me	275.62506697823744
for one of those wretches with whom the palace swarms and who are	346.21557481728473
placed about her as spies! Ah, Monsieur Bonacieux, I never did love you	297.8395602700501
much, but now it is worse than ever. I hate you, and on my word you	279.3663960082822
shall pay for this!”	281.3616947759463
At the moment she spoke these words a rap on the ceiling made her raise	353.57688064720804
her head, and a voice which reached her through the ceiling cried,	292.0169343992401
“Dear Madame Bonacieux, open for me the little door on the alley, and I	217.16325597611586
will come down to you.”	333.96416417285775
Chapter XVIII.	311.22415868490293
LOVER AND HUSBAND	332.4796582898746
Ah, Madame,” said D’Artagnan, entering by the door which the young	236.8378732401138
woman opened for him, “allow me to tell you that you have a bad sort of	258.2213850182741
a husband.”	234.13425980373745
“You have, then, overheard our conversation?” asked Mme. Bonacieux,	240.4235861375522
eagerly, and looking at D’Artagnan with disquiet.	278.6712091070406
“The whole.”	207.69440418442417
“But how, my God?”	175.415036487302
“By a mode of proceeding known to myself, and by which I likewise	168.62997846337868
overheard the more animated conversation which he had with the	198.51614802034166
cardinal’s police.”	257.2638806440577
“And what did you understand by what we said?”	312.8416324414843
“A thousand things. In the first place, that, unfortunately, your	174.7113231041572
husband is a simpleton and a fool; in the next place, you are in	280.8244157444799
trouble, of which I am very glad, as it gives me an opportunity of	360.7755636466004
placing myself at your service, and God knows I am ready to throw	358.0654760791199
myself into the fire for you; finally, that the queen wants a brave,	220.9558838809381
intelligent, devoted man to make a journey to London for her. I have at	320.86673693900076
least two of the three qualities you stand in need of, and here I am.”	203.09292716595948
Mme. Bonacieux made no reply; but her heart beat with joy and secret	206.57309348751966
hope shone in her eyes.	333.916731526015
“And what guarantee will you give me,” asked she, “if I consent to	212.10394554895015
confide this message to you?”	285.44807614244786
“My love for you. Speak! Command! What is to be done?”	174.06151104553808
“My God, my God!” murmured the young woman, “ought I to confide such a	281.3916029441103
secret to you, monsieur? You are almost a boy.”	241.18397879971968
“I see that you require someone to answer for me?”	260.7230261044653
“I admit that would reassure me greatly.”	296.15608876376086
“Do you know Athos?”	355.40578618657656
“No.”	313.7632694246141
“Porthos?”	363.06511809400195
“No.”	182.4892881548467
“Aramis?”	222.75642450044177
“No. Who are these gentleman?”	189.7108252454459
“Three of the king’s Musketeers. Do you know Monsieur de Tréville,	333.90447681708076
their captain?”	341.1459881779243
“Oh, yes, him! I know him; not personally, but from having heard the	268.65889849639063
queen speak of him more than once as a brave and loyal gentleman.”	172.68909914360063
“You do not fear lest he should betray you to the cardinal?”	339.359007994631
“Oh, no, certainly not!”	324.42921034550386
“Well, reveal your secret to him, and ask him whether, however	322.0949766188112
important, however valuable, however terrible it may be, you may not	336.3551154674718
confide it to me.”	314.1172059845232
“But this secret is not mine, and I cannot reveal it in this manner.”	253.93886108803258
“You were about to confide it to Monsieur Bonacieux,” said D’Artagnan,	199.961153831695
with chagrin.	252.3356724103516
“As one confides a letter to the hollow of a tree, to the wing of a	253.828138285497
pigeon, to the collar of a dog.”	226.35246607495424
“And yet, me—you see plainly that I love you.”	273.95707802292696
“You say so.”	273.35747823116066
“I am an honorable man.”	313.88155130575603
“You say so.”	269.5912842361323
“I am a gallant fellow.”	354.38487402174405
“I believe it.”	290.79621310439603
“I am brave.”	237.83807411575054
“Oh, I am sure of that!”	300.7379957619804
“Then, put me to the proof.”	203.7504967179526
Mme. Bonacieux looked at the young man, restrained for a minute by a	234.02166451665448
last hesitation; but there was such an ardor in his eyes, such	333.6693789993051
persuasion in his voice, that she felt herself constrained to confide	271.03390390517825
in him. Besides, she found herself in circumstances where everything	255.17281745313832
must be risked for the sake of everything. The queen might be as much	315.3878487828579
injured by too much reticence as by too much confidence; and—let us	211.31554400606163
admit it—the involuntary sentiment which she felt for her young	357.95026750506315
protector decided her to speak.	301.7696653555497
“Listen,” said she; “I yield to your protestations, I yield to your	169.71746877461345
assurances. But I swear to you, before God who hears us, that if you	253.92815112830164
betray me, and my enemies pardon me, I will kill myself, while accusing	306.2740249646229
you of my death.”	254.8322864884041
“And I—I swear to you before God, madame,” said D’Artagnan, “that if I	182.23260789514066
am taken while accomplishing the orders you give me, I will die sooner	331.9932162327831
than do anything that may compromise anyone.”	297.3695709995242
Then the young woman confided in him the terrible secret of which	350.87881927330267
chance had already communicated to him a part in front of the	293.9413189183033
Samaritaine. This was their mutual declaration of love.	222.867145037194
D’Artagnan was radiant with joy and pride. This secret which he	250.06058417283788
possessed, this woman whom he loved! Confidence and love made him a	289.60738768798404
giant.	252.1186378870526
“I go,” said he; “I go at once.”	337.2839814994028
“How, you will go!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “and your regiment, your	194.60964998136163
captain?”	256.95133837366194
“By my soul, you had made me forget all that, dear Constance! Yes, you	225.82932390770756
are right; a furlough is needful.”	307.6917035328079
“Still another obstacle,” murmured Mme. Bonacieux, sorrowfully.	207.74921289244492
“As to that,” cried D’Artagnan, after a moment of reflection, “I shall	260.6787706650817
surmount it, be assured.”	364.2875125519388
“How so?”	222.93149036884887
“I will go this very evening to Tréville, whom I will request to ask	176.2435901253713
this favor for me of his brother-in-law, Monsieur Dessessart.”	247.2270951323001
“But another thing.”	324.7115626678502
“What?” asked D’Artagnan, seeing that Mme. Bonacieux hesitated to	223.31350248624972
continue.	277.8133313250256
“You have, perhaps, no money?”	210.07481862110197
“_Perhaps_ is too much,” said D’Artagnan, smiling.	233.6115940759036
“Then,” replied Mme. Bonacieux, opening a cupboard and taking from it	166.50905856146187
the very bag which a half hour before her husband had caressed so	180.16241891154203
affectionately, “take this bag.”	331.0244533971638
“The cardinal’s?” cried D’Artagnan, breaking into a loud laugh, he	338.8029693044185
having heard, as may be remembered, thanks to the broken boards, every	198.37575130608633
syllable of the conversation between the mercer and his wife.	251.00769036932786
“The cardinal’s,” replied Mme. Bonacieux. “You see it makes a very	266.2488532956461
respectable appearance.”	306.2275824281621
“_Pardieu_,” cried D’Artagnan, “it will be a double amusing affair to	178.62121621386808
save the queen with the cardinal’s money!”	247.75404796102643
“You are an amiable and charming young man,” said Mme. Bonacieux. “Be	288.98906943785084
assured you will not find her Majesty ungrateful.”	248.89247407868834
“Oh, I am already grandly recompensed!” cried D’Artagnan. “I love you;	175.60618974521336
you permit me to tell you that I do—that is already more happiness than	269.411358430281
I dared to hope.”	292.2654529002304
“Silence!” said Mme. Bonacieux, starting.	347.5603102604475
“What!”	265.13668194878784
“Someone is talking in the street.”	269.87961924526263
“It is the voice of—”	193.06125523921634
“Of my husband! Yes, I recognize it!”	234.91973768273732
D’Artagnan ran to the door and pushed the bolt.	293.09794047403267
“He shall not come in before I am gone,” said he; “and when I am gone,	359.72457948054296
you can open to him.”	210.5573513286128
“But I ought to be gone, too. And the disappearance of his money; how	228.66169569518505
am I to justify it if I am here?”	209.50930966466296
“You are right; we must go out.”	294.66282133703567
“Go out? How? He will see us if we go out.”	350.67790006051735
“Then you must come up into my room.”	347.7909337490489
“Ah,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “you speak that in a tone that frightens	277.05449713671857
me!”	335.06748614433945
Mme. Bonacieux pronounced these words with tears in her eyes.	304.4181759682827
D’Artagnan saw those tears, and much disturbed, softened, he threw	230.61681859009238
himself at her feet.	316.1026206222178
“With me you will be as safe as in a temple; I give you my word of a	248.813114230264
gentleman.”	287.97634089724585
“Let us go,” said she, “I place full confidence in you, my friend!”	216.70585656137226
D’Artagnan drew back the bolt with precaution, and both, light as	235.76771034341618
shadows, glided through the interior door into the passage, ascended	254.71894852338244
the stairs as quietly as possible, and entered D’Artagnan’s chambers.	191.41891895818995
Once there, for greater security, the young man barricaded the door.	343.71118253918337
They both approached the window, and through a slit in the shutter they	169.2056635831533
saw Bonacieux talking with a man in a cloak.	253.72154787276818
At sight of this man, D’Artagnan started, and half drawing his sword,	278.0277924955311
sprang toward the door.	251.55596269745402
It was the man of Meung.	341.37152305688784
“What are you going to do?” cried Mme. Bonacieux; “you will ruin us	275.23990208909447
all!”	190.7625419578822
“But I have sworn to kill that man!” said D’Artagnan.	188.31921454817672
“Your life is devoted from this moment, and does not belong to you. In	169.7552285377181
the name of the queen I forbid you to throw yourself into any peril	207.18632033140446
which is foreign to that of your journey.”	273.3926059210806
“And do you command nothing in your own name?”	207.94463539437868
“In my name,” said Mme. Bonacieux, with great emotion, “in my name I	243.1403203092009
beg you! But listen; they appear to be speaking of me.”	363.5286755083722
D’Artagnan drew near the window, and lent his ear.	345.5525638395502
M. Bonacieux had opened his door, and seeing the apartment, had	277.8024867500645
returned to the man in the cloak, whom he had left alone for an	248.63379237603883
instant.	233.85283369937807
“She is gone,” said he; “she must have returned to the Louvre.”	169.49277099850295
“You are sure,” replied the stranger, “that she did not suspect the	280.12295468497655
intentions with which you went out?”	302.9065491772154
“No,” replied Bonacieux, with a self-sufficient air, “she is too	228.0520806717912
superficial a woman.”	243.30256381957219
“Is the young Guardsman at home?”	245.19009251102204
“I do not think he is; as you see, his shutter is closed, and you can	216.6545549266539
see no light shine through the chinks of the shutters.”	199.57358481689346
“All the same, it is well to be certain.”	291.30931657993074
“How so?”	212.1690160842927
“By knocking at his door. Go.”	207.60611834897446
“I will ask his servant.”	216.24075539776436
Bonacieux re-entered the house, passed through the same door that had	356.02953868676354
afforded a passage for the two fugitives, went up to D’Artagnan’s door,	360.23420507465147
and knocked.	341.8086066718116
No one answered. Porthos, in order to make a greater display, had that	179.9392418981041
evening borrowed Planchet. As to D’Artagnan, he took care not to give	350.6125444822358
the least sign of existence.	308.92138832061903
The moment the hand of Bonacieux sounded on the door, the two young	289.22338110818254
people felt their hearts bound within them.	191.31862291253634
“There is nobody within,” said Bonacieux.	234.8115241974104
“Never mind. Let us return to your apartment. We shall be safer there	250.66365967506061
than in the doorway.”	176.40597658890593
“Ah, my God!” whispered Mme. Bonacieux, “we shall hear no more.”	324.0555258340237
“On the contrary,” said D’Artagnan, “we shall hear better.”	236.30732282458052
D’Artagnan raised the three or four boards which made his chamber	195.0714050073345
another ear of Dionysius, spread a carpet on the floor, went upon his	299.36234798024714
knees, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to stoop as he did toward the	357.6006738621996
opening.	346.78836323679695
“You are sure there is nobody there?” said the stranger.	284.7200514697202
“I will answer for it,” said Bonacieux.	199.15919743337332
“And you think that your wife—”	208.39853620328932
“Has returned to the Louvre.”	275.11025730130245
“Without speaking to anyone but yourself?”	362.46933851857847
“I am sure of it.”	279.5809801028332
“That is an important point, do you understand?”	244.21416398107442
“Then the news I brought you is of value?”	182.05136924274098
“The greatest, my dear Bonacieux; I don’t conceal this from you.”	208.59844714405892
“Then the cardinal will be pleased with me?”	293.82763099100595
“I have no doubt of it.”	235.8075597989518
“The great cardinal!”	269.23819762867157
“Are you sure, in her conversation with you, that your wife mentioned	248.2514157801248
no names?”	226.9551154769111
“I think not.”	353.58399399483994
“She did not name Madame de Chevreuse, the Duke of Buckingham, or	186.32295779072896
Madame de Vernet?”	255.98169091888568
“No; she only told me she wished to send me to London to serve the	322.8018376794697
interests of an illustrious personage.”	271.50398802466947
“The traitor!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux.	316.72068596141895
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, taking her hand, which, without thinking of	214.1319786510619
it, she abandoned to him.	334.1644838319363
“Never mind,” continued the man in the cloak; “you were a fool not to	292.90294928272095
have pretended to accept the mission. You would then be in present	244.8475253629133
possession of the letter. The state, which is now threatened, would be	259.8065249309191
safe, and you—”	224.5635596712622
“And I?”	170.33691365219016
“Well you—the cardinal would have given you letters of nobility.”	325.3689349099994
“Did he tell you so?”	347.10502876294044
“Yes, I know that he meant to afford you that agreeable surprise.”	344.0817653343592
“Be satisfied,” replied Bonacieux; “my wife adores me, and there is yet	215.70707819273161
time.”	187.54766198915556
“The ninny!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux.	196.93724952215433
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, pressing her hand more closely.	254.46104009519723
“How is there still time?” asked the man in the cloak.	322.1231947647083
“I go to the Louvre; I ask for Mme. Bonacieux; I say that I have	172.48312425260596
reflected; I renew the affair; I obtain the letter, and I run directly	285.1067384051781
to the cardinal.”	192.8013218791454
“Well, go quickly! I will return soon to learn the result of your	358.22808043860346
trip.”	352.46335960877377
The stranger went out.	285.59885320700056
“Infamous!” said Mme. Bonacieux, addressing this epithet to her	346.8109651527915
husband.	283.0736404655104
“Silence!” said D’Artagnan, pressing her hand still more warmly.	193.16209655010093
A terrible howling interrupted these reflections of D’Artagnan and Mme.	316.40203863907345
Bonacieux. It was her husband, who had discovered the disappearance of	307.9401943450133
the moneybag, and was crying “Thieves!”	289.31509661521784
“Oh, my God!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “he will rouse the whole quarter.”	360.96915451749487
Bonacieux called a long time; but as such cries, on account of their	213.77784823421152
frequency, brought nobody in the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and as lately the	166.38151092338455
mercer’s house had a bad name, finding that nobody came, he went out	269.32100117652436
continuing to call, his voice being heard fainter and fainter as he	314.21997182025086
went in the direction of the Rue du Bac.	342.3822859122612
“Now he is gone, it is your turn to get out,” said Mme. Bonacieux.	190.0095882556347
“Courage, my friend, but above all, prudence, and think what you owe to	359.168257468145
the queen.”	313.5607180433576
“To her and to you!” cried D’Artagnan. “Be satisfied, beautiful	279.8468034766013
Constance. I shall become worthy of her gratitude; but shall I likewise	168.19862379105754
return worthy of your love?”	187.69497573147632
The young woman only replied by the beautiful glow which mounted to her	210.103040115071
cheeks. A few seconds afterward D’Artagnan also went out enveloped in a	346.99314144026846
large cloak, which ill-concealed the sheath of a long sword.	334.64507098660215
Mme. Bonacieux followed him with her eyes, with that long, fond look	285.8288143670342
with which he had turned the angle of the street, she fell on her	351.62827391622966
knees, and clasping her hands, “Oh, my God,” cried she, “protect the	338.14077935490985
queen, protect me!”	355.38901877705075
Chapter XIX.	357.45666490111853
PLAN OF CAMPAIGN	190.5933503864983
D’Artagnan went straight to M. de Tréville’s. He had reflected that in	172.45550768868807
a few minutes the cardinal would be warned by this cursed stranger, who	177.2424076419915
appeared to be his agent, and he judged, with reason, he had not a	291.0375902702897
moment to lose.	224.3667996982577
The heart of the young man overflowed with joy. An opportunity	239.0678030985824
presented itself to him in which there would be at the same time glory	336.7071581777759
to be acquired, and money to be gained; and as a far higher	221.86403270943606
encouragement, it brought him into close intimacy with a woman he	294.0042057944263
adored. This chance did, then, for him at once more than he would have	221.40452518139955
dared to ask of Providence.	344.9081714353907
M. de Tréville was in his saloon with his habitual court of gentlemen.	166.11018369775172
D’Artagnan, who was known as a familiar of the house, went straight to	365.9467762406227
his office, and sent word that he wished to see him on something of	346.3778002305848
importance.	183.6734695063312
D’Artagnan had been there scarcely five minutes when M. de Tréville	349.80184099954647
entered. At the first glance, and by the joy which was painted on his	225.42872224007914
countenance, the worthy captain plainly perceived that something new	290.55396510510695
was on foot.	223.20245604127905
All the way along D’Artagnan had been consulting with himself whether	186.74920600791629
he should place confidence in M. de Tréville, or whether he should only	217.91650453346193
ask him to give him _carte blanche_ for some secret affair. But M. de	244.53518238064137
Tréville had always been so thoroughly his friend, had always been so	298.4408660784944
devoted to the king and queen, and hated the cardinal so cordially,	194.9434225923906
that the young man resolved to tell him everything.	331.95470664753583
“Did you ask for me, my good friend?” said M. de Tréville.	209.64352317618426
“Yes, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, lowering his voice, “and you will	326.4818643115543
pardon me, I hope, for having disturbed you when you know the	255.658351132413
importance of my business.”	309.72719361151564
“Speak, then, I am all attention.”	206.1954466095312
“It concerns nothing less,” said D’Artagnan, “than the honor, perhaps	294.90231954615354
the life of the queen.”	195.4691999892239
“What did you say?” asked M. de Tréville, glancing round to see if they	216.87180771483077
were surely alone, and then fixing his questioning look upon	240.97259611591772
D’Artagnan.	288.4420705451657
“I say, monsieur, that chance has rendered me master of a secret—”	356.9172691922865
“Which you will guard, I hope, young man, as your life.”	350.76032252269135
“But which I must impart to you, monsieur, for you alone can assist me	224.7579536020795
in the mission I have just received from her Majesty.”	329.36972083347877
“Is this secret your own?”	347.09904401505
“No, monsieur; it is her Majesty’s.”	340.25391233683644
“Are you authorized by her Majesty to communicate it to me?”	170.7273510225928
“No, monsieur, for, on the contrary, I am desired to preserve the	345.62942244637253
profoundest mystery.”	206.79201526569295
“Why, then, are you about to betray it to me?”	334.9283198593581
“Because, as I said, without you I can do nothing; and I am afraid you	284.56306795257825
will refuse me the favor I come to ask if you do not know to what end I	261.57842342798983
ask it.”	294.2429365541733
“Keep your secret, young man, and tell me what you wish.”	289.94383041916365
“I wish you to obtain for me, from Monsieur Dessessart, leave of	357.0024607851638
absence for fifteen days.”	269.4460877007295
“When?”	204.39521026666333
“This very night.”	267.76176449193247
“You leave Paris?”	322.4760149734741
“I am going on a mission.”	209.83375230648767
“May you tell me whither?”	204.77628093645285
“To London.”	216.91602300848785
“Has anyone an interest in preventing your arrival there?”	294.2688764938282
“The cardinal, I believe, would give the world to prevent my success.”	346.56328474840143
“And you are going alone?”	192.2970169357561
“I am going alone.”	284.67353261054706
“In that case you will not get beyond Bondy. I tell you so, by the	364.4284503954638
faith of de Tréville.”	341.4289067339233
“How so?”	240.26459449950428
“You will be assassinated.”	264.6965406751077
“And I shall die in the performance of my duty.”	209.25102121378637
“But your mission will not be accomplished.”	295.27157973217754
“That is true,” replied D’Artagnan.	273.34327576294777
“Believe me,” continued Tréville, “in enterprises of this kind, in	196.76864612041035
order that one may arrive, four must set out.”	254.20163659262468
“Ah, you are right, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan; “but you know Athos,	238.97495484612074
Porthos, and Aramis, and you know if I can dispose of them.”	352.8114802806533
“Without confiding to them the secret which I am not willing to know?”	213.13298383804536
“We are sworn, once for all, to implicit confidence and devotedness	356.55494323592035
against all proof. Besides, you can tell them that you have full	289.15488959364404
confidence in me, and they will not be more incredulous than you.”	199.70940525663974
“I can send to each of them leave of absence for fifteen days, that is	312.7097643173196
all—to Athos, whose wound still makes him suffer, to go to the waters	277.3371139510618
of Forges; to Porthos and Aramis to accompany their friend, whom they	227.46372045240494
are not willing to abandon in such a painful condition. Sending their	351.896750379192
leave of absence will be proof enough that I authorize their journey.”	271.5166348761536
“Thanks, monsieur. You are a hundred times too good.”	349.4646891477267
“Begone, then, find them instantly, and let all be done tonight! Ha!	325.68963440775565
But first write your request to Dessessart. Perhaps you had a spy at	317.6349852681663
your heels; and your visit, if it should ever be known to the cardinal,	257.45967667681685
will thus seem legitimate.”	320.16256475628006
D’Artagnan drew up his request, and M. de Tréville, on receiving it,	252.17681367820927
assured him that by two o’clock in the morning the four leaves of	239.36443905749715
absence should be at the respective domiciles of the travelers.	309.89345072038543
“Have the goodness to send mine to Athos’s residence. I should dread	168.3428877073134
some disagreeable encounter if I were to go home.”	294.74419455042784
“Be easy. Adieu, and a prosperous voyage. _A propos_,” said M. de	304.8456862322781
Tréville, calling him back.	205.36208305422628
D’Artagnan returned.	354.573242414257
“Have you any money?”	273.0475121874031
D’Artagnan tapped the bag he had in his pocket.	270.87043787403593
“Enough?” asked M. de Tréville.	333.34619278860237
“Three hundred pistoles.”	345.7944726890253
“Oh, plenty! That would carry you to the end of the world. Begone,	291.76433044002704
then!”	207.94074809522178
D’Artagnan saluted M. de Tréville, who held out his hand to him;	323.65411017761323
D’Artagnan pressed it with a respect mixed with gratitude. Since his	337.92865949899783
first arrival at Paris, he had had constant occasion to honor this	332.8596967002454
excellent man, whom he had always found worthy, loyal, and great.	326.0966866909157
His first visit was to Aramis, at whose residence he had not been since	167.1689936188322
the famous evening on which he had followed Mme. Bonacieux. Still	255.02294677588696
further, he had seldom seen the young Musketeer; but every time he had	357.4544183882762
seen him, he had remarked a deep sadness imprinted on his countenance.	210.78053441046657
This evening, especially, Aramis was melancholy and thoughtful.	300.92768649359084
D’Artagnan asked some questions about this prolonged melancholy. Aramis	222.52191077696608
pleaded as his excuse a commentary upon the eighteenth chapter of St.	271.08631739675815
Augustine, which he was forced to write in Latin for the following	208.76309975422234
week, and which preoccupied him a good deal.	317.2639250272915
After the two friends had been chatting a few moments, a servant from	337.84891412492493
M. de Tréville entered, bringing a sealed packet.	286.6570352022133
“What is that?” asked Aramis.	179.17503083980523
“The leave of absence Monsieur has asked for,” replied the lackey.	236.0184746740194
“For me! I have asked for no leave of absence.”	264.2353243731355
“Hold your tongue and take it!” said D’Artagnan. “And you, my friend,	279.55830450372594
there is a demipistole for your trouble; you will tell Monsieur de	299.0207497386445
Tréville that Monsieur Aramis is very much obliged to him. Go.”	284.5615932282507
The lackey bowed to the ground and departed.	301.03241569203385
“What does all this mean?” asked Aramis.	284.78714097862155
“Pack up all you want for a journey of a fortnight, and follow me.”	251.77548678826096
“But I cannot leave Paris just now without knowing—”	246.23389180331662
Aramis stopped.	259.0636964647522
“What is become of her? I suppose you mean—” continued D’Artagnan.	183.70027842688125
“Become of whom?” replied Aramis.	287.7872693144834
“The woman who was here—the woman with the embroidered handkerchief.”	203.3910862010514
“Who told you there was a woman here?” replied Aramis, becoming as pale	234.8073614707984
as death.	359.76677563523793
“I saw her.”	217.7600376745469
“And you know who she is?”	201.75184769742333
“I believe I can guess, at least.”	183.10748283608152
“Listen!” said Aramis. “Since you appear to know so many things, can	284.2961672448266
you tell me what is become of that woman?”	166.53663686425105
“I presume that she has returned to Tours.”	353.9874927053052
“To Tours? Yes, that may be. You evidently know her. But why did she	314.2148079677407
return to Tours without telling me anything?”	284.8550980653505
“Because she was in fear of being arrested.”	183.48547825660282
“Why has she not written to me, then?”	326.8533199703733
“Because she was afraid of compromising you.”	194.1162874319347
“D’Artagnan, you restore me to life!” cried Aramis. “I fancied myself	336.04037239391084
despised, betrayed. I was so delighted to see her again! I could not	263.91957089273825
have believed she would risk her liberty for me, and yet for what other	182.85326008645836
cause could she have returned to Paris?”	234.1072460905087
“For the cause which today takes us to England.”	359.6475826163834
“And what is this cause?” demanded Aramis.	268.00801067555733
“Oh, you’ll know it someday, Aramis; but at present I must imitate the	185.0283718409308
discretion of ‘the doctor’s niece.’”	348.5949054454522
Aramis smiled, as he remembered the tale he had told his friends on a	196.0942745956296
certain evening. “Well, then, since she has left Paris, and you are	266.4397757577097
sure of it, D’Artagnan, nothing prevents me, and I am ready to follow	243.70387857108824
you. You say we are going—”	195.30615711201966
“To see Athos now, and if you will come thither, I beg you to make	175.03072978265112
haste, for we have lost much time already. _A propos_, inform Bazin.”	263.08057895610096
“Will Bazin go with us?” asked Aramis.	330.8010790569016
“Perhaps so. At all events, it is best that he should follow us to	227.61302081250417
Athos’s.”	355.69617227636127
Aramis called Bazin, and, after having ordered him to join them at	319.72143237558464
Athos’s residence, said “Let us go then,” at the same time taking his	275.1897962416553
cloak, sword, and three pistols, opening uselessly two or three drawers	188.14791675384416
to see if he could not find stray coin. When well assured this search	303.3919127487871
was superfluous, he followed D’Artagnan, wondering to himself how this	184.2269704404761
young Guardsman should know so well who the lady was to whom he had	287.58600019782637
given hospitality, and that he should know better than himself what had	244.82290625371482
become of her.	262.4156603032118
Only as they went out Aramis placed his hand upon the arm of	301.4334851787214
D’Artagnan, and looking at him earnestly, “You have not spoken of this	361.0220349476464
lady?” said he.	279.7199179591559
“To nobody in the world.”	291.8020619115289
“Not even to Athos or Porthos?”	312.04601187518654
“I have not breathed a syllable to them.”	252.61923381468736
“Good enough!”	300.6269230969565
Tranquil on this important point, Aramis continued his way with	291.8381360228392
D’Artagnan, and both soon arrived at Athos’s dwelling. They found him	284.6334239801232
holding his leave of absence in one hand, and M. de Tréville’s note in	178.41209041651868
the other.	229.02591812958195
“Can you explain to me what signify this leave of absence and this	214.47270262176875
letter, which I have just received?” said the astonished Athos.	315.7190199629674
MY DEAR ATHOS,	218.02215051465998
    I wish, as your health absolutely requires it, that you should rest	314.98488134797174
    for a fortnight. Go, then, and take the waters of Forges, or any	258.7211466570485
    that may be more agreeable to you, and recuperate yourself as	308.75561883132923
    quickly as possible.	272.6919422164393
Yours affectionate,	227.31634171322156
DE TRÉVILLE	167.8579429740793
“Well, this leave of absence and that letter mean that you must follow	223.07556989511917
me, Athos.”	257.131479390985
“To the waters of Forges?”	311.3982787802231
“There or elsewhere.”	334.2193479098326
“In the king’s service?”	323.18701704895716
“Either the king’s or the queen’s. Are we not their Majesties’	308.8823359700956
servants?”	187.36714920987907
At that moment Porthos entered. “_Pardieu!_” said he, “here is a	241.66873970606855
strange thing! Since when, I wonder, in the Musketeers, did they grant	221.01036772434972
men leave of absence without their asking for it?”	328.92263996187864
“Since,” said D’Artagnan, “they have friends who ask it for them.”	337.96003964918873
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “it appears there’s something fresh here.”	172.6652708433236
“Yes, we are going—” said Aramis.	307.5486897013463
“To what country?” demanded Porthos.	268.1407780576074
“My faith! I don’t know much about it,” said Athos. “Ask D’Artagnan.”	310.47051296332324
“To London, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan.	186.23164045747006
“To London!” cried Porthos; “and what the devil are we going to do in	236.72202421158067
London?”	326.2748517544071
“That is what I am not at liberty to tell you, gentlemen; you must	172.60378512676175
trust to me.”	324.19658757293394
“But in order to go to London,” added Porthos, “money is needed, and I	294.958890834646
have none.”	234.73085416412079
“Nor I,” said Aramis.	167.68826170442878
“Nor I,” said Athos.	334.3603728016516
“I have,” replied D’Artagnan, pulling out his treasure from his pocket,	310.9783244991528
and placing it on the table. “There are in this bag three hundred	176.27060100089153
pistoles. Let each take seventy-five; that is enough to take us to	297.21955748860114
London and back. Besides, make yourselves easy; we shall not all arrive	235.04178460703986
at London.”	287.835879218851
“Why so?”	301.43240971730205
“Because, in all probability, some one of us will be left on the road.”	266.5150234982051
“Is this, then, a campaign upon which we are now entering?”	226.1357941167084
“One of a most dangerous kind, I give you notice.”	336.2897066407073
“Ah! But if we do risk being killed,” said Porthos, “at least I should	214.54858743762418
like to know what for.”	251.92453002071926
“You would be all the wiser,” said Athos.	272.554926861199
“And yet,” said Aramis, “I am somewhat of Porthos’s opinion.”	269.1731040010461
“Is the king accustomed to give you such reasons? No. He says to you	283.9436929106128
jauntily, ‘Gentlemen, there is fighting going on in Gascony or in	334.73936164472406
Flanders; go and fight,’ and you go there. Why? You need give	172.03357023921964
yourselves no more uneasiness about this.”	331.07740885501596
“D’Artagnan is right,” said Athos; “here are our three leaves of	241.84181154494416
absence which came from Monsieur de Tréville, and here are three	226.14194366327928
hundred pistoles which came from I don’t know where. So let us go and	224.684651377283
get killed where we are told to go. Is life worth the trouble of so	348.5331142617126
many questions? D’Artagnan, I am ready to follow you.”	307.9193020503606
“And I also,” said Porthos.	248.0849651333455
“And I also,” said Aramis. “And, indeed, I am not sorry to quit Paris;	352.7503282563479
I had need of distraction.”	223.83886477039317
“Well, you will have distractions enough, gentlemen, be assured,” said	235.24120072017053
D’Artagnan.	187.9231425194555
“And, now, when are we to go?” asked Athos.	334.0267250102789
“Immediately,” replied D’Artagnan; “we have not a minute to lose.”	361.4001583605844
“Hello, Grimaud! Planchet! Mousqueton! Bazin!” cried the four young	265.1453828740583
men, calling their lackeys, “clean my boots, and fetch the horses from	224.17673391298405
the hôtel.”	362.07229957878076
Each Musketeer was accustomed to leave at the general hôtel, as at a	170.64752204224612
barrack, his own horse and that of his lackey. Planchet, Grimaud,	289.2046105984547
Mousqueton, and Bazin set off at full speed.	277.43709105893447
“Now let us lay down the plan of campaign,” said Porthos. “Where do we	187.24429009711872
go first?”	297.6631402335051
“To Calais,” said D’Artagnan; “that is the most direct line to London.”	240.1988940664765
“Well,” said Porthos, “this is my advice—”	307.5618837036835
“Speak!”	217.08308704960658
“Four men traveling together would be suspected. D’Artagnan will give	198.23729538019484
each of us his instructions. I will go by the way of Boulogne to clear	319.9020615153219
the way; Athos will set out two hours after, by that of Amiens; Aramis	278.4905140301747
will follow us by that of Noyon; as to D’Artagnan, he will go by what	283.4282658996706
route he thinks is best, in Planchet’s clothes, while Planchet will	298.1940708735051
follow us like D’Artagnan, in the uniform of the Guards.”	202.24352622615763
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “my opinion is that it is not proper to allow	361.3533561939497
lackeys to have anything to do in such an affair. A secret may, by	250.07172686845345
chance, be betrayed by gentlemen; but it is almost always sold by	278.42214128558896
lackeys.”	252.0481366759852
“Porthos’s plan appears to me to be impracticable,” said D’Artagnan,	222.0613908599453
“inasmuch as I am myself ignorant of what instructions I can give you.	190.80675636212308
I am the bearer of a letter, that is all. I have not, and I cannot make	328.3976783553377
three copies of that letter, because it is sealed. We must, then, as it	223.89507508297973
appears to me, travel in company. This letter is here, in this pocket,”	222.4749154575291
and he pointed to the pocket which contained the letter. “If I should	173.0167680882842
be killed, one of you must take it, and continue the route; if he be	289.6411540124772
killed, it will be another’s turn, and so on—provided a single one	187.71904212340178
arrives, that is all that is required.”	342.1520216092158
“Bravo, D’Artagnan, your opinion is mine,” cried Athos, “Besides, we	206.5947268528114
must be consistent; I am going to take the waters, you will accompany	214.47542636418433
me. Instead of taking the waters of Forges, I go and take sea waters; I	175.94667287970935
am free to do so. If anyone wishes to stop us, I will show Monsieur de	219.25924783060594
Tréville’s letter, and you will show your leaves of absence. If we are	219.0733175800021
attacked, we will defend ourselves; if we are tried, we will stoutly	292.2862873651786
