maintain that we were only anxious to dip ourselves a certain number of	173.92508600075422
times in the sea. They would have an easy bargain of four isolated men;	216.97074462916035
whereas four men together make a troop. We will arm our four lackeys	266.4881495438033
with pistols and musketoons; if they send an army out against us, we	220.46579873919535
will give battle, and the survivor, as D’Artagnan says, will carry the	263.84104123987134
letter.”	257.9695227922448
“Well said,” cried Aramis; “you don’t often speak, Athos, but when you	255.18806016151
do speak, it is like St. John of the Golden Mouth. I agree to Athos’s	362.4387488376234
plan. And you, Porthos?”	326.7240235541075
“I agree to it, too,” said Porthos, “if D’Artagnan approves of it.	365.09966727608844
D’Artagnan, being the bearer of the letter, is naturally the head of	271.86268563568797
the enterprise; let him decide, and we will execute.”	232.55219371746642
“Well,” said D’Artagnan, “I decide that we should adopt Athos’s plan,	238.7132728289527
and that we set off in half an hour.”	293.47809456408925
“Agreed!” shouted the three Musketeers in chorus.	287.1317908798516
Each one, stretching out his hand to the bag, took his seventy-five	222.17000439870145
pistoles, and made his preparations to set out at the time appointed.	277.81266803499597
Chapter XX.	313.67843669970915
THE JOURNEY	365.2797031355926
At two o’clock in the morning, our four adventurers left Paris by the	245.21156627898762
Barrière St. Denis. As long as it was dark they remained silent; in	286.695999416409
spite of themselves they submitted to the influence of the obscurity,	341.6798946764291
and apprehended ambushes on every side.	242.5131603946981
With the first rays of day their tongues were loosened; with the sun	277.062570895568
gaiety revived. It was like the eve of a battle; the heart beat, the	334.058452277951
eyes laughed, and they felt that the life they were perhaps going to	174.7038415136327
lose, was, after all, a good thing.	327.89024292859085
Besides, the appearance of the caravan was formidable. The black horses	282.7600083563138
of the Musketeers, their martial carriage, with the regimental step of	200.4624485669059
these noble companions of the soldier, would have betrayed the most	315.86003562766484
strict incognito. The lackeys followed, armed to the teeth.	207.1673835709776
All went well till they arrived at Chantilly, which they reached about	190.8861279322011
eight o’clock in the morning. They needed breakfast, and alighted at	289.2084509472006
the door of an _auberge_, recommended by a sign representing St. Martin	312.9925669004133
giving half his cloak to a poor man. They ordered the lackeys not to	289.09884854001365
unsaddle the horses, and to hold themselves in readiness to set off	300.7708666322985
again immediately.	219.1135301047837
They entered the common hall, and placed themselves at table. A	268.1019190009697
gentleman, who had just arrived by the route of Dammartin, was seated	245.00157257324048
at the same table, and was breakfasting. He opened the conversation	334.7834886455123
about rain and fine weather; the travelers replied. He drank to their	278.89603302724595
good health, and the travelers returned his politeness.	329.0030678458231
But at the moment Mousqueton came to announce that the horses were	200.3811433477796
ready, and they were arising from table, the stranger proposed to	231.34163410104443
Porthos to drink the health of the cardinal. Porthos replied that he	284.69127049237585
asked no better if the stranger, in his turn, would drink the health of	347.80370490602303
the king. The stranger cried that he acknowledged no other king but his	323.12155196252183
Eminence. Porthos called him drunk, and the stranger drew his sword.	341.99158936165946
“You have committed a piece of folly,” said Athos, “but it can’t be	348.42660498435885
helped; there is no drawing back. Kill the fellow, and rejoin us as	185.11320164573644
soon as you can.”	224.62269978857833
All three remounted their horses, and set out at a good pace, while	216.7668475767548
Porthos was promising his adversary to perforate him with all the	357.85902795823375
thrusts known in the fencing schools.	190.11264816882618
“There goes one!” cried Athos, at the end of five hundred paces.	220.6126281010377
“But why did that man attack Porthos rather than any other one of us?”	247.3509424536412
asked Aramis.	193.2738873595709
“Because, as Porthos was talking louder than the rest of us, he took	294.50342841953136
him for the chief,” said D’Artagnan.	310.85304938114587
“I always said that this cadet from Gascony was a well of wisdom,”	227.43020781883175
murmured Athos; and the travelers continued their route.	319.4287485751771
At Beauvais they stopped two hours, as well to breathe their horses a	204.22279327329824
little as to wait for Porthos. At the end of two hours, as Porthos did	221.48668740105836
not come, not any news of him, they resumed their journey.	281.90970138162925
At a league from Beauvais, where the road was confined between two high	170.88535505164737
banks, they fell in with eight or ten men who, taking advantage of the	324.0062144073953
road being unpaved in this spot, appeared to be employed in digging	268.92389043332923
holes and filling up the ruts with mud.	362.5628586290263
Aramis, not liking to soil his boots with this artificial mortar,	307.50147654236434
apostrophized them rather sharply. Athos wished to restrain him, but it	166.78838494111653
was too late. The laborers began to jeer the travelers and by their	243.39447329523404
insolence disturbed the equanimity even of the cool Athos, who urged on	354.54450670574954
his horse against one of them.	353.30482113663504
Then each of these men retreated as far as the ditch, from which each	297.68524915385785
took a concealed musket; the result was that our seven travelers were	302.57863822931745
outnumbered in weapons. Aramis received a ball which passed through his	357.3090229193807
shoulder, and Mousqueton another ball which lodged in the fleshy part	229.8498609321097
which prolongs the lower portion of the loins. Therefore Mousqueton	333.1999951749755
alone fell from his horse, not because he was severely wounded, but not	276.05851061509685
being able to see the wound, he judged it to be more serious than it	176.9750026271043
really was.	307.7934101282416
“It was an ambuscade!” shouted D’Artagnan. “Don’t waste a charge!	182.64486084760662
Forward!”	251.77938028320494
Aramis, wounded as he was, seized the mane of his horse, which carried	176.9566577630643
him on with the others. Mousqueton’s horse rejoined them, and galloped	335.5759347344454
by the side of his companions.	331.96281184878865
“That will serve us for a relay,” said Athos.	342.7480935683317
“I would rather have had a hat,” said D’Artagnan. “Mine was carried	314.9528315730479
away by a ball. By my faith, it is very fortunate that the letter was	219.867062389372
not in it.”	339.85103732877513
“They’ll kill poor Porthos when he comes up,” said Aramis.	218.8091146464277
“If Porthos were on his legs, he would have rejoined us by this time,”	336.0756501691693
said Athos. “My opinion is that on the ground the drunken man was not	364.3886230444527
intoxicated.”	203.76801606838146
They continued at their best speed for two hours, although the horses	325.7845156905969
were so fatigued that it was to be feared they would soon refuse	219.05095397145797
service.	219.9548209033058
The travelers had chosen crossroads in the hope that they might meet	281.9987792474718
with less interruption; but at Crèvecœur, Aramis declared he could	365.1184981265011
proceed no farther. In fact, it required all the courage which he	246.46920842357162
concealed beneath his elegant form and polished manners to bear him so	242.29482455056336
far. He grew more pale every minute, and they were obliged to support	342.83096285182717
him on his horse. They lifted him off at the door of a cabaret, left	355.6288749070105
Bazin with him, who, besides, in a skirmish was more embarrassing than	231.49453923347284
useful, and set forward again in the hope of sleeping at Amiens.	221.2997568736788
“_Morbleu_,” said Athos, as soon as they were again in motion, “reduced	321.4155337829893
to two masters and Grimaud and Planchet! _Morbleu!_ I won’t be their	336.0332609949376
dupe, I will answer for it. I will neither open my mouth nor draw my	233.93016837408578
sword between this and Calais. I swear by—”	338.9929307738904
“Don’t waste time in swearing,” said D’Artagnan; “let us gallop, if our	276.95882707953314
horses will consent.”	328.84755644663744
And the travelers buried their rowels in their horses’ flanks, who thus	168.80716111334948
vigorously stimulated recovered their energies. They arrived at Amiens	219.3250473305912
at midnight, and alighted at the _auberge_ of the Golden Lily.	247.6848666594684
The host had the appearance of as honest a man as any on earth. He	260.31391286058334
received the travelers with his candlestick in one hand and his cotton	352.66120784181845
nightcap in the other. He wished to lodge the two travelers each in a	277.11882476952906
charming chamber; but unfortunately these charming chambers were at the	233.40899637379192
opposite extremities of the hôtel. D’Artagnan and Athos refused them.	168.70618504153975
The host replied that he had no other worthy of their Excellencies; but	214.28502814625335
the travelers declared they would sleep in the common chamber, each on	318.9960365159192
a mattress which might be thrown upon the ground. The host insisted;	188.80288471504497
but the travelers were firm, and he was obliged to do as they wished.	289.2001621825428
They had just prepared their beds and barricaded their door within,	303.3846700060117
when someone knocked at the yard shutter; they demanded who was there,	268.78331924874414
and recognizing the voices of their lackeys, opened the shutter. It was	218.17714209370163
indeed Planchet and Grimaud.	290.7823824296013
“Grimaud can take care of the horses,” said Planchet. “If you are	318.3662450615924
willing, gentlemen, I will sleep across your doorway, and you will then	339.8646874303879
be certain that nobody can reach you.”	356.2709776390428
“And on what will you sleep?” said D’Artagnan.	178.0369316551984
“Here is my bed,” replied Planchet, producing a bundle of straw.	209.3309159089847
“Come, then,” said D’Artagnan, “you are right. Mine host’s face does	167.31381549552617
not please me at all; it is too gracious.”	305.3566110736743
“Nor me either,” said Athos.	219.628205921227
Planchet mounted by the window and installed himself across the	320.4253546834043
doorway, while Grimaud went and shut himself up in the stable,	172.81394614964245
undertaking that by five o’clock in the morning he and the four horses	290.8981656658998
should be ready.	166.1741526709587
The night was quiet enough. Toward two o’clock in the morning somebody	238.61351511862188
endeavored to open the door; but as Planchet awoke in an instant and	221.68268788523756
cried, “Who goes there?” somebody replied that he was mistaken, and	297.1723987645141
went away.	353.88664878262784
At four o’clock in the morning they heard a terrible riot in the	340.62067694155616
stables. Grimaud had tried to waken the stable boys, and the stable	210.2482715826032
boys had beaten him. When they opened the window, they saw the poor lad	294.5184829898865
lying senseless, with his head split by a blow with a pitchfork.	251.99357127308292
Planchet went down into the yard, and wished to saddle the horses; but	336.4626046581659
the horses were all used up. Mousqueton’s horse which had traveled for	187.9712356381815
five or six hours without a rider the day before, might have been able	208.69297098732966
to pursue the journey; but by an inconceivable error the veterinary	329.97352464808137
surgeon, who had been sent for, as it appeared, to bleed one of the	192.68990734351573
host’s horses, had bled Mousqueton’s.	195.07173420370387
This began to be annoying. All these successive accidents were perhaps	300.6720013335425
the result of chance; but they might be the fruits of a plot. Athos and	241.90213444754224
D’Artagnan went out, while Planchet was sent to inquire if there were	311.669905831327
not three horses for sale in the neighborhood. At the door stood two	304.207305061335
horses, fresh, strong, and fully equipped. These would just have suited	297.8938011936025
them. He asked where their masters were, and was informed that they had	262.9023252456225
passed the night in the inn, and were then settling their bill with the	314.2203548747178
host.	295.95393528415525
Athos went down to pay the reckoning, while D’Artagnan and Planchet	198.82126292093025
stood at the street door. The host was in a lower and back room, to	347.76079863190904
which Athos was requested to go.	217.2121115850146
Athos entered without the least mistrust, and took out two pistoles to	209.4476003353734
pay the bill. The host was alone, seated before his desk, one of the	305.43021781745813
drawers of which was partly open. He took the money which Athos offered	365.51432032292735
to him, and after turning and turning it over and over in his hands,	284.2397073649445
suddenly cried out that it was bad, and that he would have him and his	303.2745011312245
companions arrested as forgers.	359.1026150781088
“You blackguard!” cried Athos, going toward him, “I’ll cut your ears	222.86479770243344
off!”	354.90846597744434
At the same instant, four men, armed to the teeth, entered by side	221.75515008488213
doors, and rushed upon Athos.	295.5818830688487
“I am taken!” shouted Athos, with all the power of his lungs. “Go on,	343.50460330153965
D’Artagnan! Spur, spur!” and he fired two pistols.	199.04371906786997
D’Artagnan and Planchet did not require twice bidding; they unfastened	344.85525547045813
the two horses that were waiting at the door, leaped upon them, buried	314.3693874800953
their spurs in their sides, and set off at full gallop.	346.9414219545997
“Do you know what has become of Athos?” asked D’Artagnan of Planchet,	189.61896897530352
as they galloped on.	342.69098232932436
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, “I saw one fall at each of his two	253.1457082898275
shots, and he appeared to me, through the glass door, to be fighting	296.7692628660715
with his sword with the others.”	217.33040958783812
“Brave Athos!” murmured D’Artagnan, “and to think that we are compelled	203.33504106127975
to leave him; maybe the same fate awaits us two paces hence. Forward,	316.2686970451566
Planchet, forward! You are a brave fellow.”	271.334248439451
“As I told you, monsieur,” replied Planchet, “Picards are found out by	304.6177441842487
being used. Besides, I am here in my own country, and that excites me.”	192.15410782768922
And both, with free use of the spur, arrived at St. Omer without	341.36772516003157
drawing bit. At St. Omer they breathed their horses with the bridles	330.77897232193175
passed under their arms for fear of accident, and ate a morsel from	287.0787941046201
their hands on the stones of the street, after they departed again.	365.7056934967827
At a hundred paces from the gates of Calais, D’Artagnan’s horse gave	176.79140529980126
out, and could not by any means be made to get up again, the blood	295.27772946662094
flowing from his eyes and his nose. There still remained Planchet’s	221.38486573196315
horse; but he stopped short, and could not be made to move a step.	251.26172725300478
Fortunately, as we have said, they were within a hundred paces of the	363.36710258620366
city; they left their two nags upon the high road, and ran toward the	185.23151548717152
quay. Planchet called his master’s attention to a gentleman who had	328.7355571119395
just arrived with his lackey, and only preceded them by about fifty	324.94625619314047
paces. They made all speed to come up to this gentleman, who appeared	204.4164462433592
to be in great haste. His boots were covered with dust, and he inquired	204.7985573501341
if he could not instantly cross over to England.	225.42161506183953
“Nothing would be more easy,” said the captain of a vessel ready to set	297.44962282245945
sail, “but this morning came an order to let no one leave without	342.0880656434032
express permission from the cardinal.”	181.06590559755722
“I have that permission,” said the gentleman, drawing the paper from	363.529739138453
his pocket; “here it is.”	282.14109084102097
“Have it examined by the governor of the port,” said the shipmaster,	180.89590126200542
“and give me the preference.”	169.56988342202612
“Where shall I find the governor?”	259.2673959643241
“At his country house.”	204.77594138934055
“And that is situated?”	178.54481126612657
“At a quarter of a league from the city. Look, you may see it from	188.29662892348543
here—at the foot of that little hill, that slated roof.”	330.9323456753784
“Very well,” said the gentleman. And, with his lackey, he took the road	178.97161663155288
to the governor’s country house.	219.68593085370378
D’Artagnan and Planchet followed the gentleman at a distance of five	176.91874613678806
hundred paces. Once outside the city, D’Artagnan overtook the gentleman	230.6519197570091
as he was entering a little wood.	290.3109009205092
“Monsieur, you appear to be in great haste?”	247.46780917112784
“No one can be more so, monsieur.”	355.2139008301051
“I am sorry for that,” said D’Artagnan; “for as I am in great haste	208.15740750897456
likewise, I wish to beg you to render me a service.”	214.03314836966615
“What?”	193.8441112397497
“To let me sail first.”	277.0539411699582
“That’s impossible,” said the gentleman; “I have traveled sixty leagues	248.14914664194532
in forty hours, and by tomorrow at midday I must be in London.”	224.34900529940018
“I have performed that same distance in forty hours, and by ten o’clock	267.8392326744671
in the morning I must be in London.”	265.19622873796504
“Very sorry, monsieur; but I was here first, and will not sail second.”	202.64098375809942
“I am sorry, too, monsieur; but I arrived second, and must sail first.”	274.98431074199584
“The king’s service!” said the gentleman.	231.1625943490914
“My own service!” said D’Artagnan.	356.31590559700277
“But this is a needless quarrel you seek with me, as it seems to me.”	265.6845721662562
“_Parbleu!_ What do you desire it to be?”	304.94749961166985
“What do you want?”	287.997558788765
“Would you like to know?”	362.6631273152623
“Certainly.”	170.70468053686042
“Well, then, I wish that order of which you are bearer, seeing that I	346.3006902708862
have not one of my own and must have one.”	181.0191267342831
“You jest, I presume.”	232.28634193261243
“I never jest.”	278.06223067546625
“Let me pass!”	288.13012450184937
“You shall not pass.”	230.84327053901018
“My brave young man, I will blow out your brains. _Hola_, Lubin, my	253.13079263670656
pistols!”	207.2014879139005
“Planchet,” called out D’Artagnan, “take care of the lackey; I will	360.2802634233135
manage the master.”	249.90517439884468
Planchet, emboldened by the first exploit, sprang upon Lubin; and being	267.7133178786698
strong and vigorous, he soon got him on the broad of his back, and	229.26566745401084
placed his knee upon his breast.	169.90520383273227
“Go on with your affair, monsieur,” cried Planchet; “I have finished	258.3604942606065
mine.”	354.54045515769644
Seeing this, the gentleman drew his sword, and sprang upon D’Artagnan;	264.2719876885305
but he had too strong an adversary. In three seconds D’Artagnan had	263.57248443716674
wounded him three times, exclaiming at each thrust, “One for Athos, one	336.6245662974443
for Porthos; and one for Aramis!”	214.16570440275007
At the third hit the gentleman fell like a log. D’Artagnan believed him	276.76489478418466
to be dead, or at least insensible, and went toward him for the purpose	277.32640821595623
of taking the order; but the moment he extended his hand to search for	323.2694427539152
it, the wounded man, who had not dropped his sword, plunged the point	219.6039415279727
into D’Artagnan’s breast, crying, “One for you!”	174.25748001848282
“And one for me—the best for last!” cried D’Artagnan, furious, nailing	344.752629999647
him to the earth with a fourth thrust through his body.	316.783235749814
This time the gentleman closed his eyes and fainted. D’Artagnan	183.26737889839544
searched his pockets, and took from one of them the order for the	249.7184051160578
passage. It was in the name of Comte de Wardes.	329.16407432299377
Then, casting a glance on the handsome young man, who was scarcely	214.27618228874303
twenty-five years of age, and whom he was leaving in his gore, deprived	359.4365919147881
of sense and perhaps dead, he gave a sigh for that unaccountable	208.41225693417013
destiny which leads men to destroy each other for the interests of	179.92799769535682
people who are strangers to them and who often do not even know that	301.50377158289996
they exist. But he was soon aroused from these reflections by Lubin,	338.4359692280408
who uttered loud cries and screamed for help with all his might.	335.53228956336903
Planchet grasped him by the throat, and pressed as hard as he could.	268.04205371415793
“Monsieur,” said he, “as long as I hold him in this manner, he can’t	323.2197932008367
cry, I’ll be bound; but as soon as I let go he will howl again. I know	177.68801428360436
him for a Norman, and Normans are obstinate.”	321.7700915635495
In fact, tightly held as he was, Lubin endeavored still to cry out.	191.88261321598773
“Stay!” said D’Artagnan; and taking out his handkerchief, he gagged	281.12349870378233
him.	188.05819434910347
“Now,” said Planchet, “let us bind him to a tree.”	291.7949695953936
This being properly done, they drew the Comte de Wardes close to his	252.22489215938646
servant; and as night was approaching, and as the wounded man and the	186.91151640135791
bound man were at some little distance within the wood, it was evident	335.2902410728184
they were likely to remain there till the next day.	300.2412261690379
“And now,” said D’Artagnan, “to the Governor’s.”	205.4207949122145
“But you are wounded, it seems,” said Planchet.	273.13877232140965
“Oh, that’s nothing! Let us attend to what is more pressing first, and	353.78367532451796
then we will attend to my wound; besides, it does not seem very	357.2366264678949
dangerous.”	278.7638961470544
And they both set forward as fast as they could toward the country	245.35817988508896
house of the worthy functionary.	281.0927387521426
The Comte de Wardes was announced, and D’Artagnan was introduced.	204.66275948364927
“You have an order signed by the cardinal?” said the governor.	215.652940837489
“Yes, monsieur,” replied D’Artagnan; “here it is.”	313.8745159565153
“Ah, ah! It is quite regular and explicit,” said the governor.	244.67141136627276
“Most likely,” said D’Artagnan; “I am one of his most faithful	316.5830115481417
servants.”	267.11988538376767
“It appears that his Eminence is anxious to prevent someone from	311.4652521601047
crossing to England?”	217.16952766389159
“Yes; a certain D’Artagnan, a Béarnese gentleman who left Paris in	359.555776233683
company with three of his friends, with the intention of going to	312.9968807515314
London.”	268.7547814019372
“Do you know him personally?” asked the governor.	238.66263204757593
“Whom?”	295.27956842022303
“This D’Artagnan.”	347.2401613757027
“Perfectly well.”	210.03398358735524
“Describe him to me, then.”	207.52388458490958
“Nothing more easy.”	321.1529256561156
And D’Artagnan gave, feature for feature, a description of the Comte de	356.6923006911834
Wardes.	227.09861653029913
“Is he accompanied?”	170.18618862453613
“Yes; by a lackey named Lubin.”	259.06029313217806
“We will keep a sharp lookout for them; and if we lay hands on them his	259.3322378057994
Eminence may be assured they will be reconducted to Paris under a good	197.5017072311723
escort.”	246.717086361614
“And by doing so, Monsieur the Governor,” said D’Artagnan, “you will	228.19510264514935
deserve well of the cardinal.”	346.3579585661214
“Shall you see him on your return, Monsieur Count?”	306.1525503702569
“Without a doubt.”	282.6090800302615
“Tell him, I beg you, that I am his humble servant.”	216.18822639914055
“I will not fail.”	349.0492288261139
Delighted with this assurance the governor countersigned the passport	235.66769495390315
and delivered it to D’Artagnan. D’Artagnan lost no time in useless	186.76054981251423
compliments. He thanked the governor, bowed, and departed. Once	223.93018556769388
outside, he and Planchet set off as fast as they could; and by making a	358.19473391025565
long detour avoided the wood and reentered the city by another gate.	331.03077915282245
The vessel was quite ready to sail, and the captain was waiting on the	356.1044492359475
wharf. “Well?” said he, on perceiving D’Artagnan.	345.5494858670531
“Here is my pass countersigned,” said the latter.	195.16816308208803
“And that other gentleman?	279.2626708529973
“He will not go today,” said D’Artagnan; “but here, I’ll pay you for us	245.80676738791874
two.”	307.71669196297717
“In that case let us go,” said the shipmaster.	268.13526706092097
“Let us go,” repeated D’Artagnan.	341.0633219064107
He leaped with Planchet into the boat, and five minutes after they were	177.55791978165382
on board. It was time; for they had scarcely sailed half a league, when	242.2342356348966
D’Artagnan saw a flash and heard a detonation. It was the cannon which	268.9378399267664
announced the closing of the port.	360.77557584815935
He had now leisure to look to his wound. Fortunately, as D’Artagnan had	208.56038084315122
thought, it was not dangerous. The point of the sword had touched a	188.95455737163954
rib, and glanced along the bone. Still further, his shirt had stuck to	277.02659128674287
the wound, and he had lost only a few drops of blood.	352.0269839300054
D’Artagnan was worn out with fatigue. A mattress was laid upon the deck	256.35472710211957
for him. He threw himself upon it, and fell asleep.	169.99232185236687
On the morrow, at break of day, they were still three or four leagues	321.2847597542373
from the coast of England. The breeze had been so light all night, they	260.89505907887957
had made but little progress. At ten o’clock the vessel cast anchor in	351.38121138576605
the harbor of Dover, and at half past ten D’Artagnan placed his foot on	170.07649934863807
English land, crying, “Here I am at last!”	188.15759414361395
But that was not all; they must get to London. In England the post was	352.5836519795497
well served. D’Artagnan and Planchet took each a post horse, and a	221.50156851473525
postillion rode before them. In a few hours they were in the capital.	204.97946924659996
D’Artagnan did not know London; he did not know a word of English; but	201.91611396777506
he wrote the name of Buckingham on a piece of paper, and everyone	243.74091716121734
pointed out to him the way to the duke’s hôtel.	212.5916648790519
The duke was at Windsor hunting with the king. D’Artagnan inquired for	319.47693044641187
the confidential valet of the duke, who, having accompanied him in all	347.22339791709265
his voyages, spoke French perfectly well; he told him that he came from	306.85244413292014
Paris on an affair of life and death, and that he must speak with his	347.2326014766134
master instantly.	202.99622443853733
The confidence with which D’Artagnan spoke convinced Patrick, which was	362.53408791399073
the name of this minister of the minister. He ordered two horses to be	331.02124396375257
saddled, and himself went as guide to the young Guardsman. As for	287.63109524173564
Planchet, he had been lifted from his horse as stiff as a rush; the	207.1608870191223
poor lad’s strength was almost exhausted. D’Artagnan seemed iron.	281.4955960015169
On their arrival at the castle they learned that Buckingham and the	214.60693498208173
king were hawking in the marshes two or three leagues away. In twenty	188.51663840158525
minutes they were on the spot named. Patrick soon caught the sound of	256.48183397656624
his master’s voice calling his falcon.	352.65993637742304
“Whom must I announce to my Lord Duke?” asked Patrick.	296.9786887958368
“The young man who one evening sought a quarrel with him on the Pont	304.55718136462167
Neuf, opposite the Samaritaine.”	325.30955573541587
“A singular introduction!”	170.95363708644638
“You will find that it is as good as another.”	243.33406089539127
Patrick galloped off, reached the duke, and announced to him in the	278.0430799925285
terms directed that a messenger awaited him.	224.22007745612288
Buckingham at once remembered the circumstance, and suspecting that	180.5102353627193
something was going on in France of which it was necessary he should be	169.22790570769837
informed, he only took the time to inquire where the messenger was, and	360.54941296061133
recognizing from afar the uniform of the Guards, he put his horse into	194.8932331037466
a gallop, and rode straight up to D’Artagnan. Patrick discreetly kept	341.73034539473736
in the background.	304.43044376403003
“No misfortune has happened to the queen?” cried Buckingham, the	186.25946326929554
instant he came up, throwing all his fear and love into the question.	362.49572707475824
“I believe not; nevertheless I believe she runs some great peril from	216.6677634315557
which your Grace alone can extricate her.”	347.90931524621135
“I!” cried Buckingham. “What is it? I should be too happy to be of any	204.66894158243332
service to her. Speak, speak!”	179.76765987018405
“Take this letter,” said D’Artagnan.	301.16400417033253
“This letter! From whom comes this letter?”	276.72041445127246
“From her Majesty, as I think.”	174.0019502807633
“From her Majesty!” said Buckingham, becoming so pale that D’Artagnan	202.3220843679823
feared he would faint as he broke the seal.	264.3703815197965
“What is this rent?” said he, showing D’Artagnan a place where it had	297.11456074510653
been pierced through.	312.2098886247333
“Ah,” said D’Artagnan, “I did not see that; it was the sword of the	311.3468138914381
Comte de Wardes which made that hole, when he gave me a good thrust in	221.0508566349954
the breast.”	283.7031135519251
“You are wounded?” asked Buckingham, as he opened the letter.	280.06475895075005
“Oh, nothing but a scratch,” said D’Artagnan.	176.62465216050654
“Just heaven, what have I read?” cried the duke. “Patrick, remain here,	181.8219113259649
or rather join the king, wherever he may be, and tell his Majesty that	227.5736551319048
I humbly beg him to excuse me, but an affair of the greatest importance	365.2273157943187
recalls me to London. Come, monsieur, come!” and both set off towards	317.6937029166244
the capital at full gallop.	173.27993358281398
Chapter XXI.	279.5607252439217
THE COUNTESS DE WINTER	300.5054715389296
As they rode along, the duke endeavored to draw from D’Artagnan, not	278.9233260222822
all that had happened, but what D’Artagnan himself knew. By adding all	283.97516482367496
that he heard from the mouth of the young man to his own remembrances,	292.0867569741737
he was enabled to form a pretty exact idea of a position of the	333.328261663729
seriousness of which, for the rest, the queen’s letter, short but	297.7973722162511
explicit, gave him the clue. But that which astonished him most was	326.7378456385013
that the cardinal, so deeply interested in preventing this young man	249.77221483150709
from setting his foot in England, had not succeeded in arresting him on	247.8554499514662
the road. It was then, upon the manifestation of this astonishment,	328.41600184785955
that D’Artagnan related to him the precaution taken, and how, thanks to	332.4057737011224
the devotion of his three friends, whom he had left scattered and	204.46821347493798
bleeding on the road, he had succeeded in coming off with a single	176.6679130723149
sword thrust, which had pierced the queen’s letter and for which he had	183.2094423331449
repaid M. de Wardes with such terrible coin. While he was listening to	192.65816168737814
this recital, delivered with the greatest simplicity, the duke looked	254.67216136842873
from time to time at the young man with astonishment, as if he could	183.65050139750602
not comprehend how so much prudence, courage, and devotedness could be	249.64816747346768
allied with a countenance which indicated not more than twenty years.	225.29028943869451
The horses went like the wind, and in a few minutes they were at the	279.9883037949676
gates of London. D’Artagnan imagined that on arriving in town the duke	179.2521774899604
would slacken his pace, but it was not so. He kept on his way at the	250.1651837508125
same rate, heedless about upsetting those whom he met on the road. In	302.02191655225647
fact, in crossing the city two or three accidents of this kind	206.32451646913267
happened; but Buckingham did not even turn his head to see what became	298.37473124684027
of those he had knocked down. D’Artagnan followed him amid cries which	335.1582885285229
strongly resembled curses.	234.33342831004296
On entering the court of his hôtel, Buckingham sprang from his horse,	306.53512812226097
and without thinking what became of the animal, threw the bridle on his	267.9244296141855
neck, and sprang toward the vestibule. D’Artagnan did the same, with a	202.93955175458063
little more concern, however, for the noble creatures, whose merits he	181.3931655903923
fully appreciated; but he had the satisfaction of seeing three or four	237.21858235399603
grooms run from the kitchens and the stables, and busy themselves with	336.7450393992464
the steeds.	216.7706178601243
The duke walked so fast that D’Artagnan had some trouble in keeping up	263.2391923754605
with him. He passed through several apartments, of an elegance of which	233.64632542241517
even the greatest nobles of France had not even an idea, and arrived at	222.36901317382035
length in a bedchamber which was at once a miracle of taste and of	345.59974492751314
richness. In the alcove of this chamber was a door concealed in the	200.98607107306177
tapestry which the duke opened with a little gold key which he wore	281.3128778489657
suspended from his neck by a chain of the same metal. With discretion	365.6421959502703
D’Artagnan remained behind; but at the moment when Buckingham crossed	300.85164912279265
the threshold, he turned round, and seeing the hesitation of the young	315.41438749595767
man, “Come in!” cried he, “and if you have the good fortune to be	215.57645966996805
admitted to her Majesty’s presence, tell her what you have seen.”	183.8741594055802
Encouraged by this invitation, D’Artagnan followed the duke, who closed	282.2372693415269
the door after them. The two found themselves in a small chapel covered	263.97702436619284
with a tapestry of Persian silk worked with gold, and brilliantly	334.30385652593225
lighted with a vast number of candles. Over a species of altar, and	254.03239668398948
beneath a canopy of blue velvet, surmounted by white and red plumes,	274.36920517176344
was a full-length portrait of Anne of Austria, so perfect in its	252.38122808740985
resemblance that D’Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise on beholding it.	191.06252252946817
One might believe the queen was about to speak. On the altar, and	344.0635569376425
beneath the portrait, was the casket containing the diamond studs.	350.2015067376391
The duke approached the altar, knelt as a priest might have done before	224.67994570480948
a crucifix, and opened the casket. “There,” said he, drawing from the	249.4628522952185
casket a large bow of blue ribbon all sparkling with diamonds, “there	169.08518385191664
are the precious studs which I have taken an oath should be buried with	255.76156143913568
me. The queen gave them to me, the queen requires them again. Her will	176.82523671568808
be done, like that of God, in all things.”	179.83878094838477
Then, he began to kiss, one after the other, those dear studs with	309.86870361487945
which he was about to part. All at once he uttered a terrible cry.	171.06277317283238
“What is the matter?” exclaimed D’Artagnan, anxiously; “what has	213.24137939712688
happened to you, my Lord?”	257.78787894215606
“All is lost!” cried Buckingham, becoming as pale as a corpse; “two of	349.81598927718926
the studs are wanting, there are only ten.”	301.0273907243095
“Can you have lost them, my Lord, or do you think they have been	200.80374786041003
stolen?”	281.04650220823214
“They have been stolen,” replied the duke, “and it is the cardinal who	247.21438941551628
has dealt this blow. Hold; see! The ribbons which held them have been	346.47058136958475
cut with scissors.”	330.70618847339233
“If my Lord suspects they have been stolen, perhaps the person who	213.2705612358385
stole them still has them in his hands.”	263.56372499319673
“Wait, wait!” said the duke. “The only time I have worn these studs was	294.830228958602
at a ball given by the king eight days ago at Windsor. The Comtesse de	363.26056949232157
Winter, with whom I had quarreled, became reconciled to me at that	361.94211141018917
ball. That reconciliation was nothing but the vengeance of a jealous	248.62370429497855
woman. I have never seen her from that day. The woman is an agent of	282.0343861607908
the cardinal.”	243.67846417942013
“He has agents, then, throughout the world?” cried D’Artagnan.	359.3255194962819
“Oh, yes,” said Buckingham, grating his teeth with rage. “Yes, he is a	193.14255275923375
terrible antagonist. But when is this ball to take place?”	194.4418245352354
“Monday next.”	279.4160583381722
“Monday next! Still five days before us. That’s more time than we want.	312.4411763091499
Patrick!” cried the duke, opening the door of the chapel, “Patrick!”	344.86140432625734
His confidential valet appeared.	364.86332918098594
“My jeweler and my secretary.”	230.4732209082115
The valet went out with a mute promptitude which showed him accustomed	294.42518235042235
to obey blindly and without reply.	179.52196678264352
But although the jeweler had been mentioned first, it was the secretary	198.18823684239987
who first made his appearance. This was simply because he lived in the	308.7556349892934
hôtel. He found Buckingham seated at a table in his bedchamber, writing	175.0551626556663
orders with his own hand.	328.79317770270154
“Mr. Jackson,” said he, “go instantly to the Lord Chancellor, and tell	272.2536798438021
him that I charge him with the execution of these orders. I wish them	328.49337561328286
to be promulgated immediately.”	248.177020213076
“But, my Lord, if the Lord Chancellor interrogates me upon the motives	242.27497968848257
which may have led your Grace to adopt such an extraordinary measure,	203.45260041232476
what shall I reply?”	201.28604920607214
“That such is my pleasure, and that I answer for my will to no man.”	222.7832888106118
“Will that be the answer,” replied the secretary, smiling, “which he	173.47800562134424
must transmit to his Majesty if, by chance, his Majesty should have the	288.1398713751149
curiosity to know why no vessel is to leave any of the ports of Great	176.4177924109216
Britain?”	287.5113374533331
“You are right, Mr. Jackson,” replied Buckingham. “He will say, in that	199.05566876358887
case, to the king that I am determined on war, and that this measure is	251.7088319318166
my first act of hostility against France.”	200.67243105684338
The secretary bowed and retired.	306.86307097821975
“We are safe on that side,” said Buckingham, turning toward D’Artagnan.	268.9899248970229
“If the studs are not yet gone to Paris, they will not arrive till	279.7043870806337
after you.”	209.08467777262746
“How so?”	227.7799612783167
“I have just placed an embargo on all vessels at present in his	178.9414229501182
Majesty’s ports, and without particular permission, not one dare lift	269.207072680077
an anchor.”	323.15353419492305
D’Artagnan looked with stupefaction at a man who thus employed the	309.49367456719426
unlimited power with which he was clothed by the confidence of a king	174.96998591433214
in the prosecution of his intrigues. Buckingham saw by the expression	220.13571767464282
of the young man’s face what was passing in his mind, and he smiled.	209.8526935354273
“Yes,” said he, “yes, Anne of Austria is my true queen. Upon a word	335.72036139829504
from her, I would betray my country, I would betray my king, I would	244.96315113712342
betray my God. She asked me not to send the Protestants of La Rochelle	352.83805227735206
the assistance I promised them; I have not done so. I broke my word, it	212.7294568226258
is true; but what signifies that? I obeyed my love; and have I not been	302.15139429125134
richly paid for that obedience? It was to that obedience I owe her	294.67125410924615
portrait.”	342.608994594904
D’Artagnan was amazed to note by what fragile and unknown threads the	345.26396456363506
destinies of nations and the lives of men are suspended. He was lost in	329.57478696326405
these reflections when the goldsmith entered. He was an Irishman—one of	214.76923149859633
the most skillful of his craft, and who himself confessed that he	221.8076551345444
gained a hundred thousand livres a year by the Duke of Buckingham.	286.8557566016095
“Mr. O’Reilly,” said the duke, leading him into the chapel, “look at	290.6796936315395
these diamond studs, and tell me what they are worth apiece.”	220.8396697915115
The goldsmith cast a glance at the elegant manner in which they were	357.07407941891165
set, calculated, one with another, what the diamonds were worth, and	289.4966519863516
without hesitation said, “Fifteen hundred pistoles each, my Lord.”	192.15075096283786
“How many days would it require to make two studs exactly like them?	225.20159519973814
You see there are two wanting.”	306.5827446521708
“Eight days, my Lord.”	254.06626896772894
“I will give you three thousand pistoles apiece if I can have them by	229.08642082058134
the day after tomorrow.”	340.82329000443497
“My Lord, they shall be yours.”	209.64790691655264
“You are a jewel of a man, Mr. O’Reilly; but that is not all. These	210.1667156949577
studs cannot be trusted to anybody; it must be done in the palace.”	313.3246534423776
“Impossible, my Lord! There is no one but myself can so execute them	309.67416329258856
that one cannot tell the new from the old.”	331.2684327144149
“Therefore, my dear Mr. O’Reilly, you are my prisoner. And if you wish	309.7578220161211
ever to leave my palace, you cannot; so make the best of it. Name to me	284.1585142585982
such of your workmen as you need, and point out the tools they must	297.9949427425662
bring.”	281.32862842845174
The goldsmith knew the duke. He knew all objection would be useless,	289.87919406548974
and instantly determined how to act.	270.7342093231227
“May I be permitted to inform my wife?” said he.	166.4296957173639
“Oh, you may even see her if you like, my dear Mr. O’Reilly. Your	174.10168351368628
captivity shall be mild, be assured; and as every inconvenience	207.2878413971217
deserves its indemnification, here is, in addition to the price of the	298.05335435727886
studs, an order for a thousand pistoles, to make you forget the	290.4496551664254
annoyance I cause you.”	187.9736859401022
D’Artagnan could not get over the surprise created in him by this	237.7257654649876
minister, who thus open-handed, sported with men and millions.	288.480579589891
As to the goldsmith, he wrote to his wife, sending her the order for	248.52335470101502
the thousand pistoles, and charging her to send him, in exchange, his	185.51196189056472
most skillful apprentice, an assortment of diamonds, of which he gave	180.00757112322003
the names and the weight, and the necessary tools.	303.38034680886165
Buckingham conducted the goldsmith to the chamber destined for him, and	256.21773440002045
which, at the end of half an hour, was transformed into a workshop.	200.57688867608547
Then he placed a sentinel at each door, with an order to admit nobody	238.424053868018
upon any pretense but his _valet de chambre_, Patrick. We need not add	352.82267506843414
that the goldsmith, O’Reilly, and his assistant, were prohibited from	316.2422946560413
going out under any pretext. This point, settled, the duke turned to	325.6752604750052
D’Artagnan. “Now, my young friend,” said he, “England is all our own.	287.125860027306
What do you wish for? What do you desire?”	298.44774009729736
“A bed, my Lord,” replied D’Artagnan. “At present, I confess, that is	360.0124815270209
the thing I stand most in need of.”	172.69128349676373
Buckingham gave D’Artagnan a chamber adjoining his own. He wished to	242.39720443682356
have the young man at hand—not that he at all mistrusted him, but for	257.17365203831076
the sake of having someone to whom he could constantly talk of the	308.1339569041887
queen.	354.680049037955
In one hour after, the ordinance was published in London that no vessel	365.69720900359675
bound for France should leave port, not even the packet boat with	248.80508689205246
letters. In the eyes of everybody this was a declaration of war between	328.71412493771095
the two kingdoms.	197.53240358724926
On the day after the morrow, by eleven o’clock, the two diamond studs	216.0531345803029
were finished, and they were so completely imitated, so perfectly	275.6338855920122
alike, that Buckingham could not tell the new ones from the old ones,	318.88682008664955
and experts in such matters would have been deceived as he was. He	361.0372619317932
immediately called D’Artagnan. “Here,” said he to him, “are the diamond	259.25921996911285
studs that you came to bring; and be my witness that I have done all	322.6270037656118
that human power could do.”	265.9584501918516
“Be satisfied, my Lord, I will tell all that I have seen. But does your	205.40503957640527
Grace mean to give me the studs without the casket?”	305.0837376188547
“The casket would encumber you. Besides, the casket is the more	171.0319929694035
precious from being all that is left to me. You will say that I keep	172.1751483952716
it.”	283.50045687673054
“I will perform your commission, word for word, my Lord.”	269.94943331087757
“And now,” resumed Buckingham, looking earnestly at the young man, “how	310.8002648289246
shall I ever acquit myself of the debt I owe you?”	311.3360044848539
D’Artagnan blushed up to the whites of his eyes. He saw that the duke	235.12899759169926
was searching for a means of making him accept something and the idea	175.35486559339108
that the blood of his friends and himself was about to be paid for with	209.24322125363446
English gold was strangely repugnant to him.	260.9245614932817
“Let us understand each other, my Lord,” replied D’Artagnan, “and let	332.0327307513229
us make things clear beforehand in order that there may be no mistake.	353.32610184328996
I am in the service of the King and Queen of France, and form part of	178.86495608953823
the company of Monsieur Dessessart, who, as well as his brother-in-law,	339.85563041227624
Monsieur de Tréville, is particularly attached to their Majesties. What	325.61188819404873
I have done, then, has been for the queen, and not at all for your	233.8548415597757
Grace. And still further, it is very probable I should not have done	210.11014482871184
anything of this, if it had not been to make myself agreeable to	280.59736245625965
someone who is my lady, as the queen is yours.”	318.92676993792736
“Yes,” said the duke, smiling, “and I even believe that I know that	262.383050337562
other person; it is—”	187.92493733877689
“My Lord, I have not named her!” interrupted the young man, warmly.	354.4396589828014
“That is true,” said the duke; “and it is to this person I am bound to	221.6570830549493
discharge my debt of gratitude.”	197.8364054636797
“You have said, my Lord; for truly, at this moment when there is	299.2357587494507
question of war, I confess to you that I see nothing in your Grace but	309.5134256263882
an Englishman, and consequently an enemy whom I should have much	204.20036506588315
greater pleasure in meeting on the field of battle than in the park at	199.92464013128986
Windsor or the corridors of the Louvre—all which, however, will not	208.18689109415882
prevent me from executing to the very point my commission or from	321.5452339143769
laying down my life, if there be need of it, to accomplish it; but I	186.37158224247716
repeat it to your Grace, without your having personally on that account	303.57452968318637
more to thank me for in this second interview than for what I did for	199.713296464105
you in the first.”	365.4746369662741
“We say, ‘Proud as a Scotsman,’” murmured the Duke of Buckingham.	356.162303102068
“And we say, ‘Proud as a Gascon,’” replied D’Artagnan. “The Gascons are	284.09172320240845
the Scots of France.”	272.5561464388585
D’Artagnan bowed to the duke, and was retiring.	336.79397361368456
“Well, are you going away in that manner? Where, and how?”	340.2048405279787
“That’s true!”	328.15011881122894
“Fore Gad, these Frenchmen have no consideration!”	348.23177116411574
“I had forgotten that England was an island, and that you were the king	278.77862356537054
of it.”	171.09363750993546
“Go to the riverside, ask for the brig _Sund_, and give this letter to	236.9419752858198
the captain; he will convey you to a little port, where certainly you	351.01872213017555
are not expected, and which is ordinarily only frequented by	292.93329720875863
fishermen.”	175.7998243884892
“The name of that port?”	248.93394991924794
“St. Valery; but listen. When you have arrived there you will go to a	271.4263886285256
mean tavern, without a name and without a sign—a mere fisherman’s hut.	226.49907106185805
You cannot be mistaken; there is but one.”	333.8117483078598
“Afterward?”	204.94739468354484
“You will ask for the host, and will repeat to him the word ‘Forward!’”	305.2852442170371
“Which means?”	214.39626715067791
“In French, _En avant_. It is the password. He will give you a horse	221.54285456713885
all saddled, and will point out to you the road you ought to take. You	364.732074515829
will find, in the same way, four relays on your route. If you will give	305.94013385003433
at each of these relays your address in Paris, the four horses will	330.89859598194676
follow you thither. You already know two of them, and you appeared to	327.2921550293088
appreciate them like a judge. They were those we rode on; and you may	239.7728734133179
rely upon me for the others not being inferior to them. These horses	218.1263109243204
are equipped for the field. However proud you may be, you will not	257.59248449636533
refuse to accept one of them, and to request your three companions to	229.44388921066837
accept the others—that is, in order to make war against us. Besides,	246.27498085095255
the end justified the means, as you Frenchmen say, does it not?”	356.27264144594983
“Yes, my Lord, I accept them,” said D’Artagnan; “and if it please God,	319.4092205816981
we will make a good use of your presents.”	325.60029102120563
“Well, now, your hand, young man. Perhaps we shall soon meet on the	181.4342641142373
field of battle; but in the meantime we shall part good friends, I	252.16935490543239
hope.”	226.03165117738575
“Yes, my Lord; but with the hope of soon becoming enemies.”	228.67591101868288
“Be satisfied; I promise you that.”	234.86242981467137
“I depend upon your word, my Lord.”	355.252691046064
D’Artagnan bowed to the duke, and made his way as quickly as possible	256.34985583501486
to the riverside. Opposite the Tower of London he found the vessel that	206.74388932763273
had been named to him, delivered his letter to the captain, who after	282.2990906580844
having it examined by the governor of the port made immediate	251.5519565377924
preparations to sail.	229.05466594765744
Fifty vessels were waiting to set out. Passing alongside one of them,	351.6026481271674
D’Artagnan fancied he perceived on board it the woman of Meung—the same	340.15323840792666
whom the unknown gentleman had called Milady, and whom D’Artagnan had	179.37076185169192
thought so handsome; but thanks to the current of the stream and a fair	265.9016174683467
wind, his vessel passed so quickly that he had little more than a	364.9411280099508
glimpse of her.	197.68892094649266
The next day about nine o’clock in the morning, he landed at St.	239.70468212840922
Valery. D’Artagnan went instantly in search of the inn, and easily	357.9263817945315
discovered it by the riotous noise which resounded from it. War between	340.67802759277015
England and France was talked of as near and certain, and the jolly	239.47379836371763
sailors were having a carousal.	190.5902151336252
D’Artagnan made his way through the crowd, advanced toward the host,	363.34439232977115
and pronounced the word “Forward!” The host instantly made him a sign	203.22972044138194
to follow, went out with him by a door which opened into a yard, led	192.87536416647563
him to the stable, where a saddled horse awaited him, and asked him if	197.70092632369852
he stood in need of anything else.	335.5439305465201
“I want to know the route I am to follow,” said D’Artagnan.	171.04751764162796
“Go from hence to Blangy, and from Blangy to Neufchâtel. At Neufchâtel,	352.18919234819805
go to the tavern of the Golden Harrow, give the password to the	295.8171291707299
landlord, and you will find, as you have here, a horse ready saddled.”	181.53642879557998
“Have I anything to pay?” demanded D’Artagnan.	198.10693251823596
“Everything is paid,” replied the host, “and liberally. Begone, and may	289.1862048659161
God guide you!”	272.21916836864534
“Amen!” cried the young man, and set off at full gallop.	178.46609962507424
Four hours later he was in Neufchâtel. He strictly followed the	289.799033949806
instructions he had received. At Neufchâtel, as at St. Valery, he found	329.98995531665616
a horse quite ready and awaiting him. He was about to remove the	280.2896863423066
pistols from the saddle he had quit to the one he was about to fill,	180.9428748919661
but he found the holsters furnished with similar pistols.	251.98082592589066
“Your address at Paris?”	260.3791890456272
“Hôtel of the Guards, company of Dessessart.”	334.0892552317579
“Enough,” replied the questioner.	310.1848068751116
“Which route must I take?” demanded D’Artagnan, in his turn.	282.7230414945513
“That of Rouen; but you will leave the city on your right. You must	202.56875381195906
stop at the little village of Eccuis, in which there is but one	191.0610106105751
tavern—the Shield of France. Don’t condemn it from appearances; you	230.1633711404015
will find a horse in the stables quite as good as this.”	239.1615103851376
“The same password?”	325.4493476514516
“Exactly.”	360.771536363823
“Adieu, master!”	193.75102091847035
“A good journey, gentlemen! Do you want anything?”	290.9741384394914
D’Artagnan shook his head, and set off at full speed. At Eccuis, the	284.2809281665457
same scene was repeated. He found as provident a host and a fresh	288.5474036615058
horse. He left his address as he had done before, and set off again at	215.5817975896435
the same pace for Pontoise. At Pontoise he changed his horse for the	314.36489970329336
last time, and at nine o’clock galloped into the yard of Tréville’s	332.4868137568824
hôtel. He had made nearly sixty leagues in little more than twelve	275.28255435442577
hours.	183.13561188264123
M. de Tréville received him as if he had seen him that same morning;	307.9579183832511
only, when pressing his hand a little more warmly than usual, he	233.4181357989128
informed him that the company of Dessessart was on duty at the Louvre,	357.13730855914423
and that he might repair at once to his post.	170.8740201664735
Chapter XXII.	298.1093513448448
THE BALLET OF LA MERLAISON	258.4451430022833
On the morrow, nothing was talked of in Paris but the ball which the	264.9246480789448
aldermen of the city were to give to the king and queen, and in which	339.30241389619067
their Majesties were to dance the famous La Merlaison—the favorite	292.04081936968953
ballet of the king.	306.25120482825423
Eight days had been occupied in preparations at the Hôtel de Ville for	229.74014383945803
this important evening. The city carpenters had erected scaffolds upon	198.45532072272388
which the invited ladies were to be placed; the city grocer had	197.07449252434543
ornamented the chambers with two hundred _flambeaux_ of white wax, a	282.183890935324
piece of luxury unheard of at that period; and twenty violins were	351.6710131516313
ordered, and the price for them fixed at double the usual rate, upon	247.5845217861546
condition, said the report, that they should be played all night.	247.10892666631963
At ten o’clock in the morning the Sieur de la Coste, ensign in the	231.16549264456447
king’s Guards, followed by two officers and several archers of that	256.9898174611328
body, came to the city registrar, named Clement, and demanded of him	175.38451837536311
all the keys of the rooms and offices of the hôtel. These keys were	177.37913622295324
given up to him instantly. Each of them had a ticket attached to it, by	276.21632137013864
which it might be recognized; and from that moment the Sieur de la	245.3735102034624
Coste was charged with the care of all the doors and all the avenues.	201.56012227879438
At eleven o’clock came in his turn Duhallier, captain of the Guards,	283.47033299891086
bringing with him fifty archers, who were distributed immediately	263.1032641689257
through the Hôtel de Ville, at the doors assigned them.	208.78290427954377
At three o’clock came two companies of the Guards, one French, the	293.02705137501385
other Swiss. The company of French guards was composed of half of M.	175.1838563287944
Duhallier’s men and half of M. Dessessart’s men.	230.54886931124125
At six in the evening the guests began to come. As fast as they	321.8407722612297
entered, they were placed in the grand saloon, on the platforms	264.0878595865939
prepared for them.	303.1813956780411
At nine o’clock Madame la Première Présidente arrived. As next to the	268.8057797830264
queen, she was the most considerable personage of the fête, she was	279.56698507663
received by the city officials, and placed in a box opposite to that	216.03272290128783
which the queen was to occupy.	166.48538316265237
At ten o’clock, the king’s collation, consisting of preserves and other	223.3483037775173
delicacies, was prepared in the little room on the side of the church	171.96171692061944
of St. Jean, in front of the silver buffet of the city, which was	176.7151603965126
guarded by four archers.	287.41121280282454
At midnight great cries and loud acclamations were heard. It was the	287.4133437377824
king, who was passing through the streets which led from the Louvre to	341.70097566841935
the Hôtel de Ville, and which were all illuminated with colored	225.09348384021135
lanterns.	225.42958763664328
Immediately the aldermen, clothed in their cloth robes and preceded by	301.25010370378413
six sergeants, each holding a _flambeau_ in his hand, went to attend	330.2500367320364
upon the king, whom they met on the steps, where the provost of the	342.50083667822827
merchants made him the speech of welcome—a compliment to which his	226.53800757617316
Majesty replied with an apology for coming so late, laying the blame	214.06358615618194
upon the cardinal, who had detained him till eleven o’clock, talking of	290.50773162330677
affairs of state.	300.05877578458467
His Majesty, in full dress, was accompanied by his royal Highness, M.	180.58864421005907
le Comte de Soissons, by the Grand Prior, by the Duc de Longueville, by	344.48489976137876
the Duc d’Eubœuf, by the Comte d’Harcourt, by the Comte de la	233.65271101509657
Roche-Guyon, by M. de Liancourt, by M. de Baradas, by the Comte de	361.24479159961254
Cramail, and by the Chevalier de Souveray. Everybody noticed that the	320.8891706506407
king looked dull and preoccupied.	303.8167245557503
A private room had been prepared for the king and another for Monsieur.	352.6405175720788
In each of these closets were placed masquerade dresses. The same had	213.08643051135243
been done for the queen and Madame the President. The nobles and ladies	166.08972979039268
of their Majesties’ suites were to dress, two by two, in chambers	172.74248472441502
prepared for the purpose. Before entering his closet the king desired	264.757668194397
to be informed the moment the cardinal arrived.	349.1560129409611
Half an hour after the entrance of the king, fresh acclamations were	258.2873709563721
heard; these announced the arrival of the queen. The aldermen did as	330.9599068914282
they had done before, and preceded by their sergeants, advanced to	288.28531699445443
receive their illustrious guest. The queen entered the great hall; and	266.9235108359852
it was remarked that, like the king, she looked dull and even weary.	245.26635010153265
At the moment she entered, the curtain of a small gallery which to that	220.62072986850947
time had been closed, was drawn, and the pale face of the cardinal	219.63814846964084
appeared, he being dressed as a Spanish cavalier. His eyes were fixed	317.7530560999493
upon those of the queen, and a smile of terrible joy passed over his	265.24412033944384
lips; the queen did not wear her diamond studs.	222.00670517201243
The queen remained for a short time to receive the compliments of the	196.89943314352897
city dignitaries and to reply to the salutations of the ladies. All at	188.50430389664214
once the king appeared with the cardinal at one of the doors of the	350.0037728337377
hall. The cardinal was speaking to him in a low voice, and the king was	350.25822688219836
very pale.	228.55588050472898
The king made his way through the crowd without a mask, and the ribbons	272.85814164382634
of his doublet scarcely tied. He went straight to the queen, and in an	337.36961576991047
altered voice said, “Why, madame, have you not thought proper to wear	324.7102746838822
your diamond studs, when you know it would give me so much	242.39698682608434
gratification?”	268.314622659158
The queen cast a glance around her, and saw the cardinal behind, with a	170.18942929515384
diabolical smile on his countenance.	356.44030194198285
“Sire,” replied the queen, with a faltering voice, “because, in the	195.21205923580465
midst of such a crowd as this, I feared some accident might happen to	228.3916792222127
them.”	268.20635297893233
“And you were wrong, madame. If I made you that present it was that you	180.20308827661094
might adorn yourself therewith. I tell you that you were wrong.”	207.19148608613935
The voice of the king was tremulous with anger. Everybody looked and	364.02505178601564
listened with astonishment, comprehending nothing of what passed.	220.33051975914339
“Sire,” said the queen, “I can send for them to the Louvre, where they	290.8309045535773
are, and thus your Majesty’s wishes will be complied with.”	296.32614175897584
“Do so, madame, do so, and that at once; for within an hour the ballet	184.77645413022105
will commence.”	200.37683612714014
The queen bent in token of submission, and followed the ladies who were	353.8663873757379
to conduct her to her room. On his part the king returned to his	340.035485488977
apartment.	349.33752718013733
There was a moment of trouble and confusion in the assembly. Everybody	309.22188441310254
had remarked that something had passed between the king and queen; but	316.6009420577553
both of them had spoken so low that everybody, out of respect, withdrew	324.84084761200694
several steps, so that nobody had heard anything. The violins began to	319.01806865715366
sound with all their might, but nobody listened to them.	334.19213657245496
The king came out first from his room. He was in a most elegant hunting	266.3394494059896
costume; and Monsieur and the other nobles were dressed like him. This	324.9228146404974
was the costume that best became the king. So dressed, he really	362.29255166818416
appeared the first gentleman of his kingdom.	202.83522290556425
The cardinal drew near to the king, and placed in his hand a small	308.84858791304356
casket. The king opened it, and found in it two diamond studs.	272.87182782680503
“What does this mean?” demanded he of the cardinal.	248.4941426318447
“Nothing,” replied the latter; “only, if the queen has the studs, which	209.21781721316614
I very much doubt, count them, sire, and if you only find ten, ask her	173.2302262851368
Majesty who can have stolen from her the two studs that are here.”	332.3054467743242
The king looked at the cardinal as if to interrogate him; but he had	198.3324230072874
not time to address any question to him—a cry of admiration burst from	228.95288778240263
every mouth. If the king appeared to be the first gentleman of his	289.85448373936333
kingdom, the queen was without doubt the most beautiful woman in	357.1877964228538
France.	171.6851236599638
It is true that the habit of a huntress became her admirably. She wore	351.5724022020237
a beaver hat with blue feathers, a surtout of gray-pearl velvet,	333.5614076172337
fastened with diamond clasps, and a petticoat of blue satin,	209.02294396670163
embroidered with silver. On her left shoulder sparkled the diamond	225.27217072191567
studs, on a bow of the same color as the plumes and the petticoat.	364.27856415543863
The king trembled with joy and the cardinal with vexation; although,	310.27736248510996
distant as they were from the queen, they could not count the studs.	255.388033323013
The queen had them. The only question was, had she ten or twelve?	350.10848378446167
At that moment the violins sounded the signal for the ballet. The king	209.25443622556875
advanced toward Madame the President, with whom he was to dance, and	201.56453836810715
his Highness Monsieur with the queen. They took their places, and the	267.2115080434734
ballet began.	363.56656856857063
The king danced facing the queen, and every time he passed by her, he	200.55002042009747
devoured with his eyes those studs of which he could not ascertain the	252.5399791660505
number. A cold sweat covered the brow of the cardinal.	220.77837257258187
The ballet lasted an hour, and had sixteen _entrées_. The ballet ended	282.42461966126274
amid the applause of the whole assemblage, and everyone reconducted his	219.7789253171434
lady to her place; but the king took advantage of the privilege he had	237.71900869568765
of leaving his lady, to advance eagerly toward the queen.	289.9240925619186
“I thank you, madame,” said he, “for the deference you have shown to my	174.56910594371533
wishes, but I think you want two of the studs, and I bring them back to	184.63588759684896
you.”	360.67722559938875
With these words he held out to the queen the two studs the cardinal	224.58154247086281
had given him.	281.21720651945225
“How, sire?” cried the young queen, affecting surprise, “you are giving	246.47859962512553
me, then, two more: I shall have fourteen.”	173.0648885374934
In fact the king counted them, and the twelve studs were all on her	354.03795573017874
Majesty’s shoulder.	237.2230452146058
The king called the cardinal.	331.7220378890364
“What does this mean, Monsieur Cardinal?” asked the king in a severe	276.1362632766355
tone.	184.43326859897883
“This means, sire,” replied the cardinal, “that I was desirous of	330.52386262039784
presenting her Majesty with these two studs, and that not daring to	170.89647123725018
offer them myself, I adopted this means of inducing her to accept	316.40126668582457
them.”	271.25031221819165
“And I am the more grateful to your Eminence,” replied Anne of Austria,	220.184817613422
with a smile that proved she was not the dupe of this ingenious	322.6789423726947
gallantry, “from being certain that these two studs alone have cost you	322.0076112908462
as much as all the others cost his Majesty.”	310.66097148514814
Then saluting the king and the cardinal, the queen resumed her way to	215.38625572962397
the chamber in which she had dressed, and where she was to take off her	277.41109347080993
costume.	357.20144425626484
The attention which we have been obliged to give, during the	364.06127998536465
commencement of the chapter, to the illustrious personages we have	166.7824330448483
introduced into it, has diverted us for an instant from him to whom	302.7937068947772
Anne of Austria owed the extraordinary triumph she had obtained over	284.650225056993
the cardinal; and who, confounded, unknown, lost in the crowd gathered	246.2095086544295
at one of the doors, looked on at this scene, comprehensible only to	288.8315061164345
four persons—the king, the queen, his Eminence, and himself.	201.15177221386432
The queen had just regained her chamber, and D’Artagnan was about to	357.92926659262605
retire, when he felt his shoulder lightly touched. He turned and saw a	307.15895917960313
young woman, who made him a sign to follow her. The face of this young	358.35549559749074
woman was covered with a black velvet mask; but notwithstanding this	211.90777359593426
precaution, which was in fact taken rather against others than against	347.35423447825815
him, he at once recognized his usual guide, the light and intelligent	345.40710181886334
Mme. Bonacieux.	216.9972893188199
On the evening before, they had scarcely seen each other for a moment	274.286755895786
at the apartment of the Swiss guard, Germain, whither D’Artagnan had	351.96243188536687
sent for her. The haste which the young woman was in to convey to the	302.13798582318896
queen the excellent news of the happy return of her messenger prevented	230.51161561806282
the two lovers from exchanging more than a few words. D’Artagnan	258.3071437702089
therefore followed Mme. Bonacieux moved by a double sentiment—love and	181.1024653906083
curiosity. All the way, and in proportion as the corridors became more	305.7824229734074
deserted, D’Artagnan wished to stop the young woman, seize her and gaze	293.9634842659734
upon her, were it only for a minute; but quick as a bird she glided	261.65817104083783
between his hands, and when he wished to speak to her, her finger	342.46865283576653
placed upon her mouth, with a little imperative gesture full of grace,	322.3584079230011
reminded him that he was under the command of a power which he must	263.4734258900075
blindly obey, and which forbade him even to make the slightest	214.96391408553103
complaint. At length, after winding about for a minute or two, Mme.	276.57898251620577
Bonacieux opened the door of a closet, which was entirely dark, and led	218.83831443759985
D’Artagnan into it. There she made a fresh sign of silence, and opened	270.8105436514879
a second door concealed by tapestry. The opening of this door disclosed	334.25455757831674
a brilliant light, and she disappeared.	169.96403182487035
D’Artagnan remained for a moment motionless, asking himself where he	171.57278849155523
could be; but soon a ray of light which penetrated through the chamber,	298.65619243665526
together with the warm and perfumed air which reached him from the same	316.70814952913463
aperture, the conversation of two of three ladies in language at once	189.5565676483449
respectful and refined, and the word “Majesty” several times repeated,	260.30742345102544
indicated clearly that he was in a closet attached to the queen’s	337.1178663509392
apartment. The young man waited in comparative darkness and listened.	355.36170173465746
The queen appeared cheerful and happy, which seemed to astonish the	281.13474817996365
persons who surrounded her and who were accustomed to see her almost	218.58171053245044
always sad and full of care. The queen attributed this joyous feeling	347.4818310193082
to the beauty of the fête, to the pleasure she had experienced in the	350.4201044477511
ballet; and as it is not permissible to contradict a queen, whether she	301.4550415652457
smile or weep, everybody expatiated on the gallantry of the aldermen of	221.26903575752561
the city of Paris.	233.57543364604254
Although D’Artagnan did not at all know the queen, he soon	278.35768793946727
distinguished her voice from the others, at first by a slightly foreign	186.38003340995795
accent, and next by that tone of domination naturally impressed upon	316.6770691759732
all royal words. He heard her approach and withdraw from the partially	297.83877269110724
open door; and twice or three times he even saw the shadow of a person	321.195493563785
intercept the light.	259.29828638249967
At length a hand and an arm, surpassingly beautiful in their form and	261.9343009719469
whiteness, glided through the tapestry. D’Artagnan at once comprehended	329.8524115201629
that this was his recompense. He cast himself on his knees, seized the	193.39979616185704
hand, and touched it respectfully with his lips. Then the hand was	203.10893966034857
withdrawn, leaving in his an object which he perceived to be a ring.	330.3993118588947
The door immediately closed, and D’Artagnan found himself again in	267.1197955777368
complete obscurity.	196.6251762527422
D’Artagnan placed the ring on his finger, and again waited; it was	360.1945202115346
evident that all was not yet over. After the reward of his devotion,	170.81889441658606
that of his love was to come. Besides, although the ballet was danced,	248.6192476369599
the evening had scarcely begun. Supper was to be served at three, and	293.47712369371243
the clock of St. Jean had struck three quarters past two.	316.2849973780825
The sound of voices diminished by degrees in the adjoining chamber. The	337.0277078301882
company was then heard departing; then the door of the closet in which	345.2121167320722
D’Artagnan was, was opened, and Mme. Bonacieux entered.	268.4269687544639
“You at last?” cried D’Artagnan.	299.9817279359281
“Silence!” said the young woman, placing her hand upon his lips;	174.48243189606163
“silence, and go the same way you came!”	357.0750996732902
“But where and when shall I see you again?” cried D’Artagnan.	205.43113191713917
“A note which you will find at home will tell you. Begone, begone!”	276.86502045714286
At these words she opened the door of the corridor, and pushed	180.38860914155842
D’Artagnan out of the room. D’Artagnan obeyed like a child, without the	189.89373037787192
least resistance or objection, which proved that he was really in love.	304.60526294715146
Chapter XXIII.	260.7784462414106
THE RENDEZVOUS	199.663936558013
D’Artagnan ran home immediately, and although it was three o’clock in	232.33853348634946
the morning and he had some of the worst quarters of Paris to traverse,	281.7851730544366
he met with no misadventure. Everyone knows that drunkards and lovers	298.3074101442194
have a protecting deity.	206.66724168180397
He found the door of his passage open, sprang up the stairs and knocked	278.22578185069517
softly in a manner agreed upon between him and his lackey. Planchet*,	227.49764031209207
whom he had sent home two hours before from the Hôtel de Ville, telling	209.57460302748038
him to sit up for him, opened the door for him.	257.92340717307724
* The reader may ask, “How came Planchet here?” when he was left “stiff	179.78253538877726
as a rush” in London. In the intervening time Buckingham perhaps sent	321.0844087214788
him to Paris, as he did the horses.	338.04984587658356
“Has anyone brought a letter for me?” asked D’Artagnan, eagerly.	287.1921856446245
“No one has _brought_ a letter, monsieur,” replied Planchet; “but one	311.86437190412414
has come of itself.”	284.47924229695707
“What do you mean, blockhead?”	262.2917045265759
“I mean to say that when I came in, although I had the key of your	249.29877466386597
apartment in my pocket, and that key had never quit me, I found a	286.83564490915234
letter on the green table cover in your bedroom.”	347.4412984856902
“And where is that letter?”	201.31762568858886
“I left it where I found it, monsieur. It is not natural for letters to	353.197363189435
enter people’s houses in this manner. If the window had been open or	263.17179283488315
even ajar, I should think nothing of it; but, no—all was hermetically	286.2116346585467
sealed. Beware, monsieur; there is certainly some magic underneath.”	344.88466669359536
Meanwhile, the young man had darted in to his chamber, and opened the	262.069986272772
letter. It was from Mme. Bonacieux, and was expressed in these terms:	347.43702823423007
“There are many thanks to be offered to you, and to be transmitted to	360.96205844861356
you. Be this evening about ten o’clock at St. Cloud, in front of the	359.1199588739206
pavilion which stands at the corner of the house of M. d’Estrées.—C.B.”	330.38626741864005
While reading this letter, D’Artagnan felt his heart dilated and	232.25266085097942
compressed by that delicious spasm which tortures and caresses the	182.43715303932655
hearts of lovers.	250.89923009922418
It was the first billet he had received; it was the first rendezvous	291.6338123469369
that had been granted him. His heart, swelled by the intoxication of	270.22793830466696
joy, felt ready to dissolve away at the very gate of that terrestrial	228.79571338560444
paradise called Love!	220.9810554442442
“Well, monsieur,” said Planchet, who had observed his master grow red	364.58946859057716
and pale successively, “did I not guess truly? Is it not some bad	280.75614249459153
affair?”	169.99121002483048
“You are mistaken, Planchet,” replied D’Artagnan; “and as a proof,	365.6081845383176
there is a crown to drink my health.”	193.02682352216374
“I am much obliged to Monsieur for the crown he has given me, and I	245.5489375859376
promise him to follow his instructions exactly; but it is not the less	314.31201664770794
true that letters which come in this way into shut-up houses—”	196.38266951552885
“Fall from heaven, my friend, fall from heaven.”	295.1830582022154
“Then Monsieur is satisfied?” asked Planchet.	356.9110220931931
“My dear Planchet, I am the happiest of men!”	356.9214546405132
“And I may profit by Monsieur’s happiness, and go to bed?”	242.50342724584596
“Yes, go.”	338.05501663741177
“May the blessings of heaven fall upon Monsieur! But it is not the less	222.21085378421037
true that that letter—”	221.19257208138205
And Planchet retired, shaking his head with an air of doubt, which the	272.96684334802745
liberality of D’Artagnan had not entirely effaced.	218.5664683472857
Left alone, D’Artagnan read and reread his billet. Then he kissed and	211.41523876965158
rekissed twenty times the lines traced by the hand of his beautiful	343.12488888607305
mistress. At length he went to bed, fell asleep, and had golden dreams.	199.942269679236
At seven o’clock in the morning he arose and called Planchet, who at	322.2309755086095
the second summons opened the door, his countenance not yet quite freed	184.9412438365103
from the anxiety of the preceding night.	228.60089551739506
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, “I am going out for all day, perhaps. You	232.73229030646348
are, therefore, your own master till seven o’clock in the evening; but	329.1752918278559
at seven o’clock you must hold yourself in readiness with two horses.”	286.43979880172697
“There!” said Planchet. “We are going again, it appears, to have our	357.3765829704194
hides pierced in all sorts of ways.”	212.17152912755535
“You will take your musketoon and your pistols.”	271.1245429971019
“There, now! Didn’t I say so?” cried Planchet. “I was sure of it—the	318.90596786160813
cursed letter!”	256.44882664541797
“Don’t be afraid, you idiot; there is nothing in hand but a party of	253.7712988903047
pleasure.”	349.9459135900811
“Ah, like the charming journey the other day, when it rained bullets	174.45173540258645
and produced a crop of steel traps!”	173.0679541695964
“Well, if you are really afraid, Monsieur Planchet,” resumed	313.1846958013753
D’Artagnan, “I will go without you. I prefer traveling alone to having	208.7293794516468
a companion who entertains the least fear.”	328.6105520918836
“Monsieur does me wrong,” said Planchet; “I thought he had seen me at	283.10850773802605
