work.”	268.4163264992665
“Yes, but I thought perhaps you had worn out all your courage the first	344.6818290724941
time.”	280.2165506408545
“Monsieur shall see that upon occasion I have some left; only I beg	314.43627217140704
Monsieur not to be too prodigal of it if he wishes it to last long.”	268.1538724146396
“Do you believe you have still a certain amount of it to expend this	365.5060998983876
evening?”	332.93560844605076
“I hope so, monsieur.”	250.25353407538722
“Well, then, I count on you.”	354.5074531891504
“At the appointed hour I shall be ready; only I believed that Monsieur	330.3378044382191
had but one horse in the Guard stables.”	186.87307280669364
“Perhaps there is but one at this moment; but by this evening there	299.7259387295635
will be four.”	302.81811199119556
“It appears that our journey was a remounting journey, then?”	316.45784097036494
“Exactly so,” said D’Artagnan; and nodding to Planchet, he went out.	213.94184185802487
M. Bonacieux was at his door. D’Artagnan’s intention was to go out	302.2496355816379
without speaking to the worthy mercer; but the latter made so polite	182.28176427824965
and friendly a salutation that his tenant felt obliged, not only to	235.10912656824337
stop, but to enter into conversation with him.	268.6666372194309
Besides, how is it possible to avoid a little condescension toward a	172.71870702981255
husband whose pretty wife has appointed a meeting with you that same	247.7172640371907
evening at St. Cloud, opposite D’Estrées’s pavilion? D’Artagnan	365.0344714755865
approached him with the most amiable air he could assume.	177.70267922066975
The conversation naturally fell upon the incarceration of the poor man.	184.71218936452397
M. Bonacieux, who was ignorant that D’Artagnan had overheard his	244.18384602136874
conversation with the stranger of Meung, related to his young tenant	325.5555598803036
the persecutions of that monster, M. de Laffemas, whom he never ceased	323.6412082277643
to designate, during his account, by the title of the “cardinal’s	190.9715116234946
executioner,” and expatiated at great length upon the Bastille, the	265.3293985238689
bolts, the wickets, the dungeons, the gratings, the instruments of	330.41858244729303
torture.	208.80606524544658
D’Artagnan listened to him with exemplary complaisance, and when he had	193.35925764892914
finished said, “And Madame Bonacieux, do you know who carried her	252.72458309971177
off?—For I do not forget that I owe to that unpleasant circumstance the	279.2789250506151
good fortune of having made your acquaintance.”	340.67271508417855
“Ah!” said Bonacieux, “they took good care not to tell me that; and my	263.7355304262037
wife, on her part, has sworn to me by all that’s sacred that she does	361.21305127505127
not know. But you,” continued M. Bonacieux, in a tone of perfect good	215.76054282976196
fellowship, “what has become of you all these days? I have not seen you	256.5865431483376
nor your friends, and I don’t think you could gather all that dust that	205.18818272140518
I saw Planchet brush off your boots yesterday from the pavement of	182.02176770473872
Paris.”	324.2671473672567
“You are right, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, my friends and I have been	173.52426753733238
on a little journey.”	306.84522045617814
“Far from here?”	335.28549360888326
“Oh, Lord, no! About forty leagues only. We went to take Monsieur Athos	222.09011772516746
to the waters of Forges, where my friends still remain.”	213.95090879410367
“And you have returned, have you not?” replied M. Bonacieux, giving to	241.96412674972345
his countenance a most sly air. “A handsome young fellow like you does	205.46154629437993
not obtain long leaves of absence from his mistress; and we were	349.67279190904685
impatiently waited for at Paris, were we not?”	206.83330165195224
“My faith!” said the young man, laughing, “I confess it, and so much	266.57999457516684
more the readily, my dear Bonacieux, as I see there is no concealing	350.4475116624186
anything from you. Yes, I was expected, and very impatiently, I	225.51642059822188
acknowledge.”	179.53683091896357
A slight shade passed over the brow of Bonacieux, but so slight that	276.7911481106902
D’Artagnan did not perceive it.	345.88012389638027
“And we are going to be recompensed for our diligence?” continued the	299.86887697483985
mercer, with a trifling alteration in his voice—so trifling, indeed,	267.164038955222
that D’Artagnan did not perceive it any more than he had the momentary	341.51793313930557
shade which, an instant before, had darkened the countenance of the	181.78038882313814
worthy man.	180.1085094306144
“Ah, may you be a true prophet!” said D’Artagnan, laughing.	218.6559520542032
“No; what I say,” replied Bonacieux, “is only that I may know whether I	201.73421996379614
am delaying you.”	298.60039616691256
“Why that question, my dear host?” asked D’Artagnan. “Do you intend to	333.09442582619806
sit up for me?”	328.01787306604393
“No; but since my arrest and the robbery that was committed in my	296.16330574673225
house, I am alarmed every time I hear a door open, particularly in the	307.0412339774836
night. What the deuce can you expect? I am no swordsman.”	349.76505906206665
“Well, don’t be alarmed if I return at one, two or three o’clock in the	278.6491001932858
morning; indeed, do not be alarmed if I do not come at all.”	255.40373561281834
This time Bonacieux became so pale that D’Artagnan could not help	187.18307467514595
perceiving it, and asked him what was the matter.	323.04909965974923
“Nothing,” replied Bonacieux, “nothing. Since my misfortunes I have	340.02827949444026
been subject to faintnesses, which seize me all at once, and I have	196.0445603023142
just felt a cold shiver. Pay no attention to it; you have nothing to	217.28607570497155
occupy yourself with but being happy.”	200.78995766920724
“Then I have full occupation, for I am so.”	267.9398402426903
“Not yet; wait a little! This evening, you said.”	359.3118812774306
“Well, this evening will come, thank God! And perhaps you look for it	267.815647168621
with as much impatience as I do; perhaps this evening Madame Bonacieux	259.4607898735328
will visit the conjugal domicile.”	332.09403254772906
“Madame Bonacieux is not at liberty this evening,” replied the husband,	189.58201719664953
seriously; “she is detained at the Louvre this evening by her duties.”	248.20537682697756
“So much the worse for you, my dear host, so much the worse! When I am	326.1680472119398
happy, I wish all the world to be so; but it appears that is not	233.0815781140102
possible.”	197.55656910702405
The young man departed, laughing at the joke, which he thought he alone	200.1929718416169
could comprehend.	334.64576045591957
“Amuse yourself well!” replied Bonacieux, in a sepulchral tone.	195.18965926953547
But D’Artagnan was too far off to hear him; and if he had heard him in	169.53293129051573
the disposition of mind he then enjoyed, he certainly would not have	266.66166122217356
remarked it.	324.3429943278783
He took his way toward the hôtel of M. de Tréville; his visit of the	179.38351896309143
day before, it is to be remembered, had been very short and very little	338.19711711656
explicative.	186.48155236774667
He found Tréville in a joyful mood. He had thought the king and queen	217.8388480508115
charming at the ball. It is true the cardinal had been particularly	240.52868369108313
ill-tempered. He had retired at one o’clock under the pretense of being	281.5776778707569
indisposed. As to their Majesties, they did not return to the Louvre	256.85506381122616
till six o’clock in the morning.	249.92323549247314
“Now,” said Tréville, lowering his voice, and looking into every corner	357.7899566184743
of the apartment to see if they were alone, “now let us talk about	186.86353608054173
yourself, my young friend; for it is evident that your happy return has	213.63063379407748
something to do with the joy of the king, the triumph of the queen, and	328.50064026955226
the humiliation of his Eminence. You must look out for yourself.”	343.44012475043314
“What have I to fear,” replied D’Artagnan, “as long as I shall have the	324.32928708237614
luck to enjoy the favor of their Majesties?”	241.77066658782184
“Everything, believe me. The cardinal is not the man to forget a	237.022783508156
mystification until he has settled account with the mystifier; and the	285.58337712743037
mystifier appears to me to have the air of being a certain young Gascon	308.6934304214677
of my acquaintance.”	345.2327428512589
“Do you believe that the cardinal is as well posted as yourself, and	354.03436830526744
knows that I have been to London?”	172.26597955139746
“The devil! You have been to London! Was it from London you brought	242.66156134038897
that beautiful diamond that glitters on your finger? Beware, my dear	248.94880103970146
D’Artagnan! A present from an enemy is not a good thing. Are there not	221.51587246182083
some Latin verses upon that subject? Stop!”	213.54461357820546
“Yes, doubtless,” replied D’Artagnan, who had never been able to cram	316.13271770812577
the first rudiments of that language into his head, and who had by his	268.3932745960414
ignorance driven his master to despair, “yes, doubtless there is one.”	291.7173371391708
“There certainly is one,” said M. de Tréville, who had a tincture of	214.6189669877339
literature, “and Monsieur de Benserade was quoting it to me the other	316.30844556672054
day. Stop a minute—ah, this is it: ‘Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes,’	191.27299085715507
which means, ‘Beware of the enemy who makes you presents.”	219.9006608019482
“This diamond does not come from an enemy, monsieur,” replied	316.84965255769464
D’Artagnan, “it comes from the queen.”	178.60040124060205
“From the queen! Oh, oh!” said M. de Tréville. “Why, it is indeed a	212.4770356247555
true royal jewel, which is worth a thousand pistoles if it is worth a	327.54903836991224
denier. By whom did the queen send you this jewel?”	201.43812300977595
“She gave it to me herself.”	233.16576030763298
“Where?”	209.55593534496148
“In the room adjoining the chamber in which she changed her toilet.”	351.7243774879993
“How?”	241.39884655796578
“Giving me her hand to kiss.”	294.3952979355313
“You have kissed the queen’s hand?” said M. de Tréville, looking	351.07459094277556
earnestly at D’Artagnan.	166.41404430439195
“Her Majesty did me the honor to grant me that favor.”	293.7531979340322
“And that in the presence of witnesses! Imprudent, thrice imprudent!”	316.21544391751615
“No, monsieur, be satisfied; nobody saw her,” replied D’Artagnan, and	305.61731885201124
he related to M. de Tréville how the affair came to pass.	257.5696153258524
“Oh, the women, the women!” cried the old soldier. “I know them by	239.84659675059677
their romantic imagination. Everything that savors of mystery charms	303.9335928309389
them. So you have seen the arm, that was all. You would meet the queen,	233.71950439549698
and she would not know who you are?”	337.695947351687
“No; but thanks to this diamond,” replied the young man.	242.746918997842
“Listen,” said M. de Tréville; “shall I give you counsel, good counsel,	364.62343794457894
the counsel of a friend?”	296.858562634094
“You will do me honor, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan.	287.3827147614794
“Well, then, off to the nearest goldsmith’s, and sell that diamond for	188.9332588689317
the highest price you can get from him. However much of a Jew he may	232.43910532643034
be, he will give you at least eight hundred pistoles. Pistoles have no	297.00387761586285
name, young man, and that ring has a terrible one, which may betray him	198.13826440340955
who wears it.”	216.0713778088409
“Sell this ring, a ring which comes from my sovereign? Never!” said	303.82950156641346
D’Artagnan.	365.05104624663124
“Then, at least turn the gem inside, you silly fellow; for everybody	170.405634013298
must be aware that a cadet from Gascony does not find such stones in	269.2094068104888
his mother’s jewel case.”	254.9935378289431
“You think, then, I have something to dread?” asked D’Artagnan.	277.6646300978083
“I mean to say, young man, that he who sleeps over a mine the match of	235.3904660514882
which is already lighted, may consider himself in safety in comparison	299.6718206204392
with you.”	169.6166231765135
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, whom the positive tone of M. de Tréville	321.77038391214285
began to disquiet, “the devil! What must I do?”	338.3642891849628
“Above all things be always on your guard. The cardinal has a tenacious	229.39651626552268
memory and a long arm; you may depend upon it, he will repay you by	202.022870374536
some ill turn.”	219.18665006495226
“But of what sort?”	189.69462537191907
“Eh! How can I tell? Has he not all the tricks of a demon at his	273.7386909268126
command? The least that can be expected is that you will be arrested.”	183.46862796612785
“What! Will they dare to arrest a man in his Majesty’s service?”	195.0948007487085
“_Pardieu!_ They did not scruple much in the case of Athos. At all	269.9015820950795
events, young man, rely upon one who has been thirty years at court. Do	353.67179663682657
not lull yourself in security, or you will be lost; but, on the	318.72438514544876
contrary—and it is I who say it—see enemies in all directions. If	212.7326542769717
anyone seeks a quarrel with you, shun it, were it with a child of ten	356.05246303673107
years old. If you are attacked by day or by night, fight, but retreat,	358.23575276861504
without shame; if you cross a bridge, feel every plank of it with your	343.46528268559416
foot, lest one should give way beneath you; if you pass before a house	328.6020146131935
which is being built, look up, for fear a stone should fall upon your	311.423214887061
head; if you stay out late, be always followed by your lackey, and let	336.831356388895
your lackey be armed—if, by the by, you can be sure of your lackey.	291.6111610170359
Mistrust everybody, your friend, your brother, your mistress—your	321.4848762327824
mistress above all.”	176.15564035402662
D’Artagnan blushed.	235.02329271576153
“My mistress above all,” repeated he, mechanically; “and why her rather	251.35070073208158
than another?”	222.56804773069456
“Because a mistress is one of the cardinal’s favorite means; he has not	242.90894510552312
one that is more expeditious. A woman will sell you for ten pistoles,	227.9464110580285
witness Delilah. You are acquainted with the Scriptures?”	345.5100181355804
D’Artagnan thought of the appointment Mme. Bonacieux had made with him	273.30423909854886
for that very evening; but we are bound to say, to the credit of our	199.294566596373
hero, that the bad opinion entertained by M. de Tréville of women in	303.39701913278316
general, did not inspire him with the least suspicion of his pretty	288.48660725386867
hostess.	308.66451310320406
“But, _à propos_,” resumed M. de Tréville, “what has become of your	292.4441182175756
three companions?”	334.50241811710225
“I was about to ask you if you had heard any news of them?”	324.8859038059577
“None, monsieur.”	226.88563305495296
“Well, I left them on my road—Porthos at Chantilly, with a duel on his	334.8785263080772
hands; Aramis at Crèvecœur, with a ball in his shoulder; and Athos at	210.60777761756745
Amiens, detained by an accusation of coining.”	194.25921353802707
“See there, now!” said M. de Tréville; “and how the devil did you	296.2064645141258
escape?”	329.5925090974258
“By a miracle, monsieur, I must acknowledge, with a sword thrust in my	304.17194809593104
breast, and by nailing the Comte de Wardes on the byroad to Calais,	176.85262431185836
like a butterfly on a tapestry.”	268.9708797291368
“There again! De Wardes, one of the cardinal’s men, a cousin of	205.533019718292
Rochefort! Stop, my friend, I have an idea.”	356.2945210070884
“Speak, monsieur.”	225.08758322881593
“In your place, I would do one thing.”	208.12754932524115
“What?”	323.7360634017365
“While his Eminence was seeking for me in Paris, I would take, without	335.7421138647681
sound of drum or trumpet, the road to Picardy, and would go and make	324.73371479975765
some inquiries concerning my three companions. What the devil! They	312.8250791227133
merit richly that piece of attention on your part.”	354.97020758003185
“The advice is good, monsieur, and tomorrow I will set out.”	306.97114120860147
“Tomorrow! Any why not this evening?”	329.7377493356548
“This evening, monsieur, I am detained in Paris by indispensable	174.96164063748304
business.”	245.49684764775932
“Ah, young man, young man, some flirtation or other. Take care, I	355.226974444354
repeat to you, take care. It is woman who has ruined us, still ruins	166.9601057825179
us, and will ruin us, as long as the world stands. Take my advice and	288.51769563899103
set out this evening.”	258.8124838792605
“Impossible, monsieur.”	284.2002020213386
“You have given your word, then?”	187.6818709956463
“Yes, monsieur.”	257.1269759523021
“Ah, that’s quite another thing; but promise me, if you should not be	186.68021562129536
killed tonight, that you will go tomorrow.”	301.6255362362
“I promise it.”	221.83588331513357
“Do you need money?”	217.79097039515293
“I have still fifty pistoles. That, I think, is as much as I shall	365.21258658409045
want.”	351.7213305528164
“But your companions?”	342.809136821931
“I don’t think they can be in need of any. We left Paris, each with	341.1437617224328
seventy-five pistoles in his pocket.”	177.3507734231376
“Shall I see you again before your departure?”	237.50398239856534
“I think not, monsieur, unless something new should happen.”	359.9115090302754
“Well, a pleasant journey.”	171.01175399874225
“Thanks, monsieur.”	170.53688742379535
D’Artagnan left M. de Tréville, touched more than ever by his paternal	285.175307296554
solicitude for his Musketeers.	334.1548264361585
He called successively at the abodes of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.	312.730487900801
Neither of them had returned. Their lackeys likewise were absent, and	248.06074315168334
nothing had been heard of either the one or the other. He would have	202.28181692638125
inquired after them of their mistresses, but he was neither acquainted	274.5177092368885
with Porthos’s nor Aramis’s, and as to Athos, he had none.	279.29465469021
As he passed the Hôtel des Gardes, he took a glance into the stables.	262.4674855813523
Three of the four horses had already arrived. Planchet, all	191.65212554573148
astonishment, was busy grooming them, and had already finished two.	305.70621385817424
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, on perceiving D’Artagnan, “how glad I am	186.23060503446638
to see you.”	323.1603296813537
“Why so, Planchet?” asked the young man.	338.44392843300795
“Do you place confidence in our landlord—Monsieur Bonacieux?”	205.80765916338424
“I? Not the least in the world.”	317.01294445705645
“Oh, you do quite right, monsieur.”	206.39766364811103
“But why this question?”	362.8102239125535
“Because, while you were talking with him, I watched you without	269.0081374726905
listening to you; and, monsieur, his countenance changed color two or	361.4713924235199
three times!”	236.76801499027428
“Bah!”	175.978396391399
“Preoccupied as Monsieur was with the letter he had received, he did	237.44838698155633
not observe that; but I, whom the strange fashion in which that letter	229.2965847581644
came into the house had placed on my guard—I did not lose a movement of	279.39645302884924
his features.”	203.54953659310206
“And you found it?”	253.42344273519683
“Traitorous, monsieur.”	323.68291769886275
“Indeed!”	280.97480764302134
“Still more; as soon as Monsieur had left and disappeared round the	186.47689055904965
corner of the street, Monsieur Bonacieux took his hat, shut his door,	302.05684167606444
and set off at a quick pace in an opposite direction.”	278.5131899456179
“It seems you are right, Planchet; all this appears to be a little	266.8125912590218
mysterious; and be assured that we will not pay him our rent until the	258.38787703397213
matter shall be categorically explained to us.”	243.7166218072556
“Monsieur jests, but Monsieur will see.”	338.2063895656453
“What would you have, Planchet? What must come is written.”	195.49236832282173
“Monsieur does not then renounce his excursion for this evening?”	285.0502567645095
“Quite the contrary, Planchet; the more ill will I have toward Monsieur	182.74943704492355
Bonacieux, the more punctual I shall be in keeping the appointment made	335.42335213450866
by that letter which makes you so uneasy.”	199.22145140434654
“Then that is Monsieur’s determination?”	260.5595586215793
“Undeniably, my friend. At nine o’clock, then, be ready here at the	358.2430742697845
hôtel, I will come and take you.”	237.3699006565351
Planchet seeing there was no longer any hope of making his master	357.3720390259886
renounce his project, heaved a profound sigh and set to work to groom	259.4908371071066
the third horse.	278.15392152334243
As to D’Artagnan, being at bottom a prudent youth, instead of returning	332.7186790284434
home, went and dined with the Gascon priest, who, at the time of the	269.1584273195391
distress of the four friends, had given them a breakfast of chocolate.	224.93454122861885
Chapter XXIV.	307.7731339560873
THE PAVILION	182.41227932892414
At nine o’clock D’Artagnan was at the Hôtel des Gardes; he found	228.79656107608588
Planchet all ready. The fourth horse had arrived.	249.44615308486902
Planchet was armed with his musketoon and a pistol. D’Artagnan had his	265.8442949856744
sword and placed two pistols in his belt; then both mounted and	359.0254663663294
departed quietly. It was quite dark, and no one saw them go out.	178.85548240974285
Planchet took place behind his master, and kept at a distance of ten	353.7382722616895
paces from him.	208.60651195106192
D’Artagnan crossed the quays, went out by the gate of La Conférence and	335.304502525207
followed the road, much more beautiful then than it is now, which leads	278.2035783019962
to St. Cloud.	291.7759827206628
As long as he was in the city, Planchet kept at the respectful distance	340.39958677185086
he had imposed upon himself; but as soon as the road began to be more	354.85672986582216
lonely and dark, he drew softly nearer, so that when they entered the	262.9305406440756
Bois de Boulogne he found himself riding quite naturally side by side	334.1982901237734
with his master. In fact, we must not dissemble that the oscillation of	341.8564752432717
the tall trees and the reflection of the moon in the dark underwood	190.37526056173704
gave him serious uneasiness. D’Artagnan could not help perceiving that	338.0728775209625
something more than usual was passing in the mind of his lackey and	303.1086242465049
said, “Well, Monsieur Planchet, what is the matter with us now?”	183.40233874668525
“Don’t you think, monsieur, that woods are like churches?”	213.15682646790142
“How so, Planchet?”	299.04274852261904
“Because we dare not speak aloud in one or the other.”	355.5720535199399
“But why did you not dare to speak aloud, Planchet—because you are	206.0690028493563
afraid?”	316.03643429419435
“Afraid of being heard? Yes, monsieur.”	284.24302417257115
“Afraid of being heard! Why, there is nothing improper in our	260.5616188838304
conversation, my dear Planchet, and no one could find fault with it.”	260.43165170178804
“Ah, monsieur!” replied Planchet, recurring to his besetting idea,	262.1272781742311
“that Monsieur Bonacieux has something vicious in his eyebrows, and	260.8316974164228
something very unpleasant in the play of his lips.”	292.40399229311174
“What the devil makes you think of Bonacieux?”	284.36408680856573
“Monsieur, we think of what we can, and not of what we will.”	169.05763994217253
“Because you are a coward, Planchet.”	240.86307925952258
“Monsieur, we must not confound prudence with cowardice; prudence is a	211.79066657327303
virtue.”	314.4087567454791
“And you are very virtuous, are you not, Planchet?”	175.83059973999127
“Monsieur, is not that the barrel of a musket which glitters yonder?	246.8551112228081
Had we not better lower our heads?”	330.59299964857234
“In truth,” murmured D’Artagnan, to whom M. de Tréville’s	205.7490029752987
recommendation recurred, “this animal will end by making me afraid.”	214.25977189494674
And he put his horse into a trot.	292.5804102784655
Planchet followed the movements of his master as if he had been his	207.0080973392285
shadow, and was soon trotting by his side.	175.8226733323879
“Are we going to continue this pace all night?” asked Planchet.	258.50693214536307
“No; you are at your journey’s end.”	241.28145184207716
“How, monsieur! And you?”	238.04127482541838
“I am going a few steps farther.”	333.28888523564103
“And Monsieur leaves me here alone?”	209.59168370712663
“You are afraid, Planchet?”	359.30558761146347
“No; I only beg leave to observe to Monsieur that the night will be	277.0561531540477
very cold, that chills bring on rheumatism, and that a lackey who has	259.443794654856
the rheumatism makes but a poor servant, particularly to a master as	223.7120214360333
active as Monsieur.”	174.5464651148316
“Well, if you are cold, Planchet, you can go into one of those cabarets	341.89607257644775
that you see yonder, and be in waiting for me at the door by six	250.52069861075182
o’clock in the morning.”	280.10197675667234
“Monsieur, I have eaten and drunk respectfully the crown you gave me	208.62693492575423
this morning, so that I have not a sou left in case I should be cold.”	352.57693889096436
“Here’s half a pistole. Tomorrow morning.”	195.85557818473
D’Artagnan sprang from his horse, threw the bridle to Planchet, and	354.31708574796994
departed at a quick pace, folding his cloak around him.	359.1199522850394
“Good Lord, how cold I am!” cried Planchet, as soon as he had lost	307.5067054678442
sight of his master; and in such haste was he to warm himself that he	292.8161465737887
went straight to a house set out with all the attributes of a suburban	251.2897809851508
tavern, and knocked at the door.	300.59656555203526
In the meantime D’Artagnan, who had plunged into a bypath, continued	292.7182604773619
his route and reached St. Cloud; but instead of following the main	361.3325636681841
street he turned behind the château, reached a sort of retired lane,	200.0406818113289
and found himself soon in front of the pavilion named. It was situated	190.80520959426133
in a very private spot. A high wall, at the angle of which was the	297.2450373864713
pavilion, ran along one side of this lane, and on the other was a	330.0674281652798
little garden connected with a poor cottage which was protected by a	272.72684421213484
hedge from passers-by.	332.66276201170365
He gained the place appointed, and as no signal had been given him by	227.70193795848442
which to announce his presence, he waited.	178.47024738698906
Not the least noise was to be heard; it might be imagined that he was a	237.67589405995503
hundred miles from the capital. D’Artagnan leaned against the hedge,	248.48006869265762
after having cast a glance behind it. Beyond that hedge, that garden,	170.71230806183777
and that cottage, a dark mist enveloped with its folds that immensity	275.8515042289779
where Paris slept—a vast void from which glittered a few luminous	218.16328251155454
points, the funeral stars of that hell!	301.4413004111789
But for D’Artagnan all aspects were clothed happily, all ideas wore a	173.53838042099312
smile, all shades were diaphanous. The appointed hour was about to	317.74854646788833
strike. In fact, at the end of a few minutes the belfry of St. Cloud	187.18390271906435
let fall slowly ten strokes from its sonorous jaws. There was something	181.86365454862695
melancholy in this brazen voice pouring out its lamentations in the	230.69922689838282
middle of the night; but each of those strokes, which made up the	276.13952030247634
expected hour, vibrated harmoniously to the heart of the young man.	271.14826357719323
His eyes were fixed upon the little pavilion situated at the angle of	207.88424639820644
the wall, of which all the windows were closed with shutters, except	298.2562272132475
one on the first story. Through this window shone a mild light which	222.87466523847905
silvered the foliage of two or three linden trees which formed a group	312.0213948521473
outside the park. There could be no doubt that behind this little	233.47450145626712
window, which threw forth such friendly beams, the pretty Mme.	320.87690864291676
Bonacieux expected him.	334.2034503796474
Wrapped in this sweet idea, D’Artagnan waited half an hour without the	230.19386241475524
least impatience, his eyes fixed upon that charming little abode of	288.7493486186429
which he could perceive a part of the ceiling with its gilded moldings,	340.9533282869375
attesting the elegance of the rest of the apartment.	354.1908204385443
The belfry of St. Cloud sounded half past ten.	282.03298591075543
This time, without knowing why, D’Artagnan felt a cold shiver run	224.7823670485599
through his veins. Perhaps the cold began to affect him, and he took a	205.4798526576097
perfectly physical sensation for a moral impression.	176.0355149929059
Then the idea seized him that he had read incorrectly, and that the	236.63833336789696
appointment was for eleven o’clock. He drew near to the window, and	321.63403265285865
placing himself so that a ray of light should fall upon the letter as	208.1726565106377
he held it, he drew it from his pocket and read it again; but he had	221.23103356463284
not been mistaken, the appointment was for ten o’clock. He went and	290.46924348793186
resumed his post, beginning to be rather uneasy at this silence and	182.25157642653596
this solitude.	209.5229749540491
Eleven o’clock sounded.	335.787078392318
D’Artagnan began now really to fear that something had happened to Mme.	322.3862920156082
Bonacieux. He clapped his hands three times—the ordinary signal of	303.5203673411338
lovers; but nobody replied to him, not even an echo.	322.3526837458728
He then thought, with a touch of vexation, that perhaps the young woman	282.59515096926816
had fallen asleep while waiting for him. He approached the wall, and	277.75439378300655
tried to climb it; but the wall had been recently pointed, and	242.87200853501213
D’Artagnan could get no hold.	249.70750964382825
At that moment he thought of the trees, upon whose leaves the light	173.5709428536189
still shone; and as one of them drooped over the road, he thought that	355.4929569994966
from its branches he might get a glimpse of the interior of the	197.88691647572745
pavilion.	210.23031157517588
The tree was easy to climb. Besides, D’Artagnan was but twenty years	232.8820944670927
old, and consequently had not yet forgotten his schoolboy habits. In an	318.6149183866034
instant he was among the branches, and his keen eyes plunged through	296.49365879726986
the transparent panes into the interior of the pavilion.	223.1361842695938
It was a strange thing, and one which made D’Artagnan tremble from the	297.28449535162076
sole of his foot to the roots of his hair, to find that this soft	297.89447052600167
light, this calm lamp, enlightened a scene of fearful disorder. One of	350.90585159209206
the windows was broken, the door of the chamber had been beaten in and	246.19162309314527
hung, split in two, on its hinges. A table, which had been covered with	248.461446101089
an elegant supper, was overturned. The decanters broken in pieces, and	300.09384951853673
the fruits crushed, strewed the floor. Everything in the apartment gave	267.24356185710883
evidence of a violent and desperate struggle. D’Artagnan even fancied	317.0154297099456
he could recognize amid this strange disorder, fragments of garments,	289.3661005175942
and some bloody spots staining the cloth and the curtains. He hastened	299.6671507646803
to descend into the street, with a frightful beating at his heart; he	227.79038863848572
wished to see if he could find other traces of violence.	352.5434955589293
The little soft light shone on in the calmness of the night. D’Artagnan	355.8650316011534
then perceived a thing that he had not before remarked—for nothing had	205.52842448552056
led him to the examination—that the ground, trampled here and	199.31770618169176
hoofmarked there, presented confused traces of men and horses. Besides,	212.2617342086754
the wheels of a carriage, which appeared to have come from Paris, had	350.71488428009616
made a deep impression in the soft earth, which did not extend beyond	218.15310069890342
the pavilion, but turned again toward Paris.	348.31141714879436
At length D’Artagnan, in pursuing his researches, found near the wall a	275.3293551019466
woman’s torn glove. This glove, wherever it had not touched the muddy	284.15874293653724
ground, was of irreproachable odor. It was one of those perfumed gloves	339.65667351185795
that lovers like to snatch from a pretty hand.	208.49671050769166
As D’Artagnan pursued his investigations, a more abundant and more icy	357.2317654157857
sweat rolled in large drops from his forehead; his heart was oppressed	338.05240191553276
by a horrible anguish; his respiration was broken and short. And yet he	297.0843872798173
said, to reassure himself, that this pavilion perhaps had nothing in	180.41119009029467
common with Mme. Bonacieux; that the young woman had made an	190.64876293115182
appointment with him before the pavilion, and not in the pavilion; that	229.22399370233097
she might have been detained in Paris by her duties, or perhaps by the	351.2299970808982
jealousy of her husband.	266.19025040316035
But all these reasons were combated, destroyed, overthrown, by that	208.05750718239028
feeling of intimate pain which, on certain occasions, takes possession	313.3828107226643
of our being, and cries to us so as to be understood unmistakably that	311.3715656001694
some great misfortune is hanging over us.	183.33167599504716
Then D’Artagnan became almost wild. He ran along the high road, took	261.50397795943337
the path he had before taken, and reaching the ferry, interrogated the	206.66583696335255
boatman.	321.7365596933682
About seven o’clock in the evening, the boatman had taken over a young	234.20881412977127
woman, wrapped in a black mantle, who appeared to be very anxious not	324.63685291748936
to be recognized; but entirely on account of her precautions, the	241.63274704520126
boatman had paid more attention to her and discovered that she was	184.9195343518362
young and pretty.	166.59204127063418
There were then, as now, a crowd of young and pretty women who came to	278.8520662240336
St. Cloud, and who had reasons for not being seen, and yet D’Artagnan	255.569012588271
did not for an instant doubt that it was Mme. Bonacieux whom the	262.5261532282553
boatman had noticed.	251.67799221051746
D’Artagnan took advantage of the lamp which burned in the cabin of the	307.73163957033125
ferryman to read the billet of Mme. Bonacieux once again, and satisfy	212.2828008012451
himself that he had not been mistaken, that the appointment was at St.	210.73512087240468
Cloud and not elsewhere, before the D’Estrées’s pavilion and not in	251.52630937917127
another street. Everything conspired to prove to D’Artagnan that his	192.6315405046429
presentiments had not deceived him, and that a great misfortune had	326.68741470183727
happened.	185.036910187417
He again ran back to the château. It appeared to him that something	311.480244174773
might have happened at the pavilion in his absence, and that fresh	259.55654312703894
information awaited him. The lane was still deserted, and the same calm	333.8114725793949
soft light shone through the window.	167.25774284777225
D’Artagnan then thought of that cottage, silent and obscure, which had	281.2270717342366
no doubt seen all, and could tell its tale. The gate of the enclosure	360.58858890598583
was shut; but he leaped over the hedge, and in spite of the barking of	338.9418632187784
a chained-up dog, went up to the cabin.	259.5054353176073
No one answered to his first knocking. A silence of death reigned in	194.88879938182197
the cabin as in the pavilion; but as the cabin was his last resource,	221.50583849675525
he knocked again.	245.87755941884814
It soon appeared to him that he heard a slight noise within—a timid	207.21785404710548
noise which seemed to tremble lest it should be heard.	190.71553935498588
Then D’Artagnan ceased knocking, and prayed with an accent so full of	182.4972029556647
anxiety and promises, terror and cajolery, that his voice was of a	183.34610324277145
nature to reassure the most fearful. At length an old, worm-eaten	334.3298463215088
shutter was opened, or rather pushed ajar, but closed again as soon as	283.1794880305382
the light from a miserable lamp which burned in the corner had shone	240.22376426805198
upon the baldric, sword belt, and pistol pommels of D’Artagnan.	203.79869363292363
Nevertheless, rapid as the movement had been, D’Artagnan had had time	219.40341856365822
to get a glimpse of the head of an old man.	286.0977071031019
“In the name of heaven!” cried he, “listen to me; I have been waiting	239.5882861060415
for someone who has not come. I am dying with anxiety. Has anything	324.5937983796007
particular happened in the neighborhood? Speak!”	226.11172316882022
The window was again opened slowly, and the same face appeared, only it	233.1458153745973
was now still more pale than before.	339.78249196381114
D’Artagnan related his story simply, with the omission of names. He	233.97127607844095
told how he had a rendezvous with a young woman before that pavilion,	338.55048171117096
and how, not seeing her come, he had climbed the linden tree, and by	250.86218627895755
the light of the lamp had seen the disorder of the chamber.	364.54929034296015
The old man listened attentively, making a sign only that it was all	203.74978842405488
so; and then, when D’Artagnan had ended, he shook his head with an air	184.36492347093613
that announced nothing good.	296.57353220281874
“What do you mean?” cried D’Artagnan. “In the name of heaven, explain	294.6829615972521
yourself!”	214.14081206913278
“Oh! Monsieur,” said the old man, “ask me nothing; for if I dared tell	347.9010003133942
you what I have seen, certainly no good would befall me.”	287.981874064629
“You have, then, seen something?” replied D’Artagnan. “In that case, in	264.20734537915354
the name of heaven,” continued he, throwing him a pistole, “tell me	224.3524767881852
what you have seen, and I will pledge you the word of a gentleman that	247.76143640645302
not one of your words shall escape from my heart.”	220.37762480828889
The old man read so much truth and so much grief in the face of the	223.80732246507742
young man that he made him a sign to listen, and repeated in a low	226.55288517335276
voice: “It was scarcely nine o’clock when I heard a noise in the	218.87089094092372
street, and was wondering what it could be, when on coming to my door,	234.63825044174467
I found that somebody was endeavoring to open it. As I am very poor and	180.12509237211177
am not afraid of being robbed, I went and opened the gate and saw three	273.02540165358334
men at a few paces from it. In the shadow was a carriage with two	259.9003945726166
horses, and some saddlehorses. These horses evidently belonged to the	278.9186369485081
three men, who were dressed as cavaliers. ‘Ah, my worthy gentlemen,’	287.3311367162322
cried I, ‘what do you want?’ ‘You must have a ladder?’ said he who	230.06666707027782
appeared to be the leader of the party. ‘Yes, monsieur, the one with	282.6279350956163
which I gather my fruit.’ ‘Lend it to us, and go into your house again;	315.86196143887577
there is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you. Only remember	217.14450391010732
this—if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may hear (for	320.4650162098503
you will look and you will listen, I am quite sure, however we may	342.6075688163877
threaten you), you are lost.’ At these words he threw me a crown, which	233.25956270313839
I picked up, and he took the ladder. After shutting the gate behind	275.279742416646
them, I pretended to return to the house, but I immediately went out a	335.50119196260033
back door, and stealing along in the shade of the hedge, I gained	189.70146736297897
yonder clump of elder, from which I could hear and see everything. The	226.07308259898844
three men brought the carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little	174.3006392185136
man, stout, short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark	299.9489545160029
color, who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in	285.7701740495243
at the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone up,	347.7475023134464
and whispered, ‘It is she!’ Immediately, he who had spoken to me	327.7912786569714
approached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key he had in his	280.81473050334785
hand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the same time the other	259.7107817193133
two men ascended the ladder. The little old man remained at the coach	218.69719753313314
door; the coachman took care of his horses, the lackey held the	238.7612133694588
saddlehorses. All at once great cries resounded in the pavilion, and a	276.8923125165717
woman came to the window, and opened it, as if to throw herself out of	271.2679830747029
it; but as soon as she perceived the other two men, she fell back and	340.8522086317579
they went into the chamber. Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise	218.9877380646294
of breaking furniture. The woman screamed, and cried for help; but her	328.5415594204045
cries were soon stifled. Two of the men appeared, bearing the woman in	279.0170788362831
their arms, and carried her to the carriage, into which the little old	282.23292834872814
man got after her. The leader closed the window, came out an instant	364.5230899764791
after by the door, and satisfied himself that the woman was in the	316.65877541438454
carriage. His two companions were already on horseback. He sprang into	195.95703569177005
his saddle; the lackey took his place by the coachman; the carriage	243.37937443771858
went off at a quick pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was	198.19706852830336
over. From that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything.”	268.23575150971624
D’Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained	289.7045163788697
motionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy were	252.29136022882898
howling in his heart.	319.2639693599657
“But, my good gentleman,” resumed the old man, upon whom this mute	201.00597100255985
despair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and tears would	186.19637287113846
have done, “do not take on so; they did not kill her, and that’s a	357.8190578876642
comfort.”	304.69027218435815
“Can you guess,” said D’Artagnan, “who was the man who headed this	170.06986559772167
infernal expedition?”	293.36612367353234
“I don’t know him.”	228.45699447050757
“But as you spoke to him you must have seen him.”	224.02224360616572
“Oh, it’s a description you want?”	202.95565374219126
“Exactly so.”	189.8289799710614
“A tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air of a	236.96115550947317
gentleman.”	181.40533975247592
“That’s the man!” cried D’Artagnan, “again he, forever he! He is my	190.45194078614196
demon, apparently. And the other?”	302.42648103674287
“Which?”	298.52468077445997
“The short one.”	308.1176214484479
“Oh, he was not a gentleman, I’ll answer for it; besides, he did not	340.81771707375196
wear a sword, and the others treated him with small consideration.”	169.5597625415843
“Some lackey,” murmured D’Artagnan. “Poor woman, poor woman, what have	288.0670424680471
they done with you?”	198.13830468865336
“You have promised to be secret, my good monsieur?” said the old man.	239.357922920014
“And I renew my promise. Be easy, I am a gentleman. A gentleman has but	259.38022653016947
his word, and I have given you mine.”	246.5839988466465
With a heavy heart, D’Artagnan again bent his way toward the ferry.	282.5023127776277
Sometimes he hoped it could not be Mme. Bonacieux, and that he should	169.02006529851482
find her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he feared she had had an	217.8648572466543
intrigue with another, who, in a jealous fit, had surprised her and	186.44523558021734
carried her off. His mind was torn by doubt, grief, and despair.	255.0308008827535
“Oh, if I had my three friends here,” cried he, “I should have, at	272.94808882914697
least, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has become of	348.570229685883
them?”	181.1642517865983
It was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet. D’Artagnan	315.234539016725
went successively into all the cabarets in which there was a light, but	265.71162584196054
could not find Planchet in any of them.	334.3782689994142
At the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather dubious.	284.6401191796832
D’Artagnan had appointed six o’clock in the morning for his lackey, and	202.0437280086351
wherever he might be, he was right.	338.98359740005617
Besides, it came into the young man’s mind that by remaining in the	202.28282464572624
environs of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he would,	352.2999320657058
perhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious affair. At the	281.04833853753183
sixth cabaret, then, as we said, D’Artagnan stopped, asked for a bottle	293.052607968773
of wine of the best quality, and placing himself in the darkest corner	317.5033686419206
of the room, determined thus to wait till daylight; but this time again	315.08956215448967
his hopes were disappointed, and although he listened with all his	351.2108285170268
ears, he heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which	253.12234661085023
passed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised the	184.67845419527038
honorable society of which he formed a part, which could put him upon	327.32860975549363
the least track of her who had been stolen from him. He was compelled,	189.5983323390319
then, after having swallowed the contents of his bottle, to pass the	194.60923201391796
time as well as to evade suspicion, to fall into the easiest position	171.25420910792155
in his corner and to sleep, whether well or ill. D’Artagnan, be it	294.8003986538615
remembered, was only twenty years old, and at that age sleep has its	257.8180100346281
imprescriptible rights which it imperiously insists upon, even with the	347.61029642830056
saddest hearts.	294.0927032628398
Toward six o’clock D’Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable feeling	333.9622132313775
which generally accompanies the break of day after a bad night. He was	185.33779581375143
not long in making his toilet. He examined himself to see if advantage	274.026294622098
had been taken of his sleep, and having found his diamond ring on his	185.28535515207432
finger, his purse in his pocket, and his pistols in his belt, he rose,	217.75959424007618
paid for his bottle, and went out to try if he could have any better	341.8143161749105
luck in his search after his lackey than he had had the night before.	300.98731796735854
The first thing he perceived through the damp gray mist was honest	334.97979952981757
Planchet, who, with the two horses in hand, awaited him at the door of	289.8790956469144
a little blind cabaret, before which D’Artagnan had passed without even	339.3971873764617
a suspicion of its existence.	262.7189905368362
Chapter XXV.	236.26939005303734
PORTHOS	350.9717820232885
Instead of returning directly home, D’Artagnan alighted at the door of	218.44358932016004
M. de Tréville, and ran quickly up the stairs. This time he had decided	314.10915171425756
to relate all that had passed. M. de Tréville would doubtless give him	178.4306612536932
good advice as to the whole affair. Besides, as M. de Tréville saw the	169.70735284890924
queen almost daily, he might be able to draw from her Majesty some	168.89989122661032
intelligence of the poor young woman, whom they were doubtless making	175.6391782507246
pay very dearly for her devotedness to her mistress.	184.99895016739714
M. de Tréville listened to the young man’s account with a seriousness	337.1947886739363
which proved that he saw something else in this adventure besides a	195.0156375971438
love affair. When D’Artagnan had finished, he said, “Hum! All this	243.86850611531926
savors of his Eminence, a league off.”	362.5556123546917
“But what is to be done?” said D’Artagnan.	292.08601245813804
“Nothing, absolutely nothing, at present, but quitting Paris, as I told	279.1833241301132
you, as soon as possible. I will see the queen; I will relate to her	347.42505886901773
the details of the disappearance of this poor woman, of which she is no	285.41135773883695
doubt ignorant. These details will guide her on her part, and on your	254.6179157412601
return, I shall perhaps have some good news to tell you. Rely on me.”	334.1281632376812
D’Artagnan knew that, although a Gascon, M. de Tréville was not in the	260.00065302595453
habit of making promises, and that when by chance he did promise, he	174.04900109167286
more than kept his word. He bowed to him, then, full of gratitude for	295.66819314892234
the past and for the future; and the worthy captain, who on his side	166.93790208152524
felt a lively interest in this young man, so brave and so resolute,	234.786826143702
pressed his hand kindly, wishing him a pleasant journey.	234.142877480889
Determined to put the advice of M. de Tréville in practice instantly,	255.77512316094248
D’Artagnan directed his course toward the Rue des Fossoyeurs, in order	360.451531157463
to superintend the packing of his valise. On approaching the house, he	299.3942147672848
perceived M. Bonacieux in morning costume, standing at his threshold.	287.89266891101306
All that the prudent Planchet had said to him the preceding evening	225.47934577558684
about the sinister character of the old man recurred to the mind of	199.0960038704461
D’Artagnan, who looked at him with more attention than he had done	323.7275685591851
before. In fact, in addition to that yellow, sickly paleness which	247.18965341754654
indicates the insinuation of the bile in the blood, and which might,	201.0915048379884
besides, be accidental, D’Artagnan remarked something perfidiously	214.24643764877231
significant in the play of the wrinkled features of his countenance. A	353.2895732839624
rogue does not laugh in the same way that an honest man does; a	325.5271607110112
hypocrite does not shed the tears of a man of good faith. All falsehood	250.08305003008851
is a mask; and however well made the mask may be, with a little	359.922655088831
attention we may always succeed in distinguishing it from the true	308.29880093600565
face.	339.10000503882856
It appeared, then, to D’Artagnan that M. Bonacieux wore a mask, and	335.0246472386805
likewise that that mask was most disagreeable to look upon. In	298.5793271045604
consequence of this feeling of repugnance, he was about to pass without	172.23849415746326
speaking to him, but, as he had done the day before, M. Bonacieux	198.3828993744578
accosted him.	232.40267510884
“Well, young man,” said he, “we appear to pass rather gay nights! Seven	265.6519974411915
o’clock in the morning! _Peste!_ You seem to reverse ordinary customs,	169.1055546963209
and come home at the hour when other people are going out.”	220.41798456536623
“No one can reproach you for anything of the kind, Monsieur Bonacieux,”	205.48040350187338
said the young man; “you are a model for regular people. It is true	333.401301618476
that when a man possesses a young and pretty wife, he has no need to	196.95075934971103
seek happiness elsewhere. Happiness comes to meet him, does it not,	183.86109412349566
Monsieur Bonacieux?”	201.67660011986612
Bonacieux became as pale as death, and grinned a ghastly smile.	265.52030437360713
“Ah, ah!” said Bonacieux, “you are a jocular companion! But where the	338.48774367132273
devil were you gadding last night, my young master? It does not appear	354.94217850166876
to be very clean in the crossroads.”	360.1126410306709
D’Artagnan glanced down at his boots, all covered with mud; but that	246.44819423424104
same glance fell upon the shoes and stockings of the mercer, and it	308.342978435341
might have been said they had been dipped in the same mud heap. Both	220.78650688508296
were stained with splashes of mud of the same appearance.	299.61749915450787
Then a sudden idea crossed the mind of D’Artagnan. That little stout	257.5537016204991
man, short and elderly, that sort of lackey, dressed in dark clothes,	305.04096772935134
treated without ceremony by the men wearing swords who composed the	330.6548079841668
escort, was Bonacieux himself. The husband had presided at the	347.68212168871446
abduction of his wife.	249.62201122284245
A terrible inclination seized D’Artagnan to grasp the mercer by the	176.9098542789228
throat and strangle him; but, as we have said, he was a very prudent	317.57953131169364
youth, and he restrained himself. However, the revolution which	272.3231621670818
appeared upon his countenance was so visible that Bonacieux was	290.6151992008561
terrified at it, and he endeavored to draw back a step or two; but as	216.48753412592063
he was standing before the half of the door which was shut, the	291.21062957019853
obstacle compelled him to keep his place.	320.3780308899255
“Ah, but you are joking, my worthy man!” said D’Artagnan. “It appears	330.787410143448
to me that if my boots need a sponge, your stockings and shoes stand in	311.57028020848446
equal need of a brush. May you not have been philandering a little	353.34991685589864
also, Monsieur Bonacieux? Oh, the devil! That’s unpardonable in a man	270.69533088309026
of your age, and who besides, has such a pretty wife as yours.”	319.9054448111583
“Oh, Lord! no,” said Bonacieux, “but yesterday I went to St. Mandé to	183.16622919706168
make some inquiries after a servant, as I cannot possibly do without	348.02391133230185
one; and the roads were so bad that I brought back all this mud, which	206.95714382880317
I have not yet had time to remove.”	175.1466899594622
The place named by Bonacieux as that which had been the object of his	334.75807983450454
journey was a fresh proof in support of the suspicions D’Artagnan had	357.10052376723155
conceived. Bonacieux had named Mandé because Mandé was in an exactly	353.28348744146456
opposite direction from St. Cloud. This probability afforded him his	173.7690144780358
first consolation. If Bonacieux knew where his wife was, one might, by	232.39515593702492
extreme means, force the mercer to open his teeth and let his secret	316.67937460430335
escape. The question, then, was how to change this probability into a	175.63806526313948
certainty.	241.7716281328938
“Pardon, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, if I don’t stand upon ceremony,”	285.53960980283637
said D’Artagnan, “but nothing makes one so thirsty as want of sleep. I	195.07113525320256
am parched with thirst. Allow me to take a glass of water in your	285.63387580438024
apartment; you know that is never refused among neighbors.”	270.3272800418828
Without waiting for the permission of his host, D’Artagnan went quickly	360.5787420142751
into the house, and cast a rapid glance at the bed. It had not been	321.4715772686794
used. Bonacieux had not been abed. He had only been back an hour or	245.81660680179186
two; he had accompanied his wife to the place of her confinement, or	238.97504086334595
else at least to the first relay.	188.3776881010921
“Thanks, Monsieur Bonacieux,” said D’Artagnan, emptying his glass,	199.09908272040937
“that is all I wanted of you. I will now go up into my apartment. I	353.59198347082736
will make Planchet brush my boots; and when he has done, I will, if you	314.9008875328722
like, send him to you to brush your shoes.”	264.1773756079125
He left the mercer quite astonished at his singular farewell, and	245.2187334198893
asking himself if he had not been a little inconsiderate.	251.99161838390728
At the top of the stairs he found Planchet in a great fright.	354.2610905999991
“Ah, monsieur!” cried Planchet, as soon as he perceived his master,	186.64782957571654
“here is more trouble. I thought you would never come in.”	345.8964590633039
“What’s the matter now, Planchet?” demanded D’Artagnan.	331.59538699838413
“Oh! I give you a hundred, I give you a thousand times to guess,	212.68271886904645
monsieur, the visit I received in your absence.”	263.5823367303387
“When?”	174.08149154272132
“About half an hour ago, while you were at Monsieur de Tréville’s.”	312.7419983044798
“Who has been here? Come, speak.”	171.07012606371265
“Monsieur de Cavois.”	183.9183715447639
“Monsieur de Cavois?”	191.87192868509655
“In person.”	346.9392999794801
“The captain of the cardinal’s Guards?”	255.82137469097484
“Himself.”	230.27448515228923
“Did he come to arrest me?”	349.8562764920163
“I have no doubt that he did, monsieur, for all his wheedling manner.”	329.976689685897
“Was he so sweet, then?”	307.60177267179506
“Indeed, he was all honey, monsieur.”	191.45724493316538
“Indeed!”	287.09341335404054
“He came, he said, on the part of his Eminence, who wished you well,	276.3732382428848
and to beg you to follow him to the Palais-Royal*.”	170.8016761364608
* It was called the Palais-Cardinal before Richelieu gave it to the	280.13591773525377
King.	175.1489083176947
“What did you answer him?”	236.78809899262728
“That the thing was impossible, seeing that you were not at home, as he	249.69995831930572
could see.”	310.5491589492586
“Well, what did he say then?”	333.425182997359
“That you must not fail to call upon him in the course of the day; and	332.9300140712836
then he added in a low voice, ‘Tell your master that his Eminence is	192.03344255851735
very well disposed toward him, and that his fortune perhaps depends	303.41720294779407
upon this interview.’”	315.53460557184405
“The snare is rather _maladroit_ for the cardinal,” replied the young	333.53773277749406
man, smiling.	307.7384793483925
“Oh, I saw the snare, and I answered you would be quite in despair on	317.97676561941273
your return.	226.12153092635094
“‘Where has he gone?’ asked Monsieur de Cavois.	201.3301168264206
“‘To Troyes, in Champagne,’ I answered.	257.2257948977725
“‘And when did he set out?’	233.25768774535584
“‘Yesterday evening.’”	218.52996315103275
“Planchet, my friend,” interrupted D’Artagnan, “you are really a	182.84464050325602
precious fellow.”	265.16892527093324
“You will understand, monsieur, I thought there would be still time, if	329.62036432994915
you wish, to see Monsieur de Cavois to contradict me by saying you were	357.393895786634
not yet gone. The falsehood would then lie at my door, and as I am not	170.2798309113827
a gentleman, I may be allowed to lie.”	170.04395243634093
“Be of good heart, Planchet, you shall preserve your reputation as a	272.6831521416057
veracious man. In a quarter of an hour we set off.”	174.51073290956046
“That’s the advice I was about to give Monsieur; and where are we	253.48242782151252
going, may I ask, without being too curious?”	293.2740357608469
_“Pardieu!_ In the opposite direction to that which you said I was	316.6046869083458
gone. Besides, are you not as anxious to learn news of Grimaud,	343.76536682774264
Mousqueton, and Bazin as I am to know what has become of Athos,	170.92522289322915
Porthos, and Aramis?”	209.59498246758287
“Yes, monsieur,” said Planchet, “and I will go as soon as you please.	193.54398719310612
Indeed, I think provincial air will suit us much better just now than	258.2305849186033
the air of Paris. So then—”	242.06151086799755
“So then, pack up our luggage, Planchet, and let us be off. On my part,	222.4842723305375
I will go out with my hands in my pockets, that nothing may be	195.00932238436226
suspected. You may join me at the Hôtel des Gardes. By the way,	327.5151777741329
Planchet, I think you are right with respect to our host, and that he	316.98397884606936
is decidedly a frightfully low wretch.”	179.0118987119246
“Ah, monsieur, you may take my word when I tell you anything. I am a	321.00574767441924
physiognomist, I assure you.”	224.4590944414615
D’Artagnan went out first, as had been agreed upon. Then, in order that	340.62830582798506
he might have nothing to reproach himself with, he directed his steps,	358.0579355168267
for the last time, toward the residences of his three friends. No news	221.4693801648902
had been received of them; only a letter, all perfumed and of an	324.15870520313103
elegant writing in small characters, had come for Aramis. D’Artagnan	345.7910175833367
took charge of it. Ten minutes afterward Planchet joined him at the	294.66945027605124
stables of the Hôtel des Gardes. D’Artagnan, in order that there might	289.2152641605557
be no time lost, had saddled his horse himself.	174.36952199600572
“That’s well,” said he to Planchet, when the latter added the	321.24052328495327
portmanteau to the equipment. “Now saddle the other three horses.”	172.89474488923236
“Do you think, then, monsieur, that we shall travel faster with two	331.5558900917907
horses apiece?” said Planchet, with his shrewd air.	199.9332681058615
“No, Monsieur Jester,” replied D’Artagnan; “but with our four horses we	229.5439357011935
may bring back our three friends, if we should have the good fortune to	257.5389716493318
find them living.”	348.30126656422175
“Which is a great chance,” replied Planchet, “but we must not despair	334.50212790404896
of the mercy of God.”	358.6561730220776
“Amen!” said D’Artagnan, getting into his saddle.	246.3876765037749
As they went from the Hôtel des Gardes, they separated, leaving the	339.802762670199
street at opposite ends, one having to quit Paris by the Barrière de la	208.8833788647571
Villette and the other by the Barrière Montmartre, to meet again beyond	220.25611820325418
St. Denis—a strategic maneuver which, having been executed with equal	207.5211925305586
punctuality, was crowned with the most fortunate results. D’Artagnan	168.87139745134044
and Planchet entered Pierrefitte together.	217.05860889557195
Planchet was more courageous, it must be admitted, by day than by	339.2959957665808
night. His natural prudence, however, never forsook him for a single	241.15122642553155
instant. He had forgotten not one of the incidents of the first	188.4811073954004
journey, and he looked upon everybody he met on the road as an enemy.	324.3937743740722
It followed that his hat was forever in his hand, which procured him	176.74267739576638
some severe reprimands from D’Artagnan, who feared that his excess of	316.35598191942984
politeness would lead people to think he was the lackey of a man of no	217.28013781716277
consequence.	319.8470696282354
Nevertheless, whether the passengers were really touched by the	236.0254851870328
urbanity of Planchet or whether this time nobody was posted on the	212.99426946586678
young man’s road, our two travelers arrived at Chantilly without any	338.1756945036037
accident, and alighted at the tavern of Great St. Martin, the same at	255.6887149264819
which they had stopped on their first journey.	328.33343172538025
The host, on seeing a young man followed by a lackey with two extra	339.4808669484913
horses, advanced respectfully to the door. Now, as they had already	359.20184799010764
traveled eleven leagues, D’Artagnan thought it time to stop, whether	285.7089169885743
Porthos were or were not in the inn. Perhaps it would not be prudent to	196.91289728148277
ask at once what had become of the Musketeer. The result of these	296.3341492903354
reflections was that D’Artagnan, without asking information of any	354.31662594448846
kind, alighted, commended the horses to the care of his lackey, entered	220.18424453134074
a small room destined to receive those who wished to be alone, and	343.7659793592851
desired the host to bring him a bottle of his best wine and as good a	175.64128577591285
breakfast as possible—a desire which further corroborated the high	200.5677581702059
opinion the innkeeper had formed of the traveler at first sight.	294.4605607081395
D’Artagnan was therefore served with miraculous celerity. The regiment	179.71113743972444
of the Guards was recruited among the first gentlemen of the kingdom;	319.7062230992315
and D’Artagnan, followed by a lackey, and traveling with four	340.0286143083637
magnificent horses, despite the simplicity of his uniform, could not	177.07677980313198
fail to make a sensation. The host desired himself to serve him; which	297.7390246875797
D’Artagnan perceiving, ordered two glasses to be brought, and commenced	314.0866645018824
the following conversation.	178.43748444526557
“My faith, my good host,” said D’Artagnan, filling the two glasses, “I	168.7854149143146
asked for a bottle of your best wine, and if you have deceived me, you	365.70523348346524
will be punished in what you have sinned; for seeing that I hate	183.66052890143828
drinking by myself, you shall drink with me. Take your glass, then, and	350.8821008792005
let us drink. But what shall we drink to, so as to avoid wounding any	233.4389991520004
susceptibility? Let us drink to the prosperity of your establishment.”	323.0494724638812
“Your Lordship does me much honor,” said the host, “and I thank you	278.9223007198487
sincerely for your kind wish.”	364.876326212644
“But don’t mistake,” said D’Artagnan, “there is more selfishness in my	186.8867459264204
toast than perhaps you may think—for it is only in prosperous	194.16587058996495
establishments that one is well received. In hôtels that do not	223.0707962272707
flourish, everything is in confusion, and the traveler is a victim to	289.3814241697705
the embarrassments of his host. Now, I travel a great deal,	230.4110501572689
particularly on this road, and I wish to see all innkeepers making a	196.7697171458563
fortune.”	249.42932067082862
“It seems to me,” said the host, “that this is not the first time I	253.07848329939145
have had the honor of seeing Monsieur.”	189.5177986722686
“Bah, I have passed perhaps ten times through Chantilly, and out of the	301.28346607368496
ten times I have stopped three or four times at your house at least.	234.81118700540088
Why I was here only ten or twelve days ago. I was conducting some	336.45680662181445
friends, Musketeers, one of whom, by the by, had a dispute with a	292.26301018477034
stranger—a man who sought a quarrel with him, for I don’t know what.”	328.7388926748637
“Exactly so,” said the host; “I remember it perfectly. It is not	315.3126473322291
Monsieur Porthos that your Lordship means?”	228.67380938062934
“Yes, that is my companion’s name. My God, my dear host, tell me if	350.73662812782453
anything has happened to him?”	342.68762460784717
“Your Lordship must have observed that he could not continue his	291.04753004530454
journey.”	226.7425172036427
“Why, to be sure, he promised to rejoin us, and we have seen nothing of	285.2227346380606
him.”	270.85123573448243
“He has done us the honor to remain here.”	304.73462904421797
“What, he had done you the honor to remain here?”	355.70167660631716
“Yes, monsieur, in this house; and we are even a little uneasy—”	180.87282048007793
“On what account?”	331.70128559770444
“Of certain expenses he has contracted.”	221.85534498892966
“Well, but whatever expenses he may have incurred, I am sure he is in a	311.63683412391623
condition to pay them.”	254.84296496536263
“Ah, monsieur, you infuse genuine balm into my blood. We have made	178.15778648388053
considerable advances; and this very morning the surgeon declared that	354.6881601288229
if Monsieur Porthos did not pay him, he should look to me, as it was I	335.0150933971014
who had sent for him.”	238.86361081547557
“Porthos is wounded, then?”	243.83197742775525
“I cannot tell you, monsieur.”	189.97195816068356
“What! You cannot tell me? Surely you ought to be able to tell me	271.78162646207636
better than any other person.”	263.3388036798214
“Yes; but in our situation we must not say all we know—particularly as	179.0920818092869
we have been warned that our ears should answer for our tongues.”	320.12908065144654
“Well, can I see Porthos?”	359.17891542673254
“Certainly, monsieur. Take the stairs on your right; go up the first	340.1665165091754
flight and knock at Number One. Only warn him that it is you.”	304.7039047587182
“Why should I do that?”	327.69597403738305
“Because, monsieur, some mischief might happen to you.”	198.5143141617963
“Of what kind, in the name of wonder?”	286.1235609901869
“Monsieur Porthos may imagine you belong to the house, and in a fit of	226.61367633265917
passion might run his sword through you or blow out your brains.”	302.94535632686336
“What have you done to him, then?”	271.5187610494792
“We have asked him for money.”	231.835013019209
“The devil! Ah, I can understand that. It is a demand that Porthos	222.80791342937312
takes very ill when he is not in funds; but I know he must be so at	246.97606325078726
present.”	357.76417952799386
“We thought so, too, monsieur. As our house is carried on very	220.10025627728095
regularly, and we make out our bills every week, at the end of eight	229.80568295546763
days we presented our account; but it appeared we had chosen an unlucky	217.22214229479562
moment, for at the first word on the subject, he sent us to all the	308.1343369264274
devils. It is true he had been playing the day before.”	257.4765052519993
“Playing the day before! And with whom?”	327.8394966286329
“Lord, who can say, monsieur? With some gentleman who was traveling	195.79595563559275
this way, to whom he proposed a game of _lansquenet_.”	227.31149994714
“That’s it, then, and the foolish fellow lost all he had?”	269.9972161392845
“Even to his horse, monsieur; for when the gentleman was about to set	361.26922453996906
out, we perceived that his lackey was saddling Monsieur Porthos’s	329.82496082044366
horse, as well as his master’s. When we observed this to him, he told	176.49677791012675
us all to trouble ourselves about our own business, as this horse	318.5855008368874
belonged to him. We also informed Monsieur Porthos of what was going	226.92457245220268
on; but he told us we were scoundrels to doubt a gentleman’s word, and	307.7456378917712
that as he had said the horse was his, it must be so.”	265.76583724828856
“That’s Porthos all over,” murmured D’Artagnan.	196.07313942340437
“Then,” continued the host, “I replied that as from the moment we	344.86893797265236
seemed not likely to come to a good understanding with respect to	203.62150292296315
payment, I hoped that he would have at least the kindness to grant the	221.12118824035025
favor of his custom to my brother host of the Golden Eagle; but	290.6303164156866
Monsieur Porthos replied that, my house being the best, he should	303.134400234734
remain where he was. This reply was too flattering to allow me to	241.5147350673783
insist on his departure. I confined myself then to begging him to give	186.37393094319864
up his chamber, which is the handsomest in the hôtel, and to be	219.24368899400457
satisfied with a pretty little room on the third floor; but to this	173.5503758590134
Monsieur Porthos replied that as he every moment expected his mistress,	279.63667842873457
who was one of the greatest ladies in the court, I might easily	350.1432352934861
comprehend that the chamber he did me the honor to occupy in my house	330.8295670840613
was itself very mean for the visit of such a personage. Nevertheless,	210.2601161816895
while acknowledging the truth of what he said, I thought proper to	258.0104890797042
insist; but without even giving himself the trouble to enter into any	215.15244402637575
discussion with me, he took one of his pistols, laid it on his table,	301.7237007862062
day and night, and said that at the first word that should be spoken to	280.682089963999
him about removing, either within the house or out of it, he would blow	230.95680195801765
out the brains of the person who should be so imprudent as to meddle	227.7850943023668
with a matter which only concerned himself. Since that time, monsieur,	341.88701505907454
nobody entered his chamber but his servant.”	344.8604374456214
“What! Mousqueton is here, then?”	224.79325322559652
“Oh, yes, monsieur. Five days after your departure, he came back, and	322.50056842197864
in a very bad condition, too. It appears that he had met with	184.00420761341684
disagreeableness, likewise, on his journey. Unfortunately, he is more	194.15812587811394
nimble than his master; so that for the sake of his master, he puts us	244.64468531205762
all under his feet, and as he thinks we might refuse what he asked for,	304.08615211399194
he takes all he wants without asking at all.”	278.5376020890305
“The fact is,” said D’Artagnan, “I have always observed a great degree	265.4873540862869
of intelligence and devotedness in Mousqueton.”	349.5528180389963
“That is possible, monsieur; but suppose I should happen to be brought	171.9427793758599
in contact, even four times a year, with such intelligence and	240.44783227872364
devotedness—why, I should be a ruined man!”	361.5009960338689
“No, for Porthos will pay you.”	231.58999213815582
“Hum!” said the host, in a doubtful tone.	196.66327526491708
“The favorite of a great lady will not be allowed to be inconvenienced	363.13224718058916
for such a paltry sum as he owes you.”	215.31991798049407
“If I durst say what I believe on that head—”	288.87260769323126
“What you believe?”	231.2990297964699
“I ought rather to say, what I know.”	304.3351251406738
“What you know?”	362.88708573319616
“And even what I am sure of.”	322.3641225612757
“And of what are you so sure?”	184.98464295319323
“I would say that I know this great lady.”	351.2931889512567
“You?”	266.3348957248801
“Yes; I.”	325.70501396210335
“And how do you know her?”	278.1733224540907
“Oh, monsieur, if I could believe I might trust in your discretion.”	215.1368553942305
“Speak! By the word of a gentleman, you shall have no cause to repent	360.542557307431
of your confidence.”	344.0529380494272
“Well, monsieur, you understand that uneasiness makes us do many	330.9004237372356
things.”	343.8417403119071
“What have you done?”	194.10146478822722
“Oh, nothing which was not right in the character of a creditor.”	284.3741199731953
“Well?”	237.49237307017424
“Monsieur Porthos gave us a note for his duchess, ordering us to put it	167.74013589418323
in the post. This was before his servant came. As he could not leave	301.15071581998944
his chamber, it was necessary to charge us with this commission.”	175.14794870769586
“And then?”	309.42849564968856
“Instead of putting the letter in the post, which is never safe, I took	252.7000284937688
advantage of the journey of one of my lads to Paris, and ordered him to	200.9286307543682
convey the letter to this duchess himself. This was fulfilling the	180.9383896278377
intentions of Monsieur Porthos, who had desired us to be so careful of	184.97841597629005
this letter, was it not?”	292.2620039890388
“Nearly so.”	196.47777693547684
“Well, monsieur, do you know who this great lady is?”	335.0017594768608
“No; I have heard Porthos speak of her, that’s all.”	275.9322718349823
“Do you know who this pretended duchess is?	185.6325202500741
“I repeat to you, I don’t know her.”	310.9802888434966
“Why, she is the old wife of a procurator* of the Châtelet, monsieur,	301.1037757254103
named Madame Coquenard, who, although she is at least fifty, still	263.60492162207436
gives herself jealous airs. It struck me as very odd that a princess	293.82468509391134
should live in the Rue aux Ours.”	322.2244360693287
* Attorney	297.44348178259395
“But how do you know all this?”	262.4855672751875
“Because she flew into a great passion on receiving the letter, saying	341.65314959837883
that Monsieur Porthos was a weathercock, and that she was sure it was	170.30878506598097
for some woman he had received this wound.”	292.91806241278334
“Has he been wounded, then?”	256.42254058327325
“Oh, good Lord! What have I said?”	211.3608390060478
“You said that Porthos had received a sword cut.”	298.9240556281237
“Yes, but he has forbidden me so strictly to say so.”	356.3793655885594
“And why so.”	360.2481416263775
“Zounds, monsieur! Because he had boasted that he would perforate the	231.92002392577064
stranger with whom you left him in dispute; whereas the stranger, on	199.96202400878002
the contrary, in spite of all his rodomontades quickly threw him on his	206.46389717115056
back. As Monsieur Porthos is a very boastful man, he insists that	216.13075885684978
nobody shall know he has received this wound except the duchess, whom	269.099182687568
he endeavored to interest by an account of his adventure.”	166.85973177093246
“It is a wound that confines him to his bed?”	365.03868877778564
“Ah, and a master stroke, too, I assure you. Your friend’s soul must	169.26407472337877
stick tight to his body.”	248.61169489306587
“Were you there, then?”	223.91117808433023
“Monsieur, I followed them from curiosity, so that I saw the combat	302.2794445492651
without the combatants seeing me.”	361.4099243894012
“And what took place?”	214.1858480673976
“Oh! The affair was not long, I assure you. They placed themselves on	286.37815629832187
guard; the stranger made a feint and a lunge, and that so rapidly that	299.3969209999184
when Monsieur Porthos came to the _parade_, he had already three inches	297.53213149101293
of steel in his breast. He immediately fell backward. The stranger	239.70618881367267
placed the point of his sword at his throat; and Monsieur Porthos,	306.7693879585455
finding himself at the mercy of his adversary, acknowledged himself	224.46470169545938
conquered. Upon which the stranger asked his name, and learning that it	361.20299868317005
was Porthos, and not D’Artagnan, he assisted him to rise, brought him	305.26338080578705
back to the hôtel, mounted his horse, and disappeared.”	247.7060054295247
“So it was with Monsieur d’Artagnan this stranger meant to quarrel?”	303.48897573503507
“It appears so.”	287.11131180996847
“And do you know what has become of him?”	314.2289985914556
“No, I never saw him until that moment, and have not seen him since.”	352.24980864550344
“Very well; I know all that I wish to know. Porthos’s chamber is, you	289.99528917585144
say, on the first story, Number One?”	296.8504023403216
“Yes, monsieur, the handsomest in the inn—a chamber that I could have	248.57461976253163
let ten times over.”	279.5341501421758
“Bah! Be satisfied,” said D’Artagnan, laughing, “Porthos will pay you	253.72096151088977
with the money of the Duchess Coquenard.”	262.8692958546617
“Oh, monsieur, procurator’s wife or duchess, if she will but loosen her	325.52613757633287
pursestrings, it will be all the same; but she positively answered that	357.72690249855094
she was tired of the exigencies and infidelities of Monsieur Porthos,	327.1503888910081
and that she would not send him a denier.”	200.15438646334536
“And did you convey this answer to your guest?”	243.4116428349855
“We took good care not to do that; he would have found in what fashion	185.20122612519881
we had executed his commission.”	172.73353507917867
“So that he still expects his money?”	185.77066366972323
“Oh, Lord, yes, monsieur! Yesterday he wrote again; but it was his	286.13653486197535
servant who this time put the letter in the post.”	306.52072235160927
“Do you say the procurator’s wife is old and ugly?”	208.8841967866079
“Fifty at least, monsieur, and not at all handsome, according to	275.3004108396364
Pathaud’s account.”	240.9455312307901
“In that case, you may be quite at ease; she will soon be softened.	292.2201994299591
Besides, Porthos cannot owe you much.”	230.1917034382583
“How, not much! Twenty good pistoles, already, without reckoning the	335.47080170891127
doctor. He denies himself nothing; it may easily be seen he has been	200.23384369327982
accustomed to live well.”	362.9365284146621
