“Never mind; if his mistress abandons him, he will find friends, I will	330.73690742177683
answer for it. So, my dear host, be not uneasy, and continue to take	171.29827522880652
all the care of him that his situation requires.”	213.42932773508562
“Monsieur has promised me not to open his mouth about the procurator’s	184.8547782181772
wife, and not to say a word of the wound?”	351.3196030504015
“That’s agreed; you have my word.”	179.17432576309946
“Oh, he would kill me!”	362.42583190291316
“Don’t be afraid; he is not so much of a devil as he appears.”	242.83084305478135
Saying these words, D’Artagnan went upstairs, leaving his host a little	307.6368920654351
better satisfied with respect to two things in which he appeared to be	275.4070516533726
very much interested—his debt and his life.	200.95881544815913
At the top of the stairs, upon the most conspicuous door of the	166.67044490133762
corridor, was traced in black ink a gigantic number “1.” D’Artagnan	191.2687775561697
knocked, and upon the bidding to come in which came from inside, he	168.73558579242928
entered the chamber.	267.16090177998956
Porthos was in bed, and was playing a game at _lansquenet_ with	282.33172756439524
Mousqueton, to keep his hand in; while a spit loaded with partridges	244.4447946774512
was turning before the fire, and on each side of a large chimneypiece,	232.89877886068103
over two chafing dishes, were boiling two stewpans, from which exhaled	210.301159064081
a double odor of rabbit and fish stews, rejoicing to the smell. In	255.97242692778977
addition to this he perceived that the top of a wardrobe and the marble	272.81213511373693
of a commode were covered with empty bottles.	238.8906569854422
At the sight of his friend, Porthos uttered a loud cry of joy; and	213.20739225911842
Mousqueton, rising respectfully, yielded his place to him, and went to	233.33050266362443
give an eye to the two stewpans, of which he appeared to have the	184.30511524715848
particular inspection.	351.9142581381059
“Ah, _pardieu!_ Is that you?” said Porthos to D’Artagnan. “You are	239.41605672669556
right welcome. Excuse my not coming to meet you; but,” added he,	255.13545498886458
looking at D’Artagnan with a certain degree of uneasiness, “you know	284.93391493872286
what has happened to me?”	306.46147830406824
“No.”	267.3513464755633
“Has the host told you nothing, then?”	283.2212383904971
“I asked after you, and came up as soon as I could.”	280.1132819505752
Porthos seemed to breathe more freely.	199.50724465757196
“And what has happened to you, my dear Porthos?” continued D’Artagnan.	270.61407629342546
“Why, on making a thrust at my adversary, whom I had already hit three	230.52467517356524
times, and whom I meant to finish with the fourth, I put my foot on a	318.00299668958155
stone, slipped, and strained my knee.”	248.85868130544787
“Truly?”	200.18732726652507
“Honor! Luckily for the rascal, for I should have left him dead on the	281.8133813179037
spot, I assure you.”	183.92491889500633
“And what has became of him?”	350.14370678009936
“Oh, I don’t know; he had enough, and set off without waiting for the	220.3445325599792
rest. But you, my dear D’Artagnan, what has happened to you?”	328.6814227869808
“So that this strain of the knee,” continued D’Artagnan, “my dear	310.56269678717797
Porthos, keeps you in bed?”	286.04421676225616
“My God, that’s all. I shall be about again in a few days.”	244.83316186676092
“Why did you not have yourself conveyed to Paris? You must be cruelly	198.0594019939283
bored here.”	170.6020585133719
“That was my intention; but, my dear friend, I have one thing to	350.6760572811213
confess to you.”	280.99057057972016
“What’s that?”	343.11632402291156
“It is that as I was cruelly bored, as you say, and as I had the	343.04202842337713
seventy-five pistoles in my pocket which you had distributed to me, in	341.37117012786695
order to amuse myself I invited a gentleman who was traveling this way	284.7931954195752
to walk up, and proposed a cast of dice. He accepted my challenge, and,	220.8272956407091
my faith, my seventy-five pistoles passed from my pocket to his,	234.15666209678136
without reckoning my horse, which he won into the bargain. But you, my	196.37107035404296
dear D’Artagnan?”	166.97609094912318
“What can you expect, my dear Porthos; a man is not privileged in all	240.42846058123797
ways,” said D’Artagnan. “You know the proverb ‘Unlucky at play, lucky	345.80050441188826
in love.’ You are too fortunate in your love for play not to take its	234.30439358187323
revenge. What consequence can the reverses of fortune be to you? Have	267.405263897213
you not, happy rogue that you are—have you not your duchess, who cannot	239.72428473597853
fail to come to your aid?”	259.2046824214421
“Well, you see, my dear D’Artagnan, with what ill luck I play,” replied	320.6551821825624
Porthos, with the most careless air in the world. “I wrote to her to	243.53890521234385
send me fifty louis or so, of which I stood absolutely in need on	314.7431127623446
account of my accident.”	263.8614724596161
“Well?”	179.27468348275994
“Well, she must be at her country seat, for she has not answered me.”	270.6564617506108
“Truly?”	191.19612558932297
“No; so I yesterday addressed another epistle to her, still more	294.1472966977413
pressing than the first. But you are here, my dear fellow, let us speak	250.50324487139136
of you. I confess I began to be very uneasy on your account.”	203.25845490814936
“But your host behaves very well toward you, as it appears, my dear	241.6486381669583
Porthos,” said D’Artagnan, directing the sick man’s attention to the	317.16696415872264
full stewpans and the empty bottles.	186.8759986258843
“So, so,” replied Porthos. “Only three or four days ago the impertinent	187.3518161019437
jackanapes gave me his bill, and I was forced to turn both him and his	198.8167300721707
bill out of the door; so that I am here something in the fashion of a	325.5466179929728
conqueror, holding my position, as it were, my conquest. So you see,	253.76986401608383
being in constant fear of being forced from that position, I am armed	244.48098278642726
to the teeth.”	329.59585163770055
“And yet,” said D’Artagnan, laughing, “it appears to me that from time	213.52217218443883
to time you must make _sorties_.” And he again pointed to the bottles	184.90256428341655
and the stewpans.	282.8099478521339
“Not I, unfortunately!” said Porthos. “This miserable strain confines	225.4791799602705
me to my bed; but Mousqueton forages, and brings in provisions. Friend	306.18932861038013
Mousqueton, you see that we have a reinforcement, and we must have an	303.63388878965765
increase of supplies.”	304.43007614201684
“Mousqueton,” said D’Artagnan, “you must render me a service.”	226.42484787316525
“What, monsieur?”	286.4596830117297
“You must give your recipe to Planchet. I may be besieged in my turn,	331.9539600392653
and I shall not be sorry for him to be able to let me enjoy the same	354.65180969562005
advantages with which you gratify your master.”	335.919677395163
“Lord, monsieur! There is nothing more easy,” said Mousqueton, with a	213.7135677464153
modest air. “One only needs to be sharp, that’s all. I was brought up	195.47734149181946
in the country, and my father in his leisure time was something of a	249.82997406980178
poacher.”	180.2001914265549
“And what did he do the rest of his time?”	341.0529453789162
“Monsieur, he carried on a trade which I have always thought	200.27122148062338
satisfactory.”	266.2997445422069
“Which?”	298.7507805807837
“As it was a time of war between the Catholics and the Huguenots, and	344.24813768166547
as he saw the Catholics exterminate the Huguenots and the Huguenots	276.3282298368346
exterminate the Catholics—all in the name of religion—he adopted a	303.11138721797386
mixed belief which permitted him to be sometimes Catholic, sometimes a	315.2097990657239
Huguenot. Now, he was accustomed to walk with his fowling piece on his	310.8469860424923
shoulder, behind the hedges which border the roads, and when he saw a	243.09281612929396
Catholic coming alone, the Protestant religion immediately prevailed in	302.2134832955729
his mind. He lowered his gun in the direction of the traveler; then,	231.1626885439434
when he was within ten paces of him, he commenced a conversation which	202.97230972808632
almost always ended by the traveler’s abandoning his purse to save his	330.773471827949
life. It goes without saying that when he saw a Huguenot coming, he	217.43987923083483
felt himself filled with such ardent Catholic zeal that he could not	201.01776627834846
understand how, a quarter of an hour before, he had been able to have	359.2684507842801
any doubts upon the superiority of our holy religion. For my part,	276.68396605836074
monsieur, I am Catholic—my father, faithful to his principles, having	267.46033070807863
made my elder brother a Huguenot.”	225.08234044234496
“And what was the end of this worthy man?” asked D’Artagnan.	197.31817267653855
“Oh, of the most unfortunate kind, monsieur. One day he was surprised	276.6331283841523
in a lonely road between a Huguenot and a Catholic, with both of whom	344.2716469055667
he had before had business, and who both knew him again; so they united	196.5024414969357
against him and hanged him on a tree. Then they came and boasted of	298.6777302627333
their fine exploit in the cabaret of the next village, where my brother	339.568993046091
and I were drinking.”	224.5408767110765
“And what did you do?” said D’Artagnan.	194.53431630660867
“We let them tell their story out,” replied Mousqueton. “Then, as in	232.0645392179365
leaving the cabaret they took different directions, my brother went and	299.43520726607164
hid himself on the road of the Catholic, and I on that of the Huguenot.	269.9890479745408
Two hours after, all was over; we had done the business of both,	284.05130189324746
admiring the foresight of our poor father, who had taken the precaution	203.73533796609783
to bring each of us up in a different religion.”	346.8178168334499
“Well, I must allow, as you say, your father was a very intelligent	343.82367157159786
fellow. And you say in his leisure moments the worthy man was a	282.9476058319426
poacher?”	336.5422803099401
“Yes, monsieur, and it was he who taught me to lay a snare and ground a	346.08575721105973
line. The consequence is that when I saw our laborers, which did not at	247.96614924496225
all suit two such delicate stomachs as ours, I had recourse to a little	250.54091109866977
of my old trade. While walking near the wood of Monsieur le Prince, I	229.50590004833958
laid a few snares in the runs; and while reclining on the banks of his	330.6142832736133
Highness’s pieces of water, I slipped a few lines into his fish ponds.	337.4347982026801
So that now, thanks be to God, we do not want, as Monsieur can testify,	355.6413736404686
for partridges, rabbits, carp or eels—all light, wholesome food,	331.69277005481933
suitable for the sick.”	231.32196250204828
“But the wine,” said D’Artagnan, “who furnishes the wine? Your host?”	257.03316791206294
“That is to say, yes and no.”	266.6984600947588
“How yes and no?”	209.62008775248933
“He furnishes it, it is true, but he does not know that he has that	257.9517331764457
honor.”	207.6313383043209
“Explain yourself, Mousqueton; your conversation is full of instructive	257.58066594211226
things.”	320.57875179951407
“That is it, monsieur. It has so chanced that I met with a Spaniard in	190.75571169293923
my peregrinations who had seen many countries, and among them the New	181.6303226302084
World.”	187.26863820781807
“What connection can the New World have with the bottles which are on	301.99493224177263
the commode and the wardrobe?”	332.498076431252
“Patience, monsieur, everything will come in its turn.”	264.33925408481747
“This Spaniard had in his service a lackey who had accompanied him in	250.21062090321044
his voyage to Mexico. This lackey was my compatriot; and we became the	341.6234546772872
more intimate from there being many resemblances of character between	363.15457481253003
us. We loved sporting of all kinds better than anything; so that he	275.2170938250901
related to me how in the plains of the Pampas the natives hunt the	331.4177300157954
tiger and the wild bull with simple running nooses which they throw to	259.46951987353384
a distance of twenty or thirty paces the end of a cord with such	321.24137707265265
nicety; but in face of the proof I was obliged to acknowledge the truth	201.89872098247616
of the recital. My friend placed a bottle at the distance of thirty	350.0005442964608
paces, and at each cast he caught the neck of the bottle in his running	309.18494339146844
noose. I practiced this exercise, and as nature has endowed me with	253.8596670865604
some faculties, at this day I can throw the lasso with any man in the	322.7116727933963
world. Well, do you understand, monsieur? Our host has a well-furnished	297.46404828477614
cellar the key of which never leaves him; only this cellar has a	208.89174328397436
ventilating hole. Now through this ventilating hole I throw my lasso,	228.35336508461722
and as I now know in which part of the cellar is the best wine, that’s	187.43767377055767
my point for sport. You see, monsieur, what the New World has to do	173.43579810000517
with the bottles which are on the commode and the wardrobe. Now, will	179.4005418639025
you taste our wine, and without prejudice say what you think of it?”	288.0726295082946
“Thank you, my friend, thank you; unfortunately, I have just	182.53244625337834
breakfasted.”	286.78913356101236
“Well,” said Porthos, “arrange the table, Mousqueton, and while we	362.94576577820857
breakfast, D’Artagnan will relate to us what has happened to him during	268.588990360577
the ten days since he left us.”	277.6688164563135
“Willingly,” said D’Artagnan.	257.22899934038526
While Porthos and Mousqueton were breakfasting, with the appetites of	291.6823307754754
convalescents and with that brotherly cordiality which unites men in	312.770014541865
misfortune, D’Artagnan related how Aramis, being wounded, was obliged	307.6911386790465
to stop at Crèvecœur, how he had left Athos fighting at Amiens with	212.92945663992822
four men who accused him of being a coiner, and how he, D’Artagnan, had	326.25502461351925
been forced to run the Comtes de Wardes through the body in order to	287.908770483987
reach England.	220.64555215791546
But there the confidence of D’Artagnan stopped. He only added that on	234.08869410666313
his return from Great Britain he had brought back four magnificent	170.38243483591515
horses—one for himself, and one for each of his companions; then he	223.80876125372956
informed Porthos that the one intended for him was already installed in	308.58850897554123
the stable of the tavern.	343.58060061095415
At this moment Planchet entered, to inform his master that the horses	218.65125422440636
were sufficiently refreshed and that it would be possible to sleep at	340.2902654930433
Clermont.	225.25650808208061
As D’Artagnan was tolerably reassured with regard to Porthos, and as he	272.00699760513317
was anxious to obtain news of his two other friends, he held out his	280.8532993046166
hand to the wounded man, and told him he was about to resume his route	191.54333613171428
in order to continue his researches. For the rest, as he reckoned upon	181.6580951587782
returning by the same route in seven or eight days, if Porthos were	216.19840447904824
still at the Great St. Martin, he would call for him on his way.	350.13930826902265
Porthos replied that in all probability his sprain would not permit him	280.0861596658831
to depart yet awhile. Besides, it was necessary he should stay at	363.1620209843546
Chantilly to wait for the answer from his duchess.	359.0824897851604
D’Artagnan wished that answer might be prompt and favorable; and having	199.62086414298676
again recommended Porthos to the care of Mousqueton, and paid his bill	269.6167079229459
to the host, he resumed his route with Planchet, already relieved of	342.95292471871335
one of his led horses.	291.93935303089694
Chapter XXVI.	333.9153983371146
ARAMIS AND HIS THESIS	194.2193361297839
D’Artagnan had said nothing to Porthos of his wound or of his	333.069504906775
procurator’s wife. Our Béarnais was a prudent lad, however young he	176.57302201458242
might be. Consequently he had appeared to believe all that the	167.29930209352048
vainglorious Musketeer had told him, convinced that no friendship will	262.6020444484483
hold out against a surprised secret. Besides, we feel always a sort of	242.14958803605333
mental superiority over those whose lives we know better than they	329.0656830489529
suppose. In his projects of intrigue for the future, and determined as	207.74928638208343
he was to make his three friends the instruments of his fortune,	237.14617590131638
D’Artagnan was not sorry at getting into his grasp beforehand the	216.76161050507574
invisible strings by which he reckoned upon moving them.	293.79051876185594
And yet, as he journeyed along, a profound sadness weighed upon his	248.41206749508652
heart. He thought of that young and pretty Mme. Bonacieux who was to	311.4688271658373
have paid him the price of his devotedness; but let us hasten to say	177.07443342905623
that this sadness possessed the young man less from the regret of the	303.538173131579
happiness he had missed, than from the fear he entertained that some	245.64166713570359
serious misfortune had befallen the poor woman. For himself, he had no	216.88257948726834
doubt she was a victim of the cardinal’s vengeance; and, as was well	266.3715656003925
known, the vengeance of his Eminence was terrible. How he had found	339.56549581562166
grace in the eyes of the minister, he did not know; but without doubt	314.53754245599555
M. de Cavois would have revealed this to him if the captain of the	340.37913332925956
Guards had found him at home.	330.64840124721155
Nothing makes time pass more quickly or more shortens a journey than a	296.55093353674306
thought which absorbs in itself all the faculties of the organization	363.57224475666044
of him who thinks. External existence then resembles a sleep of which	220.9955335942973
this thought is the dream. By its influence, time has no longer	187.7316570794194
measure, space has no longer distance. We depart from one place, and	298.2552554767999
arrive at another, that is all. Of the interval passed, nothing remains	273.1552612629311
in the memory but a vague mist in which a thousand confused images of	314.16905085681196
trees, mountains, and landscapes are lost. It was as a prey to this	252.16736609857767
hallucination that D’Artagnan traveled, at whatever pace his horse	336.3150405789451
pleased, the six or eight leagues that separated Chantilly from	355.6871035159703
Crèvecœur, without his being able to remember on his arrival in the	318.7864200910425
village any of the things he had passed or met with on the road.	286.62045327258704
There only his memory returned to him. He shook his head, perceived the	257.46603512352686
cabaret at which he had left Aramis, and putting his horse to the trot,	292.20096411180145
he shortly pulled up at the door.	236.35412917869132
This time it was not a host but a hostess who received him. D’Artagnan	170.65064483780085
was a physiognomist. His eye took in at a glance the plump, cheerful	284.7015062283357
countenance of the mistress of the place, and he at once perceived	205.42453759276165
there was no occasion for dissembling with her, or of fearing anything	167.79500838652837
from one blessed with such a joyous physiognomy.	194.43097667962357
“My good dame,” asked D’Artagnan, “can you tell me what has become of	247.1070458044851
one of my friends, whom we were obliged to leave here about a dozen	222.17657763155614
days ago?”	320.2882775245464
“A handsome young man, three- or four-and-twenty years old, mild,	309.1004920938334
amiable, and well made?”	191.0736988580603
“That is he—wounded in the shoulder.”	284.0226692839169
“Just so. Well, monsieur, he is still here.”	251.48842842891213
“Ah, _pardieu!_ My dear dame,” said D’Artagnan, springing from his	234.25206730933368
horse, and throwing the bridle to Planchet, “you restore me to life;	328.66145873310086
where is this dear Aramis? Let me embrace him, I am in a hurry to see	310.21563950703626
him again.”	239.70895899177174
“Pardon, monsieur, but I doubt whether he can see you at this moment.”	307.65076749284833
“Why so? Has he a lady with him?”	272.2169277104932
“Jesus! What do you mean by that? Poor lad! No, monsieur, he has not a	317.9789083934228
lady with him.”	204.2513519715842
“With whom is he, then?”	231.64682830713963
“With the curate of Montdidier and the superior of the Jesuits of	321.6428472517929
Amiens.”	243.80166340951902
“Good heavens!” cried D’Artagnan, “is the poor fellow worse, then?”	255.131648971403
“No, monsieur, quite the contrary; but after his illness grace touched	220.399740141523
him, and he determined to take orders.”	355.0915320918915
“That’s it!” said D’Artagnan, “I had forgotten that he was only a	335.83704954546283
Musketeer for a time.”	306.4881807634619
“Monsieur still insists upon seeing him?”	235.355285354995
“More than ever.”	236.0751918318769
“Well, monsieur has only to take the right-hand staircase in the	196.75090913597444
courtyard, and knock at Number Five on the second floor.”	265.8996273626574
D’Artagnan walked quickly in the direction indicated, and found one of	261.18093475659145
those exterior staircases that are still to be seen in the yards of our	279.25716484926954
old-fashioned taverns. But there was no getting at the place of sojourn	354.29313176871597
of the future abbé; the defiles of the chamber of Aramis were as well	197.49335230671448
guarded as the gardens of Armida. Bazin was stationed in the corridor,	340.19589117508553
and barred his passage with the more intrepidity that, after many years	251.04713352639462
of trial, Bazin found himself near a result of which he had ever been	351.1096606799915
ambitious.	246.13369933165376
In fact, the dream of poor Bazin had always been to serve a churchman;	190.461281370705
and he awaited with impatience the moment, always in the future, when	341.08013000595383
Aramis would throw aside the uniform and assume the cassock. The	286.598711199302
daily-renewed promise of the young man that the moment would not long	256.3638236393889
be delayed, had alone kept him in the service of a Musketeer—a service	298.32302847973915
in which, he said, his soul was in constant jeopardy.	281.2819147203693
Bazin was then at the height of joy. In all probability, this time his	323.16782729959374
master would not retract. The union of physical pain with moral	269.4198471707723
uneasiness had produced the effect so long desired. Aramis, suffering	364.50899527439014
at once in body and mind, had at length fixed his eyes and his thoughts	254.53389720984035
upon religion, and he had considered as a warning from heaven the	297.6286640197747
double accident which had happened to him; that is to say, the sudden	184.92180018279672
disappearance of his mistress and the wound in his shoulder.	334.3910406722412
It may be easily understood that in the present disposition of his	264.36917547596994
master nothing could be more disagreeable to Bazin than the arrival of	195.92610117426045
D’Artagnan, which might cast his master back again into that vortex of	181.1029595391799
mundane affairs which had so long carried him away. He resolved, then,	199.88659541795533
to defend the door bravely; and as, betrayed by the mistress of the	321.63145252195477
inn, he could not say that Aramis was absent, he endeavored to prove to	306.3971165805433
the newcomer that it would be the height of indiscretion to disturb his	363.928875760139
master in his pious conference, which had commenced with the morning	178.50936473149113
and would not, as Bazin said, terminate before night.	202.07355972296696
But D’Artagnan took very little heed of the eloquent discourse of M.	273.5637111792186
Bazin; and as he had no desire to support a polemic discussion with his	180.08032950800316
friend’s valet, he simply moved him out of the way with one hand, and	305.1312745718841
with the other turned the handle of the door of Number Five. The door	258.3730672985983
opened, and D’Artagnan went into the chamber.	330.78974137520885
Aramis, in a black gown, his head enveloped in a sort of round flat	346.91094959420775
cap, not much unlike a _calotte_, was seated before an oblong table,	178.62509377062952
covered with rolls of paper and enormous volumes in folio. At his right	280.81476962642637
hand was placed the superior of the Jesuits, and on his left the curate	257.17149816092336
of Montdidier. The curtains were half drawn, and only admitted the	244.40925090369078
mysterious light calculated for beatific reveries. All the mundane	199.35822302083133
objects that generally strike the eye on entering the room of a young	341.97581937275686
man, particularly when that young man is a Musketeer, had disappeared	287.44225116008937
as if by enchantment; and for fear, no doubt, that the sight of them	180.55910163553736
might bring his master back to ideas of this world, Bazin had laid his	195.89616837875514
hands upon sword, pistols, plumed hat, and embroideries and laces of	307.3121539576996
all kinds and sorts. In their stead D’Artagnan thought he perceived in	360.1983199010465
an obscure corner a discipline cord suspended from a nail in the wall.	307.9114928122633
At the noise made by D’Artagnan in entering, Aramis lifted up his head,	200.34921216009047
and beheld his friend; but to the great astonishment of the young man,	169.17777051193698
the sight of him did not produce much effect upon the Musketeer, so	307.7995657925481
completely was his mind detached from the things of this world.	313.1121179239887
“Good day, dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis; “believe me, I am glad to see	322.08110030406124
you.”	205.3042912309111
“So am I delighted to see you,” said D’Artagnan, “although I am not yet	347.9197949586609
sure that it is Aramis I am speaking to.”	323.8402034978939
“To himself, my friend, to himself! But what makes you doubt it?”	172.72778716726162
“I was afraid I had made a mistake in the chamber, and that I had found	358.01175776551463
my way into the apartment of some churchman. Then another error seized	337.84455494508575
me on seeing you in company with these gentlemen—I was afraid you were	167.74389640915012
dangerously ill.”	208.45872096117247
The two men in black, who guessed D’Artagnan’s meaning, darted at him a	175.86716767713352
glance which might have been thought threatening; but D’Artagnan took	325.698910761415
no heed of it.	217.8737553653561
“I disturb you, perhaps, my dear Aramis,” continued D’Artagnan, “for by	226.28422004626552
what I see, I am led to believe that you are confessing to these	286.54361060812494
gentlemen.”	312.5247963278846
Aramis colored imperceptibly. “You disturb me? Oh, quite the contrary,	194.25441028202943
dear friend, I swear; and as a proof of what I say, permit me to	192.64239961524112
declare I am rejoiced to see you safe and sound.”	346.31829318204143
“Ah, he’ll come round,” thought D’Artagnan; “that’s not bad!”	308.5831496236471
“This gentleman, who is my friend, has just escaped from a serious	363.9798696977861
danger,” continued Aramis, with unction, pointing to D’Artagnan with	310.61951275448905
his hand, and addressing the two ecclesiastics.	365.34030642447823
“Praise God, monsieur,” replied they, bowing together.	243.6290126942698
“I have not failed to do so, your Reverences,” replied the young man,	327.3635250617159
returning their salutation.	351.4714447615865
“You arrive in good time, dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, “and by taking	319.020642621471
part in our discussion may assist us with your intelligence. Monsieur	168.99248263132642
the Principal of Amiens, Monsieur the Curate of Montdidier, and I are	306.78912925700433
arguing certain theological questions in which we have been much	296.0980704393194
interested; I shall be delighted to have your opinion.”	223.6695067556826
“The opinion of a swordsman can have very little weight,” replied	319.94248023892146
D’Artagnan, who began to be uneasy at the turn things were taking, “and	245.46875627935282
you had better be satisfied, believe me, with the knowledge of these	217.395455577456
gentlemen.”	196.40168610442416
The two men in black bowed in their turn.	245.1013575201144
“On the contrary,” replied Aramis, “your opinion will be very valuable.	361.0737337310098
The question is this: Monsieur the Principal thinks that my thesis	299.5333467367857
ought to be dogmatic and didactic.”	172.5071131089438
“Your thesis! Are you then making a thesis?”	349.9655585971284
“Without doubt,” replied the Jesuit. “In the examination which precedes	207.54065832925568
ordination, a thesis is always a requisite.”	197.87961744898138
“Ordination!” cried D’Artagnan, who could not believe what the hostess	261.39986814699046
and Bazin had successively told him; and he gazed, half stupefied, upon	312.2940652327493
the three persons before him.	358.18112204065073
“Now,” continued Aramis, taking the same graceful position in his easy	267.36223167750427
chair that he would have assumed in bed, and complacently examining his	172.4334868390297
hand, which was as white and plump as that of a woman, and which he	333.556424552352
held in the air to cause the blood to descend, “now, as you have heard,	323.4970600651128
D’Artagnan, Monsieur the Principal is desirous that my thesis should be	349.85940511818967
dogmatic, while I, for my part, would rather it should be ideal. This	234.75163359987363
is the reason why Monsieur the Principal has proposed to me the	172.55006031361108
following subject, which has not yet been treated upon, and in which I	342.5860120487168
perceive there is matter for magnificent elaboration—‘_Utraque manus in	332.48594200452186
benedicendo clericis inferioribus necessaria est_.’”	275.73701636740566
D’Artagnan, whose erudition we are well acquainted with, evinced no	311.59586171809775
more interest on hearing this quotation than he had at that of M. de	362.82070407184983
Tréville in allusion to the gifts he pretended that D’Artagnan had	282.3039970553096
received from the Duke of Buckingham.	193.5980391758841
“Which means,” resumed Aramis, that he might perfectly understand,	188.09974479887342
“‘The two hands are indispensable for priests of the inferior orders,	326.64672944661226
when they bestow the benediction.’”	223.2332477742579
“An admirable subject!” cried the Jesuit.	314.8823074793637
“Admirable and dogmatic!” repeated the curate, who, about as strong as	214.71388708718538
D’Artagnan with respect to Latin, carefully watched the Jesuit in order	202.77507471375807
to keep step with him, and repeated his words like an echo.	293.7351532457874
As to D’Artagnan, he remained perfectly insensible to the enthusiasm of	195.2653354727078
the two men in black.	287.5474683933413
“Yes, admirable! _prorsus admirabile!_” continued Aramis; “but which	305.4807451494682
requires a profound study of both the Scriptures and the Fathers. Now,	268.4565701199669
I have confessed to these learned ecclesiastics, and that in all	277.96431619179197
humility, that the duties of mounting guard and the service of the king	168.24755029244946
have caused me to neglect study a little. I should find myself,	210.86050948195287
therefore, more at my ease, _facilius natans_, in a subject of my own	319.04056456357876
choice, which would be to these hard theological questions what morals	293.4602782455701
are to metaphysics in philosophy.”	239.46581215755197
D’Artagnan began to be tired, and so did the curate.	263.49132109493576
“See what an exordium!” cried the Jesuit.	281.6817742623652
“Exordium,” repeated the curate, for the sake of saying something.	330.67362712298035
“_Quemadmodum inter cœlorum immensitatem_.”	307.2368274917772
Aramis cast a glance upon D’Artagnan to see what effect all this	234.94941672230254
produced, and found his friend gaping enough to split his jaws.	363.1061552398282
“Let us speak French, my father,” said he to the Jesuit; “Monsieur	324.7128614214976
d’Artagnan will enjoy our conversation better.”	352.6937985752244
“Yes,” replied D’Artagnan; “I am fatigued with reading, and all this	330.54051929111404
Latin confuses me.”	260.2160591774249
“Certainly,” replied the Jesuit, a little put out, while the curate,	295.54921793348126
greatly delighted, turned upon D’Artagnan a look full of gratitude.	341.74468077899445
“Well, let us see what is to be derived from this gloss. Moses, the	289.52722094186333
servant of God—he was but a servant, please to understand—Moses blessed	312.4097353825061
with the hands; he held out both his arms while the Hebrews beat their	182.31533680051203
enemies, and then he blessed them with his two hands. Besides, what	317.09953065075075
does the Gospel say? _Imponite manus_, and not _manum_—place the	177.29677794837696
_hands_, not the _hand_.”	245.81218259566825
“Place the _hands_,” repeated the curate, with a gesture.	303.5555303582412
“St. Peter, on the contrary, of whom the Popes are the successors,”	254.2053804323045
continued the Jesuit; “_porrige digitos_—present the fingers. Are you	173.97733207413
there, now?”	350.69656797145507
“_Certes_,” replied Aramis, in a pleased tone, “but the thing is	323.29301200337585
subtle.”	172.09031253335883
“The _fingers_,” resumed the Jesuit, “St. Peter blessed with the	240.41895999513173
_fingers_. The Pope, therefore blesses with the fingers. And with how	283.7963581545974
many fingers does he bless? With _three_ fingers, to be sure—one for	210.391846023948
the Father, one for the Son, and one for the Holy Ghost.”	293.94100604101277
All crossed themselves. D’Artagnan thought it was proper to follow this	344.1339654867767
example.	274.18410828373186
“The Pope is the successor of St. Peter, and represents the three	190.80625989134333
divine powers; the rest—_ordines inferiores_—of the ecclesiastical	318.6109157461883
hierarchy bless in the name of the holy archangels and angels. The most	359.45466327937265
humble clerks such as our deacons and sacristans, bless with holy water	198.72302834653777
sprinklers, which resemble an infinite number of blessing fingers.	327.92279765758553
There is the subject simplified. _Argumentum omni denudatum ornamento_.	281.84240724754875
I could make of that subject two volumes the size of this,” continued	202.15596829334623
the Jesuit; and in his enthusiasm he struck a St. Chrysostom in folio,	247.58902125152275
which made the table bend beneath its weight.	262.3302819107573
D’Artagnan trembled.	190.35822299360385
“_Certes_,” said Aramis, “I do justice to the beauties of this thesis;	178.90993593425452
but at the same time I perceive it would be overwhelming for me. I had	306.6176634157616
chosen this text—tell me, dear D’Artagnan, if it is not to your	189.46880007139856
taste—‘_Non inutile est desiderium in oblatione_’; that is, ‘A little	174.35103398854028
regret is not unsuitable in an offering to the Lord.’”	196.7140406555962
“Stop there!” cried the Jesuit, “for that thesis touches closely upon	298.4697863187612
heresy. There is a proposition almost like it in the _Augustinus_ of	225.67842214000734
the heresiarch Jansenius, whose book will sooner or later be burned by	321.28852287339953
the hands of the executioner. Take care, my young friend. You are	236.8663975173107
inclining toward false doctrines, my young friend; you will be lost.”	276.2941797285481
“You will be lost,” said the curate, shaking his head sorrowfully.	247.67722728626654
“You approach that famous point of free will which is a mortal rock.	316.85140249283694
You face the insinuations of the Pelagians and the semi-Pelagians.”	299.3168122304414
“But, my Reverend—” replied Aramis, a little amazed by the shower of	234.2762929740847
arguments that poured upon his head.	275.97935173541407
“How will you prove,” continued the Jesuit, without allowing him time	314.6366480176986
to speak, “that we ought to regret the world when we offer ourselves to	248.29617796889252
God? Listen to this dilemma: God is God, and the world is the devil. To	177.82476231327914
regret the world is to regret the devil; that is my conclusion.”	192.58093351895675
“And that is mine also,” said the curate.	308.4621986983931
“But, for heaven’s sake—” resumed Aramis.	363.7967614000625
“_Desideras diabolum_, unhappy man!” cried the Jesuit.	239.63592219118206
“He regrets the devil! Ah, my young friend,” added the curate,	352.44026550055366
groaning, “do not regret the devil, I implore you!”	278.6328117316625
D’Artagnan felt himself bewildered. It seemed to him as though he were	298.06135231278427
in a madhouse, and was becoming as mad as those he saw. He was,	180.99309551963853
however, forced to hold his tongue from not comprehending half the	279.8016981146319
language they employed.	302.3210270241808
“But listen to me, then,” resumed Aramis with politeness mingled with a	239.91353452450858
little impatience. “I do not say I regret; no, I will never pronounce	195.15577534907192
that sentence, which would not be orthodox.”	174.4794739556833
The Jesuit raised his hands toward heaven, and the curate did the same.	235.2233000371612
“No; but pray grant me that it is acting with an ill grace to offer to	250.3495634865546
the Lord only that with which we are perfectly disgusted! Don’t you	308.0056688642553
think so, D’Artagnan?”	310.13236974823894
“I think so, indeed,” cried he.	259.5157422656964
The Jesuit and the curate quite started from their chairs.	215.60109879361082
“This is the point of departure; it is a syllogism. The world is not	252.2382699092721
wanting in attractions. I quit the world; then I make a sacrifice. Now,	320.5233634022933
the Scripture says positively, ‘Make a sacrifice unto the Lord.’”	206.1750487455626
“That is true,” said his antagonists.	203.1873286179466
“And then,” said Aramis, pinching his ear to make it red, as he rubbed	356.4430151765856
his hands to make them white, “and then I made a certain _rondeau_ upon	244.75992421705513
it last year, which I showed to Monsieur Voiture, and that great man	213.0333910279075
paid me a thousand compliments.”	185.34850610600625
“A _rondeau!_” said the Jesuit, disdainfully.	258.106746095384
“A _rondeau!_” said the curate, mechanically.	324.81919133892274
“Repeat it! Repeat it!” cried D’Artagnan; “it will make a little	297.9336520796751
change.”	316.1418742744501
“Not so, for it is religious,” replied Aramis; “it is theology in	289.56045478050044
verse.”	339.27630703585316
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan.	176.69846259104867
“Here it is,” said Aramis, with a little look of diffidence, which,	210.70868171727054
however, was not exempt from a shade of hypocrisy:	206.70398033935948
“Vous qui pleurez un passé plein de charmes,	183.69688513628208
    Et qui trainez des jours infortunés,	320.4369552272402
    Tous vos malheurs se verront terminés,	177.11748818007493
Quand à Dieu seul vous offrirez vos larmes,	289.5009669506846
        Vous qui pleurez!”	330.0442250730049
“You who weep for pleasures fled,	322.70345854005717
    While dragging on a life of care,	329.45812584959333
    All your woes will melt in air,	190.68434475673632
If to God your tears are shed,	189.71081386619477
        You who weep!”	261.93333823098976
D’Artagnan and the curate appeared pleased. The Jesuit persisted in his	172.90497778238102
opinion. “Beware of a profane taste in your theological style. What	258.5349657507976
says Augustine on this subject: ‘_Severus sit clericorum verbo_.’”	333.1833188960908
“Yes, let the sermon be clear,” said the curate.	250.8570512864476
“Now,” hastily interrupted the Jesuit, on seeing that his acolyte was	187.60565235429897
going astray, “now your thesis would please the ladies; it would have	176.3301677626537
the success of one of Monsieur Patru’s pleadings.”	210.5366436827016
“Please God!” cried Aramis, transported.	288.126058633955
“There it is,” cried the Jesuit; “the world still speaks within you in	210.13668049510574
a loud voice, _altisimâ voce_. You follow the world, my young friend,	273.1762054154812
and I tremble lest grace prove not efficacious.”	328.6486424507812
“Be satisfied, my reverend father, I can answer for myself.”	187.53195727134565
“Mundane presumption!”	354.6359933445235
“I know myself, Father; my resolution is irrevocable.”	206.65027108544996
“Then you persist in continuing that thesis?”	230.06633041285795
“I feel myself called upon to treat that, and no other. I will see	281.7628391570958
about the continuation of it, and tomorrow I hope you will be satisfied	344.08153813617326
with the corrections I shall have made in consequence of your advice.”	365.66445793062974
“Work slowly,” said the curate; “we leave you in an excellent tone of	237.35605361599312
mind.”	235.63839400569682
“Yes, the ground is all sown,” said the Jesuit, “and we have not to	261.81094161005586
fear that one portion of the seed may have fallen upon stone, another	324.4066215035392
upon the highway, or that the birds of heaven have eaten the rest,	294.7621962413285
_aves cœli comederunt illam_.”	166.90109756393016
“Plague stifle you and your Latin!” said D’Artagnan, who began to feel	266.07308083769
all his patience exhausted.	222.33905768222334
“Farewell, my son,” said the curate, “till tomorrow.”	279.9653654751012
“Till tomorrow, rash youth,” said the Jesuit. “You promise to become	246.67078801269628
one of the lights of the Church. Heaven grant that this light prove not	222.71050863865338
a devouring fire!”	199.9572781725976
D’Artagnan, who for an hour past had been gnawing his nails with	293.96923688089544
impatience, was beginning to attack the quick.	327.74244855324685
The two men in black rose, bowed to Aramis and D’Artagnan, and advanced	324.3827915976699
toward the door. Bazin, who had been standing listening to all this	254.38107194076983
controversy with a pious jubilation, sprang toward them, took the	319.5011359562859
breviary of the curate and the missal of the Jesuit, and walked	233.39742581164847
respectfully before them to clear their way.	311.4369197466973
Aramis conducted them to the foot of the stairs, and then immediately	182.22157821183535
came up again to D’Artagnan, whose senses were still in a state of	247.09541590476294
confusion.	215.30433632533013
When left alone, the two friends at first kept an embarrassed silence.	216.64946351850446
It however became necessary for one of them to break it first, and as	219.21715429613724
D’Artagnan appeared determined to leave that honor to his companion,	256.6457716758651
Aramis said, “you see that I am returned to my fundamental ideas.”	303.3838447375473
“Yes, efficacious grace has touched you, as that gentleman said just	272.1980473782708
now.”	292.78515705748123
“Oh, these plans of retreat have been formed for a long time. You have	284.75084567582496
often heard me speak of them, have you not, my friend?”	274.3906195344905
“Yes; but I confess I always thought you jested.”	359.7770425469174
“With such things! Oh, D’Artagnan!”	331.34391161182657
“The devil! Why, people jest with death.”	186.84123547776153
“And people are wrong, D’Artagnan; for death is the door which leads to	205.17052794316538
perdition or to salvation.”	302.84590849774156
“Granted; but if you please, let us not theologize, Aramis. You must	224.76981065401628
have had enough for today. As for me, I have almost forgotten the	273.3378579407289
little Latin I have ever known. Then I confess to you that I have eaten	350.161967859736
nothing since ten o’clock this morning, and I am devilish hungry.”	259.6834295218731
“We will dine directly, my friend; only you must please to remember	297.1573001579813
that this is Friday. Now, on such a day I can neither eat flesh nor see	253.20373345106918
it eaten. If you can be satisfied with my dinner—it consists of cooked	296.9107134925032
tetragones and fruits.”	179.7568061981446
“What do you mean by tetragones?” asked D’Artagnan, uneasily.	247.7969790258703
“I mean spinach,” replied Aramis; “but on your account I will add some	216.50383907340435
eggs, and that is a serious infraction of the rule—for eggs are meat,	308.2355243121421
since they engender chickens.”	316.28530899793213
“This feast is not very succulent; but never mind, I will put up with	184.01591096980886
it for the sake of remaining with you.”	333.64836156650586
“I am grateful to you for the sacrifice,” said Aramis; “but if your	289.15355297094743
body be not greatly benefited by it, be assured your soul will.”	190.92984916663258
“And so, Aramis, you are decidedly going into the Church? What will our	222.02768196724728
two friends say? What will Monsieur de Tréville say? They will treat	289.49424309373205
you as a deserter, I warn you.”	339.33878669485193
“I do not enter the Church; I re-enter it. I deserted the Church for	329.68990347957424
the world, for you know that I forced myself when I became a	243.32493937415444
Musketeer.”	354.5195003203112
“I? I know nothing about it.”	243.05152947651126
“You don’t know I quit the seminary?”	233.3276158199488
“Not at all.”	202.95971084429303
“This is my story, then. Besides, the Scriptures say, ‘Confess	334.92675773149494
yourselves to one another,’ and I confess to you, D’Artagnan.”	292.3837257590843
“And I give you absolution beforehand. You see I am a good sort of a	359.0550264711397
man.”	318.91100250577176
“Do not jest about holy things, my friend.”	171.60506398648243
“Go on, then, I listen.”	347.5260048038925
“I had been at the seminary from nine years old; in three days I should	253.08388660638772
have been twenty. I was about to become an abbé, and all was arranged.	193.0219089208868
One evening I went, according to custom, to a house which I frequented	211.46309197484783
with much pleasure: when one is young, what can be expected?—one is	265.5492350927382
weak. An officer who saw me, with a jealous eye, reading the _Lives of	177.97904672263007
the Saints_ to the mistress of the house, entered suddenly and without	226.6088705141664
being announced. That evening I had translated an episode of Judith,	358.5260082044101
and had just communicated my verses to the lady, who gave me all sorts	262.8286748517117
of compliments, and leaning on my shoulder, was reading them a second	179.56110532899828
time with me. Her pose, which I must admit was rather free, wounded	333.8304314810808
this officer. He said nothing; but when I went out he followed, and	290.9491920368189
quickly came up with me. ‘Monsieur the Abbé,’ said he, ‘do you like	333.058024207646
blows with a cane?’ ‘I cannot say, monsieur,’ answered I; ‘no one has	180.51021297904413
ever dared to give me any.’ ‘Well, listen to me, then, Monsieur the	214.6691765110831
Abbé! If you venture again into the house in which I have met you this	215.45617242889435
evening, I will dare it myself.’ I really think I must have been	168.08669050743293
frightened. I became very pale; I felt my legs fail me; I sought for a	196.94755710057592
reply, but could find none—I was silent. The officer waited for his	282.87116349709413
reply, and seeing it so long coming, he burst into a laugh, turned upon	343.24540583597354
his heel, and re-entered the house. I returned to the seminary.	209.73590494386528
“I am a gentleman born, and my blood is warm, as you may have remarked,	282.10380790788554
my dear D’Artagnan. The insult was terrible, and although unknown to	251.13918522414815
the rest of the world, I felt it live and fester at the bottom of my	361.73242142680886
heart. I informed my superiors that I did not feel myself sufficiently	300.80050971513117
prepared for ordination, and at my request the ceremony was postponed	234.01623337495863
for a year. I sought out the best fencing master in Paris, I made an	361.2601551942139
agreement with him to take a lesson every day, and every day for a year	360.711402102451
I took that lesson. Then, on the anniversary of the day on which I had	256.04423190595264
been insulted, I hung my cassock on a peg, assumed the costume of a	317.5270882941942
cavalier, and went to a ball given by a lady friend of mine and to	309.4214975800501
which I knew my man was invited. It was in the Rue des	206.28456610825515
France-Bourgeois, close to La Force. As I expected, my officer was	252.81575952792463
there. I went up to him as he was singing a love ditty and looking	217.72115592315572
tenderly at a lady, and interrupted him exactly in the middle of the	237.51931043583568
second couplet. ‘Monsieur,’ said I, ‘does it still displease you that I	337.4072597915354
should frequent a certain house of La Rue Payenne? And would you still	300.67221575299203
cane me if I took it into my head to disobey you? The officer looked at	184.62004159563205
me with astonishment, and then said, ‘What is your business with me,	315.3921329610401
monsieur? I do not know you.’ ‘I am,’ said I, ‘the little abbé who	183.11893382849877
reads _Lives of the Saints_, and translates Judith into verse.’ ‘Ah,	285.0774608596555
ah! I recollect now,’ said the officer, in a jeering tone; ‘well, what	198.9319581454005
do you want with me?’ ‘I want you to spare time to take a walk with	185.61082360346964
me.’ ‘Tomorrow morning, if you like, with the greatest pleasure.’ ‘No,	266.8715929612282
not tomorrow morning, if you please, but immediately.’ ‘If you	300.38533349887837
absolutely insist.’ ‘I do insist upon it.’ ‘Come, then. Ladies,’ said	218.5825015015484
the officer, ‘do not disturb yourselves; allow me time just to kill	269.4570559645996
this gentleman, and I will return and finish the last couplet.’	250.04364758372216
“We went out. I took him to the Rue Payenne, to exactly the same spot	246.42668949022635
where, a year before, at the very same hour, he had paid me the	358.05848893014934
compliment I have related to you. It was a superb moonlight night. We	291.37492616294844
immediately drew, and at the first pass I laid him stark dead.”	182.18400620741664
“The devil!” cried D’Artagnan.	302.2309435054152
“Now,” continued Aramis, “as the ladies did not see the singer come	238.3117575962662
back, and as he was found in the Rue Payenne with a great sword wound	232.09220337897884
through his body, it was supposed that I had accommodated him thus; and	285.9722906826997
the matter created some scandal which obliged me to renounce the	240.65741293670783
cassock for a time. Athos, whose acquaintance I made about that period,	327.87702191126505
and Porthos, who had in addition to my lessons taught me some effective	176.88808140262225
tricks of fence, prevailed upon me to solicit the uniform of a	175.85803609790418
Musketeer. The king entertained great regard for my father, who had	207.97230914903014
fallen at the siege of Arras, and the uniform was granted. You may	363.75456157277256
understand that the moment has come for me to re-enter the bosom of the	363.3221366888802
Church.”	253.49507915877132
“And why today, rather than yesterday or tomorrow? What has happened to	277.2989300718323
you today, to raise all these melancholy ideas?”	328.3351207479168
“This wound, my dear D’Artagnan, has been a warning to me from heaven.”	356.04905105641626
“This wound? Bah, it is now nearly healed, and I am sure it is not that	365.98175338894873
which gives you the most pain.”	222.11054084677681
“What, then?” said Aramis, blushing.	283.4056429831709
“You have one at heart, Aramis, one deeper and more painful—a wound	219.38628593966277
made by a woman.”	207.84254232070145
The eye of Aramis kindled in spite of himself.	273.34915636542695
“Ah,” said he, dissembling his emotion under a feigned carelessness,	277.41605073733433
“do not talk of such things, and suffer love pains? _Vanitas	296.57946591692547
vanitatum!_ According to your idea, then, my brain is turned. And for	323.8948592772588
whom—for some _grisette_, some chambermaid with whom I have trifled in	232.4320733859567
some garrison? Fie!”	260.954143496557
“Pardon, my dear Aramis, but I thought you carried your eyes higher.”	192.6038910883325
“Higher? And who am I, to nourish such ambition? A poor Musketeer, a	341.8019822056006
beggar, an unknown—who hates slavery, and finds himself ill-placed in	280.25195164315926
the world.”	344.98269191094374
“Aramis, Aramis!” cried D’Artagnan, looking at his friend with an air	207.5891653578044
of doubt.	342.46546486928764
“Dust I am, and to dust I return. Life is full of humiliations and	221.68403115611625
sorrows,” continued he, becoming still more melancholy; “all the ties	294.5821190097378
which attach him to life break in the hand of man, particularly the	338.6865294665961
golden ties. Oh, my dear D’Artagnan,” resumed Aramis, giving to his	355.35137012408757
voice a slight tone of bitterness, “trust me! Conceal your wounds when	233.59180803284426
you have any; silence is the last joy of the unhappy. Beware of giving	302.2545449923165
anyone the clue to your griefs; the curious suck our tears as flies	201.27780273385804
suck the blood of a wounded hart.”	168.94598682343522
“Alas, my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, in his turn heaving a profound	342.61766862362396
sigh, “that is my story you are relating!”	247.12988792874353
“How?”	169.26077973725634
“Yes; a woman whom I love, whom I adore, has just been torn from me by	331.243129764513
force. I do not know where she is or whither they have conducted her.	273.31216687778334
She is perhaps a prisoner; she is perhaps dead!”	177.86387658287188
“Yes, but you have at least this consolation, that you can say to	214.24230659928338
yourself she has not quit you voluntarily, that if you learn no news of	177.1082011681451
her, it is because all communication with you is interdicted; while I—”	327.77780710305717
“Well?”	198.610249459902
“Nothing,” replied Aramis, “nothing.”	166.9182335796146
“So you renounce the world, then, forever; that is a settled thing—a	182.41462987660677
resolution registered!”	360.7338217161289
“Forever! You are my friend today; tomorrow you will be no more to me	360.43808832639445
than a shadow, or rather, even, you will no longer exist. As for the	289.47967146028674
world, it is a sepulcher and nothing else.”	229.0951829616481
“The devil! All this is very sad which you tell me.”	183.06974341262156
“What will you? My vocation commands me; it carries me away.”	308.29517811093797
D’Artagnan smiled, but made no answer.	186.76903265184666
Aramis continued, “And yet, while I do belong to the earth, I wish to	253.85019494315875
speak of you—of our friends.”	191.11454199505368
“And on my part,” said D’Artagnan, “I wished to speak of you, but I	339.40984765162693
find you so completely detached from everything! To love you cry, ‘Fie!	181.96062402367988
Friends are shadows! The world is a sepulcher!’”	209.29143888845033
“Alas, you will find it so yourself,” said Aramis, with a sigh.	176.86707841745763
“Well, then, let us say no more about it,” said D’Artagnan; “and let us	352.78316505959174
burn this letter, which, no doubt, announces to you some fresh	199.29120319661484
infidelity of your _grisette_ or your chambermaid.”	250.4690461925764
“What letter?” cried Aramis, eagerly.	287.96451147404235
“A letter which was sent to your abode in your absence, and which was	200.60587387456272
given to me for you.”	212.61723824044813
“But from whom is that letter?”	224.64217947383867
“Oh, from some heartbroken waiting woman, some desponding _grisette;_	217.31100054045342
from Madame de Chevreuse’s chambermaid, perhaps, who was obliged to	305.795354206844
return to Tours with her mistress, and who, in order to appear smart	360.2497666974265
and attractive, stole some perfumed paper, and sealed her letter with a	363.0500573474007
duchess’s coronet.”	273.32442311692773
“What do you say?”	358.43640770768184
“Hold! I must have lost it,” said the young man maliciously, pretending	275.9321237622956
to search for it. “But fortunately the world is a sepulcher; the men,	213.48269918683994
and consequently the women, are but shadows, and love is a sentiment to	241.33404750786158
which you cry, ‘Fie! Fie!’”	273.86262860575334
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan,” cried Aramis, “you are killing me!”	350.10601098630684
“Well, here it is at last!” said D’Artagnan, as he drew the letter from	270.54460987110565
his pocket.	361.7478741502324
Aramis made a bound, seized the letter, read it, or rather devoured it,	209.4103096471884
his countenance radiant.	359.97267016041235
“This same waiting maid seems to have an agreeable style,” said the	354.91790838119033
messenger, carelessly.	183.86768196937766
“Thanks, D’Artagnan, thanks!” cried Aramis, almost in a state of	363.0591958191813
delirium. “She was forced to return to Tours; she is not faithless; she	187.20107802573602
still loves me! Come, my friend, come, let me embrace you. Happiness	290.8704483721276
almost stifles me!”	311.4033355921838
The two friends began to dance around the venerable St. Chrysostom,	298.7309380090269
kicking about famously the sheets of the thesis, which had fallen on	235.3437388630677
the floor.	305.53630335825017
At that moment Bazin entered with the spinach and the omelet.	354.1417743535139
“Be off, you wretch!” cried Aramis, throwing his skullcap in his face.	364.4759015538614
“Return whence you came; take back those horrible vegetables, and that	250.65748957100408
poor kickshaw! Order a larded hare, a fat capon, mutton leg dressed	227.8339541751432
with garlic, and four bottles of old Burgundy.”	331.3389894769742
Bazin, who looked at his master, without comprehending the cause of	348.0331266249985
this change, in a melancholy manner, allowed the omelet to slip into	340.0925359771443
the spinach, and the spinach onto the floor.	312.91356258100075
“Now this is the moment to consecrate your existence to the King of	332.2465167566083
kings,” said D’Artagnan, “if you persist in offering him a civility.	290.99823573538924
_Non inutile desiderium oblatione_.”	365.6778972933781
“Go to the devil with your Latin. Let us drink, my dear D’Artagnan,	306.3860098334819
_morbleu!_ Let us drink while the wine is fresh! Let us drink heartily,	228.93907327635398
and while we do so, tell me a little of what is going on in the world	226.95629015335712
yonder.”	188.6332093610206
Chapter XXVII.	269.1974481071272
THE WIFE OF ATHOS	339.98395753135196
We have now to search for Athos,” said D’Artagnan to the vivacious	181.75684640047805
Aramis, when he had informed him of all that had passed since their	273.99140109351794
departure from the capital, and an excellent dinner had made one of	335.897673390338
them forget his thesis and the other his fatigue.	333.7294903174022
“Do you think, then, that any harm can have happened to him?” asked	341.23703635667994
Aramis. “Athos is so cool, so brave, and handles his sword so	255.4269490247139
skillfully.”	355.39062835289826
“No doubt. Nobody has a higher opinion of the courage and skill of	363.71638771502944
Athos than I have; but I like better to hear my sword clang against	314.4757776292198
lances than against staves. I fear lest Athos should have been beaten	340.38065505764854
down by serving men. Those fellows strike hard, and don’t leave off in	170.0074659880063
a hurry. This is why I wish to set out again as soon as possible.”	361.6517717389927
“I will try to accompany you,” said Aramis, “though I scarcely feel in	181.09714616641443
a condition to mount on horseback. Yesterday I undertook to employ that	194.35197914260854
cord which you see hanging against the wall, but pain prevented my	249.78307541408526
continuing the pious exercise.”	185.4513634274419
“That’s the first time I ever heard of anybody trying to cure gunshot	252.12978842137932
wounds with cat-o’-nine-tails; but you were ill, and illness renders	347.1826197672987
the head weak, therefore you may be excused.”	360.8434138239153
“When do you mean to set out?”	328.0490408833963
“Tomorrow at daybreak. Sleep as soundly as you can tonight, and	334.01585348643664
tomorrow, if you can, we will take our departure together.”	206.38490751269208
“Till tomorrow, then,” said Aramis; “for iron-nerved as you are, you	289.46005032063465
must need repose.”	225.76846640200307
The next morning, when D’Artagnan entered Aramis’s chamber, he found	206.55717937162873
him at the window.	245.29276152076278
“What are you looking at?” asked D’Artagnan.	245.7418080257973
“My faith! I am admiring three magnificent horses which the stable boys	175.18706239100206
are leading about. It would be a pleasure worthy of a prince to travel	187.62281514904254
upon such horses.”	263.744347384124
“Well, my dear Aramis, you may enjoy that pleasure, for one of those	263.8600476779721
three horses is yours.”	196.68529055611103
“Ah, bah! Which?”	305.5684360208385
“Whichever of the three you like, I have no preference.”	175.92228444742426
“And the rich caparison, is that mine, too?”	201.78868834577787
“Without doubt.”	311.94850890089003
“You laugh, D’Artagnan.”	176.71259076078567
“No, I have left off laughing, now that you speak French.”	254.29057875302772
“What, those rich holsters, that velvet housing, that saddle studded	348.8556030016263
with silver—are they all for me?”	292.34000374383913
“For you and nobody else, as the horse which paws the ground is mine,	343.86896904328853
and the other horse, which is caracoling, belongs to Athos.”	275.151165847547
“_Peste!_ They are three superb animals!”	344.306251739554
“I am glad they please you.”	337.9907037472941
“Why, it must have been the king who made you such a present.”	175.33261691795389
“Certainly it was not the cardinal; but don’t trouble yourself whence	218.95671458934723
they come, think only that one of the three is your property.”	264.5228707321288
“I choose that which the red-headed boy is leading.”	261.0191782316035
“It is yours!”	303.2927573838739
“Good heaven! That is enough to drive away all my pains; I could mount	255.31993436020912
him with thirty balls in my body. On my soul, handsome stirrups!	317.5746356469602
_Holà_, Bazin, come here this minute.”	353.00686909465844
Bazin appeared on the threshold, dull and spiritless.	272.54337710389956
“That last order is useless,” interrupted D’Artagnan; “there are loaded	295.59233435091465
pistols in your holsters.”	207.25418014611006
Bazin sighed.	354.7816856279901
“Come, Monsieur Bazin, make yourself easy,” said D’Artagnan; “people of	241.40169164710687
all conditions gain the kingdom of heaven.”	299.82960845284674
“Monsieur was already such a good theologian,” said Bazin, almost	299.6443020719325
weeping; “he might have become a bishop, and perhaps a cardinal.”	257.5813988881936
“Well, but my poor Bazin, reflect a little. Of what use is it to be a	169.09407830820282
churchman, pray? You do not avoid going to war by that means; you see,	238.65541951264402
the cardinal is about to make the next campaign, helm on head and	227.77844030468765
partisan in hand. And Monsieur de Nogaret de la Valette, what do you	253.31212626900506
say of him? He is a cardinal likewise. Ask his lackey how often he has	313.7968200282945
had to prepare lint of him.”	283.4314336331753
“Alas!” sighed Bazin. “I know it, monsieur; everything is turned	310.51611966060057
topsy-turvy in the world nowadays.”	187.57877259791246
While this dialogue was going on, the two young men and the poor lackey	236.2629443427694
descended.	217.93183145559993
“Hold my stirrup, Bazin,” cried Aramis; and Aramis sprang into the	231.0991017726509
saddle with his usual grace and agility, but after a few vaults and	265.3557971908574
curvets of the noble animal his rider felt his pains come on so	348.20001225454996
insupportably that he turned pale and became unsteady in his seat.	305.87729663674145
D’Artagnan, who, foreseeing such an event, had kept his eye on him,	347.11311717183537
sprang toward him, caught him in his arms, and assisted him to his	300.5359040852969
chamber.	346.82820901331877
“That’s all right, my dear Aramis, take care of yourself,” said he; “I	271.914405050288
will go alone in search of Athos.”	359.2023342400371
“You are a man of brass,” replied Aramis.	285.793595899974
“No, I have good luck, that is all. But how do you mean to pass your	175.522506212876
time till I come back? No more theses, no more glosses upon the fingers	276.4976337176615
or upon benedictions, hey?”	222.18955336831772
Aramis smiled. “I will make verses,” said he.	224.82275146953955
“Yes, I dare say; verses perfumed with the odor of the billet from the	240.18828266413698
attendant of Madame de Chevreuse. Teach Bazin prosody; that will	274.6570833765587
console him. As to the horse, ride him a little every day, and that	268.4628410750187
will accustom you to his maneuvers.”	328.6904207058793
“Oh, make yourself easy on that head,” replied Aramis. “You will find	290.4413873918184
me ready to follow you.”	214.5825118779557
They took leave of each other, and in ten minutes, after having	186.44991320543753
commended his friend to the cares of the hostess and Bazin, D’Artagnan	228.2085864214319
was trotting along in the direction of Amiens.	346.95363489263445
How was he going to find Athos? Should he find him at all? The position	221.81751717089787
in which he had left him was critical. He probably had succumbed. This	256.484533244752
idea, while darkening his brow, drew several sighs from him, and caused	263.3017169755004
him to formulate to himself a few vows of vengeance. Of all his	175.59347823435857
friends, Athos was the eldest, and the least resembling him in	188.06387280951773
appearance, in his tastes and sympathies.	203.27280913157665
Yet he entertained a marked preference for this gentleman. The noble	261.34242971692174
and distinguished air of Athos, those flashes of greatness which from	184.46356265881556
time to time broke out from the shade in which he voluntarily kept	267.170956267342
himself, that unalterable equality of temper which made him the most	361.25263675967403
pleasant companion in the world, that forced and cynical gaiety, that	300.44165510375603
bravery which might have been termed blind if it had not been the	216.6561688136173
result of the rarest coolness—such qualities attracted more than the	270.6873951272879
esteem, more than the friendship of D’Artagnan; they attracted his	247.50013973898285
admiration.	327.09162002080643
Indeed, when placed beside M. de Tréville, the elegant and noble	341.41782753731195
courtier, Athos in his most cheerful days might advantageously sustain	169.67686000958759
a comparison. He was of middle height; but his person was so admirably	252.22366506524196
shaped and so well proportioned that more than once in his struggles	315.6127965475124
with Porthos he had overcome the giant whose physical strength was	362.13636234769217
proverbial among the Musketeers. His head, with piercing eyes, a	256.5010650701329
straight nose, a chin cut like that of Brutus, had altogether an	173.09731897247406
indefinable character of grandeur and grace. His hands, of which he	246.7374174636047
took little care, were the despair of Aramis, who cultivated his with	350.2330791252614
almond paste and perfumed oil. The sound of his voice was at once	168.0491524477075
penetrating and melodious; and then, that which was inconceivable in	355.7215640709891
Athos, who was always retiring, was that delicate knowledge of the	326.54031342652473
world and of the usages of the most brilliant society—those manners of	301.0476112802819
a high degree which appeared, as if unconsciously to himself, in his	343.3243181705752
least actions.	299.1424944182102
If a repast were on foot, Athos presided over it better than any other,	341.80889200160397
placing every guest exactly in the rank which his ancestors had earned	224.54753144010067
for him or that he had made for himself. If a question in heraldry were	255.2940276308484
started, Athos knew all the noble families of the kingdom, their	232.975310265347
genealogy, their alliances, their coats of arms, and the origin of	363.5654782584826
them. Etiquette had no minutiæ unknown to him. He knew what were the	335.5526338347503
rights of the great land owners. He was profoundly versed in hunting	342.1124007185448
and falconry, and had one day when conversing on this great art	311.2330480354062
astonished even Louis XIII. himself, who took a pride in being	293.4335852876852
considered a past master therein.	233.16260565999823
Like all the great nobles of that period, Athos rode and fenced to	267.0109281538908
perfection. But still further, his education had been so little	295.90310346312344
neglected, even with respect to scholastic studies, so rare at this	214.44773729499946
time among gentlemen, that he smiled at the scraps of Latin which	177.87323378628577
Aramis sported and which Porthos pretended to understand. Two or three	266.2649893584581
times, even, to the great astonishment of his friends, he had, when	349.1764524128322
Aramis allowed some rudimental error to escape him, replaced a verb in	306.73695783114937
its right tense and a noun in its case. Besides, his probity was	168.57223095099673
irreproachable, in an age in which soldiers compromised so easily with	328.72525317008046
their religion and their consciences, lovers with the rigorous delicacy	235.4042467334653
of our era, and the poor with God’s Seventh Commandment. This Athos,	213.52849535825257
then, was a very extraordinary man.	268.38551259639917
And yet this nature so distinguished, this creature so beautiful, this	295.88339607559396
essence so fine, was seen to turn insensibly toward material life, as	314.1455655415541
old men turn toward physical and moral imbecility. Athos, in his hours	306.9421529449953
of gloom—and these hours were frequent—was extinguished as to the whole	211.05505040783356
of the luminous portion of him, and his brilliant side disappeared as	307.91584851923454
into profound darkness.	353.88877849329356
Then the demigod vanished; he remained scarcely a man. His head hanging	167.48576129634728
down, his eye dull, his speech slow and painful, Athos would look for	328.7575053717345
hours together at his bottle, his glass, or at Grimaud, who, accustomed	169.87586233760337
to obey him by signs, read in the faint glance of his master his least	363.0740674875384
desire, and satisfied it immediately. If the four friends were	329.87892700759
assembled at one of these moments, a word, thrown forth occasionally	299.4012665452129
with a violent effort, was the share Athos furnished to the	313.5285404237982
conversation. In exchange for his silence Athos drank enough for four,	296.47936110498847
and without appearing to be otherwise affected by wine than by a more	187.21169573211648
marked constriction of the brow and by a deeper sadness.	334.6666564404609
D’Artagnan, whose inquiring disposition we are acquainted with, had	175.30201932688686
not—whatever interest he had in satisfying his curiosity on this	359.8647240698239
subject—been able to assign any cause for these fits, or for the	277.11161574259717
periods of their recurrence. Athos never received any letters; Athos	218.28408476344907
never had concerns which all his friends did not know.	265.1440522185696
It could not be said that it was wine which produced this sadness; for	179.2233973391178
in truth he only drank to combat this sadness, which wine however, as	179.9501678159905
we have said, rendered still darker. This excess of bilious humor could	265.5751951351952
not be attributed to play; for unlike Porthos, who accompanied the	316.23324088783204
variations of chance with songs or oaths, Athos when he won remained as	312.46489099597426
unmoved as when he lost. He had been known, in the circle of the	349.8143048969761
Musketeers, to win in one night three thousand pistoles; to lose them	185.88167269023367
even to the gold-embroidered belt for gala days, win all this again	254.8676905039481
with the addition of a hundred louis, without his beautiful eyebrow	181.06901433597736
being heightened or lowered half a line, without his hands losing their	338.43661650650733
pearly hue, without his conversation, which was cheerful that evening,	305.9092872437599
ceasing to be calm and agreeable.	298.2507544333356
Neither was it, as with our neighbors, the English, an atmospheric	343.6927608964162
influence which darkened his countenance; for the sadness generally	305.7978615694105
became more intense toward the fine season of the year. June and July	268.7391841417881
were the terrible months with Athos.	170.98775973865258
For the present he had no anxiety. He shrugged his shoulders when	265.7542295870519
people spoke of the future. His secret, then, was in the past, as had	218.85772629291463
often been vaguely said to D’Artagnan.	359.50457795660316
This mysterious shade, spread over his whole person, rendered still	238.24043593974363
more interesting the man whose eyes or mouth, even in the most complete	215.41359110032192
intoxication, had never revealed anything, however skillfully questions	242.6476496302753
had been put to him.	270.2095125503873
“Well,” thought D’Artagnan, “poor Athos is perhaps at this moment dead,	203.86609163901508
and dead by my fault—for it was I who dragged him into this affair, of	283.51011421713036
which he did not know the origin, of which he is ignorant of the	217.8685367944082
result, and from which he can derive no advantage.”	272.26668567970546
“Without reckoning, monsieur,” added Planchet to his master’s audibly	260.4478735649235
expressed reflections, “that we perhaps owe our lives to him. Do you	265.6325070000068
remember how he cried, ‘On, D’Artagnan, on, I am taken’? And when he	337.4898519166997
had discharged his two pistols, what a terrible noise he made with his	208.47905417937943
sword! One might have said that twenty men, or rather twenty mad	212.63499577645234
devils, were fighting.”	170.3344557030706
These words redoubled the eagerness of D’Artagnan, who urged his horse,	302.6380720724844
though he stood in need of no incitement, and they proceeded at a rapid	219.6724386917499
pace. About eleven o’clock in the morning they perceived Amiens, and at	188.61715800946305
half past eleven they were at the door of the cursed inn.	197.935777249293
D’Artagnan had often meditated against the perfidious host one of those	311.6781171574838
hearty vengeances which offer consolation while they are hoped for. He	272.6184299803631
entered the hostelry with his hat pulled over his eyes, his left hand	260.1128476514757
on the pommel of the sword, and cracking his whip with his right hand.	226.23476366971255
“Do you remember me?” said he to the host, who advanced to greet him.	250.21785085362703
“I have not that honor, monseigneur,” replied the latter, his eyes	189.2664596251388
dazzled by the brilliant style in which D’Artagnan traveled.	251.49370105350613
“What, you don’t know me?”	257.83647552748675
“No, monseigneur.”	211.56729693233083
“Well, two words will refresh your memory. What have you done with that	282.77600917287657
gentleman against whom you had the audacity, about twelve days ago, to	204.01013769977726
make an accusation of passing false money?”	359.40961283829245
The host became as pale as death; for D’Artagnan had assumed a	361.6018993832191
threatening attitude, and Planchet modeled himself after his master.	213.7672875659576
“Ah, monseigneur, do not mention it!” cried the host, in the most	238.36011468244772
pitiable voice imaginable. “Ah, monseigneur, how dearly have I paid for	231.33148456306677
that fault, unhappy wretch as I am!”	184.10973702209753
“That gentleman, I say, what has become of him?”	289.2580471151159
“Deign to listen to me, monseigneur, and be merciful! Sit down, in	247.0446603318336
mercy!”	324.5875821775871
D’Artagnan, mute with anger and anxiety, took a seat in the threatening	169.85390554156987
attitude of a judge. Planchet glared fiercely over the back of his	221.76126125854296
armchair.	265.81185759955173
“Here is the story, monseigneur,” resumed the trembling host; “for I	362.3482371146804
now recollect you. It was you who rode off at the moment I had that	299.34820580122295
unfortunate difference with the gentleman you speak of.”	250.760280013952
“Yes, it was I; so you may plainly perceive that you have no mercy to	200.02520569178176
expect if you do not tell me the whole truth.”	315.2070312378702
“Condescend to listen to me, and you shall know all.”	278.7565293080145
“I listen.”	310.72306013693276
“I had been warned by the authorities that a celebrated coiner of bad	216.7054830547745
money would arrive at my inn, with several of his companions, all	359.0529674600276
disguised as Guards or Musketeers. Monseigneur, I was furnished with a	252.71565134680378
description of your horses, your lackeys, your countenances—nothing was	356.59558794157033
omitted.”	172.97484389506525
“Go on, go on!” said D’Artagnan, who quickly understood whence such an	320.80829683112245
exact description had come.	294.06175305503643
“I took then, in conformity with the orders of the authorities, who	358.50417943389755
sent me a reinforcement of six men, such measures as I thought	330.46270721214006
necessary to get possession of the persons of the pretended coiners.”	355.80901973152856
“Again!” said D’Artagnan, whose ears chafed terribly under the	276.6141324980788
repetition of this word _coiners_.	183.729956618984
“Pardon me, monseigneur, for saying such things, but they form my	199.92716060295783
excuse. The authorities had terrified me, and you know that an	230.6159987875415
innkeeper must keep on good terms with the authorities.”	172.68931149036445
“But once again, that gentleman—where is he? What has become of him? Is	319.5008105532945
he dead? Is he living?”	233.4771610249229
“Patience, monseigneur, we are coming to it. There happened then that	349.06863913635766
which you know, and of which your precipitate departure,” added the	180.7110313790397
host, with an acuteness that did not escape D’Artagnan, “appeared to	283.18553730644885
authorize the issue. That gentleman, your friend, defended himself	221.0082433347775
desperately. His lackey, who, by an unforeseen piece of ill luck, had	356.32719137965734
quarreled with the officers, disguised as stable lads—”	221.73013423917718
“Miserable scoundrel!” cried D’Artagnan, “you were all in the plot,	228.70765765175196
then! And I really don’t know what prevents me from exterminating you	346.31328700617865
all.”	166.26874203146994
“Alas, monseigneur, we were not in the plot, as you will soon see.	352.048459321265
Monsieur your friend (pardon for not calling him by the honorable name	183.73486299879247
which no doubt he bears, but we do not know that name), Monsieur your	257.1149969574205
friend, having disabled two men with his pistols, retreated fighting	215.28722824877713
with his sword, with which he disabled one of my men, and stunned me	207.9465329103789
with a blow of the flat side of it.”	280.0749841540911
“You villain, will you finish?” cried D’Artagnan, “Athos—what has	213.8879221684745
become of Athos?”	304.1456182645269
“While fighting and retreating, as I have told Monseigneur, he found	174.24980878694373
the door of the cellar stairs behind him, and as the door was open, he	265.6829490810171
took out the key, and barricaded himself inside. As we were sure of	258.1023612123692
finding him there, we left him alone.”	289.8585326896283
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “you did not really wish to kill; you only	191.2629950137922
wished to imprison him.”	284.29250617650325
“Good God! To imprison him, monseigneur? Why, he imprisoned himself, I	249.06922978553195
swear to you he did. In the first place he had made rough work of it;	291.1602262043275
one man was killed on the spot, and two others were severely wounded.	224.15567102389912
The dead man and the two wounded were carried off by their comrades,	358.50743161521973
and I have heard nothing of either of them since. As for myself, as	319.7382959093114
