soon as I recovered my senses I went to Monsieur the Governor, to whom	224.8912188696507
I related all that had passed, and asked, what I should do with my	222.01718991093907
prisoner. Monsieur the Governor was all astonishment. He told me he	365.343793345779
knew nothing about the matter, that the orders I had received did not	314.15028862181845
come from him, and that if I had the audacity to mention his name as	208.84981874885526
being concerned in this disturbance he would have me hanged. It appears	218.2635232863576
that I had made a mistake, monsieur, that I had arrested the wrong	246.97695639285456
person, and that he whom I ought to have arrested had escaped.”	244.54428018205567
“But Athos!” cried D’Artagnan, whose impatience was increased by the	193.43601278492994
disregard of the authorities, “Athos, where is he?”	272.1364602240208
“As I was anxious to repair the wrongs I had done the prisoner,”	239.25003507193844
resumed the innkeeper, “I took my way straight to the cellar in order	166.24520578292498
to set him at liberty. Ah, monsieur, he was no longer a man, he was a	298.7042073267483
devil! To my offer of liberty, he replied that it was nothing but a	262.6001951098659
snare, and that before he came out he intended to impose his own	240.03577715875883
conditions. I told him very humbly—for I could not conceal from myself	299.0975303342195
the scrape I had got into by laying hands on one of his Majesty’s	278.3862528236273
Musketeers—I told him I was quite ready to submit to his conditions.	343.6003451243476
“‘In the first place,’ said he, ‘I wish my lackey placed with me, fully	215.03088942673241
armed.’ We hastened to obey this order; for you will please to	344.4548990147654
understand, monsieur, we were disposed to do everything your friend	234.94083358175175
could desire. Monsieur Grimaud (he told us his name, although he does	274.4265122284681
not talk much)—Monsieur Grimaud, then, went down to the cellar, wounded	274.0912011087274
as he was; then his master, having admitted him, barricaded the door	284.51443178449153
afresh, and ordered us to remain quietly in our own bar.”	191.63011568628093
“But where is Athos now?” cried D’Artagnan. “Where is Athos?”	241.79254902312363
“In the cellar, monsieur.”	197.92769871390715
“What, you scoundrel! Have you kept him in the cellar all this time?”	180.75711495741896
“Merciful heaven! No, monsieur! We keep him in the cellar! You do not	257.0288158330716
know what he is about in the cellar. Ah! If you could but persuade him	218.13131068883067
to come out, monsieur, I should owe you the gratitude of my whole life;	283.0298183318839
I should adore you as my patron saint!”	302.4623501483789
“Then he is there? I shall find him there?”	168.22235857396157
“Without doubt you will, monsieur; he persists in remaining there. We	181.34348293549735
every day pass through the air hole some bread at the end of a fork,	272.9640019962499
and some meat when he asks for it; but alas! It is not of bread and	262.5443387931832
meat of which he makes the greatest consumption. I once endeavored to	229.55517376791488
go down with two of my servants; but he flew into terrible rage. I	290.8890145984798
heard the noise he made in loading his pistols, and his servant in	216.9880049015979
loading his musketoon. Then, when we asked them what were their	346.8546519562916
intentions, the master replied that he had forty charges to fire, and	262.32412716383357
that he and his lackey would fire to the last one before he would allow	267.44284074743456
a single soul of us to set foot in the cellar. Upon this I went and	208.0731842650006
complained to the governor, who replied that I only had what I	308.71162810848745
deserved, and that it would teach me to insult honorable gentlemen who	209.14013258660682
took up their abode in my house.”	347.31906655193393
“So that since that time—” replied D’Artagnan, totally unable to	219.3493299714117
refrain from laughing at the pitiable face of the host.	301.4316409380914
“So from that time, monsieur,” continued the latter, “we have led the	247.19132531196834
most miserable life imaginable; for you must know, monsieur, that all	353.84449022197487
our provisions are in the cellar. There is our wine in bottles, and our	211.22396026463844
wine in casks; the beer, the oil, and the spices, the bacon, and	310.2227401194553
sausages. And as we are prevented from going down there, we are forced	246.32889730905703
to refuse food and drink to the travelers who come to the house; so	339.4206810722013
that our hostelry is daily going to ruin. If your friend remains	177.43817982081606
another week in my cellar I shall be a ruined man.”	362.0233755386146
“And not more than justice, either, you ass! Could you not perceive by	330.00671569473207
our appearance that we were people of quality, and not coiners—say?”	202.45780543136303
“Yes, monsieur, you are right,” said the host. “But, hark, hark! There	290.538573417953
he is!”	253.80209107897156
“Somebody has disturbed him, without doubt,” said D’Artagnan.	316.5300249655261
“But he must be disturbed,” cried the host; “Here are two English	294.6874747028698
gentlemen just arrived.”	209.45882337133162
“Well?”	328.8026135004493
“Well, the English like good wine, as you may know, monsieur; these	255.35041113942395
have asked for the best. My wife has perhaps requested permission of	308.55636080836246
Monsieur Athos to go into the cellar to satisfy these gentlemen; and	202.5972484315385
he, as usual, has refused. Ah, good heaven! There is the hullabaloo	360.107450525275
louder than ever!”	274.3366449816134
D’Artagnan, in fact, heard a great noise on the side next the cellar.	231.52129117225684
He rose, and preceded by the host wringing his hands, and followed by	268.089143459229
Planchet with his musketoon ready for use, he approached the scene of	268.53433933821435
action.	334.6307669910683
The two gentlemen were exasperated; they had had a long ride, and were	228.0437097647126
dying with hunger and thirst.	291.3529136415748
“But this is tyranny!” cried one of them, in very good French, though	276.10750350094287
with a foreign accent, “that this madman will not allow these good	296.5800476072383
people access to their own wine! Nonsense, let us break open the door,	242.84844444759852
and if he is too far gone in his madness, well, we will kill him!”	211.06477070780807
“Softly, gentlemen!” said D’Artagnan, drawing his pistols from his	228.4067408378078
belt, “you will kill nobody, if you please!”	186.19522270569985
“Good, good!” cried the calm voice of Athos, from the other side of the	281.71797939740327
door, “let them just come in, these devourers of little children, and	191.61335940710285
we shall see!”	364.12906175052444
Brave as they appeared to be, the two English gentlemen looked at each	350.0144694178686
other hesitatingly. One might have thought there was in that cellar one	189.2486437450413
of those famished ogres—the gigantic heroes of popular legends, into	211.95598803692658
whose cavern nobody could force their way with impunity.	198.47990702371956
There was a moment of silence; but at length the two Englishmen felt	263.83689850961053
ashamed to draw back, and the angrier one descended the five or six	260.0930810065885
steps which led to the cellar, and gave a kick against the door enough	244.62933068603695
to split a wall.	187.75565402693337
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, cocking his pistols, “I will take charge	220.62367985574156
of the one at the top; you look to the one below. Ah, gentlemen, you	229.90660606987043
want battle; and you shall have it.”	300.62296583598106
“Good God!” cried the hollow voice of Athos, “I can hear D’Artagnan, I	301.0850141485741
think.”	263.0109741419682
“Yes,” cried D’Artagnan, raising his voice in turn, “I am here, my	284.7316306103582
friend.”	230.34999087454338
“Ah, good, then,” replied Athos, “we will teach them, these door	353.1125080317536
breakers!”	285.1783728277792
The gentlemen had drawn their swords, but they found themselves taken	174.04330862396083
between two fires. They still hesitated an instant; but, as before,	254.66778860338934
pride prevailed, and a second kick split the door from bottom to top.	213.81167864123836
“Stand on one side, D’Artagnan, stand on one side,” cried Athos. “I am	197.71205130879892
going to fire!”	307.44757971458466
“Gentlemen,” exclaimed D’Artagnan, whom reflection never abandoned,	338.5166060527172
“gentlemen, think of what you are about. Patience, Athos! You are	232.02855195764522
running your heads into a very silly affair; you will be riddled. My	190.54852823453678
lackey and I will have three shots at you, and you will get as many	341.0935462529769
from the cellar. You will then have our swords, with which, I can	207.70112244639296
assure you, my friend and I can play tolerably well. Let me conduct	208.0575397532918
your business and my own. You shall soon have something to drink; I	183.52293202763477
give you my word.”	218.30819144208692
“If there is any left,” grumbled the jeering voice of Athos.	268.0956662422448
The host felt a cold sweat creep down his back.	173.50483285307826
“How! ‘If there is any left!’” murmured he.	344.7844718836668
“What the devil! There must be plenty left,” replied D’Artagnan. “Be	335.366220021687
satisfied of that; these two cannot have drunk all the cellar.	194.3653164112355
Gentlemen, return your swords to their scabbards.”	224.91521838556986
“Well, provided you replace your pistols in your belt.”	233.57775111850452
“Willingly.”	207.8112928583693
And D’Artagnan set the example. Then, turning toward Planchet, he made	330.9455180746894
him a sign to uncock his musketoon.	298.27741254933085
The Englishmen, convinced of these peaceful proceedings, sheathed their	328.86950622633753
swords grumblingly. The history of Athos’s imprisonment was then	192.9497270424639
related to them; and as they were really gentlemen, they pronounced the	173.60116982009302
host in the wrong.	255.45338451314456
“Now, gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “go up to your room again; and in	357.7641003897094
ten minutes, I will answer for it, you shall have all you desire.”	318.35891500661603
The Englishmen bowed and went upstairs.	226.0771875519111
“Now I am alone, my dear Athos,” said D’Artagnan; “open the door, I beg	263.2127300918928
of you.”	203.49242393573587
“Instantly,” said Athos.	177.15959078542053
Then was heard a great noise of fagots being removed and of the	260.2303956349622
groaning of posts; these were the counterscarps and bastions of Athos,	182.2607983525423
which the besieged himself demolished.	277.51818237026964
An instant after, the broken door was removed, and the pale face of	197.4027242083419
Athos appeared, who with a rapid glance took a survey of the	198.14329454839816
surroundings.	174.43398836592291
D’Artagnan threw himself on his neck and embraced him tenderly. He then	239.76369442396452
tried to draw him from his moist abode, but to his surprise he	245.2609679327253
perceived that Athos staggered.	360.48512177087196
“You are wounded,” said he.	282.37932620198245
“I! Not at all. I am dead drunk, that’s all, and never did a man more	209.96039600718953
strongly set about getting so. By the Lord, my good host! I must at	363.34499919984773
least have drunk for my part a hundred and fifty bottles.”	173.98226067049183
“Mercy!” cried the host, “if the lackey has drunk only half as much as	219.02907484894715
the master, I am a ruined man.”	182.31899557568767
“Grimaud is a well-bred lackey. He would never think of faring in the	354.02557461734375
same manner as his master; he only drank from the cask. Hark! I don’t	342.1105194290702
think he put the faucet in again. Do you hear it? It is running now.”	220.8400288662899
D’Artagnan burst into a laugh which changed the shiver of the host into	314.37297661332894
a burning fever.	208.82397536201015
In the meantime, Grimaud appeared in his turn behind his master, with	293.8211952174944
the musketoon on his shoulder, and his head shaking. Like one of those	185.66877265449688
drunken satyrs in the pictures of Rubens. He was moistened before and	302.290017307399
behind with a greasy liquid which the host recognized as his best olive	326.66734212352776
oil.	193.37003531869445
The four crossed the public room and proceeded to take possession of	215.9778425268863
the best apartment in the house, which D’Artagnan occupied with	255.81953084342163
authority.	191.07658158606233
In the meantime the host and his wife hurried down with lamps into the	208.69146775335597
cellar, which had so long been interdicted to them and where a	327.07092084650384
frightful spectacle awaited them.	220.01180178323696
Beyond the fortifications through which Athos had made a breach in	207.5930614916051
order to get out, and which were composed of fagots, planks, and empty	249.86210985184206
casks, heaped up according to all the rules of the strategic art, they	197.02104591561778
found, swimming in puddles of oil and wine, the bones and fragments of	233.1167498073635
all the hams they had eaten; while a heap of broken bottles filled the	205.54382955370806
whole left-hand corner of the cellar, and a tun, the cock of which was	193.36542108498816
left running, was yielding, by this means, the last drop of its blood.	293.7288602200003
“The image of devastation and death,” as the ancient poet says,	234.6197645755036
“reigned as over a field of battle.”	312.91415887716516
Of fifty large sausages, suspended from the joists, scarcely ten	291.70736338393624
remained.	310.8022878700938
Then the lamentations of the host and hostess pierced the vault of the	207.43574248617043
cellar. D’Artagnan himself was moved by them. Athos did not even turn	294.85749192089236
his head.	171.23167758129392
To grief succeeded rage. The host armed himself with a spit, and rushed	315.212178785104
into the chamber occupied by the two friends.	305.3908585072787
“Some wine!” said Athos, on perceiving the host.	339.1573974823122
“Some wine!” cried the stupefied host, “some wine? Why you have drunk	293.11693003650487
more than a hundred pistoles’ worth! I am a ruined man, lost,	187.83063156127054
destroyed!”	252.24266773181347
“Bah,” said Athos, “we were always dry.”	273.3558760732257
“If you had been contented with drinking, well and good; but you have	279.064391337546
broken all the bottles.”	237.5111520820913
“You pushed me upon a heap which rolled down. That was your fault.”	287.91989127332295
“All my oil is lost!”	275.1442250544885
“Oil is a sovereign balm for wounds; and my poor Grimaud here was	342.4154645327609
obliged to dress those you had inflicted on him.”	359.35580061650046
“All my sausages are gnawed!”	329.47877618234236
“There is an enormous quantity of rats in that cellar.”	175.29838749492225
“You shall pay me for all this,” cried the exasperated host.	340.99259209576127
“Triple ass!” said Athos, rising; but he sank down again immediately.	285.43061882637994
He had tried his strength to the utmost. D’Artagnan came to his relief	265.32660313278484
with his whip in his hand.	168.572425547868
The host drew back and burst into tears.	356.52681919617925
“This will teach you,” said D’Artagnan, “to treat the guests God sends	228.57475057522367
you in a more courteous fashion.”	244.53554869101072
“God? Say the devil!”	281.50417937053356
“My dear friend,” said D’Artagnan, “if you annoy us in this manner we	166.08348251242515
will all four go and shut ourselves up in your cellar, and we will see	188.3301268510595
if the mischief is as great as you say.”	208.72077185308476
“Oh, gentlemen,” said the host, “I have been wrong. I confess it, but	235.81191306462887
pardon to every sin! You are gentlemen, and I am a poor innkeeper. You	285.1724914778627
will have pity on me.”	338.35467198099013
“Ah, if you speak in that way,” said Athos, “you will break my heart,	266.308209014944
and the tears will flow from my eyes as the wine flowed from the cask.	333.25833396620413
We are not such devils as we appear to be. Come hither, and let us	263.5902428761795
talk.”	300.6802738685109
The host approached with hesitation.	260.41963402215663
“Come hither, I say, and don’t be afraid,” continued Athos. “At the	209.08027639513227
very moment when I was about to pay you, I had placed my purse on the	169.68484218046004
table.”	293.99209621175805
“Yes, monsieur.”	196.77726618240757
“That purse contained sixty pistoles; where is it?”	288.0671772182865
“Deposited with the justice; they said it was bad money.”	204.33454694079313
“Very well; get me my purse back and keep the sixty pistoles.”	295.7821221428974
“But Monseigneur knows very well that justice never lets go that which	166.34774327025823
it once lays hold of. If it were bad money, there might be some hopes;	238.1173857073088
but unfortunately, those were all good pieces.”	244.2553024033819
“Manage the matter as well as you can, my good man; it does not concern	337.7154022490855
me, the more so as I have not a livre left.”	313.98999990228936
“Come,” said D’Artagnan, “let us inquire further. Athos’s horse, where	192.46681548862952
is that?”	266.7904598246401
“In the stable.”	173.88705876737112
“How much is it worth?”	361.4593539955955
“Fifty pistoles at most.”	266.5318478383093
“It’s worth eighty. Take it, and there ends the matter.”	270.5403042299161
“What,” cried Athos, “are you selling my horse—my Bajazet? And pray	363.3693569473837
upon what shall I make my campaign; upon Grimaud?”	289.6573901657518
“I have brought you another,” said D’Artagnan.	323.5894869818045
“Another?”	354.6827742100961
“And a magnificent one!” cried the host.	226.4759845924848
“Well, since there is another finer and younger, why, you may take the	252.14062081998514
old one; and let us drink.”	197.8670980553302
“What?” asked the host, quite cheerful again.	316.3488100009887
“Some of that at the bottom, near the laths. There are twenty-five	198.40942686403676
bottles of it left; all the rest were broken by my fall. Bring six of	227.03124417950605
them.”	321.7868300062455
“Why, this man is a cask!” said the host, aside. “If he only remains	249.620365902986
here a fortnight, and pays for what he drinks, I shall soon	338.6638689314382
re-establish my business.”	170.6711981194845
“And don’t forget,” said D’Artagnan, “to bring up four bottles of the	333.0559144252833
same sort for the two English gentlemen.”	214.73700670034003
“And now,” said Athos, “while they bring the wine, tell me, D’Artagnan,	282.0123718931346
what has become of the others, come!”	309.6497671227444
D’Artagnan related how he had found Porthos in bed with a strained	203.09160082687777
knee, and Aramis at a table between two theologians. As he finished,	201.16112186935504
the host entered with the wine ordered and a ham which, fortunately for	302.5614269755125
him, had been left out of the cellar.	297.713263928167
“That’s well!” said Athos, filling his glass and that of his friend;	358.9758095711531
“here’s to Porthos and Aramis! But you, D’Artagnan, what is the matter	220.16754860825228
with you, and what has happened to you personally? You have a sad air.”	228.30127159472136
“Alas,” said D’Artagnan, “it is because I am the most unfortunate.”	346.1294394838643
“Tell me.”	196.3268498323605
“Presently,” said D’Artagnan.	212.74830338815744
“Presently! And why presently? Because you think I am drunk?	337.5558255718547
D’Artagnan, remember this! My ideas are never so clear as when I have	196.41866643456237
had plenty of wine. Speak, then, I am all ears.”	346.39972906652997
D’Artagnan related his adventure with Mme. Bonacieux. Athos listened to	279.75848989848265
him without a frown; and when he had finished, said, “Trifles, only	324.00230498733475
trifles!” That was his favorite word.	236.36655103937102
“You always say _trifles_, my dear Athos!” said D’Artagnan, “and that	311.12689976434854
comes very ill from you, who have never loved.”	277.4518418304855
The drink-deadened eye of Athos flashed out, but only for a moment; it	352.2844898929536
became as dull and vacant as before.	317.2484925411161
“That’s true,” said he, quietly, “for my part I have never loved.”	246.09400977320354
“Acknowledge, then, you stony heart,” said D’Artagnan, “that you are	232.0870996705058
wrong to be so hard upon us tender hearts.”	180.2293798175322
“Tender hearts! Pierced hearts!” said Athos.	213.59381008600255
“What do you say?”	328.02115403858875
“I say that love is a lottery in which he who wins, wins death! You are	318.3749174148908
very fortunate to have lost, believe me, my dear D’Artagnan. And if I	169.42306840262293
have any counsel to give, it is, always lose!”	201.84298503162088
“She seemed to love me so!”	351.1818740253086
“She _seemed_, did she?”	244.09637995006975
“Oh, she _did_ love me!”	270.29377351860444
“You child, why, there is not a man who has not believed, as you do,	252.20917982950766
that his mistress loved him, and there lives not a man who has not been	344.8560367088711
deceived by his mistress.”	291.54039203097807
“Except you, Athos, who never had one.”	196.1101579113507
“That’s true,” said Athos, after a moment’s silence, “that’s true! I	204.12017076231072
never had one! Let us drink!”	272.98702918733096
“But then, philosopher that you are,” said D’Artagnan, “instruct me,	335.91088985081836
support me. I stand in need of being taught and consoled.”	232.54843079366174
“Consoled for what?”	283.57234790206326
“For my misfortune.”	300.2816721753291
“Your misfortune is laughable,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders; “I	303.2834099778393
should like to know what you would say if I were to relate to you a	278.2995531517747
real tale of love!”	229.08692339205152
“Which has happened to you?”	360.5293938732318
“Or one of my friends, what matters?”	329.2082927664969
“Tell it, Athos, tell it.”	230.06660614788956
“Better if I drink.”	190.5426440127505
“Drink and relate, then.”	339.58196957974246
“Not a bad idea!” said Athos, emptying and refilling his glass. “The	329.19996388577283
two things agree marvelously well.”	365.19604344556706
“I am all attention,” said D’Artagnan.	173.27531030516639
Athos collected himself, and in proportion as he did so, D’Artagnan saw	226.6434067481468
that he became pale. He was at that period of intoxication in which	266.44461926922713
vulgar drinkers fall on the floor and go to sleep. He kept himself	211.38416205156125
upright and dreamed, without sleeping. This somnambulism of drunkenness	215.2447625099721
had something frightful in it.	345.8924100683316
“You particularly wish it?” asked he.	169.1665600133212
“I pray for it,” said D’Artagnan.	288.7911139692653
“Be it then as you desire. One of my friends—one of my friends, please	282.5715844343914
to observe, not myself,” said Athos, interrupting himself with a	292.83920334627095
melancholy smile, “one of the counts of my province—that is to say, of	341.39828322723974
Berry—noble as a Dandolo or a Montmorency, at twenty-five years of age	353.6427793225679
fell in love with a girl of sixteen, beautiful as fancy can paint.	199.85503581828726
Through the ingenuousness of her age beamed an ardent mind, not of the	218.3591755061084
woman, but of the poet. She did not please; she intoxicated. She lived	293.8000594337807
in a small town with her brother, who was a curate. Both had recently	358.09451204128413
come into the country. They came nobody knew whence; but when seeing	180.82950218486982
her so lovely and her brother so pious, nobody thought of asking whence	292.51835964882304
they came. They were said, however, to be of good extraction. My	177.5265562108187
friend, who was seigneur of the country, might have seduced her, or	267.26833367401093
taken her by force, at his will—for he was master. Who would have come	312.56433816279286
to the assistance of two strangers, two unknown persons? Unfortunately	254.14522942980233
he was an honorable man; he married her. The fool! The ass! The idiot!”	173.71671790510754
“How so, if he loved her?” asked D’Artagnan.	309.0405024309183
“Wait,” said Athos. “He took her to his château, and made her the first	166.53313841839687
lady in the province; and in justice it must be allowed that she	317.51311555147583
supported her rank becomingly.”	258.18299768826785
“Well?” asked D’Artagnan.	225.84798024640588
“Well, one day when she was hunting with her husband,” continued Athos,	233.00030197499515
in a low voice, and speaking very quickly, “she fell from her horse and	333.67628660279956
fainted. The count flew to her to help, and as she appeared to be	292.5417264233068
oppressed by her clothes, he ripped them open with his poniard, and in	334.1775641976217
so doing laid bare her shoulder. D’Artagnan,” said Athos, with a	291.92177283404146
maniacal burst of laughter, “guess what she had on her shoulder.”	243.1132901002855
“How can I tell?” said D’Artagnan.	299.1030068239899
“A _fleur-de-lis_,” said Athos. “She was branded.”	243.06755811763838
Athos emptied at a single draught the glass he held in his hand.	216.75201193167052
“Horror!” cried D’Artagnan. “What do you tell me?”	229.11059023871243
“Truth, my friend. The angel was a demon; the poor young girl had	291.88203141762176
stolen the sacred vessels from a church.”	277.1569365523227
“And what did the count do?”	259.0509995171368
“The count was of the highest nobility. He had on his estates the	234.559597016172
rights of high and low tribunals. He tore the dress of the countess to	203.07939234166813
pieces; he tied her hands behind her, and hanged her on a tree.”	306.5766782812145
“Heavens, Athos, a murder?” cried D’Artagnan.	286.7305380158663
“No less,” said Athos, as pale as a corpse. “But methinks I need wine!”	249.56683588758676
and he seized by the neck the last bottle that was left, put it to his	238.58514925130737
mouth, and emptied it at a single draught, as he would have emptied an	276.39287768375243
ordinary glass.	302.80409068298917
Then he let his head sink upon his two hands, while D’Artagnan stood	176.27383528510288
before him, stupefied.	200.89230330840286
“That has cured me of beautiful, poetical, and loving women,” said	176.0412949495289
Athos, after a considerable pause, raising his head, and forgetting to	208.32033508250012
continue the fiction of the count. “God grant you as much! Let us	193.51989885836147
drink.”	264.2209906720709
“Then she is dead?” stammered D’Artagnan.	230.21725550506486
“_Parbleu!_” said Athos. “But hold out your glass. Some ham, my boy, or	338.29576876337813
we can’t drink.”	356.97737622891685
“And her brother?” added D’Artagnan, timidly.	183.8168951077905
“Her brother?” replied Athos.	263.58866883350765
“Yes, the priest.”	231.0266138203229
“Oh, I inquired after him for the purpose of hanging him likewise; but	196.54103105058607
he was beforehand with me, he had quit the curacy the night before.”	220.62015295959958
“Was it ever known who this miserable fellow was?”	214.35573251671585
“He was doubtless the first lover and accomplice of the fair lady. A	271.1963013357265
worthy man, who had pretended to be a curate for the purpose of getting	304.4624065754367
his mistress married, and securing her a position. He has been hanged	166.23854592463786
and quartered, I hope.”	268.1165199814189
“My God, my God!” cried D’Artagnan, quite stunned by the relation of	188.46883471433867
this horrible adventure.	222.01854851320022
“Taste some of this ham, D’Artagnan; it is exquisite,” said Athos,	332.4391462387235
cutting a slice, which he placed on the young man’s plate.	251.51947837613068
“What a pity it is there were only four like this in the cellar. I	235.4843798322094
could have drunk fifty bottles more.”	194.46342483027763
D’Artagnan could no longer endure this conversation, which had made him	286.3509095887877
bewildered. Allowing his head to sink upon his two hands, he pretended	219.5660386633065
to sleep.	282.5795280032219
“These young fellows can none of them drink,” said Athos, looking at	233.64829656689307
him with pity, “and yet this is one of the best!”	216.67407720598828
Chapter XXVIII.	308.4806206816247
THE RETURN	207.03263390646276
D’Artagnan was astounded by the terrible confidence of Athos; yet many	281.5958017407462
things appeared very obscure to him in this half revelation. In the	276.5443051553417
first place it had been made by a man quite drunk to one who was half	336.45168356956844
drunk; and yet, in spite of the incertainty which the vapor of three or	299.39753644439554
four bottles of Burgundy carries with it to the brain, D’Artagnan, when	332.89343760705736
awaking on the following morning, had all the words of Athos as present	263.6344528557836
to his memory as if they then fell from his mouth—they had been so	221.87549177088619
impressed upon his mind. All this doubt only gave rise to a more lively	227.156270851945
desire of arriving at a certainty, and he went into his friend’s	332.52320742413167
chamber with a fixed determination of renewing the conversation of the	323.8287498937801
preceding evening; but he found Athos quite himself again—that is to	315.15958202849447
say, the most shrewd and impenetrable of men. Besides which, the	356.18530985509216
Musketeer, after having exchanged a hearty shake of the hand with him,	266.86160375559007
broached the matter first.	184.16921779454162
“I was pretty drunk yesterday, D’Artagnan,” said he, “I can tell that	336.06865106700104
by my tongue, which was swollen and hot this morning, and by my pulse,	302.0841816334978
which was very tremulous. I wager that I uttered a thousand	226.2264673333412
extravagances.”	244.74281792833762
While saying this he looked at his friend with an earnestness that	234.81434659362742
embarrassed him.	212.96689719560632
“No,” replied D’Artagnan, “if I recollect well what you said, it was	289.35484646557893
nothing out of the common way.”	196.26033064318202
“Ah, you surprise me. I thought I had told you a most lamentable	283.6726579804209
story.” And he looked at the young man as if he would read the bottom	246.32208499803008
of his heart.	315.51972099148935
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan, “it appears that I was more drunk than	276.136228904557
you, since I remember nothing of the kind.”	167.18493063677798
Athos did not trust this reply, and he resumed; “you cannot have failed	197.17694929611883
to remark, my dear friend, that everyone has his particular kind of	294.9291121835698
drunkenness, sad or gay. My drunkenness is always sad, and when I am	256.1706323489765
thoroughly drunk my mania is to relate all the lugubrious stories which	255.18210851269845
my foolish nurse inculcated into my brain. That is my failing—a capital	176.35697159622435
failing, I admit; but with that exception, I am a good drinker.”	244.12494561235297
Athos spoke this in so natural a manner that D’Artagnan was shaken in	257.7726653322356
his conviction.	345.3694749690917
“It is that, then,” replied the young man, anxious to find out the	210.3609381346327
truth, “it is that, then, I remember as we remember a dream. We were	253.8766445299255
speaking of hanging.”	235.5961919823667
“Ah, you see how it is,” said Athos, becoming still paler, but yet	344.77702170918724
attempting to laugh; “I was sure it was so—the hanging of people is my	167.08742946670358
nightmare.”	339.28239832930814
“Yes, yes,” replied D’Artagnan. “I remember now; yes, it was about—stop	230.572576606256
a minute—yes, it was about a woman.”	217.6050909743875
“That’s it,” replied Athos, becoming almost livid; “that is my grand	328.6316262667311
story of the fair lady, and when I relate that, I must be very drunk.”	287.09488676966663
“Yes, that was it,” said D’Artagnan, “the story of a tall, fair lady,	327.63069888352334
with blue eyes.”	261.6645793910139
“Yes, who was hanged.”	191.58061021385402
“By her husband, who was a nobleman of your acquaintance,” continued	332.3663985302918
D’Artagnan, looking intently at Athos.	306.0654788350014
“Well, you see how a man may compromise himself when he does not know	242.31431525268397
what he says,” replied Athos, shrugging his shoulders as if he thought	334.5603202582091
himself an object of pity. “I certainly never will get drunk again,	361.514758379467
D’Artagnan; it is too bad a habit.”	169.57873955294232
D’Artagnan remained silent; and then changing the conversation all at	194.41876141922182
once, Athos said:	242.74696729288772
“By the by, I thank you for the horse you have brought me.”	254.2237172294524
“Is it to your mind?” asked D’Artagnan.	334.77618073478345
“Yes; but it is not a horse for hard work.”	177.3404427013301
“You are mistaken; I rode him nearly ten leagues in less than an hour	339.5453450678592
and a half, and he appeared no more distressed than if he had only made	169.20282805210678
the tour of the Place St. Sulpice.”	191.6520197509921
“Ah, you begin to awaken my regret.”	327.56799843885335
“Regret?”	222.84410976790937
“Yes; I have parted with him.”	336.8109126548285
“How?”	252.46014575033325
“Why, here is the simple fact. This morning I awoke at six o’clock. You	217.68357583579558
were still fast asleep, and I did not know what to do with myself; I	241.3208028047366
was still stupid from our yesterday’s debauch. As I came into the	291.4213572374975
public room, I saw one of our Englishman bargaining with a dealer for a	349.3382552326128
horse, his own having died yesterday from bleeding. I drew near, and	358.8092456211423
found he was bidding a hundred pistoles for a chestnut nag.	203.50703103589507
‘_Pardieu_,’ said I, ‘my good gentleman, I have a horse to sell, too.’	187.5233232743752
‘Ay, and a very fine one! I saw him yesterday; your friend’s lackey was	325.9438876217642
leading him.’ ‘Do you think he is worth a hundred pistoles?’ ‘Yes! Will	331.2836193746019
you sell him to me for that sum?’ ‘No; but I will play for him.’	258.4329378752585
‘What?’ ‘At dice.’ No sooner said than done, and I lost the horse. Ah,	249.4292342274719
ah! But please to observe I won back the equipage,” cried Athos.	174.9714558539743
D’Artagnan looked much disconcerted.	202.13836121618203
“This vexes you?” said Athos.	356.20658437260147
“Well, I must confess it does,” replied D’Artagnan. “That horse was to	283.0802526980584
have identified us in the day of battle. It was a pledge, a	244.02604712020587
remembrance. Athos, you have done wrong.”	331.66488782669273
“But, my dear friend, put yourself in my place,” replied the Musketeer.	359.73222458896464
“I was hipped to death; and still further, upon my honor, I don’t like	334.3687984376113
English horses. If it is only to be recognized, why the saddle will	252.54974088938434
suffice for that; it is quite remarkable enough. As to the horse, we	184.79797401791376
can easily find some excuse for its disappearance. Why the devil! A	283.2550395509642
horse is mortal; suppose mine had had the glanders or the farcy?”	334.33616189340654
D’Artagnan did not smile.	172.59753063293894
“It vexes me greatly,” continued Athos, “that you attach so much	234.7107747034762
importance to these animals, for I am not yet at the end of my story.”	341.9060403966344
“What else have you done.”	174.0296657207711
“After having lost my own horse, nine against ten—see how near—I formed	360.88020917096594
an idea of staking yours.”	244.54383734000294
“Yes; but you stopped at the idea, I hope?”	202.0440508986763
“No; for I put it in execution that very minute.”	239.6357303824637
“And the consequence?” said D’Artagnan, in great anxiety.	229.13582026093138
“I threw, and I lost.”	270.5791288609865
“What, my horse?”	298.63722382318014
“Your horse, seven against eight; a point short—you know the proverb.”	264.0864084314204
“Athos, you are not in your right senses, I swear.”	185.1171008390815
“My dear lad, that was yesterday, when I was telling you silly stories,	300.44921539784497
it was proper to tell me that, and not this morning. I lost him then,	298.666296635449
with all his appointments and furniture.”	302.6109148107347
“Really, this is frightful.”	182.52193436724576
“Stop a minute; you don’t know all yet. I should make an excellent	228.2994667379354
gambler if I were not too hot-headed; but I was hot-headed, just as if	226.36022505439917
I had been drinking. Well, I was not hot-headed then—”	247.1330193026904
“Well, but what else could you play for? You had nothing left?”	170.48467558771142
“Oh, yes, my friend; there was still that diamond left which sparkles	189.34558328511423
on your finger, and which I had observed yesterday.”	208.13378520776226
“This diamond!” said D’Artagnan, placing his hand eagerly on his ring.	196.70178354944943
“And as I am a connoisseur in such things, having had a few of my own	234.3171453982185
once, I estimated it at a thousand pistoles.”	309.80116811380896
“I hope,” said D’Artagnan, half dead with fright, “you made no mention	285.1189875005224
of my diamond?”	320.2642345998478
“On the contrary, my dear friend, this diamond became our only	283.06262895622643
resource; with it I might regain our horses and their harnesses, and	208.58825902191688
even money to pay our expenses on the road.”	320.3934137714319
“Athos, you make me tremble!” cried D’Artagnan.	270.76533696041616
“I mentioned your diamond then to my adversary, who had likewise	305.7225705938928
remarked it. What the devil, my dear, do you think you can wear a star	363.62771161716785
from heaven on your finger, and nobody observe it? Impossible!”	273.2349682544804
“Go on, go on, my dear fellow!” said D’Artagnan; “for upon my honor,	352.37320710801174
you will kill me with your indifference.”	349.33940224788057
“We divided, then, this diamond into ten parts of a hundred pistoles	295.86778924798244
each.”	320.4283019258563
“You are laughing at me, and want to try me!” said D’Artagnan, whom	259.626134881432
anger began to take by the hair, as Minerva takes Achilles, in the	252.3460167263894
_Iliad_.	220.41802311368306
“No, I do not jest, _mordieu!_ I should like to have seen you in my	364.9190465446373
place! I had been fifteen days without seeing a human face, and had	358.2631745026774
been left to brutalize myself in the company of bottles.”	350.2643185039203
“That was no reason for staking my diamond!” replied D’Artagnan,	297.88616890500873
closing his hand with a nervous spasm.	244.41983954098683
“Hear the end. Ten parts of a hundred pistoles each, in ten throws,	258.10750445411816
without revenge; in thirteen throws I had lost all—in thirteen throws.	199.98730710389026
The number thirteen was always fatal to me; it was on the thirteenth of	256.1374000851287
July that—”	278.3645996646072
“_Ventrebleu!_” cried D’Artagnan, rising from the table, the story of	283.1394904708601
the present day making him forget that of the preceding one.	207.38613857018683
“Patience!” said Athos; “I had a plan. The Englishman was an original;	282.2433107900962
I had seen him conversing that morning with Grimaud, and Grimaud had	347.1718178642591
told me that he had made him proposals to enter into his service. I	198.2176496419616
staked Grimaud, the silent Grimaud, divided into ten portions.”	208.41636255416313
“Well, what next?” said D’Artagnan, laughing in spite of himself.	298.869848175236
“Grimaud himself, understand; and with the ten parts of Grimaud, which	354.8788380036833
are not worth a ducatoon, I regained the diamond. Tell me, now, if	226.90289937809757
persistence is not a virtue?”	200.07082923683353
“My faith! But this is droll,” cried D’Artagnan, consoled, and holding	211.6624307578006
his sides with laughter.	334.41460800643483
“You may guess, finding the luck turned, that I again staked the	215.36784944815514
diamond.”	250.6450403498402
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, becoming angry again.	246.2639134808081
“I won back your harness, then your horse, then my harness, then my	297.486252812127
horse, and then I lost again. In brief, I regained your harness and	339.72467032847226
then mine. That’s where we are. That was a superb throw, so I left off	340.5587831022789
there.”	206.5942526344565
D’Artagnan breathed as if the whole hostelry had been removed from his	355.79044773487726
breast.	193.5597638535881
“Then the diamond is safe?” said he, timidly.	356.38093412362207
“Intact, my dear friend; besides the harness of your Bucephalus and	358.33849926030575
mine.”	194.42115264693717
“But what is the use of harnesses without horses?”	239.26379139401763
“I have an idea about them.”	217.1295946073504
“Athos, you make me shudder.”	231.39205392434934
“Listen to me. You have not played for a long time, D’Artagnan.”	255.2787078985033
“And I have no inclination to play.”	354.75461701576893
“Swear to nothing. You have not played for a long time, I said; you	178.29423224332425
ought, then, to have a good hand.”	303.3580783630374
“Well, what then?”	277.05850221251177
“Well; the Englishman and his companion are still here. I remarked that	299.7054225180316
he regretted the horse furniture very much. You appear to think much of	228.3248890964852
your horse. In your place I would stake the furniture against the	166.9598677600405
horse.”	321.52417233643683
“But he will not wish for only one harness.”	338.8926905305826
“Stake both, _pardieu!_ I am not selfish, as you are.”	312.680143370254
“You would do so?” said D’Artagnan, undecided, so strongly did the	247.5879589165612
confidence of Athos begin to prevail, in spite of himself.	360.23192800613515
“On my honor, in one single throw.”	313.9978532335182
“But having lost the horses, I am particularly anxious to preserve the	188.41457461633794
harnesses.”	311.83784645262426
“Stake your diamond, then.”	216.89451920170856
“This? That’s another matter. Never, never!”	278.4666467630848
“The devil!” said Athos. “I would propose to you to stake Planchet, but	295.599374249039
as that has already been done, the Englishman would not, perhaps, be	181.90440387293376
willing.”	266.71120588451254
“Decidedly, my dear Athos,” said D’Artagnan, “I should like better not	211.66448998368173
to risk anything.”	346.3077191231786
“That’s a pity,” said Athos, coolly. “The Englishman is overflowing	344.23408719066856
with pistoles. Good Lord, try one throw! One throw is soon made!”	301.19492606594224
“And if I lose?”	269.35262395395847
“You will win.”	199.77298921432828
“But if I lose?”	303.6807728306504
“Well, you will surrender the harnesses.”	184.1291856224948
“Have with you for one throw!” said D’Artagnan.	252.4033057497157
Athos went in quest of the Englishman, whom he found in the stable,	311.70306459549994
examining the harnesses with a greedy eye. The opportunity was good. He	201.48175718966425
proposed the conditions—the two harnesses, either against one horse or	302.77969316111853
a hundred pistoles. The Englishman calculated fast; the two harnesses	187.70807527563085
were worth three hundred pistoles. He consented.	285.86509128819836
D’Artagnan threw the dice with a trembling hand, and turned up the	278.1134032987959
number three; his paleness terrified Athos, who, however, consented	308.223179315322
himself with saying, “That’s a sad throw, comrade; you will have the	296.32584480765786
horses fully equipped, monsieur.”	301.0737090686883
The Englishman, quite triumphant, did not even give himself the trouble	240.86138850756325
to shake the dice. He threw them on the table without looking at them,	261.4206790906728
so sure was he of victory; D’Artagnan turned aside to conceal his ill	205.8597776382743
humor.	291.6167204070273
“Hold, hold, hold!” said Athos, wit his quiet tone; “that throw of the	211.7612085684662
dice is extraordinary. I have not seen such a one four times in my	297.580175156625
life. Two aces!”	295.0163347468589
The Englishman looked, and was seized with astonishment. D’Artagnan	189.26759715326307
looked, and was seized with pleasure.	320.73280539580816
“Yes,” continued Athos, “four times only; once at the house of Monsieur	184.13297863174378
Créquy; another time at my own house in the country, in my château	174.18164421748045
at—when I had a château; a third time at Monsieur de Tréville’s where	354.7725260691766
it surprised us all; and the fourth time at a cabaret, where it fell to	166.1622451845413
my lot, and where I lost a hundred louis and a supper on it.”	323.2776688621783
“Then Monsieur takes his horse back again,” said the Englishman.	237.50186753525327
“Certainly,” said D’Artagnan.	182.93913574702816
“Then there is no revenge?”	292.8289040904008
“Our conditions said, ‘No revenge,’ you will please to recollect.”	234.5881075539004
“That is true; the horse shall be restored to your lackey, monsieur.”	328.42319386894724
“A moment,” said Athos; “with your permission, monsieur, I wish to	359.7574144198394
speak a word with my friend.”	337.3909454378677
“Say on.”	171.97770198262987
Athos drew D’Artagnan aside.	306.9582165539188
“Well, Tempter, what more do you want with me?” said D’Artagnan. “You	263.3268695792931
want me to throw again, do you not?”	259.06150902442255
“No, I would wish you to reflect.”	178.59480418233525
“On what?”	303.88588632012807
“You mean to take your horse?”	206.01924987331844
“Without doubt.”	238.4094056817977
“You are wrong, then. I would take the hundred pistoles. You know you	280.03894158274693
have staked the harnesses against the horse or a hundred pistoles, at	226.18126699904184
your choice.”	313.8478024325741
“Yes.”	167.4423640351035
“Well, then, I repeat, you are wrong. What is the use of one horse for	316.56265030511616
us two? I could not ride behind. We should look like the two sons of	206.3933594941326
Aymon, who had lost their brother. You cannot think of humiliating me	168.6833581996537
by prancing along by my side on that magnificent charger. For my part,	308.2248940053148
I should not hesitate a moment; I should take the hundred pistoles. We	285.99226998012387
want money for our return to Paris.”	285.0748631838034
“I am much attached to that horse, Athos.”	274.0262421697846
“And there again you are wrong. A horse slips and injures a joint; a	346.93004871557105
horse stumbles and breaks his knees to the bone; a horse eats out of a	173.76032479108792
manger in which a glandered horse has eaten. There is a horse, while on	272.41468768487493
the contrary, the hundred pistoles feed their master.”	330.6948776818049
“But how shall we get back?”	296.56111198153746
“Upon our lackey’s horses, _pardieu_. Anybody may see by our bearing	203.95020844079605
that we are people of condition.”	237.968594486079
“Pretty figures we shall cut on ponies while Aramis and Porthos	166.90489483805766
caracole on their steeds.”	191.85362738695994
“Aramis! Porthos!” cried Athos, and laughed aloud.	204.08352480900973
“What is it?” asked D’Artagnan, who did not at all comprehend the	307.14289032417537
hilarity of his friend.	191.7789045577945
“Nothing, nothing! Go on!”	212.89234119818795
“Your advice, then?”	227.481242245499
“To take the hundred pistoles, D’Artagnan. With the hundred pistoles we	253.00574907836804
can live well to the end of the month. We have undergone a great deal	285.52596335630074
of fatigue, remember, and a little rest will do no harm.”	288.47390153302206
“I rest? Oh, no, Athos. Once in Paris, I shall prosecute my search for	201.37882869684796
that unfortunate woman!”	173.11153584024436
“Well, you may be assured that your horse will not be half so	179.84722243017367
serviceable to you for that purpose as good golden louis. Take the	258.7490589630853
hundred pistoles, my friend; take the hundred pistoles!”	331.3405404128131
D’Artagnan only required one reason to be satisfied. This last reason	225.58377900851465
appeared convincing. Besides, he feared that by resisting longer he	303.07107625721426
should appear selfish in the eyes of Athos. He acquiesced, therefore,	365.61839996266895
and chose the hundred pistoles, which the Englishman paid down on the	261.84641947438377
spot.	300.0163381699714
They then determined to depart. Peace with the landlord, in addition to	298.82489816210784
Athos’s old horse, cost six pistoles. D’Artagnan and Athos took the	320.54827628314206
nags of Planchet and Grimaud, and the two lackeys started on foot,	281.6815763416772
carrying the saddles on their heads.	357.33789462827326
However ill our two friends were mounted, they were soon far in advance	177.5481337032129
of their servants, and arrived at Crèvecœur. From a distance they	296.4702469955235
perceived Aramis, seated in a melancholy manner at his window, looking	297.3712723881023
out, like Sister Anne, at the dust in the horizon.	328.5494183393223
“_Holà_, Aramis! What the devil are you doing there?” cried the two	172.58965959939158
friends.	225.81665437415225
“Ah, is that you, D’Artagnan, and you, Athos?” said the young man. “I	240.0113855953374
was reflecting upon the rapidity with which the blessings of this world	187.92557512094183
leave us. My English horse, which has just disappeared amid a cloud of	278.90165203586855
dust, has furnished me with a living image of the fragility of the	261.48407160223377
things of the earth. Life itself may be resolved into three words:	233.0231923989101
_Erat, est, fuit_.”	218.1479192485664
“Which means—” said D’Artagnan, who began to suspect the truth.	303.4881534019116
“Which means that I have just been duped—sixty louis for a horse which	236.85361831380914
by the manner of his gait can do at least five leagues an hour.”	269.7557749390837
D’Artagnan and Athos laughed aloud.	264.72645651465587
“My dear D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, “don’t be too angry with me, I beg.	349.43036369601646
Necessity has no law; besides, I am the person punished, as that	241.073587901482
rascally horsedealer has robbed me of fifty louis, at least. Ah, you	276.9040712984494
fellows are good managers! You ride on our lackey’s horses, and have	215.7158452078758
your own gallant steeds led along carefully by hand, at short stages.”	340.23874886484975
At the same instant a market cart, which some minutes before had	176.54222905643095
appeared upon the Amiens road, pulled up at the inn, and Planchet and	264.3009931514008
Grimaud came out of it with the saddles on their heads. The cart was	188.73315387125524
returning empty to Paris, and the two lackeys had agreed, for their	260.19860658326525
transport, to slake the wagoner’s thirst along the route.	314.57475412021904
“What is this?” said Aramis, on seeing them arrive. “Nothing but	170.73360198903202
saddles?”	187.41539638566462
“Now do you understand?” said Athos.	185.35137270590775
“My friends, that’s exactly like me! I retained my harness by instinct.	175.24106105485717
_Holà_, Bazin! Bring my new saddle and carry it along with those of	191.89298485377594
these gentlemen.”	273.01434121941344
“And what have you done with your ecclesiastics?” asked D’Artagnan.	278.8650312003133
“My dear fellow, I invited them to a dinner the next day,” replied	168.4235340120322
Aramis. “They have some capital wine here—please to observe that in	177.57811346382766
passing. I did my best to make them drunk. Then the curate forbade me	318.98008190107106
to quit my uniform, and the Jesuit entreated me to get him made a	329.765924622615
Musketeer.”	299.42759695737186
“Without a thesis?” cried D’Artagnan, “without a thesis? I demand the	297.8472933484318
suppression of the thesis.”	330.64058846747673
“Since then,” continued Aramis, “I have lived very agreeably. I have	275.70095743702456
begun a poem in verses of one syllable. That is rather difficult, but	299.7239795955659
the merit in all things consists in the difficulty. The matter is	183.9193592142324
gallant. I will read you the first canto. It has four hundred lines,	212.19835310190098
and lasts a minute.”	361.96055981845245
“My faith, my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, who detested verses almost	335.5586841669373
as much as he did Latin, “add to the merit of the difficulty that of	324.91504997375534
the brevity, and you are sure that your poem will at least have two	224.7507832058538
merits.”	205.08064070233314
“You will see,” continued Aramis, “that it breathes irreproachable	209.38245184792396
passion. And so, my friends, we return to Paris? Bravo! I am ready. We	307.391238954502
are going to rejoin that good fellow, Porthos. So much the better. You	283.9223087079334
can’t think how I have missed him, the great simpleton. To see him so	299.22762157227305
self-satisfied reconciles me with myself. He would not sell his horse;	221.93843694684244
not for a kingdom! I think I can see him now, mounted upon his superb	338.31109557542004
animal and seated in his handsome saddle. I am sure he will look like	273.7217496116453
the Great Mogul!”	293.9389458724299
They made a halt for an hour to refresh their horses. Aramis discharged	299.2493092803115
his bill, placed Bazin in the cart with his comrades, and they set	283.869412843678
forward to join Porthos.	193.83905020953102
They found him up, less pale than when D’Artagnan left him after his	199.75948922006813
first visit, and seated at a table on which, though he was alone, was	254.86447961461306
spread enough for four persons. This dinner consisted of meats nicely	217.37234300124842
dressed, choice wines, and superb fruit.	286.9102311174488
“Ah, _pardieu!_” said he, rising, “you come in the nick of time,	292.74043963784436
gentlemen. I was just beginning the soup, and you will dine with me.”	221.39428874728645
“Oh, oh!” said D’Artagnan, “Mousqueton has not caught these bottles	252.7571752074758
with his lasso. Besides, here is a piquant _fricandeau_ and a fillet of	188.02622041329332
beef.”	317.55567854694704
“I am recruiting myself,” said Porthos, “I am recruiting myself.	241.4327264924516
Nothing weakens a man more than these devilish strains. Did you ever	343.65169362301555
suffer from a strain, Athos?”	272.7850222290761
“Never! Though I remember, in our affair of the Rue Férou, I received a	180.27947654251446
sword wound which at the end of fifteen or eighteen days produced the	320.97152759084724
same effect.”	329.1841377353066
“But this dinner was not intended for you alone, Porthos?” said Aramis.	276.338780629147
“No,” said Porthos, “I expected some gentlemen of the neighborhood, who	344.95158458131476
have just sent me word they could not come. You will take their places	315.20082860099865
and I shall not lose by the exchange. _Holà_, Mousqueton, seats, and	217.2412035179087
order double the bottles!”	200.9845441596378
“Do you know what we are eating here?” said Athos, at the end of ten	236.97902688176475
minutes.	240.0539220529317
“_Pardieu!_” replied D’Artagnan, “for my part, I am eating veal	175.49589938703954
garnished with shrimps and vegetables.”	290.35017958880127
“And I some lamb chops,” said Porthos.	358.9761020459467
“And I a plain chicken,” said Aramis.	239.81796933985822
“You are all mistaken, gentlemen,” answered Athos, gravely; “you are	363.28629787933426
eating horse.”	217.33248655428207
“Eating what?” said D’Artagnan.	342.3670204336901
“Horse!” said Aramis, with a grimace of disgust.	332.14147681586286
Porthos alone made no reply.	260.6970145743379
“Yes, horse. Are we not eating a horse, Porthos? And perhaps his	348.9189700225087
saddle, therewith.”	175.39178455056685
“No, gentlemen, I have kept the harness,” said Porthos.	348.6199305182183
“My faith,” said Aramis, “we are all alike. One would think we had	266.2329704062528
tipped the wink.”	178.3969757010038
“What could I do?” said Porthos. “This horse made my visitors ashamed	274.7081412199528
of theirs, and I don’t like to humiliate people.”	273.7581348573072
“Then your duchess is still at the waters?” asked D’Artagnan.	303.2596062707786
“Still,” replied Porthos. “And, my faith, the governor of the	253.1188196154243
province—one of the gentlemen I expected today—seemed to have such a	245.72610205603507
wish for him, that I gave him to him.”	349.24003042796573
“Gave him?” cried D’Artagnan.	295.77522936512605
“My God, yes, _gave_, that is the word,” said Porthos; “for the animal	167.44462197343412
was worth at least a hundred and fifty louis, and the stingy fellow	215.75291702177404
would only give me eighty.”	224.7119040693124
“Without the saddle?” said Aramis.	187.33622370933878
“Yes, without the saddle.”	349.5542288906664
“You will observe, gentlemen,” said Athos, “that Porthos has made the	283.5478290404618
best bargain of any of us.”	199.59935590939367
And then commenced a roar of laughter in which they all joined, to the	216.56404606199987
astonishment of poor Porthos; but when he was informed of the cause of	209.79132386458517
their hilarity, he shared it vociferously according to his custom.	275.7748980048353
“There is one comfort, we are all in cash,” said D’Artagnan.	189.6901353507236
“Well, for my part,” said Athos, “I found Aramis’s Spanish wine so good	282.60613584160376
that I sent on a hamper of sixty bottles of it in the wagon with the	231.83724625993355
lackeys. That has weakened my purse.”	247.02743839609104
“And I,” said Aramis, “imagined that I had given almost my last sou to	352.17798683576234
the church of Montdidier and the Jesuits of Amiens, with whom I had	269.809979774622
made engagements which I ought to have kept. I have ordered Masses for	355.73223941595813
myself, and for you, gentlemen, which will be said, gentlemen, for	280.5710265926841
which I have not the least doubt you will be marvelously benefited.”	225.95544623177705
“And I,” said Porthos, “do you think my strain cost me nothing?—without	266.67013948437955
reckoning Mousqueton’s wound, for which I had to have the surgeon twice	251.7276879030024
a day, and who charged me double on account of that foolish Mousqueton	175.9378772159459
having allowed himself a ball in a part which people generally only	300.8309889292449
show to an apothecary; so I advised him to try never to get wounded	234.3078356886491
there any more.”	364.03680947858413
“Ay, ay!” said Athos, exchanging a smile with D’Artagnan and Aramis,	276.7586867260457
“it is very clear you acted nobly with regard to the poor lad; that is	184.5653271723946
like a good master.”	223.98908335782363
“In short,” said Porthos, “when all my expenses are paid, I shall have,	355.92166231214276
at most, thirty crowns left.”	304.8016142466768
“And I about ten pistoles,” said Aramis.	343.4697731811149
“Well, then it appears that we are the Crœsuses of the society. How	339.4684557570837
much have you left of your hundred pistoles, D’Artagnan?”	246.07275553590338
“Of my hundred pistoles? Why, in the first place I gave you fifty.”	353.0672893141565
“You think so?”	339.3071115469231
“_Pardieu!_”	335.53679592178946
“Ah, that is true. I recollect.”	170.5492757954074
“Then I paid the host six.”	349.7000488118968
“What a brute of a host! Why did you give him six pistoles?”	194.75870208326913
“You told me to give them to him.”	215.3513550406185
“It is true; I am too good-natured. In brief, how much remains?”	330.3054631430398
“Twenty-five pistoles,” said D’Artagnan.	337.482372206112
“And I,” said Athos, taking some small change from his pocket, “I—”	346.39580349065534
“You? Nothing!”	330.7807573688291
“My faith! So little that it is not worth reckoning with the general	328.02185146928196
stock.”	260.1672683676178
“Now, then, let us calculate how much we posses in all.”	216.68172552675014
“Porthos?”	300.3975684578252
“Thirty crowns.”	176.3809465389262
“Aramis?”	199.52236662391354
“Ten pistoles.”	356.13911142562176
“And you, D’Artagnan?”	174.10792485082553
“Twenty-five.”	364.59411196536905
“That makes in all?” said Athos.	215.43458444587873
“Four hundred and seventy-five livres,” said D’Artagnan, who reckoned	357.7876915807351
like Archimedes.	212.57115861722542
“On our arrival in Paris, we shall still have four hundred, besides the	201.04875835081805
harnesses,” said Porthos.	335.8156354597355
“But our troop horses?” said Aramis.	312.07463281254263
“Well, of the four horses of our lackeys we will make two for the	361.08664895135644
masters, for which we will draw lots. With the four hundred livres we	236.3747078793288
will make the half of one for one of the unmounted, and then we will	335.39778852925656
give the turnings out of our pockets to D’Artagnan, who has a steady	327.584481380826
hand, and will go and play in the first gaming house we come to.	250.17190250943108
There!”	218.45514479891636
“Let us dine, then,” said Porthos; “it is getting cold.”	222.84111703879327
The friends, at ease with regard to the future, did honor to the	236.25733290297757
repast, the remains of which were abandoned to Mousqueton, Bazin,	200.09737062942813
Planchet, and Grimaud.	350.4580724674749
On arriving in Paris, D’Artagnan found a letter from M. de Tréville,	325.3141507627009
which informed him that, at his request, the king had promised that he	333.11475738932904
should enter the company of the Musketeers.	364.1758515694445
As this was the height of D’Artagnan’s worldly ambition—apart, be it	284.92292513117746
well understood, from his desire of finding Mme. Bonacieux—he ran, full	230.98498790704943
of joy, to seek his comrades, whom he had left only half an hour	207.20564259104745
before, but whom he found very sad and deeply preoccupied. They were	300.9938900335959
assembled in council at the residence of Athos, which always indicated	197.59884436980482
an event of some gravity. M. de Tréville had intimated to them his	334.82280308366035
Majesty’s fixed intention to open the campaign on the first of May, and	297.5952359650629
they must immediately prepare their outfits.	263.67063691156807
The four philosophers looked at one another in a state of bewilderment.	349.65703850162964
M. de Tréville never jested in matters relating to discipline.	191.2170377835498
“And what do you reckon your outfit will cost?” said D’Artagnan.	346.54094150102446
“Oh, we can scarcely say. We have made our calculations with Spartan	177.15947495485423
economy, and we each require fifteen hundred livres.”	331.2152346135214
“Four times fifteen makes sixty—six thousand livres,” said Athos.	233.1554968571694
“It seems to me,” said D’Artagnan, “with a thousand livres each—I do	166.42493303427284
not speak as a Spartan, but as a procurator—”	218.15897977073337
This word _procurator_ roused Porthos. “Stop,” said he, “I have an	352.69701638060405
idea.”	269.7575136075559
“Well, that’s something, for I have not the shadow of one,” said Athos	318.68892720695965
coolly; “but as to D’Artagnan, gentlemen, the idea of belonging to	339.4846017791896
_ours_ has driven him out of his senses. A thousand livres! For my	205.73546599171254
part, I declare I want two thousand.”	253.3876129459582
“Four times two makes eight,” then said Aramis; “it is eight thousand	236.02772085504142
that we want to complete our outfits, toward which, it is true, we have	310.5208117162474
already the saddles.”	249.24110564814464
“Besides,” said Athos, waiting till D’Artagnan, who went to thank	231.10883662972003
Monsieur de Tréville, had shut the door, “besides, there is that	317.49712292319214
beautiful ring which beams from the finger of our friend. What the	231.0329180951142
devil! D’Artagnan is too good a comrade to leave his brothers in	364.698414632337
embarrassment while he wears the ransom of a king on his finger.”	325.4588080335193
Chapter XXIX.	233.08332441546344
HUNTING FOR THE EQUIPMENTS	257.51717061406
The most preoccupied of the four friends was certainly D’Artagnan,	182.52690043446444
although he, in his quality of Guardsman, would be much more easily	228.44421890901464
equipped than Messieurs the Musketeers, who were all of high rank; but	183.09386104690404
our Gascon cadet was, as may have been observed, of a provident and	271.1041719349947
almost avaricious character, and with that (explain the contradiction)	186.24806215329372
so vain as almost to rival Porthos. To this preoccupation of his	221.42106963572544
vanity, D’Artagnan at this moment joined an uneasiness much less	190.8608047984407
selfish. Notwithstanding all his inquiries respecting Mme. Bonacieux,	288.57807610994763
he could obtain no intelligence of her. M. de Tréville had spoken of	334.6626721044704
her to the queen. The queen was ignorant where the mercer’s young wife	179.69425861612962
was, but had promised to have her sought for; but this promise was very	252.345259640376
vague and did not at all reassure D’Artagnan.	305.1810661685969
Athos did not leave his chamber; he made up his mind not to take a	192.39370438783305
single step to equip himself.	313.88616573472444
“We have still fifteen days before us,” said he to his friends, “well,	249.1965968434979
if at the end of a fortnight I have found nothing, or rather if nothing	239.2121173571188
has come to find me, as I, too good a Catholic to kill myself with a	228.08552022443675
pistol bullet, I will seek a good quarrel with four of his Eminence’s	353.56828675304916
Guards or with eight Englishmen, and I will fight until one of them has	215.36849734149393
killed me, which, considering the number, cannot fail to happen. It	183.77335653193322
will then be said of me that I died for the king; so that I shall have	290.8327841557449
performed my duty without the expense of an outfit.”	217.9748676659461
Porthos continued to walk about with his hands behind him, tossing his	265.6130781591089
head and repeating, “I shall follow up on my idea.”	274.88106158088436
Aramis, anxious and negligently dressed, said nothing.	172.2596353278758
It may be seen by these disastrous details that desolation reigned in	172.74677775075597
the community.	255.26040581702182
The lackeys on their part, like the coursers of Hippolytus, shared the	239.54467182845025
sadness of their masters. Mousqueton collected a store of crusts;	317.0216177443947
Bazin, who had always been inclined to devotion, never quit the	175.95501830120006
churches; Planchet watched the flight of flies; and Grimaud, whom the	292.61643773763467
general distress could not induce to break the silence imposed by his	282.846197664823
master, heaved sighs enough to soften the stones.	362.5433405381066
The three friends—for, as we have said, Athos had sworn not to stir a	354.20838697294425
foot to equip himself—went out early in the morning, and returned late	241.04916512595753
at night. They wandered about the streets, looking at the pavement as	264.44110689097795
if to see whether the passengers had not left a purse behind them. They	344.7554427127592
might have been supposed to be following tracks, so observant were they	283.86829461616423
wherever they went. When they met they looked desolately at one	236.91662597131034
another, as much as to say, “Have you found anything?”	263.72970489584065
However, as Porthos had first found an idea, and had thought of it	254.0147423028999
earnestly afterward, he was the first to act. He was a man of	363.0866514820518
execution, this worthy Porthos. D’Artagnan perceived him one day	277.08133230125816
walking toward the church of St. Leu, and followed him instinctively.	257.43449069015713
He entered, after having twisted his mustache and elongated his	242.28009900450013
imperial, which always announced on his part the most triumphant	267.92734831705707
resolutions. As D’Artagnan took some precautions to conceal himself,	219.42596280192603
Porthos believed he had not been seen. D’Artagnan entered behind him.	332.055348447802
Porthos went and leaned against the side of a pillar. D’Artagnan, still	201.63625465717837
unperceived, supported himself against the other side.	308.22248037486366
There happened to be a sermon, which made the church very full of	290.0033643920974
people. Porthos took advantage of this circumstance to ogle the women.	226.16703448011637
Thanks to the cares of Mousqueton, the exterior was far from announcing	211.51833758646453
the distress of the interior. His hat was a little napless, his feather	319.77513831406077
was a little faded, his gold lace was a little tarnished, his laces	260.30767809323845
were a trifle frayed; but in the obscurity of the church these things	240.63583286401888
were not seen, and Porthos was still the handsome Porthos.	201.6771967882551
D’Artagnan observed, on the bench nearest to the pillar against which	223.11621424214746
Porthos leaned, a sort of ripe beauty, rather yellow and rather dry,	343.5285534822814
but erect and haughty under her black hood. The eyes of Porthos were	357.3600782313081
furtively cast upon this lady, and then roved about at large over the	236.9217038704456
nave.	266.1172621892436
On her side the lady, who from time to time blushed, darted with the	307.2814278713762
rapidity of lightning a glance toward the inconstant Porthos; and then	214.3919093593766
immediately the eyes of Porthos wandered anxiously. It was plain that	212.2580259427283
this mode of proceeding piqued the lady in the black hood, for she bit	270.39062931110726
her lips till they bled, scratched the end of her nose, and could not	248.66211590458244
sit still in her seat.	208.33634295463278
Porthos, seeing this, retwisted his mustache, elongated his imperial a	207.97704521769504
second time, and began to make signals to a beautiful lady who was near	357.77197804886066
the choir, and who not only was a beautiful lady, but still further, no	351.83265128306056
doubt, a great lady—for she had behind her a Negro boy who had brought	330.62897387328746
the cushion on which she knelt, and a female servant who held the	309.18538284908465
emblazoned bag in which was placed the book from which she read the	319.8403979030063
Mass.	289.1488784039419
The lady with the black hood followed through all their wanderings the	316.4239940143066
looks of Porthos, and perceived that they rested upon the lady with the	310.1080830078805
velvet cushion, the little Negro, and the maid-servant.	354.15006742135813
During this time Porthos played close. It was almost imperceptible	320.32727348588395
motions of his eyes, fingers placed upon the lips, little assassinating	218.33773440455772
smiles, which really did assassinate the disdained beauty.	278.8387943468816
Then she cried, “Ahem!” under cover of the _mea culpa_, striking her	289.43371978659434
breast so vigorously that everybody, even the lady with the red	331.3646015215928
cushion, turned round toward her. Porthos paid no attention.	284.15764113399797
Nevertheless, he understood it all, but was deaf.	311.7553959503441
The lady with the red cushion produced a great effect—for she was very	293.3590550363422
handsome—upon the lady with the black hood, who saw in her a rival	353.96628410044127
really to be dreaded; a great effect upon Porthos, who thought her much	362.4413420597167
prettier than the lady with the black hood; a great effect upon	259.83998763413746
D’Artagnan, who recognized in her the lady of Meung, of Calais, and of	301.25227699621314
Dover, whom his persecutor, the man with the scar, had saluted by the	173.07719623932232
name of Milady.	350.6629681196097
D’Artagnan, without losing sight of the lady of the red cushion,	249.99510278429057
continued to watch the proceedings of Porthos, which amused him	334.4961117612175
greatly. He guessed that the lady of the black hood was the	329.3102129929369
procurator’s wife of the Rue aux Ours, which was the more probable from	320.02684469486655
the church of St. Leu being not far from that locality.	322.9422856411799
He guessed, likewise, by induction, that Porthos was taking his revenge	265.38788877767627
for the defeat of Chantilly, when the procurator’s wife had proved so	283.10271241376716
refractory with respect to her purse.	257.4933399153533
Amid all this, D’Artagnan remarked also that not one countenance	354.2518337369987
responded to the gallantries of Porthos. There were only chimeras and	270.34208644699834
illusions; but for real love, for true jealousy, is there any reality	220.06932449723755
except illusions and chimeras?	180.4543239746903
The sermon over, the procurator’s wife advanced toward the holy font.	194.75344442874538
Porthos went before her, and instead of a finger, dipped his whole hand	347.3374644123248
in. The procurator’s wife smiled, thinking that it was for her Porthos	229.80694932391913
had put himself to this trouble; but she was cruelly and promptly	289.7456189090814
undeceived. When she was only about three steps from him, he turned his	248.5024575327065
head round, fixing his eyes steadfastly upon the lady with the red	249.0880394176482
cushion, who had risen and was approaching, followed by her black boy	208.93038392466644
and her woman.	364.0341001040408
When the lady of the red cushion came close to Porthos, Porthos drew	283.22807463002124
his dripping hand from the font. The fair worshipper touched the great	295.19331642827876
hand of Porthos with her delicate fingers, smiled, made the sign of the	350.3428715491709
cross, and left the church.	238.50101811529447
This was too much for the procurator’s wife; she doubted not there was	339.96690130862703
an intrigue between this lady and Porthos. If she had been a great lady	192.69044475916837
she would have fainted; but as she was only a procurator’s wife, she	262.9632460322333
contented herself saying to the Musketeer with concentrated fury, “Eh,	339.2349200052971
Monsieur Porthos, you don’t offer me any holy water?”	360.51419225361605
Porthos, at the sound of that voice, started like a man awakened from a	166.89687068340947
sleep of a hundred years.	299.5269006351425
“Ma-madame!” cried he; “is that you? How is your husband, our dear	196.40628921638066
Monsieur Coquenard? Is he still as stingy as ever? Where can my eyes	241.25132656793394
have been not to have seen you during the two hours of the sermon?”	333.3505523179734
“I was within two paces of you, monsieur,” replied the procurator’s	311.84489644677427
wife; “but you did not perceive me because you had no eyes but for the	179.38267570230124
pretty lady to whom you just now gave the holy water.”	286.9403030277135
Porthos pretended to be confused. “Ah,” said he, “you have remarked—”	334.2668302183772
“I must have been blind not to have seen.”	188.78426413770666
“Yes,” said Porthos, “that is a duchess of my acquaintance whom I have	305.7479696956701
great trouble to meet on account of the jealousy of her husband, and	283.6365184204224
who sent me word that she should come today to this poor church, buried	230.75574952664445
in this vile quarter, solely for the sake of seeing me.”	349.7562971112085
“Monsieur Porthos,” said the procurator’s wife, “will you have the	341.01387851561265
kindness to offer me your arm for five minutes? I have something to say	211.55501494927353
to you.”	190.3811644746096
“Certainly, madame,” said Porthos, winking to himself, as a gambler	204.62655217798374
does who laughs at the dupe he is about to pluck.	184.35718603395065
At that moment D’Artagnan passed in pursuit of Milady; he cast a	249.7863907979277
passing glance at Porthos, and beheld this triumphant look.	170.13825234713735
“Eh, eh!” said he, reasoning to himself according to the strangely easy	219.36839945093314
morality of that gallant period, “there is one who will be equipped in	249.09663537956362
good time!”	307.30454833249553
Porthos, yielding to the pressure of the arm of the procurator’s wife,	258.2191436897958
as a bark yields to the rudder, arrived at the cloister St. Magloire—a	260.8066120121359
little-frequented passage, enclosed with a turnstile at each end. In	356.1542650102309
the daytime nobody was seen there but mendicants devouring their	268.59461327249227
crusts, and children at play.	194.41220533822798
“Ah, Monsieur Porthos,” cried the procurator’s wife, when she was	288.31074837469237
assured that no one who was a stranger to the population of the	310.84121258146223
locality could either see or hear her, “ah, Monsieur Porthos, you are a	328.9255139572166
great conqueror, as it appears!”	214.30287424737077
“I, madame?” said Porthos, drawing himself up proudly; “how so?”	188.7259442610066
“The signs just now, and the holy water! But that must be a princess,	244.07914840977665
at least—that lady with her Negro boy and her maid!”	267.34930295949437
“My God! Madame, you are deceived,” said Porthos; “she is simply a	183.01799538207067
duchess.”	180.96030267604473
“And that running footman who waited at the door, and that carriage	305.62692853440353
with a coachman in grand livery who sat waiting on his seat?”	177.20252136007895
Porthos had seen neither the footman nor the carriage, but with the eye	286.59245829985116
of a jealous woman, Mme. Coquenard had seen everything.	339.5905825053875
Porthos regretted that he had not at once made the lady of the red	281.5272150234232
cushion a princess.	170.59282613815014
“Ah, you are quite the pet of the ladies, Monsieur Porthos!” resumed	318.64438888548005
the procurator’s wife, with a sigh.	312.4005455768128
“Well,” responded Porthos, “you may imagine, with the physique with	308.02057201910367
which nature has endowed me, I am not in want of good luck.”	273.7022281825906
“Good Lord, how quickly men forget!” cried the procurator’s wife,	292.2902578250629
raising her eyes toward heaven.	241.74673752699994
“Less quickly than the women, it seems to me,” replied Porthos; “for I,	346.6148951571601
madame, I may say I was your victim, when wounded, dying, I was	263.13773270664853
abandoned by the surgeons. I, the offspring of a noble family, who	235.75513665711506
placed reliance upon your friendship—I was near dying of my wounds at	259.26563826241426
first, and of hunger afterward, in a beggarly inn at Chantilly, without	188.11204999328618
you ever deigning once to reply to the burning letters I addressed to	208.8472118289815
you.”	202.50262127368026
“But, Monsieur Porthos,” murmured the procurator’s wife, who began to	284.3885794877116
feel that, to judge by the conduct of the great ladies of the time, she	268.4710098228445
was wrong.	202.58686069495934
“I, who had sacrificed for you the Baronne de—”	244.53364404617574
“I know it well.”	254.48955164999475
“The Comtesse de—”	291.5112014233831
“Monsieur Porthos, be generous!”	273.0923081274161
“You are right, madame, and I will not finish.”	192.2249689982373
“But it was my husband who would not hear of lending.”	337.53169044430774
“Madame Coquenard,” said Porthos, “remember the first letter you wrote	185.69218367516862
me, and which I preserve engraved in my memory.”	173.22278062957395
The procurator’s wife uttered a groan.	301.50764057466574
“Besides,” said she, “the sum you required me to borrow was rather	210.08250927336147
large.”	312.48572728029137
“Madame Coquenard, I gave you the preference. I had but to write to the	310.4350319648134
Duchesse—but I won’t repeat her name, for I am incapable of	169.96895518282852
compromising a woman; but this I know, that I had but to write to her	325.14027007048134
and she would have sent me fifteen hundred.”	190.81635739790477
The procurator’s wife shed a tear.	274.55424837551607
“Monsieur Porthos,” said she, “I can assure you that you have severely	327.17856312077123
punished me; and if in the time to come you should find yourself in a	182.39848418579248
similar situation, you have but to apply to me.”	196.99343276091562
“Fie, madame, fie!” said Porthos, as if disgusted. “Let us not talk	275.023271036194
about money, if you please; it is humiliating.”	249.96143902527828
“Then you no longer love me!” said the procurator’s wife, slowly and	169.28684867505856
sadly.	263.12938993835087
Porthos maintained a majestic silence.	269.70549464427575
“And that is the only reply you make? Alas, I understand.”	188.78560664918172
“Think of the offense you have committed toward me, madame! It remains	183.39772505335338
_here!_” said Porthos, placing his hand on his heart, and pressing it	352.6141394834193
strongly.	199.6886693220595
“I will repair it, indeed I will, my dear Porthos.”	282.5022994172929
“Besides, what did I ask of you?” resumed Porthos, with a movement of	333.5476098576354
the shoulders full of good fellowship. “A loan, nothing more! After	353.10870407836467
all, I am not an unreasonable man. I know you are not rich, Madame	297.81949519184565
Coquenard, and that your husband is obliged to bleed his poor clients	340.3555737744957
to squeeze a few paltry crowns from them. Oh! If you were a duchess, a	185.5925991532937
