marchioness, or a countess, it would be quite a different thing; it	358.5094070411518
would be unpardonable.”	186.78278657265952
The procurator’s wife was piqued.	218.07145802478544
“Please to know, Monsieur Porthos,” said she, “that my strongbox, the	341.9464550327533
strongbox of a procurator’s wife though it may be, is better filled	216.66639018630417
than those of your affected minxes.”	242.9904634771321
“That doubles the offense,” said Porthos, disengaging his arm from that	295.1224715080956
of the procurator’s wife; “for if you are rich, Madame Coquenard, then	365.1061929534676
there is no excuse for your refusal.”	295.90335358221375
“When I said rich,” replied the procurator’s wife, who saw that she had	260.7706119400725
gone too far, “you must not take the word literally. I am not precisely	259.7773629125185
rich, though I am pretty well off.”	209.1031489192662
“Hold, madame,” said Porthos, “let us say no more upon the subject, I	339.69593687194026
beg of you. You have misunderstood me, all sympathy is extinct between	216.3724747432018
us.”	236.76444421803055
“Ingrate that you are!”	174.34661863111822
“Ah! I advise you to complain!” said Porthos.	182.66916502248876
“Begone, then, to your beautiful duchess; I will detain you no longer.”	291.1330026107896
“And she is not to be despised, in my opinion.”	177.0708209337254
“Now, Monsieur Porthos, once more, and this is the last! Do you love me	291.3070198398953
still?”	230.96415394562155
“Ah, madame,” said Porthos, in the most melancholy tone he could	294.9486768555041
assume, “when we are about to enter upon a campaign—a campaign, in	274.80813284653806
which my presentiments tell me I shall be killed—”	243.692595767256
“Oh, don’t talk of such things!” cried the procurator’s wife, bursting	203.95807970030666
into tears.	247.20727089303878
“Something whispers me so,” continued Porthos, becoming more and more	177.06064143321902
melancholy.	328.84192397481877
“Rather say that you have a new love.”	247.3844927459994
“Not so; I speak frankly to you. No object affects me; and I even feel	327.06676140259117
here, at the bottom of my heart, something which speaks for you. But in	196.6887997019724
fifteen days, as you know, or as you do not know, this fatal campaign	245.3863846307991
is to open. I shall be fearfully preoccupied with my outfit. Then I	310.2147384024064
must make a journey to see my family, in the lower part of Brittany, to	173.6048704285853
obtain the sum necessary for my departure.”	228.66055363328744
Porthos observed a last struggle between love and avarice.	354.5565693029106
“And as,” continued he, “the duchess whom you saw at the church has	258.02417747030023
estates near to those of my family, we mean to make the journey	176.28922237220883
together. Journeys, you know, appear much shorter when we travel two in	256.69737186575776
company.”	181.81014988638054
“Have you no friends in Paris, then, Monsieur Porthos?” said the	305.88299084297967
procurator’s wife.	226.61208847159463
“I thought I had,” said Porthos, resuming his melancholy air; “but I	268.6769879421688
have been taught my mistake.”	301.3845248023625
“You have some!” cried the procurator’s wife, in a transport that	212.15332838326074
surprised even herself. “Come to our house tomorrow. You are the son of	346.92499602765247
my aunt, consequently my cousin; you come from Noyon, in Picardy; you	264.58687054007834
have several lawsuits and no attorney. Can you recollect all that?”	174.32555402891407
“Perfectly, madame.”	191.16037927698463
“Come at dinnertime.”	318.5571993605896
“Very well.”	332.7376592416166
“And be upon your guard before my husband, who is rather shrewd,	287.677296095001
notwithstanding his seventy-six years.”	344.21002299537656
“Seventy-six years! _Peste!_ That’s a fine age!” replied Porthos.	176.63264279291326
“A great age, you mean, Monsieur Porthos. Yes, the poor man may be	264.25936538581385
expected to leave me a widow, any hour,” continued she, throwing a	211.34295204710057
significant glance at Porthos. “Fortunately, by our marriage contract,	247.6791193120372
the survivor takes everything.”	224.06387435531695
“All?”	248.5622698689159
“Yes, all.”	175.6704532368252
“You are a woman of precaution, I see, my dear Madame Coquenard,” said	311.11751659808647
Porthos, squeezing the hand of the procurator’s wife tenderly.	233.86772983268065
“We are then reconciled, dear Monsieur Porthos?” said she, simpering.	197.35077256568056
“For life,” replied Porthos, in the same manner.	269.2844847081088
“Till we meet again, then, dear traitor!”	271.0751925417949
“Till we meet again, my forgetful charmer!”	223.87632004817735
“Tomorrow, my angel!”	318.0971769256621
“Tomorrow, flame of my life!”	241.02058831250417
Chapter XXX.	267.2156555982583
D’ARTAGNAN AND THE ENGLISHMAN	186.92193149730005
D’Artagnan followed Milady without being perceived by her. He saw her	242.49157687370615
get into her carriage, and heard her order the coachman to drive to St.	254.23048192756397
Germain.	171.73881343235772
It was useless to try to keep pace on foot with a carriage drawn by two	206.71606459012742
powerful horses. D’Artagnan therefore returned to the Rue Férou.	256.4620003168473
In the Rue de Seine he met Planchet, who had stopped before the house	198.28254121752127
of a pastry cook, and was contemplating with ecstasy a cake of the most	229.26045838193915
appetizing appearance.	305.17610611180714
He ordered him to go and saddle two horses in M. de Tréville’s	364.6846311288191
stables—one for himself, D’Artagnan, and one for Planchet—and bring	202.02685606611553
them to Athos’s place. Once for all, Tréville had placed his stable at	176.68743865476478
D’Artagnan’s service.	309.51066487290683
Planchet proceeded toward the Rue du Colombier, and D’Artagnan toward	198.8458720405196
the Rue Férou. Athos was at home, emptying sadly a bottle of the famous	185.91137349672977
Spanish wine he had brought back with him from his journey into	346.0415371189034
Picardy. He made a sign for Grimaud to bring a glass for D’Artagnan,	263.3893139491043
and Grimaud obeyed as usual.	255.7782291995461
D’Artagnan related to Athos all that had passed at the church between	336.4444700495877
Porthos and the procurator’s wife, and how their comrade was probably	167.89403966653063
by that time in a fair way to be equipped.	287.19244436601673
“As for me,” replied Athos to this recital, “I am quite at my ease; it	324.6792421137642
will not be women that will defray the expense of my outfit.”	288.71440291739367
“Handsome, well-bred, noble lord as you are, my dear Athos, neither	180.14019374619176
princesses nor queens would be secure from your amorous solicitations.”	176.70787607227263
“How young this D’Artagnan is!” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders;	176.38237425606917
and he made a sign to Grimaud to bring another bottle.	268.69725753704444
At that moment Planchet put his head modestly in at the half-open door,	282.7755880478362
and told his master that the horses were ready.	347.8051760009556
“What horses?” asked Athos.	237.00450910721267
“Two horses that Monsieur de Tréville lends me at my pleasure, and with	212.86439624366707
which I am now going to take a ride to St. Germain.”	176.59617794534475
“Well, and what are you going to do at St. Germain?” then demanded	181.22021079903948
Athos.	199.18772378529349
Then D’Artagnan described the meeting which he had at the church, and	217.5564173451825
how he had found that lady who, with the seigneur in the black cloak	223.99463904592744
and with the scar near his temple, filled his mind constantly.	252.98817199125358
“That is to say, you are in love with this lady as you were with Madame	308.45268890003575
Bonacieux,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders contemptuously, as if	298.2800342331947
he pitied human weakness.	347.8553721457987
“I? not at all!” said D’Artagnan. “I am only curious to unravel the	357.10812696972323
mystery to which she is attached. I do not know why, but I imagine that	291.71273255340884
this woman, wholly unknown to me as she is, and wholly unknown to her	331.32667035110126
as I am, has an influence over my life.”	208.30785146872716
“Well, perhaps you are right,” said Athos. “I do not know a woman that	340.91388533625684
is worth the trouble of being sought for when she is once lost. Madame	303.46990703847143
Bonacieux is lost; so much the worse for her if she is found.”	295.834738025857
“No, Athos, no, you are mistaken,” said D’Artagnan; “I love my poor	233.90478955817366
Constance more than ever, and if I knew the place in which she is, were	240.84864227161768
it at the end of the world, I would go to free her from the hands of	312.1349181879101
her enemies; but I am ignorant. All my researches have been useless.	278.68551912573196
What is to be said? I must divert my attention!”	290.9030430306992
“Amuse yourself with Milady, my dear D’Artagnan; I wish you may with	315.22737233198876
all my heart, if that will amuse you.”	181.34300132351052
“Hear me, Athos,” said D’Artagnan. “Instead of shutting yourself up	285.945984897873
here as if you were under arrest, get on horseback and come and take a	304.89783937213383
ride with me to St. Germain.”	297.23400111127773
“My dear fellow,” said Athos, “I ride horses when I have any; when I	263.4189831516263
have none, I go afoot.”	224.9372298375061
“Well,” said D’Artagnan, smiling at the misanthropy of Athos, which	227.10100369409207
from any other person would have offended him, “I ride what I can get;	305.93276203322034
I am not so proud as you. So _au revoir_, dear Athos.”	272.0978034739593
“_Au revoir_,” said the Musketeer, making a sign to Grimaud to uncork	213.11507875132264
the bottle he had just brought.	236.1410468271013
D’Artagnan and Planchet mounted, and took the road to St. Germain.	229.86606221189876
All along the road, what Athos had said respecting Mme. Bonacieux	237.74452853382064
recurred to the mind of the young man. Although D’Artagnan was not of a	357.86163530669114
very sentimental character, the mercer’s pretty wife had made a real	274.67504455901644
impression upon his heart. As he said, he was ready to go to the end of	220.48842948160748
the world to seek her; but the world, being round, has many ends, so	260.1891802672983
that he did not know which way to turn. Meantime, he was going to try	191.4212444016304
to find out Milady. Milady had spoken to the man in the black cloak;	227.3418437884654
therefore she knew him. Now, in the opinion of D’Artagnan, it was	244.79866833242033
certainly the man in the black cloak who had carried off Mme. Bonacieux	194.77465514672105
the second time, as he had carried her off the first. D’Artagnan then	329.12163790013926
only half-lied, which is lying but little, when he said that by going	245.87481843968223
in search of Milady he at the same time went in search of Constance.	242.40790089614427
Thinking of all this, and from time to time giving a touch of the spur	236.24220505299954
to his horse, D’Artagnan completed his short journey, and arrived at	304.7768019522392
St. Germain. He had just passed by the pavilion in which ten years	173.36546230117133
later Louis XIV. was born. He rode up a very quiet street, looking to	213.11883492308868
the right and the left to see if he could catch any vestige of his	304.16915799174024
beautiful Englishwoman, when from the ground floor of a pretty house,	322.2678810299275
which, according to the fashion of the time, had no window toward the	187.51525445288505
street, he saw a face peep out with which he thought he was acquainted.	166.68092144323344
This person walked along the terrace, which was ornamented with	359.5483311916407
flowers. Planchet recognized him first.	265.87056188459144
“Eh, monsieur!” said he, addressing D’Artagnan, “don’t you remember	323.49724068028996
that face which is blinking yonder?”	363.79211396319744
“No,” said D’Artagnan, “and yet I am certain it is not the first time I	289.48785975420407
have seen that visage.”	177.5114114010864
“_Parbleu_, I believe it is not,” said Planchet. “Why, it is poor	301.2728151801096
Lubin, the lackey of the Comte de Wardes—he whom you took such good	319.34021619597183
care of a month ago at Calais, on the road to the governor’s country	333.94036737673173
house!”	259.4485497758948
“So it is!” said D’Artagnan; “I know him now. Do you think he would	232.69546785876005
recollect you?”	270.7944127207717
“My faith, monsieur, he was in such trouble that I doubt if he can have	245.25739426842222
retained a very clear recollection of me.”	360.5687240385736
“Well, go and talk with the boy,” said D’Artagnan, “and make out if you	341.05409579259674
can from his conversation whether his master is dead.”	228.06789713354271
Planchet dismounted and went straight up to Lubin, who did not at all	256.4278132112401
remember him, and the two lackeys began to chat with the best	197.2933526715152
understanding possible; while D’Artagnan turned the two horses into a	249.94737596400898
lane, went round the house, and came back to watch the conference from	220.81274602654884
behind a hedge of filberts.	303.95380152522023
At the end of an instant’s observation he heard the noise of a vehicle,	245.69891673370387
and saw Milady’s carriage stop opposite to him. He could not be	362.3413731362348
mistaken; Milady was in it. D’Artagnan leaned upon the neck of his	222.31121685901252
horse, in order that he might see without being seen.	207.50633292648166
Milady put her charming blond head out at the window, and gave her	333.64450661672026
orders to her maid.	347.8752561498286
The latter—a pretty girl of about twenty or twenty-two years, active	346.4658449957655
and lively, the true _soubrette_ of a great lady—jumped from the step	188.99826829296538
upon which, according to the custom of the time, she was seated, and	262.1534697359142
took her way toward the terrace upon which D’Artagnan had perceived	365.6571429339575
Lubin.	173.5365238026468
D’Artagnan followed the _soubrette_ with his eyes, and saw her go	261.5920438820907
toward the terrace; but it happened that someone in the house called	352.3789998330061
Lubin, so that Planchet remained alone, looking in all directions for	362.50057293115407
the road where D’Artagnan had disappeared.	355.37618979634755
The maid approached Planchet, whom she took for Lubin, and holding out	222.55660747609159
a little billet to him said, “For your master.”	296.8848958079446
“For my master?” replied Planchet, astonished.	318.37952418898004
“Yes, and important. Take it quickly.”	276.6782292760256
Thereupon she ran toward the carriage, which had turned round toward	168.90963096759754
the way it came, jumped upon the step, and the carriage drove off.	258.7393592388252
Planchet turned and returned the billet. Then, accustomed to passive	332.7650071497817
obedience, he jumped down from the terrace, ran toward the lane, and at	296.86562115869924
the end of twenty paces met D’Artagnan, who, having seen all, was	274.60156512105226
coming to him.	214.02179797664684
“For you, monsieur,” said Planchet, presenting the billet to the young	204.33921153140648
man.	247.8901630787949
“For me?” said D’Artagnan; “are you sure of that?”	357.4292626857219
“_Pardieu_, monsieur, I can’t be more sure. The _soubrette_ said, ‘For	204.41074532124097
your master.’ I have no other master but you; so—a pretty little lass,	330.73507138138064
my faith, is that _soubrette!_”	210.46344046557653
D’Artagnan opened the letter, and read these words:	261.18466723126437
“A person who takes more interest in you than she is willing to confess	348.1464499677689
wishes to know on what day it will suit you to walk in the forest?	260.78381435734286
Tomorrow, at the Hôtel Field of the Cloth of Gold, a lackey in black	344.3732024135975
and red will wait for your reply.”	189.7173347256558
“Oh!” said D’Artagnan, “this is rather warm; it appears that Milady and	231.0448470398005
I are anxious about the health of the same person. Well, Planchet, how	297.1235611938181
is the good Monsieur de Wardes? He is not dead, then?”	360.04991909370506
“No, monsieur, he is as well as a man can be with four sword wounds in	172.29351771146068
his body; for you, without question, inflicted four upon the dear	207.4145046034168
gentleman, and he is still very weak, having lost almost all his blood.	208.19351283258413
As I said, monsieur, Lubin did not know me, and told me our adventure	255.08129823224306
from one end to the other.”	193.80647646644462
“Well done, Planchet! you are the king of lackeys. Now jump onto your	215.003952450387
horse, and let us overtake the carriage.”	172.8365145306019
This did not take long. At the end of five minutes they perceived the	323.7508831256607
carriage drawn up by the roadside; a cavalier, richly dressed, was	228.32825596702386
close to the door.	350.602426108289
The conversation between Milady and the cavalier was so animated that	273.70523414271946
D’Artagnan stopped on the other side of the carriage without anyone but	265.3007195603961
the pretty _soubrette_ perceiving his presence.	170.87729081876978
The conversation took place in English—a language which D’Artagnan	294.62975622021673
could not understand; but by the accent the young man plainly saw that	312.86170045508686
the beautiful Englishwoman was in a great rage. She terminated it by an	232.01820258722233
action which left no doubt as to the nature of this conversation; this	308.17578249059704
was a blow with her fan, applied with such force that the little	307.8373886433527
feminine weapon flew into a thousand pieces.	260.72543804904547
The cavalier laughed aloud, which appeared to exasperate Milady still	252.52152428728812
more.	167.78065755889165
D’Artagnan thought this was the moment to interfere. He approached the	214.51834314691354
other door, and taking off his hat respectfully, said, “Madame, will	194.48312972258154
you permit me to offer you my services? It appears to me that this	291.4537277773994
cavalier has made you very angry. Speak one word, madame, and I take	270.9713344971951
upon myself to punish him for his want of courtesy.”	324.5963355896113
At the first word Milady turned, looking at the young man with	234.71954457909789
astonishment; and when he had finished, she said in very good French,	239.98646192616508
“Monsieur, I should with great confidence place myself under your	322.1729505331725
protection if the person with whom I quarrel were not my brother.”	308.7587415487196
“Ah, excuse me, then,” said D’Artagnan. “You must be aware that I was	274.6283591180964
ignorant of that, madame.”	247.4254098736335
“What is that stupid fellow troubling himself about?” cried the	298.68734667997035
cavalier whom Milady had designated as her brother, stooping down to	230.58174347164334
the height of the coach window. “Why does not he go about his	274.10007840772573
business?”	217.57377222879137
“Stupid fellow yourself!” said D’Artagnan, stooping in his turn on the	203.08190619950074
neck of his horse, and answering on his side through the carriage	194.836150364527
window. “I do not go on because it pleases me to stop here.”	274.03969072136
The cavalier addressed some words in English to his sister.	177.20690930856378
“I speak to you in French,” said D’Artagnan; “be kind enough, then, to	216.65086767065534
reply to me in the same language. You are Madame’s brother, I learn—be	202.55067972970713
it so; but fortunately you are not mine.”	339.85039244423194
It might be thought that Milady, timid as women are in general, would	222.84850926748922
have interposed in this commencement of mutual provocations in order to	272.82033759902583
prevent the quarrel from going too far; but on the contrary, she threw	347.34011353694103
herself back in her carriage, and called out coolly to the coachman,	258.06764463841733
“Go on—home!”	236.96285339797566
The pretty _soubrette_ cast an anxious glance at D’Artagnan, whose good	258.97817850935877
looks seemed to have made an impression on her.	233.91483100362728
The carriage went on, and left the two men facing each other; no	361.33026885763695
material obstacle separated them.	344.34661295818694
The cavalier made a movement as if to follow the carriage; but	334.34617844830063
D’Artagnan, whose anger, already excited, was much increased by	279.6647550581705
recognizing in him the Englishman of Amiens who had won his horse and	238.91224971624342
had been very near winning his diamond of Athos, caught at his bridle	190.6886801777903
and stopped him.	351.72436473986255
“Well, monsieur,” said he, “you appear to be more stupid than I am, for	250.7142539384452
you forget there is a little quarrel to arrange between us two.”	270.87454896668623
“Ah,” said the Englishman, “is it you, my master? It seems you must	207.91343706469416
always be playing some game or other.”	332.39093608635915
“Yes; and that reminds me that I have a revenge to take. We will see,	203.21427188067935
my dear monsieur, if you can handle a sword as skillfully as you can a	340.2937868472112
dice box.”	244.86987825517974
“You see plainly that I have no sword,” said the Englishman. “Do you	314.45089984132164
wish to play the braggart with an unarmed man?”	275.1230961259487
“I hope you have a sword at home; but at all events, I have two, and if	186.73110751473442
you like, I will throw with you for one of them.”	196.27266205596038
“Needless,” said the Englishman; “I am well furnished with such	176.74845765537705
playthings.”	297.9667429172546
“Very well, my worthy gentleman,” replied D’Artagnan, “pick out the	295.41332732770263
longest, and come and show it to me this evening.”	214.8932242451521
“Where, if you please?”	270.93559211036654
“Behind the Luxembourg; that’s a charming spot for such amusements as	348.1270775950072
the one I propose to you.”	174.93116580017667
“That will do; I will be there.”	199.9643010222069
“Your hour?”	220.45005643507267
“Six o’clock.”	178.62724270151716
“_A propos_, you have probably one or two friends?”	363.56911125615494
“I have three, who would be honored by joining in the sport with me.”	256.1612777008116
“Three? Marvelous! That falls out oddly! Three is just my number!”	180.90801622651264
“Now, then, who are you?” asked the Englishman.	361.7940774071633
“I am Monsieur d’Artagnan, a Gascon gentleman, serving in the king’s	196.62651343597932
Musketeers. And you?”	359.58875320597724
“I am Lord de Winter, Baron Sheffield.”	200.43762816776967
“Well, then, I am your servant, Monsieur Baron,” said D’Artagnan,	263.2631605418639
“though you have names rather difficult to recollect.” And touching his	210.2256381301473
horse with the spur, he cantered back to Paris. As he was accustomed to	188.28906321287596
do in all cases of any consequence, D’Artagnan went straight to the	251.29359274487027
residence of Athos.	272.05820822502375
He found Athos reclining upon a large sofa, where he was waiting, as he	274.96205806275447
said, for his outfit to come and find him. He related to Athos all that	305.3150216639233
had passed, except the letter to M. de Wardes.	304.4928226000645
Athos was delighted to find he was going to fight an Englishman. We	228.78556355358836
might say that was his dream.	197.30939973301642
They immediately sent their lackeys for Porthos and Aramis, and on	350.31328189223996
their arrival made them acquainted with the situation.	357.11048120728844
Porthos drew his sword from the scabbard, and made passes at the wall,	325.59512299591245
springing back from time to time, and making contortions like a dancer.	192.893349843298
Aramis, who was constantly at work at his poem, shut himself up in	201.24859230150793
Athos’s closet, and begged not to be disturbed before the moment of	331.1965049901446
drawing swords.	193.16825164719796
Athos, by signs, desired Grimaud to bring another bottle of wine.	199.8272871829426
D’Artagnan employed himself in arranging a little plan, of which we	271.33103476450856
shall hereafter see the execution, and which promised him some	355.32468045802204
agreeable adventure, as might be seen by the smiles which from time to	341.38169635026
time passed over his countenance, whose thoughtfulness they animated.	191.86379713208922
Chapter XXXI.	361.33780187455517
ENGLISH AND FRENCH	313.08335142745796
The hour having come, they went with their four lackeys to a spot	303.1174350101647
behind the Luxembourg given up to the feeding of goats. Athos threw a	333.9297837572534
piece of money to the goatkeeper to withdraw. The lackeys were ordered	235.96624343212096
to act as sentinels.	364.2770017600926
A silent party soon drew near to the same enclosure, entered, and	364.72070838666843
joined the Musketeers. Then, according to foreign custom, the	265.577735067128
presentations took place.	240.00347522572605
The Englishmen were all men of rank; consequently the odd names of	355.21430730334333
their adversaries were for them not only a matter of surprise, but of	304.62282065963393
annoyance.	207.29546685911527
“But after all,” said Lord de Winter, when the three friends had been	204.20995547217962
named, “we do not know who you are. We cannot fight with such names;	362.531220599708
they are names of shepherds.”	252.14541259243197
“Therefore your lordship may suppose they are only assumed names,” said	185.03433743187492
Athos.	325.32465036169503
“Which only gives us a greater desire to know the real ones,” replied	282.7866325094843
the Englishman.	215.98935653686544
“You played very willingly with us without knowing our names,” said	247.26469209438622
Athos, “by the same token that you won our horses.”	264.5656032653107
“That is true, but we then only risked our pistoles; this time we risk	215.21846469024348
our blood. One plays with anybody; but one fights only with equals.”	296.4608253102127
“And that is but just,” said Athos, and he took aside the one of the	249.2077410059517
four Englishmen with whom he was to fight, and communicated his name in	305.3291982799646
a low voice.	215.79931913039576
Porthos and Aramis did the same.	185.26286416438816
“Does that satisfy you?” said Athos to his adversary. “Do you find me	216.9627282242296
of sufficient rank to do me the honor of crossing swords with me?”	360.7451004126871
“Yes, monsieur,” said the Englishman, bowing.	246.03929208911734
“Well! now shall I tell you something?” added Athos, coolly.	240.02413955801626
“What?” replied the Englishman.	287.10415286248997
“Why, that is that you would have acted much more wisely if you had not	283.16091540127456
required me to make myself known.”	252.5421616239379
“Why so?”	343.666052089505
“Because I am believed to be dead, and have reasons for wishing nobody	279.3116653001094
to know I am living; so that I shall be obliged to kill you to prevent	324.33304727185487
my secret from roaming over the fields.”	180.16562946155207
The Englishman looked at Athos, believing that he jested, but Athos did	350.17789035627493
not jest the least in the world.	250.7301084187001
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, addressing at the same time his companions and	241.5962561926746
their adversaries, “are we ready?”	269.0404779971923
“Yes!” answered the Englishmen and the Frenchmen, as with one voice.	230.4462457366746
“On guard, then!” cried Athos.	196.44078664591882
Immediately eight swords glittered in the rays of the setting sun, and	258.14616924964844
the combat began with an animosity very natural between men twice	338.25304350684814
enemies.	286.0786555793811
Athos fenced with as much calmness and method as if he had been	323.35831034090205
practicing in a fencing school.	215.7377895156921
Porthos, abated, no doubt, of his too-great confidence by his adventure	353.53758950381643
of Chantilly, played with skill and prudence. Aramis, who had the third	214.21155844480666
canto of his poem to finish, behaved like a man in haste.	336.52283477750984
Athos killed his adversary first. He hit him but once, but as he had	209.86661493382627
foretold, that hit was a mortal one; the sword pierced his heart.	303.6067917034182
Second, Porthos stretched his upon the grass with a wound through his	339.1056044131266
thigh, As the Englishman, without making any further resistance, then	351.4939815386032
surrendered his sword, Porthos took him up in his arms and bore him to	328.03718676738094
his carriage.	269.42346500062075
Aramis pushed his so vigorously that after going back fifty paces, the	298.6806216490087
man ended by fairly taking to his heels, and disappeared amid the	279.87692944348805
hooting of the lackeys.	259.97808118921284
As to D’Artagnan, he fought purely and simply on the defensive; and	292.44097177058217
when he saw his adversary pretty well fatigued, with a vigorous side	362.03448539745625
thrust sent his sword flying. The baron, finding himself disarmed, took	175.95868983182345
two or three steps back, but in this movement his foot slipped and he	244.41709686022244
fell backward.	319.9996442617031
D’Artagnan was over him at a bound, and said to the Englishman,	296.83731769966477
pointing his sword to his throat, “I could kill you, my Lord, you are	213.04682135308224
completely in my hands; but I spare your life for the sake of your	280.3212441882867
sister.”	214.84794301319025
D’Artagnan was at the height of joy; he had realized the plan he had	279.7456577653126
imagined beforehand, whose picturing had produced the smiles we noted	218.5064338021963
upon his face.	288.60579778576243
The Englishman, delighted at having to do with a gentleman of such a	255.93128253168004
kind disposition, pressed D’Artagnan in his arms, and paid a thousand	244.7089432718086
compliments to the three Musketeers, and as Porthos’s adversary was	215.81235159169879
already installed in the carriage, and as Aramis’s had taken to his	199.9458798099011
heels, they had nothing to think about but the dead.	176.657557165445
As Porthos and Aramis were undressing him, in the hope of finding his	253.84493915360247
wound not mortal, a large purse dropped from his clothes. D’Artagnan	316.4675138653919
picked it up and offered it to Lord de Winter.	245.834608282045
“What the devil would you have me do with that?” said the Englishman.	360.49537394639844
“You can restore it to his family,” said D’Artagnan.	196.50810830616211
“His family will care much about such a trifle as that! His family will	298.91226387030235
inherit fifteen thousand louis a year from him. Keep the purse for your	177.7991896820714
lackeys.”	305.5438817715112
D’Artagnan put the purse into his pocket.	355.278355016682
“And now, my young friend, for you will permit me, I hope, to give you	354.36257765707694
that name,” said Lord de Winter, “on this very evening, if agreeable to	255.40347753040578
you, I will present you to my sister, Milady Clarik, for I am desirous	291.7267891034284
that she should take you into her good graces; and as she is not in bad	182.9715098263976
odor at court, she may perhaps on some future day speak a word that	200.30701594093358
will not prove useless to you.”	326.1133798000615
D’Artagnan blushed with pleasure, and bowed a sign of assent.	337.5741052235471
At this time Athos came up to D’Artagnan.	228.13041460316808
“What do you mean to do with that purse?” whispered he.	310.3115578057881
“Why, I meant to pass it over to you, my dear Athos.”	290.06097290744924
“Me! why to me?”	176.94211787413008
“Why, you killed him! They are the spoils of victory.”	280.7165656432535
“I, the heir of an enemy!” said Athos; “for whom, then, do you take	201.22889598767756
me?”	218.85174349600584
“It is the custom in war,” said D’Artagnan, “why should it not be the	291.1445385180246
custom in a duel?”	271.0380163294527
“Even on the field of battle, I have never done that.”	177.48967657139426
Porthos shrugged his shoulders; Aramis by a movement of his lips	307.5056097211496
endorsed Athos.	302.64749549433185
“Then,” said D’Artagnan, “let us give the money to the lackeys, as Lord	169.78675692339266
de Winter desired us to do.”	335.8973657376308
“Yes,” said Athos; “let us give the money to the lackeys—not to our	190.9936041464559
lackeys, but to the lackeys of the Englishmen.”	304.23711070980585
Athos took the purse, and threw it into the hand of the coachman. “For	336.02171311397524
you and your comrades.”	286.42614699145065
This greatness of spirit in a man who was quite destitute struck even	172.71231702055678
Porthos; and this French generosity, repeated by Lord de Winter and his	196.7087910870073
friend, was highly applauded, except by MM. Grimaud, Bazin, Mousqueton	350.62582587806025
and Planchet.	277.35252013359866
Lord de Winter, on quitting D’Artagnan, gave him his sister’s address.	203.46638825551676
She lived in the Place Royale—then the fashionable quarter—at Number 6,	197.2500023309821
and he undertook to call and take D’Artagnan with him in order to	183.08114124468594
introduce him. D’Artagnan appointed eight o’clock at Athos’s residence.	171.5746634975
This introduction to Milady Clarik occupied the head of our Gascon	325.36112507354306
greatly. He remembered in what a strange manner this woman had hitherto	174.13028155496667
been mixed up in his destiny. According to his conviction, she was some	293.60167417278
creature of the cardinal, and yet he felt himself invincibly drawn	288.49516052671436
toward her by one of those sentiments for which we cannot account. His	332.099747355149
only fear was that Milady would recognize in him the man of Meung and	182.5434447344674
of Dover. Then she knew that he was one of the friends of M. de	310.8200062836674
Tréville, and consequently, that he belonged body and soul to the king;	231.0757888815454
which would make him lose a part of his advantage, since when known to	190.80082417420252
Milady as he knew her, he played only an equal game with her. As to the	200.30772432499734
commencement of an intrigue between her and M. de Wardes, our	278.74433584898793
presumptuous hero gave but little heed to that, although the marquis	226.25932599107068
was young, handsome, rich, and high in the cardinal’s favor. It is not	305.1593218598762
for nothing we are but twenty years old, above all if we were born at	349.7764104905306
Tarbes.	179.4981869851273
D’Artagnan began by making his most splendid toilet, then returned to	244.4808915912073
Athos’s, and according to custom, related everything to him. Athos	167.10875197920794
listened to his projects, then shook his head, and recommended prudence	309.81731594855324
to him with a shade of bitterness.	189.4345579060052
“What!” said he, “you have just lost one woman, whom you call good,	175.71300579820797
charming, perfect; and here you are, running headlong after another.”	291.4176360208104
D’Artagnan felt the truth of this reproach.	301.2040265136851
“I loved Madame Bonacieux with my heart, while I only love Milady with	291.64776318476294
my head,” said he. “In getting introduced to her, my principal object	241.7117875839452
is to ascertain what part she plays at court.”	350.97390127554
“The part she plays, _pardieu!_ It is not difficult to divine that,	234.27429459482317
after all you have told me. She is some emissary of the cardinal; a	321.7786780926242
woman who will draw you into a snare in which you will leave your	353.60893846349234
head.”	227.2180127719945
“The devil! my dear Athos, you view things on the dark side, methinks.”	340.4856474935725
“My dear fellow, I mistrust women. Can it be otherwise? I bought my	183.78623449146198
experience dearly—particularly fair women. Milady is fair, you say?”	246.75132670503828
“She has the most beautiful light hair imaginable!”	234.09690518486514
“Ah, my poor D’Artagnan!” said Athos.	180.3334463181544
“Listen to me! I want to be enlightened on a subject; then, when I	224.5074228594043
shall have learned what I desire to know, I will withdraw.”	307.5017758980103
“Be enlightened!” said Athos, phlegmatically.	300.5122850472781
Lord de Winter arrived at the appointed time; but Athos, being warned	300.51643823559516
of his coming, went into the other chamber. He therefore found	170.07934273942868
D’Artagnan alone, and as it was nearly eight o’clock he took the young	218.3311970672729
man with him.	211.3155526350509
An elegant carriage waited below, and as it was drawn by two excellent	291.5489148948298
horses, they were soon at the Place Royale.	169.40995731193522
Milady Clarik received D’Artagnan ceremoniously. Her hôtel was	184.30291914714036
remarkably sumptuous, and while the most part of the English had quit,	206.3221183332597
or were about to quit, France on account of the war, Milady had just	173.2183470955961
been laying out much money upon her residence; which proved that the	312.90427853599147
general measure which drove the English from France did not affect her.	180.9895055642591
“You see,” said Lord de Winter, presenting D’Artagnan to his sister, “a	313.7181836534293
young gentleman who has held my life in his hands, and who has not	354.02671211449
abused his advantage, although we have been twice enemies, although it	270.00130229962315
was I who insulted him, and although I am an Englishman. Thank him,	335.85101777156194
then, madame, if you have any affection for me.”	324.3851276911974
Milady frowned slightly; a scarcely visible cloud passed over her brow,	293.67794590751936
and so peculiar a smile appeared upon her lips that the young man, who	233.04729980151706
saw and observed this triple shade, almost shuddered at it.	253.03986573443967
The brother did not perceive this; he had turned round to play with	312.71321034217647
Milady’s favorite monkey, which had pulled him by the doublet.	227.37123359188124
“You are welcome, monsieur,” said Milady, in a voice whose singular	252.084591048986
sweetness contrasted with the symptoms of ill-humor which D’Artagnan	365.2367413174757
had just remarked; “you have today acquired eternal rights to my	293.80481403672815
gratitude.”	363.46616261132453
The Englishman then turned round and described the combat without	178.93522620075115
omitting a single detail. Milady listened with the greatest attention,	273.9493114051763
and yet it was easily to be perceived, whatever effort she made to	264.5192752555925
conceal her impressions, that this recital was not agreeable to her.	364.940145492046
The blood rose to her head, and her little foot worked with impatience	238.8501256242705
beneath her robe.	266.7151439552998
Lord de Winter perceived nothing of this. When he had finished, he went	179.44657256842444
to a table upon which was a salver with Spanish wine and glasses. He	176.29480146346373
filled two glasses, and by a sign invited D’Artagnan to drink.	275.3367535466051
D’Artagnan knew it was considered disobliging by an Englishman to	226.17423183393478
refuse to pledge him. He therefore drew near to the table and took the	315.0889703025348
second glass. He did not, however, lose sight of Milady, and in a	294.92067143445536
mirror he perceived the change that came over her face. Now that she	287.2121798306357
believed herself to be no longer observed, a sentiment resembling	237.59173930953102
ferocity animated her countenance. She bit her handkerchief with her	286.3758781499276
beautiful teeth.	221.9445138615527
That pretty little _soubrette_ whom D’Artagnan had already observed	301.0540910942974
then came in. She spoke some words to Lord de Winter in English, who	259.3802206395424
thereupon requested D’Artagnan’s permission to retire, excusing himself	176.0284394847703
on account of the urgency of the business that had called him away, and	219.66742695482495
charging his sister to obtain his pardon.	271.2531683854659
D’Artagnan exchanged a shake of the hand with Lord de Winter, and then	318.18164924361304
returned to Milady. Her countenance, with surprising mobility, had	352.45048561512203
recovered its gracious expression; but some little red spots on her	309.5224816319536
handkerchief indicated that she had bitten her lips till the blood	287.9482773873807
came. Those lips were magnificent; they might be said to be of coral.	323.80970222578867
The conversation took a cheerful turn. Milady appeared to have entirely	302.53524002972995
recovered. She told D’Artagnan that Lord de Winter was her	171.64307622591153
brother-in-law, and not her brother. She had married a younger brother	176.17982198369262
of the family, who had left her a widow with one child. This child was	222.80858926569024
the only heir to Lord de Winter, if Lord de Winter did not marry. All	193.0748273146194
this showed D’Artagnan that there was a veil which concealed something;	354.67764017222964
but he could not yet see under this veil.	255.86322561894423
In addition to this, after a half hour’s conversation D’Artagnan was	353.41816679623906
convinced that Milady was his compatriot; she spoke French with an	256.6245960412576
elegance and a purity that left no doubt on that head.	321.1372247687727
D’Artagnan was profuse in gallant speeches and protestations of	311.51156899896046
devotion. To all the simple things which escaped our Gascon, Milady	263.83860020800495
replied with a smile of kindness. The hour came for him to retire.	356.71510975113966
D’Artagnan took leave of Milady, and left the saloon the happiest of	171.17321023414746
men.	197.17962369869673
On the staircase he met the pretty _soubrette_, who brushed gently	183.0162923787979
against him as she passed, and then, blushing to the eyes, asked his	299.1311515677571
pardon for having touched him in a voice so sweet that the pardon was	238.63024143616224
granted instantly.	351.187477496004
D’Artagnan came again on the morrow, and was still better received than	322.53861713780725
on the evening before. Lord de Winter was not at home; and it was	285.4727791720355
Milady who this time did all the honors of the evening. She appeared to	280.024471769891
take a great interest in him, asked him whence he came, who were his	337.2851793100342
friends, and whether he had not sometimes thought of attaching himself	343.16378289109156
to the cardinal.	220.8256173363024
D’Artagnan, who, as we have said, was exceedingly prudent for a young	337.7813275930644
man of twenty, then remembered his suspicions regarding Milady. He	331.9176514750973
launched into a eulogy of his Eminence, and said that he should not	191.19967816521915
have failed to enter into the Guards of the cardinal instead of the	330.98563526553903
king’s Guards if he had happened to know M. de Cavois instead of M. de	276.63478968077965
Tréville.	319.35298168657965
Milady changed the conversation without any appearance of affectation,	343.66140022281974
and asked D’Artagnan in the most careless manner possible if he had	293.0773488263497
ever been in England.	302.3715919981544
D’Artagnan replied that he had been sent thither by M. de Tréville to	290.22544137023544
treat for a supply of horses, and that he had brought back four as	361.4356628103541
specimens.	333.087391345702
Milady in the course of the conversation twice or thrice bit her lips;	246.39020192063953
she had to deal with a Gascon who played close.	301.5128326727778
At the same hour as on the preceding evening, D’Artagnan retired. In	297.13442166511993
the corridor he again met the pretty Kitty; that was the name of the	246.76404616648443
_soubrette_. She looked at him with an expression of kindness which it	186.6124984852947
was impossible to mistake; but D’Artagnan was so preoccupied by the	335.6726997361631
mistress that he noticed absolutely nothing but her.	258.16127322795006
D’Artagnan came again on the morrow and the day after that, and each	327.61248821269686
day Milady gave him a more gracious reception.	342.21781098415204
Every evening, either in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the	182.2182205149173
stairs, he met the pretty _soubrette_. But, as we have said, D’Artagnan	280.2322575150207
paid no attention to this persistence of poor Kitty.	247.15811794968081
Chapter XXXII.	365.0178665973136
A PROCURATOR’S DINNER	176.2491985803293
However brilliant had been the part played by Porthos in the duel, it	200.55472663201667
had not made him forget the dinner of the procurator’s wife.	342.649850687322
On the morrow he received the last touches of Mousqueton’s brush for an	213.10906197763268
hour, and took his way toward the Rue aux Ours with the steps of a man	282.6307857960328
who was doubly in favor with fortune.	273.3983450456832
His heart beat, but not like D’Artagnan’s with a young and impatient	232.76872070721038
love. No; a more material interest stirred his blood. He was about at	232.1445453766138
last to pass that mysterious threshold, to climb those unknown stairs	286.3972993794655
by which, one by one, the old crowns of M. Coquenard had ascended. He	221.2408988133074
was about to see in reality a certain coffer of which he had twenty	351.57174755808285
times beheld the image in his dreams—a coffer long and deep, locked,	267.3002853850751
bolted, fastened in the wall; a coffer of which he had so often heard,	322.1661568548666
and which the hands—a little wrinkled, it is true, but still not	201.6855858599564
without elegance—of the procurator’s wife were about to open to his	239.63390287617148
admiring looks.	276.2238066086176
And then he—a wanderer on the earth, a man without fortune, a man	235.1596488761091
without family, a soldier accustomed to inns, cabarets, taverns, and	210.15639023398518
restaurants, a lover of wine forced to depend upon chance treats—was	326.5739179631388
about to partake of family meals, to enjoy the pleasures of a	194.0984836877831
comfortable establishment, and to give himself up to those little	246.1063612922503
attentions which “the harder one is, the more they please,” as old	312.9317283167835
soldiers say.	276.219647619573
To come in the capacity of a cousin, and seat himself every day at a	314.8150824225378
good table; to smooth the yellow, wrinkled brow of the old procurator;	247.3696180966121
to pluck the clerks a little by teaching them _bassette_, _passe-dix_,	266.86684740734097
and _lansquenet_, in their utmost nicety, and winning from them, by way	326.9877443571368
of fee for the lesson he would give them in an hour, their savings of a	178.27263031032913
month—all this was enormously delightful to Porthos.	171.6263215833018
The Musketeer could not forget the evil reports which then prevailed,	242.3314697071715
and which indeed have survived them, of the procurators of the	215.6936569831041
period—meanness, stinginess, fasts; but as, after all, excepting some	336.9360292806365
few acts of economy which Porthos had always found very unseasonable,	224.89910710526777
the procurator’s wife had been tolerably liberal—that is, be it	206.12145221062565
understood, for a procurator’s wife—he hoped to see a household of a	311.2249869355826
highly comfortable kind.	356.7742032973999
And yet, at the very door the Musketeer began to entertain some doubts.	360.2414210140329
The approach was not such as to prepossess people—an ill-smelling, dark	180.85814478500626
passage, a staircase half-lighted by bars through which stole a glimmer	294.0113639832066
from a neighboring yard; on the first floor a low door studded with	350.38705035460055
enormous nails, like the principal gate of the Grand Châtelet.	263.90851077707197
Porthos knocked with his hand. A tall, pale clerk, his face shaded by a	360.97529278004424
forest of virgin hair, opened the door, and bowed with the air of a man	278.96137227443273
forced at once to respect in another lofty stature, which indicated	291.18519917805133
strength, the military dress, which indicated rank, and a ruddy	228.5084542542466
countenance, which indicated familiarity with good living.	205.5773926411915
A shorter clerk came behind the first, a taller clerk behind the	252.93082068154223
second, a stripling of a dozen years rising behind the third. In all,	174.57198864901534
three clerks and a half, which, for the time, argued a very extensive	259.85864239040785
clientage.	334.9227857973658
Although the Musketeer was not expected before one o’clock, the	311.805413455048
procurator’s wife had been on the watch ever since midday, reckoning	239.6737658335445
that the heart, or perhaps the stomach, of her lover would bring him	223.70837135170393
before his time.	325.89671114615203
Mme. Coquenard therefore entered the office from the house at the same	323.3151051973545
moment her guest entered from the stairs, and the appearance of the	188.95175178171843
worthy lady relieved him from an awkward embarrassment. The clerks	178.95385601644975
surveyed him with great curiosity, and he, not knowing well what to say	186.09120270037317
to this ascending and descending scale, remained tongue-tied.	324.96582136445386
“It is my cousin!” cried the procurator’s wife. “Come in, come in,	320.27857668256695
Monsieur Porthos!”	318.98649941345707
The name of Porthos produced its effect upon the clerks, who began to	261.6150566038196
laugh; but Porthos turned sharply round, and every countenance quickly	275.6397414253003
recovered its gravity.	230.08858575653855
They reached the office of the procurator after having passed through	236.88755257610708
the antechamber in which the clerks were, and the study in which they	235.33165584390662
ought to have been. This last apartment was a sort of dark room,	253.7823285926035
littered with papers. On quitting the study they left the kitchen on	321.9860812385607
the right, and entered the reception room.	212.5936279173541
All these rooms, which communicated with one another, did not inspire	199.91266183538266
Porthos favorably. Words might be heard at a distance through all these	313.91643210351435
open doors. Then, while passing, he had cast a rapid, investigating	200.02997381500293
glance into the kitchen; and he was obliged to confess to himself, to	307.4843795135756
the shame of the procurator’s wife and his own regret, that he did not	349.08214966972173
see that fire, that animation, that bustle, which when a good repast is	185.9061838898263
on foot prevails generally in that sanctuary of good living.	208.70789371728316
The procurator had without doubt been warned of his visit, as he	274.7329987541257
expressed no surprise at the sight of Porthos, who advanced toward him	201.51258459319223
with a sufficiently easy air, and saluted him courteously.	230.32737231147848
“We are cousins, it appears, Monsieur Porthos?” said the procurator,	344.83669197425365
rising, yet supporting his weight upon the arms of his cane chair.	201.3127070105009
The old man, wrapped in a large black doublet, in which the whole of	235.68995723953935
his slender body was concealed, was brisk and dry. His little gray eyes	331.79713749707594
shone like carbuncles, and appeared, with his grinning mouth, to be the	216.42542331381156
only part of his face in which life survived. Unfortunately the legs	364.2407596133501
began to refuse their service to this bony machine. During the last	200.54937296760113
five or six months that this weakness had been felt, the worthy	230.9057959420935
procurator had nearly become the slave of his wife.	238.3567286340408
The cousin was received with resignation, that was all. M. Coquenard,	327.1717077094188
firm upon his legs, would have declined all relationship with M.	191.95056332751017
Porthos.	237.1450491877257
“Yes, monsieur, we are cousins,” said Porthos, without being	247.13174111352922
disconcerted, as he had never reckoned upon being received	291.00405467459643
enthusiastically by the husband.	269.30940776227044
“By the female side, I believe?” said the procurator, maliciously.	365.3132010830168
Porthos did not feel the ridicule of this, and took it for a piece of	353.09900542563275
simplicity, at which he laughed in his large mustache. Mme. Coquenard,	231.31113237231546
who knew that a simple-minded procurator was a very rare variety in the	184.69122474618666
species, smiled a little, and colored a great deal.	291.52376181309313
M. Coquenard had, since the arrival of Porthos, frequently cast his	248.86680204839317
eyes with great uneasiness upon a large chest placed in front of his	221.47786034001854
oak desk. Porthos comprehended that this chest, although it did not	252.05812556262214
correspond in shape with that which he had seen in his dreams, must be	249.13954230008423
the blessed coffer, and he congratulated himself that the reality was	236.88225945891122
several feet higher than the dream.	198.99714014342706
M. Coquenard did not carry his genealogical investigations any further;	265.48483074918994
but withdrawing his anxious look from the chest and fixing it upon	221.63785067981416
Porthos, he contented himself with saying, “Monsieur our cousin will do	236.00225353783435
us the favor of dining with us once before his departure for the	266.6718578962162
campaign, will he not, Madame Coquenard?”	348.984563992338
This time Porthos received the blow right in his stomach, and felt it.	213.67336635987556
It appeared likewise that Mme. Coquenard was not less affected by it on	360.12990447851513
her part, for she added, “My cousin will not return if he finds that we	246.98122471858747
do not treat him kindly; but otherwise he has so little time to pass in	321.43289251877565
Paris, and consequently to spare to us, that we must entreat him to	202.5500104252244
give us every instant he can call his own previous to his departure.”	358.6370821864585
“Oh, my legs, my poor legs! where are you?” murmured Coquenard, and he	225.16245596602002
tried to smile.	274.22336785868185
This succor, which came to Porthos at the moment in which he was	275.28501304179906
attacked in his gastronomic hopes, inspired much gratitude in the	354.05403594874997
Musketeer toward the procurator’s wife.	257.3591555110767
The hour of dinner soon arrived. They passed into the eating room—a	229.462638225634
large dark room situated opposite the kitchen.	286.1013487272106
The clerks, who, as it appeared, had smelled unusual perfumes in the	321.10260384538964
house, were of military punctuality, and held their stools in hand	168.82202989037023
quite ready to sit down. Their jaws moved preliminarily with fearful	257.9309827483144
threatenings.	357.13991651281617
“Indeed!” thought Porthos, casting a glance at the three hungry	225.59637211450953
clerks—for the errand boy, as might be expected, was not admitted to	191.71695426929102
the honors of the magisterial table, “in my cousin’s place, I would not	298.78736884187026
keep such gourmands! They look like shipwrecked sailors who have not	214.8932087067408
eaten for six weeks.”	219.86535725454476
M. Coquenard entered, pushed along upon his armchair with casters by	241.43606049047398
Mme. Coquenard, whom Porthos assisted in rolling her husband up to the	173.64020026792704
table. He had scarcely entered when he began to agitate his nose and	256.1727749324494
his jaws after the example of his clerks.	358.34256139885554
“Oh, oh!” said he; “here is a soup which is rather inviting.”	305.5671932090596
“What the devil can they smell so extraordinary in this soup?” said	353.71192208478044
Porthos, at the sight of a pale liquid, abundant but entirely free from	238.84229982241453
meat, on the surface of which a few crusts swam about as rare as the	175.76931801377526
islands of an archipelago.	338.8593636946687
Mme. Coquenard smiled, and upon a sign from her everyone eagerly took	328.05230370726474
his seat.	348.40552053054785
M. Coquenard was served first, then Porthos. Afterward Mme. Coquenard	168.64335607853653
filled her own plate, and distributed the crusts without soup to the	326.78510124011666
impatient clerks. At this moment the door of the dining room unclosed	291.3821249532373
with a creak, and Porthos perceived through the half-open flap the	209.10715281832998
little clerk who, not being allowed to take part in the feast, ate his	296.48414422568106
dry bread in the passage with the double odor of the dining room and	236.72974112718947
kitchen.	167.86586700191796
After the soup the maid brought a boiled fowl—a piece of magnificence	231.6493215853206
which caused the eyes of the diners to dilate in such a manner that	313.87786927098017
they seemed ready to burst.	283.99121687581146
“One may see that you love your family, Madame Coquenard,” said the	235.0585709137116
procurator, with a smile that was almost tragic. “You are certainly	216.89461182353295
treating your cousin very handsomely!”	208.49503353634037
The poor fowl was thin, and covered with one of those thick, bristly	176.67721316389603
skins through which the teeth cannot penetrate with all their efforts.	355.23630261478945
The fowl must have been sought for a long time on the perch, to which	184.8320254368285
it had retired to die of old age.	348.5467308000808
“The devil!” thought Porthos, “this is poor work. I respect old age,	324.7137869310298
but I don’t much like it boiled or roasted.”	222.1982927326332
And he looked round to see if anybody partook of his opinion; but on	259.2452269768831
the contrary, he saw nothing but eager eyes which were devouring, in	323.7617708424608
anticipation, that sublime fowl which was the object of his contempt.	303.12571313895813
Mme. Coquenard drew the dish toward her, skillfully detached the two	230.93106733817217
great black feet, which she placed upon her husband’s plate, cut off	274.5943452699436
the neck, which with the head she put on one side for herself, raised	304.38576947353727
the wing for Porthos, and then returned the bird otherwise intact to	234.7211581339311
the servant who had brought it in, who disappeared with it before the	303.95401901380365
Musketeer had time to examine the variations which disappointment	352.69611408634574
produces upon faces, according to the characters and temperaments of	205.53190304970204
those who experience it.	238.81400733216356
In the place of the fowl a dish of haricot beans made its appearance—an	339.61250483083836
enormous dish in which some bones of mutton that at first sight one	269.40179781431726
might have believed to have some meat on them pretended to show	354.7593025643682
themselves.	197.08710305280638
But the clerks were not the dupes of this deceit, and their lugubrious	191.35726904723305
looks settled down into resigned countenances.	231.58562710984697
Mme. Coquenard distributed this dish to the young men with the	305.67150608450663
moderation of a good housewife.	261.59842910247187
The time for wine came. M. Coquenard poured from a very small stone	280.74740729473575
bottle the third of a glass for each of the young men, served himself	365.15885475137054
in about the same proportion, and passed the bottle to Porthos and Mme.	168.69467440887894
Coquenard.	193.53621766925235
The young men filled up their third of a glass with water; then, when	337.6577797756884
they had drunk half the glass, they filled it up again, and continued	190.6821935622237
to do so. This brought them, by the end of the repast, to swallowing a	204.831219370427
drink which from the color of the ruby had passed to that of a pale	253.68941497914307
topaz.	362.57240234653153
Porthos ate his wing of the fowl timidly, and shuddered when he felt	351.65579817714547
the knee of the procurator’s wife under the table, as it came in search	318.5879252334039
of his. He also drank half a glass of this sparingly served wine, and	273.3111064695306
found it to be nothing but that horrible Montreuil—the terror of all	356.2375550788616
expert palates.	195.48667616399487
M. Coquenard saw him swallowing this wine undiluted, and sighed deeply.	281.21234177663
“Will you eat any of these beans, Cousin Porthos?” said Mme. Coquenard,	298.11748705028447
in that tone which says, “Take my advice, don’t touch them.”	365.9170632322945
“Devil take me if I taste one of them!” murmured Porthos to himself,	294.5381812005746
and then said aloud, “Thank you, my cousin, I am no longer hungry.”	278.1462605734941
There was silence. Porthos could hardly keep his countenance.	200.81933278651684
The procurator repeated several times, “Ah, Madame Coquenard! Accept my	176.25999121615394
compliments; your dinner has been a real feast. Lord, how I have	348.27535510297207
eaten!”	225.97194810340628
M. Coquenard had eaten his soup, the black feet of the fowl, and the	236.6541641683371
only mutton bone on which there was the least appearance of meat.	197.81448750328644
Porthos fancied they were mystifying him, and began to curl his	291.416286946842
mustache and knit his eyebrows; but the knee of Mme. Coquenard gently	317.5439035194306
advised him to be patient.	333.97448198272446
This silence and this interruption in serving, which were	266.219654635001
unintelligible to Porthos, had, on the contrary, a terrible meaning for	201.01318124623964
the clerks. Upon a look from the procurator, accompanied by a smile	192.56955716982873
from Mme. Coquenard, they arose slowly from the table, folded their	355.5688596184044
napkins more slowly still, bowed, and retired.	239.38806992739322
“Go, young men! go and promote digestion by working,” said the	325.80662154635456
procurator, gravely.	352.9464722446825
The clerks gone, Mme. Coquenard rose and took from a buffet a piece of	302.7023389455701
cheese, some preserved quinces, and a cake which she had herself made	282.414544809666
of almonds and honey.	280.46310279942713
M. Coquenard knit his eyebrows because there were too many good things.	249.20027520860984
Porthos bit his lips because he saw not the wherewithal to dine. He	183.2941934707881
looked to see if the dish of beans was still there; the dish of beans	229.71232453695507
had disappeared.	225.00650227403224
“A positive feast!” cried M. Coquenard, turning about in his chair, “a	269.4604759909156
real feast, _epulœ epulorum_. Lucullus dines with Lucullus.”	220.44022966107588
Porthos looked at the bottle, which was near him, and hoped that with	335.07538254148983
wine, bread, and cheese, he might make a dinner; but wine was wanting,	252.809691249879
the bottle was empty. M. and Mme. Coquenard did not seem to observe it.	358.14307129823953
“This is fine!” said Porthos to himself; “I am prettily caught!”	245.1850622486918
He passed his tongue over a spoonful of preserves, and stuck his teeth	253.21484400209883
into the sticky pastry of Mme. Coquenard.	248.11981217247876
“Now,” said he, “the sacrifice is consummated! Ah! if I had not the	284.6133423699615
hope of peeping with Madame Coquenard into her husband’s chest!”	338.78697978020926
M. Coquenard, after the luxuries of such a repast, which he called an	263.24410612054737
excess, felt the want of a siesta. Porthos began to hope that the thing	179.62116476371196
would take place at the present sitting, and in that same locality; but	231.18781931811486
the procurator would listen to nothing, he would be taken to his room,	343.03128173532826
and was not satisfied till he was close to his chest, upon the edge of	318.595489656575
which, for still greater precaution, he placed his feet.	213.55459636086857
The procurator’s wife took Porthos into an adjoining room, and they	327.36974708413777
began to lay the basis of a reconciliation.	245.4718911280508
“You can come and dine three times a week,” said Mme. Coquenard.	213.8259855847911
“Thanks, madame!” said Porthos, “but I don’t like to abuse your	279.2311980275253
kindness; besides, I must think of my outfit!”	195.68829694392974
“That’s true,” said the procurator’s wife, groaning, “that unfortunate	292.856715801454
outfit!”	228.80010617364655
“Alas, yes,” said Porthos, “it is so.”	320.02770719985904
“But of what, then, does the equipment of your company consist,	263.9944268772591
Monsieur Porthos?”	273.8821159700663
“Oh, of many things!” said Porthos. “The Musketeers are, as you know,	347.8447539413895
picked soldiers, and they require many things useless to the Guardsmen	223.6342101541612
or the Swiss.”	316.61022898291344
“But yet, detail them to me.”	322.516781163397
“Why, they may amount to—“, said Porthos, who preferred discussing the	169.68735775500343
total to taking them one by one.	282.15181195236096
The procurator’s wife waited tremblingly.	308.433654437903
“To how much?” said she. “I hope it does not exceed—” She stopped;	188.73002556062954
speech failed her.	336.0469226168582
“Oh, no,” said Porthos, “it does not exceed two thousand five hundred	357.18522647499844
livres! I even think that with economy I could manage it with two	238.62621144634426
thousand livres.”	198.3823225097865
“Good God!” cried she, “two thousand livres! Why, that is a fortune!”	320.62343437199877
Porthos made a most significant grimace; Mme. Coquenard understood it.	205.08509509423658
“I wished to know the detail,” said she, “because, having many	210.69322690397698
relatives in business, I was almost sure of obtaining things at a	233.8089720846067
hundred per cent less than you would pay yourself.”	225.58363960141423
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “that is what you meant to say!”	186.72572565326945
“Yes, dear Monsieur Porthos. Thus, for instance, don’t you in the first	309.636216134081
place want a horse?”	234.60046497408098
“Yes, a horse.”	187.54064377008444
“Well, then! I can just suit you.”	223.0497150836791
“Ah!” said Porthos, brightening, “that’s well as regards my horse; but	312.8954806728318
I must have the appointments complete, as they include objects which a	365.7258491519999
Musketeer alone can purchase, and which will not amount, besides, to	303.6898404514569
more than three hundred livres.”	185.46793674203482
“Three hundred livres? Then put down three hundred livres,” said the	321.19679018017416
procurator’s wife, with a sigh.	347.4533760883197
Porthos smiled. It may be remembered that he had the saddle which came	305.88282849235014
from Buckingham. These three hundred livres he reckoned upon putting	364.84573880825843
snugly into his pocket.	237.00360155102638
“Then,” continued he, “there is a horse for my lackey, and my valise.	245.3312952945939
As to my arms, it is useless to trouble you about them; I have them.”	350.89196034307724
“A horse for your lackey?” resumed the procurator’s wife, hesitatingly;	348.55594830058
“but that is doing things in lordly style, my friend.”	209.70290735091834
“Ah, madame!” said Porthos, haughtily; “do you take me for a beggar?”	291.0427508892289
“No; I only thought that a pretty mule makes sometimes as good an	243.16670803999284
appearance as a horse, and it seemed to me that by getting a pretty	175.41800980199042
mule for Mousqueton—”	301.9949360126946
“Well, agreed for a pretty mule,” said Porthos; “you are right, I have	211.33278444999212
seen very great Spanish nobles whose whole suite were mounted on mules.	352.16958928299476
But then you understand, Madame Coquenard, a mule with feathers and	346.2430652588812
bells.”	185.5103573899539
“Be satisfied,” said the procurator’s wife.	217.20196185661007
“There remains the valise,” added Porthos.	244.79846220448616
“Oh, don’t let that disturb you,” cried Mme. Coquenard. “My husband has	230.31433554985585
five or six valises; you shall choose the best. There is one in	188.14825393336292
particular which he prefers in his journeys, large enough to hold all	173.26170803072137
the world.”	253.29605305441362
“Your valise is then empty?” asked Porthos, with simplicity.	308.4585893727302
“Certainly it is empty,” replied the procurator’s wife, in real	241.2093496108912
innocence.	283.4180584280658
“Ah, but the valise I want,” cried Porthos, “is a well-filled one, my	291.5893895654173
dear.”	238.15466190094162
Madame uttered fresh sighs. Molière had not written his scene in	230.17229458809217
“L’Avare” then. Mme. Coquenard was in the dilemma of Harpagan.	300.4180906445363
Finally, the rest of the equipment was successively debated in the same	202.42682366979597
manner; and the result of the sitting was that the procurator’s wife	208.6751838256018
should give eight hundred livres in money, and should furnish the horse	252.03373379295525
and the mule which should have the honor of carrying Porthos and	248.06676465437957
Mousqueton to glory.	216.9168928342032
These conditions being agreed to, Porthos took leave of Mme. Coquenard.	219.35872455151764
The latter wished to detain him by darting certain tender glances; but	224.45189550499478
Porthos urged the commands of duty, and the procurator’s wife was	259.9981553125604
obliged to give place to the king.	246.9386831385441
The Musketeer returned home hungry and in bad humor.	275.8859946843232
Chapter XXXIII.	194.36163264362722
SOUBRETTE AND MISTRESS	331.40335719722975
Meantime, as we have said, despite the cries of his conscience and the	352.8177341703599
wise counsels of Athos, D’Artagnan became hourly more in love with	318.6235048109899
Milady. Thus he never failed to pay his diurnal court to her; and the	172.5642879228968
self-satisfied Gascon was convinced that sooner or later she could not	308.16938956274635
fail to respond.	364.5610679075701
One day, when he arrived with his head in the air, and as light at	322.0441661914508
heart as a man who awaits a shower of gold, he found the _soubrette_	214.73856906683142
under the gateway of the hôtel; but this time the pretty Kitty was not	218.58550193229652
contented with touching him as he passed, she took him gently by the	336.4362034648772
hand.	236.18314067034098
“Good!” thought D’Artagnan, “She is charged with some message for me	206.5999409966121
from her mistress; she is about to appoint some rendezvous of which she	274.46449629040654
had not courage to speak.” And he looked down at the pretty girl with	346.4176847418053
the most triumphant air imaginable.	242.89792875010772
“I wish to say three words to you, Monsieur Chevalier,” stammered the	315.33520655200596
_soubrette_.	276.44284449674615
“Speak, my child, speak,” said D’Artagnan; “I listen.”	249.87597331379996
“Here? Impossible! That which I have to say is too long, and above all,	198.7662109153245
too secret.”	297.455254515522
“Well, what is to be done?”	247.0451204899933
“If Monsieur Chevalier would follow me?” said Kitty, timidly.	320.5032719338738
“Where you please, my dear child.”	363.8199990142806
“Come, then.”	182.30814276869083
And Kitty, who had not let go the hand of D’Artagnan, led him up a	294.5352314142759
little dark, winding staircase, and after ascending about fifteen	331.65047246010073
steps, opened a door.	185.99470709204306
“Come in here, Monsieur Chevalier,” said she; “here we shall be alone,	314.95159621840446
and can talk.”	230.20784450287937
“And whose room is this, my dear child?”	242.65259860029178
“It is mine, Monsieur Chevalier; it communicates with my mistress’s by	354.58644561723906
that door. But you need not fear. She will not hear what we say; she	267.3539860993279
never goes to bed before midnight.”	284.7553167029955
D’Artagnan cast a glance around him. The little apartment was charming	205.31278312251067
for its taste and neatness; but in spite of himself, his eyes were	212.69847433146975
directed to that door which Kitty said led to Milady’s chamber.	194.70353918715057
Kitty guessed what was passing in the mind of the young man, and heaved	181.7826931476669
a deep sigh.	342.81228110757274
“You love my mistress, then, very dearly, Monsieur Chevalier?” said	346.30902840508315
she.	286.9743440680227
“Oh, more than I can say, Kitty! I am mad for her!”	361.23801121586234
Kitty breathed a second sigh.	171.3324238965576
“Alas, monsieur,” said she, “that is too bad.”	248.65901271176506
“What the devil do you see so bad in it?” said D’Artagnan.	296.44083237151153
“Because, monsieur,” replied Kitty, “my mistress loves you not at all.”	239.52216850432993
“_Hein!_” said D’Artagnan, “can she have charged you to tell me so?”	167.78573225693498
“Oh, no, monsieur; but out of the regard I have for you, I have taken	281.5691762895784
the resolution to tell you so.”	352.6253995002384
“Much obliged, my dear Kitty; but for the intention only—for the	259.2427679721497
information, you must agree, is not likely to be at all agreeable.”	206.8927821826531
“That is to say, you don’t believe what I have told you; is it not so?”	221.28487947830362
“We have always some difficulty in believing such things, my pretty	354.88455581225446
dear, were it only from self-love.”	258.2406888101493
“Then you don’t believe me?”	242.75851481961917
“I confess that unless you deign to give me some proof of what you	327.1705570222707
advance—”	365.95405056659865
“What do you think of this?”	191.39438361953484
Kitty drew a little note from her bosom.	316.0029057538332
“For me?” said D’Artagnan, seizing the letter.	230.4043184407862
“No; for another.”	192.3771098753599
“For another?”	195.84696633639922
“Yes.”	340.2199828135816
“His name; his name!” cried D’Artagnan.	294.03650755374883
“Read the address.”	329.9330877597167
“Monsieur El Comte de Wardes.”	322.4488681231711
The remembrance of the scene at St. Germain presented itself to the	330.9526154527546
mind of the presumptuous Gascon. As quick as thought, he tore open the	182.223693508787
letter, in spite of the cry which Kitty uttered on seeing what he was	290.36825850921065
going to do, or rather, what he was doing.	235.22592272686003
“Oh, good Lord, Monsieur Chevalier,” said she, “what are you doing?”	278.6867893212618
“I?” said D’Artagnan; “nothing,” and he read,	199.47995074199656
“You have not answered my first note. Are you indisposed, or have you	332.62249133210344
forgotten the glances you favored me with at the ball of Mme. de Guise?	362.12526255533555
You have an opportunity now, Count; do not allow it to escape.”	321.1114252826588
D’Artagnan became very pale; he was wounded in his _self_-love: he	207.82529549429321
thought that it was in his _love_.	171.4516393353387
“Poor dear Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Kitty, in a voice full of	174.79525107723506
compassion, and pressing anew the young man’s hand.	184.07339117454617
“You pity me, little one?” said D’Artagnan.	291.94827605051455
“Oh, yes, and with all my heart; for I know what it is to be in love.”	181.5830562718546
“You know what it is to be in love?” said D’Artagnan, looking at her	247.55961279406023
for the first time with much attention.	343.1629655432016
“Alas, yes.”	217.2904428536711
“Well, then, instead of pitying me, you would do much better to assist	337.97382573511305
me in avenging myself on your mistress.”	365.7578599392957
“And what sort of revenge would you take?”	206.48668450730736
“I would triumph over her, and supplant my rival.”	310.1666524243896
“I will never help you in that, Monsieur Chevalier,” said Kitty,	234.71975575160687
warmly.	358.4274905768445
“And why not?” demanded D’Artagnan.	253.4582498715576
“For two reasons.”	219.71929103409082
“What ones?”	350.35489974704535
“The first is that my mistress will never love you.”	284.1588750363056
“How do you know that?”	167.2976889959058
“You have cut her to the heart.”	181.29873310140988
“I? In what can I have offended her—I who ever since I have known her	301.97085931580784
have lived at her feet like a slave? Speak, I beg you!”	245.68966399731028
“I will never confess that but to the man—who should read to the bottom	268.70521807410586
of my soul!”	293.86413014970765
D’Artagnan looked at Kitty for the second time. The young girl had	215.07736486336188
freshness and beauty which many duchesses would have purchased with	321.86991939739596
their coronets.	310.3152915220122
“Kitty,” said he, “I will read to the bottom of your soul whenever you	241.91652204640252
like; don’t let that disturb you.” And he gave her a kiss at which the	227.69303492823465
poor girl became as red as a cherry.	259.53744853147464
“Oh, no,” said Kitty, “it is not me you love! It is my mistress you	288.7631898743424
love; you told me so just now.”	352.34151009432003
“And does that hinder you from letting me know the second reason?”	346.13990330544686
“The second reason, Monsieur the Chevalier,” replied Kitty, emboldened	358.5577047050009
by the kiss in the first place, and still further by the expression of	177.3323928976361
the eyes of the young man, “is that in love, everyone for herself!”	347.50956298546265
Then only D’Artagnan remembered the languishing glances of Kitty, her	236.70530126214493
constantly meeting him in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the	260.16403537913595
stairs, those touches of the hand every time she met him, and her deep	355.45409209167417
sighs; but absorbed by his desire to please the great lady, he had	362.21159713563236
disdained the _soubrette_. He whose game is the eagle takes no heed of	334.38494821588387
the sparrow.	314.8525650921197
But this time our Gascon saw at a glance all the advantage to be	184.80779606020053
derived from the love which Kitty had just confessed so innocently, or	288.53779813193785
so boldly: the interception of letters addressed to the Comte de	175.16625381613284
Wardes, news on the spot, entrance at all hours into Kitty’s chamber,	248.7873513640373
which was contiguous to her mistress’s. The perfidious deceiver was, as	337.6634587748157
may plainly be perceived, already sacrificing, in intention, the poor	326.7699700289818
girl in order to obtain Milady, willy-nilly.	170.35410745132697
“Well,” said he to the young girl, “are you willing, my dear Kitty,	178.17613944214227
that I should give you a proof of that love which you doubt?”	284.27609238143384
“What love?” asked the young girl.	244.68258132718486
“Of that which I am ready to feel toward you.”	189.93686491420885
“And what is that proof?”	354.79160796895684
“Are you willing that I should this evening pass with you the time I	352.5451581373725
generally spend with your mistress?”	274.13733386360315
“Oh, yes,” said Kitty, clapping her hands, “very willing.”	353.3433424621315
“Well, then, come here, my dear,” said D’Artagnan, establishing himself	253.35324252899576
in an easy chair; “come, and let me tell you that you are the prettiest	307.768338008818
_soubrette_ I ever saw!”	330.15211047793065
And he did tell her so much, and so well, that the poor girl, who asked	268.20029453902634
nothing better than to believe him, did believe him. Nevertheless, to	305.086853808614
D’Artagnan’s great astonishment, the pretty Kitty defended herself	172.64800325973712
resolutely.	179.49510246638408
Time passes quickly when it is passed in attacks and defenses. Midnight	330.34019351045083
sounded, and almost at the same time the bell was rung in Milady’s	274.6503861513382
chamber.	263.15481159385814
“Good God,” cried Kitty, “there is my mistress calling me! Go; go	356.68903276763984
directly!”	215.91399148049317
D’Artagnan rose, took his hat, as if it had been his intention to obey,	222.77008715120004
then, opening quickly the door of a large closet instead of that	287.77507571866056
leading to the staircase, he buried himself amid the robes and dressing	301.47892460851784
gowns of Milady.	167.15397720510722
“What are you doing?” cried Kitty.	248.12177642665486
D’Artagnan, who had secured the key, shut himself up in the closet	172.30460770701944
without reply.	257.23188957066156
“Well,” cried Milady, in a sharp voice. “Are you asleep, that you don’t	183.75353245827625
answer when I ring?”	360.0378790016424
And D’Artagnan heard the door of communication opened violently.	350.2162494372399
“Here am I, Milady, here am I!” cried Kitty, springing forward to meet	302.7327517237187
her mistress.	167.88484885690028
Both went into the bedroom, and as the door of communication remained	342.79479101445804
open, D’Artagnan could hear Milady for some time scolding her maid. She	365.4787772771712
was at length appeased, and the conversation turned upon him while	203.27175365856186
Kitty was assisting her mistress.	350.8547841784773
“Well,” said Milady, “I have not seen our Gascon this evening.”	255.21616220529586
“What, Milady! has he not come?” said Kitty. “Can he be inconstant	291.3813433363217
before being happy?”	333.75301779932227
“Oh, no; he must have been prevented by Monsieur de Tréville or	315.14439981431167
Monsieur Dessessart. I understand my game, Kitty; I have this one	340.54487970861163
safe.”	181.1167123748773
“What will you do with him, madame?”	217.76090032334645
“What will I do with him? Be easy, Kitty, there is something between	175.04734402909938
