that man and me that he is quite ignorant of: he nearly made me lose my	170.7690297624777
credit with his Eminence. Oh, I will be revenged!”	175.22379303993714
“I believed that Madame loved him.”	302.5825337101535
“I love him? I detest him! An idiot, who held the life of Lord de	222.6458568678268
Winter in his hands and did not kill him, by which I missed three	339.13563726828625
hundred thousand livres’ income.”	196.68550729031983
“That’s true,” said Kitty; “your son was the only heir of his uncle,	174.56227565063494
and until his majority you would have had the enjoyment of his	228.2393306260968
fortune.”	249.73372137487974
D’Artagnan shuddered to the marrow at hearing this suave creature	295.3713998441661
reproach him, with that sharp voice which she took such pains to	249.09833696215554
conceal in conversation, for not having killed a man whom he had seen	363.1439932306371
load her with kindnesses.	287.04693250265353
“For all this,” continued Milady, “I should long ago have revenged	166.88098264892415
myself on him if, and I don’t know why, the cardinal had not requested	303.2032808916371
me to conciliate him.”	306.97570520137134
“Oh, yes; but Madame has not conciliated that little woman he was so	236.20409316659283
fond of.”	296.04217034693744
“What, the mercer’s wife of the Rue des Fossoyeurs? Has he not already	285.55017116108957
forgotten she ever existed? Fine vengeance that, on my faith!”	253.86118203908416
A cold sweat broke from D’Artagnan’s brow. Why, this woman was a	261.9925851970847
monster! He resumed his listening, but unfortunately the toilet was	203.18814322430194
finished.	305.7709306139048
“That will do,” said Milady; “go into your own room, and tomorrow	200.8933449419646
endeavor again to get me an answer to the letter I gave you.”	188.0589674657405
“For Monsieur de Wardes?” said Kitty.	307.05277983713484
“To be sure; for Monsieur de Wardes.”	216.6526445236803
“Now, there is one,” said Kitty, “who appears to me quite a different	196.8029251598074
sort of a man from that poor Monsieur d’Artagnan.”	327.6659643527508
“Go to bed, mademoiselle,” said Milady; “I don’t like comments.”	231.08925796501552
D’Artagnan heard the door close; then the noise of two bolts by which	360.62435755982733
Milady fastened herself in. On her side, but as softly as possible,	328.2484901415942
Kitty turned the key of the lock, and then D’Artagnan opened the closet	257.15307150039604
door.	187.4081971118164
“Oh, good Lord!” said Kitty, in a low voice, “what is the matter with	168.7512606551126
you? How pale you are!”	309.17340050297094
“The abominable creature,” murmured D’Artagnan.	332.9107204931163
“Silence, silence, begone!” said Kitty. “There is nothing but a	343.2523375657903
wainscot between my chamber and Milady’s; every word that is uttered in	357.7616957026117
one can be heard in the other.”	182.89190828004058
“That’s exactly the reason I won’t go,” said D’Artagnan.	203.70708016749728
“What!” said Kitty, blushing.	203.82033522150482
“Or, at least, I will go—later.”	307.9483170286069
He drew Kitty to him. She had the less motive to resist, resistance	254.49481573270396
would make so much noise. Therefore Kitty surrendered.	240.088766640233
It was a movement of vengeance upon Milady. D’Artagnan believed it	364.6454104544456
right to say that vengeance is the pleasure of the gods. With a little	290.0741161064021
more heart, he might have been contented with this new conquest; but	188.80448231571086
the principal features of his character were ambition and pride. It	336.7484589506855
must, however, be confessed in his justification that the first use he	361.6718096364252
made of his influence over Kitty was to try and find out what had	282.79557710031224
become of Mme. Bonacieux; but the poor girl swore upon the crucifix to	238.41127502459304
D’Artagnan that she was entirely ignorant on that head, her mistress	231.62890740040308
never admitting her into half her secrets—only she believed she could	325.6245844327343
say she was not dead.	255.71014172357587
As to the cause which was near making Milady lose her credit with the	198.09475909966312
cardinal, Kitty knew nothing about it; but this time D’Artagnan was	239.1273673044812
better informed than she was. As he had seen Milady on board a vessel	217.57993196677052
at the moment he was leaving England, he suspected that it was, almost	167.3743856603135
without a doubt, on account of the diamond studs.	362.3580740065562
But what was clearest in all this was that the true hatred, the	276.8223372775531
profound hatred, the inveterate hatred of Milady, was increased by his	197.07158871113444
not having killed her brother-in-law.	279.00342697093816
D’Artagnan came the next day to Milady’s, and finding her in a very	194.57905848552173
ill-humor, had no doubt that it was lack of an answer from M. de Wardes	226.8884664056393
that provoked her thus. Kitty came in, but Milady was very cross with	227.98198253602706
her. The poor girl ventured a glance at D’Artagnan which said, “See how	306.7383560703554
I suffer on your account!”	296.7705952438872
Toward the end of the evening, however, the beautiful lioness became	350.2204354639846
milder; she smilingly listened to the soft speeches of D’Artagnan, and	191.29456955677526
even gave him her hand to kiss.	305.74301072840274
D’Artagnan departed, scarcely knowing what to think, but as he was a	335.49674854849275
youth who did not easily lose his head, while continuing to pay his	181.64064010441572
court to Milady, he had framed a little plan in his mind.	216.47830724052733
He found Kitty at the gate, and, as on the preceding evening, went up	173.9891246280742
to her chamber. Kitty had been accused of negligence and severely	241.39518178267892
scolded. Milady could not at all comprehend the silence of the Comte de	261.8923258875164
Wardes, and she ordered Kitty to come at nine o’clock in the morning to	171.080905323816
take a third letter.	169.71046381831047
D’Artagnan made Kitty promise to bring him that letter on the following	176.73144549396721
morning. The poor girl promised all her lover desired; she was mad.	222.6496122060486
Things passed as on the night before. D’Artagnan concealed himself in	224.94723849046025
his closet; Milady called, undressed, sent away Kitty, and shut the	255.61842370964948
door. As the night before, D’Artagnan did not return home till five	251.2343107398458
o’clock in the morning.	244.64456528770546
At eleven o’clock Kitty came to him. She held in her hand a fresh	277.74834821405705
billet from Milady. This time the poor girl did not even argue with	346.296745286185
D’Artagnan; she gave it to him at once. She belonged body and soul to	227.6827588149215
her handsome soldier.	315.23824580113217
D’Artagnan opened the letter and read as follows:	303.8650666013816
This is the third time I have written to you to tell you that I love	322.1331950096135
you. Beware that I do not write to you a fourth time to tell you that I	332.9825243804835
detest you.	357.6961185670698
    If you repent of the manner in which you have acted toward me, the	232.89781313199853
    young girl who brings you this will tell you how a man of spirit	269.9285650765204
    may obtain his pardon.	238.02904216731076
D’Artagnan colored and grew pale several times in reading this billet.	172.62608537105518
“Oh, you love her still,” said Kitty, who had not taken her eyes off	363.59301437976217
the young man’s countenance for an instant.	297.1715063839948
“No, Kitty, you are mistaken. I do not love her, but I will avenge	220.9061552132367
myself for her contempt.”	180.4840806769385
“Oh, yes, I know what sort of vengeance! You told me that!”	241.9958148547019
“What matters it to you, Kitty? You know it is you alone whom I love.”	309.032077787596
“How can I know that?”	313.48056193324635
“By the scorn I will throw upon her.”	215.97425754865415
D’Artagnan took a pen and wrote:	185.45348819054652
MADAME, Until the present moment I could not believe that it was to me	256.00489534835947
your first two letters were addressed, so unworthy did I feel myself of	214.69857212461636
such an honor; besides, I was so seriously indisposed that I could not	323.85213527015384
in any case have replied to them.	211.1740077255209
    But now I am forced to believe in the excess of your kindness,	213.8378033907075
    since not only your letter but your servant assures me that I have	316.3561010766084
    the good fortune to be beloved by you.	261.4527165090293
    She has no occasion to teach me the way in which a man of spirit	297.01131113199983
    may obtain his pardon. I will come and ask mine at eleven o’clock	167.69456370070847
    this evening.	277.48728034566636
    To delay it a single day would be in my eyes now to commit a fresh	242.15966953056628
    offense.	253.7909586903677
    From him whom you have rendered the happiest of men,	318.35162809185914
COMTE DE WARDES	192.52412682050098
This note was in the first place a forgery; it was likewise an	361.2870458710479
indelicacy. It was even, according to our present manners, something	254.05959047793323
like an infamous action; but at that period people did not manage	183.41615105326656
affairs as they do today. Besides, D’Artagnan from her own admission	346.22918282832165
knew Milady culpable of treachery in matters more important, and could	245.96386335886427
entertain no respect for her. And yet, notwithstanding this want of	304.3263840147158
respect, he felt an uncontrollable passion for this woman boiling in	278.7857709921344
his veins—passion drunk with contempt; but passion or thirst, as the	321.44584373922714
reader pleases.	230.4862666738177
D’Artagnan’s plan was very simple. By Kitty’s chamber he could gain	246.2506759423669
that of her mistress. He would take advantage of the first moment of	279.30133606613566
surprise, shame, and terror, to triumph over her. He might fail, but	332.1911058567124
something must be left to chance. In eight days the campaign would	180.6982746782746
open, and he would be compelled to leave Paris; D’Artagnan had no time	190.76437834047906
for a prolonged love siege.	339.9838380217931
“There,” said the young man, handing Kitty the letter sealed; “give	177.46096534135975
that to Milady. It is the count’s reply.”	248.40642168987287
Poor Kitty became as pale as death; she suspected what the letter	181.37980145902577
contained.	178.63830645735234
“Listen, my dear girl,” said D’Artagnan; “you cannot but perceive that	180.90167361642455
all this must end, some way or other. Milady may discover that you gave	185.86106511652042
the first billet to my lackey instead of to the count’s; that it is I	170.28446966641275
who have opened the others which ought to have been opened by de	298.08775848776804
Wardes. Milady will then turn you out of doors, and you know she is not	364.32263846854653
the woman to limit her vengeance.”	242.26180123344528
“Alas!” said Kitty, “for whom have I exposed myself to all that?”	271.3463933358512
“For me, I well know, my sweet girl,” said D’Artagnan. “But I am	200.18990097953997
grateful, I swear to you.”	337.54866896953286
“But what does this note contain?”	353.91092205363003
“Milady will tell you.”	219.9808151408527
“Ah, you do not love me!” cried Kitty, “and I am very wretched.”	342.7974572325427
To this reproach there is always one response which deludes women.	267.05183294544236
D’Artagnan replied in such a manner that Kitty remained in her great	250.91033536105016
delusion. Although she cried freely before deciding to transmit the	315.7547169545011
letter to her mistress, she did at last so decide, which was all	306.97642259852427
D’Artagnan wished. Finally he promised that he would leave her	209.94131472374707
mistress’s presence at an early hour that evening, and that when he	293.193425289051
left the mistress he would ascend with the maid. This promise completed	198.57179031498038
poor Kitty’s consolation.	210.44955219334688
Chapter XXXIV.	262.3274726586973
IN WHICH THE EQUIPMENT OF ARAMIS AND PORTHOS IS TREATED OF	185.17257820968098
Since the four friends had been each in search of his equipments, there	265.9599823576692
had been no fixed meeting between them. They dined apart from one	264.54546282229643
another, wherever they might happen to be, or rather where they could.	180.3047092755734
Duty likewise on its part took a portion of that precious time which	169.97160577905638
was gliding away so rapidly—only they had agreed to meet once a week,	202.92887021304134
about one o’clock, at the residence of Athos, seeing that he, in	293.43198366957876
agreement with the vow he had formed, did not pass over the threshold	346.0299234697014
of his door.	195.89480138613354
This day of reunion was the same day as that on which Kitty came to	318.3047100611575
find D’Artagnan. Soon as Kitty left him, D’Artagnan directed his steps	173.32841835185113
toward the Rue Férou.	237.02857829073452
He found Athos and Aramis philosophizing. Aramis had some slight	171.3462543993744
inclination to resume the cassock. Athos, according to his system,	237.7411770296604
neither encouraged nor dissuaded him. Athos believed that everyone	356.3314813899499
should be left to his own free will. He never gave advice but when it	320.1161587633605
was asked, and even then he required to be asked twice.	169.0557171620464
“People, in general,” he said, “only ask advice not to follow it; or if	179.8236114188083
they do follow it, it is for the sake of having someone to blame for	245.7767234471308
having given it.”	305.82483469327076
Porthos arrived a minute after D’Artagnan. The four friends were	230.34517154128676
reunited.	201.08891952418685
The four countenances expressed four different feelings: that of	195.7148097728419
Porthos, tranquillity; that of D’Artagnan, hope; that of Aramis,	290.59852615000636
uneasiness; that of Athos, carelessness.	176.75566137718081
At the end of a moment’s conversation, in which Porthos hinted that a	306.2537362483175
lady of elevated rank had condescended to relieve him from his	184.54188863027267
embarrassment, Mousqueton entered. He came to request his master to	271.46119130478314
return to his lodgings, where his presence was urgent, as he piteously	227.5603941134818
said.	169.5579903493627
“Is it my equipment?”	343.9293278192815
“Yes and no,” replied Mousqueton.	363.9977141475624
“Well, but can’t you speak?”	176.4688613726751
“Come, monsieur.”	212.69542421481822
Porthos rose, saluted his friends, and followed Mousqueton. An instant	205.73666981690167
after, Bazin made his appearance at the door.	250.26720068618124
“What do you want with me, my friend?” said Aramis, with that mildness	188.26850197565673
of language which was observable in him every time that his ideas were	223.7017229237276
directed toward the Church.	334.4490991851773
“A man wishes to see Monsieur at home,” replied Bazin.	189.82295602002705
“A man! What man?”	271.92760891249947
“A mendicant.”	359.8713374090921
“Give him alms, Bazin, and bid him pray for a poor sinner.”	205.81923368428932
“This mendicant insists upon speaking to you, and pretends that you	183.6321136614994
will be very glad to see him.”	193.09215057713794
“Has he sent no particular message for me?”	316.02385666842866
“Yes. If Monsieur Aramis hesitates to come,” he said, “tell him I am	365.93362340712423
from Tours.”	210.04987986421887
“From Tours!” cried Aramis. “A thousand pardons, gentlemen; but no	306.504964269203
doubt this man brings me the news I expected.” And rising also, he went	272.2467403815548
off at a quick pace. There remained Athos and D’Artagnan.	261.47514518844264
“I believe these fellows have managed their business. What do you	274.0528173541732
think, D’Artagnan?” said Athos.	256.83646635445643
“I know that Porthos was in a fair way,” replied D’Artagnan; “and as to	199.83666360486905
Aramis to tell you the truth, I have never been seriously uneasy on his	357.2008357785012
account. But you, my dear Athos—you, who so generously distributed the	298.7810766246272
Englishman’s pistoles, which were our legitimate property—what do you	268.50018117101047
mean to do?”	288.5370088387857
“I am satisfied with having killed that fellow, my boy, seeing that it	176.06727112599498
is blessed bread to kill an Englishman; but if I had pocketed his	270.88718988157297
pistoles, they would have weighed me down like a remorse.”	319.3795551952038
“Go to, my dear Athos; you have truly inconceivable ideas.”	281.6162087452963
“Let it pass. What do you think of Monsieur de Tréville telling me,	180.0544237998301
when he did me the honor to call upon me yesterday, that you associated	205.5838241885278
with the suspected English, whom the cardinal protects?”	219.6597639097146
“That is to say, I visit an Englishwoman—the one I named.”	224.84101464688095
“Oh, ay! the fair woman on whose account I gave you advice, which	302.778672742129
naturally you took care not to adopt.”	347.2094721873144
“I gave you my reasons.”	249.25768821559882
“Yes; you look there for your outfit, I think you said.”	231.0598468521094
“Not at all. I have acquired certain knowledge that that woman was	203.80268295647315
concerned in the abduction of Madame Bonacieux.”	282.16929304161107
“Yes, I understand now: to find one woman, you court another. It is the	315.17220040707264
longest road, but certainly the most amusing.”	358.18432908281704
D’Artagnan was on the point of telling Athos all; but one consideration	301.0107265389232
restrained him. Athos was a gentleman, punctilious in points of honor;	209.73496007798394
and there were in the plan which our lover had devised for Milady, he	208.56807847113743
was sure, certain things that would not obtain the assent of this	235.76414973096126
Puritan. He was therefore silent; and as Athos was the least	281.517009857919
inquisitive of any man on earth, D’Artagnan’s confidence stopped there.	364.03933736914485
We will therefore leave the two friends, who had nothing important to	287.62072602762936
say to each other, and follow Aramis.	332.48729112879676
Upon being informed that the person who wanted to speak to him came	287.2212445731999
from Tours, we have seen with what rapidity the young man followed, or	339.4502696319947
rather went before, Bazin; he ran without stopping from the Rue Férou	253.89909006384346
to the Rue de Vaugirard. On entering he found a man of short stature	167.62223712986415
and intelligent eyes, but covered with rags.	359.9724948008613
“You have asked for me?” said the Musketeer.	314.39461155463346
“I wish to speak with Monsieur Aramis. Is that your name, monsieur?”	221.72541504983025
“My very own. You have brought me something?”	286.53941503948715
“Yes, if you show me a certain embroidered handkerchief.”	282.23609679231737
“Here it is,” said Aramis, taking a small key from his breast and	348.5425177140905
opening a little ebony box inlaid with mother of pearl, “here it is.	289.0086251638396
Look.”	256.9498113787116
“That is right,” replied the mendicant; “dismiss your lackey.”	180.24412150587912
In fact, Bazin, curious to know what the mendicant could want with his	274.6363477842739
master, kept pace with him as well as he could, and arrived almost at	210.2437446615524
the same time he did; but his quickness was not of much use to him. At	279.5970659911826
the hint from the mendicant his master made him a sign to retire, and	255.3794292956913
he was obliged to obey.	364.24863476958376
Bazin gone, the mendicant cast a rapid glance around him in order to be	204.76043740255454
sure that nobody could either see or hear him, and opening his ragged	222.70459902478598
vest, badly held together by a leather strap, he began to rip the upper	241.5161750847891
part of his doublet, from which he drew a letter.	252.40389900704488
Aramis uttered a cry of joy at the sight of the seal, kissed the	206.61208609782327
superscription with an almost religious respect, and opened the	193.4543153670879
epistle, which contained what follows:	202.84396841344716
“My Friend, it is the will of fate that we should be still for some	204.82486674414474
time separated; but the delightful days of youth are not lost beyond	173.2632039764558
return. Perform your duty in camp; I will do mine elsewhere. Accept	173.4912673597301
that which the bearer brings you; make the campaign like a handsome	346.4875304853166
true gentleman, and think of me, who kisses tenderly your black eyes.	308.9480203083842
    “Adieu; or rather, _au revoir_.”	302.5692575933409
The mendicant continued to rip his garments; and drew from amid his	270.67140352450235
rags a hundred and fifty Spanish double pistoles, which he laid down on	365.1465420150973
the table; then he opened the door, bowed, and went out before the	318.95806546224094
young man, stupefied by his letter, had ventured to address a word to	295.4706224645431
him.	348.0578373851807
Aramis then reperused the letter, and perceived a postscript:	246.81808540137587
PS. You may behave politely to the bearer, who is a count and a grandee	228.466983687119
of Spain!	220.9017773773352
“Golden dreams!” cried Aramis. “Oh, beautiful life! Yes, we are young;	248.58541685346674
yes, we shall yet have happy days! My love, my blood, my life! all,	170.63207241922262
all, all, are thine, my adored mistress!”	194.45425607127063
And he kissed the letter with passion, without even vouchsafing a look	197.59002486727348
at the gold which sparkled on the table.	223.85380209077323
Bazin scratched at the door, and as Aramis had no longer any reason to	264.5434277112528
exclude him, he bade him come in.	294.71298795812413
Bazin was stupefied at the sight of the gold, and forgot that he came	296.973658836704
to announce D’Artagnan, who, curious to know who the mendicant could	336.59194831682663
be, came to Aramis on leaving Athos.	354.18366650204234
Now, as D’Artagnan used no ceremony with Aramis, seeing that Bazin	285.9237757485297
forgot to announce him, he announced himself.	236.31030327286237
“The devil! my dear Aramis,” said D’Artagnan, “if these are the prunes	227.3235879454567
that are sent to you from Tours, I beg you will make my compliments to	209.11902069205078
the gardener who gathers them.”	216.37417828714987
“You are mistaken, friend D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, always on his	345.3573687759609
guard; “this is from my publisher, who has just sent me the price of	279.6390998637918
that poem in one-syllable verse which I began yonder.”	241.83434556748335
“Ah, indeed,” said D’Artagnan. “Well, your publisher is very generous,	189.88463663814244
my dear Aramis, that’s all I can say.”	278.32685852779997
“How, monsieur?” cried Bazin, “a poem sell so dear as that! It is	172.11979996843453
incredible! Oh, monsieur, you can write as much as you like; you may	313.1489972877946
become equal to Monsieur de Voiture and Monsieur de Benserade. I like	328.9494974831035
that. A poet is as good as an abbé. Ah! Monsieur Aramis, become a poet,	242.27954561273333
I beg of you.”	358.7680113618902
“Bazin, my friend,” said Aramis, “I believe you meddle with my	213.29824646185153
conversation.”	318.10323241838967
Bazin perceived he was wrong; he bowed and went out.	189.28686560930984
“Ah!” said D’Artagnan with a smile, “you sell your productions at their	303.4784274046493
weight in gold. You are very fortunate, my friend; but take care or you	177.33720853444686
will lose that letter which is peeping from your doublet, and which	275.53227474292527
also comes, no doubt, from your publisher.”	214.08449740130823
Aramis blushed to the eyes, crammed in the letter, and re-buttoned his	288.3246942773619
doublet.	176.28749055192796
“My dear D’Artagnan,” said he, “if you please, we will join our	330.3901414926294
friends; as I am rich, we will today begin to dine together again,	227.29104912521916
expecting that you will be rich in your turn.”	349.6249863479003
“My faith!” said D’Artagnan, with great pleasure. “It is long since we	248.29163504508338
have had a good dinner; and I, for my part, have a somewhat hazardous	306.06677820144836
expedition for this evening, and shall not be sorry, I confess, to	316.534801019769
fortify myself with a few glasses of good old Burgundy.”	285.3606998946495
“Agreed, as to the old Burgundy; I have no objection to that,” said	223.68992441877253
Aramis, from whom the letter and the gold had removed, as by magic, his	261.51618635834427
ideas of conversion.	290.93944345710713
And having put three or four double pistoles into his pocket to answer	337.7527096249771
the needs of the moment, he placed the others in the ebony box, inlaid	281.91574883565977
with mother of pearl, in which was the famous handkerchief which served	363.87529237395563
him as a talisman.	227.24928015211705
The two friends repaired to Athos’s, and he, faithful to his vow of not	280.5962601293795
going out, took upon him to order dinner to be brought to them. As he	188.57468791733731
was perfectly acquainted with the details of gastronomy, D’Artagnan and	222.06435771437535
Aramis made no objection to abandoning this important care to him.	352.4788242365096
They went to find Porthos, and at the corner of the Rue Bac met	291.70171102731615
Mousqueton, who, with a most pitiable air, was driving before him a	229.79372299402212
mule and a horse.	312.9266792812064
D’Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise, which was not quite free from	192.3219553002834
joy.	333.1777525850914
“Ah, my yellow horse,” cried he. “Aramis, look at that horse!”	249.1490902335119
“Oh, the frightful brute!” said Aramis.	209.37345462967127
“Ah, my dear,” replied D’Artagnan, “upon that very horse I came to	319.4719437948196
Paris.”	182.4754113003392
“What, does Monsieur know this horse?” said Mousqueton.	196.90709635559713
“It is of an original color,” said Aramis; “I never saw one with such a	204.76181813751634
hide in my life.”	177.8992143950997
“I can well believe it,” replied D’Artagnan, “and that was why I got	230.22923343155372
three crowns for him. It must have been for his hide, for, _certes_,	190.5295250740509
the carcass is not worth eighteen livres. But how did this horse come	300.6353671762165
into your hands, Mousqueton?”	357.29585372030795
“Pray,” said the lackey, “say nothing about it, monsieur; it is a	336.6072907598096
frightful trick of the husband of our duchess!”	194.4456648653523
“How is that, Mousqueton?”	342.4994314644387
“Why, we are looked upon with a rather favorable eye by a lady of	221.5850369906069
quality, the Duchesse de—but, your pardon; my master has commanded me	208.23967209239436
to be discreet. She had forced us to accept a little souvenir, a	231.84150387534766
magnificent Spanish _genet_ and an Andalusian mule, which were	319.60443712836917
beautiful to look upon. The husband heard of the affair; on their way	344.31909521704046
he confiscated the two magnificent beasts which were being sent to us,	291.4043881616418
and substituted these horrible animals.”	317.4099679218501
“Which you are taking back to him?” said D’Artagnan.	195.09071256522813
“Exactly!” replied Mousqueton. “You may well believe that we will not	324.2684585494618
accept such steeds as these in exchange for those which had been	227.70544601106582
promised to us.”	191.34391079200546
“No, _pardieu;_ though I should like to have seen Porthos on my yellow	235.4132919653507
horse. That would give me an idea of how I looked when I arrived in	247.515704379491
Paris. But don’t let us hinder you, Mousqueton; go and perform your	209.05765009302465
master’s orders. Is he at home?”	328.25834258483866
“Yes, monsieur,” said Mousqueton, “but in a very ill humor. Get up!”	192.27519337920273
He continued his way toward the Quai des Grands Augustins, while the	223.474699222331
two friends went to ring at the bell of the unfortunate Porthos. He,	289.4393142671823
having seen them crossing the yard, took care not to answer, and they	317.27720528759494
rang in vain.	248.25254377045974
Meanwhile Mousqueton continued on his way, and crossing the Pont Neuf,	287.6433998478134
still driving the two sorry animals before him, he reached the Rue aux	285.64102466046677
Ours. Arrived there, he fastened, according to the orders of his	179.42411793672252
master, both horse and mule to the knocker of the procurator’s door;	235.34186220045643
then, without taking any thought for their future, he returned to	246.84168692130416
Porthos, and told him that his commission was completed.	339.45618595320485
In a short time the two unfortunate beasts, who had not eaten anything	355.92941062006287
since the morning, made such a noise in raising and letting fall the	185.4883405414952
knocker that the procurator ordered his errand boy to go and inquire in	305.7660158598834
the neighborhood to whom this horse and mule belonged.	272.3648094432664
Mme. Coquenard recognized her present, and could not at first	320.4540998406024
comprehend this restitution; but the visit of Porthos soon enlightened	214.05790639933005
her. The anger which fired the eyes of the Musketeer, in spite of his	210.8815620956375
efforts to suppress it, terrified his sensitive inamorata. In fact,	211.55144221839842
Mousqueton had not concealed from his master that he had met D’Artagnan	356.0597615498341
and Aramis, and that D’Artagnan in the yellow horse had recognized the	186.12207040172632
Béarnese pony upon which he had come to Paris, and which he had sold	303.7837703376638
for three crowns.	334.88028031986653
Porthos went away after having appointed a meeting with the	273.2960600152811
procurator’s wife in the cloister of St. Magloire. The procurator,	233.95700023889202
seeing he was going, invited him to dinner—an invitation which the	307.2954936366262
Musketeer refused with a majestic air.	176.20265829399315
Mme. Coquenard repaired trembling to the cloister of St. Magloire, for	189.7904243681873
she guessed the reproaches that awaited her there; but she was	364.7802903398087
fascinated by the lofty airs of Porthos.	198.13347237639198
All that which a man wounded in his self-love could let fall in the	181.07366580338794
shape of imprecations and reproaches upon the head of a woman Porthos	296.35523949449953
let fall upon the bowed head of the procurator’s wife.	260.32706475785034
“Alas,” said she, “I did all for the best! One of our clients is a	340.39367485682664
horsedealer; he owes money to the office, and is backward in his pay. I	238.64688514059378
took the mule and the horse for what he owed us; he assured me that	353.57477230099244
they were two noble steeds.”	199.09147636644585
“Well, madame,” said Porthos, “if he owed you more than five crowns,	184.78783619086292
your horsedealer is a thief.”	195.19825027272034
“There is no harm in trying to buy things cheap, Monsieur Porthos,”	264.4352206362812
said the procurator’s wife, seeking to excuse herself.	260.08789336918403
“No, madame; but they who so assiduously try to buy things cheap ought	233.07819885823892
to permit others to seek more generous friends.” And Porthos, turning	318.5637908523073
on his heel, made a step to retire.	256.87578415792984
“Monsieur Porthos! Monsieur Porthos!” cried the procurator’s wife. “I	284.6724097590404
have been wrong; I see it. I ought not to have driven a bargain when it	329.72078173428486
was to equip a cavalier like you.”	187.13666941894164
Porthos, without reply, retreated a second step. The procurator’s wife	303.5639334290593
fancied she saw him in a brilliant cloud, all surrounded by duchesses	172.9868551219875
and marchionesses, who cast bags of money at his feet.	257.18992787534467
“Stop, in the name of heaven, Monsieur Porthos!” cried she. “Stop, and	335.62139632679424
let us talk.”	243.03629475746834
“Talking with you brings me misfortune,” said Porthos.	311.5607455321084
“But, tell me, what do you ask?”	342.5780991884323
“Nothing; for that amounts to the same thing as if I asked you for	212.55771785126558
something.”	226.56777818452977
The procurator’s wife hung upon the arm of Porthos, and in the violence	252.1066311735346
of her grief she cried out, “Monsieur Porthos, I am ignorant of all	317.6570909716528
such matters! How should I know what a horse is? How should I know what	310.535007395717
horse furniture is?”	316.8486098945517
“You should have left it to me, then, madame, who know what they are;	300.9166015196313
but you wished to be frugal, and consequently to lend at usury.”	285.1958494139836
“It was wrong, Monsieur Porthos; but I will repair that wrong, upon my	364.5980911169548
word of honor.”	186.51510082225815
“How so?” asked the Musketeer.	258.12692962586004
“Listen. This evening M. Coquenard is going to the house of the Duc de	343.24446601141403
Chaulnes, who has sent for him. It is for a consultation, which will	176.062379535313
last three hours at least. Come! We shall be alone, and can make up our	278.05398362084253
accounts.”	330.79727103223235
“In good time. Now you talk, my dear.”	227.50686474542886
“You pardon me?”	221.735587663281
“We shall see,” said Porthos, majestically; and the two separated	356.2591180222228
saying, “Till this evening.”	296.1155526602944
“The devil!” thought Porthos, as he walked away, “it appears I am	359.91166890563824
getting nearer to Monsieur Coquenard’s strongbox at last.”	352.3473584594543
Chapter XXXV.	186.57558427085266
A GASCON A MATCH FOR CUPID	177.01980407712176
The evening so impatiently waited for by Porthos and by D’Artagnan at	302.2486463708342
last arrived.	285.90688780668705
As was his custom, D’Artagnan presented himself at Milady’s at about	264.83107915202476
nine o’clock. He found her in a charming humor. Never had he been so	216.03264647860152
well received. Our Gascon knew, by the first glance of his eye, that	353.94805176150226
his billet had been delivered, and that this billet had had its effect.	355.1329627519528
Kitty entered to bring some sherbet. Her mistress put on a charming	239.12435130782566
face, and smiled on her graciously; but alas! the poor girl was so sad	270.7662409482085
that she did not even notice Milady’s condescension.	364.97316025455234
D’Artagnan looked at the two women, one after the other, and was forced	318.47310045558135
to acknowledge that in his opinion Dame Nature had made a mistake in	293.2935150140226
their formation. To the great lady she had given a heart vile and	304.0197096114537
venal; to the _soubrette_ she had given the heart of a duchess.	340.0506846492567
At ten o’clock Milady began to appear restless. D’Artagnan knew what	331.64328318839836
she wanted. She looked at the clock, rose, reseated herself, smiled at	281.9093107642479
D’Artagnan with an air which said, “You are very amiable, no doubt, but	207.5857732889727
you would be _charming_ if you would only depart.”	207.71830396200983
D’Artagnan rose and took his hat; Milady gave him her hand to kiss. The	305.09344510070355
young man felt her press his hand, and comprehended that this was a	289.8175201950306
sentiment, not of coquetry, but of gratitude because of his departure.	315.51207073403043
“She loves him devilishly,” he murmured. Then he went out.	237.2959188931593
This time Kitty was nowhere waiting for him; neither in the	170.7656268219856
antechamber, nor in the corridor, nor beneath the great door. It was	232.37214715486496
necessary that D’Artagnan should find alone the staircase and the	206.99703427395804
little chamber. She heard him enter, but she did not raise her head.	226.82206423695968
The young man went to her and took her hands; then she sobbed aloud.	200.2531033599425
As D’Artagnan had presumed, on receiving his letter, Milady in a	360.5296867731305
delirium of joy had told her servant everything; and by way of	309.6708574709013
recompense for the manner in which she had this time executed the	233.59145403970768
commission, she had given Kitty a purse.	231.96513622825233
Returning to her own room, Kitty had thrown the purse into a corner,	363.17845533747004
where it lay open, disgorging three or four gold pieces on the carpet.	327.4925114362754
The poor girl, under the caresses of D’Artagnan, lifted her head.	249.14467662974923
D’Artagnan himself was frightened by the change in her countenance. She	223.64136351305677
joined her hands with a suppliant air, but without venturing to speak a	309.7178091140962
word. As little sensitive as was the heart of D’Artagnan, he was	188.56783721376817
touched by this mute sorrow; but he held too tenaciously to his	167.8978869959284
projects, above all to this one, to change the program which he had	257.07963591172904
laid out in advance. He did not therefore allow her any hope that he	332.32828770330866
would flinch; only he represented his action as one of simple	279.8476352692619
vengeance.	233.85098092438182
For the rest this vengeance was very easy; for Milady, doubtless to	311.6527409645006
conceal her blushes from her lover, had ordered Kitty to extinguish all	226.1586176923122
the lights in the apartment, and even in the little chamber itself.	339.6689942970453
Before daybreak M. de Wardes must take his departure, still in	198.13266658865746
obscurity.	197.12223968917456
Presently they heard Milady retire to her room. D’Artagnan slipped into	289.66287340986366
the wardrobe. Hardly was he concealed when the little bell sounded.	206.7210348736176
Kitty went to her mistress, and did not leave the door open; but the	294.089796562748
partition was so thin that one could hear nearly all that passed	237.63451921370924
between the two women.	248.71723609842252
Milady seemed overcome with joy, and made Kitty repeat the smallest	328.82973240622334
details of the pretended interview of the _soubrette_ with De Wardes	350.3363279691531
when he received the letter; how he had responded; what was the	210.6369492808214
expression of his face; if he seemed very amorous. And to all these	334.17202617854207
questions poor Kitty, forced to put on a pleasant face, responded in a	187.59915373792052
stifled voice whose dolorous accent her mistress did not however	311.9027351745917
remark, solely because happiness is egotistical.	329.08199994199447
Finally, as the hour for her interview with the count approached,	283.54685374120925
Milady had everything about her darkened, and ordered Kitty to return	362.56780160069195
to her own chamber, and introduce De Wardes whenever he presented	212.76042230949813
himself.	167.3461591992927
Kitty’s detention was not long. Hardly had D’Artagnan seen, through a	275.88058951452234
crevice in his closet, that the whole apartment was in obscurity, than	335.6702509683987
he slipped out of his concealment, at the very moment when Kitty	210.17897254247757
reclosed the door of communication.	188.05666040969254
“What is that noise?” demanded Milady.	364.09153056735136
“It is I,” said D’Artagnan in a subdued voice, “I, the Comte de	212.28654565803458
Wardes.”	348.5318314973165
“Oh, my God, my God!” murmured Kitty, “he has not even waited for the	279.1600742117184
hour he himself named!”	179.94445142262396
“Well,” said Milady, in a trembling voice, “why do you not enter?	261.7362559028445
Count, Count,” added she, “you know that I wait for you.”	311.3927348812827
At this appeal D’Artagnan drew Kitty quietly away, and slipped into the	241.7352005073798
chamber.	288.28664725312177
If rage or sorrow ever torture the heart, it is when a lover receives	343.1917034285658
under a name which is not his own protestations of love addressed to	321.3017542997304
his happy rival. D’Artagnan was in a dolorous situation which he had	219.79685328723215
not foreseen. Jealousy gnawed his heart; and he suffered almost as much	204.3748816886789
as poor Kitty, who at that very moment was crying in the next chamber.	212.19151620119138
“Yes, Count,” said Milady, in her softest voice, and pressing his hand	364.1537901803648
in her own, “I am happy in the love which your looks and your words	329.22323770048644
have expressed to me every time we have met. I also—I love you. Oh,	195.13633236367156
tomorrow, tomorrow, I must have some pledge from you which will prove	272.61882536787095
that you think of me; and that you may not forget me, take this!” and	269.4135501025234
she slipped a ring from her finger onto D’Artagnan’s. D’Artagnan	174.32334841114883
remembered having seen this ring on the finger of Milady; it was a	187.5956922082521
magnificent sapphire, encircled with brilliants.	198.5135962339566
The first movement of D’Artagnan was to return it, but Milady added,	247.86267517965166
“No, no! Keep that ring for love of me. Besides, in accepting it,” she	298.49509823534584
added, in a voice full of emotion, “you render me a much greater	333.82521025238725
service than you imagine.”	299.0682681614359
“This woman is full of mysteries,” murmured D’Artagnan to himself. At	261.731813806198
that instant he felt himself ready to reveal all. He even opened his	189.66819012612845
mouth to tell Milady who he was, and with what a revengeful purpose he	199.28464934992965
had come; but she added, “Poor angel, whom that monster of a Gascon	262.66885272498536
barely failed to kill.”	238.01937227025002
The monster was himself.	309.39405668919164
“Oh,” continued Milady, “do your wounds still make you suffer?”	276.8118334465833
“Yes, much,” said D’Artagnan, who did not well know how to answer.	307.7605146412093
“Be tranquil,” murmured Milady; “I will avenge you—and cruelly!”	274.7431641259841
“_Peste!_” said D’Artagnan to himself, “the moment for confidences has	281.13835074317194
not yet come.”	210.95142989314343
It took some time for D’Artagnan to resume this little dialogue; but	230.26776109481753
then all the ideas of vengeance which he had brought with him had	284.0626767562978
completely vanished. This woman exercised over him an unaccountable	295.62539926008316
power; he hated and adored her at the same time. He would not have	168.47121039391658
believed that two sentiments so opposite could dwell in the same heart,	198.2925706867881
and by their union constitute a passion so strange, and as it were,	338.61164402560394
diabolical.	197.15258636365382
Presently it sounded one o’clock. It was necessary to separate.	185.81989903693662
D’Artagnan at the moment of quitting Milady felt only the liveliest	211.73407740826286
regret at the parting; and as they addressed each other in a	281.80571496935397
reciprocally passionate adieu, another interview was arranged for the	275.3673548540088
following week.	278.7401737725605
Poor Kitty hoped to speak a few words to D’Artagnan when he passed	364.5824017168969
through her chamber; but Milady herself reconducted him through the	211.894625125835
darkness, and only quit him at the staircase.	327.5669751124314
The next morning D’Artagnan ran to find Athos. He was engaged in an	224.23232305069808
adventure so singular that he wished for counsel. He therefore told him	212.57655405830863
all.	287.13121419904996
“Your Milady,” said he, “appears to be an infamous creature, but not	342.58687929847235
the less you have done wrong to deceive her. In one fashion or another	166.7125357440789
you have a terrible enemy on your hands.”	188.74363726184103
While thus speaking Athos regarded with attention the sapphire set with	186.97062410421256
diamonds which had taken, on D’Artagnan’s finger, the place of the	297.1375553767133
queen’s ring, carefully kept in a casket.	271.8153878540777
“You notice my ring?” said the Gascon, proud to display so rich a gift	251.78694407801385
in the eyes of his friends.	235.17439974141845
“Yes,” said Athos, “it reminds me of a family jewel.”	277.84827877764917
“It is beautiful, is it not?” said D’Artagnan.	304.59238078321073
“Yes,” said Athos, “magnificent. I did not think two sapphires of such	315.89587968589876
a fine water existed. Have you traded it for your diamond?”	354.1832135884706
“No. It is a gift from my beautiful Englishwoman, or rather	197.69419124603408
Frenchwoman—for I am convinced she was born in France, though I have	212.95672221126136
not questioned her.”	276.03347221073216
“That ring comes from Milady?” cried Athos, with a voice in which it	352.1542905319561
was easy to detect strong emotion.	353.74485612907654
“Her very self; she gave it me last night. Here it is,” replied	338.00920873298685
D’Artagnan, taking it from his finger.	325.3730610435177
Athos examined it and became very pale. He tried it on his left hand;	189.4435978858853
it fit his finger as if made for it.	222.93279011995813
A shade of anger and vengeance passed across the usually calm brow of	184.83571640399032
this gentleman.	282.17919734349766
“It is impossible it can be she,” said he. “How could this ring come	306.51411370900473
into the hands of Milady Clarik? And yet it is difficult to suppose	282.4658655920782
such a resemblance should exist between two jewels.”	317.3840645134436
“Do you know this ring?” said D’Artagnan.	182.57020131701682
“I thought I did,” replied Athos; “but no doubt I was mistaken.” And he	275.97256598875094
returned D’Artagnan the ring without, however, ceasing to look at it.	172.73201286828186
“Pray, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, after a minute, “either take off that	207.15975431101242
ring or turn the mounting inside; it recalls such cruel recollections	321.69100320331745
that I shall have no head to converse with you. Don’t ask me for	254.6722245140508
counsel; don’t tell me you are perplexed what to do. But stop! let me	229.9331071550066
look at that sapphire again; the one I mentioned to you had one of its	272.1625072571213
faces scratched by accident.”	213.35469232182095
D’Artagnan took off the ring, giving it again to Athos.	327.6340048280255
Athos started. “Look,” said he, “is it not strange?” and he pointed out	201.97559063259368
to D’Artagnan the scratch he had remembered.	236.51460594039082
“But from whom did this ring come to you, Athos?”	233.40588442403828
“From my mother, who inherited it from her mother. As I told you, it is	293.58982684436205
an old family jewel.”	279.01474756575885
“And you—sold it?” asked D’Artagnan, hesitatingly.	275.54748593295756
“No,” replied Athos, with a singular smile. “I gave it away in a night	255.22487537585647
of love, as it has been given to you.”	271.2160844774049
D’Artagnan became pensive in his turn; it appeared as if there were	227.81425148425922
abysses in Milady’s soul whose depths were dark and unknown. He took	237.6877027359355
back the ring, but put it in his pocket and not on his finger.	335.3663755529981
“D’Artagnan,” said Athos, taking his hand, “you know I love you; if I	264.8273972522761
had a son I could not love him better. Take my advice, renounce this	184.8764778832794
woman. I do not know her, but a sort of intuition tells me she is a	182.43098076237416
lost creature, and that there is something fatal about her.”	213.26336593997604
“You are right,” said D’Artagnan; “I will have done with her. I own	291.22751902579733
that this woman terrifies me.”	346.37597241576185
“Shall you have the courage?” said Athos.	168.08443449655397
“I shall,” replied D’Artagnan, “and instantly.”	166.350728320035
“In truth, my young friend, you will act rightly,” said the gentleman,	273.5653657015563
pressing the Gascon’s hand with an affection almost paternal; “and God	290.86527201645066
grant that this woman, who has scarcely entered into your life, may not	209.40604778745643
leave a terrible trace in it!” And Athos bowed to D’Artagnan like a man	280.4492788061444
who wishes it understood that he would not be sorry to be left alone	196.09283440311071
with his thoughts.	167.0748839631022
On reaching home D’Artagnan found Kitty waiting for him. A month of	321.6101120264151
fever could not have changed her more than this one night of	197.53354007293856
sleeplessness and sorrow.	355.351768190133
She was sent by her mistress to the false De Wardes. Her mistress was	305.21869706118395
mad with love, intoxicated with joy. She wished to know when her lover	328.81345055825966
would meet her a second night; and poor Kitty, pale and trembling,	322.1016298192591
awaited D’Artagnan’s reply. The counsels of his friend, joined to the	233.90203624495268
cries of his own heart, made him determine, now his pride was saved and	205.111903521759
his vengeance satisfied, not to see Milady again. As a reply, he wrote	227.6775207551323
the following letter:	262.91120397053413
Do not depend upon me, madame, for the next meeting. Since my	173.19546045289604
convalescence I have so many affairs of this kind on my hands that I am	254.29745518119694
forced to regulate them a little. When your turn comes, I shall have	289.56478965445467
the honor to inform you of it. I kiss your hands.	268.14270379861387
COMTE DE WARDES	243.28276456010036
Not a word about the sapphire. Was the Gascon determined to keep it as	288.49205010410844
a weapon against Milady, or else, let us be frank, did he not reserve	265.6365112450618
the sapphire as a last resource for his outfit? It would be wrong to	178.83861738322955
judge the actions of one period from the point of view of another. That	229.95219754734987
which would now be considered as disgraceful to a gentleman was at that	329.5753684109568
time quite a simple and natural affair, and the younger sons of the	268.9990190312999
best families were frequently supported by their mistresses. D’Artagnan	248.4019667380472
gave the open letter to Kitty, who at first was unable to comprehend	315.3483039351047
it, but who became almost wild with joy on reading it a second time.	282.7962167083305
She could scarcely believe in her happiness; and D’Artagnan was forced	353.0549304778035
to renew with the living voice the assurances which he had written. And	262.13080247153346
whatever might be—considering the violent character of Milady—the	218.0191011739997
danger which the poor girl incurred in giving this billet to her	259.3693563913115
mistress, she ran back to the Place Royale as fast as her legs could	286.59945113862534
carry her.	214.07573399700846
The heart of the best woman is pitiless toward the sorrows of a rival.	290.10975980612096
Milady opened the letter with eagerness equal to Kitty’s in bringing	331.4935973994948
it; but at the first words she read she became livid. She crushed the	313.206949383416
paper in her hand, and turning with flashing eyes upon Kitty, she	197.58660494417478
cried, “What is this letter?”	342.97227572550264
“The answer to Madame’s,” replied Kitty, all in a tremble.	266.41440592707374
“Impossible!” cried Milady. “It is impossible a gentleman could have	201.69244553101137
written such a letter to a woman.” Then all at once, starting, she	349.7335385406164
cried, “My God! can he have—” and she stopped. She ground her teeth;	252.60661677610602
she was of the color of ashes. She tried to go toward the window for	174.63988968523688
air, but she could only stretch forth her arms; her legs failed her,	330.71985889625256
and she sank into an armchair. Kitty, fearing she was ill, hastened	231.25908334616028
toward her and was beginning to open her dress; but Milady started up,	205.38040502030867
pushing her away. “What do you want with me?” said she, “and why do you	187.73237457991638
place your hand on me?”	214.19875708354436
“I thought that Madame was ill, and I wished to bring her help,”	318.31048225719053
responded the maid, frightened at the terrible expression which had	166.46553045043157
come over her mistress’s face.	245.6802127538715
“I faint? I? I? Do you take me for half a woman? When I am insulted I	322.1008546185983
do not faint; I avenge myself!”	358.74923921636514
And she made a sign for Kitty to leave the room.	170.9342043489243
Chapter XXXVI.	205.52382816651973
DREAM OF VENGEANCE	338.3255888341753
That evening Milady gave orders that when M. d’Artagnan came as usual,	303.8856571239943
he should be immediately admitted; but he did not come.	232.03918721394734
The next day Kitty went to see the young man again, and related to him	360.4843049411352
all that had passed on the preceding evening. D’Artagnan smiled; this	230.21224639404892
jealous anger of Milady was his revenge.	293.3205826289517
That evening Milady was still more impatient than on the preceding	207.95018025851496
evening. She renewed the order relative to the Gascon; but as before	296.91162874633767
she expected him in vain.	337.5358161295004
The next morning, when Kitty presented herself at D’Artagnan’s, she was	234.36972328449664
no longer joyous and alert as on the two preceding days; but on the	175.35441106517322
contrary sad as death.	307.8503103053228
D’Artagnan asked the poor girl what was the matter with her; but she,	215.70187969892189
as her only reply, drew a letter from her pocket and gave it to him.	227.51711858777182
This letter was in Milady’s handwriting; only this time it was	308.69274083403445
addressed to M. d’Artagnan, and not to M. de Wardes.	298.87660101831773
He opened it and read as follows:	228.01859722321473
DEAR M. D’ARTAGNAN, It is wrong thus to neglect your friends,	291.8103828643546
particularly at the moment you are about to leave them for so long a	173.08520259570503
time. My brother-in-law and myself expected you yesterday and the day	186.56780643287442
before, but in vain. Will it be the same this evening?	236.8097667709535
Your very grateful,	256.498993841575
MILADY CLARIK	213.9227754135079
“That’s all very simple,” said D’Artagnan; “I expected this letter. My	174.8905076625971
credit rises by the fall of that of the Comte de Wardes.”	260.79487783878716
“And will you go?” asked Kitty.	169.19941633210303
“Listen to me, my dear girl,” said the Gascon, who sought for an excuse	211.62863235166856
in his own eyes for breaking the promise he had made Athos; “you must	329.1934783996693
understand it would be impolitic not to accept such a positive	169.14169437551323
invitation. Milady, not seeing me come again, would not be able to	236.32544586199745
understand what could cause the interruption of my visits, and might	308.6313202823544
suspect something; who could say how far the vengeance of such a woman	250.5776496726976
would go?”	330.5180033779884
“Oh, my God!” said Kitty, “you know how to represent things in such a	304.62185247805587
way that you are always in the right. You are going now to pay your	222.638278860711
court to her again, and if this time you succeed in pleasing her in	326.3952861542548
your own name and with your own face, it will be much worse than	259.0611239630507
before.”	209.91511501743287
Instinct made poor Kitty guess a part of what was to happen. D’Artagnan	185.1496933416835
reassured her as well as he could, and promised to remain insensible to	248.32931543367465
the seductions of Milady.	172.57644965121614
He desired Kitty to tell her mistress that he could not be more	299.99042445008774
grateful for her kindnesses than he was, and that he would be obedient	343.10827641263154
to her orders. He did not dare to write for fear of not being able—to	256.65194492205023
such experienced eyes as those of Milady—to disguise his writing	317.1779277918072
sufficiently.	186.85186782590839
As nine o’clock sounded, D’Artagnan was at the Place Royale. It was	193.57384296664756
evident that the servants who waited in the antechamber were warned,	279.0698031621301
for as soon as D’Artagnan appeared, before even he had asked if Milady	169.04217907101918
were visible, one of them ran to announce him.	175.34107375925458
“Show him in,” said Milady, in a quick tone, but so piercing that	273.53494326790104
D’Artagnan heard her in the antechamber.	276.80379961792414
He was introduced.	298.0761236122994
“I am at home to nobody,” said Milady; “observe, to _nobody_.”	234.831989181749
The servant went out.	166.89989683819576
D’Artagnan cast an inquiring glance at Milady. She was pale, and looked	280.1018819297108
fatigued, either from tears or want of sleep. The number of lights had	279.94935323108507
been intentionally diminished, but the young woman could not conceal	219.5262163200237
the traces of the fever which had devoured her for two days.	290.25621579453843
D’Artagnan approached her with his usual gallantry. She then made an	350.19105348229937
extraordinary effort to receive him, but never did a more distressed	315.60269336320874
countenance give the lie to a more amiable smile.	239.60209498777698
To the questions which D’Artagnan put concerning her health, she	305.16484901728154
replied, “Bad, very bad.”	199.93396704092387
“Then,” replied he, “my visit is ill-timed; you, no doubt, stand in	210.13399601718822
need of repose, and I will withdraw.”	188.19709398173887
“No, no!” said Milady. “On the contrary, stay, Monsieur d’Artagnan;	297.5311212767897
your agreeable company will divert me.”	357.272282535102
“Oh, oh!” thought D’Artagnan. “She has never been so kind before. On	305.5484885138055
guard!”	226.37979406114698
Milady assumed the most agreeable air possible, and conversed with more	335.79058806442174
than her usual brilliancy. At the same time the fever, which for an	301.96709133843046
instant abandoned her, returned to give luster to her eyes, color to	205.6043401593377
her cheeks, and vermillion to her lips. D’Artagnan was again in the	241.93999401532747
presence of the Circe who had before surrounded him with her	241.76716065838858
enchantments. His love, which he believed to be extinct but which was	196.87727277854097
only asleep, awoke again in his heart. Milady smiled, and D’Artagnan	325.0497008875924
felt that he could damn himself for that smile. There was a moment at	195.4819745760547
which he felt something like remorse.	244.96194522992693
By degrees, Milady became more communicative. She asked D’Artagnan if	346.23398075871376
he had a mistress.	218.56032485413544
“Alas!” said D’Artagnan, with the most sentimental air he could assume,	173.86490111189974
“can you be cruel enough to put such a question to me—to me, who, from	199.0756398625963
the moment I saw you, have only breathed and sighed through you and for	229.5447140694208
you?”	195.99762657970575
Milady smiled with a strange smile.	260.94821410998
“Then you love me?” said she.	312.5310320127803
“Have I any need to tell you so? Have you not perceived it?”	326.1644968795471
“It may be; but you know the more hearts are worth the capture, the	338.8006959109178
more difficult they are to be won.”	257.0409242426509
“Oh, difficulties do not affright me,” said D’Artagnan. “I shrink	243.87961339646534
before nothing but impossibilities.”	337.2243388368562
“Nothing is impossible,” replied Milady, “to true love.”	326.863064263017
“Nothing, madame?”	241.55970054198434
“Nothing,” replied Milady.	364.0143459279182
“The devil!” thought D’Artagnan. “The note is changed. Is she going to	197.82250403414403
fall in love with me, by chance, this fair inconstant; and will she be	198.38722189944613
disposed to give me myself another sapphire like that which she gave me	309.90727484374315
for De Wardes?”	256.2081860643694
D’Artagnan rapidly drew his seat nearer to Milady’s.	295.3630127301197
“Well, now,” she said, “let us see what you would do to prove this love	245.97831225405514
of which you speak.”	223.5618873238184
“All that could be required of me. Order; I am ready.”	235.2649999589108
“For everything?”	217.7191589967918
“For everything,” cried D’Artagnan, who knew beforehand that he had not	173.99035767425576
much to risk in engaging himself thus.	171.1606819736311
“Well, now let us talk a little seriously,” said Milady, in her turn	175.6753808256845
drawing her armchair nearer to D’Artagnan’s chair.	265.44102862675993
“I am all attention, madame,” said he.	193.73009706009663
Milady remained thoughtful and undecided for a moment; then, as if	258.3030693060645
appearing to have formed a resolution, she said, “I have an enemy.”	265.75749640657176
“You, madame!” said D’Artagnan, affecting surprise; “is that possible,	166.04322986897995
my God?—good and beautiful as you are!”	321.5283484671312
“A mortal enemy.”	332.21134137895604
“Indeed!”	353.6372571898137
“An enemy who has insulted me so cruelly that between him and me it is	175.3627261345117
war to the death. May I reckon on you as an auxiliary?”	316.49503451694346
D’Artagnan at once perceived the ground which the vindictive creature	172.59664400333958
wished to reach.	318.1154530646456
“You may, madame,” said he, with emphasis. “My arm and my life belong	175.8252963051469
to you, like my love.”	301.97765292452584
“Then,” said Milady, “since you are as generous as you are loving—”	176.88578345258912
She stopped.	342.16888367587956
“Well?” demanded D’Artagnan.	167.22939862297582
“Well,” replied Milady, after a moment of silence, “from the present	344.19543494667545
time, cease to talk of impossibilities.”	322.56221611105263
“Do not overwhelm me with happiness,” cried D’Artagnan, throwing	238.47313285942687
himself on his knees, and covering with kisses the hands abandoned to	332.56650244308054
him.	294.8177708178471
“Avenge me of that infamous De Wardes,” said Milady, between her teeth,	317.2332093902976
“and I shall soon know how to get rid of you—you double idiot, you	239.79264594655575
animated sword blade!”	261.15521488486814
“Fall voluntarily into my arms, hypocritical and dangerous woman,” said	192.02030042249476
D’Artagnan, likewise to himself, “after having abused me with such	175.3772388879308
effrontery, and afterward I will laugh at you with him whom you wish me	365.46665936314804
to kill.”	301.17842116000134
D’Artagnan lifted up his head.	360.99427641015666
“I am ready,” said he.	204.26074881581866
“You have understood me, then, dear Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Milady.	307.33308710491207
“I could interpret one of your looks.”	311.4108701883707
“Then you would employ for me your arm which has already acquired so	293.9738064392353
much renown?”	324.82258262044536
“Instantly!”	217.3781051012661
“But on my part,” said Milady, “how should I repay such a service? I	288.73579257765005
know these lovers. They are men who do nothing for nothing.”	230.2760772410623
“You know the only reply that I desire,” said D’Artagnan, “the only one	236.0778799245196
worthy of you and of me!”	231.5628927987192
And he drew nearer to her.	296.0344193621589
She scarcely resisted.	275.3343506120758
“Interested man!” cried she, smiling.	332.21876367745733
“Ah,” cried D’Artagnan, really carried away by the passion this woman	270.5730440187807
had the power to kindle in his heart, “ah, that is because my happiness	268.48902768188236
appears so impossible to me; and I have such fear that it should fly	355.4107985482096
away from me like a dream that I pant to make a reality of it.”	361.3837755624245
“Well, merit this pretended happiness, then!”	179.22451394953384
“I am at your orders,” said D’Artagnan.	287.2158560262774
“Quite certain?” said Milady, with a last doubt.	353.321131436159
“Only name to me the base man that has brought tears into your	273.04946398182017
beautiful eyes!”	294.68822665096957
“Who told you that I had been weeping?” said she.	196.0797477775751
“It appeared to me—”	218.86092304587584
“Such women as I never weep,” said Milady.	178.793268766326
“So much the better! Come, tell me his name!”	253.41248086487644
“Remember that his name is all my secret.”	200.4510603299677
“Yet I must know his name.”	270.98640523487234
“Yes, you must; see what confidence I have in you!”	359.6601549530202
“You overwhelm me with joy. What is his name?”	221.86606284859613
“You know him.”	177.6199266066021
“Indeed.”	243.67359360231433
“Yes.”	231.30141227316068
“It is surely not one of my friends?” replied D’Artagnan, affecting	203.71356923865065
hesitation in order to make her believe him ignorant.	187.21269374597864
“If it were one of your friends you would hesitate, then?” cried	268.76590370160875
Milady; and a threatening glance darted from her eyes.	188.86890109274037
“Not if it were my own brother!” cried D’Artagnan, as if carried away	222.17786841031275
by his enthusiasm.	253.85544275532567
Our Gascon promised this without risk, for he knew all that was meant.	334.84113136173715
“I love your devotedness,” said Milady.	239.69266034873007
“Alas, do you love nothing else in me?” asked D’Artagnan.	349.87918219522754
“I love you also, _you!_” said she, taking his hand.	212.87891180627298
The warm pressure made D’Artagnan tremble, as if by the touch that	306.2105031810239
fever which consumed Milady attacked himself.	298.25225920911566
“You love me, you!” cried he. “Oh, if that were so, I should lose my	360.378803348469
reason!”	185.32153280421966
And he folded her in his arms. She made no effort to remove her lips	179.2161523276359
from his kisses; only she did not respond to them. Her lips were cold;	317.11173768099445
it appeared to D’Artagnan that he had embraced a statue.	192.68062881788464
He was not the less intoxicated with joy, electrified by love. He	175.10642930988053
almost believed in the tenderness of Milady; he almost believed in the	317.754371701095
crime of De Wardes. If De Wardes had at that moment been under his	314.5736544623045
hand, he would have killed him.	356.597774215414
Milady seized the occasion.	218.4568827562117
“His name is—” said she, in her turn.	312.2943619325057
“De Wardes; I know it,” cried D’Artagnan.	261.4576851922949
“And how do you know it?” asked Milady, seizing both his hands, and	238.03467949210437
endeavoring to read with her eyes to the bottom of his heart.	217.84555492211462
D’Artagnan felt he had allowed himself to be carried away, and that he	300.9957767335944
had committed an error.	250.97169355087797
“Tell me, tell me, tell me, I say,” repeated Milady, “how do you know	242.4120520360146
it?”	322.4547789152515
“How do I know it?” said D’Artagnan.	206.887465990221
“Yes.”	348.0048835787478
“I know it because yesterday Monsieur de Wardes, in a saloon where I	283.3895114918426
was, showed a ring which he said he had received from you.”	307.39309377085567
“Wretch!” cried Milady.	171.40517840547545
The epithet, as may be easily understood, resounded to the very bottom	232.56869281092187
of D’Artagnan’s heart.	352.6387062018843
“Well?” continued she.	251.92116475694957
“Well, I will avenge you of this wretch,” replied D’Artagnan, giving	175.83788340774365
himself the airs of Don Japhet of Armenia.	365.806647128873
“Thanks, my brave friend!” cried Milady; “and when shall I be avenged?”	180.9252518826183
“Tomorrow—immediately—when you please!”	316.7030193351
Milady was about to cry out, “Immediately,” but she reflected that such	183.77711822912997
precipitation would not be very gracious toward D’Artagnan.	209.90589974158883
Besides, she had a thousand precautions to take, a thousand counsels to	290.5462102775961
give to her defender, in order that he might avoid explanations with	236.00912877454903
the count before witnesses. All this was answered by an expression of	351.5482360580328
D’Artagnan’s. “Tomorrow,” said he, “you will be avenged, or I shall be	287.50962596975336
dead.”	242.877386758768
“No,” said she, “you will avenge me; but you will not be dead. He is a	323.81472542809274
coward.”	327.3498401763284
“With women, perhaps; but not with men. I know something of him.”	255.45356354671506
“But it seems you had not much reason to complain of your fortune in	332.89538765917064
your contest with him.”	326.3878241352728
“Fortune is a courtesan; favorable yesterday, she may turn her back	210.66594676135006
tomorrow.”	279.18193483172206
“Which means that you now hesitate?”	286.1773245745239
“No, I do not hesitate; God forbid! But would it be just to allow me to	295.32763402909666
go to a possible death without having given me at least something more	177.69620625702638
than hope?”	214.16957996173483
Milady answered by a glance which said, “Is that all?—speak, then.” And	319.2256361612142
then accompanying the glance with explanatory words, “That is but too	288.4183400876005
just,” said she, tenderly.	300.9437254668355
“Oh, you are an angel!” exclaimed the young man.	293.87859223517813
“Then all is agreed?” said she.	239.7482441507625
“Except that which I ask of you, dear love.”	215.2216624556852
“But when I assure you that you may rely on my tenderness?”	212.34862000670944
“I cannot wait till tomorrow.”	212.3671870061601
“Silence! I hear my brother. It will be useless for him to find you	252.93474194603283
here.”	324.5202666666256
She rang the bell and Kitty appeared.	214.71175649356422
“Go out this way,” said she, opening a small private door, “and come	305.03403588303615
back at eleven o’clock; we will then terminate this conversation. Kitty	280.7575854075857
will conduct you to my chamber.”	198.3967922027848
The poor girl almost fainted at hearing these words.	202.88361755828274
“Well, mademoiselle, what are you thinking about, standing there like a	273.58927175347964
statue? Do as I bid you: show the chevalier out; and this evening at	243.95694742777775
eleven o’clock—you have heard what I said.”	273.42160708863383
“It appears that these appointments are all made for eleven o’clock,”	321.6291075607404
thought D’Artagnan; “that’s a settled custom.”	206.70207621353921
Milady held out her hand to him, which he kissed tenderly.	232.9270653429686
“But,” said he, as he retired as quickly as possible from the	320.77183497057746
reproaches of Kitty, “I must not play the fool. This woman is certainly	283.73454236767736
a great liar. I must take care.”	196.7279247730727
Chapter XXXVII.	309.5447786931836
MILADY’S SECRET	321.51508415340163
D’Artagnan left the hôtel instead of going up at once to Kitty’s	249.12255481361728
chamber, as she endeavored to persuade him to do—and that for two	214.49879465114742
reasons: the first, because by this means he should escape reproaches,	343.5057561082217
recriminations, and prayers; the second, because he was not sorry to	256.7742531782958
have an opportunity of reading his own thoughts and endeavoring, if	234.57428793294508
possible, to fathom those of this woman.	216.30843594260278
What was most clear in the matter was that D’Artagnan loved Milady like	337.3427405866927
a madman, and that she did not love him at all. In an instant	177.12912481815417
D’Artagnan perceived that the best way in which he could act would be	170.8403719252499
to go home and write Milady a long letter, in which he would confess to	321.164632949846
her that he and De Wardes were, up to the present moment absolutely the	167.63083454061962
same, and that consequently he could not undertake, without committing	333.75572728303246
suicide, to kill the Comte de Wardes. But he also was spurred on by a	186.4931348015856
ferocious desire of vengeance. He wished to subdue this woman in his	219.51180334599695
own name; and as this vengeance appeared to him to have a certain	343.9420010414667
sweetness in it, he could not make up his mind to renounce it.	292.7803637473953
He walked six or seven times round the Place Royale, turning at every	167.03718057155086
ten steps to look at the light in Milady’s apartment, which was to be	340.02039661673274
seen through the blinds. It was evident that this time the young woman	200.38702512928347
was not in such haste to retire to her apartment as she had been the	325.9461320681331
first.	282.04013221103276
At length the light disappeared. With this light was extinguished the	295.51521536426117
last irresolution in the heart of D’Artagnan. He recalled to his mind	227.829047796154
the details of the first night, and with a beating heart and a brain on	255.15695464711658
fire he re-entered the hôtel and flew toward Kitty’s chamber.	311.8293426406668
The poor girl, pale as death and trembling in all her limbs, wished to	185.6560149137645
delay her lover; but Milady, with her ear on the watch, had heard the	234.80009005807494
noise D’Artagnan had made, and opening the door, said, “Come in.”	361.481491542443
All this was of such incredible immodesty, of such monstrous	236.54086095221874
effrontery, that D’Artagnan could scarcely believe what he saw or what	363.08214138999097
he heard. He imagined himself to be drawn into one of those fantastic	349.72913468852244
intrigues one meets in dreams. He, however, darted not the less quickly	336.5509746140907
toward Milady, yielding to that magnetic attraction which the loadstone	183.76033942493774
exercises over iron.	273.96600536421016
As the door closed after them Kitty rushed toward it. Jealousy, fury,	326.39189989356447
offended pride, all the passions in short that dispute the heart of an	214.2373679420104
outraged woman in love, urged her to make a revelation; but she	218.45304014966374
reflected that she would be totally lost if she confessed having	244.39814421819872
assisted in such a machination, and above all, that D’Artagnan would	362.2155624163812
also be lost to her forever. This last thought of love counseled her to	323.4011156168147
make this last sacrifice.	194.06803605757747
D’Artagnan, on his part, had gained the summit of all his wishes. It	335.3266900058004
was no longer a rival who was beloved; it was himself who was	302.71790016001137
apparently beloved. A secret voice whispered to him, at the bottom of	323.6432078240108
his heart, that he was but an instrument of vengeance, that he was only	298.5369146870354
caressed till he had given death; but pride, but self-love, but madness	292.79893610512295
silenced this voice and stifled its murmurs. And then our Gascon, with	284.89132615787173
that large quantity of conceit which we know he possessed, compared	224.39472419130854
himself with De Wardes, and asked himself why, after all, he should not	288.81952051559995
be beloved for himself?	345.36542735882085
He was absorbed entirely by the sensations of the moment. Milady was no	269.59697357659525
longer for him that woman of fatal intentions who had for a moment	195.46779048382467
terrified him; she was an ardent, passionate mistress, abandoning	307.4390768925755
herself to love which she also seemed to feel. Two hours thus glided	284.45644563511496
away. When the transports of the two lovers were calmer, Milady, who	208.70637327368968
had not the same motives for forgetfulness that D’Artagnan had, was the	274.78541270028643
first to return to reality, and asked the young man if the means which	346.97228862149166
were on the morrow to bring on the encounter between him and De Wardes	224.33398087721758
were already arranged in his mind.	268.430980952964
But D’Artagnan, whose ideas had taken quite another course, forgot	227.74031217563316
himself like a fool, and answered gallantly that it was too late to	360.955453857336
think about duels and sword thrusts.	296.415848229118
This coldness toward the only interests that occupied her mind	290.6543092395892
terrified Milady, whose questions became more pressing.	206.69683982178847
Then D’Artagnan, who had never seriously thought of this impossible	205.70894721440482
duel, endeavored to turn the conversation; but he could not succeed.	284.1376968404536
Milady kept him within the limits she had traced beforehand with her	284.18052636804066
irresistible spirit and her iron will.	245.8703124793846
D’Artagnan fancied himself very cunning when advising Milady to	227.03215822571008
renounce, by pardoning De Wardes, the furious projects she had formed.	251.98895429592454
But at the first word the young woman started, and exclaimed in a	191.4438151795273
sharp, bantering tone, which sounded strangely in the darkness, “Are	209.12637167744256
you afraid, dear Monsieur d’Artagnan?”	260.2192596243294
“You cannot think so, dear love!” replied D’Artagnan; “but now, suppose	201.60246165197603
this poor Comte de Wardes were less guilty than you think him?”	357.80959529333734
“At all events,” said Milady, seriously, “he has deceived me, and from	239.37028231591233
the moment he deceived me, he merited death.”	276.96577785518457
“He shall die, then, since you condemn him!” said D’Artagnan, in so	214.5162340443743
firm a tone that it appeared to Milady an undoubted proof of devotion.	308.0830269124725
This reassured her.	310.8541149377302
We cannot say how long the night seemed to Milady, but D’Artagnan	290.86846107848504
believed it to be hardly two hours before the daylight peeped through	287.92019784607885
the window blinds, and invaded the chamber with its paleness. Seeing	196.0214347162554
D’Artagnan about to leave her, Milady recalled his promise to avenge	205.12518422947585
her on the Comte de Wardes.	181.13632858755847
“I am quite ready,” said D’Artagnan; “but in the first place I should	174.1378243442825
like to be certain of one thing.”	210.5096564034923
“And what is that?” asked Milady.	169.41322184757445
“That is, whether you really love me?”	213.97824000896392
“I have given you proof of that, it seems to me.”	225.80868666100957
“And I am yours, body and soul!”	344.4548190927419
“Thanks, my brave lover; but as you are satisfied of my love, you must,	194.5435291510679
in your turn, satisfy me of yours. Is it not so?”	216.92658253390897
“Certainly; but if you love me as much as you say,” replied D’Artagnan,	220.077831613922
“do you not entertain a little fear on my account?”	350.27591461213524
“What have I to fear?”	243.5632739949815
“Why, that I may be dangerously wounded—killed even.”	292.6898829646739
“Impossible!” cried Milady, “you are such a valiant man, and such an	173.53613134619994
expert swordsman.”	266.9341771747295
“You would not, then, prefer a method,” resumed D’Artagnan, “which	281.4098527164128
would equally avenge you while rendering the combat useless?”	339.47258095237646
Milady looked at her lover in silence. The pale light of the first rays	324.55554207957823
of day gave to her clear eyes a strangely frightful expression.	358.28307704125615
“Really,” said she, “I believe you now begin to hesitate.”	332.8558511136454
“No, I do not hesitate; but I really pity this poor Comte de Wardes,	309.2572239633516
since you have ceased to love him. I think that a man must be so	196.7422211135438
severely punished by the loss of your love that he stands in need of no	176.45843358390164
other chastisement.”	300.86695919603244
“Who told you that I loved him?” asked Milady, sharply.	243.75371219830242
“At least, I am now at liberty to believe, without too much fatuity,	233.57805995121146
that you love another,” said the young man, in a caressing tone, “and I	278.51647118130904
repeat that I am really interested for the count.”	199.66674093130166
“You?” asked Milady.	181.5756471010576
“Yes, I.”	293.05691327846677
“And why _you?_”	218.92962443883354
“Because I alone know—”	331.04138375849305
“What?”	318.1167897702072
“That he is far from being, or rather having been, so guilty toward you	299.6771791419783
as he appears.”	246.6074735937973
“Indeed!” said Milady, in an anxious tone; “explain yourself, for I	220.8952378010892
really cannot tell what you mean.”	301.8836391251346
And she looked at D’Artagnan, who embraced her tenderly, with eyes	262.05428769303217
which seemed to burn themselves away.	224.75989235087786
“Yes; I am a man of honor,” said D’Artagnan, determined to come to an	311.439188884432
end, “and since your love is mine, and I am satisfied I possess it—for	221.00494181949207
I do possess it, do I not?”	212.773048330358
“Entirely; go on.”	191.8413424115121
“Well, I feel as if transformed—a confession weighs on my mind.”	173.57636606542462
“A confession!”	225.0547858577483
“If I had the least doubt of your love I would not make it, but you	174.29774065463073
love me, my beautiful mistress, do you not?”	266.0546437637668
“Without doubt.”	247.4056165695263
“Then if through excess of love I have rendered myself culpable toward	260.42520055803294
you, you will pardon me?”	181.45701044095662
“Perhaps.”	331.4337072217119
D’Artagnan tried with his sweetest smile to touch his lips to Milady’s,	184.8765358726189
but she evaded him.	169.82172262040532
“This confession,” said she, growing paler, “what is this confession?”	300.972222363692
“You gave De Wardes a meeting on Thursday last in this very room, did	232.10826193730742
you not?”	264.3184985510077
“No, no! It is not true,” said Milady, in a tone of voice so firm, and	222.47606228027672
with a countenance so unchanged, that if D’Artagnan had not been in	276.29947999383694
