such perfect possession of the fact, he would have doubted.	275.2180351947095
“Do not lie, my angel,” said D’Artagnan, smiling; “that would be	297.5471654068423
useless.”	261.9911478587706
“What do you mean? Speak! you kill me.”	260.5083217155818
“Be satisfied; you are not guilty toward me, and I have already	270.76724348418685
pardoned you.”	314.72777332313626
“What next? what next?”	330.9058916250482
“De Wardes cannot boast of anything.”	222.46269165186646
“How is that? You told me yourself that that ring—”	286.88840293233307
“That ring I have! The Comte de Wardes of Thursday and the D’Artagnan	300.8733840145286
of today are the same person.”	303.49004935683774
The imprudent young man expected a surprise, mixed with shame—a slight	187.32533426166125
storm which would resolve itself into tears; but he was strangely	182.25735479666795
deceived, and his error was not of long duration.	303.5088441519415
Pale and trembling, Milady repulsed D’Artagnan’s attempted embrace by a	242.81964877079272
violent blow on the chest, as she sprang out of bed.	326.6408830426634
It was almost broad daylight.	194.9241838650183
D’Artagnan detained her by her night dress of fine India linen, to	327.49461022810044
implore her pardon; but she, with a strong movement, tried to escape.	242.79412897562727
Then the cambric was torn from her beautiful shoulders; and on one of	228.57061555369492
those lovely shoulders, round and white, D’Artagnan recognized, with	285.39525992455987
inexpressible astonishment, the _fleur-de-lis_—that indelible mark	187.26949984198234
which the hand of the infamous executioner had imprinted.	232.98445167322558
“Great God!” cried D’Artagnan, loosing his hold of her dress, and	286.8040704940623
remaining mute, motionless, and frozen.	295.9394910633697
But Milady felt herself denounced even by his terror. He had doubtless	191.82867362307758
seen all. The young man now knew her secret, her terrible secret—the	297.762611254385
secret she concealed even from her maid with such care, the secret of	202.11316113326558
which all the world was ignorant, except himself.	166.8250815067238
She turned upon him, no longer like a furious woman, but like a wounded	198.73943559111888
panther.	350.65085708384794
“Ah, wretch!” cried she, “you have basely betrayed me, and still more,	298.59774832099845
you have my secret! You shall die.”	177.502207534788
And she flew to a little inlaid casket which stood upon the dressing	288.74238572366363
table, opened it with a feverish and trembling hand, drew from it a	301.86559444118313
small poniard, with a golden haft and a sharp thin blade, and then	249.64304122755672
threw herself with a bound upon D’Artagnan.	254.33665677001846
Although the young man was brave, as we know, he was terrified at that	284.3652518679646
wild countenance, those terribly dilated pupils, those pale cheeks, and	196.89145850519884
those bleeding lips. He recoiled to the other side of the room as he	316.11926377197216
would have done from a serpent which was crawling toward him, and his	260.70941316115363
sword coming in contact with his nervous hand, he drew it almost	183.34796769890428
unconsciously from the scabbard. But without taking any heed of the	213.13624822868348
sword, Milady endeavored to get near enough to him to stab him, and did	198.86582589194097
not stop till she felt the sharp point at her throat.	307.26912676898144
She then tried to seize the sword with her hands; but D’Artagnan kept	293.20498137331623
it free from her grasp, and presenting the point, sometimes at her	231.68166508640337
eyes, sometimes at her breast, compelled her to glide behind the	333.051042050678
bedstead, while he aimed at making his retreat by the door which led to	211.72815351856903
Kitty’s apartment.	361.55205728973704
Milady during this time continued to strike at him with horrible fury,	222.59100800755152
screaming in a formidable way.	167.07245916023192
As all this, however, bore some resemblance to a duel, D’Artagnan began	215.51176246725828
to recover himself little by little.	258.26087436146383
“Well, beautiful lady, very well,” said he; “but, _pardieu_, if you	198.1552674592239
don’t calm yourself, I will design a second _fleur-de-lis_ upon one of	236.55274522522865
those pretty cheeks!”	309.55514950314375
“Scoundrel, infamous scoundrel!” howled Milady.	238.2860072666901
But D’Artagnan, still keeping on the defensive, drew near to Kitty’s	279.81471708414034
door. At the noise they made, she in overturning the furniture in her	276.7709215389243
efforts to get at him, he in screening himself behind the furniture to	250.75484853567883
keep out of her reach, Kitty opened the door. D’Artagnan, who had	222.0613824874578
unceasingly maneuvered to gain this point, was not at more than three	341.4470171390242
paces from it. With one spring he flew from the chamber of Milady into	251.43100656093014
that of the maid, and quick as lightning, he slammed to the door, and	272.0911566506057
placed all his weight against it, while Kitty pushed the bolts.	167.57688595650148
Then Milady attempted to tear down the doorcase, with a strength	245.9431881982198
apparently above that of a woman; but finding she could not accomplish	308.06004073309805
this, she in her fury stabbed at the door with her poniard, the point	240.4547643652437
of which repeatedly glittered through the wood. Every blow was	189.83780124021712
accompanied with terrible imprecations.	318.7402891802524
“Quick, Kitty, quick!” said D’Artagnan, in a low voice, as soon as the	186.4105689835719
bolts were fast, “let me get out of the hôtel; for if we leave her time	283.489769054775
to turn round, she will have me killed by the servants.”	276.26348492347455
“But you can’t go out so,” said Kitty; “you are naked.”	241.8022206641083
“That’s true,” said D’Artagnan, then first thinking of the costume he	234.82107585016203
found himself in, “that’s true. But dress me as well as you are able,	209.8157469335407
only make haste; think, my dear girl, it’s life and death!”	216.16239772227806
Kitty was but too well aware of that. In a turn of the hand she muffled	258.98820214765834
him up in a flowered robe, a large hood, and a cloak. She gave him some	249.4146856163109
slippers, in which he placed his naked feet, and then conducted him	249.36530258576997
down the stairs. It was time. Milady had already rung her bell, and	291.05872476388356
roused the whole hôtel. The porter was drawing the cord at the moment	177.1244772794337
Milady cried from her window, “Don’t open!”	264.0451146820427
The young man fled while she was still threatening him with an impotent	213.7125017035377
gesture. The moment she lost sight of him, Milady tumbled fainting into	238.9344951406606
her chamber.	278.4343046689029
Chapter XXXVIII.	259.50874536752116
HOW, WITHOUT INCOMMDING HIMSELF, ATHOS PROCURES HIS EQUIPMENT	337.24570340128275
D’Artagnan was so completely bewildered that without taking any heed of	302.01740856343974
what might become of Kitty he ran at full speed across half Paris, and	177.43817710927283
did not stop till he came to Athos’s door. The confusion of his mind,	262.5685234907393
the terror which spurred him on, the cries of some of the patrol who	209.27064705069566
started in pursuit of him, and the hooting of the people who,	168.06053451088175
notwithstanding the early hour, were going to their work, only made him	342.24371210633785
precipitate his course.	189.19263162622337
He crossed the court, ran up the two flights to Athos’s apartment, and	274.17905021098454
knocked at the door enough to break it down.	213.42743382541187
Grimaud came, rubbing his half-open eyes, to answer this noisy summons,	289.9232968950962
and D’Artagnan sprang with such violence into the room as nearly to	365.11502610097745
overturn the astonished lackey.	353.86390892594693
In spite of his habitual silence, the poor lad this time found his	215.3595391121527
speech.	251.18720477235868
“Holloa, there!” cried he; “what do you want, you strumpet? What’s your	304.72718590295153
business here, you hussy?”	299.44998450913033
D’Artagnan threw off his hood, and disengaged his hands from the folds	296.399261550829
of the cloak. At sight of the mustaches and the naked sword, the poor	355.9172405501767
devil perceived he had to deal with a man. He then concluded it must be	302.0884346463098
an assassin.	239.85010634396127
“Help! murder! help!” cried he.	304.3773301659038
“Hold your tongue, you stupid fellow!” said the young man; “I am	215.7822824174024
D’Artagnan; don’t you know me? Where is your master?”	286.8552444405957
“You, Monsieur d’Artagnan!” cried Grimaud, “impossible.”	202.3715845248709
“Grimaud,” said Athos, coming out of his apartment in a dressing gown,	240.12351038887104
“Grimaud, I thought I heard you permitting yourself to speak?”	330.0411792865069
“Ah, monsieur, it is—”	219.89729676902817
“Silence!”	312.0485523240985
Grimaud contented himself with pointing D’Artagnan out to his master	279.24074484451717
with his finger.	201.058715053123
Athos recognized his comrade, and phlegmatic as he was, he burst into a	191.94405592084422
laugh which was quite excused by the strange masquerade before his	341.6096467431256
eyes—petticoats falling over his shoes, sleeves tucked up, and	182.56486894372384
mustaches stiff with agitation.	265.98769903350694
“Don’t laugh, my friend!” cried D’Artagnan; “for heaven’s sake, don’t	230.74876987526733
laugh, for upon my soul, it’s no laughing matter!”	327.863318117744
And he pronounced these words with such a solemn air and with such a	289.66733638011755
real appearance of terror, that Athos eagerly seized his hand, crying,	272.71262317591277
“Are you wounded, my friend? How pale you are!”	345.97494260407507
“No, but I have just met with a terrible adventure! Are you alone,	261.48092671443374
Athos?”	192.54024409879105
“_Parbleu!_ whom do you expect to find with me at this hour?”	308.2012291661404
“Well, well!” and D’Artagnan rushed into Athos’s chamber.	328.21157728951886
“Come, speak!” said the latter, closing the door and bolting it, that	320.4138736157097
they might not be disturbed. “Is the king dead? Have you killed the	263.34466962990683
cardinal? You are quite upset! Come, come, tell me; I am dying with	193.10096440797182
curiosity and uneasiness!”	332.34313137525555
“Athos,” said D’Artagnan, getting rid of his female garments, and	349.78986654022714
appearing in his shirt, “prepare yourself to hear an incredible, an	253.39727082938657
unheard-of story.”	266.48596590952735
“Well, but put on this dressing gown first,” said the Musketeer to his	343.94578012585544
friend.	352.69561993813596
D’Artagnan donned the robe as quickly as he could, mistaking one sleeve	304.7617342018608
for the other, so greatly was he still agitated.	260.28562552862167
“Well?” said Athos.	190.60608366391142
“Well,” replied D’Artagnan, bending his mouth to Athos’s ear, and	231.61472321691144
lowering his voice, “Milady is marked with a _fleur-de-lis_ upon her	324.20424422250926
shoulder!”	256.09571032542954
“Ah!” cried the Musketeer, as if he had received a ball in his heart.	311.24977033048924
“Let us see,” said D’Artagnan. “Are you _sure_ that the _other_ is	334.01661908006736
dead?”	338.88427444842046
“_The other?_” said Athos, in so stifled a voice that D’Artagnan	201.45640441053575
scarcely heard him.	348.0651185004292
“Yes, she of whom you told me one day at Amiens.”	313.76759193008525
Athos uttered a groan, and let his head sink on his hands.	365.5966979949743
“This is a woman of twenty-six or twenty-eight years.”	281.4179437361834
“Fair,” said Athos, “is she not?”	316.7685141101568
“Very.”	199.62565631248538
“Blue and clear eyes, of a strange brilliancy, with black eyelids and	325.37125888423566
eyebrows?”	246.20350897077668
“Yes.”	216.96562671861273
“Tall, well-made? She has lost a tooth, next to the eyetooth on the	263.8893303558175
left?”	181.12600641092996
“Yes.”	204.4744843650167
“The _fleur-de-lis_ is small, rosy in color, and looks as if efforts	171.5017163890204
had been made to efface it by the application of poultices?”	191.91637369608102
“Yes.”	259.3869198317164
“But you say she is English?”	223.268702906626
“She is called Milady, but she may be French. Lord de Winter is only	221.19991636159614
her brother-in-law.”	235.96424770976463
“I will see her, D’Artagnan!”	218.3669452431089
“Beware, Athos, beware. You tried to kill her; she is a woman to return	276.85365145166816
you the like, and not to fail.”	306.77265589901947
“She will not dare to say anything; that would be to denounce herself.”	203.40579595984718
“She is capable of anything or everything. Did you ever see her	325.2245264978419
furious?”	330.0832843341315
“No,” said Athos.	258.86283167167187
“A tigress, a panther! Ah, my dear Athos, I am greatly afraid I have	354.2759572742341
drawn a terrible vengeance on both of us!”	348.0292311812453
D’Artagnan then related all—the mad passion of Milady and her menaces	323.42670957577195
of death.	318.253900993016
“You are right; and upon my soul, I would give my life for a hair,”	217.12820176389812
said Athos. “Fortunately, the day after tomorrow we leave Paris. We are	339.03454189866966
going according to all probability to La Rochelle, and once gone—”	342.6059390057869
“She will follow you to the end of the world, Athos, if she recognizes	285.86141811178294
you. Let her, then, exhaust her vengeance on me alone!”	219.51847009776924
“My dear friend, of what consequence is it if she kills me?” said	351.4815427329291
Athos. “Do you, perchance, think I set any great store by life?”	319.4590564461297
“There is something horribly mysterious under all this, Athos; this	312.1795700279567
woman is one of the cardinal’s spies, I am sure of that.”	243.7988517891862
“In that case, take care! If the cardinal does not hold you in high	231.8569554052666
admiration for the affair of London, he entertains a great hatred for	331.8105195502634
you; but as, considering everything, he cannot accuse you openly, and	343.6880913544062
as hatred must be satisfied, particularly when it’s a cardinal’s	177.84117897665647
hatred, take care of yourself. If you go out, do not go out alone; when	218.5747247008265
you eat, use every precaution. Mistrust everything, in short, even your	262.1477625807556
own shadow.”	262.7905252974965
“Fortunately,” said D’Artagnan, “all this will be only necessary till	205.75328649994964
after tomorrow evening, for when once with the army, we shall have, I	303.4258826631587
hope, only men to dread.”	202.44860490474827
“In the meantime,” said Athos, “I renounce my plan of seclusion, and	346.8529423253182
wherever you go, I will go with you. You must return to the Rue des	284.23127874531076
Fossoyeurs; I will accompany you.”	230.21075649086012
“But however near it may be,” replied D’Artagnan, “I cannot go thither	181.58133437531671
in this guise.”	358.7103372100021
“That’s true,” said Athos, and he rang the bell.	291.7004177662729
Grimaud entered.	209.2648534324769
Athos made him a sign to go to D’Artagnan’s residence, and bring back	268.11232024916245
some clothes. Grimaud replied by another sign that he understood	252.4448072393007
perfectly, and set off.	230.21436994795556
“All this will not advance your outfit,” said Athos; “for if I am not	323.0383175733
mistaken, you have left the best of your apparel with Milady, and she	318.5055031309316
will certainly not have the politeness to return it to you.	269.4464832778757
Fortunately, you have the sapphire.”	269.0453057751932
“The jewel is yours, my dear Athos! Did you not tell me it was a family	267.6804063072683
jewel?”	304.31904796699916
“Yes, my grandfather gave two thousand crowns for it, as he once told	278.5456208966541
me. It formed part of the nuptial present he made his wife, and it is	341.9066567241112
magnificent. My mother gave it to me, and I, fool as I was, instead of	223.75987207985742
keeping the ring as a holy relic, gave it to this wretch.”	270.50366736076205
“Then, my friend, take back this ring, to which I see you attach much	348.0019586850501
value.”	231.3430674541737
“I take back the ring, after it has passed through the hands of that	186.3089564808497
infamous creature? Never; that ring is defiled, D’Artagnan.”	219.92102453160442
“Sell it, then.”	361.2614850179356
“Sell a jewel which came from my mother! I vow I should consider it a	236.3273130858592
profanation.”	284.5274794152886
“Pledge it, then; you can borrow at least a thousand crowns on it. With	292.46699387115723
that sum you can extricate yourself from your present difficulties; and	363.20901277310463
when you are full of money again, you can redeem it, and take it back	192.50806349681304
cleansed from its ancient stains, as it will have passed through the	188.41708060758646
hands of usurers.”	308.0579030007865
Athos smiled.	300.63866183848256
“You are a capital companion, D’Artagnan,” said he; “your never-failing	301.36021323562125
cheerfulness raises poor souls in affliction. Well, let us pledge the	295.55224825028097
ring, but upon one condition.”	299.52512636343454
“What?”	288.8048461283945
“That there shall be five hundred crowns for you, and five hundred	280.20271262724674
crowns for me.”	201.10285735777836
“Don’t dream it, Athos. I don’t need the quarter of such a sum—I who am	352.0549036271716
still only in the Guards—and by selling my saddles, I shall procure it.	198.16193243814132
What do I want? A horse for Planchet, that’s all. Besides, you forget	264.6687875869012
that I have a ring likewise.”	207.17462620266033
“To which you attach more value, it seems, than I do to mine; at least,	272.3825439153358
I have thought so.”	308.58413497038305
“Yes, for in any extreme circumstance it might not only extricate us	200.7521243085894
from some great embarrassment, but even a great danger. It is not only	266.3941430455294
a valuable diamond, but it is an enchanted talisman.”	298.2150374495218
“I don’t at all understand you, but I believe all you say to be true.	353.67776473475965
Let us return to my ring, or rather to yours. You shall take half the	342.5095654241121
sum that will be advanced upon it, or I will throw it into the Seine;	255.98476167327686
and I doubt, as was the case with Polycrates, whether any fish will be	175.7882825266891
sufficiently complaisant to bring it back to us.”	180.26788030959852
“Well, I will take it, then,” said D’Artagnan.	271.21076634178974
At this moment Grimaud returned, accompanied by Planchet; the latter,	259.8860135911912
anxious about his master and curious to know what had happened to him,	222.713448391614
had taken advantage of the opportunity and brought the garments	346.858499960414
himself.	170.20090564132124
D’Artagnan dressed himself, and Athos did the same. When the two were	296.9071772129963
ready to go out, the latter made Grimaud the sign of a man taking aim,	241.44676322067534
and the lackey immediately took down his musketoon, and prepared to	217.857989490448
follow his master.	227.97918821897707
They arrived without accident at the Rue des Fossoyeurs. Bonacieux was	314.4235404736182
standing at the door, and looked at D’Artagnan hatefully.	202.2607155478905
“Make haste, dear lodger,” said he; “there is a very pretty girl	220.65698261876463
waiting for you upstairs; and you know women don’t like to be kept	175.76987284615257
waiting.”	299.7648686491981
“That’s Kitty!” said D’Artagnan to himself, and darted into the	184.74712634661574
passage.	364.9485917612685
Sure enough! Upon the landing leading to the chamber, and crouching	227.81546654917835
against the door, he found the poor girl, all in a tremble. As soon as	357.32493544312877
she perceived him, she cried, “You have promised your protection; you	184.27852969357554
have promised to save me from her anger. Remember, it is you who have	219.15006039250582
ruined me!”	330.3530260097789
“Yes, yes, to be sure, Kitty,” said D’Artagnan; “be at ease, my girl.	357.78329913737707
But what happened after my departure?”	303.886552311445
“How can I tell!” said Kitty. “The lackeys were brought by the cries	362.300877151894
she made. She was mad with passion. There exist no imprecations she did	234.32744943030468
not pour out against you. Then I thought she would remember it was	251.83638089058527
through my chamber you had penetrated hers, and that then she would	296.7219811702111
suppose I was your accomplice; so I took what little money I had and	218.327439762102
the best of my things, and I got away.	301.29847033248444
“Poor dear girl! But what can I do with you? I am going away the day	357.8669133830525
after tomorrow.”	233.1522847908426
“Do what you please, Monsieur Chevalier. Help me out of Paris; help me	344.731376714761
out of France!”	250.75367150667708
“I cannot take you, however, to the siege of La Rochelle,” said	190.33426829075734
D’Artagnan.	190.94172593757796
“No; but you can place me in one of the provinces with some lady of	186.52460071485706
your acquaintance—in your own country, for instance.”	213.77043499081577
“My dear little love! In my country the ladies do without chambermaids.	334.3741361030028
But stop! I can manage your business for you. Planchet, go and find	275.72146183211146
Aramis. Request him to come here directly. We have something very	212.9170554958523
important to say to him.”	297.7583843128016
“I understand,” said Athos; “but why not Porthos? I should have thought	351.7312744517737
that his duchess—”	215.2402877454638
“Oh, Porthos’s duchess is dressed by her husband’s clerks,” said	286.5431706117886
D’Artagnan, laughing. “Besides, Kitty would not like to live in the Rue	363.21964283051113
aux Ours. Isn’t it so, Kitty?”	280.5334608136046
“I do not care where I live,” said Kitty, “provided I am well	215.68684037230992
concealed, and nobody knows where I am.”	174.88867017170344
“Meanwhile, Kitty, when we are about to separate, and you are no longer	176.50249957758604
jealous of me—”	352.7764163952696
“Monsieur Chevalier, far off or near,” said Kitty, “I shall always love	305.6980467451536
you.”	209.14612030547707
“Where the devil will constancy niche itself next?” murmured Athos.	356.5297426862586
“And I, also,” said D’Artagnan, “I also. I shall always love you; be	327.5159310417773
sure of that. But now answer me. I attach great importance to the	187.81813799768128
question I am about to put to you. Did you never hear talk of a young	364.9359528027772
woman who was carried off one night?”	206.41690987823512
“There, now! Oh, Monsieur Chevalier, do you love that woman still?”	208.33767553134518
“No, no; it is one of my friends who loves her—Monsieur Athos, this	275.97144325577113
gentleman here.”	283.82615488470924
“I?” cried Athos, with an accent like that of a man who perceives he is	197.814158639881
about to tread upon an adder.	211.1654205799186
“You, to be sure!” said D’Artagnan, pressing Athos’s hand. “You know	278.82209651350195
the interest we both take in this poor little Madame Bonacieux.	341.65748101980387
Besides, Kitty will tell nothing; will you, Kitty? You understand, my	347.91911799571767
dear girl,” continued D’Artagnan, “she is the wife of that frightful	317.724263517426
baboon you saw at the door as you came in.”	287.5010714400799
“Oh, my God! You remind me of my fright! If he should have known me	168.60155144886522
again!”	214.73276976367248
“How? know you again? Did you ever see that man before?”	336.5046683599832
“He came twice to Milady’s.”	324.3535272819912
“That’s it. About what time?”	194.41475946421554
“Why, about fifteen or eighteen days ago.”	318.3193429495054
“Exactly so.”	262.5143077525802
“And yesterday evening he came again.”	217.70523722127282
“Yesterday evening?”	355.6012606296423
“Yes, just before you came.”	363.9729053237962
“My dear Athos, we are enveloped in a network of spies. And do you	195.95960413893556
believe he knew you again, Kitty?”	177.56294517868426
“I pulled down my hood as soon as I saw him, but perhaps it was too	323.29034504994763
late.”	171.45480530744567
“Go down, Athos—he mistrusts you less than me—and see if he be still at	310.29207246512397
his door.”	250.81133808458713
Athos went down and returned immediately.	279.3833150119916
“He has gone,” said he, “and the house door is shut.”	328.31836698445136
“He has gone to make his report, and to say that all the pigeons are at	278.83177434402194
this moment in the dovecot.”	167.08861890339003
“Well, then, let us all fly,” said Athos, “and leave nobody here but	191.92420891329272
Planchet to bring us news.”	169.3057006754778
“A minute. Aramis, whom we have sent for!”	260.4380214129446
“That’s true,” said Athos; “we must wait for Aramis.”	328.3397989842989
At that moment Aramis entered.	294.2438119973241
The matter was all explained to him, and the friends gave him to	296.9191916116673
understand that among all his high connections he must find a place for	266.1074736118794
Kitty.	234.70122047434054
Aramis reflected for a minute, and then said, coloring, “Will it be	239.1671747813623
really rendering you a service, D’Artagnan?”	313.09523077528866
“I shall be grateful to you all my life.”	346.5499526365856
“Very well. Madame de Bois-Tracy asked me, for one of her friends who	344.35629110386833
resides in the provinces, I believe, for a trustworthy maid. If you	354.54657535548125
can, my dear D’Artagnan, answer for Mademoiselle—”	266.2826872659533
“Oh, monsieur, be assured that I shall be entirely devoted to the	177.83835090823771
person who will give me the means of quitting Paris.”	253.33233469707
“Then,” said Aramis, “this falls out very well.”	218.95320827737936
He placed himself at the table and wrote a little note which he sealed	286.5009721927102
with a ring, and gave the billet to Kitty.	293.8311650520008
“And now, my dear girl,” said D’Artagnan, “you know that it is not good	182.5936323695788
for any of us to be here. Therefore let us separate. We shall meet	358.3410271841809
again in better days.”	169.80073923646447
“And whenever we find each other, in whatever place it may be,” said	181.8654285962969
Kitty, “you will find me loving you as I love you today.”	346.5498864826477
“Dicers’ oaths!” said Athos, while D’Artagnan went to conduct Kitty	239.13904011959323
downstairs.	203.56369392898785
An instant afterward the three young men separated, agreeing to meet	302.51261440412065
again at four o’clock with Athos, and leaving Planchet to guard the	289.23962713279155
house.	203.39310592626072
Aramis returned home, and Athos and D’Artagnan busied themselves about	176.57063213766185
pledging the sapphire.	220.96790883239868
As the Gascon had foreseen, they easily obtained three hundred pistoles	301.12824140333885
on the ring. Still further, the Jew told them that if they would sell	346.8414508089024
it to him, as it would make a magnificent pendant for earrings, he	171.9993120846659
would give five hundred pistoles for it.	331.4106713578917
Athos and D’Artagnan, with the activity of two soldiers and the	171.55564908743384
knowledge of two connoisseurs, hardly required three hours to purchase	350.16740820839465
the entire equipment of the Musketeer. Besides, Athos was very easy,	173.72137049708263
and a noble to his fingers’ ends. When a thing suited him he paid the	334.9161105242233
price demanded, without thinking to ask for any abatement. D’Artagnan	308.2233685337046
would have remonstrated at this; but Athos put his hand upon his	306.11355781110547
shoulder, with a smile, and D’Artagnan understood that it was all very	343.25754645642166
well for such a little Gascon gentleman as himself to drive a bargain,	317.96886192010425
but not for a man who had the bearing of a prince. The Musketeer met	175.31499259289345
with a superb Andalusian horse, black as jet, nostrils of fire, legs	220.91355352422485
clean and elegant, rising six years. He examined him, and found him	294.7885805983563
sound and without blemish. They asked a thousand livres for him.	233.21725590259763
He might perhaps have been bought for less; but while D’Artagnan was	321.94054606901585
discussing the price with the dealer, Athos was counting out the money	210.2923463799843
on the table.	244.63478802443385
Grimaud had a stout, short Picard cob, which cost three hundred livres.	184.21970193494798
But when the saddle and arms for Grimaud were purchased, Athos had not	290.9169099095877
a sou left of his hundred and fifty pistoles. D’Artagnan offered his	223.76461441124292
friend a part of his share which he should return when convenient.	313.9228598499049
But Athos only replied to this proposal by shrugging his shoulders.	314.60276158805664
“How much did the Jew say he would give for the sapphire if he	301.316293124285
purchased it?” said Athos.	260.6101030890549
“Five hundred pistoles.”	241.2226373343833
“That is to say, two hundred more—a hundred pistoles for you and a	346.2469148384722
hundred pistoles for me. Well, now, that would be a real fortune to us,	189.63425792845695
my friend; let us go back to the Jew’s again.”	329.8534975565103
“What! will you—”	282.344886495388
“This ring would certainly only recall very bitter remembrances; then	264.71301584459013
we shall never be masters of three hundred pistoles to redeem it, so	260.0510282991037
that we really should lose two hundred pistoles by the bargain. Go and	269.7465874012403
tell him the ring is his, D’Artagnan, and bring back the two hundred	273.6654748727072
pistoles with you.”	355.08387181617434
“Reflect, Athos!”	263.4989064384278
“Ready money is needful for the present time, and we must learn how to	237.44464998901267
make sacrifices. Go, D’Artagnan, go; Grimaud will accompany you with	352.4888110615361
his musketoon.”	292.4040888006674
A half hour afterward, D’Artagnan returned with the two thousand	256.889252194445
livres, and without having met with any accident.	216.08193521841542
It was thus Athos found at home resources which he did not expect.	307.8646217935528
Chapter XXXIX.	317.51295221444553
A VISION	183.83843794390913
At four o’clock the four friends were all assembled with Athos. Their	248.69092096984832
anxiety about their outfits had all disappeared, and each countenance	351.61845964196004
only preserved the expression of its own secret disquiet—for behind all	261.1723456818119
present happiness is concealed a fear for the future.	176.99705409447182
Suddenly Planchet entered, bringing two letters for D’Artagnan.	168.78338706811562
The one was a little billet, genteelly folded, with a pretty seal in	290.21306785319507
green wax on which was impressed a dove bearing a green branch.	182.0915569070271
The other was a large square epistle, resplendent with the terrible	285.98153310275643
arms of his Eminence the cardinal duke.	319.79640521429457
At the sight of the little letter the heart of D’Artagnan bounded, for	207.4897339483261
he believed he recognized the handwriting, and although he had seen	256.1679474909498
that writing but once, the memory of it remained at the bottom of his	185.61307270721218
heart.	215.74654150196045
He therefore seized the little epistle, and opened it eagerly.	217.38080191129797
“Be,” said the letter, “on Thursday next, at from six to seven o’clock	195.97645429699884
in the evening, on the road to Chaillot, and look carefully into the	169.05080699008607
carriages that pass; but if you have any consideration for your own	344.68264317929186
life or that of those who love you, do not speak a single word, do not	349.91883070881653
make a movement which may lead anyone to believe you have recognized	242.75622546279257
her who exposes herself to everything for the sake of seeing you but	166.10837816392728
for an instant.”	286.44230196204865
No signature.	197.12532435686762
“That’s a snare,” said Athos; “don’t go, D’Artagnan.”	277.85919642010884
“And yet,” replied D’Artagnan, “I think I recognize the writing.”	207.49368495280603
“It may be counterfeit,” said Athos. “Between six and seven o’clock the	241.62028885253454
road of Chaillot is quite deserted; you might as well go and ride in	285.6947391081592
the forest of Bondy.”	305.0289124609377
“But suppose we all go,” said D’Artagnan; “what the devil! They won’t	174.47346223384454
devour us all four, four lackeys, horses, arms, and all!”	228.78597162271438
“And besides, it will be a chance for displaying our new equipments,”	278.6640720456749
said Porthos.	293.1621750049867
“But if it is a woman who writes,” said Aramis, “and that woman desires	345.095272527779
not to be seen, remember, you compromise her, D’Artagnan; which is not	339.9852411414709
the part of a gentleman.”	339.9831213851211
“We will remain in the background,” said Porthos, “and he will advance	362.20422840661126
alone.”	228.04052078007155
“Yes; but a pistol shot is easily fired from a carriage which goes at a	240.92033884389798
gallop.”	265.50935936214546
“Bah!” said D’Artagnan, “they will miss me; if they fire we will ride	269.02749023527497
after the carriage, and exterminate those who may be in it. They must	267.98708805621885
be enemies.”	200.85566618059391
“He is right,” said Porthos; “battle. Besides, we must try our own	202.88721502186866
arms.”	334.92117213298536
“Bah, let us enjoy that pleasure,” said Aramis, with his mild and	337.40948125963564
careless manner.	174.92503368378968
“As you please,” said Athos.	247.0653087664233
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “it is half past four, and we have	230.55544474930403
scarcely time to be on the road of Chaillot by six.”	235.63316007364267
“Besides, if we go out too late, nobody will see us,” said Porthos,	195.0655579377771
“and that will be a pity. Let us get ready, gentlemen.”	270.9518336761521
“But this second letter,” said Athos, “you forget that; it appears to	271.61246508604387
me, however, that the seal denotes that it deserves to be opened. For	227.86888264846212
my part, I declare, D’Artagnan, I think it of much more consequence	239.3747311525993
than the little piece of waste paper you have so cunningly slipped into	218.96240975854346
your bosom.”	318.0979022621375
D’Artagnan blushed.	305.28489572509477
“Well,” said he, “let us see, gentlemen, what are his Eminence’s	363.75543578013924
commands,” and D’Artagnan unsealed the letter and read,	187.44467492130076
“M. d’Artagnan, of the king’s Guards, company Dessessart, is expected	178.98958914507213
at the Palais-Cardinal this evening, at eight o’clock.	173.5028410912279
“LA HOUDINIERE, _Captain of the Guards_”	274.19281046934384
“The devil!” said Athos; “here’s a rendezvous much more serious than	169.1466142059315
the other.”	208.74942839183544
“I will go to the second after attending the first,” said D’Artagnan.	181.0981985603516
“One is for seven o’clock, and the other for eight; there will be time	284.88895062179427
for both.”	193.88950154136893
“Hum! I would not go at all,” said Aramis. “A gallant knight cannot	356.0162822932751
decline a rendezvous with a lady; but a prudent gentleman may excuse	326.99971141686046
himself from not waiting on his Eminence, particularly when he has	200.6118351925823
reason to believe he is not invited to make his compliments.”	184.97015069264648
“I am of Aramis’s opinion,” said Porthos.	250.2282882529201
“Gentlemen,” replied D’Artagnan, “I have already received by Monsieur	329.09884970161903
de Cavois a similar invitation from his Eminence. I neglected it, and	321.4817891897149
on the morrow a serious misfortune happened to me—Constance	193.75323761574344
disappeared. Whatever may ensue, I will go.”	358.2686135187114
“If you are determined,” said Athos, “do so.”	280.5255027974639
“But the Bastille?” said Aramis.	246.25358922200374
“Bah! you will get me out if they put me there,” said D’Artagnan.	174.56379961210948
“To be sure we will,” replied Aramis and Porthos, with admirable	248.72343204968007
promptness and decision, as if that were the simplest thing in the	305.0609879223848
world, “to be sure we will get you out; but meantime, as we are to set	302.9319658328224
off the day after tomorrow, you would do much better not to risk this	189.8662485599807
Bastille.”	343.35602826160937
“Let us do better than that,” said Athos; “do not let us leave him	229.1222378325154
during the whole evening. Let each of us wait at a gate of the palace	324.286625970546
with three Musketeers behind him; if we see a close carriage, at all	244.8603397009529
suspicious in appearance, come out, let us fall upon it. It is a long	184.05686113071013
time since we have had a skirmish with the Guards of Monsieur the	181.27574792980425
Cardinal; Monsieur de Tréville must think us dead.”	211.2583828579075
“To a certainty, Athos,” said Aramis, “you were meant to be a general	270.05511909472705
of the army! What do you think of the plan, gentlemen?”	201.43660114188194
“Admirable!” replied the young men in chorus.	282.1885649961177
“Well,” said Porthos, “I will run to the hôtel, and engage our comrades	337.613557314509
to hold themselves in readiness by eight o’clock; the rendezvous, the	265.10212593828373
Place du Palais-Cardinal. Meantime, you see that the lackeys saddle the	184.63724059826245
horses.”	230.4125246942396
“I have no horse,” said D’Artagnan; “but that is of no consequence, I	305.71522654160185
can take one of Monsieur de Tréville’s.”	169.88214811545998
“That is not worth while,” said Aramis, “you can have one of mine.”	302.55218259968285
“One of yours! how many have you, then?” asked D’Artagnan.	340.63503623461474
“Three,” replied Aramis, smiling.	173.9490626274018
“_Certes_,” cried Athos, “you are the best-mounted poet of France or	213.36826206032202
Navarre.”	321.39234031420733
“Well, my dear Aramis, you don’t want three horses? I cannot comprehend	335.99909508885406
what induced you to buy three!”	274.7621742302646
“Therefore I only purchased two,” said Aramis.	168.9442247631123
“The third, then, fell from the clouds, I suppose?”	341.3318007781188
“No, the third was brought to me this very morning by a groom out of	228.76048091284557
livery, who would not tell me in whose service he was, and who said he	330.62953582094195
had received orders from his master.”	237.43434358966758
“Or his mistress,” interrupted D’Artagnan.	182.37369933718733
“That makes no difference,” said Aramis, coloring; “and who affirmed,	212.85053788827423
as I said, that he had received orders from his master or mistress to	320.40770780372605
place the horse in my stable, without informing me whence it came.”	265.4078495774804
“It is only to poets that such things happen,” said Athos, gravely.	180.92997679200198
“Well, in that case, we can manage famously,” said D’Artagnan; “which	341.9960568502226
of the two horses will you ride—that which you bought or the one that	316.99789055066503
was given to you?”	228.6867893058415
“That which was given to me, assuredly. You cannot for a moment	299.28953635212326
imagine, D’Artagnan, that I would commit such an offense toward—”	181.09934175142683
“The unknown giver,” interrupted D’Artagnan.	273.6711995569856
“Or the mysterious benefactress,” said Athos.	280.33761486578896
“The one you bought will then become useless to you?”	274.0880995012475
“Nearly so.”	220.64569411730398
“And you selected it yourself?”	339.10440938503103
“With the greatest care. The safety of the horseman, you know, depends	241.2580284888635
almost always upon the goodness of his horse.”	198.0385590048079
“Well, transfer it to me at the price it cost you?”	267.58194953704424
“I was going to make you the offer, my dear D’Artagnan, giving you all	268.0706120725244
the time necessary for repaying me such a trifle.”	275.6402194405322
“How much did it cost you?”	173.41858354055643
“Eight hundred livres.”	259.993285851339
“Here are forty double pistoles, my dear friend,” said D’Artagnan,	315.4398175813337
taking the sum from his pocket; “I know that is the coin in which you	167.72194744636585
were paid for your poems.”	254.8182518689872
“You are rich, then?” said Aramis.	275.0725590130536
“Rich? Richest, my dear fellow!”	191.99909600875765
And D’Artagnan chinked the remainder of his pistoles in his pocket.	260.4884786774635
“Send your saddle, then, to the hôtel of the Musketeers, and your horse	242.44259317924016
can be brought back with ours.”	197.50174424178266
“Very well; but it is already five o’clock, so make haste.”	302.0843442630403
A quarter of an hour afterward Porthos appeared at the end of the Rue	267.90568819574025
Férou on a very handsome _genet_. Mousqueton followed him upon an	227.17608052817593
Auvergne horse, small but very handsome. Porthos was resplendent with	266.3833314824511
joy and pride.	299.58594145707053
At the same time, Aramis made his appearance at the other end of the	334.31285679789966
street upon a superb English charger. Bazin followed him upon a roan,	317.46171570436104
holding by the halter a vigorous Mecklenburg horse; this was	210.33275193793247
D’Artagnan’s mount.	333.992863378586
The two Musketeers met at the gate. Athos and D’Artagnan watched their	293.41165993297693
approach from the window.	242.60983961311507
“The devil!” cried Aramis, “you have a magnificent horse there,	248.41797802458106
Porthos.”	305.7466632578396
“Yes,” replied Porthos, “it is the one that ought to have been sent to	287.4144554350595
me at first. A bad joke of the husband’s substituted the other; but the	200.95639690953857
husband has been punished since, and I have obtained full	259.5768291604344
satisfaction.”	184.26293147248876
Planchet and Grimaud appeared in their turn, leading their masters’	361.82496715141724
steeds. D’Artagnan and Athos put themselves into saddle with their	289.26079515475453
companions, and all four set forward; Athos upon a horse he owed to a	178.94631389921778
woman, Aramis on a horse he owed to his mistress, Porthos on a horse he	315.9848549705001
owed to his procurator’s wife, and D’Artagnan on a horse he owed to his	295.53837913560494
good fortune—the best mistress possible.	306.08920043223213
The lackeys followed.	353.2396815073568
As Porthos had foreseen, the cavalcade produced a good effect; and if	284.9696903835233
Mme. Coquenard had met Porthos and seen what a superb appearance he	291.4513977923009
made upon his handsome Spanish _genet_, she would not have regretted	309.64008922212
the bleeding she had inflicted upon the strongbox of her husband.	179.2832522804342
Near the Louvre the four friends met with M. de Tréville, who was	337.4005212929403
returning from St. Germain; he stopped them to offer his compliments	166.27092932378983
upon their appointments, which in an instant drew round them a hundred	305.9505531065556
gapers.	360.2343210775557
D’Artagnan profited by the circumstance to speak to M. de Tréville of	201.68624527273423
the letter with the great red seal and the cardinal’s arms. It is well	298.03637243635075
understood that he did not breathe a word about the other.	246.02823370347565
M. de Tréville approved of the resolution he had adopted, and assured	260.50394269943195
him that if on the morrow he did not appear, he himself would undertake	247.29760374812562
to find him, let him be where he might.	309.1207854621588
At this moment the clock of La Samaritaine struck six; the four friends	294.54482615443686
pleaded an engagement, and took leave of M. de Tréville.	241.0783899847325
A short gallop brought them to the road of Chaillot; the day began to	216.95192063551377
decline, carriages were passing and repassing. D’Artagnan, keeping at	277.26161849433464
some distance from his friends, darted a scrutinizing glance into every	168.8382203271923
carriage that appeared, but saw no face with which he was acquainted.	324.3784102461379
At length, after waiting a quarter of an hour and just as twilight was	302.36535616321794
beginning to thicken, a carriage appeared, coming at a quick pace on	297.5638467500669
the road of Sèvres. A presentiment instantly told D’Artagnan that this	335.58553128088374
carriage contained the person who had appointed the rendezvous; the	245.47107831043337
young man was himself astonished to find his heart beat so violently.	244.89627066879783
Almost instantly a female head was put out at the window, with two	189.54189978554518
fingers placed upon her mouth, either to enjoin silence or to send him	270.3312653488285
a kiss. D’Artagnan uttered a slight cry of joy; this woman, or rather	222.08199153428268
this apparition—for the carriage passed with the rapidity of a	177.9499522756689
vision—was Mme. Bonacieux.	311.40882452103176
By an involuntary movement and in spite of the injunction given,	218.32705338067575
D’Artagnan put his horse into a gallop, and in a few strides overtook	273.30198223909616
the carriage; but the window was hermetically closed, the vision had	204.45266107888375
disappeared.	215.3529390725581
D’Artagnan then remembered the injunction: “If you value your own life	244.13862701298945
or that of those who love you, remain motionless, and as if you had	317.6905819517773
seen nothing.”	325.14974496668714
He stopped, therefore, trembling not for himself but for the poor woman	289.38644253274714
who had evidently exposed herself to great danger by appointing this	318.5932642426286
rendezvous.	225.86678054251354
The carriage pursued its way, still going at a great pace, till it	234.9307689339468
dashed into Paris, and disappeared.	195.0682098955186
D’Artagnan remained fixed to the spot, astounded and not knowing what	214.24096815565179
to think. If it was Mme. Bonacieux and if she was returning to Paris,	249.56620828317747
why this fugitive rendezvous, why this simple exchange of a glance, why	281.83529854148617
this lost kiss? If, on the other side, it was not she—which was still	295.51830982269814
quite possible—for the little light that remained rendered a mistake	213.64675795255891
easy—might it not be the commencement of some plot against him through	317.6855393629676
the allurement of this woman, for whom his love was known?	291.9147328388866
His three companions joined him. All had plainly seen a woman’s head	166.36854259062005
appear at the window, but none of them, except Athos, knew Mme.	274.4170730197866
Bonacieux. The opinion of Athos was that it was indeed she; but less	222.8022838581481
preoccupied by that pretty face than D’Artagnan, he had fancied he saw	187.20597709868093
a second head, a man’s head, inside the carriage.	275.9999127350548
“If that be the case,” said D’Artagnan, “they are doubtless	174.35836453387063
transporting her from one prison to another. But what can they intend	319.34823650990256
to do with the poor creature, and how shall I ever meet her again?”	316.3134670288191
“Friend,” said Athos, gravely, “remember that it is the dead alone with	215.13201857431795
whom we are not likely to meet again on this earth. You know something	214.6055646894269
of that, as well as I do, I think. Now, if your mistress is not dead,	321.34450651054647
if it is she we have just seen, you will meet with her again some day	288.8511042536039
or other. And perhaps, my God!” added he, with that misanthropic tone	356.94153263336455
which was peculiar to him, “perhaps sooner than you wish.”	344.3340696118116
Half past seven had sounded. The carriage had been twenty minutes	238.058570451144
behind the time appointed. D’Artagnan’s friends reminded him that he	279.1886215869073
had a visit to pay, but at the same time bade him observe that there	355.39289724887715
was yet time to retract.	198.09937281439963
But D’Artagnan was at the same time impetuous and curious. He had made	241.6767295006848
up his mind that he would go to the Palais-Cardinal, and that he would	309.9789563282775
learn what his Eminence had to say to him. Nothing could turn him from	172.4095382292253
his purpose.	216.34637598412343
They reached the Rue St. Honoré, and in the Place du Palais-Cardinal	211.31057779952354
they found the twelve invited Musketeers, walking about in expectation	288.2091385723676
of their comrades. There only they explained to them the matter in	355.93776815325833
hand.	229.17847562262307
D’Artagnan was well known among the honorable corps of the king’s	167.98705139783672
Musketeers, in which it was known he would one day take his place; he	313.90965335211376
was considered beforehand as a comrade. It resulted from these	328.1332631435595
antecedents that everyone entered heartily into the purpose for which	237.00492595382693
they met; besides, it would not be unlikely that they would have an	319.065242952615
opportunity of playing either the cardinal or his people an ill turn,	276.7079768653659
and for such expeditions these worthy gentlemen were always ready.	181.19560964743644
Athos divided them into three groups, assumed the command of one, gave	219.50926049126346
the second to Aramis, and the third to Porthos; and then each group	313.2911534988243
went and took their watch near an entrance.	204.5115104357265
D’Artagnan, on his part, entered boldly at the principal gate.	307.7935957032711
Although he felt himself ably supported, the young man was not without	286.3778025061279
a little uneasiness as he ascended the great staircase, step by step.	332.79434685306927
His conduct toward Milady bore a strong resemblance to treachery, and	253.88666118120352
he was very suspicious of the political relations which existed between	182.33352869031805
that woman and the cardinal. Still further, De Wardes, whom he had	348.3839748428907
treated so ill, was one of the tools of his Eminence; and D’Artagnan	216.45616027229232
knew that while his Eminence was terrible to his enemies, he was	190.98833842867094
strongly attached to his friends.	345.0680396285899
“If De Wardes has related all our affair to the cardinal, which is not	351.4661679631406
to be doubted, and if he has recognized me, as is probable, I may	354.5748146253245
consider myself almost as a condemned man,” said D’Artagnan, shaking	345.7776299182752
his head. “But why has he waited till now? That’s all plain enough.	180.4737472842857
Milady has laid her complaints against me with that hypocritical grief	169.54399215177853
which renders her so interesting, and this last offense has made the	348.17003554383973
cup overflow.”	214.92637067530407
“Fortunately,” added he, “my good friends are down yonder, and they	234.91342198945685
will not allow me to be carried away without a struggle. Nevertheless,	268.1522813791261
Monsieur de Tréville’s company of Musketeers alone cannot maintain a	243.9498271273456
war against the cardinal, who disposes of the forces of all France, and	304.4422681918344
before whom the queen is without power and the king without will.	206.66666160662677
D’Artagnan, my friend, you are brave, you are prudent, you have	188.16594470335028
excellent qualities; but the women will ruin you!”	232.82522355214235
He came to this melancholy conclusion as he entered the antechamber. He	185.69488145456023
placed his letter in the hands of the usher on duty, who led him into	268.09922487206194
the waiting room and passed on into the interior of the palace.	206.633481663264
In this waiting room were five or six of the cardinal’s Guards, who	316.0277878124755
recognized D’Artagnan, and knowing that it was he who had wounded	244.709971649397
Jussac, they looked upon him with a smile of singular meaning.	207.8225755083223
This smile appeared to D’Artagnan to be of bad augury. Only, as our	351.0460697346136
Gascon was not easily intimidated—or rather, thanks to a great pride	212.4217918365581
natural to the men of his country, he did not allow one easily to see	347.92841036782033
what was passing in his mind when that which was passing at all	231.55739780721612
resembled fear—he placed himself haughtily in front of Messieurs the	254.24705848855302
Guards, and waited with his hand on his hip, in an attitude by no means	251.87393284706806
deficient in majesty.	222.8543265342982
The usher returned and made a sign to D’Artagnan to follow him. It	304.6047692121176
appeared to the young man that the Guards, on seeing him depart,	249.83590625665445
chuckled among themselves.	176.56660312620295
He traversed a corridor, crossed a grand saloon, entered a library, and	340.25836383188505
found himself in the presence of a man seated at a desk and writing.	312.9521502070967
The usher introduced him, and retired without speaking a word.	271.2392695878122
D’Artagnan remained standing and examined this man.	288.74261052405683
D’Artagnan at first believed that he had to do with some judge	350.64176674897783
examining his papers; but he perceived that the man at the desk wrote,	298.15264121007937
or rather corrected, lines of unequal length, scanning the words on his	239.04174812160994
fingers. He saw then that he was with a poet. At the end of an instant	324.67872296652024
the poet closed his manuscript, upon the cover of which was written	296.338270456784
“Mirame, a Tragedy in Five Acts,” and raised his head.	179.77866135567686
D’Artagnan recognized the cardinal.	246.48873126679976
Chapter XL.	294.38947103711297
A TERRIBLE VISION	322.21161754013406
The cardinal leaned his elbow on his manuscript, his cheek upon his	257.3656947981791
hand, and looked intently at the young man for a moment. No one had a	272.81234272698896
more searching eye than the Cardinal de Richelieu, and D’Artagnan felt	185.55433719416266
this glance run through his veins like a fever.	299.75104058363115
He however kept a good countenance, holding his hat in his hand and	185.10953077177652
awaiting the good pleasure of his Eminence, without too much assurance,	289.63592860092507
but also without too much humility.	360.8801041586331
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “are you a D’Artagnan from Béarn?”	317.0888373262035
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the young man.	182.6600441749938
“There are several branches of the D’Artagnans at Tarbes and in its	222.9609957724635
environs,” said the cardinal; “to which do you belong?”	258.2742148974094
“I am the son of him who served in the Religious Wars under the great	172.91715802258702
King Henry, the father of his gracious Majesty.”	356.27930863273264
“That is well. It is you who set out seven or eight months ago from	297.4717327670145
your country to seek your fortune in the capital?”	242.60924501497874
“Yes, monseigneur.”	259.8664802067747
“You came through Meung, where something befell you. I don’t very well	237.72647587678182
know what, but still something.”	283.8988131173329
“Monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan, “this was what happened to me—”	320.6584361388461
“Never mind, never mind!” resumed the cardinal, with a smile which	339.86975000939947
indicated that he knew the story as well as he who wished to relate it.	213.79867142013484
“You were recommended to Monsieur de Tréville, were you not?”	297.979676422236
“Yes, monseigneur; but in that unfortunate affair at Meung—”	211.90472425295945
“The letter was lost,” replied his Eminence; “yes, I know that. But	231.86094289236235
Monsieur de Tréville is a skilled physiognomist, who knows men at first	344.5137105984642
sight; and he placed you in the company of his brother-in-law, Monsieur	193.07169245903128
Dessessart, leaving you to hope that one day or other you should enter	332.73543718679934
the Musketeers.”	166.40216491695443
“Monseigneur is correctly informed,” said D’Artagnan.	285.68543829938346
“Since that time many things have happened to you. You were walking one	352.4324184061737
day behind the Chartreux, when it would have been better if you had	269.44314643057896
been elsewhere. Then you took with your friends a journey to the waters	235.212607806678
of Forges; they stopped on the road, but you continued yours. That is	298.1896022584828
all very simple: you had business in England.”	356.3908767940859
“Monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan, quite confused, “I went—”	295.8251930824133
“Hunting at Windsor, or elsewhere—that concerns nobody. I know, because	239.21658838560427
it is my office to know everything. On your return you were received by	213.93470837559272
an august personage, and I perceive with pleasure that you preserve the	259.03025673571716
souvenir she gave you.”	232.21372990971844
D’Artagnan placed his hand upon the queen’s diamond, which he wore, and	284.9354250285471
quickly turned the stone inward; but it was too late.	350.45907869340397
“The day after that, you received a visit from Cavois,” resumed the	307.5714819645267
cardinal. “He went to desire you to come to the palace. You have not	198.51682799168424
returned that visit, and you were wrong.”	240.9952720408424
“Monseigneur, I feared I had incurred disgrace with your Eminence.”	348.4250029909839
“How could that be, monsieur? Could you incur my displeasure by having	196.54055557091226
followed the orders of your superiors with more intelligence and	189.06690577330096
courage than another would have done? It is the people who do not obey	347.34577810074893
that I punish, and not those who, like you, obey—but too well. As a	175.4188903498965
proof, remember the date of the day on which I had you bidden to come	292.61000004422664
to me, and seek in your memory for what happened to you that very	220.53343834454753
night.”	254.33144439289322
That was the very evening when the abduction of Mme. Bonacieux took	261.7310684035987
place. D’Artagnan trembled; and he likewise recollected that during the	174.71370309232182
past half hour the poor woman had passed close to him, without doubt	198.43332605701414
carried away by the same power that had caused her disappearance.	197.41370432305274
“In short,” continued the cardinal, “as I have heard nothing of you for	248.11982724275472
some time past, I wished to know what you were doing. Besides, you owe	259.93685392606443
me some thanks. You must yourself have remarked how much you have been	232.4245866012427
considered in all the circumstances.”	295.99207014670213
D’Artagnan bowed with respect.	166.85154665191848
“That,” continued the cardinal, “arose not only from a feeling of	245.8142531831636
natural equity, but likewise from a plan I have marked out with respect	360.92178667472865
to you.”	315.41493929503247
D’Artagnan became more and more astonished.	349.02504075824777
“I wished to explain this plan to you on the day you received my first	194.57665804410757
invitation; but you did not come. Fortunately, nothing is lost by this	178.20443803942413
delay, and you are now about to hear it. Sit down there, before me,	236.69800954970387
D’Artagnan; you are gentleman enough not to listen standing.” And the	296.7167891341679
cardinal pointed with his finger to a chair for the young man, who was	355.19553520226697
so astonished at what was passing that he awaited a second sign from	172.31300132047053
his interlocutor before he obeyed.	280.46487725718947
“You are brave, Monsieur d’Artagnan,” continued his Eminence; “you are	171.77345637938544
prudent, which is still better. I like men of head and heart. Don’t be	240.07410537201886
afraid,” said he, smiling. “By men of heart I mean men of courage. But	351.05129632498097
young as you are, and scarcely entering into the world, you have	227.1444553844663
powerful enemies; if you do not take great heed, they will destroy	201.4443296292864
you.”	176.91496987753342
“Alas, monseigneur!” replied the young man, “very easily, no doubt, for	298.0334888838354
they are strong and well supported, while I am alone.”	255.1661066160179
“Yes, that’s true; but alone as you are, you have done much already,	232.902673191839
and will do still more, I don’t doubt. Yet you have need, I believe, to	196.47469210245657
be guided in the adventurous career you have undertaken; for, if I	295.0856132373906
mistake not, you came to Paris with the ambitious idea of making your	361.00637107347137
fortune.”	174.95894478687148
“I am at the age of extravagant hopes, monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan.	265.3402321512691
“There are no extravagant hopes but for fools, monsieur, and you are a	193.55128336799328
man of understanding. Now, what would you say to an ensign’s commission	277.31137724868745
in my Guards, and a company after the campaign?”	270.3506416212762
“Ah, monseigneur.”	297.1957472941285
“You accept it, do you not?”	269.58098977939835
“Monseigneur,” replied D’Artagnan, with an embarrassed air.	322.77137207698956
“How? You refuse?” cried the cardinal, with astonishment.	214.0321823911762
“I am in his Majesty’s Guards, monseigneur, and I have no reason to be	224.9414491255086
dissatisfied.”	302.01865550862
“But it appears to me that my Guards—mine—are also his Majesty’s	174.5634521195061
Guards; and whoever serves in a French corps serves the king.”	363.2472898342338
“Monseigneur, your Eminence has ill understood my words.”	238.2410484500855
“You want a pretext, do you not? I comprehend. Well, you have this	208.703395423649
excuse: advancement, the opening campaign, the opportunity which I	225.99181421190104
offer you—so much for the world. As regards yourself, the need of	270.0501418214013
protection; for it is fit you should know, Monsieur d’Artagnan, that I	204.25050255678073
have received heavy and serious complaints against you. You do not	215.36606326077992
consecrate your days and nights wholly to the king’s service.”	245.0348722764563
D’Artagnan colored.	273.05547567236175
“In fact,” said the cardinal, placing his hand upon a bundle of papers,	302.97844253059213
“I have here a whole pile which concerns you. I know you to be a man of	362.76493143589073
resolution; and your services, well directed, instead of leading you to	333.1865791310284
ill, might be very advantageous to you. Come; reflect, and decide.”	170.42247028746283
“Your goodness confounds me, monseigneur,” replied D’Artagnan, “and I	197.16673639104735
am conscious of a greatness of soul in your Eminence that makes me mean	351.14536664103366
as an earthworm; but since Monseigneur permits me to speak freely—”	186.09061808129732
D’Artagnan paused.	222.3582318355372
“Yes; speak.”	219.9842124990471
“Then, I will presume to say that all my friends are in the king’s	301.40359716752914
Musketeers and Guards, and that by an inconceivable fatality my enemies	230.32914672994403
are in the service of your Eminence; I should, therefore, be ill	216.87931101583513
received here and ill regarded there if I accepted what Monseigneur	231.84817524941403
offers me.”	201.96590226725232
“Do you happen to entertain the haughty idea that I have not yet made	255.95066174395814
you an offer equal to your value?” asked the cardinal, with a smile of	259.05173491951814
disdain.	225.7116424121978
“Monseigneur, your Eminence is a hundred times too kind to me; and on	258.55095860671486
the contrary, I think I have not proved myself worthy of your goodness.	240.50774506103292
The siege of La Rochelle is about to be resumed, monseigneur. I shall	229.4246966635372
serve under the eye of your Eminence, and if I have the good fortune to	327.22389081411325
conduct myself at the siege in such a manner as merits your attention,	210.43994106749042
then I shall at least leave behind me some brilliant action to justify	335.3472488103141
the protection with which you honor me. Everything is best in its time,	185.5741411800763
monseigneur. Hereafter, perhaps, I shall have the right of _giving_	255.23126366738614
myself; at present I shall appear to sell myself.”	284.7479818812575
“That is to say, you refuse to serve me, monsieur,” said the cardinal,	322.0336317499067
with a tone of vexation, through which, however, might be seen a sort	277.58411147333925
of esteem; “remain free, then, and guard your hatreds and your	182.10438200297355
sympathies.”	185.05001814773013
“Monseigneur—”	248.62086176519642
“Well, well,” said the cardinal, “I don’t wish you any ill; but you	313.2226272688923
must be aware that it is quite trouble enough to defend and recompense	336.16067259678914
our friends. We owe nothing to our enemies; and let me give you a piece	300.59229832507157
of advice; take care of yourself, Monsieur d’Artagnan, for from the	220.51242841069993
moment I withdraw my hand from behind you, I would not give an _obolus_	171.77178710464494
for your life.”	326.27598688030344
“I will try to do so, monseigneur,” replied the Gascon, with a noble	257.85169934050305
confidence.	223.43487358152058
“Remember at a later period and at a certain moment, if any mischance	308.47976031648517
should happen to you,” said Richelieu, significantly, “that it was I	178.7488751481221
who came to seek you, and that I did all in my power to prevent this	265.5336109715264
misfortune befalling you.”	171.95897561420023
“I shall entertain, whatever may happen,” said D’Artagnan, placing his	225.78709337492555
hand upon his breast and bowing, “an eternal gratitude toward your	330.9324590257347
Eminence for that which you now do for me.”	259.15215068710177
“Well, let it be, then, as you have said, Monsieur d’Artagnan; we shall	194.59928022210113
see each other again after the campaign. I will have my eye upon you,	186.655537983584
for I shall be there,” replied the cardinal, pointing with his finger	239.67466768929944
to a magnificent suit of armor he was to wear, “and on our return,	350.7890655339965
well—we will settle our account!”	286.5166772549844
“Ah, monseigneur,” cried D’Artagnan, “spare me the weight of your	227.16893515298864
displeasure. Remain neutral monseigneur, if you find that I act as	307.47608532260426
becomes a gallant man.”	254.63875161429766
“Young man,” said Richelieu, “if I shall be able to say to you at	280.84948753644545
another time what I have said to you today, I promise you to do so.”	251.79177656517518
This last expression of Richelieu’s conveyed a terrible doubt; it	194.625204484101
alarmed D’Artagnan more than a menace would have done, for it was a	202.47824488507706
warning. The cardinal, then, was seeking to preserve him from some	335.47149836578626
misfortune which threatened him. He opened his mouth to reply, but with	295.82712483492753
a haughty gesture the cardinal dismissed him.	188.01268661370568
D’Artagnan went out, but at the door his heart almost failed him, and	230.7753271745557
he felt inclined to return. Then the noble and severe countenance of	292.43155873768256
Athos crossed his mind; if he made the compact with the cardinal which	331.0431570392757
he required, Athos would no more give him his hand—Athos would renounce	196.1681460677954
him.	330.66598851019194
It was this fear that restrained him, so powerful is the influence of a	252.85614447897734
truly great character on all that surrounds it.	169.25914789167075
D’Artagnan descended by the staircase at which he had entered, and	256.0113621112048
found Athos and the four Musketeers waiting his appearance, and	181.3225965323479
beginning to grow uneasy. With a word, D’Artagnan reassured them; and	237.89558966284943
Planchet ran to inform the other sentinels that it was useless to keep	293.04211452032155
guard longer, as his master had come out safe from the Palais-Cardinal.	203.20973599430445
Returned home with Athos, Aramis and Porthos inquired eagerly the cause	250.1238114173566
of the strange interview; but D’Artagnan confined himself to telling	298.77151946454495
them that M. de Richelieu had sent for him to propose to him to enter	229.73369560864427
into his guards with the rank of ensign, and that he had refused.	330.2692265975391
“And you were right,” cried Aramis and Porthos, with one voice.	340.13695656047247
Athos fell into a profound reverie and answered nothing. But when they	279.05909252751155
were alone he said, “You have done that which you ought to have done,	183.09929118584256
D’Artagnan; but perhaps you have been wrong.”	222.38932919409447
D’Artagnan sighed deeply, for this voice responded to a secret voice of	175.8011016726974
his soul, which told him that great misfortunes awaited him.	189.2909170920573
The whole of the next day was spent in preparations for departure.	266.24670959158357
D’Artagnan went to take leave of M. de Tréville. At that time it was	273.82693336280005
believed that the separation of the Musketeers and the Guards would be	300.957520871405
but momentary, the king holding his Parliament that very day and	276.1673579703318
proposing to set out the day after. M. de Tréville contented himself	175.9435363609174
with asking D’Artagnan if he could do anything for him, but D’Artagnan	197.5282162903108
answered that he was supplied with all he wanted.	247.11905106038594
That night brought together all those comrades of the Guards of M.	242.85213153709282
Dessessart and the company of Musketeers of M. de Tréville who had been	299.5702521128693
accustomed to associate together. They were parting to meet again when	308.5890733107502
it pleased God, and if it pleased God. That night, then, was somewhat	178.2213748736208
riotous, as may be imagined. In such cases extreme preoccupation is	251.06797313787098
only to be combated by extreme carelessness.	295.2783638101523
At the first sound of the morning trumpet the friends separated; the	186.91121654649692
Musketeers hastening to the hôtel of M. de Tréville, the Guards to that	175.5872477257794
of M. Dessessart. Each of the captains then led his company to the	223.33494341726242
Louvre, where the king held his review.	196.51462545848176
The king was dull and appeared ill, which detracted a little from his	267.28942025041187
usual lofty bearing. In fact, the evening before, a fever had seized	245.7860025654137
him in the midst of the Parliament, while he was holding his Bed of	309.16480758277726
Justice. He had, not the less, decided upon setting out that same	177.3904648938118
evening; and in spite of the remonstrances that had been offered to	277.8059353228794
him, he persisted in having the review, hoping by setting it at	301.80159638108546
defiance to conquer the disease which began to lay hold upon him.	213.5052721911869
The review over, the Guards set forward alone on their march, the	363.6067339756173
Musketeers waiting for the king, which allowed Porthos time to go and	340.14339704599934
take a turn in his superb equipment in the Rue aux Ours.	195.9088799850749
The procurator’s wife saw him pass in his new uniform and on his fine	320.6413544535942
horse. She loved Porthos too dearly to allow him to part thus; she made	355.5875981455446
him a sign to dismount and come to her. Porthos was magnificent; his	364.3065563101087
spurs jingled, his cuirass glittered, his sword knocked proudly against	349.3005016903667
his ample limbs. This time the clerks evinced no inclination to laugh,	352.5126192061001
such a real ear clipper did Porthos appear.	266.3517245036141
The Musketeer was introduced to M. Coquenard, whose little gray eyes	312.93060253209126
sparkled with anger at seeing his cousin all blazing new. Nevertheless,	285.22524659785415
one thing afforded him inward consolation; it was expected by everybody	275.3766132296979
that the campaign would be a severe one. He whispered a hope to himself	337.6350897810844
that this beloved relative might be killed in the field.	333.3827474456119
Porthos paid his compliments to M. Coquenard and bade him farewell. M.	195.75955336041875
Coquenard wished him all sorts of prosperities. As to Mme. Coquenard,	252.47465692116322
she could not restrain her tears; but no evil impressions were taken	242.19962223398386
from her grief as she was known to be very much attached to her	269.0112849582845
relatives, about whom she was constantly having serious disputes with	365.5603347976113
her husband.	334.39964858654974
But the real adieux were made in Mme. Coquenard’s chamber; they were	316.70189249099565
heartrending.	256.04767551611104
As long as the procurator’s wife could follow him with her eyes, she	186.45607414730426
waved her handkerchief to him, leaning so far out of the window as to	332.2237613439533
lead people to believe she wished to precipitate herself. Porthos	303.8174205547716
received all these attentions like a man accustomed to such	292.15045650163484
demonstrations, only on turning the corner of the street he lifted his	341.72950896684154
hat gracefully, and waved it to her as a sign of adieu.	178.49021042605244
On his part Aramis wrote a long letter. To whom? Nobody knew. Kitty,	344.53500581332764
who was to set out that evening for Tours, was waiting in the next	211.8425720256858
chamber.	167.42587393270438
Athos sipped the last bottle of his Spanish wine.	254.8620308061271
In the meantime D’Artagnan was defiling with his company. Arriving at	169.22601342163554
the Faubourg St. Antoine, he turned round to look gaily at the	186.90823170459458
Bastille; but as it was the Bastille alone he looked at, he did not	214.12308852919458
observe Milady, who, mounted upon a light chestnut horse, designated	175.00175013739073
him with her finger to two ill-looking men who came close up to the	317.2155401084061
ranks to take notice of him. To a look of interrogation which they	326.7471364515909
made, Milady replied by a sign that it was he. Then, certain that there	199.51947653276
could be no mistake in the execution of her orders, she started her	207.93596085383757
horse and disappeared.	365.67941580462536
The two men followed the company, and on leaving the Faubourg St.	214.10619264710215
Antoine, mounted two horses properly equipped, which a servant without	185.7937500041418
livery had waiting for them.	182.20837206775576
Chapter XLI.	337.4687049287736
THE SIEGE OF LA ROCHELLE	329.86080493120784
The Siege of La Rochelle was one of the great political events of the	333.18464007161094
reign of Louis XIII., and one of the great military enterprises of the	307.6101532556184
cardinal. It is, then, interesting and even necessary that we should	336.8346790967716
say a few words about it, particularly as many details of this siege	225.91100167665752
are connected in too important a manner with the story we have	272.07707738827304
undertaken to relate to allow us to pass it over in silence.	245.01478813233172
The political plans of the cardinal when he undertook this siege were	187.06491762195654
extensive. Let us unfold them first, and then pass on to the private	252.80111253182832
plans which perhaps had not less influence upon his Eminence than the	334.5503538143028
others.	275.45768799087807
Of the important cities given up by Henry IV. to the Huguenots as places	252.0440818427371
of safety, there only remained La Rochelle. It became necessary,	339.46976857435357
therefore, to destroy this last bulwark of Calvinism—a dangerous leaven	190.1086269347182
with which the ferments of civil revolt and foreign war were constantly	210.59774605349625
mingling.	193.54538680093714
Spaniards, Englishmen, and Italian malcontents, adventurers of all	308.75728130659587
nations, and soldiers of fortune of every sect, flocked at the first	337.22506340103746
summons under the standard of the Protestants, and organized themselves	198.1534895904024
like a vast association, whose branches diverged freely over all parts	231.85105588251275
of Europe.	325.3241454077823
La Rochelle, which had derived a new importance from the ruin of the	191.50417116780818
other Calvinist cities, was, then, the focus of dissensions and	332.4717734236508
ambition. Moreover, its port was the last in the kingdom of France open	347.2495834468808
to the English, and by closing it against England, our eternal enemy,	199.6337570002182
the cardinal completed the work of Joan of Arc and the Duc de Guise.	312.80022234502445
Thus Bassompierre, who was at once Protestant and Catholic—Protestant	356.86836589264306
by conviction and Catholic as commander of the order of the Holy Ghost;	198.10797147791004
Bassompierre, who was a German by birth and a Frenchman at heart—in	293.5040901541595
short, Bassompierre, who had a distinguished command at the siege of La	243.2460118601783
Rochelle, said, in charging at the head of several other Protestant	300.27133562613244
nobles like himself, “You will see, gentlemen, that we shall be fools	227.02481134331575
enough to take La Rochelle.”	352.30813011842895
And Bassompierre was right. The cannonade of the Isle of Ré presaged to	256.6081234091588
him the dragonnades of the Cévennes; the taking of La Rochelle was the	188.2490962641318
preface to the revocation of the Edict of Nantes.	309.8536451446082
We have hinted that by the side of these views of the leveling and	207.12400432852542
simplifying minister, which belong to history, the chronicler is forced	242.8286053795078
to recognize the lesser motives of the amorous man and jealous rival.	345.00472292674476
Richelieu, as everyone knows, had loved the queen. Was this love a	325.2471568908431
simple political affair, or was it naturally one of those profound	363.15709462952225
passions which Anne of Austria inspired in those who approached her?	302.4817655451127
That we are not able to say; but at all events, we have seen, by the	241.44881154265192
anterior developments of this story, that Buckingham had the advantage	295.18761738977366
over him, and in two or three circumstances, particularly that of the	217.1489723422369
diamond studs, had, thanks to the devotedness of the three Musketeers	354.01680111008125
and the courage and conduct of D’Artagnan, cruelly mystified him.	200.4902671060628
It was, then, Richelieu’s object, not only to get rid of an enemy of	203.77849047688244
France, but to avenge himself on a rival; but this vengeance must be	178.0371705732756
grand and striking and worthy in every way of a man who held in his	168.0654483924331
hand, as his weapon for combat, the forces of a kingdom.	209.39700046582658
Richelieu knew that in combating England he combated Buckingham; that	234.4348379528734
in triumphing over England he triumphed over Buckingham—in short, that	322.06814565646346
in humiliating England in the eyes of Europe he humiliated Buckingham	233.8000164452788
in the eyes of the queen.	358.51327410375075
On his side Buckingham, in pretending to maintain the honor of England,	335.0093884509018
was moved by interests exactly like those of the cardinal. Buckingham	186.54092242884147
also was pursuing a private vengeance. Buckingham could not under any	355.5016598230327
pretense be admitted into France as an ambassador; he wished to enter	174.58936193065307
it as a conqueror.	350.21933614433857
It resulted from this that the real stake in this game, which two most	335.5222990320901
powerful kingdoms played for the good pleasure of two amorous men, was	342.2313084134161
simply a kind look from Anne of Austria.	321.90845890344315
The first advantage had been gained by Buckingham. Arriving	278.52579024972545
unexpectedly in sight of the Isle of Ré with ninety vessels and nearly	269.71195025586013
twenty thousand men, he had surprised the Comte de Toiras, who	216.53892552590244
commanded for the king in the Isle, and he had, after a bloody	272.37179330284755
conflict, effected his landing.	301.1893249119475
Allow us to observe in passing that in this fight perished the Baron de	243.73504495737595
Chantal; that the Baron de Chantal left a little orphan girl eighteen	243.7032599578236
months old, and that this little girl was afterward Mme. de Sévigné.	277.5858201486632
The Comte de Toiras retired into the citadel St. Martin with his	262.60452201906963
garrison, and threw a hundred men into a little fort called the fort of	315.1883788602786
La Prée.	268.58734466596854
This event had hastened the resolutions of the cardinal; and till the	167.99012267213888
king and he could take the command of the siege of La Rochelle, which	199.80328107715442
was determined, he had sent Monsieur to direct the first operations,	298.2246227889535
and had ordered all the troops he could dispose of to march toward the	318.96043122623365
theater of war. It was of this detachment, sent as a vanguard, that our	284.10634295061163
friend D’Artagnan formed a part.	318.81039980618846
The king, as we have said, was to follow as soon as his Bed of Justice	205.77167483071776
had been held; but on rising from his Bed of Justice on the	267.3324219999975
twenty-eighth of June, he felt himself attacked by fever. He was,	244.33107393171326
notwithstanding, anxious to set out; but his illness becoming more	320.11910943020337
