serious, he was forced to stop at Villeroy.	273.58969517891387
Now, whenever the king halted, the Musketeers halted. It followed that	290.1540299422857
D’Artagnan, who was as yet purely and simply in the Guards, found	167.51649159079923
himself, for the time at least, separated from his good friends—Athos,	312.44026554236916
Porthos, and Aramis. This separation, which was no more than an	334.0696305134419
unpleasant circumstance, would have certainly become a cause of serious	281.7856988139083
uneasiness if he had been able to guess by what unknown dangers he was	243.04396184408657
surrounded.	332.9923077167597
He, however, arrived without accident in the camp established before La	229.33079033927726
Rochelle, on the tenth of the month of September of the year 1627.	211.5843659143892
Everything was in the same state. The Duke of Buckingham and his	330.9478005508417
English, masters of the Isle of Ré, continued to besiege, but without	288.2113131230244
success, the citadel St. Martin and the fort of La Prée; and	272.0571676530876
hostilities with La Rochelle had commenced, two or three days before,	312.9192120506098
about a fort which the Duc d’Angoulême had caused to be constructed	231.80268177359721
near the city.	342.9943233092723
The Guards, under the command of M. Dessessart, took up their quarters	232.8888582501296
at the Minimes; but, as we know, D’Artagnan, possessed with ambition to	197.0334478434301
enter the Musketeers, had formed but few friendships among his	168.7109436422233
comrades, and he felt himself isolated and given up to his own	316.9427203723026
reflections.	207.9704393912267
His reflections were not very cheerful. From the time of his arrival in	291.5118966912356
Paris, he had been mixed up with public affairs; but his own private	357.56090808562874
affairs had made no great progress, either in love or fortune. As to	217.04695479306082
love, the only woman he could have loved was Mme. Bonacieux; and Mme.	327.42623221876954
Bonacieux had disappeared, without his being able to discover what had	231.13708353343935
become of her. As to fortune, he had made—he, humble as he was—an enemy	358.66099977542706
of the cardinal; that is to say, of a man before whom trembled the	295.0538108888705
greatest men of the kingdom, beginning with the king.	229.3687956590494
That man had the power to crush him, and yet he had not done so. For a	353.0956381609192
mind so perspicuous as that of D’Artagnan, this indulgence was a light	326.0767005337415
by which he caught a glimpse of a better future.	224.63450704923005
Then he had made himself another enemy, less to be feared, he thought;	197.44604455653968
but nevertheless, he instinctively felt, not to be despised. This enemy	178.46090891975996
was Milady.	278.0132958030556
In exchange for all this, he had acquired the protection and good will	248.56419068617208
of the queen; but the favor of the queen was at the present time an	297.82025342447434
additional cause of persecution, and her protection, as it was known,	287.27047325155206
protected badly—as witness Chalais and Mme. Bonacieux.	247.9916722488463
What he had clearly gained in all this was the diamond, worth five or	297.8581289465201
six thousand livres, which he wore on his finger; and even this	332.7682140623699
diamond—supposing that D’Artagnan, in his projects of ambition, wished	284.7923123836242
to keep it, to make it someday a pledge for the gratitude of the	207.46881555276775
queen—had not in the meanwhile, since he could not part with it, more	282.8982431568377
value than the gravel he trod under his feet.	365.15013824761706
We say the gravel he trod under his feet, for D’Artagnan made these	312.2557404488319
reflections while walking solitarily along a pretty little road which	196.45836936064143
led from the camp to the village of Angoutin. Now, these reflections	325.78062440092003
had led him further than he intended, and the day was beginning to	174.8651391940863
decline when, by the last ray of the setting sun, he thought he saw the	257.1603337092154
barrel of a musket glitter from behind a hedge.	174.19606179082365
D’Artagnan had a quick eye and a prompt understanding. He comprehended	179.48244557196168
that the musket had not come there of itself, and that he who bore it	199.15668996824974
had not concealed himself behind a hedge with any friendly intentions.	332.2836851113507
He determined, therefore, to direct his course as clear from it as he	221.62585503629668
could when, on the opposite side of the road, from behind a rock, he	174.18491624031168
perceived the extremity of another musket.	281.04587466964347
This was evidently an ambuscade.	230.9803717813988
The young man cast a glance at the first musket and saw, with a certain	280.093297396298
degree of inquietude, that it was leveled in his direction; but as soon	261.6766496424185
as he perceived that the orifice of the barrel was motionless, he threw	191.5999183316563
himself upon the ground. At the same instant the gun was fired, and he	206.83278317085296
heard the whistling of a ball pass over his head.	325.86470907725635
No time was to be lost. D’Artagnan sprang up with a bound, and at the	293.5415267277794
same instant the ball from the other musket tore up the gravel on the	293.3228308701313
very spot on the road where he had thrown himself with his face to the	297.43629471702127
ground.	315.50106220455467
D’Artagnan was not one of those foolhardy men who seek a ridiculous	209.30060580814046
death in order that it may be said of them that they did not retreat a	266.7753713809456
single step. Besides, courage was out of the question here; D’Artagnan	168.06179331555413
had fallen into an ambush.	180.19520218658866
“If there is a third shot,” said he to himself, “I am a lost man.”	353.8407439311958
He immediately, therefore, took to his heels and ran toward the camp,	277.65808162054475
with the swiftness of the young men of his country, so renowned for	216.05941219043308
their agility; but whatever might be his speed, the first who fired,	361.96695032420524
having had time to reload, fired a second shot, and this time so well	310.65385495320936
aimed that it struck his hat, and carried it ten paces from him.	249.68724514774985
As he, however, had no other hat, he picked up this as he ran, and	327.898328343618
arrived at his quarters very pale and quite out of breath. He sat down	293.1781300389499
without saying a word to anybody, and began to reflect.	247.35419810105347
This event might have three causes:	274.53642285746236
The first and the most natural was that it might be an ambuscade of the	240.15194540873264
Rochellais, who might not be sorry to kill one of his Majesty’s Guards,	230.92945595121677
because it would be an enemy the less, and this enemy might have a	226.5066884219832
well-furnished purse in his pocket.	205.53667342312133
D’Artagnan took his hat, examined the hole made by the ball, and shook	290.4216556107175
his head. The ball was not a musket ball—it was an arquebus ball. The	249.2401712582494
accuracy of the aim had first given him the idea that a special weapon	327.68587848664566
had been employed. This could not, then, be a military ambuscade, as	261.3219830195601
the ball was not of the regular caliber.	347.552911483157
This might be a kind remembrance of Monsieur the Cardinal. It may be	207.1612052522492
observed that at the very moment when, thanks to the ray of the sun, he	191.6338781870017
perceived the gun barrel, he was thinking with astonishment on the	247.66938284587152
forbearance of his Eminence with respect to him.	183.5042958848131
But D’Artagnan again shook his head. For people toward whom he had but	325.48000104352485
to put forth his hand, his Eminence had rarely recourse to such means.	175.336728467988
It might be a vengeance of Milady; that was most probable.	308.6693924845087
He tried in vain to remember the faces or dress of the assassins; he	187.70622387322507
had escaped so rapidly that he had not had leisure to notice anything.	189.53963463554763
“Ah, my poor friends!” murmured D’Artagnan; “where are you? And that	242.87805568923875
you should fail me!”	293.3592504213059
D’Artagnan passed a very bad night. Three or four times he started up,	264.4776174940274
imagining that a man was approaching his bed for the purpose of	207.62820544738736
stabbing him. Nevertheless, day dawned without darkness having brought	277.19544613778424
any accident.	341.3104954048722
But D’Artagnan well suspected that that which was deferred was not	354.71237406918
relinquished.	199.9486745687245
D’Artagnan remained all day in his quarters, assigning as a reason to	222.2259474823721
himself that the weather was bad.	333.50376945109974
At nine o’clock the next morning, the drums beat to arms. The Duc	183.743630508611
d’Orléans visited the posts. The guards were under arms, and D’Artagnan	258.82144742215786
took his place in the midst of his comrades.	173.16543849572176
Monsieur passed along the front of the line; then all the superior	241.03888260275218
officers approached him to pay their compliments, M. Dessessart,	302.6422027196859
captain of the Guards, as well as the others.	169.8340383441562
At the expiration of a minute or two, it appeared to D’Artagnan that M.	301.10897160869183
Dessessart made him a sign to approach. He waited for a fresh gesture	217.92703838075664
on the part of his superior, for fear he might be mistaken; but this	208.4317631532983
gesture being repeated, he left the ranks, and advanced to receive	250.29941134403185
orders.	255.0514571916785
“Monsieur is about to ask for some men of good will for a dangerous	359.8475961847105
mission, but one which will do honor to those who shall accomplish it;	337.01414384338614
and I made you a sign in order that you might hold yourself in	191.34150207264094
readiness.”	237.4104815390305
“Thanks, my captain!” replied D’Artagnan, who wished for nothing better	261.498214646143
than an opportunity to distinguish himself under the eye of the	345.0861451111408
lieutenant general.	200.244801960632
In fact the Rochellais had made a _sortie_ during the night, and had	343.88662904708974
retaken a bastion of which the royal army had gained possession two	191.7295379836643
days before. The matter was to ascertain, by reconnoitering, how the	337.1345501290739
enemy guarded this bastion.	282.4616754009371
At the end of a few minutes Monsieur raised his voice, and said, “I	254.32206528517838
want for this mission three or four volunteers, led by a man who can be	255.63570750749474
depended upon.”	227.70800799586044
“As to the man to be depended upon, I have him under my hand,	300.1365020146634
monsieur,” said M. Dessessart, pointing to D’Artagnan; “and as to the	294.6412155508342
four or five volunteers, Monsieur has but to make his intentions known,	292.8036784310435
and the men will not be wanting.”	286.0080237768102
“Four men of good will who will risk being killed with me!” said	214.472235739721
D’Artagnan, raising his sword.	194.3529654131962
Two of his comrades of the Guards immediately sprang forward, and two	173.31767023734477
other soldiers having joined them, the number was deemed sufficient.	316.23517095978127
D’Artagnan declined all others, being unwilling to take the first	205.84142548500293
chance from those who had the priority.	267.8668145138992
It was not known whether, after the taking of the bastion, the	311.4968632644752
Rochellais had evacuated it or left a garrison in it; the object then	185.89852669354838
was to examine the place near enough to verify the reports.	305.7506269174834
D’Artagnan set out with his four companions, and followed the trench;	359.37302126854047
the two Guards marched abreast with him, and the two soldiers followed	232.33639870011376
behind.	215.69533100455305
They arrived thus, screened by the lining of the trench, till they came	254.67230926565057
within a hundred paces of the bastion. There, on turning round,	251.98427014143783
D’Artagnan perceived that the two soldiers had disappeared.	359.17445651646347
He thought that, beginning to be afraid, they had stayed behind, and he	336.0535980789049
continued to advance.	206.542761647269
At the turning of the counterscarp they found themselves within about	300.24721154617214
sixty paces of the bastion. They saw no one, and the bastion seemed	275.1943785065298
abandoned.	319.0976852358564
The three composing our forlorn hope were deliberating whether they	168.49847137638602
should proceed any further, when all at once a circle of smoke	197.40919719885343
enveloped the giant of stone, and a dozen balls came whistling around	256.46721754699
D’Artagnan and his companions.	238.293796169566
They knew all they wished to know; the bastion was guarded. A longer	284.36824016173136
stay in this dangerous spot would have been useless imprudence.	261.04602038505595
D’Artagnan and his two companions turned their backs, and commenced a	283.00303393609533
retreat which resembled a flight.	168.47278507068398
On arriving at the angle of the trench which was to serve them as a	290.97312840950747
rampart, one of the Guardsmen fell. A ball had passed through his	215.3186856307586
breast. The other, who was safe and sound, continued his way toward the	224.84188018201976
camp.	311.4112973856572
D’Artagnan was not willing to abandon his companion thus, and stooped	229.50142988085167
to raise him and assist him in regaining the lines; but at this moment	329.25382529707076
two shots were fired. One ball struck the head of the already-wounded	318.20464187511345
guard, and the other flattened itself against a rock, after having	264.51333339995733
passed within two inches of D’Artagnan.	270.55492722476447
The young man turned quickly round, for this attack could not have come	223.1255236970067
from the bastion, which was hidden by the angle of the trench. The idea	238.11027233780388
of the two soldiers who had abandoned him occurred to his mind, and	235.937450439018
with them he remembered the assassins of two evenings before. He	284.0671865662824
resolved this time to know with whom he had to deal, and fell upon the	326.18903996864174
body of his comrade as if he were dead.	325.3213178069868
He quickly saw two heads appear above an abandoned work within thirty	306.0711639839918
paces of him; they were the heads of the two soldiers. D’Artagnan had	198.79945649949013
not been deceived; these two men had only followed for the purpose of	305.30616546432327
assassinating him, hoping that the young man’s death would be placed to	244.61448871243815
the account of the enemy.	209.53790454036692
As he might be only wounded and might denounce their crime, they came	295.0305572124296
up to him with the purpose of making sure. Fortunately, deceived by	194.42333320922538
D’Artagnan’s trick, they neglected to reload their guns.	173.8211272316647
When they were within ten paces of him, D’Artagnan, who in falling had	199.72540183436504
taken care not to let go his sword, sprang up close to them.	174.58823265251627
The assassins comprehended that if they fled toward the camp without	260.40198790867015
having killed their man, they should be accused by him; therefore their	278.8318690665319
first idea was to join the enemy. One of them took his gun by the	237.71757365164518
barrel, and used it as he would a club. He aimed a terrible blow at	252.8440838614025
D’Artagnan, who avoided it by springing to one side; but by this	361.9777676145137
movement he left a passage free to the bandit, who darted off toward	229.50479483354025
the bastion. As the Rochellais who guarded the bastion were ignorant of	233.77928178554117
the intentions of the man they saw coming toward them, they fired upon	209.07705636716398
him, and he fell, struck by a ball which broke his shoulder.	331.3911371191632
Meantime D’Artagnan had thrown himself upon the other soldier,	287.85479484921285
attacking him with his sword. The conflict was not long; the wretch had	264.81262681690583
nothing to defend himself with but his discharged arquebus. The sword	329.3210933717191
of the Guardsman slipped along the barrel of the now-useless weapon,	206.19156660644964
and passed through the thigh of the assassin, who fell.	177.9373083423695
D’Artagnan immediately placed the point of his sword at his throat.	344.7687242067094
“Oh, do not kill me!” cried the bandit. “Pardon, pardon, my officer,	284.44642990534516
and I will tell you all.”	174.52908941573415
“Is your secret of enough importance to me to spare your life for it?”	348.8252847071401
asked the young man, withholding his arm.	294.0047073021286
“Yes; if you think existence worth anything to a man of twenty, as you	230.06621946790452
are, and who may hope for everything, being handsome and brave, as you	321.65147337352124
are.”	282.6439021480252
“Wretch,” cried D’Artagnan, “speak quickly! Who employed you to	259.0421342536804
assassinate me?”	278.12905620851274
“A woman whom I don’t know, but who is called Milady.”	324.1043254929787
“But if you don’t know this woman, how do you know her name?”	241.44300176774067
“My comrade knows her, and called her so. It was with him she agreed,	289.6144241208926
and not with me; he even has in his pocket a letter from that person,	342.468650840313
who attaches great importance to you, as I have heard him say.”	252.7184614906688
“But how did you become concerned in this villainous affair?”	263.34636391136905
“He proposed to me to undertake it with him, and I agreed.”	225.4822510206705
“And how much did she give you for this fine enterprise?”	353.66255702199635
“A hundred louis.”	305.3827555744379
“Well, come!” said the young man, laughing, “she thinks I am worth	307.84981265755107
something. A hundred louis? Well, that was a temptation for two	177.1302590254047
wretches like you. I understand why you accepted it, and I grant you my	168.97247841810722
pardon; but upon one condition.”	333.8170805940134
“What is that?” said the soldier, uneasy at perceiving that all was not	294.3618434380396
over.	184.89865635611352
“That you will go and fetch me the letter your comrade has in his	254.0541034689752
pocket.”	294.0357789500332
“But,” cried the bandit, “that is only another way of killing me. How	338.4950138871153
can I go and fetch that letter under the fire of the bastion?”	304.9865751966979
“You must nevertheless make up your mind to go and get it, or I swear	220.2370646791141
you shall die by my hand.”	211.1845507134823
“Pardon, monsieur; pity! In the name of that young lady you love, and	225.95048291189966
whom you perhaps believe dead but who is not!” cried the bandit,	325.35076570126415
throwing himself upon his knees and leaning upon his hand—for he began	331.7306772910538
to lose his strength with his blood.	231.50148969682775
“And how do you know there is a young woman whom I love, and that I	354.77773148866265
believed that woman dead?” asked D’Artagnan.	300.3678799972439
“By that letter which my comrade has in his pocket.”	201.4994161630372
“You see, then,” said D’Artagnan, “that I must have that letter. So no	223.3262614618192
more delay, no more hesitation; or else whatever may be my repugnance	237.93460143579068
to soiling my sword a second time with the blood of a wretch like you,	324.68597687319385
I swear by my faith as an honest man—” and at these words D’Artagnan	309.2274632688903
made so fierce a gesture that the wounded man sprang up.	270.65443264636883
“Stop, stop!” cried he, regaining strength by force of terror. “I will	225.60311387635906
go—I will go!”	245.61271911444499
D’Artagnan took the soldier’s arquebus, made him go on before him, and	216.6847694772009
urged him toward his companion by pricking him behind with his sword.	226.758553746154
It was a frightful thing to see this wretch, leaving a long track of	321.18327656512616
blood on the ground he passed over, pale with approaching death, trying	210.96825318376472
to drag himself along without being seen to the body of his accomplice,	224.49706930884793
which lay twenty paces from him.	184.18726810694397
Terror was so strongly painted on his face, covered with a cold sweat,	249.0873467888552
that D’Artagnan took pity on him, and casting upon him a look of	274.38023882608024
contempt, “Stop,” said he, “I will show you the difference between a	340.7707996990448
man of courage and such a coward as you. Stay where you are; I will go	346.68749213738005
myself.”	267.03091401584885
And with a light step, an eye on the watch, observing the movements of	237.14626651099377
the enemy and taking advantage of the accidents of the ground,	175.47670493706033
D’Artagnan succeeded in reaching the second soldier.	270.7576293076173
There were two means of gaining his object—to search him on the spot,	349.90864063367167
or to carry him away, making a buckler of his body, and search him in	278.4881843438793
the trench.	167.2036118075602
D’Artagnan preferred the second means, and lifted the assassin onto his	283.79556748456116
shoulders at the moment the enemy fired.	176.44970695942766
A slight shock, the dull noise of three balls which penetrated the	211.53129099990403
flesh, a last cry, a convulsion of agony, proved to D’Artagnan that the	224.61680177589966
would-be assassin had saved his life.	235.84805386577142
D’Artagnan regained the trench, and threw the corpse beside the wounded	207.8949540732845
man, who was as pale as death.	168.46054120505957
Then he began to search. A leather pocketbook, a purse, in which was	271.7849104413432
evidently a part of the sum which the bandit had received, with a dice	186.68293089287332
box and dice, completed the possessions of the dead man.	321.50588513564946
He left the box and dice where they fell, threw the purse to the	201.65743777080445
wounded man, and eagerly opened the pocketbook.	226.61865999346227
Among some unimportant papers he found the following letter, that which	245.46533620446587
he had sought at the risk of his life:	238.64436752559496
“Since you have lost sight of that woman and she is now in safety in	200.31693377697758
the convent, which you should never have allowed her to reach, try, at	180.03270579870156
least, not to miss the man. If you do, you know that my hand stretches	354.2131258299332
far, and that you shall pay very dearly for the hundred louis you have	347.3211195196923
from me.”	264.0843912856597
No signature. Nevertheless it was plain the letter came from Milady. He	312.05732458913155
consequently kept it as a piece of evidence, and being in safety behind	269.0508725871547
the angle of the trench, he began to interrogate the wounded man. He	211.5416952456765
confessed that he had undertaken with his comrade—the same who was	266.48374662517006
killed—to carry off a young woman who was to leave Paris by the	187.28064546032857
Barrière de La Villette; but having stopped to drink at a cabaret, they	178.33790123321305
had missed the carriage by ten minutes.	349.9229384199406
“But what were you to do with that woman?” asked D’Artagnan, with	185.71971728025002
anguish.	355.7444482808053
“We were to have conveyed her to a hôtel in the Place Royale,” said the	325.75251301782504
wounded man.	343.98513346252764
“Yes, yes!” murmured D’Artagnan; “that’s the place—Milady’s own	338.2931408157062
residence!”	261.6698001593673
Then the young man tremblingly comprehended what a terrible thirst for	195.68041203937275
vengeance urged this woman on to destroy him, as well as all who loved	210.64473532878284
him, and how well she must be acquainted with the affairs of the court,	326.7913317761522
since she had discovered all. There could be no doubt she owed this	261.0939492453175
information to the cardinal.	344.1786681821187
But amid all this he perceived, with a feeling of real joy, that the	169.57343370937426
queen must have discovered the prison in which poor Mme. Bonacieux was	179.03263502815622
explaining her devotion, and that she had freed her from that prison;	266.52120481151803
and the letter he had received from the young woman, and her passage	278.819012739291
along the road of Chaillot like an apparition, were now explained.	314.2698860801538
Then also, as Athos had predicted, it became possible to find Mme.	298.2297751693691
Bonacieux, and a convent was not impregnable.	213.9315902230408
This idea completely restored clemency to his heart. He turned toward	247.9974078562549
the wounded man, who had watched with intense anxiety all the various	194.02449946439674
expressions of his countenance, and holding out his arm to him, said,	170.6610823940175
“Come, I will not abandon you thus. Lean upon me, and let us return to	354.2631676138378
the camp.”	318.56041768228005
“Yes,” said the man, who could scarcely believe in such magnanimity,	231.86067811947527
“but is it not to have me hanged?”	293.9759332126057
“You have my word,” said he; “for the second time I give you your	260.0802224152151
life.”	280.8799438736858
The wounded man sank upon his knees, to again kiss the feet of his	212.27831308037233
preserver; but D’Artagnan, who had no longer a motive for staying so	279.44991193871465
near the enemy, abridged the testimonials of his gratitude.	289.3755362836129
The Guardsman who had returned at the first discharge announced the	262.6600110587658
death of his four companions. They were therefore much astonished and	297.6935134020996
delighted in the regiment when they saw the young man come back safe	261.62203132543215
and sound.	209.7291581345563
D’Artagnan explained the sword wound of his companion by a _sortie_	178.21707610545437
which he improvised. He described the death of the other soldier, and	209.24577535372913
the perils they had encountered. This recital was for him the occasion	183.45047076995235
of veritable triumph. The whole army talked of this expedition for a	239.70449114394233
day, and Monsieur paid him his compliments upon it. Besides this, as	363.17044574723786
every great action bears its recompense with it, the brave exploit of	289.00176639406595
D’Artagnan resulted in the restoration of the tranquility he had lost.	268.82802784209196
In fact, D’Artagnan believed that he might be tranquil, as one of his	167.47403877610233
two enemies was killed and the other devoted to his interests.	184.80039258912007
This tranquillity proved one thing—that D’Artagnan did not yet know	254.61794175379117
Milady.	195.97698929524512
Chapter XLII.	182.51956309186454
THE ANJOU WINE	169.11578634634887
After the most disheartening news of the king’s health, a report of his	207.74963334796274
convalescence began to prevail in the camp; and as he was very anxious	243.43037860739315
to be in person at the siege, it was said that as soon as he could	185.79897107946553
mount a horse he would set forward.	365.6692816627545
Meantime, Monsieur, who knew that from one day to the other he might	212.17046656083488
expect to be removed from his command by the Duc d’Angoulême, by	355.09236670693076
Bassompierre, or by Schomberg, who were all eager for his post, did but	228.26054364095475
little, lost his days in wavering, and did not dare to attempt any	336.8993535257561
great enterprise to drive the English from the Isle of Ré, where they	330.83606868507127
still besieged the citadel St. Martin and the fort of La Prée, as on	321.1170622373159
their side the French were besieging La Rochelle.	204.31113932621685
D’Artagnan, as we have said, had become more tranquil, as always	213.6629197150917
happens after a past danger, particularly when the danger seems to have	189.1464867857987
vanished. He only felt one uneasiness, and that was at not hearing any	361.7756967232565
tidings from his friends.	253.11371965703452
But one morning at the commencement of the month of November everything	290.86436432982214
was explained to him by this letter, dated from Villeroy:	338.8171435645931
M. D’ARTAGNAN, MM. Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, after having had an	327.5251474676792
entertainment at my house and enjoying themselves very much, created	317.7368918517135
such a disturbance that the provost of the castle, a rigid man, has	354.57230044823166
ordered them to be confined for some days; but I accomplish the order	180.94024489353626
they have given me by forwarding to you a dozen bottles of my Anjou	315.12458572940125
wine, with which they are much pleased. They are desirous that you	256.1547433596935
should drink to their health in their favorite wine. I have done this,	196.2498293571274
and am, monsieur, with great respect,	205.15619194246887
Your very humble and obedient servant,	171.4712084921828
GODEAU, _Purveyor of the Musketeers_	268.0886053795689
“That’s all well!” cried D’Artagnan. “They think of me in their	308.3510788394933
pleasures, as I thought of them in my troubles. Well, I will certainly	297.0417460328813
drink to their health with all my heart, but I will not drink alone.”	243.6278565476913
And D’Artagnan went among those Guardsmen with whom he had formed	224.65628980825406
greater intimacy than with the others, to invite them to enjoy with him	362.48938552021787
this present of delicious Anjou wine which had been sent him from	231.85336969671502
Villeroy.	311.07987211534623
One of the two Guardsmen was engaged that evening, and another the	173.75329279182841
next, so the meeting was fixed for the day after that.	344.35339049337256
D’Artagnan, on his return, sent the twelve bottles of wine to the	271.7240675111676
refreshment room of the Guards, with strict orders that great care	319.725717318939
should be taken of it; and then, on the day appointed, as the dinner	363.2269202778764
was fixed for midday D’Artagnan sent Planchet at nine in the morning to	354.32484897023875
assist in preparing everything for the entertainment.	172.07997364963623
Planchet, very proud of being raised to the dignity of landlord,	251.81545679314587
thought he would make all ready, like an intelligent man; and with this	208.87680441325077
view called in the assistance of the lackey of one of his master’s	167.40851620953623
guests, named Fourreau, and the false soldier who had tried to kill	252.11590248251446
D’Artagnan and who, belonging to no corps, had entered into the service	323.32193930304487
of D’Artagnan, or rather of Planchet, after D’Artagnan had saved his	361.3786186136466
life.	346.55849041320585
The hour of the banquet being come, the two guards arrived, took their	331.06341377488104
places, and the dishes were arranged on the table. Planchet waited,	256.82916348893036
towel on arm; Fourreau uncorked the bottles; and Brisemont, which was	261.8029159126959
the name of the convalescent, poured the wine, which was a little	320.8740743460324
shaken by its journey, carefully into decanters. Of this wine, the	334.9926096334537
first bottle being a little thick at the bottom, Brisemont poured the	287.17350789745797
lees into a glass, and D’Artagnan desired him to drink it, for the poor	360.0806116476057
devil had not yet recovered his strength.	340.0875470202434
The guests having eaten the soup, were about to lift the first glass of	219.06216754031024
wine to their lips, when all at once the cannon sounded from Fort Louis	344.42968745712653
and Fort Neuf. The Guardsmen, imagining this to be caused by some	260.06354142982775
unexpected attack, either of the besieged or the English, sprang to	291.8589222815511
their swords. D’Artagnan, not less forward than they, did likewise, and	345.0892366771641
all ran out, in order to repair to their posts.	349.9554310464265
But scarcely were they out of the room before they were made aware of	244.69854307187433
the cause of this noise. Cries of “Live the king! Live the cardinal!”	252.1549563978604
resounded on every side, and the drums were beaten in all directions.	318.9530524163059
In short, the king, impatient, as has been said, had come by forced	203.50634936144715
marches, and had that moment arrived with all his household and a	297.26030597079637
reinforcement of ten thousand troops. His Musketeers proceeded and	340.45083811342636
followed him. D’Artagnan, placed in line with his company, saluted with	237.2988600094187
an expressive gesture his three friends, whose eyes soon discovered	269.8120801786031
him, and M. de Tréville, who detected him at once.	284.3787966154722
The ceremony of reception over, the four friends were soon in one	187.02344139449542
another’s arms.	321.25107414739387
“_Pardieu!_” cried D’Artagnan, “you could not have arrived in better	311.20102992173156
time; the dinner cannot have had time to get cold! Can it, gentlemen?”	280.5554692960538
added the young man, turning to the two Guards, whom he introduced to	311.2457851102164
his friends.	332.36300891887885
“Ah, ah!” said Porthos, “it appears we are feasting!”	355.92474514701786
“I hope,” said Aramis, “there are no women at your dinner.”	284.51723892457585
“Is there any drinkable wine in your tavern?” asked Athos.	243.35169477479315
“Well, _pardieu!_ there is yours, my dear friend,” replied D’Artagnan.	198.2072474762156
“Our wine!” said Athos, astonished.	245.39271927140965
“Yes, that you sent me.”	195.72060191450637
“We sent you wine?”	259.2000181758033
“You know very well—the wine from the hills of Anjou.”	178.59646131756983
“Yes, I know what brand you are talking about.”	282.2208863513887
“The wine you prefer.”	279.0887554285379
“Well, in the absence of champagne and chambertin, you must content	282.6361830736816
yourselves with that.”	183.06281001285154
“And so, connoisseurs in wine as we are, we have sent you some Anjou	238.12559357140304
wine?” said Porthos.	284.0282753936951
“Not exactly, it is the wine that was sent by your order.”	270.4515155762144
“On our account?” said the three Musketeers.	224.68412246452777
“Did you send this wine, Aramis?” said Athos.	311.46844148273885
“No; and you, Porthos?”	353.44104139231945
“No; and you, Athos?”	272.5567471496072
“No!”	176.2111951994965
“If it was not you, it was your purveyor,” said D’Artagnan.	296.301580383142
“Our purveyor!”	227.3319564585926
“Yes, your purveyor, Godeau—the purveyor of the Musketeers.”	187.22132523555672
“My faith! never mind where it comes from,” said Porthos, “let us taste	299.8459848841911
it, and if it is good, let us drink it.”	360.6543171786486
“No,” said Athos; “don’t let us drink wine which comes from an unknown	318.70208708477696
source.”	214.02483939448925
“You are right, Athos,” said D’Artagnan. “Did none of you charge your	233.36334931339474
purveyor, Godeau, to send me some wine?”	231.33742565223662
“No! And yet you say he has sent you some as from us?”	267.6212137275979
“Here is his letter,” said D’Artagnan, and he presented the note to his	273.79527884899704
comrades.	285.76598954574314
“This is not his writing!” said Athos. “I am acquainted with it; before	191.20651521277247
we left Villeroy I settled the accounts of the regiment.”	298.18757558112
“A false letter altogether,” said Porthos, “we have not been	256.6391267641485
disciplined.”	240.58958258330335
“D’Artagnan,” said Aramis, in a reproachful tone, “how could you	178.32089665568952
believe that we had made a disturbance?”	361.211676651477
D’Artagnan grew pale, and a convulsive trembling shook all his limbs.	296.2451930013781
“Thou alarmest me!” said Athos, who never used _thee_ and _thou_ but	319.7183568940685
upon very particular occasions, “what has happened?”	330.51884395375373
“Look you, my friends!” cried D’Artagnan, “a horrible suspicion crosses	335.5465679619625
my mind! Can this be another vengeance of that woman?”	210.13574094367868
It was now Athos who turned pale.	282.18321367734427
D’Artagnan rushed toward the refreshment room, the three Musketeers and	265.52177646704575
the two Guards following him.	317.6918614602804
The first object that met the eyes of D’Artagnan on entering the room	318.4513829992078
was Brisemont, stretched upon the ground and rolling in horrible	182.1281750866502
convulsions.	288.4377116490209
Planchet and Fourreau, as pale as death, were trying to give him	355.7161712073531
succor; but it was plain that all assistance was useless—all the	298.8752347015769
features of the dying man were distorted with agony.	169.52859002093857
“Ah!” cried he, on perceiving D’Artagnan, “ah! this is frightful! You	300.2741676622149
pretend to pardon me, and you poison me!”	202.33132298167084
“I!” cried D’Artagnan. “I, wretch? What do you say?”	324.8814654922514
“I say that it was you who gave me the wine; I say that it was you who	318.00596462268174
desired me to drink it. I say you wished to avenge yourself on me, and	231.00255130922264
I say that it is horrible!”	244.70103904898247
“Do not think so, Brisemont,” said D’Artagnan; “do not think so. I	305.56791601972503
swear to you, I protest—”	253.85834712631382
“Oh, but God is above! God will punish you! My God, grant that he may	175.22344413683703
one day suffer what I suffer!”	271.4103948689016
“Upon the Gospel,” said D’Artagnan, throwing himself down by the dying	259.40886408809035
man, “I swear to you that the wine was poisoned and that I was going to	306.0359963385616
drink of it as you did.”	249.47031788031862
“I do not believe you,” cried the soldier, and he expired amid horrible	340.4379825713384
tortures.	365.01253149977686
“Frightful! frightful!” murmured Athos, while Porthos broke the bottles	284.30816948563074
and Aramis gave orders, a little too late, that a confessor should be	230.19054384687277
sent for.	173.51983042438565
“Oh, my friends,” said D’Artagnan, “you come once more to save my life,	362.6291149176251
not only mine but that of these gentlemen. Gentlemen,” continued he,	209.02715425257534
addressing the Guardsmen, “I request you will be silent with regard to	196.09962698700775
this adventure. Great personages may have had a hand in what you have	219.2936895517431
seen, and if talked about, the evil would only recoil upon us.”	295.27635589336364
“Ah, monsieur!” stammered Planchet, more dead than alive, “ah,	358.5686913966314
monsieur, what an escape I have had!”	318.396943463172
“How, sirrah! you were going to drink my wine?”	232.88794131607904
“To the health of the king, monsieur; I was going to drink a small	251.26420766248032
glass of it if Fourreau had not told me I was called.”	239.81834292321747
“Alas!” said Fourreau, whose teeth chattered with terror, “I wanted to	257.16963723886306
get him out of the way that I might drink myself.”	218.1639459293289
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, addressing the Guardsmen, “you may easily	222.04366838341065
comprehend that such a feast can only be very dull after what has taken	217.46308668824062
place; so accept my excuses, and put off the party till another day, I	201.74657140135398
beg of you.”	245.73464167382338
The two Guardsmen courteously accepted D’Artagnan’s excuses, and	220.57535903238465
perceiving that the four friends desired to be alone, retired.	244.9988457846689
When the young Guardsman and the three Musketeers were without	245.2080926462832
witnesses, they looked at one another with an air which plainly	169.47133784286743
expressed that each of them perceived the gravity of their situation.	227.50416555778583
“In the first place,” said Athos, “let us leave this chamber; the dead	325.7286902203563
are not agreeable company, particularly when they have died a violent	271.883888293645
death.”	216.9760867331055
“Planchet,” said D’Artagnan, “I commit the corpse of this poor devil to	271.3052008835606
your care. Let him be interred in holy ground. He committed a crime, it	221.88592160347855
is true; but he repented of it.”	213.0695443895998
And the four friends quit the room, leaving to Planchet and Fourreau	279.889582829905
the duty of paying mortuary honors to Brisemont.	219.72355251816438
The host gave them another chamber, and served them with fresh eggs and	223.42614263103482
some water, which Athos went himself to draw at the fountain. In a few	312.75168347986835
words, Porthos and Aramis were posted as to the situation.	316.98904202170877
“Well,” said D’Artagnan to Athos, “you see, my dear friend, that this	306.179266440086
is war to the death.”	240.93839349128683
Athos shook his head.	199.49890086079375
“Yes, yes,” replied he, “I perceive that plainly; but do you really	284.7361534502074
believe it is she?”	321.11249446418174
“I am sure of it.”	326.94836122872925
“Nevertheless, I confess I still doubt.”	194.78893866972817
“But the _fleur-de-lis_ on her shoulder?”	259.55068636729004
“She is some Englishwoman who has committed a crime in France, and has	251.55796504384938
been branded in consequence.”	166.8577219905818
“Athos, she is your wife, I tell you,” repeated D’Artagnan; “only	302.8094896394068
reflect how much the two descriptions resemble each other.”	325.80257133967984
“Yes; but I should think the other must be dead, I hanged her so	341.57350240283785
effectually.”	207.089582871011
It was D’Artagnan who now shook his head in his turn.	225.7725711570041
“But in either case, what is to be done?” said the young man.	341.46050108576173
“The fact is, one cannot remain thus, with a sword hanging eternally	333.4011731388895
over his head,” said Athos. “We must extricate ourselves from this	287.6890827477189
position.”	306.2634997963787
“But how?”	288.3173121185596
“Listen! You must try to see her, and have an explanation with her. Say	264.25956526736144
to her: ‘Peace or war! My word as a gentleman never to say anything of	312.2942383018517
you, never to do anything against you; on your side, a solemn oath to	218.06240922189875
remain neutral with respect to me. If not, I will apply to the	332.8194829272602
chancellor, I will apply to the king, I will apply to the hangman, I	320.71478126191005
will move the courts against you, I will denounce you as branded, I	188.80429912346358
will bring you to trial; and if you are acquitted, well, by the faith	330.9777645654712
of a gentleman, I will kill you at the corner of some wall, as I would	238.9456922037989
a mad dog.’”	245.36434737239475
“I like the means well enough,” said D’Artagnan, “but where and how to	269.3057708974401
meet with her?”	209.4527622522889
“Time, dear friend, time brings round opportunity; opportunity is the	287.19454168695586
martingale of man. The more we have ventured the more we gain, when we	362.0538182515231
know how to wait.”	327.76674725940825
“Yes; but to wait surrounded by assassins and poisoners.”	257.53984303604307
“Bah!” said Athos. “God has preserved us hitherto, God will preserve us	332.4374256067422
still.”	355.59307815524977
“Yes, we. Besides, we are men; and everything considered, it is our lot	218.13851245751113
to risk our lives; but _she_,” asked he, in an undertone.	278.3241298660872
“What she?” asked Athos.	196.71952733941504
“Constance.”	187.6674870517935
“Madame Bonacieux! Ah, that’s true!” said Athos. “My poor friend, I had	326.0371673653034
forgotten you were in love.”	348.99078695625246
“Well, but,” said Aramis, “have you not learned by the letter you found	362.98731372814893
on the wretched corpse that she is in a convent? One may be very	348.4268841037731
comfortable in a convent; and as soon as the siege of La Rochelle is	348.3798266738498
terminated, I promise you on my part—”	250.31111563556954
“Good,” cried Athos, “good! Yes, my dear Aramis, we all know that your	356.3550792547145
views have a religious tendency.”	288.55106502371734
“I am only temporarily a Musketeer,” said Aramis, humbly.	283.50012051390854
“It is some time since we heard from his mistress,” said Athos, in a	317.26606550930336
low voice. “But take no notice; we know all about that.”	186.08719986578063
“Well,” said Porthos, “it appears to me that the means are very	286.80078840563783
simple.”	217.83773961516061
“What?” asked D’Artagnan.	323.0984301192396
“You say she is in a convent?” replied Porthos.	211.60106244338212
“Yes.”	180.39565666371095
“Very well. As soon as the siege is over, we’ll carry her off from that	177.06699398688136
convent.”	174.69995250245182
“But we must first learn what convent she is in.”	244.50696686943294
“That’s true,” said Porthos.	266.7898068013054
“But I think I have it,” said Athos. “Don’t you say, dear D’Artagnan,	342.53981886894485
that it is the queen who has made choice of the convent for her?”	354.12506208161176
“I believe so, at least.”	236.32610459060058
“In that case Porthos will assist us.”	353.2747249932644
“And how so, if you please?”	338.9096153517017
“Why, by your marchioness, your duchess, your princess. She must have a	285.8779314241276
long arm.”	193.1529630104428
“Hush!” said Porthos, placing a finger on his lips. “I believe her to	328.41210793692153
be a cardinalist; she must know nothing of the matter.”	325.3791925470183
“Then,” said Aramis, “I take upon myself to obtain intelligence of	298.54125862134686
her.”	255.82212791242637
“You, Aramis?” cried the three friends. “You! And how?”	174.91708884778865
“By the queen’s almoner, to whom I am very intimately allied,” said	362.6761962826964
Aramis, coloring.	338.5868776043826
And on this assurance, the four friends, who had finished their modest	181.88010054160446
repast, separated, with the promise of meeting again that evening.	294.76956941618107
D’Artagnan returned to less important affairs, and the three Musketeers	243.45570520163076
repaired to the king’s quarters, where they had to prepare their	256.363437376664
lodging.	235.4996791666954
Chapter XLIII.	200.4279674913062
THE SIGN OF THE RED DOVECOT	274.4163106898506
Meanwhile the king, who, with more reason than the cardinal, showed his	285.863843419103
hatred for Buckingham, although scarcely arrived was in such a haste to	327.522256834038
meet the enemy that he commanded every disposition to be made to drive	246.45907369690622
the English from the Isle of Ré, and afterward to press the siege of La	272.53202838565915
Rochelle; but notwithstanding his earnest wish, he was delayed by the	213.71429950075748
dissensions which broke out between MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg,	309.4470814700217
against the Duc d’Angoulême.	268.03622177652215
MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg were marshals of France, and claimed	295.1971365597086
their right of commanding the army under the orders of the king; but	288.6354568558321
the cardinal, who feared that Bassompierre, a Huguenot at heart, might	204.92674110358485
press but feebly the English and Rochellais, his brothers in religion,	268.9091706525784
supported the Duc d’Angoulême, whom the king, at his instigation, had	346.9780552908237
named lieutenant general. The result was that to prevent MM.	237.15715481874247
Bassompierre and Schomberg from deserting the army, a separate command	304.0142376727265
had to be given to each. Bassompierre took up his quarters on the north	182.7506630590231
of the city, between Leu and Dompierre; the Duc d’Angoulême on the	271.96929059889146
east, from Dompierre to Perigny; and M. de Schomberg on the south, from	189.27931559572608
Perigny to Angoutin.	181.1174461591312
The quarters of Monsieur were at Dompierre; the quarters of the king	210.99090519666584
were sometimes at Estrée, sometimes at Jarrie; the cardinal’s quarters	240.00269042867643
were upon the downs, at the bridge of La Pierre, in a simple house	294.7307683801346
without any entrenchment. So that Monsieur watched Bassompierre; the	240.76504015428932
king, the Duc d’Angoulême; and the cardinal, M. de Schomberg.	270.3148382988701
As soon as this organization was established, they set about driving	337.6320482364143
the English from the Isle.	339.5655606155875
The juncture was favorable. The English, who require, above everything,	319.7567331340743
good living in order to be good soldiers, only eating salt meat and bad	281.1105389283576
biscuit, had many invalids in their camp. Still further, the sea, very	226.54331281795558
rough at this period of the year all along the sea coast, destroyed	332.5142689406185
every day some little vessel; and the shore, from the point of	284.3186746352793
l’Aiguillon to the trenches, was at every tide literally covered with	223.58302858828415
the wrecks of pinnacles, _roberges_, and feluccas. The result was that	291.28981397566986
even if the king’s troops remained quietly in their camp, it was	182.06679679920722
evident that some day or other, Buckingham, who only continued in the	310.25898700268255
Isle from obstinacy, would be obliged to raise the siege.	202.25045015837344
But as M. de Toiras gave information that everything was preparing in	180.41440330594727
the enemy’s camp for a fresh assault, the king judged that it would be	291.6038162471871
best to put an end to the affair, and gave the necessary orders for a	286.2828587762807
decisive action.	232.3013350010774
As it is not our intention to give a journal of the siege, but on the	194.38462738669898
contrary only to describe such of the events of it as are connected	199.15782019713026
with the story we are relating, we will content ourselves with saying	300.09510516880596
in two words that the expedition succeeded, to the great astonishment	180.7797875279397
of the king and the great glory of the cardinal. The English, repulsed	304.13154066143125
foot by foot, beaten in all encounters, and defeated in the passage of	227.71031630642915
the Isle of Loie, were obliged to re-embark, leaving on the field of	178.61983529060805
battle two thousand men, among whom were five colonels, three	328.3033082627136
lieutenant colonels, two hundred and fifty captains, twenty gentlemen	235.74532239334877
of rank, four pieces of cannon, and sixty flags, which were taken to	327.0754108222693
Paris by Claude de St. Simon, and suspended with great pomp in the	309.50723626661227
arches of Notre Dame.	249.34401309124218
Te Deums were chanted in camp, and afterward throughout France.	315.7087019408867
The cardinal was left free to carry on the siege, without having, at	359.27244592742386
least at the present, anything to fear on the part of the English.	317.563323400999
But it must be acknowledged, this response was but momentary. An envoy	210.42116050324057
of the Duke of Buckingham, named Montague, was taken, and proof was	174.95177328096543
obtained of a league between the German Empire, Spain, England, and	207.94643587020573
Lorraine. This league was directed against France.	212.38038540638775
Still further, in Buckingham’s lodging, which he had been forced to	345.7540896890275
abandon more precipitately than he expected, papers were found which	254.906268183358
confirmed this alliance and which, as the cardinal asserts in his	223.475527841791
memoirs, strongly compromised Mme. de Chevreuse and consequently the	261.17578167505474
queen.	352.02545753453353
It was upon the cardinal that all the responsibility fell, for one is	317.4687079198294
not a despotic minister without responsibility. All, therefore, of the	341.6875458024421
vast resources of his genius were at work night and day, engaged in	228.84503659441424
listening to the least report heard in any of the great kingdoms of	217.35937406477834
Europe.	328.7054741010112
The cardinal was acquainted with the activity, and more particularly	230.26923671423825
the hatred, of Buckingham. If the league which threatened France	239.91187948775
triumphed, all his influence would be lost. Spanish policy and Austrian	315.9039316807046
policy would have their representatives in the cabinet of the Louvre,	365.12855927252974
where they had as yet but partisans; and he, Richelieu—the French	171.17415008884828
minister, the national minister—would be ruined. The king, even while	180.94391909606608
obeying him like a child, hated him as a child hates his master, and	334.1804305711745
would abandon him to the personal vengeance of Monsieur and the queen.	335.71122213905295
He would then be lost, and France, perhaps, with him. All this must be	227.90063810199212
prepared against.	260.11077914032927
Courtiers, becoming every instant more numerous, succeeded one another,	253.3665840070579
day and night, in the little house of the bridge of La Pierre, in which	303.315590753449
the cardinal had established his residence.	262.3572467767896
There were monks who wore the frock with such an ill grace that it was	279.7801108230587
easy to perceive they belonged to the church militant; women a little	209.5375676297689
inconvenienced by their costume as pages and whose large trousers could	314.02475596642824
not entirely conceal their rounded forms; and peasants with blackened	347.2548185803969
hands but with fine limbs, savoring of the man of quality a league off.	326.77491412395364
There were also less agreeable visits—for two or three times reports	269.63199206673266
were spread that the cardinal had nearly been assassinated.	302.6919102062768
It is true that the enemies of the cardinal said that it was he himself	349.0543745500835
who set these bungling assassins to work, in order to have, if wanted,	328.1121547460317
the right of using reprisals; but we must not believe everything	171.283085611408
ministers say, nor everything their enemies say.	355.08627856800535
These attempts did not prevent the cardinal, to whom his most	334.9504736525972
inveterate detractors have never denied personal bravery, from making	230.62267218405793
nocturnal excursions, sometimes to communicate to the Duc d’Angoulême	179.67760624103508
important orders, sometimes to confer with the king, and sometimes to	290.9639126209209
have an interview with a messenger whom he did not wish to see at home.	259.09409519250516
On their part the Musketeers, who had not much to do with the siege,	325.8857510818607
were not under very strict orders and led a joyous life. This was the	348.99462008913736
more easy for our three companions in particular; for being friends of	299.8014462044385
M. de Tréville, they obtained from him special permission to be absent	190.1758201853885
after the closing of the camp.	242.33252314394497
Now, one evening when D’Artagnan, who was in the trenches, was not able	198.44067553705057
to accompany them, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, mounted on their battle	271.85929112663115
steeds, enveloped in their war cloaks, with their hands upon their	186.76438401681096
pistol butts, were returning from a drinking place called the Red	186.25999218651674
Dovecot, which Athos had discovered two days before upon the route to	305.47575202672914
Jarrie, following the road which led to the camp and quite on their	182.31249874673787
guard, as we have stated, for fear of an ambuscade, when, about a	361.6981558658401
quarter of a league from the village of Boisnau, they fancied they	195.98202561442943
heard the sound of horses approaching them. They immediately all three	279.66035145651887
halted, closed in, and waited, occupying the middle of the road. In an	342.14855783852136
instant, and as the moon broke from behind a cloud, they saw at a	327.7975414336448
turning of the road two horsemen who, on perceiving them, stopped in	167.5823305996151
their turn, appearing to deliberate whether they should continue their	238.0504740278526
route or go back. The hesitation created some suspicion in the three	173.9023399422387
friends, and Athos, advancing a few paces in front of the others, cried	309.7949309327465
in a firm voice, “Who goes there?”	351.5866604729622
“Who goes there, yourselves?” replied one of the horsemen.	315.19743895244414
“That is not an answer,” replied Athos. “Who goes there? Answer, or we	215.81062001879508
charge.”	184.72053989496567
“Beware of what you are about, gentlemen!” said a clear voice which	188.71159579983237
seemed accustomed to command.	240.03035740904713
“It is some superior officer making his night rounds,” said Athos.	242.8948522359663
“What do you wish, gentlemen?”	328.5818638109258
“Who are you?” said the same voice, in the same commanding tone.	311.2277633085831
“Answer in your turn, or you may repent of your disobedience.”	166.41130393986225
“King’s Musketeers,” said Athos, more and more convinced that he who	180.01365778118188
interrogated them had the right to do so.	341.93104743431104
“What company?”	201.08708363955145
“Company of Tréville.”	313.4040646807172
“Advance, and give an account of what you are doing here at this hour.”	181.54147784364622
The three companions advanced rather humbly—for all were now convinced	221.21263733392533
that they had to do with someone more powerful than themselves—leaving	298.99451301654756
Athos the post of speaker.	293.83127177199975
One of the two riders, he who had spoken second, was ten paces in front	357.67373783748
of his companion. Athos made a sign to Porthos and Aramis also to	231.4247050850975
remain in the rear, and advanced alone.	351.86375123481565
“Your pardon, my officer,” said Athos; “but we were ignorant with whom	275.8414875755908
we had to do, and you may see that we were keeping good guard.”	363.299480659338
“Your name?” said the officer, who covered a part of his face with his	174.01052952433622
cloak.	242.16418043352337
“But yourself, monsieur,” said Athos, who began to be annoyed by this	173.20603211842678
inquisition, “give me, I beg you, the proof that you have the right to	308.386499642545
question me.”	364.6410680792217
“Your name?” repeated the cavalier a second time, letting his cloak	236.46637431030848
fall, and leaving his face uncovered.	331.44679187018517
“Monsieur the Cardinal!” cried the stupefied Musketeer.	339.19867093525176
“Your name?” cried his Eminence, for the third time.	327.9924374363368
“Athos,” said the Musketeer.	231.00328532564237
The cardinal made a sign to his attendant, who drew near. “These three	241.33160018913694
Musketeers shall follow us,” said he, in an undertone. “I am not	284.53326326773066
willing it should be known I have left the camp; and if they follow us	278.0486509934204
we shall be certain they will tell nobody.”	225.9430211839838
“We are gentlemen, monseigneur,” said Athos; “require our parole, and	258.40076638046264
give yourself no uneasiness. Thank God, we can keep a secret.”	359.007523765933
The cardinal fixed his piercing eyes on this courageous speaker.	218.95880816538602
“You have a quick ear, Monsieur Athos,” said the cardinal; “but now	243.85677776595645
listen to this. It is not from mistrust that I request you to follow	345.41009253261956
me, but for my security. Your companions are no doubt Messieurs Porthos	304.82060982725716
and Aramis.”	306.6406954452931
“Yes, your Eminence,” said Athos, while the two Musketeers who had	196.0576858431367
remained behind advanced hat in hand.	353.2360132777555
“I know you, gentlemen,” said the cardinal, “I know you. I know you are	247.71811604744062
not quite my friends, and I am sorry you are not so; but I know you are	330.2210010772453
brave and loyal gentlemen, and that confidence may be placed in you.	354.3520972310522
Monsieur Athos, do me, then, the honor to accompany me; you and your	196.01031508736503
two friends, and then I shall have an escort to excite envy in his	192.0050666847346
Majesty, if we should meet him.”	181.49101511684864
The three Musketeers bowed to the necks of their horses.	262.32815803549835
“Well, upon my honor,” said Athos, “your Eminence is right in taking us	212.16430816772183
with you; we have seen several ill-looking faces on the road, and we	290.8066944195965
have even had a quarrel at the Red Dovecot with four of those faces.”	174.24066903304194
“A quarrel, and what for, gentlemen?” said the cardinal; “you know I	273.09454311945194
don’t like quarrelers.”	249.27111432589726
“And that is the reason why I have the honor to inform your Eminence of	309.0197076883992
what has happened; for you might learn it from others, and upon a false	280.4547346660794
account believe us to be in fault.”	236.04793397952744
“What have been the results of your quarrel?” said the cardinal,	209.6293277409917
knitting his brow.	337.438253268601
“My friend, Aramis, here, has received a slight sword wound in the arm,	263.70856988407945
but not enough to prevent him, as your Eminence may see, from mounting	316.6487496954115
to the assault tomorrow, if your Eminence orders an escalade.”	277.898850472307
“But you are not the men to allow sword wounds to be inflicted upon you	184.24003147796475
thus,” said the cardinal. “Come, be frank, gentlemen, you have settled	167.71838322535018
accounts with somebody! Confess; you know I have the right of giving	314.84666925661804
absolution.”	223.29428515959165
“I, monseigneur?” said Athos. “I did not even draw my sword, but I took	360.524873568555
him who offended me round the body, and threw him out of the window. It	166.86726778479306
appears that in falling,” continued Athos, with some hesitation, “he	316.59308060739534
broke his thigh.”	277.4867419621015
“Ah, ah!” said the cardinal; “and you, Monsieur Porthos?”	181.84798449475804
“I, monseigneur, knowing that dueling is prohibited—I seized a bench,	353.30171710501327
and gave one of those brigands such a blow that I believe his shoulder	293.08141879675776
is broken.”	238.0422311081096
“Very well,” said the cardinal; “and you, Monsieur Aramis?”	166.39555509838573
“Monseigneur, being of a very mild disposition, and being, likewise, of	250.2529409957645
which Monseigneur perhaps is not aware, about to enter into orders, I	286.4375759728835
endeavored to appease my comrades, when one of these wretches gave me a	201.5893362950425
wound with a sword, treacherously, across my left arm. Then I admit my	364.0308631996052
patience failed me; I drew my sword in my turn, and as he came back to	325.5249685245554
the charge, I fancied I felt that in throwing himself upon me, he let	201.5190072835628
it pass through his body. I only know for a certainty that he fell; and	291.8775816565468
it seemed to me that he was borne away with his two companions.”	245.2187719454093
“The devil, gentlemen!” said the cardinal, “three men placed _hors de	186.27817962370588
combat_ in a cabaret squabble! You don’t do your work by halves. And	271.32758846016475
pray what was this quarrel about?”	322.4334491419406
“These fellows were drunk,” said Athos, “and knowing there was a lady	239.18142283375448
who had arrived at the cabaret this evening, they wanted to force her	357.1604477196879
door.”	252.37511507784038
“Force her door!” said the cardinal, “and for what purpose?”	340.86315819235733
“To do her violence, without doubt,” said Athos. “I have had the honor	310.07821658530895
of informing your Eminence that these men were drunk.”	310.6175566047924
“And was this lady young and handsome?” asked the cardinal, with a	280.68297274813835
certain degree of anxiety.	336.31766662807144
“We did not see her, monseigneur,” said Athos.	199.404949986156
“You did not see her? Ah, very well,” replied the cardinal, quickly.	300.8536969046063
“You did well to defend the honor of a woman; and as I am going to the	170.20023586541797
Red Dovecot myself, I shall know if you have told me the truth.”	171.51586351261722
“Monseigneur,” said Athos, haughtily, “we are gentlemen, and to save	343.92730437183536
our heads we would not be guilty of a falsehood.”	181.74869703383055
“Therefore I do not doubt what you say, Monsieur Athos, I do not doubt	180.04742092575324
it for a single instant; but,” added he, “to change the conversation,	338.1230278638516
was this lady alone?”	173.36159393945334
“The lady had a cavalier shut up with her,” said Athos, “but as	255.88176285190153
notwithstanding the noise, this cavalier did not show himself, it is to	192.24944397624108
be presumed that he is a coward.”	175.61036267220805
“‘Judge not rashly’, says the Gospel,” replied the cardinal.	310.4924670000772
Athos bowed.	260.67804151947155
“And now, gentlemen, that’s well,” continued the cardinal. “I know what	296.6503432243028
I wish to know; follow me.”	340.81764667025857
The three Musketeers passed behind his Eminence, who again enveloped	321.4513918658772
his face in his cloak, and put his horse in motion, keeping from eight	356.87420740152436
to ten paces in advance of his four companions.	362.01908174824615
They soon arrived at the silent, solitary inn. No doubt the host knew	254.3514529139747
what illustrious visitor was expected, and had consequently sent	188.50371850574328
intruders out of the way.	200.9846588821675
Ten paces from the door the cardinal made a sign to his esquire and the	313.58724016222163
three Musketeers to halt. A saddled horse was fastened to the window	327.2363239142808
shutter. The cardinal knocked three times, and in a peculiar manner.	244.04333357726523
A man, enveloped in a cloak, came out immediately, and exchanged some	319.4045777325402
rapid words with the cardinal; after which he mounted his horse, and	215.4139870218032
set off in the direction of Surgères, which was likewise the way to	176.58868819757433
Paris.	355.9956482993068
“Advance, gentlemen,” said the cardinal.	250.64876862366705
“You have told me the truth, my gentlemen,” said he, addressing the	208.73725744562256
Musketeers, “and it will not be my fault if our encounter this evening	284.9464150123537
be not advantageous to you. In the meantime, follow me.”	290.7054028722363
The cardinal alighted; the three Musketeers did likewise. The cardinal	334.1830483623527
threw the bridle of his horse to his esquire; the three Musketeers	220.21541909200496
fastened the horses to the shutters.	272.11450786100215
The host stood at the door. For him, the cardinal was only an officer	307.67957080366136
coming to visit a lady.	209.78072373831498
“Have you any chamber on the ground floor where these gentlemen can	171.1100523878125
wait near a good fire?” said the cardinal.	215.58368701806714
The host opened the door of a large room, in which an old stove had	330.2341426560317
just been replaced by a large and excellent chimney.	233.3511233856261
“I have this,” said he.	280.0530382770887
“That will do,” replied the cardinal. “Enter, gentlemen, and be kind	357.6980248364406
enough to wait for me; I shall not be more than half an hour.”	169.58294071429154
And while the three Musketeers entered the ground floor room, the	186.53702266736332
cardinal, without asking further information, ascended the staircase	298.03976289764654
like a man who has no need of having his road pointed out to him.	300.532365583752
Chapter XLIV.	342.1480371482099
THE UTILITY OF STOVEPIPES	295.39256210934406
It was evident that without suspecting it, and actuated solely by their	202.7491412873916
chivalrous and adventurous character, our three friends had just	226.87699515769285
rendered a service to someone the cardinal honored with his special	361.564387934871
protection.	187.48001033324724
Now, who was that someone? That was the question the three Musketeers	289.41826710243186
put to one another. Then, seeing that none of their replies could throw	276.8009510214739
any light on the subject, Porthos called the host and asked for dice.	298.3701872048419
Porthos and Aramis placed themselves at the table and began to play.	204.98480574707656
Athos walked about in a contemplative mood.	259.8185143312025
While thinking and walking, Athos passed and repassed before the pipe	247.97061256502568
of the stove, broken in halves, the other extremity passing into the	304.0995812830687
chamber above; and every time he passed and repassed he heard a murmur	309.425559150887
of words, which at length fixed his attention. Athos went close to it,	311.1475749677777
and distinguished some words that appeared to merit so great an	261.88512013964305
interest that he made a sign to his friends to be silent, remaining	314.7902697263754
himself bent with his ear directed to the opening of the lower orifice.	340.97929201234905
“Listen, Milady,” said the cardinal, “the affair is important. Sit	357.16811928131415
down, and let us talk it over.”	312.7377933934369
“Milady!” murmured Athos.	309.8779312204425
“I listen to your Eminence with greatest attention,” replied a female	332.7465350805307
voice which made the Musketeer start.	187.500657741049
“A small vessel with an English crew, whose captain is on my side,	197.04514971667297
awaits you at the mouth of Charente, at Fort La Pointe*. He will set	166.0244877992381
sail tomorrow morning.”	248.01271154164627
* Fort La Pointe, or Fort Vasou, was not built until 1672, nearly 50	274.3734534536844
years later.	283.81877489405997
“I must go thither tonight?”	218.99175228744394
“Instantly! That is to say, when you have received my instructions. Two	272.0527777460323
men, whom you will find at the door on going out, will serve you as	345.68668361434936
escort. You will allow me to leave first; then, after half an hour, you	284.4372267032136
can go away in your turn.”	207.82273686334247
“Yes, monseigneur. Now let us return to the mission with which you wish	203.53371151681574
to charge me; and as I desire to continue to merit the confidence of	196.37071612756077
your Eminence, deign to unfold it to me in terms clear and precise,	293.4245544287489
that I may not commit an error.”	220.14250524871358
There was an instant of profound silence between the two interlocutors.	204.5168111318848
It was evident that the cardinal was weighing beforehand the terms in	257.6686681799188
which he was about to speak, and that Milady was collecting all her	178.63601429560853
intellectual faculties to comprehend the things he was about to say,	204.81905877883804
and to engrave them in her memory when they should be spoken.	282.05100855569515
Athos took advantage of this moment to tell his two companions to	277.52438747269065
fasten the door inside, and to make them a sign to come and listen with	274.9465928655717
him.	282.75943432782844
The two Musketeers, who loved their ease, brought a chair for each of	330.3226422423595
themselves and one for Athos. All three then sat down with their heads	202.93009195005078
together and their ears on the alert.	284.50689450696643
“You will go to London,” continued the cardinal. “Arrived in London,	247.56377612271808
you will seek Buckingham.”	320.85909954342185
“I must beg your Eminence to observe,” said Milady, “that since the	206.44548194403342
affair of the diamond studs, about which the duke always suspected me,	319.6630624704503
his Grace distrusts me.”	221.13107836677767
“Well, this time,” said the cardinal, “it is not necessary to steal his	313.73786115192314
confidence, but to present yourself frankly and loyally as a	364.51900994493707
negotiator.”	326.18679793124164
“Frankly and loyally,” repeated Milady, with an unspeakable expression	232.56354816185933
of duplicity.	186.00209849214568
“Yes, frankly and loyally,” replied the cardinal, in the same tone.	309.62986619774273
“All this negotiation must be carried on openly.”	208.72947982533512
“I will follow your Eminence’s instructions to the letter. I only wait	262.96149432510504
till you give them.”	247.42073307566358
“You will go to Buckingham in my behalf, and you will tell him I am	207.69359958807462
acquainted with all the preparations he has made; but that they give me	358.7717318276059
no uneasiness, since at the first step he takes I will ruin the queen.”	176.64337981095306
“Will he believe that your Eminence is in a position to accomplish the	362.91967921613457
threat thus made?”	188.47864369191325
“Yes; for I have the proofs.”	292.7912285704543
“I must be able to present these proofs for his appreciation.”	183.47376135344115
“Without doubt. And you will tell him I will publish the report of	285.7140426202208
Bois-Robert and the Marquis de Beautru, upon the interview which the	306.0934881704924
duke had at the residence of Madame the Constable with the queen on the	262.5159539263227
evening Madame the Constable gave a masquerade. You will tell him, in	180.39560355761006
order that he may not doubt, that he came there in the costume of the	175.12653786353323
Great Mogul, which the Chevalier de Guise was to have worn, and that he	217.07421296098673
purchased this exchange for the sum of three thousand pistoles.”	255.41849909201565
“Well, monseigneur?”	169.08114819796185
“All the details of his coming into and going out of the palace—on the	187.19414004509855
night when he introduced himself in the character of an Italian fortune	365.8619002573922
teller—you will tell him, that he may not doubt the correctness of my	350.00448762512275
information; that he had under his cloak a large white robe dotted with	311.5260320718506
black tears, death’s heads, and crossbones—for in case of a surprise,	201.37162226129607
he was to pass for the phantom of the White Lady who, as all the world	242.44043039882342
knows, appears at the Louvre every time any great event is impending.”	352.99296955461756
“Is that all, monseigneur?”	313.6514523164391
“Tell him also that I am acquainted with all the details of the	299.7024255003215
adventure at Amiens; that I will have a little romance made of it,	344.10797716378994
wittily turned, with a plan of the garden and portraits of the	311.4419844102418
principal actors in that nocturnal romance.”	319.804919303024
“I will tell him that.”	253.94493174889703
“Tell him further that I hold Montague in my power; that Montague is in	232.88913811412695
the Bastille; that no letters were found upon him, it is true, but that	251.81082532134116
torture may make him tell much of what he knows, and even what he does	278.6865768149471
not know.”	194.29074855306732
“Exactly.”	218.29814505218923
“Then add that his Grace has, in the precipitation with which he quit	236.71726508252766
the Isle of Ré, forgotten and left behind him in his lodging a certain	173.1447001206858
letter from Madame de Chevreuse which singularly compromises the queen,	328.48069987349345
inasmuch as it proves not only that her Majesty can love the enemies of	250.1990685955355
the king but that she can conspire with the enemies of France. You	347.16792391514207
recollect perfectly all I have told you, do you not?”	348.47593585850353
“Your Eminence will judge: the ball of Madame the Constable; the night	282.2693839688267
at the Louvre; the evening at Amiens; the arrest of Montague; the	343.10239283190515
letter of Madame de Chevreuse.”	330.1000330775414
“That’s it,” said the cardinal, “that’s it. You have an excellent	315.68397349272425
memory, Milady.”	361.35426986828577
“But,” resumed she to whom the cardinal addressed this flattering	318.6785024315262
compliment, “if, in spite of all these reasons, the duke does not give	356.3415878520127
way and continues to menace France?”	275.6690454161566
“The duke is in love to madness, or rather to folly,” replied	209.4199760754854
Richelieu, with great bitterness. “Like the ancient paladins, he has	268.23945112980743
only undertaken this war to obtain a look from his lady love. If he	202.79336490005403
becomes certain that this war will cost the honor, and perhaps the	310.85578781130414
liberty, of the lady of his thoughts, as he says, I will answer for it	195.39717040810896
he will look twice.”	252.71816291309528
“And yet,” said Milady, with a persistence that proved she wished to	332.7572856410845
see clearly to the end of the mission with which she was about to be	213.65885567773745
charged, “if he persists?”	213.94377836258525
“If he persists?” said the cardinal. “That is not probable.”	204.45502135377717
“It is possible,” said Milady.	336.66972537425386
“If he persists—” His Eminence made a pause, and resumed: “If he	217.26669777624096
persists—well, then I shall hope for one of those events which change	256.781172666527
the destinies of states.”	240.34766968494876
“If your Eminence would quote to me some one of these events in	230.7619382632799
history,” said Milady, “perhaps I should partake of your confidence as	209.93834203959125
to the future.”	226.6751570384251
“Well, here, for example,” said Richelieu: “when, in 1610, for a cause	202.7048137737603
similar to that which moves the duke, King Henry IV., of glorious	287.8113338198976
memory, was about, at the same time, to invade Flanders and Italy, in	170.23544917314317
order to attack Austria on both sides. Well, did there not happen an	351.7579589309889
event which saved Austria? Why should not the king of France have the	207.27345551480434
same chance as the emperor?”	308.88499780274867
“Your Eminence means, I presume, the knife stab in the Rue de la	335.5046297762749
Feronnerie?”	265.4285121031968
“Precisely,” said the cardinal.	196.52513377391733
“Does not your Eminence fear that the punishment inflicted upon	289.8587200976188
Ravaillac may deter anyone who might entertain the idea of imitating	245.16378648840146
him?”	295.9732289031287
“There will be, in all times and in all countries, particularly if	364.0695768155616
religious divisions exist in those countries, fanatics who ask nothing	271.43113733028383
better than to become martyrs. Ay, and observe—it just occurs to me	321.3637296499111
that the Puritans are furious against Buckingham, and their preachers	177.61541315210417
designate him as the Antichrist.”	180.6991327093999
“Well?” said Milady.	233.1418817802354
“Well,” continued the cardinal, in an indifferent tone, “the only thing	181.26851053835313
to be sought for at this moment is some woman, handsome, young, and	239.8129128626341
clever, who has cause of quarrel with the duke. The duke has had many	253.12532739517684
affairs of gallantry; and if he has fostered his amours by promises of	217.41848426667275
eternal constancy, he must likewise have sown the seeds of hatred by	358.9995532370217
his eternal infidelities.”	238.14889965774006
“No doubt,” said Milady, coolly, “such a woman may be found.”	249.09399967842091
“Well, such a woman, who would place the knife of Jacques Clément or of	216.8136228663773
Ravaillac in the hands of a fanatic, would save France.”	166.16465475130838
“Yes; but she would then be the accomplice of an assassination.”	232.1994544379055
“Were the accomplices of Ravaillac or of Jacques Clément ever known?”	318.00116327450525
“No; for perhaps they were too high-placed for anyone to dare look for	244.54093214759683
them where they were. The Palace of Justice would not be burned down	228.34311244854268
for everybody, monseigneur.”	321.63570305174545
“You think, then, that the fire at the Palace of Justice was not caused	253.66410250790722
by chance?” asked Richelieu, in the tone with which he would have put a	212.03494682809205
question of no importance.	185.53401025108315
“I, monseigneur?” replied Milady. “I think nothing; I quote a fact,	300.24949039720946
that is all. Only I say that if I were named Madame de Montpensier, or	170.31590016679263
the Queen Marie de Médicis, I should use less precautions than I take,	179.38127748004848
being simply called Milady Clarik.”	280.7376213619411
“That is just,” said Richelieu. “What do you require, then?”	228.8512877585277
“I require an order which would ratify beforehand all that I should	274.03389700759794
think proper to do for the greatest good of France.”	327.0993506605479
“But in the first place, this woman I have described must be found who	333.00039529485525
is desirous of avenging herself upon the duke.”	292.5288853177709
“She is found,” said Milady.	175.3400456553856
“Then the miserable fanatic must be found who will serve as an	284.60534650969817
instrument of God’s justice.”	203.69083674138267
“He will be found.”	306.0214656843872
“Well,” said the cardinal, “then it will be time to claim the order	328.330578373314
which you just now required.”	215.26478213892528
“Your Eminence is right,” replied Milady; “and I have been wrong in	341.5377244353999
seeing in the mission with which you honor me anything but that which	264.71294866513335
it really is—that is, to announce to his Grace, on the part of your	167.21976473491833
Eminence, that you are acquainted with the different disguises by means	225.14318025052032
of which he succeeded in approaching the queen during the fête given by	180.83743038159145
Madame the Constable; that you have proofs of the interview granted at	276.76051203048837
the Louvre by the queen to a certain Italian astrologer who was no	292.1379513481615
other than the Duke of Buckingham; that you have ordered a little	309.2251731178731
romance of a satirical nature to be written upon the adventures of	350.1717118149629
