Amiens, with a plan of the gardens in which those adventures took	310.5429586503251
place, and portraits of the actors who figured in them; that Montague	266.92191426170234
is in the Bastille, and that the torture may make him say things he	263.0082276885265
remembers, and even things he has forgotten; that you possess a certain	224.44947520655552
letter from Madame de Chevreuse, found in his Grace’s lodging, which	345.2896820109695
singularly compromises not only her who wrote it, but her in whose name	362.21611681941954
it was written. Then, if he persists, notwithstanding all this—as that	235.10334725469028
is, as I have said, the limit of my mission—I shall have nothing to do	231.00716041071925
but to pray God to work a miracle for the salvation of France. That is	359.489529740065
it, is it not, monseigneur, and I shall have nothing else to do?”	360.75181119347036
“That is it,” replied the cardinal, dryly.	364.0676191834415
“And now,” said Milady, without appearing to remark the change of the	358.1018256955739
duke’s tone toward her—“now that I have received the instructions of	302.93547509464474
your Eminence as concerns your enemies, Monseigneur will permit me to	305.70338155806576
say a few words to him of mine?”	226.0363092208984
“Have you enemies, then?” asked Richelieu.	328.39773761748836
“Yes, monseigneur, enemies against whom you owe me all your support,	216.84768695235468
for I made them by serving your Eminence.”	226.04551678591673
“Who are they?” replied the duke.	184.08563879241706
“In the first place, there is a little _intrigante_ named Bonacieux.”	228.55737190864426
“She is in the prison of Nantes.”	261.48712749166043
“That is to say, she was there,” replied Milady; “but the queen has	267.1278895307876
obtained an order from the king by means of which she has been conveyed	245.97139091536548
to a convent.”	312.5840210060093
“To a convent?” said the duke.	213.9245699924685
“Yes, to a convent.”	182.54903633067968
“And to which?”	198.02794499106423
“I don’t know; the secret has been well kept.”	258.3273023749508
“But _I_ will know!”	174.42352212208738
“And your Eminence will tell me in what convent that woman is?”	297.05889076009277
“I can see nothing inconvenient in that,” said the cardinal.	351.1815702353215
“Well, now I have an enemy much more to be dreaded by me than this	250.22442191313974
little Madame Bonacieux.”	297.07868484141
“Who is that?”	364.85985276357746
“Her lover.”	291.5769985642137
“What is his name?”	194.34042367905232
“Oh, your Eminence knows him well,” cried Milady, carried away by her	207.59625035287416
anger. “He is the evil genius of both of us. It is he who in an	214.44430176709315
encounter with your Eminence’s Guards decided the victory in favor of	169.59320759091622
the king’s Musketeers; it is he who gave three desperate wounds to De	242.94586866613116
Wardes, your emissary, and who caused the affair of the diamond studs	244.85424700996379
to fail; it is he who, knowing it was I who had Madame Bonacieux	332.5821613552245
carried off, has sworn my death.”	243.1334123028291
“Ah, ah!” said the cardinal, “I know of whom you speak.”	329.49315916754597
“I mean that miserable D’Artagnan.”	351.43814289480673
“He is a bold fellow,” said the cardinal.	280.31065358204575
“And it is exactly because he is a bold fellow that he is the more to	295.72359306409453
be feared.”	207.4294734992988
“I must have,” said the duke, “a proof of his connection with	279.83600372794217
Buckingham.”	213.8831389694317
“A proof?” cried Milady; “I will have ten.”	315.30584056417655
“Well, then, it becomes the simplest thing in the world; get me that	174.66032861559364
proof, and I will send him to the Bastille.”	245.61384907725375
“So far good, monseigneur; but afterwards?”	203.15967135717327
“When once in the Bastille, there is no afterward!” said the cardinal,	179.6510360666495
in a low voice. “Ah, _pardieu!_” continued he, “if it were as easy for	275.85501256303075
me to get rid of my enemy as it is easy to get rid of yours, and if it	189.38155427324105
were against such people you require impunity—”	219.2171204901482
“Monseigneur,” replied Milady, “a fair exchange. Life for life, man for	192.699008808713
man; give me one, I will give you the other.”	263.93066408920635
“I don’t know what you mean, nor do I even desire to know what you	281.5964496090699
mean,” replied the cardinal; “but I wish to please you, and see nothing	262.1330799667719
out of the way in giving you what you demand with respect to so	337.1837028792542
infamous a creature—the more so as you tell me this D’Artagnan is a	230.92822940972522
libertine, a duelist, and a traitor.”	252.37324822213213
“An infamous scoundrel, monseigneur, a scoundrel!”	239.0433648992494
“Give me paper, a quill, and some ink, then,” said the cardinal.	351.09252358310715
“Here they are, monseigneur.”	281.47554230496854
There was a moment of silence, which proved that the cardinal was	317.7745508962229
employed in seeking the terms in which he should write the note, or	288.10774982497156
else in writing it. Athos, who had not lost a word of the conversation,	218.02522314312353
took his two companions by the hand, and led them to the other end of	198.80321540530983
the room.	172.54530294286113
“Well,” said Porthos, “what do you want, and why do you not let us	332.00588340863806
listen to the end of the conversation?”	305.39549145802647
“Hush!” said Athos, speaking in a low voice. “We have heard all it was	281.89257152792334
necessary we should hear; besides, I don’t prevent you from listening,	356.86103852348015
but I must be gone.”	252.95929800936236
“You must be gone!” said Porthos; “and if the cardinal asks for you,	261.51304544631694
what answer can we make?”	337.196377044418
“You will not wait till he asks; you will speak first, and tell him	296.0317693824793
that I am gone on the lookout, because certain expressions of our host	281.04081256443476
have given me reason to think the road is not safe. I will say two	277.6643580315467
words about it to the cardinal’s esquire likewise. The rest concerns	271.9870973123142
myself; don’t be uneasy about that.”	259.32071167705806
“Be prudent, Athos,” said Aramis.	196.98189758071584
“Be easy on that head,” replied Athos; “you know I am cool enough.”	203.6616920478994
Porthos and Aramis resumed their places by the stovepipe.	320.79380314583375
As to Athos, he went out without any mystery, took his horse, which was	215.2373477707905
tied with those of his friends to the fastenings of the shutters, in	204.75651571939724
four words convinced the attendant of the necessity of a vanguard for	223.71954398004993
their return, carefully examined the priming of his pistols, drew his	216.04005821303164
sword, and took, like a forlorn hope, the road to the camp.	339.43162731322604
Chapter XLV.	233.61875967490704
A CONJUGAL SCENE	169.77924004800337
As Athos had foreseen, it was not long before the cardinal came down.	246.66377882571464
He opened the door of the room in which the Musketeers were, and found	168.87106362769492
Porthos playing an earnest game of dice with Aramis. He cast a rapid	237.09886176722773
glance around the room, and perceived that one of his men was missing.	336.32936609702506
“What has become of Monseigneur Athos?” asked he.	212.51606696080086
“Monseigneur,” replied Porthos, “he has gone as a scout, on account of	207.82103323164011
some words of our host, which made him believe the road was not safe.”	271.0920095287247
“And you, what have you done, Monsieur Porthos?”	326.03099317910187
“I have won five pistoles of Aramis.”	354.5366606637157
“Well; now will you return with me?”	281.6159418276703
“We are at your Eminence’s orders.”	212.64803732052042
“To horse, then, gentlemen; for it is getting late.”	196.16846033048083
The attendant was at the door, holding the cardinal’s horse by the	221.95046589426448
bridle. At a short distance a group of two men and three horses	187.56212241817656
appeared in the shade. These were the two men who were to conduct	210.77564097444485
Milady to Fort La Pointe, and superintend her embarkation.	312.7155082853279
The attendant confirmed to the cardinal what the two Musketeers had	208.75408371159494
already said with respect to Athos. The cardinal made an approving	220.4793765946584
gesture, and retraced his route with the same precautions he had used	170.20904025335162
in coming.	256.4200340217383
Let us leave him to follow the road to the camp protected by his	313.1847639227409
esquire and the two Musketeers, and return to Athos.	274.6222409120175
For a hundred paces he maintained the speed at which he started; but	363.66122819743356
when out of sight he turned his horse to the right, made a circuit, and	197.49039790300887
came back within twenty paces of a high hedge to watch the passage of	354.9568929477907
the little troop. Having recognized the laced hats of his companions	347.0793081539496
and the golden fringe of the cardinal’s cloak, he waited till the	172.41611064992577
horsemen had turned the angle of the road, and having lost sight of	173.75007086333835
them, he returned at a gallop to the inn, which was opened to him	221.99955357742843
without hesitation.	312.7953450502742
The host recognized him.	200.66884561936288
“My officer,” said Athos, “has forgotten to give a piece of very	346.4065035154317
important information to the lady, and has sent me back to repair his	166.92418782831845
forgetfulness.”	258.6576626739155
“Go up,” said the host; “she is still in her chamber.”	278.62448034623503
Athos availed himself of the permission, ascended the stairs with his	227.4657688872623
lightest step, gained the landing, and through the open door perceived	212.0231372323441
Milady putting on her hat.	242.79489657726452
He entered the chamber and closed the door behind him. At the noise he	171.22138820723097
made in pushing the bolt, Milady turned round.	249.80854394220162
Athos was standing before the door, enveloped in his cloak, with his	280.297907856001
hat pulled down over his eyes. On seeing this figure, mute and	292.3139028679267
immovable as a statue, Milady was frightened.	237.47840818175945
“Who are you, and what do you want?” cried she.	281.62977858359284
“Humph,” murmured Athos, “it is certainly she!”	334.43687214480326
And letting fall his cloak and raising his hat, he advanced toward	253.07795922231563
Milady.	241.39373258702582
“Do you know me, madame?” said he.	199.7708169807051
Milady made one step forward, and then drew back as if she had seen a	181.3843835545194
serpent.	276.4903062711389
“So far, well,” said Athos, “I perceive you know me.”	190.66652312337655
“The Comte de la Fère!” murmured Milady, becoming exceedingly pale, and	215.5981734525177
drawing back till the wall prevented her from going any farther.	187.39542006625098
“Yes, Milady,” replied Athos; “the Comte de la Fère in person, who	239.6745445253916
comes expressly from the other world to have the pleasure of paying you	170.8006662115759
a visit. Sit down, madame, and let us talk, as the cardinal said.”	314.54306503728196
Milady, under the influence of inexpressible terror, sat down without	241.65916716938403
uttering a word.	309.9371501413144
“You certainly are a demon sent upon the earth!” said Athos. “Your	338.6467597378042
power is great, I know; but you also know that with the help of God men	262.5762378703992
have often conquered the most terrible demons. You have once before	206.7958064224561
thrown yourself in my path. I thought I had crushed you, madame; but	365.9671549980186
either I was deceived or hell has resuscitated you!”	358.67767626575323
Milady at these words, which recalled frightful remembrances, hung down	305.616781960862
her head with a suppressed groan.	221.80229124263906
“Yes, hell has resuscitated you,” continued Athos. “Hell has made you	279.0860139715463
rich, hell has given you another name, hell has almost made you another	170.73241325537265
face; but it has neither effaced the stains from your soul nor the	336.5138118141873
brand from your body.”	221.86461427298678
Milady arose as if moved by a powerful spring, and her eyes flashed	216.71066759333348
lightning. Athos remained sitting.	264.1326615421679
“You believed me to be dead, did you not, as I believed you to be? And	168.2348067149643
the name of Athos as well concealed the Comte de la Fère, as the name	317.0410494552741
Milady Clarik concealed Anne de Breuil. Was it not so you were called	202.02939993657748
when your honored brother married us? Our position is truly a strange	289.11600491492436
one,” continued Athos, laughing. “We have only lived up to the present	232.60154138391698
time because we believed each other dead, and because a remembrance is	365.20097734964025
less oppressive than a living creature, though a remembrance is	253.22859134658933
sometimes devouring.”	194.7968708289506
“But,” said Milady, in a hollow, faint voice, “what brings you back to	302.3979833406302
me, and what do you want with me?”	260.661079091703
“I wish to tell you that though remaining invisible to your eyes, I	209.76098378506998
have not lost sight of you.”	303.8315649357136
“You know what I have done?”	175.47551896451827
“I can relate to you, day by day, your actions from your entrance to	344.0554113649269
the service of the cardinal to this evening.”	286.75754800599526
A smile of incredulity passed over the pale lips of Milady.	232.0866522355069
“Listen! It was you who cut off the two diamond studs from the shoulder	344.83075211072133
of the Duke of Buckingham; it was you who had Madame Bonacieux carried	241.4193862693228
off; it was you who, in love with De Wardes and thinking to pass the	173.71296347293233
night with him, opened the door to Monsieur d’Artagnan; it was you who,	171.1280356089673
believing that De Wardes had deceived you, wished to have him killed by	178.8717118269867
his rival; it was you who, when this rival had discovered your infamous	290.2778478049753
secret, wished to have him killed in his turn by two assassins, whom	306.2531423869323
you sent in pursuit of him; it was you who, finding the balls had	364.9557088243206
missed their mark, sent poisoned wine with a forged letter, to make	166.91073075877435
your victim believe that the wine came from his friends. In short, it	340.79461600374066
was you who have but now in this chamber, seated in this chair I now	223.2151796803252
fill, made an engagement with Cardinal Richelieu to cause the Duke of	236.45268082592804
Buckingham to be assassinated, in exchange for the promise he has made	166.1792694963023
you to allow you to assassinate D’Artagnan.”	205.59273159670593
Milady was livid.	169.54242177412834
“You must be Satan!” cried she.	321.3818339832584
“Perhaps,” said Athos; “But at all events listen well to this.	170.34958672138953
Assassinate the Duke of Buckingham, or cause him to be assassinated—I	224.69504286620375
care very little about that! I don’t know him. Besides, he is an	230.04724876115947
Englishman. But do not touch with the tip of your finger a single hair	261.4351009449494
of D’Artagnan, who is a faithful friend whom I love and defend, or I	174.11576113624167
swear to you by the head of my father the crime which you shall have	311.94830264208184
endeavored to commit, or shall have committed, shall be the last.”	319.46037225671245
“Monsieur d’Artagnan has cruelly insulted me,” said Milady, in a hollow	306.0453212053885
tone; “Monsieur d’Artagnan shall die!”	356.93044054553167
“Indeed! Is it possible to insult you, madame?” said Athos, laughing;	257.7967013822461
“he has insulted you, and he shall die!”	248.08950376345086
“He shall die!” replied Milady; “she first, and he afterward.”	294.4962734224133
Athos was seized with a kind of vertigo. The sight of this creature,	174.37496830253485
who had nothing of the woman about her, recalled awful remembrances. He	343.54522773672124
thought how one day, in a less dangerous situation than the one in	199.3758635989785
which he was now placed, he had already endeavored to sacrifice her to	180.43813917313452
his honor. His desire for blood returned, burning his brain and	234.47475999789145
pervading his frame like a raging fever; he arose in his turn, reached	193.57201519154077
his hand to his belt, drew forth a pistol, and cocked it.	282.1566580857765
Milady, pale as a corpse, endeavored to cry out; but her swollen tongue	304.8518434278227
could utter no more than a hoarse sound which had nothing human in it	324.1767464662732
and resembled the rattle of a wild beast. Motionless against the dark	246.21409139458893
tapestry, with her hair in disorder, she appeared like a horrid image	300.9259388822381
of terror.	338.23145971697295
Athos slowly raised his pistol, stretched out his arm so that the	251.97158545451916
weapon almost touched Milady’s forehead, and then, in a voice the more	283.0435036073563
terrible from having the supreme calmness of a fixed resolution,	217.29702479092083
“Madame,” said he, “you will this instant deliver to me the paper the	185.1295930071887
cardinal signed; or upon my soul, I will blow your brains out.”	171.0533896368685
With another man, Milady might have preserved some doubt; but she knew	269.0407102031907
Athos. Nevertheless, she remained motionless.	184.47728064252857
“You have one second to decide,” said he.	301.9144404635031
Milady saw by the contraction of his countenance that the trigger was	287.4813482831544
about to be pulled; she reached her hand quickly to her bosom, drew out	232.32623221040376
a paper, and held it toward Athos.	306.8474560882536
“Take it,” said she, “and be accursed!”	326.08635132484574
Athos took the paper, returned the pistol to his belt, approached the	196.5739847279203
lamp to be assured that it was the paper, unfolded it, and read:	325.1500368716494
“Dec. 3, 1627	355.8552220529165
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	326.42596970091915
this has done what he has done.	214.11358420180395
“RICHELIEU”	233.88374986211193
“And now,” said Athos, resuming his cloak and putting on his hat, “now	298.95380345195406
that I have drawn your teeth, viper, bite if you can.”	286.19588619586045
And he left the chamber without once looking behind him.	258.9024933004696
At the door he found the two men and the spare horse which they held.	190.726632878535
“Gentlemen,” said he, “Monseigneur’s order is, you know, to conduct	176.62698153947014
that woman, without losing time, to Fort La Pointe, and never to leave	297.22411254924634
her till she is on board.”	204.01584558183427
As these words agreed wholly with the order they had received, they	194.7564421986537
bowed their heads in sign of assent.	225.12176761199285
With regard to Athos, he leaped lightly into the saddle and set out at	172.77968987244125
full gallop; only instead of following the road, he went across the	178.67377715452008
fields, urging his horse to the utmost and stopping occasionally to	322.0638405601215
listen.	244.86999903931968
In one of those halts he heard the steps of several horses on the road.	253.77222337215034
He had no doubt it was the cardinal and his escort. He immediately made	290.44169731349893
a new point in advance, rubbed his horse down with some heath and	303.1981803272835
leaves of trees, and placed himself across the road, about two hundred	213.65325610834842
paces from the camp.	255.87096479706156
“Who goes there?” cried he, as soon as he perceived the horsemen.	239.3941146915613
“That is our brave Musketeer, I think,” said the cardinal.	298.2316860999173
“Yes, monseigneur,” said Porthos, “it is he.”	312.31608585168357
“Monsieur Athos,” said Richelieu, “receive my thanks for the good guard	210.1420342759963
you have kept. Gentlemen, we are arrived; take the gate on the left.	195.585378759632
The watchword is, ‘King and Ré.’”	297.3162499772054
Saying these words, the cardinal saluted the three friends with an	319.2919126554168
inclination of his head, and took the right hand, followed by his	256.6752608930168
attendant—for that night he himself slept in the camp.	283.1152195078682
“Well!” said Porthos and Aramis together, as soon as the cardinal was	213.26351088204834
out of hearing, “well, he signed the paper she required!”	314.06315424919967
“I know it,” said Athos, coolly, “since here it is.”	353.13324180456186
And the three friends did not exchange another word till they reached	238.45874816188427
their quarters, except to give the watchword to the sentinels. Only	194.70243379784782
they sent Mousqueton to tell Planchet that his master was requested,	273.04827682220025
the instant that he left the trenches, to come to the quarters of the	183.24428475188716
Musketeers.	183.27713167534344
Milady, as Athos had foreseen, on finding the two men that awaited her,	201.08002588815594
made no difficulty in following them. She had had for an instant an	185.7102870644833
inclination to be reconducted to the cardinal, and relate everything to	257.3724100143299
him; but a revelation on her part would bring about a revelation on the	341.43675469635286
part of Athos. She might say that Athos had hanged her; but then Athos	257.15379068213826
would tell that she was branded. She thought it was best to preserve	328.3867529978793
silence, to discreetly set off to accomplish her difficult mission with	294.34794477337846
her usual skill; and then, all things being accomplished to the	171.6653652174163
satisfaction of the cardinal, to come to him and claim her vengeance.	332.4062584700462
In consequence, after having traveled all night, at seven o’clock she	219.92482195710713
was at the fort of the Point; at eight o’clock she had embarked; and at	261.30010611506634
nine, the vessel, which with letters of marque from the cardinal was	323.8303985880018
supposed to be sailing for Bayonne, raised anchor, and steered its	200.8975997809448
course toward England.	307.66722133740177
Chapter XLVI.	295.7192265064291
THE BASTION SAINT-GERVAIS	170.15624577092987
On arriving at the lodgings of his three friends, D’Artagnan found them	342.2133237694279
assembled in the same chamber. Athos was meditating; Porthos was	230.24511510284526
twisting his mustache; Aramis was saying his prayers in a charming	211.5656891789959
little Book of Hours, bound in blue velvet.	207.26531841703874
“_Pardieu_, gentlemen,” said he. “I hope what you have to tell me is	284.1645788149863
worth the trouble, or else, I warn you, I will not pardon you for	315.2325829901922
making me come here instead of getting a little rest after a night	199.61657572152475
spent in taking and dismantling a bastion. Ah, why were you not there,	335.3655698953266
gentlemen? It was warm work.”	241.17907073432525
“We were in a place where it was not very cold,” replied Porthos,	237.153875850146
giving his mustache a twist which was peculiar to him.	270.43553550864425
“Hush!” said Athos.	175.219022443144
“Oh, oh!” said D’Artagnan, comprehending the slight frown of the	351.85009310897755
Musketeer. “It appears there is something fresh aboard.”	349.7636440446243
“Aramis,” said Athos, “you went to breakfast the day before yesterday	239.62342964036537
at the inn of the Parpaillot, I believe?”	335.04714250370995
“Yes.”	309.88054522429354
“How did you fare?”	238.50763272252235
“For my part, I ate but little. The day before yesterday was a fish	233.22618073867142
day, and they had nothing but meat.”	247.24793265292465
“What,” said Athos, “no fish at a seaport?”	343.7884409762811
“They say,” said Aramis, resuming his pious reading, “that the dyke	209.9666903656502
which the cardinal is making drives them all out into the open sea.”	217.7191711768187
“But that is not quite what I mean to ask you, Aramis,” replied Athos.	221.54323899582565
“I want to know if you were left alone, and nobody interrupted you.”	227.04101475129687
“Why, I think there were not many intruders. Yes, Athos, I know what	304.3049986704353
you mean: we shall do very well at the Parpaillot.”	248.92927936440196
“Let us go to the Parpaillot, then, for here the walls are like sheets	358.2600433166442
of paper.”	279.83795783433334
D’Artagnan, who was accustomed to his friend’s manner of acting, and	175.66287821377017
who perceived immediately, by a word, a gesture, or a sign from him,	213.66319117136797
that the circumstances were serious, took Athos’s arm, and went out	270.54555387935795
without saying anything. Porthos followed, chatting with Aramis.	292.09047740985415
On their way they met Grimaud. Athos made him a sign to come with them.	356.0317997702906
Grimaud, according to custom, obeyed in silence; the poor lad had	347.5206783170805
nearly come to the pass of forgetting how to speak.	225.3926493399931
They arrived at the drinking room of the Parpaillot. It was seven	195.69810919516235
o’clock in the morning, and daylight began to appear. The three friends	318.97251622291805
ordered breakfast, and went into a room in which the host said they	332.27138201788046
would not be disturbed.	172.7320430691845
Unfortunately, the hour was badly chosen for a private conference. The	304.72578958487225
morning drum had just been beaten; everyone shook off the drowsiness of	335.64660615852824
night, and to dispel the humid morning air, came to take a drop at the	350.051927245824
inn. Dragoons, Swiss, Guardsmen, Musketeers, light-horsemen, succeeded	287.1869113239967
one another with a rapidity which might answer the purpose of the host	278.23532318716224
very well, but agreed badly with the views of the four friends. Thus	333.83492579590313
they applied very curtly to the salutations, healths, and jokes of	296.7667426844654
their companions.	194.84110335572439
“I see how it will be,” said Athos: “we shall get into some pretty	228.59516997202036
quarrel or other, and we have no need of one just now. D’Artagnan, tell	354.56513017429927
us what sort of a night you have had, and we will describe ours	295.7174545921097
afterward.”	183.7228073949186
“Ah, yes,” said a light-horseman, with a glass of brandy in his hand,	229.25500033485974
which he sipped slowly. “I hear you gentlemen of the Guards have been	324.8432390076115
in the trenches tonight, and that you did not get much the best of the	241.4938146859202
Rochellais.”	359.9699291304955
D’Artagnan looked at Athos to know if he ought to reply to this	283.3036728534313
intruder who thus mixed unasked in their conversation.	280.39402919621085
“Well,” said Athos, “don’t you hear Monsieur de Busigny, who does you	189.11479714872064
the honor to ask you a question? Relate what has passed during the	256.5793606302761
night, since these gentlemen desire to know it.”	259.8832330457072
“Have you not taken a bastion?” said a Swiss, who was drinking rum out	288.1114892831048
of a beer glass.	244.11252656784984
“Yes, monsieur,” said D’Artagnan, bowing, “we have had that honor. We	173.96412640331002
even have, as you may have heard, introduced a barrel of powder under	297.9213766454823
one of the angles, which in blowing up made a very pretty breach.	266.22481398507307
Without reckoning that as the bastion was not built yesterday all the	227.47013602153794
rest of the building was badly shaken.”	174.31726131066483
“And what bastion is it?” asked a dragoon, with his saber run through a	325.5635569558184
goose which he was taking to be cooked.	338.5984896898914
“The bastion St. Gervais,” replied D’Artagnan, “from behind which the	169.41004160322055
Rochellais annoyed our workmen.”	297.26322679274347
“Was that affair hot?”	192.2114234167534
“Yes, moderately so. We lost five men, and the Rochellais eight or	268.24962148186137
ten.”	227.5746330056943
“_Balzempleu!_” said the Swiss, who, notwithstanding the admirable	265.9261111158805
collection of oaths possessed by the German language, had acquired a	255.2544306462161
habit of swearing in French.	253.7489310988541
“But it is probable,” said the light-horseman, “that they will send	265.9625737512304
pioneers this morning to repair the bastion.”	257.06616095889984
“Yes, that’s probable,” said D’Artagnan.	230.20146713098865
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “a wager!”	166.5205423516247
“Ah, _wooi_, a vager!” cried the Swiss.	360.86579023508165
“What is it?” said the light-horseman.	172.16602609506154
“Stop a bit,” said the dragoon, placing his saber like a spit upon the	219.5129600438446
two large iron dogs which held the firebrands in the chimney, “stop a	171.44808558884134
bit, I am in it. You cursed host! a dripping pan immediately, that I	175.85513808765384
may not lose a drop of the fat of this estimable bird.”	166.4904815383295
“You was right,” said the Swiss; “goose grease is kood with basdry.”	363.42940719277595
“There!” said the dragoon. “Now for the wager! We listen, Monsieur	245.93136096249856
Athos.”	338.06409911777257
“Yes, the wager!” said the light-horseman.	179.93887899484594
“Well, Monsieur de Busigny, I will bet you,” said Athos, “that my three	228.86175045553625
companions, Messieurs Porthos, Aramis, and D’Artagnan, and myself, will	243.52743323545113
go and breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais, and we will remain there	200.03015279478456
an hour, by the watch, whatever the enemy may do to dislodge us.”	360.67646572155616
Porthos and Aramis looked at each other; they began to comprehend.	345.08633210005576
“But,” said D’Artagnan, in the ear of Athos, “you are going to get us	288.4314699938783
all killed without mercy.”	220.5469689487938
“We are much more likely to be killed,” said Athos, “if we do not go.”	360.53902227405655
“My faith, gentlemen,” said Porthos, turning round upon his chair and	167.83788411510213
twisting his mustache, “that’s a fair bet, I hope.”	224.2643618734387
“I take it,” said M. de Busigny; “so let us fix the stake.”	339.6744441281855
“You are four gentlemen,” said Athos, “and we are four; an unlimited	171.85956760241274
dinner for eight. Will that do?”	232.81113530022157
“Capitally,” replied M. de Busigny.	298.7674451591065
“Perfectly,” said the dragoon.	263.0143329908514
“That shoots me,” said the Swiss.	270.0448000697638
The fourth auditor, who during all this conversation had played a mute	251.14057596131198
part, made a sign of the head in proof that he acquiesced in the	231.08158436351448
proposition.	275.5448556895595
“The breakfast for these gentlemen is ready,” said the host.	365.95621443399057
“Well, bring it,” said Athos.	242.8832490646708
The host obeyed. Athos called Grimaud, pointed to a large basket which	211.23888191223202
lay in a corner, and made a sign to him to wrap the viands up in the	181.69790235630802
napkins.	275.92945382077926
Grimaud understood that it was to be a breakfast on the grass, took the	293.31828981799606
basket, packed up the viands, added the bottles, and then took the	324.8525585347933
basket on his arm.	202.0609782358409
“But where are you going to eat my breakfast?” asked the host.	313.5289954120913
“What matter, if you are paid for it?” said Athos, and he threw two	168.23106242233382
pistoles majestically on the table.	329.2191610131418
“Shall I give you the change, my officer?” said the host.	255.23102835811528
“No, only add two bottles of champagne, and the difference will be for	338.5977267205984
the napkins.”	240.11234380043402
The host had not quite so good a bargain as he at first hoped for, but	235.58177838097077
he made amends by slipping in two bottles of Anjou wine instead of two	279.419198937946
bottles of champagne.	295.87628502280984
“Monsieur de Busigny,” said Athos, “will you be so kind as to set your	283.5387015051533
watch with mine, or permit me to regulate mine by yours?”	279.58669526845296
“Which you please, monsieur!” said the light-horseman, drawing from his	206.9972423039928
fob a very handsome watch, studded with diamonds; “half past seven.”	327.50921620789796
“Thirty-five minutes after seven,” said Athos, “by which you perceive I	272.61818397667383
am five minutes faster than you.”	188.22503149280823
And bowing to all the astonished persons present, the young men took	281.1918011852252
the road to the bastion St. Gervais, followed by Grimaud, who carried	177.28393933479663
the basket, ignorant of where he was going but in the passive obedience	277.81623856856686
which Athos had taught him not even thinking of asking.	300.6895648981267
As long as they were within the circle of the camp, the four friends	326.49886621950156
did not exchange one word; besides, they were followed by the curious,	270.1354380467667
who, hearing of the wager, were anxious to know how they would come out	284.94186316101457
of it. But when once they passed the line of circumvallation and found	285.3998039125811
themselves in the open plain, D’Artagnan, who was completely ignorant	337.0355628896235
of what was going forward, thought it was time to demand an	362.20078817594157
explanation.	290.4837623449841
“And now, my dear Athos,” said he, “do me the kindness to tell me where	315.56994637144084
we are going?”	174.42812601959363
“Why, you see plainly enough we are going to the bastion.”	231.88107202378762
“But what are we going to do there?”	258.24480351104904
“You know well that we go to breakfast there.”	294.15866289720157
“But why did we not breakfast at the Parpaillot?”	273.22184535067885
“Because we have very important matters to communicate to one another,	333.43629233852516
and it was impossible to talk five minutes in that inn without being	259.91996463798694
annoyed by all those importunate fellows, who keep coming in, saluting	215.0613250482706
you, and addressing you. Here at least,” said Athos, pointing to the	297.7095480915226
bastion, “they will not come and disturb us.”	362.7169064272439
“It appears to me,” said D’Artagnan, with that prudence which allied	311.99954778619036
itself in him so naturally with excessive bravery, “that we could have	179.2812335807994
found some retired place on the downs or the seashore.”	221.68077018302768
“Where we should have been seen all four conferring together, so that	280.38011193228317
at the end of a quarter of an hour the cardinal would have been	329.85824106096516
informed by his spies that we were holding a council.”	254.86338069511257
“Yes,” said Aramis, “Athos is right: _Animadvertuntur in desertis_.”	237.45956019199548
“A desert would not have been amiss,” said Porthos; “but it behooved us	358.0825917903395
to find it.”	332.3432902567512
“There is no desert where a bird cannot pass over one’s head, where a	172.0507020637461
fish cannot leap out of the water, where a rabbit cannot come out of	335.8427071336363
its burrow, and I believe that bird, fish, and rabbit each becomes a	326.2921485036891
spy of the cardinal. Better, then, pursue our enterprise; from which,	313.4267114932075
besides, we cannot retreat without shame. We have made a wager—a wager	207.1918427421004
which could not have been foreseen, and of which I defy anyone to	297.35591912384547
divine the true cause. We are going, in order to win it, to remain an	253.10900585864223
hour in the bastion. Either we shall be attacked, or not. If we are	257.94434677717726
not, we shall have all the time to talk, and nobody will hear us—for I	345.44201037078506
guarantee the walls of the bastion have no ears; if we are, we will	296.9817034540697
talk of our affairs just the same. Moreover, in defending ourselves, we	354.9057014855166
shall cover ourselves with glory. You see that everything is to our	296.85866977529815
advantage.”	213.1795675178344
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan; “but we shall indubitably attract a ball.”	340.77959341885537
“Well, my dear,” replied Athos, “you know well that the balls most to	336.1861213842237
be dreaded are not from the enemy.”	271.0630862421395
“But for such an expedition we surely ought to have brought our	189.1211144380806
muskets.”	323.5323804691491
“You are stupid, friend Porthos. Why should we load ourselves with a	312.25659715940355
useless burden?”	324.5912914411126
“I don’t find a good musket, twelve cartridges, and a powder flask very	278.17661423758466
useless in the face of an enemy.”	363.46759080274757
“Well,” replied Athos, “have you not heard what D’Artagnan said?”	177.6350926766939
“What did he say?” demanded Porthos.	202.74993294857816
“D’Artagnan said that in the attack of last night eight or ten	206.7750918783131
Frenchmen were killed, and as many Rochellais.”	210.27145224845316
“What then?”	175.36433486616264
“The bodies were not plundered, were they? It appears the conquerors	200.36385702279094
had something else to do.”	337.00944356177183
“Well?”	316.34074069777944
“Well, we shall find their muskets, their cartridges, and their flasks;	339.7960918397705
and instead of four musketoons and twelve balls, we shall have fifteen	272.02876511698423
guns and a hundred charges to fire.”	183.59682672429577
“Oh, Athos!” said Aramis, “truly you are a great man.”	202.3565187715754
Porthos nodded in sign of agreement. D’Artagnan alone did not seem	283.79847108293984
convinced.	184.17690681028162
Grimaud no doubt shared the misgivings of the young man, for seeing	345.9023778913702
that they continued to advance toward the bastion—something he had till	291.79887531781185
then doubted—he pulled his master by the skirt of his coat.	311.3736608470448
“Where are we going?” asked he, by a gesture.	302.8196280862119
Athos pointed to the bastion.	282.7448600055463
“But,” said Grimaud, in the same silent dialect, “we shall leave our	235.18634475574845
skins there.”	298.8751771342842
Athos raised his eyes and his finger toward heaven.	170.4389282270775
Grimaud put his basket on the ground and sat down with a shake of the	172.3394343283431
head.	183.3889543876599
Athos took a pistol from his belt, looked to see if it was properly	173.6650903183067
primed, cocked it, and placed the muzzle close to Grimaud’s ear.	265.05181729869
Grimaud was on his legs again as if by a spring. Athos then made him a	240.3623751901697
sign to take up his basket and to walk on first. Grimaud obeyed. All	198.35734779860468
that Grimaud gained by this momentary pantomime was to pass from the	363.25143388988783
rear guard to the vanguard.	221.30534604985306
Arrived at the bastion, the four friends turned round.	288.77817015153477
More than three hundred soldiers of all kinds were assembled at the	302.9240264191964
gate of the camp; and in a separate group might be distinguished M. de	297.1554067890859
Busigny, the dragoon, the Swiss, and the fourth bettor.	312.8363555333312
Athos took off his hat, placed it on the end of his sword, and waved it	257.90479270564043
in the air.	332.2328460546829
All the spectators returned him his salute, accompanying this courtesy	190.248031030933
with a loud hurrah which was audible to the four; after which all four	289.96225798227795
disappeared in the bastion, whither Grimaud had preceded them.	166.24912713548798
Chapter XLVII.	297.1926037006409
THE COUNCIL OF THE MUSKETEERS	236.91395093055166
As Athos had foreseen, the bastion was only occupied by a dozen	188.13631927614153
corpses, French and Rochellais.	263.3044453733083
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, who had assumed the command of the expedition,	360.88938581886526
“while Grimaud spreads the table, let us begin by collecting the guns	233.16570858627153
and cartridges together. We can talk while performing that necessary	275.42826167594865
task. These gentlemen,” added he, pointing to the bodies, “cannot hear	317.213224102444
us.”	288.7477499224869
“But we could throw them into the ditch,” said Porthos, “after having	226.65393580123595
assured ourselves they have nothing in their pockets.”	185.56728940318771
“Yes,” said Athos, “that’s Grimaud’s business.”	304.0344968336749
“Well, then,” cried D’Artagnan, “pray let Grimaud search them and throw	168.54024194765114
them over the walls.”	290.423581149713
“Heaven forfend!” said Athos; “they may serve us.”	248.06407301777466
“These bodies serve us?” said Porthos. “You are mad, dear friend.”	297.10230575807765
“Judge not rashly, say the gospel and the cardinal,” replied Athos.	217.9258171803427
“How many guns, gentlemen?”	281.02185269562574
“Twelve,” replied Aramis.	327.8426616209897
“How many shots?”	267.12556420141414
“A hundred.”	175.4378084337314
“That’s quite as many as we shall want. Let us load the guns.”	359.3962026446287
The four Musketeers went to work; and as they were loading the last	237.41525054324552
musket Grimaud announced that the breakfast was ready.	214.6287184444743
Athos replied, always by gestures, that that was well, and indicated to	197.39004614137068
Grimaud, by pointing to a turret that resembled a pepper caster, that	275.72598636459554
he was to stand as sentinel. Only, to alleviate the tediousness of the	253.5649867564735
duty, Athos allowed him to take a loaf, two cutlets, and a bottle of	240.6206630837416
wine.	324.8854750972589
“And now to table,” said Athos.	256.9729917778848
The four friends seated themselves on the ground with their legs	271.3367826207717
crossed like Turks, or even tailors.	233.67389907542713
“And now,” said D’Artagnan, “as there is no longer any fear of being	361.6915011537424
overheard, I hope you are going to let me into your secret.”	167.65173225207735
“I hope at the same time to procure you amusement and glory,	216.7203539382191
gentlemen,” said Athos. “I have induced you to take a charming	176.77852241675612
promenade; here is a delicious breakfast; and yonder are five hundred	255.2251214505644
persons, as you may see through the loopholes, taking us for heroes or	342.33281136399717
madmen—two classes of imbeciles greatly resembling each other.”	229.04607348230002
“But the secret!” said D’Artagnan.	168.8400339201224
“The secret is,” said Athos, “that I saw Milady last night.”	296.6697699158112
D’Artagnan was lifting a glass to his lips; but at the name of Milady,	258.95196714424264
his hand trembled so, that he was obliged to put the glass on the	265.57021559785306
ground again for fear of spilling the contents.”	250.91373145215357
“You saw your wi—”	298.87535919262547
“Hush!” interrupted Athos. “You forget, my dear, you forget that these	186.17597128476703
gentlemen are not initiated into my family affairs like yourself. I	178.54973233903615
have seen Milady.”	343.82420099531714
“Where?” demanded D’Artagnan.	237.93732357106413
“Within two leagues of this place, at the inn of the Red Dovecot.”	234.12226070724935
“In that case I am lost,” said D’Artagnan.	176.73589396988987
“Not so bad yet,” replied Athos; “for by this time she must have quit	244.49244991880408
the shores of France.”	274.04058077382956
D’Artagnan breathed again.	252.35931263333316
“But after all,” asked Porthos, “who is Milady?”	228.0166546050095
“A charming woman!” said Athos, sipping a glass of sparkling wine.	282.2068177333168
“Villainous host!” cried he, “he has given us Anjou wine instead of	261.9304101220322
champagne, and fancies we know no better! Yes,” continued he, “a	176.59553535780555
charming woman, who entertained kind views toward our friend	177.06549068721716
D’Artagnan, who, on his part, has given her some offense for which she	218.51396886678896
tried to revenge herself a month ago by having him killed by two musket	276.7576923066516
shots, a week ago by trying to poison him, and yesterday by demanding	315.54577171854055
his head of the cardinal.”	330.21874563175265
“What! by demanding my head of the cardinal?” cried D’Artagnan, pale	359.7054415218315
with terror.	237.77564711723915
“Yes, that is true as the Gospel,” said Porthos; “I heard her with my	362.84360369633225
own ears.”	311.1030914800057
“I also,” said Aramis.	272.0917849196726
“Then,” said D’Artagnan, letting his arm fall with discouragement, “it	270.08918102522637
is useless to struggle longer. I may as well blow my brains out, and	357.6918442726591
all will be over.”	266.9550238228759
“That’s the last folly to be committed,” said Athos, “seeing it is the	241.8290934587714
only one for which there is no remedy.”	274.92841703585
“But I can never escape,” said D’Artagnan, “with such enemies. First,	359.5581781556733
my stranger of Meung; then De Wardes, to whom I have given three sword	211.2128713182133
wounds; next Milady, whose secret I have discovered; finally, the	282.83232448473836
cardinal, whose vengeance I have balked.”	228.59922598790254
“Well,” said Athos, “that only makes four; and we are four—one for one.	311.33348363653846
_Pardieu!_ if we may believe the signs Grimaud is making, we are about	187.71681111711928
to have to do with a very different number of people. What is it,	358.76120794930637
Grimaud? Considering the gravity of the occasion, I permit you to	281.83116479407215
speak, my friend; but be laconic, I beg. What do you see?”	263.71567490868847
“A troop.”	235.8485762743395
“Of how many persons?”	317.4293295873707
“Twenty men.”	344.54838421401075
“What sort of men?”	210.1632784529787
“Sixteen pioneers, four soldiers.”	218.53724436577485
“How far distant?”	266.4021793064158
“Five hundred paces.”	196.0885310584073
“Good! We have just time to finish this fowl and to drink one glass of	209.8121988002386
wine to your health, D’Artagnan.”	291.5674006831618
“To your health!” repeated Porthos and Aramis.	315.70555282598883
“Well, then, to my health! although I am very much afraid that your	245.4665412749838
good wishes will not be of great service to me.”	168.56242503573696
“Bah!” said Athos, “God is great, as say the followers of Mohammed, and	247.19727432197553
the future is in his hands.”	194.18765868619766
Then, swallowing the contents of his glass, which he put down close to	245.49564877238873
him, Athos arose carelessly, took the musket next to him, and drew near	347.99869054569047
to one of the loopholes.	204.43839121664115
Porthos, Aramis and D’Artagnan followed his example. As to Grimaud, he	277.0450098580596
received orders to place himself behind the four friends in order to	198.46528203745885
reload their weapons.	193.72094761163387
“_Pardieu!_” said Athos, “it was hardly worth while to distribute	204.89579017416168
ourselves for twenty fellows armed with pickaxes, mattocks, and	175.6226017237445
shovels. Grimaud had only to make them a sign to go away, and I am	286.0553700404083
convinced they would have left us in peace.”	342.65025791107314
“I doubt that,” replied D’Artagnan, “for they are advancing very	297.6797815394436
resolutely. Besides, in addition to the pioneers, there are four	365.232712850489
soldiers and a brigadier, armed with muskets.”	360.5510985194004
“That’s because they don’t see us,” said Athos.	300.73367513120405
“My faith,” said Aramis, “I must confess I feel a great repugnance to	223.04208897499814
fire on these poor devils of civilians.”	206.30558158046753
“He is a bad priest,” said Porthos, “who has pity for heretics.”	315.1900804951087
“In truth,” said Athos, “Aramis is right. I will warn them.”	257.89828007646986
“What the devil are you going to do?” cried D’Artagnan, “you will be	313.73173835306574
shot.”	245.70621539468067
But Athos heeded not his advice. Mounting on the breach, with his	197.20948001957174
musket in one hand and his hat in the other, he said, bowing	348.2154482229171
courteously and addressing the soldiers and the pioneers, who,	179.84554933906978
astonished at this apparition, stopped fifty paces from the bastion:	365.1855284843498
“Gentlemen, a few friends and myself are about to breakfast in this	310.4042977149598
bastion. Now, you know nothing is more disagreeable than being	179.34698073495744
disturbed when one is at breakfast. We request you, then, if you really	335.6025639745857
have business here, to wait till we have finished our repast, or to	199.3374637128055
come again a short time hence; unless, which would be far better, you	299.0347377820334
form the salutary resolution to quit the side of the rebels, and come	224.55365622420734
and drink with us to the health of the King of France.”	264.77807793600067
“Take care, Athos!” cried D’Artagnan; “don’t you see they are aiming?”	252.39796609711027
“Yes, yes,” said Athos; “but they are only civilians—very bad marksmen,	208.6008233750107
who will be sure not to hit me.”	296.3106152325771
In fact, at the same instant four shots were fired, and the balls were	298.8488970564597
flattened against the wall around Athos, but not one touched him.	226.6890397458666
Four shots replied to them almost instantaneously, but much better	345.9801354102494
aimed than those of the aggressors; three soldiers fell dead, and one	176.07666441611178
of the pioneers was wounded.	202.121846476684
“Grimaud,” said Athos, still on the breach, “another musket!”	283.91313141029536
Grimaud immediately obeyed. On their part, the three friends had	314.7357516245195
reloaded their arms; a second discharge followed the first. The	314.04773582356216
brigadier and two pioneers fell dead; the rest of the troop took to	337.76664833505083
flight.	310.1691777473686
“Now, gentlemen, a _sortie!_” cried Athos.	362.4928822245921
And the four friends rushed out of the fort, gained the field of	348.65835656012916
battle, picked up the four muskets of the privates and the half-pike of	221.8503220523873
the brigadier, and convinced that the fugitives would not stop till	266.82537304343157
they reached the city, turned again toward the bastion, bearing with	343.21361302152997
them the trophies of their victory.	242.1369757008231
“Reload the muskets, Grimaud,” said Athos, “and we, gentlemen, will go	243.52613660955006
on with our breakfast, and resume our conversation. Where were we?”	182.46986950648878
“I recollect you were saying,” said D’Artagnan, “that after having	228.489878745701
demanded my head of the cardinal, Milady had quit the shores of France.	332.8485849889995
Whither goes she?” added he, strongly interested in the route Milady	301.2748500798806
followed.	321.0910067926199
“She goes into England,” said Athos.	329.11786952607645
“With what view?”	300.28178180147756
“With the view of assassinating, or causing to be assassinated, the	210.3689417704872
Duke of Buckingham.”	176.76703772599913
D’Artagnan uttered an exclamation of surprise and indignation.	296.57583954989536
“But this is infamous!” cried he.	248.65208248111378
“As to that,” said Athos, “I beg you to believe that I care very little	184.66715234906587
about it. Now you have done, Grimaud, take our brigadier’s half-pike,	347.288942807266
tie a napkin to it, and plant it on top of our bastion, that these	264.89735337939067
rebels of Rochellais may see that they have to deal with brave and	357.0927133896904
loyal soldiers of the king.”	213.86815121667874
Grimaud obeyed without replying. An instant afterward, the white flag	270.0257012900536
was floating over the heads of the four friends. A thunder of applause	282.6342085801888
saluted its appearance; half the camp was at the barrier.	342.83784159194283
“How?” replied D’Artagnan, “you care little if she kills Buckingham or	202.74190581481588
causes him to be killed? But the duke is our friend.”	179.608729924527
“The duke is English; the duke fights against us. Let her do what she	258.3818291649401
likes with the duke; I care no more about him than an empty bottle.”	292.1801521260551
And Athos threw fifteen paces from him an empty bottle from which he	342.9767309826657
had poured the last drop into his glass.	323.719800764559
“A moment,” said D’Artagnan. “I will not abandon Buckingham thus. He	272.2144851224209
gave us some very fine horses.”	225.9679823367038
“And moreover, very handsome saddles,” said Porthos, who at the moment	224.20228701870064
wore on his cloak the lace of his own.	259.8125093713245
“Besides,” said Aramis, “God desires the conversion and not the death	199.85472892804108
of a sinner.”	180.17718358650956
“Amen!” said Athos, “and we will return to that subject later, if such	265.3452976376473
be your pleasure; but what for the moment engaged my attention most	222.50135008945645
earnestly, and I am sure you will understand me, D’Artagnan, was the	365.63615135961174
getting from this woman a kind of _carte blanche_ which she had	202.3587977756389
extorted from the cardinal, and by means of which she could with	168.61872004216275
impunity get rid of you and perhaps of us.”	262.75111831595865
“But this creature must be a demon!” said Porthos, holding out his	295.953462057263
plate to Aramis, who was cutting up a fowl.	323.40222280176823
“And this _carte blanche_,” said D’Artagnan, “this _carte blanche_,	324.8026838002188
does it remain in her hands?”	219.27210800849664
“No, it passed into mine; I will not say without trouble, for if I did	170.93242430618176
I should tell a lie.”	272.58862164769425
“My dear Athos, I shall no longer count the number of times I am	272.5173780752592
indebted to you for my life.”	292.29522303026016
“Then it was to go to her that you left us?” said Aramis.	298.7317934627016
“Exactly.”	172.07740417369388
“And you have that letter of the cardinal?” said D’Artagnan.	183.52670612769404
“Here it is,” said Athos; and he took the invaluable paper from the	232.39627355558434
pocket of his uniform. D’Artagnan unfolded it with one hand, whose	236.99470489855554
trembling he did not even attempt to conceal, to read:	322.48128742773605
“Dec. 3, 1627	291.03064637882153
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	240.72841495492867
this has done what he has done.	216.82024225434333
“RICHELIEU”	191.86679018519254
“In fact,” said Aramis, “it is an absolution according to rule.”	299.7556321518612
“That paper must be torn to pieces,” said D’Artagnan, who fancied he	246.41033501955448
read in it his sentence of death.	361.2810815330091
“On the contrary,” said Athos, “it must be preserved carefully. I would	231.64837393747635
not give up this paper if covered with as many gold pieces.”	311.9307168359161
“And what will she do now?” asked the young man.	247.44567105254424
“Why,” replied Athos, carelessly, “she is probably going to write to	254.2103015415272
the cardinal that a damned Musketeer, named Athos, has taken her	200.4144335457674
safe-conduct from her by force; she will advise him in the same letter	292.0100399692886
to get rid of his two friends, Aramis and Porthos, at the same time.	219.48339758087525
The cardinal will remember that these are the same men who have often	289.1319933789
crossed his path; and then some fine morning he will arrest D’Artagnan,	216.25619481978583
and for fear he should feel lonely, he will send us to keep him company	236.80256221083152
in the Bastille.”	312.9596214780556
“Go to! It appears to me you make dull jokes, my dear,” said Porthos.	337.2347982349084
“I do not jest,” said Athos.	231.8760372798808
“Do you know,” said Porthos, “that to twist that damned Milady’s neck	279.4668470066757
would be a smaller sin than to twist those of these poor devils of	327.4443670082403
Huguenots, who have committed no other crime than singing in French the	178.43921249491342
psalms we sing in Latin?”	175.1853859439728
“What says the abbé?” asked Athos, quietly.	214.39637607602117
“I say I am entirely of Porthos’s opinion,” replied Aramis.	308.7553282912156
“And I, too,” said D’Artagnan.	198.3837171516275
“Fortunately, she is far off,” said Porthos, “for I confess she would	206.05233793374953
worry me if she were here.”	201.22333845533274
“She worries me in England as well as in France,” said Athos.	267.8749291419048
“She worries me everywhere,” said D’Artagnan.	170.35327428935764
“But when you held her in your power, why did you not drown her,	291.4324383871621
strangle her, hang her?” said Porthos. “It is only the dead who do not	205.06891174955285
return.”	276.8665497136632
“You think so, Porthos?” replied the Musketeer, with a sad smile which	238.74309121011203
D’Artagnan alone understood.	313.24754985184984
“I have an idea,” said D’Artagnan.	176.45135643614782
“What is it?” said the Musketeers.	222.8235338496664
“To arms!” cried Grimaud.	350.3983971636233
The young men sprang up, and seized their muskets.	166.9977462570601
This time a small troop advanced, consisting of from twenty to	290.6305240882439
twenty-five men; but they were not pioneers, they were soldiers of the	346.98723639829296
garrison.	295.2444960933359
“Shall we return to the camp?” said Porthos. “I don’t think the sides	297.20649621536666
are equal.”	173.8239877337879
“Impossible, for three reasons,” replied Athos. “The first, that we	222.05183513831287
have not finished breakfast; the second, that we still have some very	186.73149261220792
important things to say; and the third, that it yet wants ten minutes	193.88308303670334
before the lapse of the hour.”	254.0089357319214
“Well, then,” said Aramis, “we must form a plan of battle.”	280.4217715966433
“That’s very simple,” replied Athos. “As soon as the enemy are within	243.92042109254226
musket shot, we must fire upon them. If they continue to advance, we	335.5447942862862
must fire again. We must fire as long as we have loaded guns. If those	251.6938369773615
who remain of the troop persist in coming to the assault, we will allow	251.07240602229413
the besiegers to get as far as the ditch, and then we will push down	204.47088254883283
upon their heads that strip of wall which keeps its perpendicular by a	236.71819007853335
miracle.”	344.28954510470794
“Bravo!” cried Porthos. “Decidedly, Athos, you were born to be a	218.95003981796563
general, and the cardinal, who fancies himself a great soldier, is	321.41161541131214
nothing beside you.”	235.29042491614948
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “no divided attention, I beg; let each one	231.7491839457866
pick out his man.”	258.13460318401656
“I cover mine,” said D’Artagnan.	209.93128880268262
“And I mine,” said Porthos.	274.30619922319784
“And I _idem_,” said Aramis.	362.96200780555034
“Fire, then,” said Athos.	344.7515081408931
The four muskets made but one report, but four men fell.	331.6444254255673
The drum immediately beat, and the little troop advanced at charging	270.1528225746405
pace.	294.441436456805
Then the shots were repeated without regularity, but always aimed with	275.93256854255117
the same accuracy. Nevertheless, as if they had been aware of the	212.11411874969812
numerical weakness of the friends, the Rochellais continued to advance	257.3301974406064
in quick time.	167.18326257620572
With every three shots at least two men fell; but the march of those	255.7306071921384
who remained was not slackened.	312.7299696257892
Arrived at the foot of the bastion, there were still more than a dozen	230.13535160713076
of the enemy. A last discharge welcomed them, but did not stop them;	239.04089726781643
they jumped into the ditch, and prepared to scale the breach.	238.43899269978903
“Now, my friends,” said Athos, “finish them at a blow. To the wall; to	314.9291271341515
the wall!”	286.83852259281844
And the four friends, seconded by Grimaud, pushed with the barrels of	269.84009731495246
their muskets an enormous sheet of the wall, which bent as if pushed by	192.17911516026453
the wind, and detaching itself from its base, fell with a horrible	166.80800511154592
crash into the ditch. Then a fearful crash was heard; a cloud of dust	226.4046141082681
mounted toward the sky—and all was over!	166.80385550558682
“Can we have destroyed them all, from the first to the last?” said	176.25098798759086
Athos.	206.96858523604237
“My faith, it appears so!” said D’Artagnan.	171.66914900502186
“No,” cried Porthos; “there go three or four, limping away.”	269.19248007607933
In fact, three or four of these unfortunate men, covered with dirt and	294.1769575550792
blood, fled along the hollow way, and at length regained the city.	268.55579142162003
These were all who were left of the little troop.	333.20951905678044
Athos looked at his watch.	353.59137860232727
“Gentlemen,” said he, “we have been here an hour, and our wager is won;	284.94090676966067
but we will be fair players. Besides, D’Artagnan has not told us his	333.11673184753874
idea yet.”	231.83867462409074
And the Musketeer, with his usual coolness, reseated himself before the	181.33003532677589
remains of the breakfast.	177.09913691929992
“My idea?” said D’Artagnan.	326.37704739288415
“Yes; you said you had an idea,” said Athos.	313.1756894112287
“Oh, I remember,” said D’Artagnan. “Well, I will go to England a second	214.68279639926482
time; I will go and find Buckingham.”	206.69941647393694
“You shall not do that, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, coolly.	216.62299610095573
“And why not? Have I not been there once?”	223.03415453024118
“Yes; but at that period we were not at war. At that period Buckingham	268.18396644368545
was an ally, and not an enemy. What you would now do amounts to	246.18242055623364
treason.”	315.22681107339724
D’Artagnan perceived the force of this reasoning, and was silent.	181.79125923986425
“But,” said Porthos, “I think I have an idea, in my turn.”	249.92957539705878
“Silence for Monsieur Porthos’s idea!” said Aramis.	226.98085944771054
“I will ask leave of absence of Monsieur de Tréville, on some pretext	207.31529656811014
or other which you must invent; I am not very clever at pretexts.	309.67164926190367
Milady does not know me; I will get access to her without her	231.18814652434313
suspecting me, and when I catch my beauty, I will strangle her.”	260.1506821231702
“Well,” replied Athos, “I am not far from approving the idea of	188.2379295518098
Monsieur Porthos.”	214.69870421584602
“For shame!” said Aramis. “Kill a woman? No, listen to me; I have the	233.17220912821807
true idea.”	256.0285885183538
“Let us see your idea, Aramis,” said Athos, who felt much deference for	327.7938088056698
the young Musketeer.	322.59448684164533
“We must inform the queen.”	342.23973955984013
“Ah, my faith, yes!” said Porthos and D’Artagnan, at the same time; “we	225.12036072292017
are coming nearer to it now.”	312.84797043414676
“Inform the queen!” said Athos; “and how? Have we relations with the	344.97459345857396
court? Could we send anyone to Paris without its being known in the	326.54906349121313
camp? From here to Paris it is a hundred and forty leagues; before our	318.9159403038384
letter was at Angers we should be in a dungeon.”	251.13926140282643
“As to remitting a letter with safety to her Majesty,” said Aramis,	325.54360343716775
coloring, “I will take that upon myself. I know a clever person at	201.44377106306212
Tours—”	282.3968102509071
Aramis stopped on seeing Athos smile.	229.58895265544305
“Well, do you not adopt this means, Athos?” said D’Artagnan.	293.46615710730646
“I do not reject it altogether,” said Athos; “but I wish to remind	209.3807306459476
Aramis that he cannot quit the camp, and that nobody but one of	363.40824835889316
ourselves is trustworthy; that two hours after the messenger has set	279.8607560314573
out, all the Capuchins, all the police, all the black caps of the	222.75778436359244
cardinal, will know your letter by heart, and you and your clever	174.1203345439731
person will be arrested.”	315.9818977706858
“Without reckoning,” objected Porthos, “that the queen would save	258.4864399070691
Monsieur de Buckingham, but would take no heed of us.”	209.75808002297651
“Gentlemen,” said D’Artagnan, “what Porthos says is full of sense.”	289.88331845972783
“Ah, ah! but what’s going on in the city yonder?” said Athos.	314.91824238440233
“They are beating the general alarm.”	288.0863975290143
The four friends listened, and the sound of the drum plainly reached	168.5665506682111
them.	187.90566454344784
“You see, they are going to send a whole regiment against us,” said	309.1268141618157
Athos.	272.84335234891455
“You don’t think of holding out against a whole regiment, do you?” said	321.63772750055944
Porthos.	301.07471886311953
“Why not?” said the Musketeer. “I feel myself quite in a humor for it;	326.23590642370095
and I would hold out before an army if we had taken the precaution to	227.96448653503313
bring a dozen more bottles of wine.”	358.28772835400457
“Upon my word, the drum draws near,” said D’Artagnan.	250.8726756000541
“Let it come,” said Athos. “It is a quarter of an hour’s journey from	178.82678230951288
here to the city, consequently a quarter of an hour’s journey from the	208.75592226977034
city to hither. That is more than time enough for us to devise a plan.	219.54605260878242
If we go from this place we shall never find another so suitable. Ah,	304.09976809441775
stop! I have it, gentlemen; the right idea has just occurred to me.”	323.20033811399344
“Tell us.”	364.5146673053383
“Allow me to give Grimaud some indispensable orders.”	250.69610737760812
Athos made a sign for his lackey to approach.	349.57358020468064
“Grimaud,” said Athos, pointing to the bodies which lay under the wall	234.26262527857546
of the bastion, “take those gentlemen, set them up against the wall,	262.5145665702854
put their hats upon their heads, and their guns in their hands.”	276.6852551113288
“Oh, the great man!” cried D’Artagnan. “I comprehend now.”	317.35456172291407
“You comprehend?” said Porthos.	258.8930819731387
“And do you comprehend, Grimaud?” said Aramis.	335.5647718124575
Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative.	203.77969922379066
“That’s all that is necessary,” said Athos; “now for my idea.”	224.7822094774333
“I should like, however, to comprehend,” said Porthos.	240.0774310918403
“That is useless.”	302.868466127395
“Yes, yes! Athos’s idea!” cried Aramis and D’Artagnan, at the same	258.01258832040423
time.	227.81379284152905
“This Milady, this woman, this creature, this demon, has a	200.74257742186035
brother-in-law, as I think you told me, D’Artagnan?”	262.58619139553264
“Yes, I know him very well; and I also believe that he has not a very	245.0466790956977
warm affection for his sister-in-law.”	313.54401750631405
“There is no harm in that. If he detested her, it would be all the	275.48178328539
better,” replied Athos.	166.7761368423552
“In that case we are as well off as we wish.”	257.15421749291824
“And yet,” said Porthos, “I would like to know what Grimaud is about.”	307.3544843696419
“Silence, Porthos!” said Aramis.	275.34485317269946
“What is her brother-in-law’s name?”	171.45230745157414
“Lord de Winter.”	220.93030215538136
“Where is he now?”	279.56403280693667
“He returned to London at the first sound of war.”	250.03260775590215
“Well, there’s just the man we want,” said Athos. “It is he whom we	193.18805224712403
must warn. We will have him informed that his sister-in-law is on the	274.1472802766892
point of having someone assassinated, and beg him not to lose sight of	322.48188881184376
her. There is in London, I hope, some establishment like that of the	222.39415494317223
Magdalens, or of the Repentant Daughters. He must place his sister in	303.34009455785167
one of these, and we shall be in peace.”	229.8503418226441
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “till she comes out.”	293.84876490554524
“Ah, my faith!” said Athos, “you require too much, D’Artagnan. I have	237.59564682458657
given you all I have, and I beg leave to tell you that this is the	338.4855079766389
bottom of my sack.”	272.82587363574805
“But I think it would be still better,” said Aramis, “to inform the	174.6223605177173
queen and Lord de Winter at the same time.”	306.3406125778775
“Yes; but who is to carry the letter to Tours, and who to London?”	316.7057286451369
“I answer for Bazin,” said Aramis.	222.36807904579052
“And I for Planchet,” said D’Artagnan.	307.1826911958816
“Ay,” said Porthos, “if we cannot leave the camp, our lackeys may.”	253.71907331104228
“To be sure they may; and this very day we will write the letters,”	260.03957826267856
said Aramis. “Give the lackeys money, and they will start.”	173.97702352224866
“We will give them money?” replied Athos. “Have you any money?”	219.95605265478542
The four friends looked at one another, and a cloud came over the brows	220.55963718712752
which but lately had been so cheerful.	232.99340699199246
“Look out!” cried D’Artagnan, “I see black points and red points moving	351.83068233428276
yonder. Why did you talk of a regiment, Athos? It is a veritable army!”	167.8049521685755
“My faith, yes,” said Athos; “there they are. See the sneaks come,	210.33651099936313
without drum or trumpet. Ah, ah! have you finished, Grimaud?”	279.26983178122714
Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative, and pointed to a dozen bodies	306.4334246945074
which he had set up in the most picturesque attitudes. Some carried	171.2399852990993
arms, others seemed to be taking aim, and the remainder appeared merely	222.97543167393488
to be sword in hand.	172.71980701643292
“Bravo!” said Athos; “that does honor to your imagination.”	271.80923671894186
“All very well,” said Porthos, “but I should like to understand.”	224.20688758819733
“Let us decamp first, and you will understand afterward.”	256.5034477964298
“A moment, gentlemen, a moment; give Grimaud time to clear away the	291.422609341462
breakfast.”	349.41750931167354
“Ah, ah!” said Aramis, “the black points and the red points are visibly	251.85834197399896
enlarging. I am of D’Artagnan’s opinion; we have no time to lose in	262.5214946005497
regaining our camp.”	362.3809886568646
“My faith,” said Athos, “I have nothing to say against a retreat. We	271.9698283373268
bet upon one hour, and we have stayed an hour and a half. Nothing can	172.79870585915293
be said; let us be off, gentlemen, let us be off!”	231.52211976568913
Grimaud was already ahead, with the basket and the dessert. The four	274.7651031694475
friends followed, ten paces behind him.	256.47611750201577
“What the devil shall we do now, gentlemen?” cried Athos.	329.9164198760382
“Have you forgotten anything?” said Aramis.	341.95723573006455
“The white flag, _morbleu!_ We must not leave a flag in the hands of	263.19719872564076
the enemy, even if that flag be but a napkin.”	259.15760649779116
And Athos ran back to the bastion, mounted the platform, and bore off	326.5494800996104
the flag; but as the Rochellais had arrived within musket range, they	220.85132677672078
opened a terrible fire upon this man, who appeared to expose himself	298.89685056197686
for pleasure’s sake.	284.5908835334285
But Athos might be said to bear a charmed life. The balls passed and	312.5841609562119
whistled all around him; not one struck him.	316.3116133177185
Athos waved his flag, turning his back on the guards of the city, and	344.28900457798215
saluting those of the camp. On both sides loud cries arose—on the one	317.61365345098693
side cries of anger, on the other cries of enthusiasm.	357.8661724606138
A second discharge followed the first, and three balls, by passing	302.2471664454732
through it, made the napkin really a flag. Cries were heard from the	352.6363175739135
camp, “Come down! come down!”	190.71781954948977
Athos came down; his friends, who anxiously awaited him, saw him	349.5828790728949
returned with joy.	311.1080781347083
“Come along, Athos, come along!” cried D’Artagnan; “now we have found	353.82122148126234
everything except money, it would be stupid to be killed.”	280.24747901240454
But Athos continued to march majestically, whatever remarks his	211.95005358480097
companions made; and they, finding their remarks useless, regulated	211.26577578399056
their pace by his.	257.77566234067655
Grimaud and his basket were far in advance, out of the range of the	334.40660183411643
balls.	219.78958678676403
At the end of an instant they heard a furious fusillade.	275.19696102307887
“What’s that?” asked Porthos, “what are they firing at now? I hear no	276.6831238579958
balls whistle, and I see nobody!”	219.3673956943503
“They are firing at the corpses,” replied Athos.	220.41635220680968
“But the dead cannot return their fire.”	363.100975505893
“Certainly not! They will then fancy it is an ambuscade, they will	291.5512623897034
deliberate; and by the time they have found out the pleasantry, we	210.96818180912385
shall be out of the range of their balls. That renders it useless to	223.43075024360184
get a pleurisy by too much haste.”	239.9701553318189
“Oh, I comprehend now,” said the astonished Porthos.	248.98444759740653
“That’s lucky,” said Athos, shrugging his shoulders.	313.61944519338044
On their part, the French, on seeing the four friends return at such a	363.5101478979768
step, uttered cries of enthusiasm.	299.9954101911228
At length a fresh discharge was heard, and this time the balls came	290.1999170578165
rattling among the stones around the four friends, and whistling	217.13506723000748
sharply in their ears. The Rochellais had at last taken possession of	257.12188423519854
the bastion.	252.9872942256308
“These Rochellais are bungling fellows,” said Athos; “how many have we	357.2413539270249
killed of them—a dozen?”	311.8748833260027
“Or fifteen.”	229.52845109878092
“How many did we crush under the wall?”	334.0215555881181
“Eight or ten.”	198.9086393352446
“And in exchange for all that not even a scratch! Ah, but what is the	297.54479085798675
matter with your hand, D’Artagnan? It bleeds, seemingly.”	180.46445075826944
“Oh, it’s nothing,” said D’Artagnan.	232.12509577535138
“A spent ball?”	339.13722420942037
“Not even that.”	325.13605243307745
“What is it, then?”	331.4136950656381
We have said that Athos loved D’Artagnan like a child, and this somber	221.02724869152368
and inflexible personage felt the anxiety of a parent for the young	185.06880954702893
man.	358.18128068457503
“Only grazed a little,” replied D’Artagnan; “my fingers were caught	351.1457510475435
between two stones—that of the wall and that of my ring—and the skin	232.71136117061957
was broken.”	352.00999034640887
“That comes of wearing diamonds, my master,” said Athos, disdainfully.	233.54687521865765
“Ah, to be sure,” cried Porthos, “there is a diamond. Why the devil,	245.0689577149239
then, do we plague ourselves about money, when there is a diamond?”	311.6546907412353
“Stop a bit!” said Aramis.	234.31781624930312
“Well thought of, Porthos; this time you have an idea.”	354.4222139993475
“Undoubtedly,” said Porthos, drawing himself up at Athos’s compliment;	225.6775867581386
“as there is a diamond, let us sell it.”	363.112278886951
“But,” said D’Artagnan, “it is the queen’s diamond.”	280.2589709814696
“The stronger reason why it should be sold,” replied Athos. “The queen	224.43313976478424
saving Monsieur de Buckingham, her lover; nothing more just. The queen	322.78931200093473
saving us, her friends; nothing more moral. Let us sell the diamond.	220.36182813263395
What says Monsieur the Abbé? I don’t ask Porthos; his opinion has been	317.9494541561372
given.”	302.1038736105006
“Why, I think,” said Aramis, blushing as usual, “that his ring not	176.87156488042768
coming from a mistress, and consequently not being a love token,	308.5287715196002
D’Artagnan may sell it.”	191.48162375951816
“My dear Aramis, you speak like theology personified. Your advice,	320.70752402200026
then, is—”	266.37227495608937
“To sell the diamond,” replied Aramis.	219.35561132988437
“Well, then,” said D’Artagnan, gaily, “let us sell the diamond, and say	307.17834511877754
no more about it.”	278.97192586280744
The fusillade continued; but the four friends were out of reach, and	330.4808244390118
the Rochellais only fired to appease their consciences.	330.69582536035614
“My faith, it was time that idea came into Porthos’s head. Here we are	174.79214534985636
at the camp; therefore, gentlemen, not a word more of this affair. We	268.49210815828985
are observed; they are coming to meet us. We shall be carried in	356.72066190246807
triumph.”	263.29894300209895
In fact, as we have said, the whole camp was in motion. More than two	169.33028525764198
thousand persons had assisted, as at a spectacle, in this fortunate but	227.70530237158903
wild undertaking of the four friends—an undertaking of which they were	364.6541063285647
far from suspecting the real motive. Nothing was heard but cries of	298.95740140323846
“Live the Musketeers! Live the Guards!” M. de Busigny was the first to	217.93720697003752
come and shake Athos by the hand, and acknowledge that the wager was	322.2628638045155
lost. The dragoon and the Swiss followed him, and all their comrades	260.625291658598
followed the dragoon and the Swiss. There was nothing but	222.6488155151972
felicitations, pressures of the hand, and embraces; there was no end to	230.57107466757145
the inextinguishable laughter at the Rochellais. The tumult at length	321.6217521834053
became so great that the cardinal fancied there must be some riot, and	242.67553600983396
sent La Houdinière, his captain of the Guards, to inquire what was	324.6350663943567
going on.	345.230427367449
The affair was described to the messenger with all the effervescence of	312.6735894225902
enthusiasm.	182.65387610214106
“Well?” asked the cardinal, on seeing La Houdinière return.	289.6609097735553
“Well, monseigneur,” replied the latter, “three Musketeers and a	189.75397582563014
Guardsman laid a wager with Monsieur de Busigny that they would go and	310.8128456403456
breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais; and while breakfasting they held	338.71645230469215
it for two hours against the enemy, and have killed I don’t know how	203.9487974848359
many Rochellais.”	340.4369147534592
“Did you inquire the names of those three Musketeers?”	289.8441814800631
“Yes, monseigneur.”	166.6955612897765
“What are their names?”	249.07932950415406
“Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.”	208.4094686049063
“Still my three brave fellows!” murmured the cardinal. “And the	354.2426681531118
Guardsman?”	206.3014896922522
“D’Artagnan.”	234.9011469750559
“Still my young scapegrace. Positively, these four men must be on my	268.61731186410884
side.”	214.37038471691903
The same evening the cardinal spoke to M. de Tréville of the exploit of	357.13743394793244
the morning, which was the talk of the whole camp. M. de Tréville, who	181.0599029451465
had received the account of the adventure from the mouths of the heroes	194.43384417900768
of it, related it in all its details to his Eminence, not forgetting	315.95382433016914
the episode of the napkin.	274.6455325047313
“That’s well, Monsieur de Tréville,” said the cardinal; “pray let that	192.284072525846
napkin be sent to me. I will have three _fleur-de-lis_ embroidered on	181.4058405935521
it in gold, and will give it to your company as a standard.”	238.7416191553296
“Monseigneur,” said M. de Tréville, “that will be unjust to the	298.7995079025468
Guardsmen. Monsieur d’Artagnan is not with me; he serves under Monsieur	185.2767627876391
Dessessart.”	288.48530497534375
“Well, then, take him,” said the cardinal; “when four men are so much	304.6498285186772
attached to one another, it is only fair that they should serve in the	280.5448560737241
same company.”	356.04428672624863
That same evening M. de Tréville announced this good news to the three	273.1092416911495
Musketeers and D’Artagnan, inviting all four to breakfast with him next	301.82698561931977
morning.	281.83562216476685
D’Artagnan was beside himself with joy. We know that the dream of his	178.97670885486258
life had been to become a Musketeer. The three friends were likewise	359.4864449585232
greatly delighted.	294.20348799526266
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan to Athos, “you had a triumphant idea! As	270.996474043231
you said, we have acquired glory, and were enabled to carry on a	190.08118644201778
conversation of the highest importance.”	208.95293925617142
“Which we can resume now without anybody suspecting us, for, with the	325.007184342991
help of God, we shall henceforth pass for cardinalists.”	339.7568393939554
That evening D’Artagnan went to present his respects to M. Dessessart,	234.49235706014292
and inform him of his promotion.	253.42569038205176
M. Dessessart, who esteemed D’Artagnan, made him offers of help, as	327.7132402098411
this change would entail expenses for equipment.	248.09389917701634
D’Artagnan refused; but thinking the opportunity a good one, he begged	232.64981357291725
him to have the diamond he put into his hand valued, as he wished to	214.5857473984767
turn it into money.	249.18329276886982
The next day, M. Dessessart’s valet came to D’Artagnan’s lodging, and	318.3999624571268
gave him a bag containing seven thousand livres.	328.29738834354475
