This was the price of the queen’s diamond.	313.7408814642197
Chapter XLVIII.	337.50933654639584
A FAMILY AFFAIR	206.46665257945216
Athos had invented the phrase, family affair. A family affair was not	183.95615133909348
subject to the investigation of the cardinal; a family affair concerned	356.306182793011
nobody. People might employ themselves in a family affair before all	331.33440784236745
the world. Therefore Athos had invented the phrase, _family affair_.	269.62455546273577
Aramis had discovered the idea, _the lackeys_.	256.0135503338713
Porthos had discovered the means, _the diamond_.	365.5276541964346
D’Artagnan alone had discovered nothing—he, ordinarily the most	194.5121270733953
inventive of the four; but it must be also said that the very name of	262.5240645022505
Milady paralyzed him.	338.3324140494141
Ah! no, we were mistaken; he had discovered a purchaser for his	288.56850701505016
diamond.	197.69909361629692
The breakfast at M. de Tréville’s was as gay and cheerful as possible.	331.3688530372343
D’Artagnan already wore his uniform—for being nearly of the same size	241.54604188935036
as Aramis, and as Aramis was so liberally paid by the publisher who	259.23520245555704
purchased his poem as to allow him to buy everything double, he sold	269.1288414898696
his friend a complete outfit.	269.945478064353
D’Artagnan would have been at the height of his wishes if he had not	277.7449763997974
constantly seen Milady like a dark cloud hovering in the horizon.	305.0887083655897
After breakfast, it was agreed that they should meet again in the	332.7099106089484
evening at Athos’s lodging, and there finish their plans.	179.35049908258844
D’Artagnan passed the day in exhibiting his Musketeer’s uniform in	224.66902459191397
every street of the camp.	200.59631802885596
In the evening, at the appointed hour, the four friends met. There only	308.15162831579
remained three things to decide—what they should write to Milady’s	297.88023418191653
brother; what they should write to the clever person at Tours; and	218.4219791841567
which should be the lackeys to carry the letters.	268.29931036875433
Everyone offered his own. Athos talked of the discretion of Grimaud,	312.8307185557745
who never spoke a word but when his master unlocked his mouth. Porthos	256.9362476030517
boasted of the strength of Mousqueton, who was big enough to thrash	196.529936472349
four men of ordinary size. Aramis, confiding in the address of Bazin,	297.6345428299218
made a pompous eulogium on his candidate. Finally, D’Artagnan had	197.18461114244047
entire faith in the bravery of Planchet, and reminded them of the	220.2629202729798
manner in which he had conducted himself in the ticklish affair of	362.3316874737146
Boulogne.	226.126756959494
These four virtues disputed the prize for a length of time, and gave	305.0316358370274
birth to magnificent speeches which we do not repeat here for fear they	220.18966549396484
should be deemed too long.	284.69994905528006
“Unfortunately,” said Athos, “he whom we send must possess in himself	277.91187513432465
alone the four qualities united.”	314.55538429966947
“But where is such a lackey to be found?”	224.25998987409946
“Not to be found!” cried Athos. “I know it well, so take Grimaud.”	272.24561610142297
“Take Mousqueton.”	272.1785577464725
“Take Bazin.”	333.9540626843084
“Take Planchet. Planchet is brave and shrewd; they are two qualities	348.5041045945966
out of the four.”	295.86995166403756
“Gentlemen,” said Aramis, “the principal question is not to know which	266.9278905586344
of our four lackeys is the most discreet, the most strong, the most	359.74325857088485
clever, or the most brave; the principal thing is to know which loves	192.25620102447365
money the best.”	241.55767988592
“What Aramis says is very sensible,” replied Athos; “we must speculate	341.9909678691813
upon the faults of people, and not upon their virtues. Monsieur Abbé,	176.86374053752698
you are a great moralist.”	239.280945240161
“Doubtless,” said Aramis, “for we not only require to be well served in	230.59585280194125
order to succeed, but moreover, not to fail; for in case of failure,	258.5926404237472
heads are in question, not for our lackeys—”	344.7589135239589
“Speak lower, Aramis,” said Athos.	198.10436545997803
“That’s wise—not for the lackeys,” resumed Aramis, “but for the	289.17231723117413
master—for the _masters_, we may say. Are our lackeys sufficiently	317.37911716744327
devoted to us to risk their lives for us? No.”	213.91625535588395
“My faith,” said D’Artagnan. “I would almost answer for Planchet.”	296.00084584917283
“Well, my dear friend, add to his natural devotedness a good sum of	304.71474347331593
money, and then, instead of answering for him once, answer for him	351.8102710086322
twice.”	328.0205507159152
“Why, good God! you will be deceived just the same,” said Athos, who	243.99718474230556
was an optimist when things were concerned, and a pessimist when men	355.36802372023783
were in question. “They will promise everything for the sake of the	281.7317765949548
money, and on the road fear will prevent them from acting. Once taken,	248.95020546024023
they will be pressed; when pressed, they will confess everything. What	230.47241985514125
the devil! we are not children. To reach England”—Athos lowered his	171.5429267020997
voice—“all France, covered with spies and creatures of the cardinal,	247.8918149876154
must be crossed. A passport for embarkation must be obtained; and the	285.4363743183949
party must be acquainted with English in order to ask the way to	278.8740368498859
London. Really, I think the thing very difficult.”	206.2518350948769
“Not at all,” cried D’Artagnan, who was anxious the matter should be	201.16203077452772
accomplished; “on the contrary, I think it very easy. It would be, no	167.03648178953722
doubt, _parbleu_, if we write to Lord de Winter about affairs of vast	214.83652786447786
importance, of the horrors of the cardinal—”	356.56746728233276
“Speak lower!” said Athos.	259.25830420901025
“—of intrigues and secrets of state,” continued D’Artagnan, complying	197.22228748809516
with the recommendation. “There can be no doubt we would all be broken	317.5219576911535
on the wheel; but for God’s sake, do not forget, as you yourself said,	311.5136276914898
Athos, that we only write to him concerning a family affair; that we	323.54674495453264
only write to him to entreat that as soon as Milady arrives in London	277.1658062915685
he will put it out of her power to injure us. I will write to him,	360.33352729971574
then, nearly in these terms.”	290.19215141933586
“Let us see,” said Athos, assuming in advance a critical look.	205.493730360281
“_Monsieur and dear friend_—”	359.2752469487365
“Ah, yes! _Dear friend_ to an Englishman,” interrupted Athos; “well	360.42299947944343
commenced! Bravo, D’Artagnan! Only with that word you would be	199.35638070065085
quartered instead of being broken on the wheel.”	256.39033980881
“Well, perhaps. I will say, then, _Monsieur_, quite short.”	352.68116899556924
“You may even say, _My Lord_,” replied Athos, who stickled for	232.79268742778657
propriety.	330.0084780615314
“_My Lord, do you remember the little goat pasture of the Luxembourg?_”	201.84562443297997
“Good, _the Luxembourg!_ One might believe this is an allusion to the	207.50395035963777
queen-mother! That’s ingenious,” said Athos.	193.1214629053333
“Well, then, we will put simply, _My Lord, do you remember a certain	204.1613484877185
little enclosure where your life was spared?_”	312.39022200708257
“My dear D’Artagnan, you will never make anything but a very bad	230.74419084534793
secretary. _Where your life was spared!_ For shame! that’s unworthy. A	360.0667865345264
man of spirit is not to be reminded of such services. A benefit	264.41171261696155
reproached is an offense committed.”	332.2449176478017
“The devil!” said D’Artagnan, “you are insupportable. If the letter	220.8996394726938
must be written under your censure, my faith, I renounce the task.”	192.32933351093544
“And you will do right. Handle the musket and the sword, my dear	363.7812431846385
fellow. You will come off splendidly at those two exercises; but pass	275.07747887989495
the pen over to Monsieur Abbé. That’s his province.”	166.19050988057305
“Ay, ay!” said Porthos; “pass the pen to Aramis, who writes theses in	290.0737410766733
Latin.”	305.96788761833125
“Well, so be it,” said D’Artagnan. “Draw up this note for us, Aramis;	241.75803540890388
but by our Holy Father the Pope, cut it short, for I shall prune you in	338.46668626821895
my turn, I warn you.”	350.9708713726283
“I ask no better,” said Aramis, with that ingenious air of confidence	209.5036659216583
which every poet has in himself; “but let me be properly acquainted	170.83344032077468
with the subject. I have heard here and there that this sister-in-law	322.7348317663271
was a hussy. I have obtained proof of it by listening to her	258.5729724447374
conversation with the cardinal.”	294.756189595186
“Lower! _sacré bleu!_” said Athos.	332.95052586328745
“But,” continued Aramis, “the details escape me.”	233.9954564384617
“And me also,” said Porthos.	190.32492134452218
D’Artagnan and Athos looked at each other for some time in silence. At	276.6392192855835
length Athos, after serious reflection and becoming more pale than	316.6847985285292
usual, made a sign of assent to D’Artagnan, who by it understood he was	337.55992714938094
at liberty to speak.	234.61093190818303
“Well, this is what you have to say,” said D’Artagnan: “_My Lord, your	282.7342329123336
sister-in-law is an infamous woman, who wished to have you killed that	350.28307083754714
she might inherit your wealth; but she could not marry your brother,	251.67531959642724
being already married in France, and having been_—” D’Artagnan stopped,	167.01200209254964
as if seeking for the word, and looked at Athos.	299.1571117862393
“Repudiated by her husband,” said Athos.	174.86165653190923
“Because she had been branded,” continued D’Artagnan.	264.2993161367932
“Bah!” cried Porthos. “Impossible! What do you say—that she wanted to	189.70000400196338
have her brother-in-law killed?”	338.07825955805345
“Yes.”	171.9756258621755
“She was married?” asked Aramis.	216.33387395507623
“Yes.”	181.29075626209672
“And her husband found out that she had a _fleur-de-lis_ on her	252.7785676043868
shoulder?” cried Porthos.	218.09774568411578
“Yes.”	199.46635150073288
These three _yeses_ had been pronounced by Athos, each with a sadder	184.09724533851568
intonation.	192.93941510576522
“And who has seen this _fleur-de-lis?_” inquired Aramis.	243.46834994490655
“D’Artagnan and I. Or rather, to observe the chronological order, I and	362.02251145391324
D’Artagnan,” replied Athos.	201.35846124605175
“And does the husband of this frightful creature still live?” said	223.27989515171186
Aramis.	280.14761082061614
“He still lives.”	222.6283658374622
“Are you quite sure of it?”	328.36225608534824
“I am he.”	218.33372322701672
There was a moment of cold silence, during which everyone was affected	363.48581290664094
according to his nature.	346.9031710652478
“This time,” said Athos, first breaking the silence, “D’Artagnan has	271.7565198520742
given us an excellent program, and the letter must be written at once.”	254.59484098970455
“The devil! You are right, Athos,” said Aramis; “and it is a rather	284.49396871404366
difficult matter. The chancellor himself would be puzzled how to write	290.89225151358744
such a letter, and yet the chancellor draws up an official report very	331.8006785295422
readily. Never mind! Be silent, I will write.”	363.93048693057233
Aramis accordingly took the quill, reflected for a few moments, wrote	261.39922106256074
eight or ten lines in a charming little female hand, and then with a	211.10743662768425
voice soft and slow, as if each word had been scrupulously weighed, he	167.0085551922193
read the following:	355.44873448738974
“My Lord, The person who writes these few lines had the honor of	252.16722256079416
crossing swords with you in the little enclosure of the Rue d’Enfer. As	174.22888334404342
you have several times since declared yourself the friend of that	220.72739182907173
person, he thinks it his duty to respond to that friendship by sending	230.57221932934834
you important information. Twice you have nearly been the victim of a	246.34513984230867
near relative, whom you believe to be your heir because you are	208.42046719381412
ignorant that before she contracted a marriage in England she was	300.3728897945454
already married in France. But the third time, which is the present,	291.8788998676192
you may succumb. Your relative left La Rochelle for England during the	265.3603659253538
night. Watch her arrival, for she has great and terrible projects. If	245.48059655588477
you require to know positively what she is capable of, read her past	188.61218870365144
history on her left shoulder.”	289.9271868329946
“Well, now that will do wonderfully well,” said Athos. “My dear Aramis,	344.5975789675699
you have the pen of a secretary of state. Lord de Winter will now be	225.8551455205016
upon his guard if the letter should reach him; and even if it should	291.67596559697245
fall into the hands of the cardinal, we shall not be compromised. But	291.0372165286674
as the lackey who goes may make us believe he has been to London and	211.8786942264212
may stop at Châtellerault, let us give him only half the sum promised	308.28349576831016
him, with the letter, with an agreement that he shall have the other	212.20630268022074
half in exchange for the reply. Have you the diamond?” continued Athos.	311.36223558555866
“I have what is still better. I have the price;” and D’Artagnan threw	183.09404284697234
the bag upon the table. At the sound of the gold Aramis raised his eyes	351.51437091365125
and Porthos started. As to Athos, he remained unmoved.	189.63780207816274
“How much in that little bag?”	184.96757196229754
“Seven thousand livres, in louis of twelve francs.”	207.12843231332224
“Seven thousand livres!” cried Porthos. “That poor little diamond was	313.37549592433055
worth seven thousand livres?”	255.780668203615
“It appears so,” said Athos, “since here they are. I don’t suppose that	170.99051728047593
our friend D’Artagnan has added any of his own to the amount.”	195.34160806701794
“But, gentlemen, in all this,” said D’Artagnan, “we do not think of the	329.7507823419026
queen. Let us take some heed of the welfare of her dear Buckingham.	317.58189057658745
That is the least we owe her.”	305.16299636256554
“That’s true,” said Athos; “but that concerns Aramis.”	220.42670385465794
“Well,” replied the latter, blushing, “what must I say?”	231.61331078864274
“Oh, that’s simple enough!” replied Athos. “Write a second letter for	254.88339284538716
that clever personage who lives at Tours.”	351.75464404588035
Aramis resumed his pen, reflected a little, and wrote the following	222.22160105934847
lines, which he immediately submitted to the approbation of his	288.8739001402381
friends.	191.09028141536524
“_My dear cousin_.”	309.929201995473
“Ah, ah!” said Athos. “This clever person is your relative, then?”	287.9239108634118
“Cousin-german.”	193.430979033951
“Go on, to your cousin, then!”	249.60512579674673
Aramis continued:	293.79664219439036
“MY DEAR COUSIN, His Eminence, the cardinal, whom God preserve for the	291.1884542365132
happiness of France and the confusion of the enemies of the kingdom, is	364.6415534755225
on the point of putting an end to the hectic rebellion of La Rochelle.	262.6289895650389
It is probable that the succor of the English fleet will never even	273.180304908588
arrive in sight of the place. I will even venture to say that I am	299.85125883441526
certain M. de Buckingham will be prevented from setting out by some	244.3896880669667
great event. His Eminence is the most illustrious politician of times	189.02533352059388
past, of times present, and probably of times to come. He would	364.11418586440374
extinguish the sun if the sun incommoded him. Give these happy tidings	193.35591102680695
to your sister, my dear cousin. I have dreamed that the unlucky	203.3031053214046
Englishman was dead. I cannot recollect whether it was by steel or by	304.00766526630605
poison; only of this I am sure, I have dreamed he was dead, and you	292.5389641677972
know my dreams never deceive me. Be assured, then, of seeing me soon	271.18001160959267
return.”	198.90150332848987
“Capital!” cried Athos; “you are the king of poets, my dear Aramis. You	223.83880353498833
speak like the Apocalypse, and you are as true as the Gospel. There is	264.1901053274052
nothing now to do but to put the address to this letter.”	251.92045515993686
“That is easily done,” said Aramis.	185.6124675186549
He folded the letter fancifully, and took up his pen and wrote:	312.63263786843197
“_To Mlle. Michon, seamstress, Tours_.”	215.0681401395899
The three friends looked at one another and laughed; they were caught.	305.67126253815997
“Now,” said Aramis, “you will please to understand, gentlemen, that	324.0663974988174
Bazin alone can carry this letter to Tours. My cousin knows nobody but	362.2424751294957
Bazin, and places confidence in nobody but him; any other person would	240.1840795590674
fail. Besides, Bazin is ambitious and learned; Bazin has read history,	332.61421287742456
gentlemen, he knows that Sixtus the Fifth became Pope after having kept	316.21433990552407
pigs. Well, as he means to enter the Church at the same time as myself,	349.1474468958774
he does not despair of becoming Pope in his turn, or at least a	227.1588495458427
cardinal. You can understand that a man who has such views will never	245.74014260054977
allow himself to be taken, or if taken, will undergo martyrdom rather	323.34880703415615
than speak.”	356.9018667940722
“Very well,” said D’Artagnan, “I consent to Bazin with all my heart,	170.9855242564303
but grant me Planchet. Milady had him one day turned out of doors, with	253.72011604771672
sundry blows of a good stick to accelerate his motions. Now, Planchet	229.6992243201293
has an excellent memory; and I will be bound that sooner than	292.1412875003604
relinquish any possible means of vengeance, he will allow himself to be	208.46867170724764
beaten to death. If your arrangements at Tours are your arrangements,	173.6097617067767
Aramis, those of London are mine. I request, then, that Planchet may be	194.4801685887276
chosen, more particularly as he has already been to London with me, and	209.1174879530189
knows how to speak correctly: _London, sir, if you please, and my	312.36806683190514
master, Lord D’Artagnan_. With that you may be satisfied he can make	363.2965029885157
his way, both going and returning.”	198.5849380753696
“In that case,” said Athos, “Planchet must receive seven hundred livres	345.1526765156136
for going, and seven hundred livres for coming back; and Bazin, three	335.7825469636607
hundred livres for going, and three hundred livres for returning—that	183.5778878073064
will reduce the sum to five thousand livres. We will each take a	215.3875812746855
thousand livres to be employed as seems good, and we will leave a fund	229.3107172638447
of a thousand livres under the guardianship of Monsieur Abbé here, for	230.35904290689325
extraordinary occasions or common wants. Will that do?”	225.49012695452586
“My dear Athos,” said Aramis, “you speak like Nestor, who was, as	337.7917185470126
everyone knows, the wisest among the Greeks.”	170.16143342947692
“Well, then,” said Athos, “it is agreed. Planchet and Bazin shall go.	222.06498326120493
Everything considered, I am not sorry to retain Grimaud; he is	314.0967215596071
accustomed to my ways, and I am particular. Yesterday’s affair must	281.90888145951584
have shaken him a little; his voyage would upset him quite.”	344.81576563411613
Planchet was sent for, and instructions were given him. The matter had	228.90521537793865
been named to him by D’Artagnan, who in the first place pointed out the	198.14912058254066
money to him, then the glory, and then the danger.	235.350174027104
“I will carry the letter in the lining of my coat,” said Planchet; “and	360.9799653005449
if I am taken I will swallow it.”	219.52981531689937
“Well, but then you will not be able to fulfill your commission,” said	285.2722134783502
D’Artagnan.	237.48747719330345
“You will give me a copy this evening, which I shall know by heart	180.86727654623127
tomorrow.”	248.75342306036657
D’Artagnan looked at his friends, as if to say, “Well, what did I tell	364.0239856785646
you?”	189.0809597161847
“Now,” continued he, addressing Planchet, “you have eight days to get	313.4069104486879
an interview with Lord de Winter; you have eight days to return—in all	351.5716685909403
sixteen days. If, on the sixteenth day after your departure, at eight	243.36216361737996
o’clock in the evening you are not here, no money—even if it be but	285.7794372485495
five minutes past eight.”	195.0702981854811
“Then, monsieur,” said Planchet, “you must buy me a watch.”	208.28822268388805
“Take this,” said Athos, with his usual careless generosity, giving him	337.4644604478457
his own, “and be a good lad. Remember, if you talk, if you babble, if	186.25987554469256
you get drunk, you risk your master’s head, who has so much confidence	342.46971714026984
in your fidelity, and who answers for you. But remember, also, that if	362.2976906142095
by your fault any evil happens to D’Artagnan, I will find you, wherever	301.60349333417446
you may be, for the purpose of ripping up your belly.”	330.67811843995867
“Oh, monsieur!” said Planchet, humiliated by the suspicion, and	266.14241364897924
moreover, terrified at the calm air of the Musketeer.	216.74833899059138
“And I,” said Porthos, rolling his large eyes, “remember, I will skin	354.3626309645939
you alive.”	245.4141757012495
“Ah, monsieur!”	310.41684001916104
“And I,” said Aramis, with his soft, melodius voice, “remember that I	329.11223370525204
will roast you at a slow fire, like a savage.”	315.01766259877405
“Ah, monsieur!”	230.95252921753286
Planchet began to weep. We will not venture to say whether it was from	288.8504507777823
terror created by the threats or from tenderness at seeing four friends	202.03879089598638
so closely united.	218.43544311959087
D’Artagnan took his hand. “See, Planchet,” said he, “these gentlemen	279.95562605083217
only say this out of affection for me, but at bottom they all like	351.5126434226448
you.”	237.62564324396354
“Ah, monsieur,” said Planchet, “I will succeed or I will consent to be	316.57321061977865
cut in quarters; and if they do cut me in quarters, be assured that not	294.62824536867333
a morsel of me will speak.”	258.5972487745236
It was decided that Planchet should set out the next day, at eight	175.9737311457599
o’clock in the morning, in order, as he had said, that he might during	190.52822217188864
the night learn the letter by heart. He gained just twelve hours by	190.7336435492698
this engagement; he was to be back on the sixteenth day, by eight	287.0108091728888
o’clock in the evening.	313.7412835893373
In the morning, as he was mounting his horse, D’Artagnan, who felt at	205.32524477754896
the bottom of his heart a partiality for the duke, took Planchet aside.	329.58574104968267
“Listen,” said he to him. “When you have given the letter to Lord de	194.363165191624
Winter and he has read it, you will further say to him: _Watch over his	329.0759088958639
Grace Lord Buckingham, for they wish to assassinate him_. But this,	264.48412854097427
Planchet, is so serious and important that I have not informed my	252.63673819420904
friends that I would entrust this secret to you; and for a captain’s	254.9125254172693
commission I would not write it.”	330.50591013208157
“Be satisfied, monsieur,” said Planchet, “you shall see if confidence	313.1028577899548
can be placed in me.”	198.09999843707004
Mounted on an excellent horse, which he was to leave at the end of	296.43570189029026
twenty leagues in order to take the post, Planchet set off at a gallop,	306.0792045846283
his spirits a little depressed by the triple promise made him by the	202.68890894285312
Musketeers, but otherwise as light-hearted as possible.	307.2094992891925
Bazin set out the next day for Tours, and was allowed eight days for	290.3962212660667
performing his commission.	343.25374856224926
The four friends, during the period of these two absences, had, as may	176.32569481384473
well be supposed, the eye on the watch, the nose to the wind, and the	218.4122883539181
ear on the hark. Their days were passed in endeavoring to catch all	360.0348034345652
that was said, in observing the proceeding of the cardinal, and in	203.42963025193347
looking out for all the couriers who arrived. More than once an	266.9598296283681
involuntary trembling seized them when called upon for some unexpected	243.6969742117846
service. They had, besides, to look constantly to their own proper	267.6608899308334
safety; Milady was a phantom which, when it had once appeared to	259.0479598994634
people, did not allow them to sleep very quietly.	299.07286893027594
On the morning of the eighth day, Bazin, fresh as ever, and smiling,	270.08459132478436
according to custom, entered the cabaret of the Parpaillot as the four	299.4852683185245
friends were sitting down to breakfast, saying, as had been agreed	212.08118925625809
upon: “Monsieur Aramis, the answer from your cousin.”	334.7625012923145
The four friends exchanged a joyful glance; half of the work was done.	266.35810187151725
It is true, however, that it was the shorter and easier part.	171.68985476617127
Aramis, blushing in spite of himself, took the letter, which was in a	299.0390929238331
large, coarse hand and not particular for its orthography.	175.0236431677465
“Good God!” cried he, laughing, “I quite despair of my poor Michon; she	266.3875832428846
will never write like Monsieur de Voiture.”	182.22084001774678
“What does you mean by boor Michon?” said the Swiss, who was chatting	279.1224591905683
with the four friends when the letter came.	275.7822655118151
“Oh, _pardieu_, less than nothing,” said Aramis; “a charming little	288.82221754361035
seamstress, whom I love dearly and from whose hand I requested a few	256.19998396151055
lines as a sort of keepsake.”	204.13990716719272
“The duvil!” said the Swiss, “if she is as great a lady as her writing	222.92640769785498
is large, you are a lucky fellow, gomrade!”	336.83387410184764
Aramis read the letter, and passed it to Athos.	273.95444690489074
“See what she writes to me, Athos,” said he.	285.5358968850242
Athos cast a glance over the epistle, and to disperse all the	311.5857612660634
suspicions that might have been created, read aloud:	261.18653332087547
“MY COUSIN, My sister and I are skillful in interpreting dreams, and	324.67917535904155
even entertain great fear of them; but of yours it may be said, I hope,	208.02985411509854
every dream is an illusion. Adieu! Take care of yourself, and act so	303.81861770186026
that we may from time to time hear you spoken of.	310.889997156802
“MARIE MICHON”	170.9561288583007
“And what dream does she mean?” asked the dragoon, who had approached	207.04824164796887
during the reading.	290.82729370489307
“Yez; what’s the dream?” said the Swiss.	240.95264159873696
“Well, _pardieu!_” said Aramis, “it was only this: I had a dream, and I	203.1608601864076
related it to her.”	315.308980649286
“Yez, yez,” said the Swiss; “it’s simple enough to dell a dream, but I	256.7639419726565
neffer dream.”	227.1896683588027
“You are very fortunate,” said Athos, rising; “I wish I could say as	344.4508545683866
much!”	184.02882630541177
“Neffer,” replied the Swiss, enchanted that a man like Athos could envy	329.1436664661925
him anything. “Neffer, neffer!”	358.5875524425718
D’Artagnan, seeing Athos rise, did likewise, took his arm, and went	291.9458732836198
out.	192.23624097713022
Porthos and Aramis remained behind to encounter the jokes of the	232.1828893661234
dragoon and the Swiss.	323.68422577671447
As to Bazin, he went and lay down on a truss of straw; and as he had	183.61050740507827
more imagination than the Swiss, he dreamed that Aramis, having become	335.0500824075513
pope, adorned his head with a cardinal’s hat.	248.74303515261425
But, as we have said, Bazin had not, by his fortunate return, removed	249.9204137239164
more than a part of the uneasiness which weighed upon the four friends.	325.72507679723327
The days of expectation are long, and D’Artagnan, in particular, would	287.0078118000579
have wagered that the days were forty-four hours. He forgot the	336.5035718818308
necessary slowness of navigation; he exaggerated to himself the power	190.46239235986855
of Milady. He credited this woman, who appeared to him the equal of a	348.4521336363282
demon, with agents as supernatural as herself; at the least noise, he	338.11074391322825
imagined himself about to be arrested, and that Planchet was being	238.69348980729518
brought back to be confronted with himself and his friends. Still	190.514415659266
further, his confidence in the worthy Picard, at one time so great,	329.74358831631463
diminished day by day. This anxiety became so great that it even	207.42217711873556
extended to Aramis and Porthos. Athos alone remained unmoved, as if no	215.01000154257494
danger hovered over him, and as if he breathed his customary	305.55255304244963
atmosphere.	190.3751757889314
On the sixteenth day, in particular, these signs were so strong in	232.38519934893685
D’Artagnan and his two friends that they could not remain quiet in one	333.6667615806907
place, and wandered about like ghosts on the road by which Planchet was	356.31881507954165
expected.	358.50259239916613
“Really,” said Athos to them, “you are not men but children, to let a	204.4506598112505
woman terrify you so! And what does it amount to, after all? To be	270.57712083194406
imprisoned. Well, but we should be taken out of prison; Madame	332.28440446185334
Bonacieux was released. To be decapitated? Why, every day in the	273.73983532507543
trenches we go cheerfully to expose ourselves to worse than that—for a	349.68186819753134
bullet may break a leg, and I am convinced a surgeon would give us more	245.54573349739826
pain in cutting off a thigh than an executioner in cutting off a head.	210.57832085960766
Wait quietly, then; in two hours, in four, in six hours at latest,	204.74548423094694
Planchet will be here. He promised to be here, and I have very great	308.13583609631246
faith in Planchet, who appears to me to be a very good lad.”	279.1759195146607
“But if he does not come?” said D’Artagnan.	334.67376273919257
“Well, if he does not come, it will be because he has been delayed,	345.3081165277147
that’s all. He may have fallen from his horse, he may have cut a caper	291.76178269137245
from the deck; he may have traveled so fast against the wind as to have	303.7477655741851
brought on a violent catarrh. Eh, gentlemen, let us reckon upon	319.6930830577886
accidents! Life is a chaplet of little miseries which the philosopher	328.8518534079393
counts with a smile. Be philosophers, as I am, gentlemen; sit down at	248.40157288548426
the table and let us drink. Nothing makes the future look so bright as	322.76102918446077
surveying it through a glass of chambertin.”	260.95346500506736
“That’s all very well,” replied D’Artagnan; “but I am tired of fearing	297.5615195345207
when I open a fresh bottle that the wine may come from the cellar of	302.86166539679607
Milady.”	233.99931080497987
“You are very fastidious,” said Athos; “such a beautiful woman!”	258.309887843788
“A woman of mark!” said Porthos, with his loud laugh.	320.6872243013206
Athos started, passed his hand over his brow to remove the drops of	300.1906831172022
perspiration that burst forth, and rose in his turn with a nervous	171.66453335514748
movement he could not repress.	255.83051509213018
The day, however, passed away; and the evening came on slowly, but	184.29801277026877
finally it came. The bars were filled with drinkers. Athos, who had	183.0403436641485
pocketed his share of the diamond, seldom quit the Parpaillot. He had	226.69764772976768
found in M. de Busigny, who, by the by, had given them a magnificent	172.66685221214743
dinner, a partner worthy of his company. They were playing together, as	184.14852372741103
usual, when seven o’clock sounded; the patrol was heard passing to	260.9226813232028
double the posts. At half past seven the retreat was sounded.	253.234838668181
“We are lost,” said D’Artagnan, in the ear of Athos.	314.3467844081515
“You mean to say we _have lost_,” said Athos, quietly, drawing four	324.32921462432944
pistoles from his pocket and throwing them upon the table. “Come,	340.2332173330897
gentlemen,” said he, “they are beating the tattoo. Let us to bed!”	217.42566707720806
And Athos went out of the Parpaillot, followed by D’Artagnan. Aramis	290.6138624622939
came behind, giving his arm to Porthos. Aramis mumbled verses to	263.8989075370693
himself, and Porthos from time to time pulled a hair or two from his	240.00904498677653
mustache, in sign of despair.	307.2850975428839
But all at once a shadow appeared in the darkness the outline of which	230.26543695795831
was familiar to D’Artagnan, and a well-known voice said, “Monsieur, I	338.24221715136446
have brought your cloak; it is chilly this evening.”	344.35509687696253
“Planchet!” cried D’Artagnan, beside himself with joy.	263.1977261916138
“Planchet!” repeated Aramis and Porthos.	351.63232422639896
“Well, yes, Planchet, to be sure,” said Athos, “what is there so	240.53178896109497
astonishing in that? He promised to be back by eight o’clock, and eight	285.1360632740167
is striking. Bravo, Planchet, you are a lad of your word, and if ever	288.16716402503874
you leave your master, I will promise you a place in my service.”	246.7581421730494
“Oh, no, never,” said Planchet, “I will never leave Monsieur	203.36518360162125
d’Artagnan.”	292.1241306612133
At the same time D’Artagnan felt that Planchet slipped a note into his	243.76184935094096
hand.	229.5697396286019
D’Artagnan felt a strong inclination to embrace Planchet as he had	221.74867396859315
embraced him on his departure; but he feared lest this mark of	357.15620344843273
affection, bestowed upon his lackey in the open street, might appear	248.45290227265463
extraordinary to passers-by, and he restrained himself.	294.540337647579
“I have the note,” said he to Athos and to his friends.	172.70011220294543
“That’s well,” said Athos, “let us go home and read it.”	330.5696553291013
The note burned the hand of D’Artagnan. He wished to hasten their	343.73054067159717
steps; but Athos took his arm and passed it under his own, and the	226.80417312955288
young man was forced to regulate his pace by that of his friend.	318.17124256412967
At length they reached the tent, lit a lamp, and while Planchet stood	174.76506723871046
at the entrance that the four friends might not be surprised,	241.29566311548209
D’Artagnan, with a trembling hand, broke the seal and opened the so	318.8216264713545
anxiously expected letter.	204.77718349211614
It contained half a line, in a hand perfectly British, and with a	327.77067037167654
conciseness as perfectly Spartan:	214.78064662835448
_Thank you; be easy_.	340.67248844424574
D’Artagnan translated this for the others.	284.9921689015197
Athos took the letter from the hands of D’Artagnan, approached the	310.0875509350343
lamp, set fire to the paper, and did not let go till it was reduced to	248.77892136670602
a cinder.	297.86589676620645
Then, calling Planchet, he said, “Now, my lad, you may claim your seven	225.77301080783917
hundred livres, but you did not run much risk with such a note as	290.6794833236671
that.”	212.45151785903147
“I am not to blame for having tried every means to compress it,” said	311.649115840635
Planchet.	193.82723213020492
“Well!” cried D’Artagnan, “tell us all about it.”	176.69818922507812
“_Dame_, that’s a long job, monsieur.”	365.5282041494095
“You are right, Planchet,” said Athos; “besides, the tattoo has been	252.55517500181702
sounded, and we should be observed if we kept a light burning much	348.9769577841694
longer than the others.”	262.360969099899
“So be it,” said D’Artagnan. “Go to bed, Planchet, and sleep soundly.”	282.6429645276101
“My faith, monsieur! that will be the first time I have done so for	341.5576484423823
sixteen days.”	177.51341188520433
“And me, too!” said D’Artagnan.	327.1103511643528
“And me, too!” said Porthos.	194.97404094107702
“And me, too!” said Aramis.	342.1042022425757
“Well, if you will have the truth, and me, too!” said Athos.	231.99758245058172
Chapter XLIX.	263.9584064341794
FATALITY	359.9733959505434
Meantime Milady, drunk with passion, roaring on the deck like a lioness	297.95572927745104
that has been embarked, had been tempted to throw herself into the sea	328.1365170915111
that she might regain the coast, for she could not get rid of the	321.88511046707913
thought that she had been insulted by D’Artagnan, threatened by Athos,	351.6803696103748
and that she had quit France without being revenged on them. This idea	309.4287055833594
soon became so insupportable to her that at the risk of whatever	192.0392482725643
terrible consequences might result to herself from it, she implored the	173.47437292266426
captain to put her on shore; but the captain, eager to escape from his	316.0645366974221
false position—placed between French and English cruisers, like the bat	211.4934055513541
between the mice and the birds—was in great haste to regain England,	270.38662540157196
and positively refused to obey what he took for a woman’s caprice,	244.9426582677674
promising his passenger, who had been particularly recommended to him	280.11318008398325
by the cardinal, to land her, if the sea and the French permitted him,	276.19529422016694
at one of the ports of Brittany, either at Lorient or Brest. But the	206.9215928639755
wind was contrary, the sea bad; they tacked and kept offshore. Nine	317.7175389254267
days after leaving the Charente, pale with fatigue and vexation, Milady	362.9804424258758
saw only the blue coasts of Finisterre appear.	342.2690969834463
She calculated that to cross this corner of France and return to the	243.5398207265481
cardinal it would take her at least three days. Add another day for	257.94667428928267
landing, and that would make four. Add these four to the nine others,	191.90373314672297
that would be thirteen days lost—thirteen days, during which so many	182.94984528715187
important events might pass in London. She reflected likewise that the	362.4467447736133
cardinal would be furious at her return, and consequently would be more	234.807473009893
disposed to listen to the complaints brought against her than to the	338.3201244913814
accusations she brought against others.	324.98473393426434
She allowed the vessel to pass Lorient and Brest without repeating her	334.4081864316322
request to the captain, who, on his part, took care not to remind her	201.52614381027234
of it. Milady therefore continued her voyage, and on the very day that	353.84953070694587
Planchet embarked at Portsmouth for France, the messenger of his	227.99150757352893
Eminence entered the port in triumph.	234.81540323830933
All the city was agitated by an extraordinary movement. Four large	235.17598206690386
vessels, recently built, had just been launched. At the end of the	176.7674457561368
jetty, his clothes richly laced with gold, glittering, as was customary	224.76520732959193
with him, with diamonds and precious stones, his hat ornamented with a	212.1246343531053
white feather which drooped upon his shoulder, Buckingham was seen	259.03188216958813
surrounded by a staff almost as brilliant as himself.	329.5256228315952
It was one of those rare and beautiful days in winter when England	248.4084326835334
remembers that there is a sun. The star of day, pale but nevertheless	345.6459658741953
still splendid, was setting in the horizon, glorifying at once the	275.38127490210627
heavens and the sea with bands of fire, and casting upon the towers and	245.95574691040792
the old houses of the city a last ray of gold which made the windows	271.2348026397344
sparkle like the reflection of a conflagration. Breathing that sea	168.71613088983455
breeze, so much more invigorating and balsamic as the land is	213.33681607315108
approached, contemplating all the power of those preparations she was	192.31989776221437
commissioned to destroy, all the power of that army which she was to	318.64133383867147
combat alone—she, a woman with a few bags of gold—Milady compared	365.6094206164563
herself mentally to Judith, the terrible Jewess, when she penetrated	184.6350900745247
the camp of the Assyrians and beheld the enormous mass of chariots,	365.6216132418513
horses, men, and arms, which a gesture of her hand was to dissipate	271.1145130954738
like a cloud of smoke.	338.252238939221
They entered the roadstead; but as they drew near in order to cast	174.03475090570777
anchor, a little cutter, looking like a coastguard formidably armed,	217.7164909417432
approached the merchant vessel and dropped into the sea a boat which	333.6926385048352
directed its course to the ladder. This boat contained an officer, a	183.83336470343747
mate, and eight rowers. The officer alone went on board, where he was	265.05669243663965
received with all the deference inspired by the uniform.	248.14034898197622
The officer conversed a few instants with the captain, gave him several	311.71450651116265
papers, of which he was the bearer, to read, and upon the order of the	221.45470395551155
merchant captain the whole crew of the vessel, both passengers and	313.8741795293691
sailors, were called upon deck.	331.67968203699616
When this species of summons was made the officer inquired aloud the	351.89120070846707
point of the brig’s departure, its route, its landings; and to all	327.4087462876124
these questions the captain replied without difficulty and without	215.65380790214195
hesitation. Then the officer began to pass in review all the people,	190.45163636277397
one after the other, and stopping when he came to Milady, surveyed her	209.19123677255237
very closely, but without addressing a single word to her.	278.67695998868146
He then returned to the captain, said a few words to him, and as if	181.81935443880153
from that moment the vessel was under his command, he ordered a	351.3024804280436
maneuver which the crew executed immediately. Then the vessel resumed	344.3058091023148
its course, still escorted by the little cutter, which sailed side by	278.07876532231614
side with it, menacing it with the mouths of its six cannon. The boat	267.41181462568744
followed in the wake of the ship, a speck near the enormous mass.	314.0652402538901
During the examination of Milady by the officer, as may well be	252.4384268436068
imagined, Milady on her part was not less scrutinizing in her glances.	356.324531215502
But however great was the power of this woman with eyes of flame in	175.89329919519136
reading the hearts of those whose secrets she wished to divine, she met	268.2981523214238
this time with a countenance of such impassivity that no discovery	263.78083785219553
followed her investigation. The officer who had stopped in front of her	234.4157457272757
and studied her with so much care might have been twenty-five or	181.28525679367485
twenty-six years of age. He was of pale complexion, with clear blue	360.3635508891973
eyes, rather deeply set; his mouth, fine and well cut, remained	190.13918847294016
motionless in its correct lines; his chin, strongly marked, denoted	245.91682274550442
that strength of will which in the ordinary Britannic type denotes	250.26473547459733
mostly nothing but obstinacy; a brow a little receding, as is proper	276.0897590799207
for poets, enthusiasts, and soldiers, was scarcely shaded by short thin	247.2703664776389
hair which, like the beard which covered the lower part of his face,	254.5297723219706
was of a beautiful deep chestnut color.	197.33811596191524
When they entered the port, it was already night. The fog increased the	338.06363598873935
darkness, and formed round the sternlights and lanterns of the jetty a	345.07619087416236
circle like that which surrounds the moon when the weather threatens to	216.7980169421579
become rainy. The air they breathed was heavy, damp, and cold.	327.2992712400673
Milady, that woman so courageous and firm, shivered in spite of	166.91524152250778
herself.	266.00641831346627
The officer desired to have Milady’s packages pointed out to him, and	243.4935118438242
ordered them to be placed in the boat. When this operation was	186.14276482730895
complete, he invited her to descend by offering her his hand.	209.95487321745543
Milady looked at this man, and hesitated. “Who are you, sir,” asked	334.9157122590989
she, “who has the kindness to trouble yourself so particularly on my	187.67453816979122
account?”	234.24787686110267
“You may perceive, madame, by my uniform, that I am an officer in the	194.5870323777412
English navy,” replied the young man.	267.7349403589688
“But is it the custom for the officers in the English navy to place	352.968805471606
themselves at the service of their female compatriots when they land in	168.62298928120865
a port of Great Britain, and carry their gallantry so far as to conduct	267.3554024896272
them ashore?”	245.34209765445135
“Yes, madame, it is the custom, not from gallantry but prudence, that	318.25432930989086
in time of war foreigners should be conducted to particular hôtels, in	308.3580185734386
order that they may remain under the eye of the government until full	222.31423346483444
information can be obtained about them.”	345.1186868610431
These words were pronounced with the most exact politeness and the most	296.64672318025396
perfect calmness. Nevertheless, they had not the power of convincing	357.76594049921164
Milady.	300.40937097502484
“But I am not a foreigner, sir,” said she, with an accent as pure as	194.26111887799442
ever was heard between Portsmouth and Manchester; “my name is Lady	174.3734394767501
Clarik, and this measure—”	168.91367675162797
“This measure is general, madame; and you will seek in vain to evade	279.6986030284588
it.”	274.0669508837925
“I will follow you, then, sir.”	221.3234126075868
Accepting the hand of the officer, she began the descent of the ladder,	179.15620932469392
at the foot of which the boat waited. The officer followed her. A large	356.7564333516966
cloak was spread at the stern; the officer requested her to sit down	303.2267077110761
upon this cloak, and placed himself beside her.	275.80476488646997
“Row!” said he to the sailors.	240.6048853614267
The eight oars fell at once into the sea, making but a single sound,	239.77297978499686
giving but a single stroke, and the boat seemed to fly over the surface	342.81139065096363
of the water.	280.7704829897465
In five minutes they gained the land.	203.12967261324505
The officer leaped to the pier, and offered his hand to Milady. A	215.17657108157545
carriage was in waiting.	337.92153953405835
“Is this carriage for us?” asked Milady.	274.8931060041908
“Yes, madame,” replied the officer.	203.71977113045142
“The hôtel, then, is far away?”	294.2419011727544
“At the other end of the town.”	288.62776334804425
“Very well,” said Milady; and she resolutely entered the carriage.	295.6869040652055
The officer saw that the baggage was fastened carefully behind the	210.71089350601824
carriage; and this operation ended, he took his place beside Milady,	222.1117648177243
and shut the door.	242.99844604396932
Immediately, without any order being given or his place of destination	230.65934838636485
indicated, the coachman set off at a rapid pace, and plunged into the	332.04699973458764
streets of the city.	182.19111211937
So strange a reception naturally gave Milady ample matter for	244.00970122113876
reflection; so seeing that the young officer did not seem at all	279.15376987548444
disposed for conversation, she reclined in her corner of the carriage,	251.82563102956846
and one after the other passed in review all the surmises which	318.03897023544346
presented themselves to her mind.	356.49975450170075
At the end of a quarter of an hour, however, surprised at the length of	226.58980119581776
the journey, she leaned forward toward the door to see whither she was	235.0689517866827
being conducted. Houses were no longer to be seen; trees appeared in	178.74341608452767
the darkness like great black phantoms chasing one another. Milady	179.1674133426245
shuddered.	243.42231948624823
“But we are no longer in the city, sir,” said she.	286.5939079549157
The young officer preserved silence.	273.0419083234555
“I beg you to understand, sir, I will go no farther unless you tell me	365.0643519987658
whither you are taking me.”	361.3147229293057
This threat brought no reply.	203.45092025000977
“Oh, this is too much,” cried Milady. “Help! help!”	342.7053705558744
No voice replied to hers; the carriage continued to roll on with	296.45051824915936
rapidity; the officer seemed a statue.	311.2270075156222
Milady looked at the officer with one of those terrible expressions	344.0973836092883
peculiar to her countenance, and which so rarely failed of their	185.22812960864223
effect; anger made her eyes flash in the darkness.	172.5904024530079
The young man remained immovable.	191.89476468389492
Milady tried to open the door in order to throw herself out.	237.0478468766545
“Take care, madame,” said the young man, coolly, “you will kill	340.3132424454251
yourself in jumping.”	184.08408964854397
Milady reseated herself, foaming. The officer leaned forward, looked at	363.0381716749462
her in his turn, and appeared surprised to see that face, just before	251.0189326515383
so beautiful, distorted with passion and almost hideous. The artful	305.3041432050634
creature at once comprehended that she was injuring herself by allowing	205.6333090059125
him thus to read her soul; she collected her features, and in a	259.38056696064734
complaining voice said: “In the name of heaven, sir, tell me if it is	170.54238599729874
to you, if it is to your government, if it is to an enemy I am to	252.60166206448702
attribute the violence that is done me?”	255.0530126114108
“No violence will be offered to you, madame, and what happens to you is	166.2075144640991
the result of a very simple measure which we are obliged to adopt with	191.94731673037387
all who land in England.”	271.5210787269444
“Then you don’t know me, sir?”	345.0090188933107
“It is the first time I have had the honor of seeing you.”	284.0086645638961
“And on your honor, you have no cause of hatred against me?”	317.22637117141244
“None, I swear to you.”	296.2003456487947
There was so much serenity, coolness, mildness even, in the voice of	239.89826485438613
the young man, that Milady felt reassured.	178.41080080662567
At length after a journey of nearly an hour, the carriage stopped	204.70567000949805
before an iron gate, which closed an avenue leading to a castle severe	280.06364284359194
in form, massive, and isolated. Then, as the wheels rolled over a fine	313.99534177111275
gravel, Milady could hear a vast roaring, which she at once recognized	239.1086733006319
as the noise of the sea dashing against some steep cliff.	343.6336871129711
The carriage passed under two arched gateways, and at length stopped in	272.0326946134283
a court large, dark, and square. Almost immediately the door of the	288.09548423174874
carriage was opened, the young man sprang lightly out and presented his	212.37223697689495
hand to Milady, who leaned upon it, and in her turn alighted with	254.87788268705458
tolerable calmness.	176.27853571746175
“Still, then, I am a prisoner,” said Milady, looking around her, and	336.51658850892306
bringing back her eyes with a most gracious smile to the young officer;	209.92929438754717
“but I feel assured it will not be for long,” added she. “My own	223.0531764706706
conscience and your politeness, sir, are the guarantees of that.”	329.16804468779856
However flattering this compliment, the officer made no reply; but	261.92653703272816
drawing from his belt a little silver whistle, such as boatswains use	308.3458067762428
in ships of war, he whistled three times, with three different	294.86377356821686
modulations. Immediately several men appeared, who unharnessed the	209.75007042666476
smoking horses, and put the carriage into a coach house.	340.06836286004534
Then the officer, with the same calm politeness, invited his prisoner	193.4999742403849
to enter the house. She, with a still-smiling countenance, took his	174.88466351907002
arm, and passed with him under a low arched door, which by a vaulted	175.11968458306114
passage, lighted only at the farther end, led to a stone staircase	188.1105908645298
around an angle of stone. They then came to a massive door, which after	292.63819406470014
the introduction into the lock of a key which the young man carried	211.02103691395394
with him, turned heavily upon its hinges, and disclosed the chamber	280.2553875306764
destined for Milady.	301.8411967543992
With a single glance the prisoner took in the apartment in its minutest	297.35326374018086
details. It was a chamber whose furniture was at once appropriate for a	364.3457921658544
prisoner or a free man; and yet bars at the windows and outside bolts	220.29231970774325
at the door decided the question in favor of the prison.	196.867109784388
In an instant all the strength of mind of this creature, though drawn	217.6352506138536
from the most vigorous sources, abandoned her; she sank into a large	339.10574786915095
easy chair, with her arms crossed, her head lowered, and expecting	219.74391940491003
every instant to see a judge enter to interrogate her.	312.6392690058772
But no one entered except two or three marines, who brought her trunks	346.74054655104123
and packages, deposited them in a corner, and retired without speaking.	307.83697186685674
The officer superintended all these details with the same calmness	339.82989786089064
Milady had constantly seen in him, never pronouncing a word himself,	265.35210585226883
and making himself obeyed by a gesture of his hand or a sound of his	192.70776633006636
whistle.	279.2813708321828
It might have been said that between this man and his inferiors spoken	169.7795869025446
language did not exist, or had become useless.	228.0633209219539
At length Milady could hold out no longer; she broke the silence. “In	305.94275526122834
the name of heaven, sir,” cried she, “what means all that is passing?	327.87892927004077
Put an end to my doubts; I have courage enough for any danger I can	353.09602791411675
foresee, for every misfortune which I understand. Where am I, and why	267.8191133810163
am I here? If I am free, why these bars and these doors? If I am a	174.09737905773707
prisoner, what crime have I committed?”	358.99698071408585
“You are here in the apartment destined for you, madame. I received	198.28765188134133
orders to go and take charge of you on the sea, and to conduct you to	268.75024570821597
this castle. This order I believe I have accomplished with all the	205.6187846388733
exactness of a soldier, but also with the courtesy of a gentleman.	259.2962473439027
There terminates, at least to the present moment, the duty I had to	317.8781796027775
fulfill toward you; the rest concerns another person.”	362.26869285171017
“And who is that other person?” asked Milady, warmly. “Can you not tell	206.02238625765926
me his name?”	177.0442605693841
At the moment a great jingling of spurs was heard on the stairs. Some	320.1882418973998
voices passed and faded away, and the sound of a single footstep	183.37399781307744
approached the door.	300.93775835923606
“That person is here, madame,” said the officer, leaving the entrance	229.93371073328967
open, and drawing himself up in an attitude of respect.	184.6131089724219
At the same time the door opened; a man appeared on the threshold. He	166.30180298044272
was without a hat, carried a sword, and flourished a handkerchief in	257.52126009208996
his hand.	304.5408162768846
Milady thought she recognized this shadow in the gloom; she supported	314.66254996915484
herself with one hand upon the arm of the chair, and advanced her head	288.3851826108188
as if to meet a certainty.	216.93108555967405
The stranger advanced slowly, and as he advanced, after entering into	281.86455436549073
the circle of light projected by the lamp, Milady involuntarily drew	280.62537621498166
back.	364.6357217964404
Then when she had no longer any doubt, she cried, in a state of stupor,	342.71332579879487
“What, my brother, is it you?”	334.60994224455067
“Yes, fair lady!” replied Lord de Winter, making a bow, half courteous,	309.46744901848683
half ironical; “it is I, myself.”	351.7993830837168
“But this castle, then?”	268.3329346150655
“Is mine.”	277.1622342680126
“This chamber?”	282.3534472177215
“Is yours.”	280.7999757810489
“I am, then, your prisoner?”	211.4572166855584
“Nearly so.”	349.78433776008205
“But this is a frightful abuse of power!”	315.7434343342925
“No high-sounding words! Let us sit down and chat quietly, as brother	252.36989961551546
and sister ought to do.”	179.09996767544365
Then, turning toward the door, and seeing that the young officer was	306.9140254503381
waiting for his last orders, he said. “All is well, I thank you; now	260.0935852018914
leave us alone, Mr. Felton.”	281.30727585603734
Chapter L.	306.66643839853396
CHAT BETWEEN BROTHER AND SISTER	253.68626676865767
During the time which Lord de Winter took to shut the door, close a	299.9554401419372
shutter, and draw a chair near to his sister-in-law’s _fauteuil_,	296.6610951830021
Milady, anxiously thoughtful, plunged her glance into the depths of	186.97057917299296
possibility, and discovered all the plan, of which she could not even	282.18828483772535
obtain a glance as long as she was ignorant into whose hands she had	177.36738922199987
fallen. She knew her brother-in-law to be a worthy gentleman, a bold	330.49068930277423
hunter, an intrepid player, enterprising with women, but by no means	181.4697615307275
remarkable for his skill in intrigues. How had he discovered her	219.05563165234042
arrival, and caused her to be seized? Why did he detain her?	208.36247564851627
Athos had dropped some words which proved that the conversation she had	355.066397619144
with the cardinal had fallen into outside ears; but she could not	311.6492252881485
suppose that he had dug a countermine so promptly and so boldly. She	174.71839197228957
rather feared that her preceding operations in England might have been	176.9853347069106
discovered. Buckingham might have guessed that it was she who had cut	200.80095716410256
off the two studs, and avenge himself for that little treachery; but	188.6910163595102
Buckingham was incapable of going to any excess against a woman,	299.5553195255235
particularly if that woman was supposed to have acted from a feeling of	319.90051233354313
jealousy.	344.13941413340376
This supposition appeared to her most reasonable. It seemed to her that	322.0993167064512
they wanted to revenge the past, and not to anticipate the future. At	337.6199275504099
all events, she congratulated herself upon having fallen into the hands	300.66463683179
of her brother-in-law, with whom she reckoned she could deal very	353.14849953710655
easily, rather than into the hands of an acknowledged and intelligent	347.51230269474263
enemy.	307.33953767338517
“Yes, let us chat, brother,” said she, with a kind of cheerfulness,	233.97549446843433
decided as she was to draw from the conversation, in spite of all the	270.607113181508
dissimulation Lord de Winter could bring, the revelations of which she	176.6522228080111
stood in need to regulate her future conduct.	361.8812091250206
“You have, then, decided to come to England again,” said Lord de	288.68150729081265
Winter, “in spite of the resolutions you so often expressed in Paris	361.7505379193317
never to set your feet on British ground?”	167.2322792264876
Milady replied to this question by another question. “To begin with,	354.12647589391884
tell me,” said she, “how have you watched me so closely as to be aware	205.27463792710734
beforehand not only of my arrival, but even of the day, the hour, and	217.80481535264596
the port at which I should arrive?”	271.58071291153476
Lord de Winter adopted the same tactics as Milady, thinking that as his	189.202222738557
sister-in-law employed them they must be the best.	288.61080872005175
“But tell me, my dear sister,” replied he, “what makes you come to	293.73960274188835
England?”	313.4258196558644
“I come to see you,” replied Milady, without knowing how much she	178.27701101570466
aggravated by this reply the suspicions to which D’Artagnan’s letter	316.4412265361086
had given birth in the mind of her brother-in-law, and only desiring to	230.49831117054308
gain the good will of her auditor by a falsehood.	361.1582844822516
“Ah, to see me?” said de Winter, cunningly.	345.6698599358833
“To be sure, to see you. What is there astonishing in that?”	266.3256542106787
“And you had no other object in coming to England but to see me?”	182.79312259918885
“No.”	300.2180447501749
“So it was for me alone you have taken the trouble to cross the	247.70902869458405
Channel?”	353.76022239534825
“For you alone.”	281.6046140160205
“The deuce! What tenderness, my sister!”	346.15917553189036
“But am I not your nearest relative?” demanded Milady, with a tone of	309.0158068626673
the most touching ingenuousness.	294.30446117301284
“And my only heir, are you not?” said Lord de Winter in his turn,	297.8424264145593
fixing his eyes on those of Milady.	227.52384765852037
Whatever command she had over herself, Milady could not help starting;	188.06910433386892
and as in pronouncing the last words Lord de Winter placed his hand	194.29297751627337
upon the arm of his sister, this start did not escape him.	219.61804960833632
In fact, the blow was direct and severe. The first idea that occurred	297.8041519652047
to Milady’s mind was that she had been betrayed by Kitty, and that she	251.38938147219488
had recounted to the baron the selfish aversion toward himself of which	234.67611467095398
she had imprudently allowed some marks to escape before her servant.	325.8127592756353
She also recollected the furious and imprudent attack she had made upon	183.69586259236766
D’Artagnan when he spared the life of her brother.	181.54091611397604
“I do not understand, my Lord,” said she, in order to gain time and	319.0549465195287
make her adversary speak out. “What do you mean to say? Is there any	284.364605209721
secret meaning concealed beneath your words?”	270.1190779821411
“Oh, my God, no!” said Lord de Winter, with apparent good nature. “You	233.17743882791626
wish to see me, and you come to England. I learn this desire, or rather	263.67375098943756
I suspect that you feel it; and in order to spare you all the	306.4007895542653
annoyances of a nocturnal arrival in a port and all the fatigues of	261.37585959811673
landing, I send one of my officers to meet you, I place a carriage at	197.01985080175064
his orders, and he brings you hither to this castle, of which I am	236.3383804983397
governor, whither I come every day, and where, in order to satisfy our	202.58191890028874
mutual desire of seeing each other, I have prepared you a chamber. What	313.79076472581505
is there more astonishing in all that I have said to you than in what	273.7362896453856
you have told me?”	361.69809576451996
“No; what I think astonishing is that you should expect my coming.”	275.976069833656
“And yet that is the most simple thing in the world, my dear sister.	219.0824547643972
Have you not observed that the captain of your little vessel, on	258.11910250892834
entering the roadstead, sent forward, in order to obtain permission to	172.7214794897025
enter the port, a little boat bearing his logbook and the register of	299.8193546875127
his voyagers? I am commandant of the port. They brought me that book. I	290.69032481789407
recognized your name in it. My heart told me what your mouth has just	187.25451179230419
confirmed—that is to say, with what view you have exposed yourself to	171.99032243036223
the dangers of a sea so perilous, or at least so troublesome at this	205.8370364609666
moment—and I sent my cutter to meet you. You know the rest.”	224.51023290364805
Milady knew that Lord de Winter lied, and she was the more alarmed.	275.2828358390984
“My brother,” continued she, “was not that my Lord Buckingham whom I	235.00172924573363
saw on the jetty this evening as we arrived?”	207.51769621890563
“Himself. Ah, I can understand how the sight of him struck you,”	291.44561915361027
replied Lord de Winter. “You came from a country where he must be very	330.656829996817
much talked of, and I know that his armaments against France greatly	355.1998029990224
engage the attention of your friend the cardinal.”	208.1531272530184
“My friend the cardinal!” cried Milady, seeing that on this point as on	208.4228419423944
the other Lord de Winter seemed well instructed.	308.26649951380966
“Is he not your friend?” replied the baron, negligently. “Ah, pardon! I	269.496700512101
thought so; but we will return to my Lord Duke presently. Let us not	299.66327411713223
depart from the sentimental turn our conversation had taken. You came,	189.61123420102905
you say, to see me?”	285.68458108530535
“Yes.”	217.04397624842318
“Well, I reply that you shall be served to the height of your wishes,	250.07738648269668
and that we shall see each other every day.”	242.61335266430046
“Am I, then, to remain here eternally?” demanded Milady, with a certain	225.9787957432981
terror.	362.69417622299375
“Do you find yourself badly lodged, sister? Demand anything you want,	203.36293214812952
and I will hasten to have you furnished with it.”	345.6520483013089
“But I have neither my women nor my servants.”	238.48293752358896
“You shall have all, madame. Tell me on what footing your household was	254.87731887375674
established by your first husband, and although I am only your	197.43682745612955
brother-in-law, I will arrange one similar.”	221.87724963988524
“My first husband!” cried Milady, looking at Lord de Winter with eyes	238.482847970648
almost starting from their sockets.	348.4168586738467
“Yes, your French husband. I don’t speak of my brother. If you have	176.1124392812721
forgotten, as he is still living, I can write to him and he will send	216.09249013600203
me information on the subject.”	187.54416934156887
A cold sweat burst from the brow of Milady.	353.9393768293353
“You jest!” said she, in a hollow voice.	293.6669780333864
“Do I look so?” asked the baron, rising and going a step backward.	248.6735593353288
“Or rather you insult me,” continued she, pressing with her stiffened	254.7877057873232
hands the two arms of her easy chair, and raising herself upon her	239.39698232200845
wrists.	280.2953914478396
“I insult you!” said Lord de Winter, with contempt. “In truth, madame,	215.88196986470547
do you think that can be possible?”	299.6309402890439
“Indeed, sir,” said Milady, “you must be either drunk or mad. Leave the	249.50252325336265
room, and send me a woman.”	245.58033753688
“Women are very indiscreet, my sister. Cannot I serve you as a waiting	206.52085749640946
maid? By that means all our secrets will remain in the family.”	273.5530932259725
“Insolent!” cried Milady; and as if acted upon by a spring, she bounded	183.07771383591145
toward the baron, who awaited her attack with his arms crossed, but	317.1447133633428
nevertheless with one hand on the hilt of his sword.	337.5909780575398
“Come!” said he. “I know you are accustomed to assassinate people; but	178.1333715723348
I warn you I shall defend myself, even against you.”	224.45289659738916
“You are right,” said Milady. “You have all the appearance of being	333.6053335750223
cowardly enough to lift your hand against a woman.”	297.91873105273714
“Perhaps so; and I have an excuse, for mine would not be the first hand	315.34649305483606
of a man that has been placed upon you, I imagine.”	281.0454384802796
And the baron pointed, with a slow and accusing gesture, to the left	218.67336170608823
shoulder of Milady, which he almost touched with his finger.	301.85179630326036
Milady uttered a deep, inward shriek, and retreated to a corner of the	175.20180956528893
room like a panther which crouches for a spring.	336.45764805608576
“Oh, growl as much as you please,” cried Lord de Winter, “but don’t try	168.21095283602125
to bite, for I warn you that it would be to your disadvantage. There	185.1151742037095
are here no procurators who regulate successions beforehand. There is	260.9666479459289
no knight-errant to come and seek a quarrel with me on account of the	324.5098635973991
fair lady I detain a prisoner; but I have judges quite ready who will	284.96085210178444
quickly dispose of a woman so shameless as to glide, a bigamist, into	212.88232690002175
the bed of Lord de Winter, my brother. And these judges, I warn you,	290.30430975191814
will soon send you to an executioner who will make both your shoulders	209.12891040682268
alike.”	236.6998612384486
The eyes of Milady darted such flashes that although he was a man and	200.97144409983343
armed before an unarmed woman, he felt the chill of fear glide through	201.79381920544202
his whole frame. However, he continued all the same, but with	320.32294490039885
increasing warmth: “Yes, I can very well understand that after having	266.29588543556656
inherited the fortune of my brother it would be very agreeable to you	167.2681487999468
to be my heir likewise; but know beforehand, if you kill me or cause me	337.83042004735665
to be killed, my precautions are taken. Not a penny of what I possess	271.4232849469289
will pass into your hands. Were you not already rich enough—you who	330.050241352444
possess nearly a million? And could you not stop your fatal career, if	279.8576517763712
you did not do evil for the infinite and supreme joy of doing it? Oh,	325.67476692478465
be assured, if the memory of my brother were not sacred to me, you	315.80763684459794
should rot in a state dungeon or satisfy the curiosity of sailors at	176.82179711604374
Tyburn. I will be silent, but you must endure your captivity quietly.	355.3130484888185
In fifteen or twenty days I shall set out for La Rochelle with the	295.35288780977
army; but on the eve of my departure a vessel which I shall see depart	190.08745702831715
will take you hence and convey you to our colonies in the south. And be	267.76625293521045
assured that you shall be accompanied by one who will blow your brains	321.54642545173886
out at the first attempt you make to return to England or the	298.4346382470379
Continent.”	192.98043854710093
Milady listened with an attention that dilated her inflamed eyes.	265.1544788809183
“Yes, at present,” continued Lord de Winter, “you will remain in this	236.41629252889675
castle. The walls are thick, the doors strong, and the bars solid;	363.6919607171071
besides, your window opens immediately over the sea. The men of my	244.73645182897997
crew, who are devoted to me for life and death, mount guard around this	261.7571109811465
apartment, and watch all the passages that lead to the courtyard. Even	204.32376862414392
if you gained the yard, there would still be three iron gates for you	334.56017475338376
to pass. The order is positive. A step, a gesture, a word, on your	217.28755624799277
part, denoting an effort to escape, and you are to be fired upon. If	243.60891546126095
they kill you, English justice will be under an obligation to me for	335.81290949762854
having saved it trouble. Ah! I see your features regain their calmness,	268.65273051099734
your countenance recovers its assurance. You are saying to yourself:	288.9948381117684
‘Fifteen days, twenty days? Bah! I have an inventive mind; before that	219.97366120981962
is expired some idea will occur to me. I have an infernal spirit. I	284.6468352601893
shall meet with a victim. Before fifteen days are gone by I shall be	299.98483195630274
away from here.’ Ah, try it!”	284.00057806926117
Milady, finding her thoughts betrayed, dug her nails into her flesh to	221.38808785011145
subdue every emotion that might give to her face any expression except	357.6660623289544
agony.	198.2128071181731
Lord de Winter continued: “The officer who commands here in my absence	326.2138571983798
you have already seen, and therefore know him. He knows how, as you	208.89802124304492
must have observed, to obey an order—for you did not, I am sure, come	166.36604887182082
from Portsmouth hither without endeavoring to make him speak. What do	177.2892067438093
you say of him? Could a statue of marble have been more impassive and	263.07670473954994
more mute? You have already tried the power of your seductions upon	193.4064476287788
many men, and unfortunately you have always succeeded; but I give you	179.03487392202447
leave to try them upon this one. _Pardieu!_ if you succeed with him, I	346.1220811679509
pronounce you the demon himself.”	344.9602757038672
He went toward the door and opened it hastily.	308.639110430854
“Call Mr. Felton,” said he. “Wait a minute longer, and I will introduce	218.65653611179178
him to you.”	173.56208074949944
There followed between these two personages a strange silence, during	272.73396996829183
which the sound of a slow and regular step was heard approaching.	170.98727074220943
Shortly a human form appeared in the shade of the corridor, and the	260.3219744941033
young lieutenant, with whom we are already acquainted, stopped at the	324.24309653626193
threshold to receive the orders of the baron.	317.42865201818853
“Come in, my dear John,” said Lord de Winter, “come in, and shut the	342.2374513204222
door.”	187.85057412681576
The young officer entered.	256.4825288391918
“Now,” said the baron, “look at this woman. She is young; she is	174.5399085861682
beautiful; she possesses all earthly seductions. Well, she is a	196.318840731968
monster, who, at twenty-five years of age, has been guilty of as many	286.57397429792485
crimes as you could read of in a year in the archives of our tribunals.	211.85033203761893
Her voice prejudices her hearers in her favor; her beauty serves as a	226.90234577849074
bait to her victims; her body even pays what she promises—I must do her	322.5775819555348
that justice. She will try to seduce you, perhaps she will try to kill	214.83563216402456
you. I have extricated you from misery, Felton; I have caused you to be	187.21801163948462
named lieutenant; I once saved your life, you know on what occasion. I	255.75970775833733
am for you not only a protector, but a friend; not only a benefactor,	200.30211762126163
but a father. This woman has come back again into England for the	250.96648750557014
purpose of conspiring against my life. I hold this serpent in my hands.	285.7119982847887
Well, I call you, and say to you: Friend Felton, John, my child, guard	171.09723037474572
me, and more particularly guard yourself, against this woman. Swear, by	196.98475731654017
your hopes of salvation, to keep her safely for the chastisement she	355.38374832952
has merited. John Felton, I trust your word! John Felton, I put faith	315.86024123215003
in your loyalty!”	306.2189542998151
“My Lord,” said the young officer, summoning to his mild countenance	283.9295346267937
all the hatred he could find in his heart, “my Lord, I swear all shall	336.55925497603664
be done as you desire.”	334.9710006220841
Milady received this look like a resigned victim; it was impossible to	221.13699115307338
imagine a more submissive or a more mild expression than that which	335.77272171252343
prevailed on her beautiful countenance. Lord de Winter himself could	185.56727858445777
scarcely recognize the tigress who, a minute before, prepared	272.23738989117635
apparently for a fight.	354.43337638112916
“She is not to leave this chamber, understand, John,” continued the	225.30495577053944
baron. “She is to correspond with nobody; she is to speak to no one but	234.63196251120797
you—if you will do her the honor to address a word to her.”	190.81841459347504
“That is sufficient, my Lord! I have sworn.”	206.33743032342022
“And now, madame, try to make your peace with God, for you are judged	189.2592175309686
by men!”	313.10837614410906
Milady let her head sink, as if crushed by this sentence. Lord de	319.7432507998275
Winter went out, making a sign to Felton, who followed him, shutting	292.2775874677851
the door after him.	225.98088871986283
One instant after, the heavy step of a marine who served as sentinel	267.39775325995026
was heard in the corridor—his ax in his girdle and his musket on his	358.4643184910154
shoulder.	210.2250752929138
Milady remained for some minutes in the same position, for she thought	264.1830185128973
they might perhaps be examining her through the keyhole; she then	223.25039681297267
slowly raised her head, which had resumed its formidable expression of	333.5213365308251
menace and defiance, ran to the door to listen, looked out of her	222.78410146953817
window, and returning to bury herself again in her large armchair, she	276.14000225970625
reflected.	322.268828813666
Chapter LI.	328.4044910934723
OFFICER	355.8287512066911
Meanwhile, the cardinal looked anxiously for news from England; but no	200.38755032148808
news arrived that was not annoying and threatening.	166.0317174153965
Although La Rochelle was invested, however certain success might	355.5997430316894
appear—thanks to the precautions taken, and above all to the dyke,	213.04929746723397
which prevented the entrance of any vessel into the besieged city—the	174.08340065177342
blockade might last a long time yet. This was a great affront to the	240.6307695266445
king’s army, and a great inconvenience to the cardinal, who had no	265.88672585826714
longer, it is true, to embroil Louis XIII. with Anne of Austria—for that	232.03061710174006
affair was over—but he had to adjust matters for M. de Bassompierre,	363.729993909893
who was embroiled with the Duc d’Angoulême.	340.52816841785443
As to Monsieur, who had begun the siege, he left to the cardinal the	210.43674024148868
task of finishing it.	344.79834198610735
The city, notwithstanding the incredible perseverance of its mayor, had	327.954181958362
attempted a sort of mutiny for a surrender; the mayor had hanged the	328.1408882157863
mutineers. This execution quieted the ill-disposed, who resolved to	212.62675584775076
allow themselves to die of hunger—this death always appearing to them	224.8489262627647
more slow and less sure than strangulation.	261.87325717525476
On their side, from time to time, the besiegers took the messengers	354.22868535559974
which the Rochellais sent to Buckingham, or the spies which Buckingham	246.563463194701
sent to the Rochellais. In one case or the other, the trial was soon	221.5368378991767
over. The cardinal pronounced the single word, “Hanged!” The king was	231.31338923696558
invited to come and see the hanging. He came languidly, placing himself	299.7016709112068
in a good situation to see all the details. This amused him sometimes a	298.4373917437263
little, and made him endure the siege with patience; but it did not	216.39423919746966
prevent his getting very tired, or from talking at every moment of	245.61496826626816
returning to Paris—so that if the messengers and the spies had failed,	364.3803299939043
his Eminence, notwithstanding all his inventiveness, would have found	333.04271334005375
himself much embarrassed.	286.785945670125
Nevertheless, time passed on, and the Rochellais did not surrender. The	222.46227977249825
last spy that was taken was the bearer of a letter. This letter told	276.58918823086447
