Buckingham that the city was at an extremity; but instead of adding,	291.25091823092885
“If your succor does not arrive within fifteen days, we will	197.14158300347148
surrender,” it added, quite simply, “If your succor comes not within	237.64464436267025
fifteen days, we shall all be dead with hunger when it comes.”	309.1630820636045
The Rochellais, then, had no hope but in Buckingham. Buckingham was	187.76246365185537
their Messiah. It was evident that if they one day learned positively	356.79528099135825
that they must not count on Buckingham, their courage would fail with	252.089305521017
their hope.	317.3528997130363
The cardinal looked, then, with great impatience for the news from	243.12610250148452
England which would announce to him that Buckingham would not come.	178.40317083482353
The question of carrying the city by assault, though often debated in	216.41460369549657
the council of the king, had been always rejected. In the first place,	251.37777748342353
La Rochelle appeared impregnable. Then the cardinal, whatever he said,	229.66707213215943
very well knew that the horror of bloodshed in this encounter, in which	172.2262022939584
Frenchman would combat against Frenchman, was a retrograde movement of	199.02152615763723
sixty years impressed upon his policy; and the cardinal was at that	173.42223950271503
period what we now call a man of progress. In fact, the sack of La	253.08538691712556
Rochelle, and the assassination of three of four thousand Huguenots who	361.17679602267674
allowed themselves to be killed, would resemble too closely, in 1628,	256.8835565108298
the massacre of St. Bartholomew in 1572; and then, above all this, this	357.2477407239188
extreme measure, which was not at all repugnant to the king, good	231.30164775808274
Catholic as he was, always fell before this argument of the besieging	304.4030847922387
generals—La Rochelle is impregnable except to famine.	184.3210055993747
The cardinal could not drive from his mind the fear he entertained of	364.0095552838244
his terrible emissary—for he comprehended the strange qualities of this	290.7640609826693
woman, sometimes a serpent, sometimes a lion. Had she betrayed him? Was	355.7568271472197
she dead? He knew her well enough in all cases to know that, whether	227.74658772890925
acting for or against him, as a friend or an enemy, she would not	329.9209204470437
remain motionless without great impediments; but whence did these	198.91444671472573
impediments arise? That was what he could not know.	271.9235700161581
And yet he reckoned, and with reason, on Milady. He had divined in the	344.972291191374
past of this woman terrible things which his red mantle alone could	315.6797689728363
cover; and he felt, from one cause or another, that this woman was his	319.3043366862554
own, as she could look to no other but himself for a support superior	323.63384071706923
to the danger which threatened her.	357.7681425774114
He resolved, then, to carry on the war alone, and to look for no	349.3597205383313
success foreign to himself, but as we look for a fortunate chance. He	297.1257185577284
continued to press the raising of the famous dyke which was to starve	228.04828858517246
La Rochelle. Meanwhile, he cast his eyes over that unfortunate city,	246.2119681264744
which contained so much deep misery and so many heroic virtues, and	199.89528854829365
recalling the saying of Louis XI., his political predecessor, as he	317.2859412186998
himself was the predecessor of Robespierre, he repeated this maxim of	241.23975377490024
Tristan’s gossip: “Divide in order to reign.”	248.92641082176578
Henry IV., when besieging Paris, had loaves and provisions thrown over	239.91462244097625
the walls. The cardinal had little notes thrown over in which he	305.56673102270554
represented to the Rochellais how unjust, selfish, and barbarous was	185.90603308695063
the conduct of their leaders. These leaders had corn in abundance, and	362.13074108429225
would not let them partake of it; they adopted as a maxim—for they,	322.08766538926193
too, had maxims—that it was of very little consequence that women,	215.882401258376
children, and old men should die, so long as the men who were to defend	293.71565163977493
the walls remained strong and healthy. Up to that time, whether from	178.98548242469312
devotedness or from want of power to act against it, this maxim,	302.4468696845064
without being generally adopted, nevertheless passed from theory into	289.5798952352603
practice; but the notes did it injury. The notes reminded the men that	331.5838725284127
the children, women, and old men whom they allowed to die were their	245.08348179950121
sons, their wives, and their fathers, and that it would be more just	235.35972530325233
for everyone to be reduced to the common misery, in order that equal	349.4307231541593
conditions should give birth to unanimous resolutions.	205.40722967966227
These notes had all the effect that he who wrote them could expect, in	271.86814249086297
that they induced a great number of the inhabitants to open private	174.2319829892954
negotiations with the royal army.	255.26766639134695
But at the moment when the cardinal saw his means already bearing	256.9148814291356
fruit, and applauded himself for having put it in action, an inhabitant	269.0727573591057
of La Rochelle who had contrived to pass the royal lines—God knows how,	348.8841686041128
such was the watchfulness of Bassompierre, Schomberg, and the Duc	199.40581675082836
d’Angoulême, themselves watched over by the cardinal—an inhabitant of	222.12369699484572
La Rochelle, we say, entered the city, coming from Portsmouth, and	302.4971408994382
saying that he had seen a magnificent fleet ready to sail within eight	169.4343111364592
days. Still further, Buckingham announced to the mayor that at length	315.0218323598397
the great league was about to declare itself against France, and that	291.1458162631897
the kingdom would be at once invaded by the English, Imperial, and	329.17849044788494
Spanish armies. This letter was read publicly in all parts of the city.	284.9879082605287
Copies were put up at the corners of the streets; and even they who had	236.4992989554558
begun to open negotiations interrupted them, being resolved to await	252.78006709264687
the succor so pompously announced.	297.7972293580229
This unexpected circumstance brought back Richelieu’s former anxiety,	169.00229092532967
and forced him in spite of himself once more to turn his eyes to the	212.17183413779003
other side of the sea.	293.5975155970744
During this time, exempt from the anxiety of its only and true chief,	318.2878145489274
the royal army led a joyous life, neither provisions nor money being	193.9567240697119
wanting in the camp. All the corps rivaled one another in audacity and	218.87887166588902
gaiety. To take spies and hang them, to make hazardous expeditions upon	225.26350691769488
the dyke or the sea, to imagine wild plans, and to execute them	297.1659001360701
coolly—such were the pastimes which made the army find these days short	197.11504674914966
which were not only so long to the Rochellais, a prey to famine and	253.60237668455989
anxiety, but even to the cardinal, who blockaded them so closely.	169.23491425488535
Sometimes when the cardinal, always on horseback, like the lowest	193.29992581991297
_gendarme_ of the army, cast a pensive glance over those works, so	188.36325726940998
slowly keeping pace with his wishes, which the engineers, brought from	332.89787069143773
all the corners of France, were executing under his orders, if he met a	345.0948392307722
Musketeer of the company of Tréville, he drew near and looked at him in	290.6963187788143
a peculiar manner, and not recognizing in him one of our four	227.77468605533008
companions, he turned his penetrating look and profound thoughts in	279.63906648299854
another direction.	227.00527479146305
One day when oppressed with a mortal weariness of mind, without hope in	326.5907824738911
the negotiations with the city, without news from England, the cardinal	324.80978170918814
went out, without any other aim than to be out of doors, and	252.34279976472249
accompanied only by Cahusac and La Houdinière, strolled along the	333.42462226274205
beach. Mingling the immensity of his dreams with the immensity of the	279.756370052464
ocean, he came, his horse going at a foot’s pace, to a hill from the	175.34368390365208
top of which he perceived behind a hedge, reclining on the sand and	167.54393531724267
catching in its passage one of those rays of the sun so rare at this	315.1637238908295
period of the year, seven men surrounded by empty bottles. Four of	287.253665126223
these men were our Musketeers, preparing to listen to a letter one of	168.375004667538
them had just received. This letter was so important that it made them	357.6723833415832
forsake their cards and their dice on the drumhead.	298.2747161570426
The other three were occupied in opening an enormous flagon of	321.4018668094956
Collicure wine; these were the lackeys of these gentlemen.	298.4512167510783
The cardinal was, as we have said, in very low spirits; and nothing	365.8150888089043
when he was in that state of mind increased his depression so much as	210.19084937535138
gaiety in others. Besides, he had another strange fancy, which was	186.26068165109598
always to believe that the causes of his sadness created the gaiety of	189.09597231609587
others. Making a sign to La Houdinière and Cahusac to stop, he alighted	318.9164149992258
from his horse, and went toward these suspected merry companions,	299.50573175734905
hoping, by means of the sand which deadened the sound of his steps and	227.0909234002261
of the hedge which concealed his approach, to catch some words of this	326.19286792287096
conversation which appeared so interesting. At ten paces from the hedge	169.3824604218698
he recognized the talkative Gascon; and as he had already perceived	259.82950035835603
that these men were Musketeers, he did not doubt that the three others	217.88155948497968
were those called the Inseparables; that is to say, Athos, Porthos, and	334.93074268350335
Aramis.	363.70901460484663
It may be supposed that his desire to hear the conversation was	281.90726577029534
augmented by this discovery. His eyes took a strange expression, and	169.3622856488406
with the step of a tiger-cat he advanced toward the hedge; but he had	252.53238434865997
not been able to catch more than a few vague syllables without any	350.3293088635136
positive sense, when a sonorous and short cry made him start, and	249.36300740586552
attracted the attention of the Musketeers.	184.951597285937
“Officer!” cried Grimaud.	309.59740559174134
“You are speaking, you scoundrel!” said Athos, rising upon his elbow,	249.56457215676105
and transfixing Grimaud with his flaming look.	263.9856720705796
Grimaud therefore added nothing to his speech, but contented himself	297.0499961136559
with pointing his index finger in the direction of the hedge,	278.6754383790545
announcing by this gesture the cardinal and his escort.	168.34683653100015
With a single bound the Musketeers were on their feet, and saluted with	243.5016451865506
respect.	234.53956554144682
The cardinal seemed furious.	304.7905462617018
“It appears that Messieurs the Musketeers keep guard,” said he. “Are	177.71467447648288
the English expected by land, or do the Musketeers consider themselves	263.03022463472524
superior officers?”	274.970642568043
“Monseigneur,” replied Athos, for amid the general fright he alone had	248.280685177999
preserved the noble calmness and coolness that never forsook him,	168.5681194028911
“Monseigneur, the Musketeers, when they are not on duty, or when their	223.0192505214633
duty is over, drink and play at dice, and they are certainly superior	238.59395179119596
officers to their lackeys.”	287.0957016037084
“Lackeys?” grumbled the cardinal. “Lackeys who have the order to warn	348.10244044056265
their masters when anyone passes are not lackeys, they are sentinels.”	275.5754738679241
“Your Eminence may perceive that if we had not taken this precaution,	179.68829102319827
we should have been exposed to allowing you to pass without presenting	170.16368326946838
you our respects or offering you our thanks for the favor you have done	321.1236557565935
us in uniting us. D’Artagnan,” continued Athos, “you, who but lately	228.3250830779497
were so anxious for such an opportunity for expressing your gratitude	311.74357092112143
to Monseigneur, here it is; avail yourself of it.”	332.2242771731512
These words were pronounced with that imperturbable phlegm which	290.2293354613252
distinguished Athos in the hour of danger, and with that excessive	226.4631077358969
politeness which made of him at certain moments a king more majestic	299.33800194268235
than kings by birth.	190.16869490624308
D’Artagnan came forward and stammered out a few words of gratitude	312.8588734360095
which soon expired under the gloomy looks of the cardinal.	304.5016455662915
“It does not signify, gentlemen,” continued the cardinal, without	347.2266623007297
appearing to be in the least swerved from his first intention by the	283.7337006632497
diversion which Athos had started, “it does not signify, gentlemen. I	311.00628411745356
do not like to have simple soldiers, because they have the advantage of	281.88346880643
serving in a privileged corps, thus to play the great lords; discipline	259.49926640031936
is the same for them as for everybody else.”	189.98835742326543
Athos allowed the cardinal to finish his sentence completely, and bowed	311.60684893419767
in sign of assent. Then he resumed in his turn: “Discipline,	295.4433560833983
Monseigneur, has, I hope, in no way been forgotten by us. We are not on	203.06660639025466
duty, and we believed that not being on duty we were at liberty to	224.37360708019057
dispose of our time as we pleased. If we are so fortunate as to have	335.50049054388853
some particular duty to perform for your Eminence, we are ready to obey	263.9596980458213
you. Your Eminence may perceive,” continued Athos, knitting his brow,	360.9621819057094
for this sort of investigation began to annoy him, “that we have not	203.10990997208026
come out without our arms.”	217.33839695130413
And he showed the cardinal, with his finger, the four muskets piled	284.10178733060025
near the drum, on which were the cards and dice.	216.2636239397521
“Your Eminence may believe,” added D’Artagnan, “that we would have come	169.25028573349255
to meet you, if we could have supposed it was Monseigneur coming toward	316.84174826464033
us with so few attendants.”	219.22784878018874
The cardinal bit his mustache, and even his lips a little.	333.11948202537053
“Do you know what you look like, all together, as you are armed and	260.29052398622497
guarded by your lackeys?” said the cardinal. “You look like four	285.37317870437306
conspirators.”	307.3539185117356
“Oh, as to that, Monseigneur, it is true,” said Athos; “we do conspire,	291.4725041354301
as your Eminence might have seen the other morning. Only we conspire	213.24975650617887
against the Rochellais.”	336.79719012749456
“Ah, you gentlemen of policy!” replied the cardinal, knitting his brow	289.58086004002206
in his turn, “the secret of many unknown things might perhaps be found	255.66414555878617
in your brains, if we could read them as you read that letter which you	264.9703559116599
concealed as soon as you saw me coming.”	265.2224990734811
The color mounted to the face of Athos, and he made a step toward his	276.7235156068274
Eminence.	307.49327110139285
“One might think you really suspected us, monseigneur, and we were	176.708268039571
undergoing a real interrogatory. If it be so, we trust your Eminence	286.90096118594886
will deign to explain yourself, and we should then at least be	168.23276897306363
acquainted with our real position.”	279.04944826421934
“And if it were an interrogatory!” replied the cardinal. “Others	299.9624421001812
besides you have undergone such, Monsieur Athos, and have replied	320.7357836437631
thereto.”	177.73488893488198
“Thus I have told your Eminence that you had but to question us, and we	237.3726735381009
are ready to reply.”	173.88717044135248
“What was that letter you were about to read, Monsieur Aramis, and	339.45860226906336
which you so promptly concealed?”	198.58633558043465
“A woman’s letter, monseigneur.”	197.81961254699178
“Ah, yes, I see,” said the cardinal; “we must be discreet with this	170.3465395250448
sort of letters; but nevertheless, we may show them to a confessor, and	303.62491233875164
you know I have taken orders.”	302.9212582409763
“Monseigneur,” said Athos, with a calmness the more terrible because he	361.5079115194555
risked his head in making this reply, “the letter is a woman’s letter,	224.6244920144125
but it is neither signed Marion de Lorme, nor Madame d’Aiguillon.”	341.66618689126994
The cardinal became as pale as death; lightning darted from his eyes.	269.62393517795533
He turned round as if to give an order to Cahusac and Houdinière. Athos	202.06485319457406
saw the movement; he made a step toward the muskets, upon which the	172.59310136066543
other three friends had fixed their eyes, like men ill-disposed to	224.09115049479027
allow themselves to be taken. The cardinalists were three; the	243.90180365405155
Musketeers, lackeys included, were seven. He judged that the match	232.33902813876023
would be so much the less equal, if Athos and his companions were	333.07334572104105
really plotting; and by one of those rapid turns which he always had at	274.12252562577163
command, all his anger faded away into a smile.	274.9078299705106
“Well, well!” said he, “you are brave young men, proud in daylight,	189.82458773554703
faithful in darkness. We can find no fault with you for watching over	183.77249424336276
yourselves, when you watch so carefully over others. Gentlemen, I have	221.510368397448
not forgotten the night in which you served me as an escort to the Red	266.54430575000197
Dovecot. If there were any danger to be apprehended on the road I am	245.04461984359878
going, I would request you to accompany me; but as there is none,	294.05300449413653
remain where you are, finish your bottles, your game, and your letter.	330.15190178910336
Adieu, gentlemen!”	228.09065351723905
And remounting his horse, which Cahusac led to him, he saluted them	282.131211307445
with his hand, and rode away.	177.18737266292064
The four young men, standing and motionless, followed him with their	214.2562181418126
eyes without speaking a single word until he had disappeared. Then they	323.9691551996992
looked at one another.	289.6181602696584
The countenances of all gave evidence of terror, for notwithstanding	311.6636974536258
the friendly adieu of his Eminence, they plainly perceived that the	237.71101403973813
cardinal went away with rage in his heart.	234.08504397010762
Athos alone smiled, with a self-possessed, disdainful smile.	357.81228107598247
When the cardinal was out of hearing and sight, “That Grimaud kept bad	169.6605685249539
watch!” cried Porthos, who had a great inclination to vent his	202.81580993595014
ill-humor on somebody.	340.26680462455755
Grimaud was about to reply to excuse himself. Athos lifted his finger,	252.39642316464443
and Grimaud was silent.	208.4703824731722
“Would you have given up the letter, Aramis?” said D’Artagnan.	280.38360649588515
“I,” said Aramis, in his most flutelike tone, “I had made up my mind.	271.79983452128795
If he had insisted upon the letter being given up to him, I would have	230.9932317808442
presented the letter to him with one hand, and with the other I would	226.4856926572379
have run my sword through his body.”	265.0980181099397
“I expected as much,” said Athos; “and that was why I threw myself	241.69355870667061
between you and him. Indeed, this man is very much to blame for talking	350.55542324533116
thus to other men; one would say he had never had to do with any but	302.74395547542895
women and children.”	263.5924253709461
“My dear Athos, I admire you, but nevertheless we were in the wrong,	289.27235472020584
after all.”	362.3385385588565
“How, in the wrong?” said Athos. “Whose, then, is the air we breathe?	228.5810004564732
Whose is the ocean upon which we look? Whose is the sand upon which we	293.74369440293873
were reclining? Whose is that letter of your mistress? Do these belong	305.7696694199698
to the cardinal? Upon my honor, this man fancies the world belongs to	364.95716819602984
him. There you stood, stammering, stupefied, annihilated. One might	305.0625378989325
have supposed the Bastille appeared before you, and that the gigantic	301.66811325680203
Medusa had converted you into stone. Is being in love conspiring? You	318.117786002854
are in love with a woman whom the cardinal has caused to be shut up,	247.24747374626014
and you wish to get her out of the hands of the cardinal. That’s a	217.10967182508278
match you are playing with his Eminence; this letter is your game. Why	194.61259471796956
should you expose your game to your adversary? That is never done. Let	276.85331941475783
him find it out if he can! We can find out his!”	176.85295725530156
“Well, that’s all very sensible, Athos,” said D’Artagnan.	187.236923395184
“In that case, let there be no more question of what’s past, and let	222.4867647594001
Aramis resume the letter from his cousin where the cardinal interrupted	267.7407175399768
him.”	252.2227247228376
Aramis drew the letter from his pocket; the three friends surrounded	282.75164384835347
him, and the three lackeys grouped themselves again near the wine jar.	251.839924924532
“You had only read a line or two,” said D’Artagnan; “read the letter	337.30757071318044
again from the commencement.”	306.02434485119466
“Willingly,” said Aramis.	274.4639946034705
“MY DEAR COUSIN, I think I shall make up my mind to set out for	278.6234874045796
Béthune, where my sister has placed our little servant in the convent	330.13436418662474
of the Carmelites; this poor child is quite resigned, as she knows she	308.47556675118597
cannot live elsewhere without the salvation of her soul being in	242.26082089986662
danger. Nevertheless, if the affairs of our family are arranged, as we	211.71811474044472
hope they will be, I believe she will run the risk of being damned, and	342.6715531322226
will return to those she regrets, particularly as she knows they are	231.6453312417474
always thinking of her. Meanwhile, she is not very wretched; what she	279.8880888047636
most desires is a letter from her intended. I know that such viands	199.10788792157211
pass with difficulty through convent gratings; but after all, as I have	188.4385906716042
given you proofs, my dear cousin, I am not unskilled in such affairs,	167.36637658209864
and I will take charge of the commission. My sister thanks you for your	258.82598420951
good and eternal remembrance. She has experienced much anxiety; but she	306.10534690818395
is now at length a little reassured, having sent her secretary away in	256.48720071551185
order that nothing may happen unexpectedly.	338.35362688762524
    “Adieu, my dear cousin. Tell us news of yourself as often as you	297.1242739918531
    can; that is to say, as often as you can with safety. I embrace	309.54931025373594
    you.	297.20981095486536
“MARIE MICHON”	317.75492030898147
“Oh, what do I not owe you, Aramis?” said D’Artagnan. “Dear Constance!	178.05657850654416
I have at length, then, intelligence of you. She lives; she is in	315.8181760074939
safety in a convent; she is at Béthune! Where is Béthune, Athos?”	175.45475327072006
“Why, upon the frontiers of Artois and of Flanders. The siege once	304.37704435427395
over, we shall be able to make a tour in that direction.”	266.1202883793723
“And that will not be long, it is to be hoped,” said Porthos; “for they	288.69047145667713
have this morning hanged a spy who confessed that the Rochellais were	172.9660763427159
reduced to the leather of their shoes. Supposing that after having	330.6171182528036
eaten the leather they eat the soles, I cannot see much that is left	264.83108526509034
unless they eat one another.”	270.8430170712276
“Poor fools!” said Athos, emptying a glass of excellent Bordeaux wine	186.6816318276242
which, without having at that period the reputation it now enjoys,	318.1763525968705
merited it no less, “poor fools! As if the Catholic religion was not	276.0895528893564
the most advantageous and the most agreeable of all religions! All the	292.9330687857798
same,” resumed he, after having clicked his tongue against his palate,	268.31668587389436
“they are brave fellows! But what the devil are you about, Aramis?”	364.67785298105673
continued Athos. “Why, you are squeezing that letter into your pocket!”	324.9418772416547
“Yes,” said D’Artagnan, “Athos is right, it must be burned. And yet if	177.89495659327375
we burn it, who knows whether Monsieur Cardinal has not a secret to	174.56868455462734
interrogate ashes?”	209.20538762798714
“He must have one,” said Athos.	324.6770168566025
“What will you do with the letter, then?” asked Porthos.	357.1392155764953
“Come here, Grimaud,” said Athos. Grimaud rose and obeyed. “As a	227.36781818117214
punishment for having spoken without permission, my friend, you will	346.55919440680844
please to eat this piece of paper; then to recompense you for the	279.25253644815155
service you will have rendered us, you shall afterward drink this glass	263.5456655446343
of wine. First, here is the letter. Eat heartily.”	198.18775400718403
Grimaud smiled; and with his eyes fixed upon the glass which Athos held	284.45832535344954
in his hand, he ground the paper well between his teeth and then	292.71873322873194
swallowed it.	219.73195016786846
“Bravo, Monsieur Grimaud!” said Athos; “and now take this. That’s well.	308.69426020303104
We dispense with your saying grace.”	260.82397150522905
Grimaud silently swallowed the glass of Bordeaux wine; but his eyes,	183.27167575758702
raised toward heaven during this delicious occupation, spoke a language	254.76762292678296
which, though mute, was not the less expressive.	230.45907361552025
“And now,” said Athos, “unless Monsieur Cardinal should form the	207.02598426999947
ingenious idea of ripping up Grimaud, I think we may be pretty much at	235.55436438341093
our ease respecting the letter.”	177.46302106095246
Meantime, his Eminence continued his melancholy ride, murmuring between	236.40292451101925
his mustaches, “These four men must positively be mine.”	288.60008732314793
Chapter LII.	317.8996718427916
CAPTIVITY: THE FIRST DAY	361.07193961814187
Let us return to Milady, whom a glance thrown upon the coast of France	362.4011845368808
has made us lose sight of for an instant.	176.2983772052699
We shall find her still in the despairing attitude in which we left	176.83736432013583
her, plunged in an abyss of dismal reflection—a dark hell at the gate	359.86062452166993
of which she has almost left hope behind, because for the first time	268.20815153977253
she doubts, for the first time she fears.	324.59863885533366
On two occasions her fortune has failed her, on two occasions she has	347.9288589670998
found herself discovered and betrayed; and on these two occasions it	270.4032985090192
was to one fatal genius, sent doubtlessly by the Lord to combat her,	280.51469491051444
that she has succumbed. D’Artagnan has conquered her—her, that	254.23313412024262
invincible power of evil.	202.25555447068388
He has deceived her in her love, humbled her in her pride, thwarted her	211.97454301957947
in her ambition; and now he ruins her fortune, deprives her of liberty,	339.6059697501801
and even threatens her life. Still more, he has lifted the corner of	202.22923356641454
her mask—that shield with which she covered herself and which rendered	229.38096674867106
her so strong.	270.7201068614954
D’Artagnan has turned aside from Buckingham, whom she hates as she	189.37296239973176
hates everyone she has loved, the tempest with which Richelieu	226.04554150331262
threatened him in the person of the queen. D’Artagnan had passed	348.5018398461485
himself upon her as De Wardes, for whom she had conceived one of those	297.72419470109014
tigerlike fancies common to women of her character. D’Artagnan knows	167.5034186231594
that terrible secret which she has sworn no one shall know without	194.65556111204864
dying. In short, at the moment in which she has just obtained from	309.60748886488574
Richelieu a _carte blanche_ by the means of which she is about to take	182.37636559982934
vengeance on her enemy, this precious paper is torn from her hands, and	357.7124464318952
it is D’Artagnan who holds her prisoner and is about to send her to	255.33325448505275
some filthy Botany Bay, some infamous Tyburn of the Indian Ocean.	317.4683412106808
All this she owes to D’Artagnan, without doubt. From whom can come so	210.02026276061187
many disgraces heaped upon her head, if not from him? He alone could	352.4145731051808
have transmitted to Lord de Winter all these frightful secrets which he	355.3548832044799
has discovered, one after another, by a train of fatalities. He knows	209.0615303613195
her brother-in-law. He must have written to him.	183.32054835659633
What hatred she distills! Motionless, with her burning and fixed	265.6974517694995
glances, in her solitary apartment, how well the outbursts of passion	349.77608326675073
which at times escape from the depths of her chest with her	331.979754238199
respiration, accompany the sound of the surf which rises, growls,	309.4583566276681
roars, and breaks itself like an eternal and powerless despair against	195.0181422555886
the rocks on which is built this dark and lofty castle! How many	300.80308565873554
magnificent projects of vengeance she conceives by the light of the	336.4484656206724
flashes which her tempestuous passion casts over her mind against Mme.	190.38651852530833
Bonacieux, against Buckingham, but above all against	298.0245974335638
D’Artagnan—projects lost in the distance of the future.	205.84192573233304
Yes; but in order to avenge herself she must be free. And to be free, a	324.2826105681951
prisoner has to pierce a wall, detach bars, cut through a floor—all	221.07396787816282
undertakings which a patient and strong man may accomplish, but before	173.78128127977502
which the feverish irritations of a woman must give way. Besides, to do	321.2520781855777
all this, time is necessary—months, years; and she has ten or twelve	284.96619908336424
days, as Lord de Winter, her fraternal and terrible jailer, has told	234.45516808036064
her.	326.75757114232596
And yet, if she were a man she would attempt all this, and perhaps	247.91250344121858
might succeed; why, then, did heaven make the mistake of placing that	356.6034841806327
manlike soul in that frail and delicate body?	324.78400399684585
The first moments of her captivity were terrible; a few convulsions of	293.32905744378667
rage which she could not suppress paid her debt of feminine weakness to	295.3243698639734
nature. But by degrees she overcame the outbursts of her mad passion;	250.10668938912517
and nervous tremblings which agitated her frame disappeared, and she	284.26387297678997
remained folded within herself like a fatigued serpent in repose.	271.1044528915459
“Go to, go to! I must have been mad to allow myself to be carried away	358.7462608898065
so,” says she, gazing into the glass, which reflects back to her eyes	290.7724882149124
the burning glance by which she appears to interrogate herself. “No	227.84890315515082
violence; violence is the proof of weakness. In the first place, I have	246.17573230704227
never succeeded by that means. Perhaps if I employed my strength	195.92408069283977
against women I might perchance find them weaker than myself, and	354.30068561324333
consequently conquer them; but it is with men that I struggle, and I am	302.0245088482235
but a woman to them. Let me fight like a woman, then; my strength is in	195.09392593305483
my weakness.”	362.48426990238676
Then, as if to render an account to herself of the changes she could	364.4266231452662
place upon her countenance, so mobile and so expressive, she made it	326.8127688930535
take all expressions from that of passionate anger, which convulsed her	329.5734908375015
features, to that of the most sweet, most affectionate, and most	304.3949959434241
seducing smile. Then her hair assumed successively, under her skillful	221.94753501889028
hands, all the undulations she thought might assist the charms of her	327.03375662236465
face. At length she murmured, satisfied with herself, “Come, nothing is	316.1336846230862
lost; I am still beautiful.”	364.98404443466796
It was then nearly eight o’clock in the evening. Milady perceived a	309.73033566395816
bed; she calculated that the repose of a few hours would not only	228.0423933349769
refresh her head and her ideas, but still further, her complexion. A	337.1613012772781
better idea, however, came into her mind before going to bed. She had	206.7813185045129
heard something said about supper. She had already been an hour in this	354.92106861500054
apartment; they could not long delay bringing her a repast. The	227.534916484119
prisoner did not wish to lose time; and she resolved to make that very	210.8423681182668
evening some attempts to ascertain the nature of the ground she had to	259.84478782832224
work upon, by studying the characters of the men to whose guardianship	324.50764720849395
she was committed.	252.66867049011455
A light appeared under the door; this light announced the reappearance	270.3654058024594
of her jailers. Milady, who had arisen, threw herself quickly into the	341.6113138140865
armchair, her head thrown back, her beautiful hair unbound and	244.42666642041158
disheveled, her bosom half bare beneath her crumpled lace, one hand on	189.76092922314325
her heart, and the other hanging down.	262.1444355493616
The bolts were drawn; the door groaned upon its hinges. Steps sounded	365.27968602922886
in the chamber, and drew near.	310.492952001441
“Place that table there,” said a voice which the prisoner recognized as	269.2013437367169
that of Felton.	235.5673517303747
The order was executed.	342.97730384413194
“You will bring lights, and relieve the sentinel,” continued Felton.	332.0738359155529
And this double order which the young lieutenant gave to the same	285.6955238152725
individuals proved to Milady that her servants were the same men as her	234.53283225362668
guards; that is to say, soldiers.	174.35978201124868
Felton’s orders were, for the rest, executed with a silent rapidity	219.92967551291684
that gave a good idea of the way in which he maintained discipline.	356.2767802634489
At length Felton, who had not yet looked at Milady, turned toward her.	336.3795727468711
“Ah, ah!” said he, “she is asleep; that’s well. When she wakes she can	275.0552927338141
sup.” And he made some steps toward the door.	332.2189771438501
“But, my lieutenant,” said a soldier, less stoical than his chief, and	277.9739157454185
who had approached Milady, “this woman is not asleep.”	341.50855061408987
“What, not asleep!” said Felton; “what is she doing, then?”	220.9210877881287
“She has fainted. Her face is very pale, and I have listened in vain; I	353.71421972079753
do not hear her breathe.”	205.91962072416905
“You are right,” said Felton, after having looked at Milady from the	279.66591079750793
spot on which he stood without moving a step toward her. “Go and tell	327.4851185844153
Lord de Winter that his prisoner has fainted—for this event not having	362.5238293480331
been foreseen, I don’t know what to do.”	217.2195825399438
The soldier went out to obey the orders of his officer. Felton sat down	304.5710663631549
upon an armchair which happened to be near the door, and waited without	215.8821468787866
speaking a word, without making a gesture. Milady possessed that great	209.1667541640635
art, so much studied by women, of looking through her long eyelashes	193.36348340978597
without appearing to open the lids. She perceived Felton, who sat with	359.70484315748274
his back toward her. She continued to look at him for nearly ten	345.04240839738395
minutes, and in these ten minutes the immovable guardian never turned	223.93357515922375
round once.	250.00132499937223
She then thought that Lord de Winter would come, and by his presence	295.1016174097057
give fresh strength to her jailer. Her first trial was lost; she acted	206.8324479430163
like a woman who reckons up her resources. As a result she raised her	223.63923497941582
head, opened her eyes, and sighed deeply.	232.59789267929426
At this sigh Felton turned round.	247.0292243593916
“Ah, you are awake, madame,” he said; “then I have nothing more to do	283.7257518124379
here. If you want anything you can ring.”	182.81821495773886
“Oh, my God, my God! how I have suffered!” said Milady, in that	352.31371826144425
harmonious voice which, like that of the ancient enchantresses, charmed	228.7288107542675
all whom she wished to destroy.	190.74789247119577
And she assumed, upon sitting up in the armchair, a still more graceful	203.01507960215346
and abandoned position than when she reclined.	265.7905115220773
Felton arose.	242.13912431405407
“You will be served, thus, madame, three times a day,” said he. “In the	290.88366295641015
morning at nine o’clock, in the day at one o’clock, and in the evening	312.26640242410735
at eight. If that does not suit you, you can point out what other hours	248.40284965685814
you prefer, and in this respect your wishes will be complied with.”	232.40610411067007
“But am I to remain always alone in this vast and dismal chamber?”	220.64108208001463
asked Milady.	331.1740144418085
“A woman of the neighbourhood has been sent for, who will be tomorrow	175.17202119220747
at the castle, and will return as often as you desire her presence.”	294.239346732943
“I thank you, sir,” replied the prisoner, humbly.	302.5112759290443
Felton made a slight bow, and directed his steps toward the door. At	292.6999180937846
the moment he was about to go out, Lord de Winter appeared in the	182.4910801966986
corridor, followed by the soldier who had been sent to inform him of	259.67009547191225
the swoon of Milady. He held a vial of salts in his hand.	357.5055233883385
“Well, what is it—what is going on here?” said he, in a jeering voice,	259.5001715440666
on seeing the prisoner sitting up and Felton about to go out. “Is this	340.4903949308141
corpse come to life already? Felton, my lad, did you not perceive that	222.77836705703487
you were taken for a novice, and that the first act was being performed	312.5802380881354
of a comedy of which we shall doubtless have the pleasure of following	307.3453033258017
out all the developments?”	340.6133973536528
“I thought so, my lord,” said Felton; “but as the prisoner is a woman,	182.19489973293093
after all, I wish to pay her the attention that every man of gentle	247.85152113650543
birth owes to a woman, if not on her account, at least on my own.”	330.33532481988345
Milady shuddered through her whole system. These words of Felton’s	277.91164697408607
passed like ice through her veins.	231.12651676728484
“So,” replied de Winter, laughing, “that beautiful hair so skillfully	280.2878894178397
disheveled, that white skin, and that languishing look, have not yet	259.3782348817159
seduced you, you heart of stone?”	249.79946412062424
“No, my Lord,” replied the impassive young man; “your Lordship may be	316.39822727597027
assured that it requires more than the tricks and coquetry of a woman	209.13094704266337
to corrupt me.”	351.74727449109423
“In that case, my brave lieutenant, let us leave Milady to find out	211.1217310695384
something else, and go to supper; but be easy! She has a fruitful	178.5937032548852
imagination, and the second act of the comedy will not delay its steps	350.74601389395355
after the first.”	264.6307715802944
And at these words Lord de Winter passed his arm through that of	263.1307182505183
Felton, and led him out, laughing.	237.11238230861937
“Oh, I will be a match for you!” murmured Milady, between her teeth;	243.3840582290114
“be assured of that, you poor spoiled monk, you poor converted soldier,	210.31284619190313
who has cut his uniform out of a monk’s frock!”	298.8049409192171
“By the way,” resumed de Winter, stopping at the threshold of the door,	320.2279975978944
“you must not, Milady, let this check take away your appetite. Taste	271.41702606273395
that fowl and those fish. On my honor, they are not poisoned. I have a	264.225460059307
very good cook, and he is not to be my heir; I have full and perfect	350.86612535643405
confidence in him. Do as I do. Adieu, dear sister, till your next	360.13044578240505
swoon!”	237.30641666553603
This was all that Milady could endure. Her hands clutched her armchair;	352.6203374446477
she ground her teeth inwardly; her eyes followed the motion of the door	285.31379623960845
as it closed behind Lord de Winter and Felton, and the moment she was	219.60367971771433
alone a fresh fit of despair seized her. She cast her eyes upon the	222.71159746289658
table, saw the glittering of a knife, rushed toward it and clutched it;	330.7044525397837
but her disappointment was cruel. The blade was round, and of flexible	258.6415097998141
silver.	282.53056897640397
A burst of laughter resounded from the other side of the ill-closed	346.8412505076426
door, and the door reopened.	329.8671364431338
“Ha, ha!” cried Lord de Winter; “ha, ha! Don’t you see, my brave	199.94582972573554
Felton; don’t you see what I told you? That knife was for you, my lad;	240.91868433398852
she would have killed you. Observe, this is one of her peculiarities,	287.5787086254854
to get rid thus, after one fashion or another, of all the people who	356.62921238397155
bother her. If I had listened to you, the knife would have been pointed	272.44928263925357
and of steel. Then no more of Felton; she would have cut your throat,	174.1303690691767
and after that everybody else’s. See, John, see how well she knows how	183.0315419899467
to handle a knife.”	304.49548311613705
In fact, Milady still held the harmless weapon in her clenched hand;	229.98810962649574
but these last words, this supreme insult, relaxed her hands, her	181.52552243870142
strength, and even her will. The knife fell to the ground.	323.06290701275486
“You were right, my Lord,” said Felton, with a tone of profound disgust	260.06693639758214
which sounded to the very bottom of the heart of Milady, “you were	191.03294841627758
right, my Lord, and I was wrong.”	346.8629441639013
And both again left the room.	187.83902434702682
But this time Milady lent a more attentive ear than the first, and she	300.1835239238611
heard their steps die away in the distance of the corridor.	332.97575906411396
“I am lost,” murmured she; “I am lost! I am in the power of men upon	360.2789692721233
whom I can have no more influence than upon statues of bronze or	287.85400273318635
granite; they know me by heart, and are steeled against all my weapons.	363.330726531668
It is, however, impossible that this should end as they have decreed!”	258.1827809679341
In fact, as this last reflection indicated—this instinctive return to	317.25174519883114
hope—sentiments of weakness or fear did not dwell long in her ardent	203.8414509079092
spirit. Milady sat down to table, ate from several dishes, drank a	235.48267480522173
little Spanish wine, and felt all her resolution return.	217.9701521560529
Before she went to bed she had pondered, analyzed, turned on all sides,	199.30388687322784
examined on all points, the words, the steps, the gestures, the signs,	248.54226402278266
and even the silence of her interlocutors; and of this profound,	322.14111878460255
skillful, and anxious study the result was that Felton, everything	202.08601146889944
considered, appeared the more vulnerable of her two persecutors.	231.01718833877993
One expression above all recurred to the mind of the prisoner: “If I	217.83862326029677
had listened to you,” Lord de Winter had said to Felton.	333.7931331291607
Felton, then, had spoken in her favor, since Lord de Winter had not	212.3582480212831
been willing to listen to him.	248.38568870022044
“Weak or strong,” repeated Milady, “that man has, then, a spark of pity	196.89227842149467
in his soul; of that spark I will make a flame that shall devour him.	309.73091946263776
As to the other, he knows me, he fears me, and knows what he has to	275.48518519594154
expect of me if ever I escape from his hands. It is useless, then, to	235.1970084006793
attempt anything with him. But Felton—that’s another thing. He is a	337.8866676598851
young, ingenuous, pure man who seems virtuous; him there are means of	343.765579842791
destroying.”	317.5547428231809
And Milady went to bed and fell asleep with a smile upon her lips.	253.18722335187363
Anyone who had seen her sleeping might have said she was a young girl	349.5067816014458
dreaming of the crown of flowers she was to wear on her brow at the	231.91817232057025
next festival.	318.77521291370306
Chapter LIII.	176.0019795937613
CAPTIVITY: THE SECOND DAY	213.51630131766711
Milady dreamed that she at length had D’Artagnan in her power, that she	309.2984098148752
was present at his execution; and it was the sight of his odious blood,	248.34106048701534
flowing beneath the ax of the headsman, which spread that charming	357.21039580756656
smile upon her lips.	193.88857913791827
She slept as a prisoner sleeps, rocked by his first hope.	184.48852599985452
In the morning, when they entered her chamber she was still in bed.	170.48218442544223
Felton remained in the corridor. He brought with him the woman of whom	233.5164867519717
he had spoken the evening before, and who had just arrived; this woman	286.1792876155511
entered, and approaching Milady’s bed, offered her services.	235.79940313003593
Milady was habitually pale; her complexion might therefore deceive a	274.2947169644624
person who saw her for the first time.	290.27961638710536
“I am in a fever,” said she; “I have not slept a single instant during	253.78177965959424
all this long night. I suffer horribly. Are you likely to be more	251.43925091826952
humane to me than others were yesterday? All I ask is permission to	227.82947042701454
remain abed.”	356.342905384232
“Would you like to have a physician called?” said the woman.	327.45963830160554
Felton listened to this dialogue without speaking a word.	170.30946122119275
Milady reflected that the more people she had around her the more she	192.8143578417454
would have to work upon, and Lord de Winter would redouble his watch.	177.22380604677176
Besides, the physician might declare the ailment feigned; and Milady,	342.3116657674027
after having lost the first trick, was not willing to lose the second.	188.23063680362952
“Go and fetch a physician?” said she. “What could be the good of that?	304.3120849828836
These gentlemen declared yesterday that my illness was a comedy; it	290.84034018871745
would be just the same today, no doubt—for since yesterday evening they	357.68255057434226
have had plenty of time to send for a doctor.”	199.75514882777338
“Then,” said Felton, who became impatient, “say yourself, madame, what	184.26021108164048
treatment you wish followed.”	234.8859926892406
“Eh, how can I tell? My God! I know that I suffer, that’s all. Give me	260.35143564941427
anything you like, it is of little consequence.”	240.5118683081795
“Go and fetch Lord de Winter,” said Felton, tired of these eternal	347.8828210067915
complaints.	349.3302836295284
“Oh, no, no!” cried Milady; “no, sir, do not call him, I conjure you. I	222.65720090108096
am well, I want nothing; do not call him.”	204.3387827639902
She gave so much vehemence, such magnetic eloquence to this	277.8070891423117
exclamation, that Felton in spite of himself advanced some steps into	212.34591097026043
the room.	356.82349450875984
“He has come!” thought Milady.	176.53972378297635
“Meanwhile, madame, if you really suffer,” said Felton, “a physician	174.889410448466
shall be sent for; and if you deceive us—well, it will be the worse for	256.99257672895794
you. But at least we shall not have to reproach ourselves with	286.63374000269755
anything.”	233.91542884349818
Milady made no reply, but turning her beautiful head round upon her	307.26497368522587
pillow, she burst into tears, and uttered heartbreaking sobs.	364.45684337725595
Felton surveyed her for an instant with his usual impassiveness; then,	173.97549777074255
seeing that the crisis threatened to be prolonged, he went out. The	234.97724270588603
woman followed him, and Lord de Winter did not appear.	254.94830713272188
“I fancy I begin to see my way,” murmured Milady, with a savage joy,	364.6326618885418
burying herself under the clothes to conceal from anybody who might be	168.17244022717114
watching her this burst of inward satisfaction.	332.4998511492329
Two hours passed away.	259.4618140605463
“Now it is time that the malady should be over,” said she; “let me	241.6957410325805
rise, and obtain some success this very day. I have but ten days, and	348.73671236320394
this evening two of them will be gone.”	361.74786626864693
In the morning, when they entered Milady’s chamber they had brought her	346.3413681327083
breakfast. Now, she thought, they could not long delay coming to clear	192.60512767580894
the table, and that Felton would then reappear.	259.5585432130012
Milady was not deceived. Felton reappeared, and without observing	261.4360774202895
whether Milady had or had not touched her repast, made a sign that the	289.98324526347096
table should be carried out of the room, it having been brought in	218.18658155460142
ready spread.	238.86207563199417
Felton remained behind; he held a book in his hand.	336.7936977670747
Milady, reclining in an armchair near the chimney, beautiful, pale, and	281.8210240985451
resigned, looked like a holy virgin awaiting martyrdom.	319.3955745809782
Felton approached her, and said, “Lord de Winter, who is a Catholic,	227.8222751721466
like yourself, madame, thinking that the deprivation of the rites and	347.21332151688887
ceremonies of your church might be painful to you, has consented that	323.3128807725328
you should read every day the ordinary of your Mass; and here is a book	262.86850344407435
which contains the ritual.”	325.06445903170584
At the manner in which Felton laid the book upon the little table near	166.46772399594434
which Milady was sitting, at the tone in which he pronounced the two	341.8961164369613
words, _your Mass_, at the disdainful smile with which he accompanied	287.6432113923542
them, Milady raised her head, and looked more attentively at the	202.07049218053854
officer.	241.8981055467532
By that plain arrangement of the hair, by that costume of extreme	272.7953198174261
simplicity, by the brow polished like marble and as hard and	265.5322979219517
impenetrable, she recognized one of those gloomy Puritans she had so	177.71549951610388
often met, not only in the court of King James, but in that of the King	307.06748854449324
of France, where, in spite of the remembrance of the St. Bartholomew,	188.72026779399408
they sometimes came to seek refuge.	313.41376563311314
She then had one of those sudden inspirations which only people of	212.51000187844232
genius receive in great crises, in supreme moments which are to decide	285.2784441928251
their fortunes or their lives.	168.61968148814142
Those two words, _your Mass_, and a simple glance cast upon Felton,	269.24529801813196
revealed to her all the importance of the reply she was about to make;	197.32831949306546
but with that rapidity of intelligence which was peculiar to her, this	339.61775640054907
reply, ready arranged, presented itself to her lips:	321.3641513283683
“I?” said she, with an accent of disdain in unison with that which she	312.624099311862
had remarked in the voice of the young officer, “I, sir? _My Mass?_	319.4210595626628
Lord de Winter, the corrupted Catholic, knows very well that I am not	330.56598311529723
of his religion, and this is a snare he wishes to lay for me!”	349.3434823001236
“And of what religion are you, then, madame?” asked Felton, with an	167.14818364792777
astonishment which in spite of the empire he held over himself he could	212.00419788863144
not entirely conceal.	275.3092887966153
“I will tell it,” cried Milady, with a feigned exultation, “on the day	328.52241373489505
when I shall have suffered sufficiently for my faith.”	350.79157784726453
The look of Felton revealed to Milady the full extent of the space she	184.79334648989945
had opened for herself by this single word.	318.85495674809135
The young officer, however, remained mute and motionless; his look	186.5557391101026
alone had spoken.	206.18949747476097
“I am in the hands of my enemies,” continued she, with that tone of	302.01220944393725
enthusiasm which she knew was familiar to the Puritans. “Well, let my	270.02948735520533
God save me, or let me perish for my God! That is the reply I beg you	339.24423550140534
to make to Lord de Winter. And as to this book,” added she, pointing to	206.48330534105128
the manual with her finger but without touching it, as if she must be	219.47728761229234
contaminated by it, “you may carry it back and make use of it yourself,	272.2416195600217
for doubtless you are doubly the accomplice of Lord de Winter—the	365.08555781760117
accomplice in his persecutions, the accomplice in his heresies.”	338.626868641153
Felton made no reply, took the book with the same appearance of	253.86241478133337
repugnance which he had before manifested, and retired pensively.	289.60132627526934
Lord de Winter came toward five o’clock in the evening. Milady had had	195.9534373855297
time, during the whole day, to trace her plan of conduct. She received	316.95062449610987
him like a woman who had already recovered all her advantages.	294.87030497138215
“It appears,” said the baron, seating himself in the armchair opposite	300.15302049220224
that occupied by Milady, and stretching out his legs carelessly upon	269.38941845315856
the hearth, “it appears we have made a little apostasy!”	362.9594781180787
“What do you mean, sir!”	242.32563627457347
“I mean to say that since we last met you have changed your religion.	337.4780161487384
You have not by chance married a Protestant for a third husband, have	269.72465580473903
you?”	228.87777742754523
“Explain yourself, my Lord,” replied the prisoner, with majesty; “for	321.3613418289735
though I hear your words, I declare I do not understand them.”	295.16973977978984
“Then you have no religion at all; I like that best,” replied Lord de	269.2688479042341
Winter, laughing.	291.1992510988224
“Certainly that is most in accord with your own principles,” replied	264.4787313516876
Milady, frigidly.	331.9857027890155
“Oh, I confess it is all the same to me.”	270.0337354482871
“Oh, you need not avow this religious indifference, my Lord; your	208.50295057948216
debaucheries and crimes would vouch for it.”	324.68289849493647
“What, you talk of debaucheries, Madame Messalina, Lady Macbeth! Either	272.4124053599397
I misunderstand you or you are very shameless!”	223.6673444465805
“You only speak thus because you are overheard,” coolly replied Milady;	354.91563810210835
“and you wish to interest your jailers and your hangmen against me.”	249.26697247942016
“My jailers and my hangmen! Heyday, madame! you are taking a poetical	187.59278492286185
tone, and the comedy of yesterday turns to a tragedy this evening. As	365.22399333501426
to the rest, in eight days you will be where you ought to be, and my	310.10530549916757
task will be completed.”	226.48773654355603
“Infamous task! impious task!” cried Milady, with the exultation of a	273.4688022767387
victim who provokes his judge.	322.0917551762221
“My word,” said de Winter, rising, “I think the hussy is going mad!	222.66044783930877
Come, come, calm yourself, Madame Puritan, or I’ll remove you to a	242.75552850966287
dungeon. It’s my Spanish wine that has got into your head, is it not?	228.148330801508
But never mind; that sort of intoxication is not dangerous, and will	213.39500554648194
have no bad effects.”	255.11436399442277
And Lord de Winter retired swearing, which at that period was a very	319.0721706059852
knightly habit.	177.366934757704
Felton was indeed behind the door, and had not lost one word of this	179.12042995113944
scene. Milady had guessed aright.	177.5542757669816
“Yes, go, go!” said she to her brother; “the effects _are_ drawing	337.1309121385475
near, on the contrary; but you, weak fool, will not see them until it	317.6882732143289
is too late to shun them.”	202.36930921358044
Silence was re-established. Two hours passed away. Milady’s supper was	281.8388769285778
brought in, and she was found deeply engaged in saying her prayers	325.3626443680885
aloud—prayers which she had learned of an old servant of her second	264.13465930029685
husband, a most austere Puritan. She appeared to be in ecstasy, and did	337.7470928367608
not pay the least attention to what was going on around her. Felton	305.3515097436566
made a sign that she should not be disturbed; and when all was	321.3611902615753
arranged, he went out quietly with the soldiers.	287.6878786900668
Milady knew she might be watched, so she continued her prayers to the	329.69395710379604
end; and it appeared to her that the soldier who was on duty at her	280.78434935191626
door did not march with the same step, and seemed to listen. For the	254.97275753758328
moment she wished nothing better. She arose, came to the table, ate but	305.42681768228476
little, and drank only water.	268.54139782875745
An hour after, her table was cleared; but Milady remarked that this	243.18474697604609
time Felton did not accompany the soldiers. He feared, then, to see her	262.9760727565375
too often.	216.08313808971414
She turned toward the wall to smile—for there was in this smile such an	273.72441529492073
expression of triumph that this smile alone would have betrayed her.	281.27289004854197
She allowed, therefore, half an hour to pass away; and as at that	283.0920436556593
moment all was silence in the old castle, as nothing was heard but the	294.58225755345705
eternal murmur of the waves—that immense breaking of the ocean—with her	335.36777975541327
pure, harmonious, and powerful voice, she began the first couplet of	334.12775862709304
the psalm then in great favor with the Puritans:	170.6204740051087
“Thou leavest thy servants, Lord,	301.5276289710537
    To see if they be strong;	178.82753936098712
But soon thou dost afford	190.7863516017065
    Thy hand to lead them on.”	192.4463851151878
These verses were not excellent—very far from it; but as it is well	237.1832312933367
known, the Puritans did not pique themselves upon their poetry.	232.54765496919134
While singing, Milady listened. The soldier on guard at her door	317.6233376294068
stopped, as if he had been changed into stone. Milady was then able to	247.53654509899195
judge of the effect she had produced.	222.38894468324023
Then she continued her singing with inexpressible fervor and feeling.	336.2779784636969
It appeared to her that the sounds spread to a distance beneath the	192.46872546258098
vaulted roofs, and carried with them a magic charm to soften the hearts	339.0853981591328
of her jailers. It however likewise appeared that the soldier on duty—a	266.8020292486398
zealous Catholic, no doubt—shook off the charm, for through the door he	312.19039662479645
called: “Hold your tongue, madame! Your song is as dismal as a ‘De	275.81142219677633
profundis’; and if besides the pleasure of being in garrison here, we	265.01301713024196
must hear such things as these, no mortal can hold out.”	202.37799795975613
“Silence!” then exclaimed another stern voice which Milady recognized	190.78868836867753
as that of Felton. “What are you meddling with, stupid? Did anybody	197.01110836686064
order you to prevent that woman from singing? No. You were told to	339.22571885108914
guard her—to fire at her if she attempted to fly. Guard her! If she	278.8329206165019
flies, kill her; but don’t exceed your orders.”	252.2507018337625
An expression of unspeakable joy lightened the countenance of Milady;	331.9244885087869
but this expression was fleeting as the reflection of lightning.	182.06378767470832
Without appearing to have heard the dialogue, of which she had not lost	302.05637702552974
a word, she began again, giving to her voice all the charm, all the	316.55575085861085
power, all the seduction the demon had bestowed upon it:	303.0022368528337
“For all my tears, my cares,	236.67677886089234
    My exile, and my chains,	303.7434483590787
I have my youth, my prayers,	288.00189804441277
    And God, who counts my pains.”	252.1149028712406
Her voice, of immense power and sublime expression, gave to the rude,	200.44767031506314
unpolished poetry of these psalms a magic and an effect which the most	167.12197716759846
exalted Puritans rarely found in the songs of their brethren, and which	192.36308720508984
they were forced to ornament with all the resources of their	180.760452830665
imagination. Felton believed he heard the singing of the angel who	177.36059039936487
consoled the three Hebrews in the furnace.	301.71785922404126
Milady continued:	263.2995965693882
“One day our doors will ope,	224.57747414718594
    With God come our desire;	328.2039882884718
And if betrays that hope,	247.14961225258818
    To death we can aspire.”	173.05681514588335
This verse, into which the terrible enchantress threw her whole soul,	260.93794840237746
completed the trouble which had seized the heart of the young officer.	269.9798732928086
He opened the door quickly; and Milady saw him appear, pale as usual,	181.18110169218286
but with his eye inflamed and almost wild.	179.7871170384953
“Why do you sing thus, and with such a voice?” said he.	249.4511051572327
“Your pardon, sir,” said Milady, with mildness. “I forgot that my songs	352.37699636222953
are out of place in this castle. I have perhaps offended you in your	359.67436540684673
creed; but it was without wishing to do so, I swear. Pardon me, then, a	179.23973797182921
fault which is perhaps great, but which certainly was involuntary.”	172.17760576181564
Milady was so beautiful at this moment, the religious ecstasy in which	268.5863704518076
she appeared to be plunged gave such an expression to her countenance,	242.882905092118
that Felton was so dazzled that he fancied he beheld the angel whom he	214.8928997222914
had only just before heard.	288.1896631340936
“Yes, yes,” said he; “you disturb, you agitate the people who live in	261.1626350051007
the castle.”	280.8231614570898
The poor, senseless young man was not aware of the incoherence of his	345.15566553546955
words, while Milady was reading with her lynx’s eyes the very depths of	360.2678444884791
his heart.	290.7723941966057
“I will be silent, then,” said Milady, casting down her eyes with all	228.66970086670437
the sweetness she could give to her voice, with all the resignation she	269.34176091687493
could impress upon her manner.	358.1161732945763
“No, no, madame,” said Felton, “only do not sing so loud, particularly	357.3969034861578
at night.”	303.1635579281522
And at these words Felton, feeling that he could not long maintain his	181.68063151852618
severity toward his prisoner, rushed out of the room.	180.76502330927158
“You have done right, Lieutenant,” said the soldier. “Such songs	215.43256551977998
disturb the mind; and yet we become accustomed to them, her voice is so	194.4063755866996
beautiful.”	341.6969734873024
Chapter LIV.	266.1458203401603
CAPTIVITY: THE THIRD DAY	284.218251036113
Felton had fallen; but there was still another step to be taken. He	237.85857268841633
must be retained, or rather he must be left quite alone; and Milady but	192.89649195516796
obscurely perceived the means which could lead to this result.	233.63632080100388
Still more must be done. He must be made to speak, in order that he	362.84634298079555
might be spoken to—for Milady very well knew that her greatest	327.1065249182551
seduction was in her voice, which so skillfully ran over the whole	238.19139636958272
gamut of tones from human speech to language celestial.	301.18906116877247
Yet in spite of all this seduction Milady might fail—for Felton was	208.55554454024207
forewarned, and that against the least chance. From that moment she	223.84052714287378
watched all his actions, all his words, from the simplest glance of his	219.5905385608787
eyes to his gestures—even to a breath that could be interpreted as a	174.13934568104528
sigh. In short, she studied everything, as a skillful comedian does to	324.1159395471921
whom a new part has been assigned in a line to which he is not	208.7516835169417
accustomed.	194.56435098370483
Face to face with Lord de Winter her plan of conduct was more easy. She	183.88948264121547
had laid that down the preceding evening. To remain silent and	355.9906238567414
dignified in his presence; from time to time to irritate him by	283.5723960303626
affected disdain, by a contemptuous word; to provoke him to threats and	196.93316076806195
violence which would produce a contrast with her own resignation—such	277.05576759958575
was her plan. Felton would see all; perhaps he would say nothing, but	240.50681130052288
he would see.	307.7078343427287
In the morning, Felton came as usual; but Milady allowed him to preside	283.7682198639558
over all the preparations for breakfast without addressing a word to	309.6940367485024
him. At the moment when he was about to retire, she was cheered with a	354.1321078958293
ray of hope, for she thought he was about to speak; but his lips moved	258.2756059847239
without any sound leaving his mouth, and making a powerful effort to	189.9900082856492
control himself, he sent back to his heart the words that were about to	355.2905226663682
escape from his lips, and went out. Toward midday, Lord de Winter	172.94055067019292
entered.	232.00693270209405
It was a tolerably fine winter’s day, and a ray of that pale English	312.7441524494078
sun which lights but does not warm came through the bars of her prison.	331.452910579222
Milady was looking out at the window, and pretended not to hear the	193.129309571747
door as it opened.	237.83204252066616
“Ah, ah!” said Lord de Winter, “after having played comedy, after	199.1603018855189
having played tragedy, we are now playing melancholy?”	175.2440496702455
The prisoner made no reply.	200.13484421030944
“Yes, yes,” continued Lord de Winter, “I understand. You would like	187.4078600031546
very well to be at liberty on that beach! You would like very well to	282.50997124243406
be in a good ship dancing upon the waves of that emerald-green sea; you	271.2927940731727
would like very well, either on land or on the ocean, to lay for me one	350.8654448356807
of those nice little ambuscades you are so skillful in planning.	269.21710088472554
Patience, patience! In four days’ time the shore will be beneath your	307.4491373929874
feet, the sea will be open to you—more open than will perhaps be	256.49579261946553
agreeable to you, for in four days England will be relieved of you.”	190.35550914853428
Milady folded her hands, and raising her fine eyes toward heaven,	324.17834867104705
“Lord, Lord,” said she, with an angelic meekness of gesture and tone,	246.3301357509278
“pardon this man, as I myself pardon him.”	301.63709212094136
“Yes, pray, accursed woman!” cried the baron; “your prayer is so much	299.23811944636384
the more generous from your being, I swear to you, in the power of a	174.1241235430052
man who will never pardon you!” and he went out.	331.77013773286797
At the moment he went out a piercing glance darted through the opening	279.4609658170719
of the nearly closed door, and she perceived Felton, who drew quickly	300.65368743725804
to one side to prevent being seen by her.	290.87467966763563
Then she threw herself upon her knees, and began to pray.	212.37576129301038
“My God, my God!” said she, “thou knowest in what holy cause I suffer;	299.30845233150507
give me, then, strength to suffer.”	296.6056129726401
The door opened gently; the beautiful supplicant pretended not to hear	182.79396709804215
the noise, and in a voice broken by tears, she continued:	288.8259751761981
“God of vengeance! God of goodness! wilt thou allow the frightful	354.8574310996379
projects of this man to be accomplished?”	185.13177594508352
Then only she pretended to hear the sound of Felton’s steps, and rising	332.59274266595224
quick as thought, she blushed, as if ashamed of being surprised on her	323.96962950832193
knees.	209.93664374637189
“I do not like to disturb those who pray, madame,” said Felton,	183.27740602398268
seriously; “do not disturb yourself on my account, I beseech you.”	223.98171563574016
“How do you know I was praying, sir?” said Milady, in a voice broken by	302.65171955178187
sobs. “You were deceived, sir; I was not praying.”	330.7072857789109
“Do you think, then, madame,” replied Felton, in the same serious	177.5621431665632
voice, but with a milder tone, “do you think I assume the right of	318.54459469018303
preventing a creature from prostrating herself before her Creator? God	297.25275203112074
forbid! Besides, repentance becomes the guilty; whatever crimes they	170.48212418722576
may have committed, for me the guilty are sacred at the feet of God!”	269.45460875230935
“Guilty? I?” said Milady, with a smile which might have disarmed the	227.70629847538663
angel of the last judgment. “Guilty? Oh, my God, thou knowest whether I	304.76204832374026
am guilty! Say I am condemned, sir, if you please; but you know that	299.30085612126766
God, who loves martyrs, sometimes permits the innocent to be	307.6766513342443
condemned.”	348.8627500649851
“Were you condemned, were you innocent, were you a martyr,” replied	266.1651670189158
Felton, “the greater would be the necessity for prayer; and I myself	279.48738919301536
would aid you with my prayers.”	186.6028227491103
“Oh, you are a just man!” cried Milady, throwing herself at his feet.	190.19429459184676
“I can hold out no longer, for I fear I shall be wanting in strength at	255.33444068875286
the moment when I shall be forced to undergo the struggle, and confess	221.71773411005523
my faith. Listen, then, to the supplication of a despairing woman. You	265.95809319488535
are abused, sir; but that is not the question. I only ask you one	308.1409200453587
favor; and if you grant it me, I will bless you in this world and in	271.6259930381492
the next.”	308.8073521646886
“Speak to the master, madame,” said Felton; “happily I am neither	336.21436831072515
charged with the power of pardoning nor punishing. It is upon one	234.25522052383354
higher placed than I am that God has laid this responsibility.”	335.5457120288115
“To you—no, to you alone! Listen to me, rather than add to my	268.42576503810534
destruction, rather than add to my ignominy!”	238.7346270488964
“If you have merited this shame, madame, if you have incurred this	178.51479100356704
ignominy, you must submit to it as an offering to God.”	269.97636359804903
“What do you say? Oh, you do not understand me! When I speak of	169.79154691904085
ignominy, you think I speak of some chastisement, of imprisonment or	181.0228728473272
death. Would to heaven! Of what consequence to me is imprisonment or	341.633484272145
death?”	229.93274417667573
“It is I who no longer understand you, madame,” said Felton.	216.0489545364926
“Or, rather, who pretend not to understand me, sir!” replied the	307.7757384600512
prisoner, with a smile of incredulity.	303.55457323940044
“No, madame, on the honor of a soldier, on the faith of a Christian.”	260.48444108415663
“What, you are ignorant of Lord de Winter’s designs upon me?”	350.4178216130735
“I am.”	355.8306742179293
“Impossible; you are his confidant!”	319.90220075728143
“I never lie, madame.”	202.30971822757394
“Oh, he conceals them too little for you not to divine them.”	175.63074895059611
“I seek to divine nothing, madame; I wait till I am confided in, and	263.1017032950757
apart from that which Lord de Winter has said to me before you, he has	216.4910246200894
confided nothing to me.”	332.32714547637636
“Why, then,” cried Milady, with an incredible tone of truthfulness,	171.6898380826022
“you are not his accomplice; you do not know that he destines me to a	249.0106263281782
disgrace which all the punishments of the world cannot equal in	216.59754151562402
horror?”	357.4520773055833
“You are deceived, madame,” said Felton, blushing; “Lord de Winter is	298.0176517769861
not capable of such a crime.”	166.19180241975937
“Good,” said Milady to herself; “without thinking what it is, he calls	183.8942115758519
it a crime!” Then aloud, “The friend of that wretch is capable of	280.3928413295825
everything.”	333.4126569459068
“Whom do you call _that wretch?_” asked Felton.	172.76512364618213
“Are there, then, in England two men to whom such an epithet can be	167.10222370790848
applied?”	210.77095180995403
“You mean George Villiers?” asked Felton, whose looks became excited.	363.5121704207131
“Whom Pagans and unbelieving Gentiles call Duke of Buckingham,” replied	287.238425435439
Milady. “I could not have thought that there was an Englishman in all	285.20202575933155
England who would have required so long an explanation to make him	281.81603741092965
understand of whom I was speaking.”	341.19159046370544
“The hand of the Lord is stretched over him,” said Felton; “he will not	254.37441853028506
escape the chastisement he deserves.”	172.75935443275966
Felton only expressed, with regard to the duke, the feeling of	229.00212913896254
execration which all the English had declared toward him whom the	211.550612623983
Catholics themselves called the extortioner, the pillager, the	194.0098804904328
debauchee, and whom the Puritans styled simply Satan.	206.91591630429852
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Milady; “when I supplicate thee to pour	207.69374413519517
upon this man the chastisement which is his due, thou knowest it is not	344.51508100517947
my own vengeance I pursue, but the deliverance of a whole nation that I	285.40176723786135
implore!”	208.56718978752977
“Do you know him, then?” asked Felton.	219.79097524560146
“At length he interrogates me!” said Milady to herself, at the height	242.96353909396782
of joy at having obtained so quickly such a great result. “Oh, know	223.82533632094885
him? Yes, yes! to my misfortune, to my eternal misfortune!” and Milady	260.42547203041534
twisted her arms as if in a paroxysm of grief.	228.083645537907
Felton no doubt felt within himself that his strength was abandoning	292.5969979546824
him, and he made several steps toward the door; but the prisoner, whose	336.0233283080378
eye never left him, sprang in pursuit of him and stopped him.	279.65526263588043
“Sir,” cried she, “be kind, be clement, listen to my prayer! That	268.7868740734258
knife, which the fatal prudence of the baron deprived me of, because he	166.76879781682518
knows the use I would make of it! Oh, hear me to the end! that knife,	172.8579939840501
give it to me for a minute only, for mercy’s, for pity’s sake! I will	356.733186679647
embrace your knees! You shall shut the door that you may be certain I	270.34551087795836
contemplate no injury to you! My God! to you—the only just, good, and	190.115604110589
compassionate being I have met with! To you—my preserver, perhaps! One	198.81067453933395
minute that knife, one minute, a single minute, and I will restore it	346.26592005732476
to you through the grating of the door. Only one minute, Mr. Felton,	241.16307491164633
and you will have saved my honor!”	291.94448220414995
“To kill yourself?” cried Felton, with terror, forgetting to withdraw	306.1091813912111
his hands from the hands of the prisoner, “to kill yourself?”	171.25021952587602
“I have told, sir,” murmured Milady, lowering her voice, and allowing	248.30265596164878
herself to sink overpowered to the ground; “I have told my secret! He	201.70879293405545
knows all! My God, I am lost!”	259.3951158290464
Felton remained standing, motionless and undecided.	247.98768142189863
“He still doubts,” thought Milady; “I have not been earnest enough.”	217.74245466823174
Someone was heard in the corridor; Milady recognized the step of Lord	229.77288202864835
de Winter.	360.9002709541101
Felton recognized it also, and made a step toward the door.	217.13684067278757
Milady sprang toward him. “Oh, not a word,” said she in a concentrated	179.88770038034244
voice, “not a word of all that I have said to you to this man, or I am	234.0054599908633
lost, and it would be you—you—”	311.9124778601421
Then as the steps drew near, she became silent for fear of being heard,	264.98990718675793
applying, with a gesture of infinite terror, her beautiful hand to	352.5212992021834
Felton’s mouth.	359.9636791766519
Felton gently repulsed Milady, and she sank into a chair.	258.2229310819781
Lord de Winter passed before the door without stopping, and they heard	240.2368783958398
the noise of his footsteps soon die away.	357.11969695295164
Felton, as pale as death, remained some instants with his ear bent and	241.75845602154055
listening; then, when the sound was quite extinct, he breathed like a	303.41945896367105
man awaking from a dream, and rushed out of the apartment.	225.20971054072837
“Ah!” said Milady, listening in her turn to the noise of Felton’s	302.0492223089399
steps, which withdrew in a direction opposite to those of Lord de	365.65444744249055
Winter; “at length you are mine!”	200.6742356087904
Then her brow darkened. “If he tells the baron,” said she, “I am	303.2592454375956
lost—for the baron, who knows very well that I shall not kill myself,	235.77537042290612
will place me before him with a knife in my hand, and he will discover	254.06933316590926
that all this despair is but acted.”	363.230307235381
She placed herself before the glass, and regarded herself attentively;	245.05373606609749
never had she appeared more beautiful.	347.28941905718364
“Oh, yes,” said she, smiling, “but we won’t tell him!”	240.16095671228354
In the evening Lord de Winter accompanied the supper.	349.18793398102827
“Sir,” said Milady, “is your presence an indispensable accessory of my	285.4480858010492
captivity? Could you not spare me the increase of torture which your	357.0504415863942
visits cause me?”	232.48140042240692
“How, dear sister!” said Lord de Winter. “Did not you sentimentally	173.30396516890724
inform me with that pretty mouth of yours, so cruel to me today, that	169.96869312647402
you came to England solely for the pleasure of seeing me at your ease,	257.533515554386
an enjoyment of which you told me you so sensibly felt the deprivation	335.4764360829028
that you had risked everything for it—seasickness, tempest, captivity?	248.1966585347027
Well, here I am; be satisfied. Besides, this time, my visit has a	225.3832290921736
motive.”	172.90411878994576
Milady trembled; she thought Felton had told all. Perhaps never in her	255.45432305204736
life had this woman, who had experienced so many opposite and powerful	199.7350146630598
emotions, felt her heart beat so violently.	292.7075324194335
She was seated. Lord de Winter took a chair, drew it toward her, and	270.12461622566866
sat down close beside her. Then taking a paper out of his pocket, he	296.43842003584996
unfolded it slowly.	183.29740695530683
“Here,” said he, “I want to show you the kind of passport which I have	356.97440654878346
drawn up, and which will serve you henceforward as the rule of order in	338.0926356219495
the life I consent to leave you.”	301.18264814416216
Then turning his eyes from Milady to the paper, he read: “‘Order to	190.3224184210735
