conduct—’ The name is blank,” interrupted Lord de Winter. “If you have	305.2126439862167
any preference you can point it out to me; and if it be not within a	325.8564762344988
thousand leagues of London, attention will be paid to your wishes. I	211.85962860996347
will begin again, then:	190.66573259856705
“‘Order to conduct to—the person named Charlotte Backson, branded by	203.44463226500716
the justice of the kingdom of France, but liberated after chastisement.	312.6075096787682
She is to dwell in this place without ever going more than three	232.5652097700133
leagues from it. In case of any attempt to escape, the penalty of death	253.96073786708087
is to be applied. She will receive five shillings per day for lodging	248.8919115309552
and food’”.	274.37878420021497
“That order does not concern me,” replied Milady, coldly, “since it	202.91338876914529
bears another name than mine.”	204.81851739916922
“A name? Have you a name, then?”	285.6726196930354
“I bear that of your brother.”	167.89727266190226
“Ay, but you are mistaken. My brother is only your second husband; and	322.59934779565924
your first is still living. Tell me his name, and I will put it in the	274.005502609754
place of the name of Charlotte Backson. No? You will not? You are	299.65026490249534
silent? Well, then you must be registered as Charlotte Backson.”	300.77984873288443
Milady remained silent; only this time it was no longer from	242.20216709449596
affectation, but from terror. She believed the order ready for	213.41936024487399
execution. She thought that Lord de Winter had hastened her departure;	211.23111162543026
she thought she was condemned to set off that very evening. Everything	239.26133590079607
in her mind was lost for an instant; when all at once she perceived	331.01489782890087
that no signature was attached to the order. The joy she felt at this	272.23399725778654
discovery was so great she could not conceal it.	323.93281874442323
“Yes, yes,” said Lord de Winter, who perceived what was passing in her	202.79672663617293
mind; “yes, you look for the signature, and you say to yourself: ‘All	266.7822448415552
is not lost, for that order is not signed. It is only shown to me to	350.37446633087995
terrify me, that’s all.’ You are mistaken. Tomorrow this order will be	226.38763871520655
sent to the Duke of Buckingham. The day after tomorrow it will return	334.7196808785222
signed by his hand and marked with his seal; and four-and-twenty hours	237.06475194892482
afterward I will answer for its being carried into execution. Adieu,	228.94199225103762
madame. That is all I had to say to you.”	208.0122675978384
“And I reply to you, sir, that this abuse of power, this exile under a	329.13434856922856
fictitious name, are infamous!”	237.12234165447111
“Would you like better to be hanged in your true name, Milady? You know	222.54383063925604
that the English laws are inexorable on the abuse of marriage. Speak	238.55186706136823
freely. Although my name, or rather that of my brother, would be mixed	343.21072511253885
up with the affair, I will risk the scandal of a public trial to make	209.31045984145837
myself certain of getting rid of you.”	218.8743467375873
Milady made no reply, but became as pale as a corpse.	341.9496239164046
“Oh, I see you prefer peregrination. That’s well madame; and there is	302.91646402112997
an old proverb that says, ‘Traveling trains youth.’ My faith! you are	197.82586171170988
not wrong after all, and life is sweet. That’s the reason why I take	360.59277142110255
such care you shall not deprive me of mine. There only remains, then,	326.47679388166847
the question of the five shillings to be settled. You think me rather	265.47148464673876
parsimonious, don’t you? That’s because I don’t care to leave you the	322.77456892633415
means of corrupting your jailers. Besides, you will always have your	311.97454608746693
charms left to seduce them with. Employ them, if your check with regard	330.1096514056098
to Felton has not disgusted you with attempts of that kind.”	171.37052229151266
“Felton has not told him,” said Milady to herself. “Nothing is lost,	308.2921156532045
then.”	179.16996997813948
“And now, madame, till I see you again! Tomorrow I will come and	362.22963448022415
announce to you the departure of my messenger.”	359.2258360910266
Lord de Winter rose, saluted her ironically, and went out.	251.9861247583603
Milady breathed again. She had still four days before her. Four days	193.02821482696544
would quite suffice to complete the seduction of Felton.	270.2825885382815
A terrible idea, however, rushed into her mind. She thought that Lord	319.18225420140504
de Winter would perhaps send Felton himself to get the order signed by	254.1299653809798
the Duke of Buckingham. In that case Felton would escape her—for in	189.54280582235043
order to secure success, the magic of a continuous seduction was	288.3243377494722
necessary. Nevertheless, as we have said, one circumstance reassured	297.4198706645063
her. Felton had not spoken.	255.21538970747338
As she would not appear to be agitated by the threats of Lord de	295.4130540917404
Winter, she placed herself at the table and ate.	236.5928781546889
Then, as she had done the evening before, she fell on her knees and	269.2528496926443
repeated her prayers aloud. As on the evening before, the soldier	259.85530924752345
stopped his march to listen to her.	325.82718429254317
Soon after she heard lighter steps than those of the sentinel, which	326.2000368817619
came from the end of the corridor and stopped before her door.	249.64956568941972
“It is he,” said she. And she began the same religious chant which had	173.9608770728455
so strongly excited Felton the evening before.	191.28572467997165
But although her voice—sweet, full, and sonorous—vibrated as	341.6718535018869
harmoniously and as affectingly as ever, the door remained shut. It	246.63999276049833
appeared however to Milady that in one of the furtive glances she	300.64342572854883
darted from time to time at the grating of the door she thought she saw	276.48860606237565
the ardent eyes of the young man through the narrow opening. But	322.32340500378945
whether this was reality or vision, he had this time sufficient	283.1998590018909
self-command not to enter.	266.0944912953878
However, a few instants after she had finished her religious song,	245.53379397174086
Milady thought she heard a profound sigh. Then the same steps she had	197.91887049447436
heard approach slowly withdrew, as if with regret.	295.6615210656661
Chapter LV.	276.44590342555114
CAPTIVITY: THE FOURTH DAY	248.33223760237388
The next day, when Felton entered Milady’s apartment he found her	240.15736842456917
standing, mounted upon a chair, holding in her hands a cord made by	346.7247003462947
means of torn cambric handkerchiefs, twisted into a kind of rope one	338.73336004770374
with another, and tied at the ends. At the noise Felton made in	233.24593713602314
entering, Milady leaped lightly to the ground, and tried to conceal	264.2608609144828
behind her the improvised cord she held in her hand.	241.94093511950388
The young man was more pale than usual, and his eyes, reddened by want	248.66198462339526
of sleep, denoted that he had passed a feverish night. Nevertheless,	285.72448712136304
his brow was armed with a severity more austere than ever.	197.0241117304195
He advanced slowly toward Milady, who had seated herself, and taking an	226.87974937728356
end of the murderous rope which by neglect, or perhaps by design, she	300.02012301930955
allowed to be seen, “What is this, madame?” he asked coldly.	186.3323911663726
“That? Nothing,” said Milady, smiling with that painful expression	222.89284801435605
which she knew so well how to give to her smile. “Ennui is the mortal	183.6870368288752
enemy of prisoners; I had ennui, and I amused myself with twisting that	258.65105199836137
rope.”	349.6011977488679
Felton turned his eyes toward the part of the wall of the apartment	328.6439148040671
before which he had found Milady standing in the armchair in which she	279.2616685512949
was now seated, and over her head he perceived a gilt-headed screw,	288.60058335871855
fixed in the wall for the purpose of hanging up clothes or weapons.	268.95235504086753
He started, and the prisoner saw that start—for though her eyes were	237.94005430158805
cast down, nothing escaped her.	319.1288549357257
“What were you doing on that armchair?” asked he.	320.8495653575129
“Of what consequence?” replied Milady.	267.7994933295781
“But,” replied Felton, “I wish to know.”	212.85510536050828
“Do not question me,” said the prisoner; “you know that we who are true	352.9501257263544
Christians are forbidden to lie.”	198.7854557110603
“Well, then,” said Felton, “I will tell you what you were doing, or	251.9496106260296
rather what you meant to do; you were going to complete the fatal	243.34669840194897
project you cherish in your mind. Remember, madame, if our God forbids	244.36406314615664
falsehood, he much more severely condemns suicide.”	255.61431527330785
“When God sees one of his creatures persecuted unjustly, placed between	186.54857553125632
suicide and dishonor, believe me, sir,” replied Milady, in a tone of	196.9144673664954
deep conviction, “God pardons suicide, for then suicide becomes	278.23472682496003
martyrdom.”	358.6429935579654
“You say either too much or too little; speak, madame. In the name of	340.75246915064895
heaven, explain yourself.”	178.85413411312558
“That I may relate my misfortunes for you to treat them as fables; that	237.7241195690503
I may tell you my projects for you to go and betray them to my	344.6277314354243
persecutor? No, sir. Besides, of what importance to you is the life or	279.2767576583792
death of a condemned wretch? You are only responsible for my body, is	177.7215337071752
it not so? And provided you produce a carcass that may be recognized as	247.89630691939385
mine, they will require no more of you; nay, perhaps you will even have	214.47945542890693
a double reward.”	221.27113819006698
“I, madame, I?” cried Felton. “You suppose that I would ever accept the	357.90390081638657
price of your life? Oh, you cannot believe what you say!”	281.47176627426325
“Let me act as I please, Felton, let me act as I please,” said Milady,	364.26275537539004
elated. “Every soldier must be ambitious, must he not? You are a	278.4387645235584
lieutenant? Well, you will follow me to the grave with the rank of	357.1518809795029
captain.”	324.1919049191249
“What have I, then, done to you,” said Felton, much agitated, “that you	304.4578853605236
should load me with such a responsibility before God and before men? In	195.87636050581432
a few days you will be away from this place; your life, madame, will	247.7489374178274
then no longer be under my care, and,” added he, with a sigh, “then you	259.06309578816365
can do what you will with it.”	272.0262065641592
“So,” cried Milady, as if she could not resist giving utterance to a	188.66203991393036
holy indignation, “you, a pious man, you who are called a just man, you	210.657037021048
ask but one thing—and that is that you may not be inculpated, annoyed,	243.4939503691014
by my death!”	287.8793044366401
“It is my duty to watch over your life, madame, and I will watch.”	326.9612338670206
“But do you understand the mission you are fulfilling? Cruel enough, if	245.7919946107914
I am guilty; but what name can you give it, what name will the Lord	245.48902936750505
give it, if I am innocent?”	234.57215357454663
“I am a soldier, madame, and fulfill the orders I have received.”	278.8517201584185
“Do you believe, then, that at the day of the Last Judgment God will	258.4001289329552
separate blind executioners from iniquitous judges? You are not willing	316.4088791893299
that I should kill my body, and you make yourself the agent of him who	211.57890967159236
would kill my soul.”	167.7436551604967
“But I repeat it again to you,” replied Felton, in great emotion, “no	307.9341882691051
danger threatens you; I will answer for Lord de Winter as for myself.”	245.5588045961467
“Dunce,” cried Milady, “dunce! who dares to answer for another man,	288.93815117924197
when the wisest, when those most after God’s own heart, hesitate to	246.44182055484515
answer for themselves, and who ranges himself on the side of the	239.606891435206
strongest and the most fortunate, to crush the weakest and the most	323.5661095479305
unfortunate.”	266.144106260222
“Impossible, madame, impossible,” murmured Felton, who felt to the	181.4180533867951
bottom of his heart the justness of this argument. “A prisoner, you	172.72634416026153
will not recover your liberty through me; living, you will not lose	212.1744583577129
your life through me.”	288.7684215642714
“Yes,” cried Milady, “but I shall lose that which is much dearer to me	347.6255971872457
than life, I shall lose my honor, Felton; and it is you, you whom I	264.35315989803235
make responsible, before God and before men, for my shame and my	170.50226508608074
infamy.”	266.5286483635149
This time Felton, immovable as he was, or appeared to be, could not	273.02112111479096
resist the secret influence which had already taken possession of him.	329.8914864223011
To see this woman, so beautiful, fair as the brightest vision, to see	338.53117877440235
her by turns overcome with grief and threatening; to resist at once the	355.2312965418544
ascendancy of grief and beauty—it was too much for a visionary; it was	243.47614532055374
too much for a brain weakened by the ardent dreams of an ecstatic	329.9859535057658
faith; it was too much for a heart furrowed by the love of heaven that	188.6513501242963
burns, by the hatred of men that devours.	197.73826874534325
Milady saw the trouble. She felt by intuition the flame of the opposing	256.30128756335193
passions which burned with the blood in the veins of the young fanatic.	309.67499644460736
As a skillful general, seeing the enemy ready to surrender, marches	276.8933737602242
toward him with a cry of victory, she rose, beautiful as an antique	216.1302066699736
priestess, inspired like a Christian virgin, her arms extended, her	239.6146220924435
throat uncovered, her hair disheveled, holding with one hand her robe	307.36226192273614
modestly drawn over her breast, her look illumined by that fire which	266.61752548821687
had already created such disorder in the veins of the young Puritan,	314.8622079473722
and went toward him, crying out with a vehement air, and in her	273.1098911208796
melodious voice, to which on this occasion she communicated a terrible	195.99030965311377
energy:	186.1413595694801
“Let this victim to Baal be sent,	187.52318922346015
    To the lions the martyr be thrown!	263.649526410922
Thy God shall teach thee to repent!	339.4396825082605
    From th’ abyss he’ll give ear to my moan.”	281.421278983669
Felton stood before this strange apparition like one petrified.	354.569142690246
“Who art thou? Who art thou?” cried he, clasping his hands. “Art thou a	215.61187362658399
messenger from God; art thou a minister from hell; art thou an angel or	352.18046774919844
a demon; callest thou thyself Eloa or Astarte?”	245.35316143102213
“Do you not know me, Felton? I am neither an angel nor a demon; I am a	320.12129126860225
daughter of earth, I am a sister of thy faith, that is all.”	232.9379974981279
“Yes, yes!” said Felton, “I doubted, but now I believe.”	277.7329569236081
“You believe, and still you are an accomplice of that child of Belial	190.33795789173686
who is called Lord de Winter! You believe, and yet you leave me in the	357.3327727591168
hands of mine enemies, of the enemy of England, of the enemy of God!	345.11465632613204
You believe, and yet you deliver me up to him who fills and defiles the	348.1063953358179
world with his heresies and debaucheries—to that infamous Sardanapalus	307.40727229369463
whom the blind call the Duke of Buckingham, and whom believers name	245.40372649860984
Antichrist!”	219.1376639499045
“I deliver you up to Buckingham? I? what mean you by that?”	362.3991091656535
“They have eyes,” cried Milady, “but they see not; ears have they, but	178.64309396034497
they hear not.”	318.31935320843326
“Yes, yes!” said Felton, passing his hands over his brow, covered with	225.00931614066062
sweat, as if to remove his last doubt. “Yes, I recognize the voice	191.5132683496703
which speaks to me in my dreams; yes, I recognize the features of the	345.43726429181476
angel who appears to me every night, crying to my soul, which cannot	251.41498422595112
sleep: ‘Strike, save England, save thyself—for thou wilt die without	308.04680070976264
having appeased God!’ Speak, speak!” cried Felton, “I can understand	302.33997927199425
you now.”	301.1371778024396
A flash of terrible joy, but rapid as thought, gleamed from the eyes of	203.3610224333281
Milady.	355.8295999765504
However fugitive this homicide flash, Felton saw it, and started as if	226.00187371872744
its light had revealed the abysses of this woman’s heart. He recalled,	326.2559681623632
all at once, the warnings of Lord de Winter, the seductions of Milady,	364.54453710614473
her first attempts after her arrival. He drew back a step, and hung	326.3377617740128
down his head, without, however, ceasing to look at her, as if,	202.5625427388114
fascinated by this strange creature, he could not detach his eyes from	190.27296208326575
her eyes.	207.6910718287726
Milady was not a woman to misunderstand the meaning of this hesitation.	355.3626583903635
Under her apparent emotions her icy coolness never abandoned her.	343.6370210296109
Before Felton replied, and before she should be forced to resume this	339.51477220901336
conversation, so difficult to be sustained in the same exalted tone,	247.71615254522982
she let her hands fall; and as if the weakness of the woman overpowered	214.71298578684468
the enthusiasm of the inspired fanatic, she said: “But no, it is not	332.5272514227554
for me to be the Judith to deliver Bethulia from this Holofernes. The	218.77203538578465
sword of the eternal is too heavy for my arm. Allow me, then, to avoid	198.5156268415695
dishonor by death; let me take refuge in martyrdom. I do not ask you	176.95342505194103
for liberty, as a guilty one would, nor for vengeance, as would a	364.75734709730284
pagan. Let me die; that is all. I supplicate you, I implore you on my	270.66942639316403
knees—let me die, and my last sigh shall be a blessing for my	282.0672287911846
preserver.”	279.05180020135526
Hearing that voice, so sweet and suppliant, seeing that look, so timid	319.6310913143086
and downcast, Felton reproached himself. By degrees the enchantress had	185.86453628805
clothed herself with that magic adornment which she assumed and threw	311.5433353521832
aside at will; that is to say, beauty, meekness, and tears—and above	206.31803055840987
all, the irresistible attraction of mystical voluptuousness, the most	233.65396312761
devouring of all voluptuousness.	352.2218752296686
“Alas!” said Felton, “I can do but one thing, which is to pity you if	323.63188569847387
you prove to me you are a victim! But Lord de Winter makes cruel	289.4599954103442
accusations against you. You are a Christian; you are my sister in	319.51360472198445
religion. I feel myself drawn toward you—I, who have never loved anyone	212.21069217792729
but my benefactor—I who have met with nothing but traitors and impious	170.92558257137787
men. But you, madame, so beautiful in reality, you, so pure in	304.3974680686089
appearance, must have committed great iniquities for Lord de Winter to	238.2843252339095
pursue you thus.”	288.3377563898994
“They have eyes,” repeated Milady, with an accent of indescribable	280.675339442004
grief, “but they see not; ears have they, but they hear not.”	325.9066680380024
“But,” cried the young officer, “speak, then, speak!”	264.8130258003408
“Confide my shame to you,” cried Milady, with the blush of modesty upon	316.2213508559606
her countenance, “for often the crime of one becomes the shame of	352.65152478628636
another—confide my shame to you, a man, and I a woman? Oh,” continued	175.281494118236
she, placing her hand modestly over her beautiful eyes, “never!	180.32741074341112
never!—I could not!”	354.764082951927
“To me, to a brother?” said Felton.	283.54148769525574
Milady looked at him for some time with an expression which the young	270.7328620488992
man took for doubt, but which, however, was nothing but observation, or	293.01246147042644
rather the wish to fascinate.	186.24871129366102
Felton, in his turn a suppliant, clasped his hands.	239.60504375011942
“Well, then,” said Milady, “I confide in my brother; I will dare to—”	309.5742262015991
At this moment the steps of Lord de Winter were heard; but this time	206.0070821989529
the terrible brother-in-law of Milady did not content himself, as on	248.15973682174248
the preceding day, with passing before the door and going away again.	341.82894919543776
He paused, exchanged two words with the sentinel; then the door opened,	300.8100845154096
and he appeared.	268.0137922332774
During the exchange of these two words Felton drew back quickly, and	223.7374963297572
when Lord de Winter entered, he was several paces from the prisoner.	317.6476554910108
The baron entered slowly, sending a scrutinizing glance from Milady to	217.073098033148
the young officer.	283.1913171592012
“You have been here a very long time, John,” said he. “Has this woman	292.10500637138233
been relating her crimes to you? In that case I can comprehend the	329.6037126944991
length of the conversation.”	338.9169860646671
Felton started; and Milady felt she was lost if she did not come to the	303.52645361760904
assistance of the disconcerted Puritan.	170.01225744779526
“Ah, you fear your prisoner should escape!” said she. “Well, ask your	324.0827720276441
worthy jailer what favor I this instant solicited of him.”	291.9373356625053
“You demanded a favor?” said the baron, suspiciously.	255.78455416952028
“Yes, my Lord,” replied the young man, confused.	205.54345410845497
“And what favor, pray?” asked Lord de Winter.	334.3760587613288
“A knife, which she would return to me through the grating of the door	294.8569490251898
a minute after she had received it,” replied Felton.	170.57924421904713
“There is someone, then, concealed here whose throat this amiable lady	290.7199930839756
is desirous of cutting,” said de Winter, in an ironical, contemptuous	225.03507632480253
tone.	278.299652563577
“There is myself,” replied Milady.	172.78965115527356
“I have given you the choice between America and Tyburn,” replied Lord	245.74166314006197
de Winter. “Choose Tyburn, madame. Believe me, the cord is more certain	365.292688778964
than the knife.”	363.68649947128006
Felton grew pale, and made a step forward, remembering that at the	238.11925755430224
moment he entered Milady had a rope in her hand.	244.0450965980118
“You are right,” said she, “I have often thought of it.” Then she added	331.29324452407445
in a low voice, “And I will think of it again.”	214.56411487190485
Felton felt a shudder run to the marrow of his bones; probably Lord de	199.1672008025232
Winter perceived this emotion.	331.96970530339934
“Mistrust yourself, John,” said he. “I have placed reliance upon you,	345.8615172114377
my friend. Beware! I have warned you! But be of good courage, my lad;	171.03186382655767
in three days we shall be delivered from this creature, and where I	239.92824676416421
shall send her she can harm nobody.”	172.20315462386668
“You hear him!” cried Milady, with vehemence, so that the baron might	169.13850448649146
believe she was addressing heaven, and that Felton might understand she	193.27755010167576
was addressing him.	243.81713573719486
Felton lowered his head and reflected.	250.04562526935584
The baron took the young officer by the arm, and turned his head over	254.48442221669103
his shoulder, so as not to lose sight of Milady till he was gone out.	276.0471635507122
“Well,” said the prisoner, when the door was shut, “I am not so far	320.2510323658654
advanced as I believed. De Winter has changed his usual stupidity into	268.56624819276954
a strange prudence. It is the desire of vengeance, and how desire molds	215.86766764467274
a man! As to Felton, he hesitates. Ah, he is not a man like that cursed	305.148658711484
D’Artagnan. A Puritan only adores virgins, and he adores them by	214.13051691581768
clasping his hands. A Musketeer loves women, and he loves them by	251.6494586853895
clasping his arms round them.”	193.60316927203215
Milady waited, then, with much impatience, for she feared the day would	191.4834255179549
pass away without her seeing Felton again. At last, in an hour after	223.6615601307246
the scene we have just described, she heard someone speaking in a low	296.7185428834472
voice at the door. Presently the door opened, and she perceived Felton.	225.5227820933822
The young man advanced rapidly into the chamber, leaving the door open	331.0134849182366
behind him, and making a sign to Milady to be silent; his face was much	211.07786368373263
agitated.	168.12566225962297
“What do you want with me?” said she.	198.63616055606556
“Listen,” replied Felton, in a low voice. “I have just sent away the	313.0862047032161
sentinel that I might remain here without anybody knowing it, in order	301.83070767104107
to speak to you without being overheard. The baron has just related a	182.54005814418122
frightful story to me.”	262.89390658216894
Milady assumed her smile of a resigned victim, and shook her head.	167.7674260607207
“Either you are a demon,” continued Felton, “or the baron—my	204.23699183476268
benefactor, my father—is a monster. I have known you four days; I have	256.2008610936297
loved him four years. I therefore may hesitate between you. Be not	203.14719666158746
alarmed at what I say; I want to be convinced. Tonight, after twelve, I	214.18064681421063
will come and see you, and you shall convince me.”	225.9482730050125
“No, Felton, no, my brother,” said she; “the sacrifice is too great,	218.734460006963
and I feel what it must cost you. No, I am lost; do not be lost with	320.3585879672206
me. My death will be much more eloquent than my life, and the silence	333.2030992319728
of the corpse will convince you much better than the words of the	171.35578952622942
prisoner.”	331.1771401912191
“Be silent, madame,” cried Felton, “and do not speak to me thus; I came	262.0374744388396
to entreat you to promise me upon your honor, to swear to me by what	262.3890308009457
you hold most sacred, that you will make no attempt upon your life.”	245.3215686438994
“I will not promise,” said Milady, “for no one has more respect for a	204.4645860024686
promise or an oath than I have; and if I make a promise I must keep	246.54923988010967
it.”	294.82651652088407
“Well,” said Felton, “only promise till you have seen me again. If,	167.34794087390972
when you have seen me again, you still persist—well, then you shall be	222.67505129127835
free, and I myself will give you the weapon you desire.”	339.6223657620924
“Well,” said Milady, “for you I will wait.”	347.7786694805095
“Swear.”	343.6251087444833
“I swear it, by our God. Are you satisfied?”	237.76054419952757
“Well,” said Felton, “till tonight.”	194.36242918023464
And he darted out of the room, shut the door, and waited in the	282.4845749478176
corridor, the soldier’s half-pike in his hand, and as if he had mounted	349.0925672865993
guard in his place.	309.17805419767564
The soldier returned, and Felton gave him back his weapon.	285.05661041351243
Then, through the grating to which she had drawn near, Milady saw the	200.06078631352648
young man make a sign with delirious fervor, and depart in an apparent	355.21102542580115
transport of joy.	296.05595088224106
As for her, she returned to her place with a smile of savage contempt	355.454124078207
upon her lips, and repeated, blaspheming, that terrible name of God, by	181.41756990902607
whom she had just sworn without ever having learned to know Him.	304.6861082051697
“My God,” said she, “what a senseless fanatic! My God, it is I—I—and	264.22370732944785
this fellow who will help me to avenge myself.”	250.22167394356134
Chapter LVI.	302.85788753017175
CAPTIVITY: THE FIFTH DAY	213.85018656302768
Milady had however achieved a half-triumph, and success doubled her	317.9383262653856
forces.	355.33602069699236
It was not difficult to conquer, as she had hitherto done, men prompt	362.35910619662405
to let themselves be seduced, and whom the gallant education of a court	234.95037041670994
led quickly into her net. Milady was handsome enough not to find much	295.91517564927733
resistance on the part of the flesh, and she was sufficiently skillful	297.02976828309875
to prevail over all the obstacles of the mind.	175.1220809329513
But this time she had to contend with an unpolished nature,	208.0669588062397
concentrated and insensible by force of austerity. Religion and its	174.7287364172376
observances had made Felton a man inaccessible to ordinary seductions.	343.08813445968246
There fermented in that sublimated brain plans so vast, projects so	231.95718734569624
tumultuous, that there remained no room for any capricious or material	302.76474564144894
love—that sentiment which is fed by leisure and grows with corruption.	230.1959574973381
Milady had, then, made a breach by her false virtue in the opinion of a	231.31968461991158
man horribly prejudiced against her, and by her beauty in the heart of	326.094286229552
a man hitherto chaste and pure. In short, she had taken the measure of	213.8447333967451
motives hitherto unknown to herself, through this experiment, made upon	316.4020354723781
the most rebellious subject that nature and religion could submit to	281.5998901271173
her study.	297.4758297316683
Many a time, nevertheless, during the evening she despaired of fate and	343.3942196031128
of herself. She did not invoke God, we very well know, but she had	177.2764089912684
faith in the genius of evil—that immense sovereignty which reigns in	261.2313321826738
all the details of human life, and by which, as in the Arabian fable, a	334.40605965769083
single pomegranate seed is sufficient to reconstruct a ruined world.	232.91986885005002
Milady, being well prepared for the reception of Felton, was able to	349.35375814110375
erect her batteries for the next day. She knew she had only two days	267.41610060778004
left; that when once the order was signed by Buckingham—and Buckingham	182.02588944661127
would sign it the more readily from its bearing a false name, and he	293.44946881362114
could not, therefore, recognize the woman in question—once this order	302.0091021669397
was signed, we say, the baron would make her embark immediately, and	213.0640495266731
she knew very well that women condemned to exile employ arms much less	237.12922763679046
powerful in their seductions than the pretendedly virtuous woman whose	362.59209927998916
beauty is lighted by the sun of the world, whose style the voice of	254.45588813746102
fashion lauds, and whom a halo of aristocracy gilds with enchanting	174.98537492195774
splendors. To be a woman condemned to a painful and disgraceful	178.0621241800062
punishment is no impediment to beauty, but it is an obstacle to the	324.60949969287134
recovery of power. Like all persons of real genius, Milady knew what	357.68361736092027
suited her nature and her means. Poverty was repugnant to her;	200.29244720890387
degradation took away two-thirds of her greatness. Milady was only a	183.6129351129883
queen while among queens. The pleasure of satisfied pride was necessary	236.77906455380258
to her domination. To command inferior beings was rather a humiliation	326.36366554280943
than a pleasure for her.	292.4358551695406
She should certainly return from her exile—she did not doubt that a	256.65789366965055
single instant; but how long might this exile last? For an active,	167.46982924339213
ambitious nature, like that of Milady, days not spent in climbing are	284.0364438249116
inauspicious days. What word, then, can be found to describe the days	347.87054204317786
which they occupy in descending? To lose a year, two years, three	315.3385921768624
years, is to talk of an eternity; to return after the death or disgrace	360.315426384684
of the cardinal, perhaps; to return when D’Artagnan and his friends,	224.32704944900127
happy and triumphant, should have received from the queen the reward	318.25839065048234
they had well acquired by the services they had rendered her—these were	330.35117495174984
devouring ideas that a woman like Milady could not endure. For the	252.98051100336272
rest, the storm which raged within her doubled her strength, and she	255.90388682851275
would have burst the walls of her prison if her body had been able to	235.13822390890772
take for a single instant the proportions of her mind.	282.60112865255303
Then that which spurred her on additionally in the midst of all this	349.49910948994204
was the remembrance of the cardinal. What must the mistrustful,	282.16379234485595
restless, suspicious cardinal think of her silence—the cardinal, not	260.1821665993746
merely her only support, her only prop, her only protector at present,	315.92572123774937
but still further, the principal instrument of her future fortune and	243.8067724322344
vengeance? She knew him; she knew that at her return from a fruitless	353.62435807970047
journey it would be in vain to tell him of her imprisonment, in vain to	298.4115181339116
enlarge upon the sufferings she had undergone. The cardinal would	204.73389379414152
reply, with the sarcastic calmness of the skeptic, strong at once by	185.15588526860108
power and genius, “You should not have allowed yourself to be taken.”	226.0267545497668
Then Milady collected all her energies, murmuring in the depths of her	342.0280535759766
soul the name of Felton—the only beam of light that penetrated to her	172.24666817251182
in the hell into which she had fallen; and like a serpent which folds	277.56252836575186
and unfolds its rings to ascertain its strength, she enveloped Felton	338.09288579491
beforehand in the thousand meshes of her inventive imagination.	330.0159730389395
Time, however, passed away; the hours, one after another, seemed to	323.52463783210845
awaken the clock as they passed, and every blow of the brass hammer	332.54893390809684
resounded upon the heart of the prisoner. At nine o’clock, Lord de	167.14794797446345
Winter made his customary visit, examined the window and the bars,	287.0792491724146
sounded the floor and the walls, looked to the chimney and the doors,	325.26446186007536
without, during this long and minute examination, he or Milady	347.1531623976294
pronouncing a single word.	237.10542744563276
Doubtless both of them understood that the situation had become too	232.2045239127754
serious to lose time in useless words and aimless wrath.	249.33424730253245
“Well,” said the baron, on leaving her “you will not escape tonight!”	251.42110381145451
At ten o’clock Felton came and placed the sentinel. Milady recognized	207.58970650049733
his step. She was as well acquainted with it now as a mistress is with	214.47537598674577
that of the lover of her heart; and yet Milady at the same time	362.1238096044142
detested and despised this weak fanatic.	215.80608041121587
That was not the appointed hour. Felton did not enter.	333.17808037929024
Two hours after, as midnight sounded, the sentinel was relieved. This	185.34353356180617
time it _was_ the hour, and from this moment Milady waited with	265.58887152632724
impatience. The new sentinel commenced his walk in the corridor. At the	280.16221511697404
expiration of ten minutes Felton came.	302.3022554362834
Milady was all attention.	265.74408091514834
“Listen,” said the young man to the sentinel. “On no pretense leave the	291.8886119045722
door, for you know that last night my Lord punished a soldier for	261.23198794117155
having quit his post for an instant, although I, during his absence,	271.52796622840947
watched in his place.”	169.97901754322922
“Yes, I know it,” said the soldier.	360.9461487655568
“I recommend you therefore to keep the strictest watch. For my part I	227.89422614002993
am going to pay a second visit to this woman, who I fear entertains	250.17343559336962
sinister intentions upon her own life, and I have received orders to	339.91001759046964
watch her.”	256.73231133100063
“Good!” murmured Milady; “the austere Puritan lies.”	192.85396924650584
As to the soldier, he only smiled.	179.16566980974105
“Zounds, Lieutenant!” said he; “you are not unlucky in being charged	315.41128684671844
with such commissions, particularly if my Lord has authorized you to	348.3251783199944
look into her bed.”	278.97833105982465
Felton blushed. Under any other circumstances he would have reprimanded	186.95505388758534
the soldier for indulging in such pleasantry, but his conscience	201.72497365263794
murmured too loud for his mouth to dare speak.	291.7701242746249
“If I call, come,” said he. “If anyone comes, call me.”	218.04429697534914
“I will, Lieutenant,” said the soldier.	340.9276090312127
Felton entered Milady’s apartment. Milady arose.	340.4698147886545
“You are here!” said she.	262.6033322966731
“I promised to come,” said Felton, “and I have come.”	348.48203893658564
“You promised me something else.”	330.60887489506746
“What, my God!” said the young man, who in spite of his self-command	229.9537041959414
felt his knees tremble and the sweat start from his brow.	228.7252058654068
“You promised to bring a knife, and to leave it with me after our	344.5075979271795
interview.”	195.3924299855342
“Say no more of that, madame,” said Felton. “There is no situation,	257.5761332027591
however terrible it may be, which can authorize a creature of God to	301.202302938495
inflict death upon himself. I have reflected, and I cannot, must not be	288.362622704206
guilty of such a sin.”	363.38715120330744
“Ah, you have reflected!” said the prisoner, sitting down in her	209.92534508223468
armchair, with a smile of disdain; “and I also have reflected.”	205.32087085834286
“Upon what?”	205.18906328450083
“That I can have nothing to say to a man who does not keep his word.”	208.37817687399618
“Oh, my God!” murmured Felton.	343.8832637502293
“You may retire,” said Milady. “I will not talk.”	322.6220096634745
“Here is the knife,” said Felton, drawing from his pocket the weapon	245.48486951922567
which he had brought, according to his promise, but which he hesitated	168.46171460959056
to give to his prisoner.	258.928259392319
“Let me see it,” said Milady.	217.51589457419777
“For what purpose?”	256.273708980847
“Upon my honor, I will instantly return it to you. You shall place it	281.96844156850807
on that table, and you may remain between it and me.”	198.9624342504955
Felton offered the weapon to Milady, who examined the temper of it	180.40976600061228
attentively, and who tried the point on the tip of her finger.	243.86958044168705
“Well,” said she, returning the knife to the young officer, “this is	302.1646269525992
fine and good steel. You are a faithful friend, Felton.”	242.1039434470841
Felton took back the weapon, and laid it upon the table, as he had	303.92895887344935
agreed with the prisoner.	183.2305190537044
Milady followed him with her eyes, and made a gesture of satisfaction.	305.09985355501436
“Now,” said she, “listen to me.”	292.8395217256099
The request was needless. The young officer stood upright before her,	307.4301168411949
awaiting her words as if to devour them.	297.97500956325143
“Felton,” said Milady, with a solemnity full of melancholy, “imagine	171.97179965393138
that your sister, the daughter of your father, speaks to you. While yet	246.67407580285155
young, unfortunately handsome, I was dragged into a snare. I resisted.	338.6280254198265
Ambushes and violences multiplied around me, but I resisted. The	191.17568671506868
religion I serve, the God I adore, were blasphemed because I called	282.05813915233466
upon that religion and that God, but still I resisted. Then outrages	325.28212697230435
were heaped upon me, and as my soul was not subdued they wished to	201.94654983252235
defile my body forever. Finally—”	321.5113819123016
Milady stopped, and a bitter smile passed over her lips.	252.25801374636004
“Finally,” said Felton, “finally, what did they do?”	200.52577962282155
“At length, one evening my enemy resolved to paralyze the resistance he	284.00113138202425
could not conquer. One evening he mixed a powerful narcotic with my	330.52411904256985
water. Scarcely had I finished my repast, when I felt myself sink by	243.79634125287205
degrees into a strange torpor. Although I was without mistrust, a vague	351.22040277764756
fear seized me, and I tried to struggle against sleepiness. I arose. I	264.91228424980704
wished to run to the window and call for help, but my legs refused	309.02958100268165
their office. It appeared as if the ceiling sank upon my head and	273.52276232389517
crushed me with its weight. I stretched out my arms. I tried to speak.	180.3966042274875
I could only utter inarticulate sounds, and irresistible faintness came	259.0204498797497
over me. I supported myself by a chair, feeling that I was about to	277.0886972125484
fall, but this support was soon insufficient on account of my weak	224.11237550437346
arms. I fell upon one knee, then upon both. I tried to pray, but my	230.89014048277974
tongue was frozen. God doubtless neither heard nor saw me, and I sank	171.05060412408326
upon the floor a prey to a slumber which resembled death.	244.5212702934798
“Of all that passed in that sleep, or the time which glided away while	167.7018128781542
it lasted, I have no remembrance. The only thing I recollect is that I	322.60685200805193
awoke in bed in a round chamber, the furniture of which was sumptuous,	270.77655440501917
and into which light only penetrated by an opening in the ceiling. No	248.13409742819232
door gave entrance to the room. It might be called a magnificent	296.81659945349804
prison.	364.1467463744917
“It was a long time before I was able to make out what place I was in,	341.89207195855704
or to take account of the details I describe. My mind appeared to	239.47000018303265
strive in vain to shake off the heavy darkness of the sleep from which	303.62159948181215
I could not rouse myself. I had vague perceptions of space traversed,	283.91500865706894
of the rolling of a carriage, of a horrible dream in which my strength	251.37653728567574
had become exhausted; but all this was so dark and so indistinct in my	307.4853754887226
mind that these events seemed to belong to another life than mine, and	222.24063213472425
yet mixed with mine in fantastic duality.	339.237014899108
“At times the state into which I had fallen appeared so strange that I	281.2251557029171
believed myself dreaming. I arose trembling. My clothes were near me on	242.96773309758404
a chair; I neither remembered having undressed myself nor going to bed.	191.91860150804627
Then by degrees the reality broke upon me, full of chaste terrors. I	353.77555291400995
was no longer in the house where I had dwelt. As well as I could judge	270.2862423773744
by the light of the sun, the day was already two-thirds gone. It was	299.77990720203786
the evening before when I had fallen asleep; my sleep, then, must have	191.69268441613852
lasted twenty-four hours! What had taken place during this long sleep?	349.54749992082264
“I dressed myself as quickly as possible; my slow and stiff motions all	185.22529368841592
attested that the effects of the narcotic were not yet entirely	269.590555906674
dissipated. The chamber was evidently furnished for the reception of a	258.982241931236
woman; and the most finished coquette could not have formed a wish, but	333.8557232746352
on casting her eyes about the apartment, she would have found that wish	350.7566408345526
accomplished.	341.29345853428475
“Certainly I was not the first captive that had been shut up in this	340.51941634071534
splendid prison; but you may easily comprehend, Felton, that the more	181.5713724338709
superb the prison, the greater was my terror.	320.5937904360495
“Yes, it was a prison, for I tried in vain to get out of it. I sounded	312.4708972021504
all the walls, in the hopes of discovering a door, but everywhere the	254.63006833235085
walls returned a full and flat sound.	363.03423237794823
“I made the tour of the room at least twenty times, in search of an	347.78354101591276
outlet of some kind; but there was none. I sank exhausted with fatigue	251.91934437203997
and terror into an armchair.	319.4336113437124
“Meantime, night came on rapidly, and with night my terrors increased.	293.79437088518523
I did not know but I had better remain where I was seated. It appeared	179.25293947366123
that I was surrounded with unknown dangers into which I was about to	346.3940452079574
fall at every instant. Although I had eaten nothing since the evening	336.35849039715345
before, my fears prevented my feeling hunger.	298.2109141586908
“No noise from without by which I could measure the time reached me; I	364.0431695387016
only supposed it must be seven or eight o’clock in the evening, for it	281.4357143124363
was in the month of October and it was quite dark.	303.5212039296922
“All at once the noise of a door, turning on its hinges, made me start.	284.4586858538918
A globe of fire appeared above the glazed opening of the ceiling,	249.38343783489867
casting a strong light into my chamber; and I perceived with terror	280.29567491870273
that a man was standing within a few paces of me.	341.95867533554735
“A table, with two covers, bearing a supper ready prepared, stood, as	338.6573175482106
if by magic, in the middle of the apartment.	298.5994328467155
“That man was he who had pursued me during a whole year, who had vowed	290.02176601109596
my dishonor, and who, by the first words that issued from his mouth,	300.4033703935755
gave me to understand he had accomplished it the preceding night.”	210.41949744660502
“Scoundrel!” murmured Felton.	235.62809879474818
“Oh, yes, scoundrel!” cried Milady, seeing the interest which the young	237.3894716721174
officer, whose soul seemed to hang on her lips, took in this strange	192.17329697759274
recital. “Oh, yes, scoundrel! He believed, having triumphed over me in	200.84576513260103
my sleep, that all was completed. He came, hoping that I would accept	193.75692767740887
my shame, as my shame was consummated; he came to offer his fortune in	210.11991914240852
exchange for my love.	193.54744789353504
“All that the heart of a woman could contain of haughty contempt and	224.40772674732872
disdainful words, I poured out upon this man. Doubtless he was	185.59511092719669
accustomed to such reproaches, for he listened to me calm and smiling,	334.26375507745956
with his arms crossed over his breast. Then, when he thought I had said	358.7221692910782
all, he advanced toward me; I sprang toward the table, I seized a	261.3950834719792
knife, I placed it to my breast.	340.8754794978489
“Take one step more,” said I, “and in addition to my dishonor, you	200.7221926696976
shall have my death to reproach yourself with.”	273.203311485021
“There was, no doubt, in my look, my voice, my whole person, that	353.13368583340355
sincerity of gesture, of attitude, of accent, which carries conviction	193.91323069675255
to the most perverse minds, for he paused.	172.23211633700384
“‘Your death?’ said he; ‘oh, no, you are too charming a mistress to	240.36158024279712
allow me to consent to lose you thus, after I have had the happiness to	203.0347307125278
possess you only a single time. Adieu, my charmer; I will wait to pay	207.83210753802894
you my next visit till you are in a better humor.’	365.7514370219958
“At these words he blew a whistle; the globe of fire which lighted the	344.3830315561836
room reascended and disappeared. I found myself again in complete	365.5115251167123
darkness. The same noise of a door opening and shutting was repeated	325.19691729948386
the instant afterward; the flaming globe descended afresh, and I was	213.9507725806389
completely alone.	310.6863293489255
“This moment was frightful; if I had any doubts as to my misfortune,	282.16695120005136
these doubts had vanished in an overwhelming reality. I was in the	365.53081574813245
power of a man whom I not only detested, but despised—of a man capable	267.07690638804485
of anything, and who had already given me a fatal proof of what he was	205.4675565417893
able to do.”	208.0945647820886
“But who, then, was this man?” asked Felton.	319.7946255532735
“I passed the night on a chair, starting at the least noise, for toward	223.5167581444361
midnight the lamp went out, and I was again in darkness. But the night	255.80589574350472
passed away without any fresh attempt on the part of my persecutor. Day	182.3843844327056
came; the table had disappeared, only I had still the knife in my hand.	183.02787499289752
“This knife was my only hope.	286.7388204917603
“I was worn out with fatigue. Sleeplessness inflamed my eyes; I had not	316.42085528445386
dared to sleep a single instant. The light of day reassured me; I went	194.2573471993862
and threw myself on the bed, without parting with the emancipating	244.2407525048476
knife, which I concealed under my pillow.	209.55561986550688
“When I awoke, a fresh meal was served.	167.42663270952445
“This time, in spite of my terrors, in spite of my agony, I began to	196.62615077446526
feel a devouring hunger. It was forty-eight hours since I had taken any	251.39323556700992
nourishment. I ate some bread and some fruit; then, remembering the	224.89102132815856
narcotic mixed with the water I had drunk, I would not touch that which	302.22127787879805
was placed on the table, but filled my glass at a marble fountain fixed	190.0535347591029
in the wall over my dressing table.	203.36092337108713
“And yet, notwithstanding these precautions, I remained for some time	250.32613664508716
in a terrible agitation of mind. But my fears were this time	266.1636409953519
ill-founded; I passed the day without experiencing anything of the kind	276.55787624340394
I dreaded.	217.23243653837775
“I took the precaution to half empty the _carafe_, in order that my	341.9049559779362
suspicions might not be noticed.	207.39417210666937
“The evening came on, and with it darkness; but however profound was	287.540442317166
this darkness, my eyes began to accustom themselves to it. I saw, amid	324.2219921772368
the shadows, the table sink through the floor; a quarter of an hour	176.1569803566318
later it reappeared, bearing my supper. In an instant, thanks to the	353.09965081183395
lamp, my chamber was once more lighted.	192.4506440737341
“I was determined to eat only such things as could not possibly have	361.60693979592384
anything soporific introduced into them. Two eggs and some fruit	169.43879834495868
composed my repast; then I drew another glass of water from my	300.50989876739436
protecting fountain, and drank it.	326.25194786461384
“At the first swallow, it appeared to me not to have the same taste as	293.5298106889828
in the morning. Suspicion instantly seized me. I paused, but I had	178.52594014165388
already drunk half a glass.	296.47960364841333
“I threw the rest away with horror, and waited, with the dew of fear	356.89695682762795
upon my brow.	198.11263568148684
“No doubt some invisible witness had seen me draw the water from that	189.62874278474087
fountain, and had taken advantage of my confidence in it, the better to	345.47798061462237
assure my ruin, so coolly resolved upon, so cruelly pursued.	321.16893632965116
“Half an hour had not passed when the same symptoms began to appear;	287.0293641239456
but as I had only drunk half a glass of the water, I contended longer,	295.8094716549059
and instead of falling entirely asleep, I sank into a state of	257.6177581387781
drowsiness which left me a perception of what was passing around me,	323.27499807179663
while depriving me of the strength either to defend myself or to fly.	350.1257496434305
“I dragged myself toward the bed, to seek the only defense I had	337.2445012306952
left—my saving knife; but I could not reach the bolster. I sank on my	340.7302432926982
knees, my hands clasped round one of the bedposts; then I felt that I	241.2738865769463
was lost.”	289.20880270667976
Felton became frightfully pale, and a convulsive tremor crept through	175.2611276884764
his whole body.	338.3919647926122
“And what was most frightful,” continued Milady, her voice altered, as	346.88570264721585
if she still experienced the same agony as at that awful minute, “was	295.1402262145085
that at this time I retained a consciousness of the danger that	347.23024050392394
threatened me; was that my soul, if I may say so, waked in my sleeping	206.16390411902276
body; was that I saw, that I heard. It is true that all was like a	236.65053961429072
dream, but it was not the less frightful.	352.2918987213051
“I saw the lamp ascend, and leave me in darkness; then I heard the	311.17436506596016
well-known creaking of the door although I had heard that door open but	185.20269887460648
twice.	329.42963896682716
“I felt instinctively that someone approached me; it is said that the	228.81389893990456
doomed wretch in the deserts of America thus feels the approach of the	279.4817950905899
serpent.	302.3053439928974
“I wished to make an effort; I attempted to cry out. By an incredible	323.61036675334674
effort of will I even raised myself up, but only to sink down again	205.6981210059846
immediately, and to fall into the arms of my persecutor.”	238.1379177112167
“Tell me who this man was!” cried the young officer.	263.34812514856975
Milady saw at a single glance all the painful feelings she inspired in	334.67494297261317
Felton by dwelling on every detail of her recital; but she would not	172.50612224439683
spare him a single pang. The more profoundly she wounded his heart, the	235.2291678133125
more certainly he would avenge her. She continued, then, as if she had	183.23724595413194
not heard his exclamation, or as if she thought the moment was not yet	168.75544507754398
come to reply to it.	178.11632165544077
“Only this time it was no longer an inert body, without feeling, that	186.36326615951768
the villain had to deal with. I have told you that without being able	352.96819280373256
to regain the complete exercise of my faculties, I retained the sense	344.3536846797077
of my danger. I struggled, then, with all my strength, and doubtless	313.93060638554635
opposed, weak as I was, a long resistance, for I heard him cry out,	230.06059081655962
‘These miserable Puritans! I knew very well that they tired out their	263.59104250018635
executioners, but I did not believe them so strong against their	229.26403524543116
lovers!’	249.11582509789747
“Alas! this desperate resistance could not last long. I felt my	303.23692651251355
strength fail, and this time it was not my sleep that enabled the	265.4920374089679
coward to prevail, but my swoon.”	291.2112348012839
Felton listened without uttering any word or sound, except an inward	273.8130836238647
expression of agony. The sweat streamed down his marble forehead, and	239.19534141946107
his hand, under his coat, tore his breast.	217.25252091196487
“My first impulse, on coming to myself, was to feel under my pillow for	290.9124052106824
the knife I had not been able to reach; if it had not been useful for	331.9938962723639
defense, it might at least serve for expiation.	273.76543454346483
“But on taking this knife, Felton, a terrible idea occurred to me. I	177.76117790577766
have sworn to tell you all, and I will tell you all. I have promised	289.06367780995157
you the truth; I will tell it, were it to destroy me.”	349.2285786102098
“The idea came into your mind to avenge yourself on this man, did it	231.33566357836074
not?” cried Felton.	234.15339581202355
“Yes,” said Milady. “The idea was not that of a Christian, I knew; but	300.02348841373845
without doubt, that eternal enemy of our souls, that lion roaring	352.0638168033716
constantly around us, breathed it into my mind. In short, what shall I	357.07839356282176
say to you, Felton?” continued Milady, in the tone of a woman accusing	231.07967925537235
herself of a crime. “This idea occurred to me, and did not leave me; it	194.52383029832276
is of this homicidal thought that I now bear the punishment.”	240.5503913182414
“Continue, continue!” said Felton; “I am eager to see you attain your	242.4674893426698
vengeance!”	205.3623610521004
“Oh, I resolved that it should take place as soon as possible. I had no	191.32242460365913
doubt he would return the following night. During the day I had nothing	360.78009425692545
to fear.	307.6511002137049
“When the hour of breakfast came, therefore, I did not hesitate to eat	349.5606420034574
and drink. I had determined to make believe sup, but to eat nothing. I	280.6167808863319
was forced, then, to combat the fast of the evening with the	201.41975782163843
nourishment of the morning.	290.71844146704166
“Only I concealed a glass of water, which remained after my breakfast,	336.48341982530457
thirst having been the chief of my sufferings when I remained	264.62683232246866
forty-eight hours without eating or drinking.	265.32742798111923
“The day passed away without having any other influence on me than to	221.14284710507673
strengthen the resolution I had formed; only I took care that my face	339.0248159719341
should not betray the thoughts of my heart, for I had no doubt I was	315.8365441779319
watched. Several times, even, I felt a smile on my lips. Felton, I dare	214.24092749881248
not tell you at what idea I smiled; you would hold me in horror—”	171.62019259717272
“Go on! go on!” said Felton; “you see plainly that I listen, and that I	176.85576902147136
am anxious to know the end.”	174.35384788750116
“Evening came; the ordinary events took place. During the darkness, as	333.8824280774784
before, my supper was brought. Then the lamp was lighted, and I sat	252.59858456501328
down to table. I only ate some fruit. I pretended to pour out water	294.36165712361395
from the jug, but I only drank that which I had saved in my glass. The	314.14880845875234
substitution was made so carefully that my spies, if I had any, could	344.3491298703009
have no suspicion of it.	255.12023853656433
“After supper I exhibited the same marks of languor as on the preceding	290.71829278216705
evening; but this time, as I yielded to fatigue, or as if I had become	184.48783576858924
familiarized with danger, I dragged myself toward my bed, let my robe	264.665674568482
fall, and lay down.	222.3351513994461
“I found my knife where I had placed it, under my pillow, and while	269.3973606818756
feigning to sleep, my hand grasped the handle of it convulsively.	231.86018560680685
“Two hours passed away without anything fresh happening. Oh, my God!	281.2502031714182
who could have said so the evening before? I began to fear that he	174.8241653045652
would not come.	240.82104594629567
“At length I saw the lamp rise softly, and disappear in the depths of	177.33358196759622
the ceiling; my chamber was filled with darkness and obscurity, but I	315.51544931670816
made a strong effort to penetrate this darkness and obscurity.	183.66917396796146
“Nearly ten minutes passed; I heard no other noise but the beating of	210.06740563713439
my own heart. I implored heaven that he might come.	347.8182965784516
“At length I heard the well-known noise of the door, which opened and	205.72487574303761
shut; I heard, notwithstanding the thickness of the carpet, a step	352.94903439179245
which made the floor creak; I saw, notwithstanding the darkness, a	194.55978810753876
shadow which approached my bed.”	188.4866214018628
“Haste! haste!” said Felton; “do you not see that each of your words	217.09295027905608
burns me like molten lead?”	208.90392938525602
“Then,” continued Milady, “then I collected all my strength; I recalled	344.38965969300006
to my mind that the moment of vengeance, or rather, of justice, had	309.5787588392896
struck. I looked upon myself as another Judith; I gathered myself up,	243.73704690968805
my knife in my hand, and when I saw him near me, stretching out his	177.56253343164758
arms to find his victim, then, with the last cry of agony and despair,	335.618496071007
I struck him in the middle of his breast.	196.14447800299945
“The miserable villain! He had foreseen all. His breast was covered	266.9805673340521
with a coat-of-mail; the knife was bent against it.	243.8878694667726
“‘Ah, ah!’ cried he, seizing my arm, and wresting from me the weapon	202.74915221560138
that had so badly served me, ‘you want to take my life, do you, my	193.34163389248118
pretty Puritan? But that’s more than dislike, that’s ingratitude! Come,	273.35487657155204
come, calm yourself, my sweet girl! I thought you had softened. I am	259.8695129505853
not one of those tyrants who detain women by force. You don’t love me.	331.8832314066566
With my usual fatuity I doubted it; now I am convinced. Tomorrow you	275.52386469017597
shall be free.’	353.51327845606255
“I had but one wish; that was that he should kill me.	226.8938459517465
“‘Beware!’ said I, ‘for my liberty is your dishonor.’	335.8894029553326
“‘Explain yourself, my pretty sibyl!’	238.9994383916958
“‘Yes; for as soon as I leave this place I will tell everything. I will	285.05611237523976
proclaim the violence you have used toward me. I will describe my	259.71773102973907
captivity. I will denounce this place of infamy. You are placed on	197.68853164575438
high, my Lord, but tremble! Above you there is the king; above the king	259.50955164444906
there is God!’	243.69699876774317
“However perfect master he was over himself, my persecutor allowed a	321.5413659901237
movement of anger to escape him. I could not see the expression of his	336.0936923635654
countenance, but I felt the arm tremble upon which my hand was placed.	326.43828989438134
“‘Then you shall not leave this place,’ said he.	293.63714587576175
“‘Very well,’ cried I, ‘then the place of my punishment will be that of	198.14583576690313
my tomb. I will die here, and you will see if a phantom that accuses is	305.21016654565165
not more terrible than a living being that threatens!’	288.0430240247641
“‘You shall have no weapon left in your power.’	238.94910274907718
“‘There is a weapon which despair has placed within the reach of every	267.37769464303824
creature who has the courage to use it. I will allow myself to die with	342.7024930961079
hunger.’	222.92374944801614
“‘Come,’ said the wretch, ‘is not peace much better than such a war as	204.2444171535377
that? I will restore you to liberty this moment; I will proclaim you a	347.2117321052237
piece of immaculate virtue; I will name you the Lucretia of England.’	311.66616401279936
“‘And I will say that you are the Sextus. I will denounce you before	178.90117652850836
men, as I have denounced you before God; and if it be necessary that,	240.1521878342542
like Lucretia, I should sign my accusation with my blood, I will sign	202.8083650767723
it.’	262.41312046865085
“‘Ah!’ said my enemy, in a jeering tone, ‘that’s quite another thing.	306.14969568991216
My faith! everything considered, you are very well off here. You shall	233.2540641327895
want for nothing, and if you let yourself die of hunger that will be	325.79925277296286
your own fault.’	353.6592646446069
“At these words he retired. I heard the door open and shut, and I	178.87447065776
remained overwhelmed, less, I confess it, by my grief than by the	277.70120900330346
mortification of not having avenged myself.	316.0801456382328
“He kept his word. All the day, all the next night passed away without	279.0549980627711
my seeing him again. But I also kept my word with him, and I neither	305.8038985650031
ate nor drank. I was, as I told him, resolved to die of hunger.	335.2365611907836
“I passed the day and the night in prayer, for I hoped that God would	285.93805085736227
pardon me my suicide.	273.48867744848144
“The second night the door opened; I was lying on the floor, for my	200.4558657335485
strength began to abandon me.	229.09895118289785
“At the noise I raised myself up on one hand.	241.01818369546953
“‘Well,’ said a voice which vibrated in too terrible a manner in my ear	253.48233390813425
not to be recognized, ‘well! Are we softened a little? Will we not pay	246.54773806400533
for our liberty with a single promise of silence? Come, I am a good	196.93794215842144
sort of a prince,’ added he, ‘and although I like not Puritans I do	298.74820911997153
them justice; and it is the same with Puritanesses, when they are	355.4170868066449
pretty. Come, take a little oath for me on the cross; I won’t ask	287.2514579935207
anything more of you.’	210.75663696069444
“‘On the cross,’ cried I, rising, for at that abhorred voice I had	239.98342053548754
recovered all my strength, ‘on the cross I swear that no promise, no	363.95959418316863
menace, no force, no torture, shall close my mouth! On the cross I	281.3226548389668
swear to denounce you everywhere as a murderer, as a thief of honor, as	365.99172897215203
a base coward! On the cross I swear, if I ever leave this place, to	329.1261394962279
call down vengeance upon you from the whole human race!’	340.86879526765347
“‘Beware!’ said the voice, in a threatening accent that I had never yet	347.3583661210174
heard. ‘I have an extraordinary means which I will not employ but in	326.62222687799556
the last extremity to close your mouth, or at least to prevent anyone	224.05992579763654
from believing a word you may utter.’	358.0798950520851
“I mustered all my strength to reply to him with a burst of laughter.	281.929136936706
“He saw that it was a merciless war between us—a war to the death.	290.74202406564154
“‘Listen!’ said he. ‘I give you the rest of tonight and all day	271.9574424336061
tomorrow. Reflect: promise to be silent, and riches, consideration,	294.9187992468103
even honor, shall surround you; threaten to speak, and I will condemn	312.2135377404294
you to infamy.’	215.2649429153941
“‘You?’ cried I. ‘You?’	292.98198903653235
“‘To interminable, ineffaceable infamy!’	354.650466849239
“‘You?’ repeated I. Oh, I declare to you, Felton, I thought him mad!	355.1644997377354
“‘Yes, yes, I!’ replied he.	341.5766669108699
“‘Oh, leave me!’ said I. ‘Begone, if you do not desire to see me dash	315.166701205363
my head against that wall before your eyes!’	231.8316194014772
“‘Very well, it is your own doing. Till tomorrow evening, then!’	243.10555143539756
“‘Till tomorrow evening, then!’ replied I, allowing myself to fall, and	174.3447610404726
biting the carpet with rage.”	246.99309656048433
Felton leaned for support upon a piece of furniture; and Milady saw,	351.3523595980651
with the joy of a demon, that his strength would fail him perhaps	264.31143912293214
before the end of her recital.	337.7156386729729
Chapter LVII.	230.90545836376515
MEANS FOR CLASSICAL TRAGEDY	285.93357810155095
After a moment of silence employed by Milady in observing the young man	282.4883768338781
who listened to her, Milady continued her recital.	327.1768767743604
“It was nearly three days since I had eaten or drunk anything. I	312.0651559386637
suffered frightful torments. At times there passed before me clouds	318.4491196625663
which pressed my brow, which veiled my eyes; this was delirium.	336.81182295146397
“When the evening came I was so weak that every time I fainted I	363.21281571195857
thanked God, for I thought I was about to die.	245.69118110596088
“In the midst of one of these swoons I heard the door open. Terror	286.5253275938678
recalled me to myself.	353.04585797280106
“He entered the apartment followed by a man in a mask. He was masked	235.0115342738273
likewise; but I knew his step, I knew his voice, I knew him by that	252.8043167208066
imposing bearing which hell has bestowed upon his person for the curse	208.5107633729167
of humanity.	323.7780522131429
“‘Well,’ said he to me, ‘have you made your mind up to take the oath I	223.5277225192077
requested of you?’	281.3578399932412
“‘You have said Puritans have but one word. Mine you have heard, and	230.133340296467
that is to pursue you—on earth to the tribunal of men, in heaven to the	225.18812004345241
tribunal of God.’	285.0793300626601
“‘You persist, then?’	319.1779518864032
“‘I swear it before the God who hears me. I will take the whole world	232.57898501566697
as a witness of your crime, and that until I have found an avenger.’	224.25068371938949
“‘You are a prostitute,’ said he, in a voice of thunder, ‘and you shall	339.3911326432403
undergo the punishment of prostitutes! Branded in the eyes of the world	267.04327828526226
you invoke, try to prove to that world that you are neither guilty nor	236.91753572822552
mad!’	282.0552428236382
“Then, addressing the man who accompanied him, ‘Executioner,’ said he,	199.42787746888155
‘do your duty.’”	183.14685453222756
“Oh, his name, his name!” cried Felton. “His name, tell it me!”	298.43764409775196
“Then in spite of my cries, in spite of my resistance—for I began to	289.20395941686957
comprehend that there was a question of something worse than death—the	244.78414060198259
executioner seized me, threw me on the floor, fastened me with his	254.95295793561877
bonds, and suffocated by sobs, almost without sense, invoking God, who	332.9990455354564
did not listen to me, I uttered all at once a frightful cry of pain and	206.37099446628577
shame. A burning fire, a red-hot iron, the iron of the executioner, was	344.84447005142624
imprinted on my shoulder.”	207.76329376582368
Felton uttered a groan.	344.31619994140783
“Here,” said Milady, rising with the majesty of a queen, “here, Felton,	227.21002594021488
behold the new martyrdom invented for a pure young girl, the victim of	250.65036459817443
the brutality of a villain. Learn to know the heart of men, and	277.98715947295807
henceforth make yourself less easily the instrument of their unjust	357.4209266449375
vengeance.”	198.21972575694326
Milady, with a rapid gesture, opened her robe, tore the cambric that	302.9841172179739
covered her bosom, and red with feigned anger and simulated shame,	312.8635558353359
showed the young man the ineffaceable impression which dishonored that	320.63979027380054
beautiful shoulder.	327.441029538255
“But,” cried Felton, “that is a _fleur-de-lis_ which I see there.”	245.00222774415693
“And therein consisted the infamy,” replied Milady. “The brand of	328.318770801898
England!—it would be necessary to prove what tribunal had imposed it on	304.64922868889755
me, and I could have made a public appeal to all the tribunals of the	195.46894251264044
kingdom; but the brand of France!—oh, by that, by _that_ I was branded	313.1276287158662
indeed!”	229.57776899368582
This was too much for Felton.	287.16385827136315
Pale, motionless, overwhelmed by this frightful revelation, dazzled by	363.4766309095495
the superhuman beauty of this woman who unveiled herself before him	334.26476690741134
with an immodesty which appeared to him sublime, he ended by falling on	230.6367257307134
his knees before her as the early Christians did before those pure and	273.75832580981324
holy martyrs whom the persecution of the emperors gave up in the circus	182.87111220526342
to the sanguinary sensuality of the populace. The brand disappeared;	358.9862338433097
the beauty alone remained.	242.0061015211595
“Pardon! Pardon!” cried Felton, “oh, pardon!”	230.88562507868704
Milady read in his eyes _love! love!_	273.77502875656614
“Pardon for what?” asked she.	180.32015508746122
“Pardon me for having joined with your persecutors.”	272.33264437937214
Milady held out her hand to him.	190.15043033992984
“So beautiful! so young!” cried Felton, covering that hand with his	199.68059999214313
kisses.	297.55674451505695
Milady let one of those looks fall upon him which make a slave of a	227.9517950641233
king.	206.60313462477885
Felton was a Puritan; he abandoned the hand of this woman to kiss her	219.65356633617588
feet.	326.72487583241514
He no longer loved her; he adored her.	236.90184122932808
When this crisis was past, when Milady appeared to have resumed her	349.70610366433084
self-possession, which she had never lost; when Felton had seen her	181.23301680240533
recover with the veil of chastity those treasures of love which were	218.060824871699
only concealed from him to make him desire them the more ardently, he	196.45893086993237
said, “Ah, now! I have only one thing to ask of you; that is, the name	181.46791912820666
of your true executioner. For to me there is but one; the other was an	354.5868469646748
instrument, that was all.”	190.52279559854503
“What, brother!” cried Milady, “must I name him again? Have you not yet	332.9080124484705
divined who he is?”	200.17499742024694
“What?” cried Felton, “he—again he—always he? What—the truly guilty?”	346.09492976167786
“The truly guilty,” said Milady, “is the ravager of England, the	280.48193452667823
persecutor of true believers, the base ravisher of the honor of so many	260.8239865442576
women—he who, to satisfy a caprice of his corrupt heart, is about to	196.62952529480603
make England shed so much blood, who protects the Protestants today and	345.5442398844605
will betray them tomorrow—”	336.29682321286606
“Buckingham! It is, then, Buckingham!” cried Felton, in a high state of	301.8347285602775
excitement.	333.15789776247516
Milady concealed her face in her hands, as if she could not endure the	237.93730263300085
shame which this name recalled to her.	313.87438559339625
“Buckingham, the executioner of this angelic creature!” cried Felton.	320.59706767544617
“And thou hast not hurled thy thunder at him, my God! And thou hast	230.62539317453178
left him noble, honored, powerful, for the ruin of us all!”	194.04300526603038
“God abandons him who abandons himself,” said Milady.	230.75560180327466
“But he will draw upon his head the punishment reserved for the	293.90828285731055
damned!” said Felton, with increasing exultation. “He wills that human	271.41431627658216
vengeance should precede celestial justice.”	327.4389206827298
“Men fear him and spare him.”	221.7476452709421
“I,” said Felton, “I do not fear him, nor will I spare him.”	288.94878074555794
The soul of Milady was bathed in an infernal joy.	167.46816686761179
“But how can Lord de Winter, my protector, my father,” asked Felton,	192.32779001656547
“possibly be mixed up with all this?”	258.0823075180548
“Listen, Felton,” resumed Milady, “for by the side of base and	365.9649314701715
contemptible men there are often found great and generous natures. I	277.7777531882724
had an affianced husband, a man whom I loved, and who loved me—a heart	304.9559724103596
like yours, Felton, a man like you. I went to him and told him all; he	278.46839450081035
knew me, that man did, and did not doubt an instant. He was a nobleman,	280.59670083804684
a man equal to Buckingham in every respect. He said nothing; he only	353.57275932213525
girded on his sword, wrapped himself in his cloak, and went straight to	275.6963236160867
Buckingham Palace.	186.17352005342207
“Yes, yes,” said Felton; “I understand how he would act. But with such	336.57455942736146
men it is not the sword that should be employed; it is the poniard.”	188.30605275035722
“Buckingham had left England the day before, sent as ambassador to	302.3331241088092
Spain, to demand the hand of the Infanta for King Charles I., who was	255.78925133665524
then only Prince of Wales. My affianced husband returned.	306.02218686105925
“‘Hear me,’ said he; ‘this man has gone, and for the moment has	296.9548284867995
consequently escaped my vengeance; but let us be united, as we were to	335.17359696424023
have been, and then leave it to Lord de Winter to maintain his own	245.7463185830942
honor and that of his wife.’”	206.76661615182795
“Lord de Winter!” cried Felton.	190.58818353092406
“Yes,” said Milady, “Lord de Winter; and now you can understand it all,	189.86043759481785
can you not? Buckingham remained nearly a year absent. A week before	270.92640339743957
his return Lord de Winter died, leaving me his sole heir. Whence came	280.6755047207173
the blow? God who knows all, knows without doubt; but as for me, I	197.9880384074892
accuse nobody.”	335.75700190215184
“Oh, what an abyss; what an abyss!” cried Felton.	335.3070756783957
“Lord de Winter died without revealing anything to his brother. The	322.5173809071654
terrible secret was to be concealed till it burst, like a clap of	233.74178437461177
thunder, over the head of the guilty. Your protector had seen with pain	355.9460679096186
this marriage of his elder brother with a portionless girl. I was	199.85894820429704
sensible that I could look for no support from a man disappointed in	312.8562336652363
his hopes of an inheritance. I went to France, with a determination to	169.25660605781843
remain there for the rest of my life. But all my fortune is in England.	179.7459297015462
Communication being closed by the war, I was in want of everything. I	217.78877750421321
was then obliged to come back again. Six days ago, I landed at	344.25115548600945
Portsmouth.”	313.8671644455598
“Well?” said Felton.	316.72494213657626
“Well; Buckingham heard by some means, no doubt, of my return. He spoke	293.7559733440277
of me to Lord de Winter, already prejudiced against me, and told him	343.7772864758949
that his sister-in-law was a prostitute, a branded woman. The noble and	355.46394064150365
pure voice of my husband was no longer here to defend me. Lord de	336.70283513506513
Winter believed all that was told him with so much the more ease that	207.82068332064432
it was his interest to believe it. He caused me to be arrested, had me	172.93621459426032
conducted hither, and placed me under your guard. You know the rest.	196.84527680509854
The day after tomorrow he banishes me, he transports me; the day after	209.9722498315317
tomorrow he exiles me among the infamous. Oh, the train is well laid;	341.39290780872875
the plot is clever. My honor will not survive it! You see, then,	299.01753385602296
Felton, I can do nothing but die. Felton, give me that knife!”	176.03126693944301
And at these words, as if all her strength was exhausted, Milady sank,	267.5487477519207
weak and languishing, into the arms of the young officer, who,	331.39574945965285
intoxicated with love, anger, and voluptuous sensations hitherto	323.78069657338693
unknown, received her with transport, pressed her against his heart,	353.25393469716687
all trembling at the breath from that charming mouth, bewildered by the	365.71547838446054
contact with that palpitating bosom.	308.627852924487
“No, no,” said he. “No, you shall live honored and pure; you shall live	308.3309458124796
to triumph over your enemies.”	338.69532838247034
Milady put him from her slowly with her hand, while drawing him nearer	272.4586859718772
with her look; but Felton, in his turn, embraced her more closely,	301.6098972964218
imploring her like a divinity.	247.68085782426567
“Oh, death, death!” said she, lowering her voice and her eyelids, “oh,	258.8586956654163
death, rather than shame! Felton, my brother, my friend, I conjure	350.95491022281635
you!”	295.69486407745467
“No,” cried Felton, “no; you shall live and you shall be avenged.”	252.60757281631714
“Felton, I bring misfortune to all who surround me! Felton, abandon me!	320.0286510259018
Felton, let me die!”	217.77265331841824
“Well, then, we will live and die together!” cried he, pressing his	327.414806431806
lips to those of the prisoner.	241.8432620989036
Several strokes resounded on the door; this time Milady really pushed	257.5836462952047
him away from her.	185.43861861998704
“Hark,” said she, “we have been overheard! Someone is coming! All is	365.8178454912078
over! We are lost!”	249.88045186483356
