“No,” said Felton; it is only the sentinel warning me that they are	330.33247687212986
about to change the guard.”	301.143806233517
“Then run to the door, and open it yourself.”	234.82780016928064
Felton obeyed; this woman was now his whole thought, his whole soul.	284.3283070295512
He found himself face to face with a sergeant commanding a	335.07734072088124
watch-patrol.	352.28058709336335
“Well, what is the matter?” asked the young lieutenant.	227.81627397757651
“You told me to open the door if I heard anyone cry out,” said the	247.25830880369304
soldier; “but you forgot to leave me the key. I heard you cry out,	358.65610256742735
without understanding what you said. I tried to open the door, but it	204.00314870587457
was locked inside; then I called the sergeant.”	210.23456652809517
“And here I am,” said the sergeant.	166.21980810063172
Felton, quite bewildered, almost mad, stood speechless.	313.4112411916227
Milady plainly perceived that it was now her turn to take part in the	188.90246453257492
scene. She ran to the table, and seizing the knife which Felton had	324.1906764192404
laid down, exclaimed, “And by what right will you prevent me from	303.0819482840283
dying?”	187.50976626379736
“Great God!” exclaimed Felton, on seeing the knife glitter in her hand.	237.70069018404857
At that moment a burst of ironical laughter resounded through the	271.1284491363448
corridor. The baron, attracted by the noise, in his chamber gown, his	215.933183811003
sword under his arm, stood in the doorway.	286.0004422303993
“Ah,” said he, “here we are, at the last act of the tragedy. You see,	231.82850439726525
Felton, the drama has gone through all the phases I named; but be easy,	287.4888838039305
no blood will flow.”	255.04693053955793
Milady perceived that all was lost unless she gave Felton an immediate	276.75688417122495
and terrible proof of her courage.	168.22604852483119
“You are mistaken, my Lord, blood will flow; and may that blood fall	296.58600204976227
back on those who cause it to flow!”	279.08409089835305
Felton uttered a cry, and rushed toward her. He was too late; Milady	313.4067689617425
had stabbed herself.	348.79008984321615
But the knife had fortunately, we ought to say skillfully, come in	327.28874124783044
contact with the steel busk, which at that period, like a cuirass,	242.97432919769568
defended the chests of women. It had glided down it, tearing the robe,	169.89450638457058
and had penetrated slantingly between the flesh and the ribs. Milady’s	333.2264680668262
robe was not the less stained with blood in a second.	215.0503776758686
Milady fell down, and seemed to be in a swoon.	196.15055618000446
Felton snatched away the knife.	324.84584039202343
“See, my Lord,” said he, in a deep, gloomy tone, “here is a woman who	221.10164212194243
was under my guard, and who has killed herself!”	254.13980344329235
“Be at ease, Felton,” said Lord de Winter. “She is not dead; demons do	179.64662915302497
not die so easily. Be tranquil, and go wait for me in my chamber.”	263.4370112003296
“But, my Lord—”	240.2861555594741
“Go, sir, I command you!”	292.4561926509873
At this injunction from his superior, Felton obeyed; but in going out,	364.1789416729281
he put the knife into his bosom.	188.7419211784095
As to Lord de Winter, he contented himself with calling the woman who	347.8332993861346
waited on Milady, and when she was come, he recommended the prisoner,	182.55863907915676
who was still fainting, to her care, and left them alone.	270.55839953172
Meanwhile, all things considered and notwithstanding his suspicions, as	348.01452626010575
the wound might be serious, he immediately sent off a mounted man to	321.4085020241859
find a physician.	274.3331622894804
Chapter LVIII.	234.94972980426587
ESCAPE	241.69825081951575
As Lord de Winter had thought, Milady’s wound was not dangerous. So	239.99630151103665
soon as she was left alone with the woman whom the baron had summoned	178.5704902175643
to her assistance she opened her eyes.	206.86264937872278
It was, however, necessary to affect weakness and pain—not a very	287.80409692175374
difficult task for so finished an actress as Milady. Thus the poor	166.97888977354728
woman was completely the dupe of the prisoner, whom, notwithstanding	319.80818059129257
her hints, she persisted in watching all night.	294.0627560603655
But the presence of this woman did not prevent Milady from thinking.	236.69067842919833
There was no longer a doubt that Felton was convinced; Felton was hers.	232.70480370672482
If an angel appeared to that young man as an accuser of Milady, he	202.79149927631371
would take him, in the mental disposition in which he now found	229.23281093021296
himself, for a messenger sent by the devil.	166.10315819730806
Milady smiled at this thought, for Felton was now her only hope—her	338.17439267231146
only means of safety.	258.003481756986
But Lord de Winter might suspect him; Felton himself might now be	252.31794316568755
watched!	319.4490593366819
Toward four o’clock in the morning the doctor arrived; but since the	205.10840512677103
time Milady stabbed herself, however short, the wound had closed. The	288.3915370087849
doctor could therefore measure neither the direction nor the depth of	247.27879753895974
it; he only satisfied himself by Milady’s pulse that the case was not	259.9731589315256
serious.	276.8882376695771
In the morning Milady, under the pretext that she had not slept well in	233.12390176763483
the night and wanted rest, sent away the woman who attended her.	260.21554098350083
She had one hope, which was that Felton would appear at the breakfast	260.0062513752863
hour; but Felton did not come.	255.60785010595555
Were her fears realized? Was Felton, suspected by the baron, about to	310.0602438555395
fail her at the decisive moment? She had only one day left. Lord de	178.64544434394338
Winter had announced her embarkation for the twenty-third, and it was	206.18710744422663
now the morning of the twenty-second.	184.09871031653879
Nevertheless she still waited patiently till the hour for dinner.	335.87487735669663
Although she had eaten nothing in the morning, the dinner was brought	228.6956633041023
in at its usual time. Milady then perceived, with terror, that the	351.7874628621147
uniform of the soldiers who guarded her was changed.	223.04984898595382
Then she ventured to ask what had become of Felton.	340.507275348618
She was told that he had left the castle an hour before on horseback.	357.3112380489083
She inquired if the baron was still at the castle. The soldier replied	200.98891735159995
that he was, and that he had given orders to be informed if the	216.9126294403102
prisoner wished to speak to him.	169.04137532870067
Milady replied that she was too weak at present, and that her only	272.3514859851699
desire was to be left alone.	195.16119511978562
The soldier went out, leaving the dinner served.	208.82006842472222
Felton was sent away. The marines were removed. Felton was then	248.1634718957356
mistrusted.	260.06100354682525
This was the last blow to the prisoner.	209.8825285240201
Left alone, she arose. The bed, which she had kept from prudence and	169.88250624328077
that they might believe her seriously wounded, burned her like a bed of	307.3268071420338
fire. She cast a glance at the door; the baron had had a plank nailed	277.19266964119066
over the grating. He no doubt feared that by this opening she might	303.2621011613728
still by some diabolical means corrupt her guards.	330.9701933178579
Milady smiled with joy. She was free now to give way to her transports	225.83297478868667
without being observed. She traversed her chamber with the excitement	211.3439697117622
of a furious maniac or of a tigress shut up in an iron cage. _Certes_,	327.770933843026
if the knife had been left in her power, she would now have thought,	182.33459396993513
not of killing herself, but of killing the baron.	331.1190635192671
At six o’clock Lord de Winter came in. He was armed at all points. This	179.989234237971
man, in whom Milady till that time had only seen a very simple	287.33653909095267
gentleman, had become an admirable jailer. He appeared to foresee all,	262.80631120924915
to divine all, to anticipate all.	353.22445595726714
A single look at Milady apprised him of all that was passing in her	207.80938323787763
mind.	198.10229384920234
“Ay!” said he, “I see; but you shall not kill me today. You have no	319.35489012796484
longer a weapon; and besides, I am on my guard. You had begun to	190.18496329106233
pervert my poor Felton. He was yielding to your infernal influence; but	249.81175563657035
I will save him. He will never see you again; all is over. Get your	318.49074972438905
clothes together. Tomorrow you will go. I had fixed the embarkation for	354.8904825416481
the twenty-fourth; but I have reflected that the more promptly the	296.75693505847113
affair takes place the more sure it will be. Tomorrow, by twelve	344.1208904492256
o’clock, I shall have the order for your exile, signed, _Buckingham_.	268.3532006045525
If you speak a single word to anyone before going aboard ship, my	173.20248412244442
sergeant will blow your brains out. He has orders to do so. If when on	323.7446099491825
the ship you speak a single word to anyone before the captain permits	275.226929189426
you, the captain will have you thrown into the sea. That is agreed	166.2020175792347
upon.	269.12789275763987
“_Au revoir_, then; that is all I have to say today. Tomorrow I will	228.2059912942986
see you again, to take my leave.” With these words the baron went out.	280.9925194922919
Milady had listened to all this menacing tirade with a smile of disdain	184.5378214232404
on her lips, but rage in her heart.	212.95144920826814
Supper was served. Milady felt that she stood in need of all her	321.0936661050493
strength. She did not know what might take place during this night	192.32975858737666
which approached so menacingly—for large masses of cloud rolled over	193.01252856481514
the face of the sky, and distant lightning announced a storm.	344.06478927903316
The storm broke about ten o’clock. Milady felt a consolation in seeing	182.63857417223738
nature partake of the disorder of her heart. The thunder growled in the	212.48837458267158
air like the passion and anger in her thoughts. It appeared to her that	192.47615127906775
the blast as it swept along disheveled her brow, as it bowed the	265.72852835350204
branches of the trees and bore away their leaves. She howled as the	181.98991871957395
hurricane howled; and her voice was lost in the great voice of nature,	167.46030640025654
which also seemed to groan with despair.	255.01957078694198
All at once she heard a tap at her window, and by the help of a flash	334.9968654908876
of lightning she saw the face of a man appear behind the bars.	173.42357577713855
She ran to the window and opened it.	190.18873512747763
“Felton!” cried she. “I am saved.”	217.038353646005
“Yes,” said Felton; “but silence, silence! I must have time to file	322.94384358575945
through these bars. Only take care that I am not seen through the	272.3571937315371
wicket.”	190.87372290280393
“Oh, it is a proof that the Lord is on our side, Felton,” replied	364.47922365286274
Milady. “They have closed up the grating with a board.”	169.33150154940907
“That is well; God has made them senseless,” said Felton.	230.2346344189875
“But what must I do?” asked Milady.	337.5954076930699
“Nothing, nothing, only shut the window. Go to bed, or at least lie	319.39631679523814
down in your clothes. As soon as I have done I will knock on one of the	167.58385336467126
panes of glass. But will you be able to follow me?”	184.78478224436745
“Oh, yes!”	232.06030092440733
“Your wound?”	286.99824932667326
“Gives me pain, but will not prevent my walking.”	185.0463421378534
“Be ready, then, at the first signal.”	225.4820774340971
Milady shut the window, extinguished the lamp, and went, as Felton had	333.86071113226177
desired her, to lie down on the bed. Amid the moaning of the storm she	233.23480149369038
heard the grinding of the file upon the bars, and by the light of every	209.98405464720804
flash she perceived the shadow of Felton through the panes.	299.90510777597365
She passed an hour without breathing, panting, with a cold sweat upon	243.79963767760154
her brow, and her heart oppressed by frightful agony at every movement	296.5920037828123
she heard in the corridor.	222.16555913815262
There are hours which last a year.	196.54216401742417
At the expiration of an hour, Felton tapped again.	339.6710327646377
Milady sprang out of bed and opened the window. Two bars removed formed	296.09421618102397
an opening for a man to pass through.	275.86919562598
“Are you ready?” asked Felton.	251.9771165855799
“Yes. Must I take anything with me?”	201.81931889762168
“Money, if you have any.”	248.6310556422917
“Yes; fortunately they have left me all I had.”	265.39881162353953
“So much the better, for I have expended all mine in chartering a	181.83219014701774
vessel.”	338.5696867316999
“Here!” said Milady, placing a bag full of louis in Felton’s hands.	240.33035171651983
Felton took the bag and threw it to the foot of the wall.	201.28124337810272
“Now,” said he, “will you come?”	361.1782716271241
“I am ready.”	181.89459606459445
Milady mounted upon a chair and passed the upper part of her body	356.74225375400874
through the window. She saw the young officer suspended over the abyss	238.8496063295823
by a ladder of ropes. For the first time an emotion of terror reminded	171.56879843862745
her that she was a woman.	261.96154147233676
The dark space frightened her.	222.68171711640355
“I expected this,” said Felton.	211.2352100752406
“It’s nothing, it’s nothing!” said Milady. “I will descend with my eyes	357.25990586181535
shut.”	348.16728578666743
“Have you confidence in me?” said Felton.	196.32481060083893
“You ask that?”	335.6981429185417
“Put your two hands together. Cross them; that’s right!”	192.5963514199842
Felton tied her two wrists together with his handkerchief, and then	217.67899410693465
with a cord over the handkerchief.	247.7394708343135
“What are you doing?” asked Milady, with surprise.	276.53103606964606
“Pass your arms around my neck, and fear nothing.”	282.1733177574166
“But I shall make you lose your balance, and we shall both be dashed to	183.11793089884316
pieces.”	358.5561043687561
“Don’t be afraid. I am a sailor.”	273.92043024491005
Not a second was to be lost. Milady passed her two arms round Felton’s	272.581841311355
neck, and let herself slip out of the window. Felton began to descend	223.23522499405823
the ladder slowly, step by step. Despite the weight of two bodies, the	326.697212105718
blast of the hurricane shook them in the air.	362.11756049097414
All at once Felton stopped.	346.51638846084916
“What is the matter?” asked Milady.	252.17931871824015
“Silence,” said Felton, “I hear footsteps.”	194.56257010213997
“We are discovered!”	203.6690844462313
There was a silence of several seconds.	199.31554426893922
“No,” said Felton, “it is nothing.”	261.4036543619555
“But what, then, is the noise?”	200.61033979106796
“That of the patrol going their rounds.”	314.7940942288176
“Where is their road?”	267.1846044789041
“Just under us.”	178.3774839278824
“They will discover us!”	193.95839019489478
“No, if it does not lighten.”	259.27473997196387
“But they will run against the bottom of the ladder.”	321.66123833610675
“Fortunately it is too short by six feet.”	314.70348768845065
“Here they are! My God!”	256.93431226051956
“Silence!”	235.00230977330992
Both remained suspended, motionless and breathless, within twenty paces	311.48278319484325
of the ground, while the patrol passed beneath them laughing and	322.61228811099863
talking. This was a terrible moment for the fugitives.	265.6254845165649
The patrol passed. The noise of their retreating footsteps and the	222.67626076818115
murmur of their voices soon died away.	301.6046694288424
“Now,” said Felton, “we are safe.”	288.9967330662141
Milady breathed a deep sigh and fainted.	343.674533075746
Felton continued to descend. Near the bottom of the ladder, when he	332.33579789021996
found no more support for his feet, he clung with his hands; at length,	174.3622326248809
arrived at the last step, he let himself hang by the strength of his	304.7919371014626
wrists, and touched the ground. He stooped down, picked up the bag of	198.37445497222802
money, and placed it between his teeth. Then he took Milady in his	291.7548792490519
arms, and set off briskly in the direction opposite to that which the	318.66096187719415
patrol had taken. He soon left the pathway of the patrol, descended	336.8333613314471
across the rocks, and when arrived on the edge of the sea, whistled.	253.52259979830035
A similar signal replied to him; and five minutes after, a boat	343.37724314767496
appeared, rowed by four men.	227.59383709728908
The boat approached as near as it could to the shore; but there was not	210.1021644631471
depth enough of water for it to touch land. Felton walked into the sea	294.0653330974244
up to his middle, being unwilling to trust his precious burden to	345.3371975686869
anybody.	314.1100473426259
Fortunately the storm began to subside, but still the sea was	290.7636049512456
disturbed. The little boat bounded over the waves like a nut-shell.	321.02954433751745
“To the sloop,” said Felton, “and row quickly.”	311.6250472581703
The four men bent to their oars, but the sea was too high to let them	284.60164463808053
get much hold of it.	315.0858407159187
However, they left the castle behind; that was the principal thing. The	197.20163669802122
night was extremely dark. It was almost impossible to see the shore	197.71303031183788
from the boat; they would therefore be less likely to see the boat from	300.30212801497066
the shore.	343.71995500187086
A black point floated on the sea. That was the sloop. While the boat	235.92694060485002
was advancing with all the speed its four rowers could give it, Felton	201.43304635750707
untied the cord and then the handkerchief which bound Milady’s hands	255.03756486443632
together. When her hands were loosed he took some sea water and	322.9848729147001
sprinkled it over her face.	225.30648713129554
Milady breathed a sigh, and opened her eyes.	355.2733811497976
“Where am I?” said she.	258.5994451679379
“Saved!” replied the young officer.	200.24068295062386
“Oh, saved, saved!” cried she. “Yes, there is the sky; here is the sea!	348.6930851819303
The air I breathe is the air of liberty! Ah, thanks, Felton, thanks!”	296.64745901910453
The young man pressed her to his heart.	321.4064715679857
“But what is the matter with my hands!” asked Milady; “it seems as if	314.8387303206581
my wrists had been crushed in a vice.”	269.58878068060784
Milady held out her arms; her wrists were bruised.	229.74004324584635
“Alas!” said Felton, looking at those beautiful hands, and shaking his	315.26210453766134
head sorrowfully.	243.47481786336306
“Oh, it’s nothing, nothing!” cried Milady. “I remember now.”	277.3384683863595
Milady looked around her, as if in search of something.	340.1901662628942
“It is there,” said Felton, touching the bag of money with his foot.	167.12265898571175
They drew near to the sloop. A sailor on watch hailed the boat; the	287.7834392516319
boat replied.	232.61035213916824
“What vessel is that?” asked Milady.	271.07946411594736
“The one I have hired for you.”	310.60661460442293
“Where will it take me?”	217.7670543313375
“Where you please, after you have put me on shore at Portsmouth.”	272.7146782079714
“What are you going to do at Portsmouth?” asked Milady.	195.54122717185024
“Accomplish the orders of Lord de Winter,” said Felton, with a gloomy	257.59140379453476
smile.	356.38590991380624
“What orders?” asked Milady.	358.01398893745716
“You do not understand?” asked Felton.	306.5665350917286
“No; explain yourself, I beg.”	244.99458284466522
“As he mistrusted me, he determined to guard you himself, and sent me	178.14761499933508
in his place to get Buckingham to sign the order for your	280.4955492424027
transportation.”	259.8907769986453
“But if he mistrusted you, how could he confide such an order to you?”	205.27028371990676
“How could I know what I was the bearer of?”	308.4470117566508
“That’s true! And you are going to Portsmouth?”	210.80044732723618
“I have no time to lose. Tomorrow is the twenty-third, and Buckingham	319.0947341736629
sets sail tomorrow with his fleet.”	256.3633904159236
“He sets sail tomorrow! Where for?”	202.03768359488134
“For La Rochelle.”	349.3033988004921
“He need not sail!” cried Milady, forgetting her usual presence of	189.05830807125804
mind.	314.2555328237329
“Be satisfied,” replied Felton; “he will not sail.”	341.25878254148506
Milady started with joy. She could read to the depths of the heart of	283.16551870436973
this young man; the death of Buckingham was written there at full	335.8427618528858
length.	314.84159953141636
“Felton,” cried she, “you are as great as Judas Maccabeus! If you die,	333.4652991877111
I will die with you; that is all I can say to you.”	303.5670656524829
“Silence!” cried Felton; “we are here.”	339.7604913991068
In fact, they touched the sloop.	209.61116045932346
Felton mounted the ladder first, and gave his hand to Milady, while the	227.45961164625135
sailors supported her, for the sea was still much agitated.	279.62545490069283
An instant after they were on the deck.	342.4152443387941
“Captain,” said Felton, “this is the person of whom I spoke to you, and	284.096416502967
whom you must convey safe and sound to France.”	188.94878055788527
“For a thousand pistoles,” said the captain.	344.01269341108843
“I have paid you five hundred of them.”	328.7975114015366
“That’s correct,” said the captain.	179.10949530519113
“And here are the other five hundred,” replied Milady, placing her hand	343.8293171050442
upon the bag of gold.	166.76576293236687
“No,” said the captain, “I make but one bargain; and I have agreed with	245.00066334444153
this young man that the other five hundred shall not be due to me till	198.9190588022263
we arrive at Boulogne.”	209.55308024483188
“And shall we arrive there?”	304.4188119183655
“Safe and sound, as true as my name’s Jack Butler.”	230.27471942988655
“Well,” said Milady, “if you keep your word, instead of five hundred, I	218.715563816829
will give you a thousand pistoles.”	270.04216224968405
“Hurrah for you, then, my beautiful lady,” cried the captain; “and may	335.4629175055672
God often send me such passengers as your Ladyship!”	353.2393481124575
“Meanwhile,” said Felton, “convey me to the little bay of—; you know it	268.48954581449897
was agreed you should put in there.”	262.07340291061263
The captain replied by ordering the necessary maneuvers, and toward	296.4873059093597
seven o’clock in the morning the little vessel cast anchor in the bay	181.9363030032035
that had been named.	222.97808334600404
During this passage, Felton related everything to Milady—how, instead	221.22979111217538
of going to London, he had chartered the little vessel; how he had	186.58616360574516
returned; how he had scaled the wall by fastening cramps in the	324.4291731563138
interstices of the stones, as he ascended, to give him foothold; and	269.94620882836864
how, when he had reached the bars, he fastened his ladder. Milady knew	329.62228130261144
the rest.	343.9247693884775
On her side, Milady tried to encourage Felton in his project; but at	279.0821570712758
the first words which issued from her mouth, she plainly saw that the	225.69379996728418
young fanatic stood more in need of being moderated than urged.	245.82239211086846
It was agreed that Milady should wait for Felton till ten o’clock; if	328.6173701571603
he did not return by ten o’clock she was to sail.	237.23936562809342
In that case, and supposing he was at liberty, he was to rejoin her in	365.42382320672476
France, at the convent of the Carmelites at Béthune.	320.01229584093034
Chapter LIX.	188.5188049531177
WHAT TOOK PLACE AT PORTSMOUTH	314.79583179796055
AUGUST 23, 1628	271.9122177564685
Felton took leave of Milady as a brother about to go for a mere walk	169.73426290119363
takes leave of his sister, kissing her hand.	258.3863439219935
His whole body appeared in its ordinary state of calmness, only an	230.93487591006686
unusual fire beamed from his eyes, like the effects of a fever; his	341.44678827466714
brow was more pale than it generally was; his teeth were clenched, and	181.11553470005472
his speech had a short dry accent which indicated that something dark	203.29433263696222
was at work within him.	271.3436266438678
As long as he remained in the boat which conveyed him to land, he kept	247.13388637939534
his face toward Milady, who, standing on the deck, followed him with	181.8400420703107
her eyes. Both were free from the fear of pursuit; nobody ever came	328.8053374883664
into Milady’s apartment before nine o’clock, and it would require three	190.48553358129618
hours to go from the castle to London.	234.41791421373327
Felton jumped onshore, climbed the little ascent which led to the top	315.82915566875374
of the cliff, saluted Milady a last time, and took his course toward	326.7833217878083
the city.	327.56883095117223
At the end of a hundred paces, the ground began to decline, and he	187.7562711046775
could only see the mast of the sloop.	206.2754752339235
He immediately ran in the direction of Portsmouth, which he saw at	345.20662776145866
nearly half a league before him, standing out in the haze of the	354.9854530864759
morning, with its houses and towers.	170.79224121551843
Beyond Portsmouth the sea was covered with vessels whose masts, like a	195.53747231351406
forest of poplars despoiled by the winter, bent with each breath of the	203.58716399849894
wind.	211.41857757597415
Felton, in his rapid walk, reviewed in his mind all the accusations	304.83777988732845
against the favorite of James I. and Charles I., furnished by two years	172.40132422272356
of premature meditation and a long sojourn among the Puritans.	258.38339310069114
When he compared the public crimes of this minister—startling crimes,	237.72190156553353
European crimes, if so we may say—with the private and unknown crimes	213.90216476397143
with which Milady had charged him, Felton found that the more culpable	283.4939190327056
of the two men which formed the character of Buckingham was the one of	260.7457570647202
whom the public knew not the life. This was because his love, so	241.38463852263607
strange, so new, and so ardent, made him view the infamous and	353.1309781589711
imaginary accusations of Milady de Winter as, through a magnifying	339.858387089448
glass, one views as frightful monsters atoms in reality imperceptible	253.66651142186652
by the side of an ant.	347.4968268020351
The rapidity of his walk heated his blood still more; the idea that he	197.69697779154225
left behind him, exposed to a frightful vengeance, the woman he loved,	242.65110061856626
or rather whom he adored as a saint, the emotion he had experienced,	292.4773612329749
present fatigue—all together exalted his mind above human feeling.	249.25194242821323
He entered Portsmouth about eight o’clock in the morning. The whole	302.3158114559866
population was on foot; drums were beating in the streets and in the	339.1257518043931
port; the troops about to embark were marching toward the sea.	176.26056265196263
Felton arrived at the palace of the Admiralty, covered with dust, and	237.63240116820378
streaming with perspiration. His countenance, usually so pale, was	316.7055206354251
purple with heat and passion. The sentinel wanted to repulse him; but	324.9240713817247
Felton called to the officer of the post, and drawing from his pocket	316.2491137881657
the letter of which he was the bearer, he said, “A pressing message	363.26295797755154
from Lord de Winter.”	358.6063182484255
At the name of Lord de Winter, who was known to be one of his Grace’s	237.1231440611512
most intimate friends, the officer of the post gave orders to let	189.95015618066287
Felton pass, who, besides, wore the uniform of a naval officer.	284.6360718306262
Felton darted into the palace.	256.7787849366056
At the moment he entered the vestibule, another man was entering	275.5706791750746
likewise, dusty, out of breath, leaving at the gate a post horse,	187.36372997318074
which, on reaching the palace, tumbled on his foreknees.	289.9061350102951
Felton and he addressed Patrick, the duke’s confidential lackey, at the	196.70295054818712
same moment. Felton named Lord de Winter; the unknown would not name	231.79827947850032
anybody, and pretended that it was to the duke alone he would make	280.40629160360385
himself known. Each was anxious to gain admission before the other.	243.69696026194964
Patrick, who knew Lord de Winter was in affairs of the service, and in	255.544016246546
relations of friendship with the duke, gave the preference to the one	253.36083245382653
who came in his name. The other was forced to wait, and it was easily	340.1247394939445
to be seen how he cursed the delay.	247.42350610485767
The valet led Felton through a large hall in which waited the deputies	335.86201690620834
from La Rochelle, headed by the Prince de Soubise, and introduced him	195.30246090613835
into a closet where Buckingham, just out of the bath, was finishing his	295.0784760938876
toilet, upon which, as at all times, he bestowed extraordinary	257.73092945277165
attention.	273.62293831553626
“Lieutenant Felton, from Lord de Winter,” said Patrick.	186.46563973576002
“From Lord de Winter!” repeated Buckingham; “let him come in.”	247.13627197100092
Felton entered. At that moment Buckingham was throwing upon a couch a	365.2946722119987
rich toilet robe, worked with gold, in order to put on a blue velvet	294.54157252327735
doublet embroidered with pearls.	199.20410679462518
“Why didn’t the baron come himself?” demanded Buckingham. “I expected	235.04203663281328
him this morning.”	290.04042467594144
“He desired me to tell your Grace,” replied Felton, “that he very much	178.08120845455514
regretted not having that honor, but that he was prevented by the guard	319.1538100393327
he is obliged to keep at the castle.”	197.5502289673826
“Yes, I know that,” said Buckingham; “he has a prisoner.”	322.00918918885327
“It is of that prisoner that I wish to speak to your Grace,” replied	301.3710746066268
Felton.	261.6745681281808
“Well, then, speak!”	356.5689991378474
“That which I have to say of her can only be heard by yourself, my	232.62061402951127
Lord!”	325.9331799826808
“Leave us, Patrick,” said Buckingham; “but remain within sound of the	279.58346069777775
bell. I shall call you presently.”	206.86943815626802
Patrick went out.	227.09731977570314
“We are alone, sir,” said Buckingham; “speak!”	241.46798956986328
“My Lord,” said Felton, “the Baron de Winter wrote to you the other day	220.102223177748
to request you to sign an order of embarkation relative to a young	326.9935963172494
woman named Charlotte Backson.”	177.41366422395856
“Yes, sir; and I answered him, to bring or send me that order and I	343.3944504796526
would sign it.”	280.838954132494
“Here it is, my Lord.”	299.0510795986024
“Give it to me,” said the duke.	281.9140353946883
And taking it from Felton, he cast a rapid glance over the paper, and	323.70081195990457
perceiving that it was the one that had been mentioned to him, he	360.5309503211642
placed it on the table, took a pen, and prepared to sign it.	200.31673064140915
“Pardon, my Lord,” said Felton, stopping the duke; “but does your Grace	169.58606178442744
know that the name of Charlotte Backson is not the true name of this	277.1540586899282
young woman?”	214.9559081164556
“Yes, sir, I know it,” replied the duke, dipping the quill in the ink.	318.23464026134565
“Then your Grace knows her real name?” asked Felton, in a sharp tone.	188.1239615987964
“I know it”; and the duke put the quill to the paper. Felton grew pale.	263.4714796817799
“And knowing that real name, my Lord,” replied Felton, “will you sign	250.62275708324177
it all the same?”	253.98076561885523
“Doubtless,” said Buckingham, “and rather twice than once.”	328.5200849870443
“I cannot believe,” continued Felton, in a voice that became more sharp	322.1517082589842
and rough, “that your Grace knows that it is to Milady de Winter this	278.6209725855729
relates.”	168.8366124960729
“I know it perfectly, although I am astonished that you know it.”	297.0717354511954
“And will your Grace sign that order without remorse?”	263.07312779024613
Buckingham looked at the young man haughtily.	238.90944214260608
“Do you know, sir, that you are asking me very strange questions, and	221.67060746909718
that I am very foolish to answer them?”	283.77346554503146
“Reply to them, my Lord,” said Felton; “the circumstances are more	226.86590729975455
serious than you perhaps believe.”	353.35501919711487
Buckingham reflected that the young man, coming from Lord de Winter,	314.5434326829158
undoubtedly spoke in his name, and softened.	327.5425686199443
“Without remorse,” said he. “The baron knows, as well as myself, that	175.64236628197787
Milady de Winter is a very guilty woman, and it is treating her very	206.26894467580232
favorably to commute her punishment to transportation.” The duke put	353.86613340857605
his pen to the paper.	309.36095712450486
“You will not sign that order, my Lord!” said Felton, making a step	337.4265428802387
toward the duke.	267.16746148556655
“I will not sign this order! And why not?”	263.9230088938509
“Because you will look into yourself, and you will do justice to the	341.1053555430541
lady.”	227.67587304824906
“I should do her justice by sending her to Tyburn,” said Buckingham.	253.96904043046453
“This lady is infamous.”	242.8353062962637
“My Lord, Milady de Winter is an angel; you know that she is, and I	305.7905242758784
demand her liberty of you.”	216.0016873034769
“Bah! Are you mad, to talk to me thus?” said Buckingham.	282.66463242800194
“My Lord, excuse me! I speak as I can; I restrain myself. But, my Lord,	303.0006827442676
think of what you’re about to do, and beware of going too far!”	314.34960185506446
“What do you say? God pardon me!” cried Buckingham, “I really think he	277.2470330652119
threatens me!”	295.19482566975864
“No, my Lord, I still plead. And I say to you: one drop of water	208.22583437547132
suffices to make the full vase overflow; one slight fault may draw down	259.91692268190263
punishment upon the head spared, despite many crimes.”	231.26365675493173
“Mr. Felton,” said Buckingham, “you will withdraw, and place yourself	243.73527092695343
at once under arrest.”	193.06642952548407
“You will hear me to the end, my Lord. You have seduced this young	188.40559466356927
girl; you have outraged, defiled her. Repair your crimes toward her;	187.01029294449765
let her go free, and I will exact nothing else from you.”	290.0891941871239
“You will exact!” said Buckingham, looking at Felton with astonishment,	196.6061484416899
and dwelling upon each syllable of the three words as he pronounced	317.44698561487553
them.	181.36373810500993
“My Lord,” continued Felton, becoming more excited as he spoke, “my	203.7407722170305
Lord, beware! All England is tired of your iniquities; my Lord, you	191.34672897689734
have abused the royal power, which you have almost usurped; my Lord,	183.03263664255653
you are held in horror by God and men. God will punish you hereafter,	264.4863358121394
but I will punish you here!”	310.98299006559625
“Ah, this is too much!” cried Buckingham, making a step toward the	271.7404219456736
door.	216.28145232702576
Felton barred his passage.	345.6018825723795
“I ask it humbly of you, my Lord,” said he; “sign the order for the	176.24594137527004
liberation of Milady de Winter. Remember that she is a woman whom you	195.7085378984644
have dishonored.”	293.5090712721461
“Withdraw, sir,” said Buckingham, “or I will call my attendant, and	281.8348512279639
have you placed in irons.”	365.8518686434935
“You shall not call,” said Felton, throwing himself between the duke	329.20566607481567
and the bell placed on a stand encrusted with silver. “Beware, my Lord,	175.1583619560924
you are in the hands of God!”	251.5728501990277
“In the hands of the devil, you mean!” cried Buckingham, raising his	196.97823804730712
voice so as to attract the notice of his people, without absolutely	294.4052580465304
shouting.	223.73262525180877
“Sign, my Lord; sign the liberation of Milady de Winter,” said Felton,	286.1520463028525
holding out a paper to the duke.	248.88739916946557
“By force? You are joking! Holloa, Patrick!”	224.30653733678156
“Sign, my Lord!”	206.80420602554403
“Never.”	299.3564279491794
“Never?”	242.77314954399537
“Help!” shouted the duke; and at the same time he sprang toward his	288.70174806912524
sword.	276.69712057757306
But Felton did not give him time to draw it. He held the knife with	222.0359137970524
which Milady had stabbed herself, open in his bosom; at one bound he	173.9507219702806
was upon the duke.	336.4089945398655
At that moment Patrick entered the room, crying, “A letter from France,	347.314645008633
my Lord.”	175.37942989004722
“From France!” cried Buckingham, forgetting everything in thinking from	245.71684316067547
whom that letter came.	236.0346964034592
Felton took advantage of this moment, and plunged the knife into his	273.3361748329247
side up to the handle.	347.57056743963443
“Ah, traitor,” cried Buckingham, “you have killed me!”	286.76198884893483
“Murder!” screamed Patrick.	275.81331266976014
Felton cast his eyes round for means of escape, and seeing the door	230.42133609616354
free, he rushed into the next chamber, in which, as we have said, the	249.9484301217818
deputies from La Rochelle were waiting, crossed it as quickly as	267.05044588219795
possible, and rushed toward the staircase; but upon the first step he	191.96675991988909
met Lord de Winter, who, seeing him pale, confused, livid, and stained	365.80441923054843
with blood both on his hands and face, seized him by the throat,	215.85527070731666
crying, “I knew it! I guessed it! But too late by a minute,	314.70567979014925
unfortunate, unfortunate that I am!”	181.58217519793394
Felton made no resistance. Lord de Winter placed him in the hands of	290.0970125612065
the guards, who led him, while awaiting further orders, to a little	225.25926203737941
terrace commanding the sea; and then the baron hastened to the duke’s	174.88452436768225
chamber.	223.2766134846202
At the cry uttered by the duke and the scream of Patrick, the man whom	244.90109337765915
Felton had met in the antechamber rushed into the chamber.	269.94980081474756
He found the duke reclining upon a sofa, with his hand pressed upon the	339.0026308955652
wound.	283.52212288750354
“Laporte,” said the duke, in a dying voice, “Laporte, do you come from	295.98331113790584
her?”	240.4787567533881
“Yes, monseigneur,” replied the faithful cloak bearer of Anne of	287.4845846972884
Austria, “but too late, perhaps.”	182.31294434786577
“Silence, Laporte, you may be overheard. Patrick, let no one enter. Oh,	219.75027454255024
I cannot tell what she says to me! My God, I am dying!”	296.9219381863264
And the duke swooned.	287.06506735848586
Meanwhile, Lord de Winter, the deputies, the leaders of the expedition,	201.99713860769248
the officers of Buckingham’s household, had all made their way into the	262.40004142458275
chamber. Cries of despair resounded on all sides. The news, which	266.35460599450414
filled the palace with tears and groans, soon became known, and spread	352.5136714747975
itself throughout the city.	270.32469475045065
The report of a cannon announced that something new and unexpected had	361.74870566203333
taken place.	172.02249366291014
Lord de Winter tore his hair.	243.00767193146106
“Too late by a minute!” cried he, “too late by a minute! Oh, my God, my	316.49616800007254
God! what a misfortune!”	352.84982475298915
He had been informed at seven o’clock in the morning that a rope ladder	191.89720715638566
floated from one of the windows of the castle; he had hastened to	174.40341032192185
Milady’s chamber, had found it empty, the window open, and the bars	180.90612982848262
filed, had remembered the verbal caution D’Artagnan had transmitted to	170.66418269878878
him by his messenger, had trembled for the duke, and running to the	207.61798173527785
stable without taking time to have a horse saddled, had jumped upon the	227.77193561930426
first he found, had galloped off like the wind, had alighted below in	343.3156200950353
the courtyard, had ascended the stairs precipitately, and on the top	348.86550512056937
step, as we have said, had encountered Felton.	167.75678471291508
The duke, however, was not dead. He recovered a little, reopened his	269.5928389188909
eyes, and hope revived in all hearts.	289.05241128787964
“Gentlemen,” said he, “leave me alone with Patrick and Laporte—ah, is	185.42169664181682
that you, De Winter? You sent me a strange madman this morning! See the	326.50925624361287
state in which he has put me.”	311.9675376324858
“Oh, my Lord!” cried the baron, “I shall never console myself.”	332.68872008084736
“And you would be quite wrong, my dear De Winter,” said Buckingham,	365.6157306472317
holding out his hand to him. “I do not know the man who deserves being	318.9348844368512
regretted during the whole life of another man; but leave us, I pray	312.5041098009502
you.”	191.01322545793795
The baron went out sobbing.	178.33461292795147
There only remained in the closet of the wounded duke Laporte and	199.52682310387775
Patrick. A physician was sought for, but none was yet found.	303.2125185093098
“You will live, my Lord, you will live!” repeated the faithful servant	245.04458548238824
of Anne of Austria, on his knees before the duke’s sofa.	242.71249961206192
“What has she written to me?” said Buckingham, feebly, streaming with	345.959547174726
blood, and suppressing his agony to speak of her he loved, “what has	248.47921558423758
she written to me? Read me her letter.”	172.05522701288425
“Oh, my Lord!” said Laporte.	324.1656097494913
“Obey, Laporte, do you not see I have no time to lose?”	219.51120915025734
Laporte broke the seal, and placed the paper before the eyes of the	178.17744176496456
duke; but Buckingham in vain tried to make out the writing.	177.752270366389
“Read!” said he, “read! I cannot see. Read, then! For soon, perhaps, I	167.58130257782773
shall not hear, and I shall die without knowing what she has written to	253.7864715123712
me.”	334.33331810610923
Laporte made no further objection, and read:	193.71805109808108
“MY LORD, By that which, since I have known you, have suffered by you	274.3435736956741
and for you, I conjure you, if you have any care for my repose, to	312.182569896142
countermand those great armaments which you are preparing against	276.4995063355758
France, to put an end to a war of which it is publicly said religion is	302.80361902854884
the ostensible cause, and of which, it is generally whispered, your	167.60004641915833
love for me is the concealed cause. This war may not only bring great	317.3799573675942
catastrophes upon England and France, but misfortune upon you, my Lord,	362.6231619941416
for which I should never console myself.	226.82926948559225
    “Be careful of your life, which is menaced, and which will be dear	337.9403638845208
    to me from the moment I am not obliged to see an enemy in you.	219.89295652155852
“Your affectionate	286.6224964341849
“ANNE”	295.1349657597857
Buckingham collected all his remaining strength to listen to the	185.2416303610466
reading of the letter; then, when it was ended, as if he had met with a	272.2464037344022
bitter disappointment, he asked, “Have you nothing else to say to me by	187.61731023191805
the living voice, Laporte?”	226.53558354419715
“The queen charged me to tell you to watch over yourself, for she had	249.6324021126896
advice that your assassination would be attempted.”	176.3317470153243
“And is that all—is that all?” replied Buckingham, impatiently.	355.36323838498015
“She likewise charged me to tell you that she still loved you.”	291.9512953653528
“Ah,” said Buckingham, “God be praised! My death, then, will not be to	237.68740471616263
her as the death of a stranger!”	274.58286574473743
Laporte burst into tears.	242.6394127918296
“Patrick,” said the duke, “bring me the casket in which the diamond	241.76040351286943
studs were kept.”	260.7653199654733
Patrick brought the object desired, which Laporte recognized as having	327.9767157406929
belonged to the queen.	315.5281004063147
“Now the scent bag of white satin, on which her cipher is embroidered	251.03115560903947
in pearls.”	191.65071740701964
Patrick again obeyed.	218.94930982406623
“Here, Laporte,” said Buckingham, “these are the only tokens I ever	249.50911254719423
received from her—this silver casket and these two letters. You will	258.2028754265245
restore them to her Majesty; and as a last memorial”—he looked round	193.62789855180182
for some valuable object—“you will add—”	324.1038965877209
He still sought; but his eyes, darkened by death, encountered only the	178.85436218751522
knife which had fallen from the hand of Felton, still smoking with the	344.9008104245651
blood spread over its blade.	297.75362474497524
“And you will add to them this knife,” said the duke, pressing the hand	196.85446860534574
of Laporte. He had just strength enough to place the scent bag at the	173.01365995234508
bottom of the silver casket, and to let the knife fall into it, making	226.1975330806775
a sign to Laporte that he was no longer able to speak; then, in a last	290.20044515702716
convulsion, which this time he had not the power to combat, he slipped	340.3968561719918
from the sofa to the floor.	325.5678306731314
Patrick uttered a loud cry.	282.4292156901345
Buckingham tried to smile a last time; but death checked his thought,	192.8611292276275
which remained engraved on his brow like a last kiss of love.	171.01195734138597
At this moment the duke’s surgeon arrived, quite terrified; he was	314.72470534758975
already on board the admiral’s ship, where they had been obliged to	329.07952821733363
seek him.	228.20040833808463
He approached the duke, took his hand, held it for an instant in his	337.79930284166966
own, and letting it fall, “All is useless,” said he, “he is dead.”	194.97147802853422
“Dead, dead!” cried Patrick.	203.94719632881737
At this cry all the crowd re-entered the apartment, and throughout the	283.46518893244166
palace and town there was nothing but consternation and tumult.	282.1708892574253
As soon as Lord de Winter saw Buckingham was dead, he ran to Felton,	241.99912600028225
whom the soldiers still guarded on the terrace of the palace.	321.2234001691637
“Wretch!” said he to the young man, who since the death of Buckingham	311.65197111527476
had regained that coolness and self-possession which never after	306.2583920050524
abandoned him, “wretch! what have you done?”	166.82428519866625
“I have avenged myself!” said he.	292.15526096312226
“Avenged yourself,” said the baron. “Rather say that you have served as	239.96719470643438
an instrument to that accursed woman; but I swear to you that this	168.52391133568045
crime shall be her last.”	180.76538089356265
“I don’t know what you mean,” replied Felton, quietly, “and I am	211.96152329813123
ignorant of whom you are speaking, my Lord. I killed the Duke of	211.8596246257115
Buckingham because he twice refused you yourself to appoint me captain;	189.02592727874253
I have punished him for his injustice, that is all.”	285.4733457177565
De Winter, stupefied, looked on while the soldiers bound Felton, and	182.8492193415851
could not tell what to think of such insensibility.	326.68121064482455
One thing alone, however, threw a shade over the pallid brow of Felton.	218.07517210678566
At every noise he heard, the simple Puritan fancied he recognized the	264.7240844923872
step and voice of Milady coming to throw herself into his arms, to	330.2470247441331
accuse herself, and die with him.	263.1284202343741
All at once he started. His eyes became fixed upon a point of the sea,	226.6021593252484
commanded by the terrace where he was. With the eagle glance of a	290.16972505110016
sailor he had recognized there, where another would have seen only a	246.13488908889985
gull hovering over the waves, the sail of a sloop which was directed	283.1398269654407
toward the coast of France.	223.2946480918293
He grew deadly pale, placed his hand upon his heart, which was	227.91147791202587
breaking, and at once perceived all the treachery.	216.69417670656537
“One last favor, my Lord!” said he to the baron.	222.46549652212656
“What?” asked his Lordship.	346.6083299652097
“What o’clock is it?”	227.05848928502567
The baron drew out his watch. “It wants ten minutes to nine,” said he.	193.18722090337243
Milady had hastened her departure by an hour and a half. As soon as she	352.7616364460641
heard the cannon which announced the fatal event, she had ordered the	255.7286003721769
anchor to be weighed. The vessel was making way under a blue sky, at	317.3821340475405
great distance from the coast.	341.11513664862514
“God has so willed it!” said he, with the resignation of a fanatic; but	258.7261298607615
without, however, being able to take his eyes from that ship, on board	304.15634327328866
of which he doubtless fancied he could distinguish the white outline of	236.06042869701832
her to whom he had sacrificed his life.	215.62779151981684
De Winter followed his look, observed his feelings, and guessed all.	289.48128447974887
“Be punished _alone_, for the first, miserable man!” said Lord de	332.935435922174
Winter to Felton, who was being dragged away with his eyes turned	362.99183737767146
toward the sea; “but I swear to you by the memory of my brother whom I	227.1961012771189
have loved so much that your accomplice is not saved.”	227.97159272068257
Felton lowered his head without pronouncing a syllable.	192.2186352034562
As to Lord de Winter, he descended the stairs rapidly, and went	275.35291982104
straight to the port.	208.47709056630492
Chapter LX.	281.47633890069346
IN FRANCE	209.287366853507
The first fear of the King of England, Charles I., on learning of the	358.79428377780204
death of the duke, was that such terrible news might discourage the	203.18905248902334
Rochellais; he tried, says Richelieu in his _Memoirs_, to conceal it	277.2220617514523
from them as long as possible, closing all the ports of his kingdom,	280.28299441227085
and carefully keeping watch that no vessel should sail until the army	208.56942265524776
which Buckingham was getting together had gone, taking upon himself, in	190.5977617187916
default of Buckingham, to superintend the departure.	359.2938147182144
He carried the strictness of this order so far as to detain in England	218.20054629477747
the ambassadors of Denmark, who had taken their leave, and the regular	186.64337299062885
ambassador of Holland, who was to take back to the port of Flushing the	222.3026508407187
Indian merchantmen of which Charles I. had made restitution to the	320.7219776637956
United Provinces.	252.7861093554372
But as he did not think of giving this order till five hours after the	289.3503011531915
event—that is to say, till two o’clock in the afternoon—two vessels had	178.33368131131638
already left the port, the one bearing, as we know, Milady, who,	339.8636478414215
already anticipating the event, was further confirmed in that belief by	167.61144550506228
seeing the black flag flying at the masthead of the admiral’s ship.	252.4701612889938
As to the second vessel, we will tell hereafter whom it carried, and	359.8543275559862
how it set sail.	334.83002517894727
During this time nothing new occurred in the camp at La Rochelle; only	167.59360450095315
the king, who was bored, as always, but perhaps a little more so in	193.74855382577752
camp than elsewhere, resolved to go incognito and spend the festival of	189.8525878216252
St. Louis at St. Germain, and asked the cardinal to order him an escort	285.8408228942946
of only twenty Musketeers. The cardinal, who sometimes became weary of	298.427055773202
the king, granted this leave of absence with great pleasure to his	184.8284928832137
royal lieutenant, who promised to return about the fifteenth of	302.7242387234776
September.	356.4885938196582
M. de Tréville, being informed of this by his Eminence, packed his	243.6519842947993
portmanteau; and as without knowing the cause he knew the great desire	320.18425349803147
and even imperative need which his friends had of returning to Paris,	259.0627656123803
it goes without saying that he fixed upon them to form part of the	219.04607899602723
escort.	286.86233583966657
The four young men heard the news a quarter of an hour after M. de	198.60907796541215
Tréville, for they were the first to whom he communicated it. It was	170.79879993894693
then that D’Artagnan appreciated the favor the cardinal had conferred	305.54914252781816
upon him in making him at last enter the Musketeers—for without that	274.3508160354736
circumstance he would have been forced to remain in the camp while his	217.35212584533724
companions left it.	269.94644830542046
It goes without saying that this impatience to return toward Paris had	363.0393587797936
for a cause the danger which Mme. Bonacieux would run of meeting at the	276.66478837733075
convent of Béthune with Milady, her mortal enemy. Aramis therefore had	239.52424049351742
written immediately to Marie Michon, the seamstress at Tours who had	179.45416122475893
such fine acquaintances, to obtain from the queen authority for Mme.	168.36944022749324
Bonacieux to leave the convent, and to retire either into Lorraine or	319.6633921550015
Belgium. They had not long to wait for an answer. Eight or ten days	281.427946268834
afterward Aramis received the following letter:	271.1485211776271
“MY DEAR COUSIN, Here is the authorization from my sister to withdraw	206.64965489062288
our little servant from the convent of Béthune, the air of which you	344.3632099381641
think is bad for her. My sister sends you this authorization with great	241.52082838256058
pleasure, for she is very partial to the little girl, to whom she	359.4909831043397
intends to be more serviceable hereafter.	169.22067106908136
“I salute you,	288.4401004327725
“MARIE MICHON”	207.27946034604787
To this letter was added an order, conceived in these terms:	211.64589783298737
“At the Louvre, August 10, 1628	331.1138107229051
“The superior of the convent of Béthune will place in the hands of the	243.18999054013653
person who shall present this note to her the novice who entered the	247.54926376544597
convent upon my recommendation and under my patronage.	340.9601171250905
“ANNE”	228.99795588718317
It may be easily imagined how the relationship between Aramis and a	174.18063961566048
seamstress who called the queen her sister amused the young men; but	322.10179779704305
Aramis, after having blushed two or three times up to the whites of his	195.96096070189694
eyes at the gross pleasantry of Porthos, begged his friends not to	257.6344449740303
revert to the subject again, declaring that if a single word more was	179.73215894017247
said to him about it, he would never again implore his cousins to	316.81597156909305
interfere in such affairs.	188.50668321733116
There was no further question, therefore, about Marie Michon among the	347.09686498018027
four Musketeers, who besides had what they wanted: that was, the order	228.7279738234757
to withdraw Mme. Bonacieux from the convent of the Carmelites of	206.22480746250008
Béthune. It was true that this order would not be of great use to them	190.44357548269383
while they were in camp at La Rochelle; that is to say, at the other	324.84757219277355
end of France. Therefore D’Artagnan was going to ask leave of absence	235.69654310455047
of M. de Tréville, confiding to him candidly the importance of his	246.20130708752686
departure, when the news was transmitted to him as well as to his three	252.3076648413647
friends that the king was about to set out for Paris with an escort of	318.08819356991955
twenty Musketeers, and that they formed part of the escort.	341.2651801943872
Their joy was great. The lackeys were sent on before with the baggage,	318.80119360186916
and they set out on the morning of the sixteenth.	166.0438111039113
The cardinal accompanied his Majesty from Surgères to Mauzes; and there	167.04499470868012
the king and his minister took leave of each other with great	174.97187127013922
demonstrations of friendship.	306.4504459949684
The king, however, who sought distraction, while traveling as fast as	251.78094879085802
possible—for he was anxious to be in Paris by the twenty-third—stopped	187.0000744920887
from time to time to fly the magpie, a pastime for which the taste had	183.5118173547527
been formerly inspired in him by de Luynes, and for which he had always	331.63075676900485
preserved a great predilection. Out of the twenty Musketeers sixteen,	196.8426939929207
when this took place, rejoiced greatly at this relaxation; but the	264.65151390720933
other four cursed it heartily. D’Artagnan, in particular, had a	178.8636605243687
perpetual buzzing in his ears, which Porthos explained thus: “A very	229.0056617886593
great lady has told me that this means that somebody is talking of you	191.40183593453577
somewhere.”	285.95801366304585
At length the escort passed through Paris on the twenty-third, in the	312.7361997439681
night. The king thanked M. de Tréville, and permitted him to distribute	276.34635898720273
furloughs for four days, on condition that the favored parties should	239.3416606630328
not appear in any public place, under penalty of the Bastille.	238.88956656899057
The first four furloughs granted, as may be imagined, were to our four	267.9683730626082
friends. Still further, Athos obtained of M. de Tréville six days	312.080093329326
instead of four, and introduced into these six days two more nights—for	238.60899573084117
they set out on the twenty-fourth at five o’clock in the evening, and	265.58376621082766
as a further kindness M. de Tréville post-dated the leave to the	316.9928687130516
morning of the twenty-fifth.	169.83412669519558
“Good Lord!” said D’Artagnan, who, as we have often said, never	324.2236988846452
stumbled at anything. “It appears to me that we are making a great	189.61360387009043
trouble of a very simple thing. In two days, and by using up two or	171.29214724589187
three horses (that’s nothing; I have plenty of money), I am at Béthune.	283.75407663403655
I present my letter from the queen to the superior, and I bring back	217.00791749286662
the dear treasure I go to seek—not into Lorraine, not into Belgium, but	260.9565698582512
to Paris, where she will be much better concealed, particularly while	276.9801758176894
the cardinal is at La Rochelle. Well, once returned from the country,	300.30841625722667
half by the protection of her cousin, half through what we have	284.3417364326122
personally done for her, we shall obtain from the queen what we desire.	249.79502083519532
Remain, then, where you are, and do not exhaust yourselves with useless	174.1857179957476
fatigue. Myself and Planchet are all that such a simple expedition	234.56003488522413
requires.”	166.4206646304528
To this Athos replied quietly: “We also have money left—for I have not	251.52641387492508
yet drunk all my share of the diamond, and Porthos and Aramis have not	312.3059908952726
eaten all theirs. We can therefore use up four horses as well as one.	283.95934868931465
But consider, D’Artagnan,” added he, in a tone so solemn that it made	259.0958510232122
the young man shudder, “consider that Béthune is a city where the	213.83352893068297
cardinal has given rendezvous to a woman who, wherever she goes, brings	272.30785578447814
misery with her. If you had only to deal with four men, D’Artagnan, I	243.58153496651573
would allow you to go alone. You have to do with that woman! We four	220.01322845470847
will go; and I hope to God that with our four lackeys we may be in	317.7519243609685
sufficient number.”	237.78501711398405
“You terrify me, Athos!” cried D’Artagnan. “My God! what do you fear?”	254.29741873169473
“Everything!” replied Athos.	221.7408173261521
D’Artagnan examined the countenances of his companions, which, like	272.8059381961374
that of Athos, wore an impression of deep anxiety; and they continued	349.37728565034155
their route as fast as their horses could carry them, but without	182.8111162337736
adding another word.	328.5938993678552
On the evening of the twenty-fifth, as they were entering Arras, and as	324.0171686755865
D’Artagnan was dismounting at the inn of the Golden Harrow to drink a	311.4915769416334
glass of wine, a horseman came out of the post yard, where he had just	365.35886724991184
had a relay, started off at a gallop, and with a fresh horse took the	300.101757704998
road to Paris. At the moment he passed through the gateway into the	310.50111862511835
street, the wind blew open the cloak in which he was wrapped, although	331.45701096257665
it was in the month of August, and lifted his hat, which the traveler	357.1833597986984
seized with his hand the moment it had left his head, pulling it	344.12502079752016
eagerly over his eyes.	299.5154766298103
D’Artagnan, who had his eyes fixed upon this man, became very pale, and	263.9955564405692
let his glass fall.	176.55077542847903
“What is the matter, monsieur?” said Planchet. “Oh, come, gentlemen, my	185.10845673845375
master is ill!”	198.40755522990688
The three friends hastened toward D’Artagnan, who, instead of being	263.4896198383992
ill, ran toward his horse. They stopped him at the door.	226.54173239228817
“Well, where the devil are you going now?” cried Athos.	343.30567296513277
“It is he!” cried D’Artagnan, pale with anger, and with the sweat on	211.91745670065905
his brow, “it is he! let me overtake him!”	238.1803768918382
“He? What he?” asked Athos.	220.73383686268775
“He, that man!”	319.39198209746513
“What man?”	176.09766082178356
“That cursed man, my evil genius, whom I have always met with when	355.9321420442425
threatened by some misfortune, he who accompanied that horrible woman	303.0343469367383
when I met her for the first time, he whom I was seeking when I	334.1190075406314
offended our Athos, he whom I saw on the very morning Madame Bonacieux	347.4311352336216
was abducted. I have seen him; that is he! I recognized him when the	329.686781828732
wind blew upon his cloak.”	334.1294118363456
“The devil!” said Athos, musingly.	197.72560704720772
“To saddle, gentlemen! to saddle! Let us pursue him, and we shall	323.60730568386276
overtake him!”	241.3812989278844
“My dear friend,” said Aramis, “remember that he goes in an opposite	319.8341676411108
direction from that in which we are going, that he has a fresh horse,	177.88680131328715
and ours are fatigued, so that we shall disable our own horses without	174.6142196141952
even a chance of overtaking him. Let the man go, D’Artagnan; let us	202.83004453503798
save the woman.”	264.31395726547186
“Monsieur, monsieur!” cried a hostler, running out and looking after	358.13968310587006
the stranger, “monsieur, here is a paper which dropped out of your hat!	348.2467837710516
Eh, monsieur, eh!”	205.66957989445086
“Friend,” said D’Artagnan, “a half-pistole for that paper!”	169.74114633718648
“My faith, monsieur, with great pleasure! Here it is!”	334.42337972691234
The hostler, enchanted with the good day’s work he had done, returned	225.8499045728289
to the yard. D’Artagnan unfolded the paper.	312.0214750062644
“Well?” eagerly demanded all his three friends.	248.19785380148235
“Nothing but one word!” said D’Artagnan.	187.32937081535215
“Yes,” said Aramis, “but that one word is the name of some town or	278.47023607718387
village.”	344.35005504740934
“_Armentières_,” read Porthos; “Armentières? I don’t know such a	178.78833593565216
place.”	288.64056215153283
“And that name of a town or village is written in her hand!” cried	293.97399232507877
Athos.	362.67188164465347
“Come on, come on!” said D’Artagnan; “let us keep that paper carefully,	321.7935145520366
perhaps I have not thrown away my half-pistole. To horse, my friends,	166.31602791595176
to horse!”	284.335581216773
And the four friends flew at a gallop along the road to Béthune.	266.459358706471
Chapter LXI.	345.9032325844262
THE CARMELITE CONVENT AT BÉTHUNE	233.59327724230295
Great criminals bear about them a kind of predestination which makes	215.61915356034848
them surmount all obstacles, which makes them escape all dangers, up to	251.15780298582195
the moment which a wearied Providence has marked as the rock of their	340.86627895022093
impious fortunes.	197.17924209618596
It was thus with Milady. She escaped the cruisers of both nations, and	185.26165658724574
arrived at Boulogne without accident.	228.09144254794498
When landing at Portsmouth, Milady was an Englishwoman whom the	320.9370063291789
persecutions of the French drove from La Rochelle; when landing at	280.72238041296146
Boulogne, after a two days’ passage, she passed for a Frenchwoman whom	282.72491319297956
the English persecuted at Portsmouth out of their hatred for France.	223.58840795413312
Milady had, likewise, the best of passports—her beauty, her noble	345.08959029997925
appearance, and the liberality with which she distributed her pistoles.	182.42691436440234
Freed from the usual formalities by the affable smile and gallant	199.3356489869106
manners of an old governor of the port, who kissed her hand, she only	214.67510136226474
remained long enough at Boulogne to put into the post a letter,	308.37047449535555
conceived in the following terms:	252.97694926337462
“_To his Eminence Monseigneur the Cardinal Richelieu, in his camp	279.2334712978944
before La Rochelle_.	265.3385466924343
“MONSEIGNEUR, Let your Eminence be reassured. His Grace the Duke of	285.5626134109675
Buckingham _will not set out_ for France.	270.8320404751866
“MILADY DE ——	290.4418084318438
“BOULOGNE, evening of the twenty-fifth.	201.6507000345694
“P.S.—According to the desire of your Eminence, I report to the convent	188.5170039095858
of the Carmelites at Béthune, where I will await your orders.”	190.21008657786342
Accordingly, that same evening Milady commenced her journey. Night	244.82550985070668
overtook her; she stopped, and slept at an inn. At five o’clock the	277.66608610403335
next morning she again proceeded, and in three hours after entered	318.2252248706179
Béthune. She inquired for the convent of the Carmelites, and went	269.7790617941939
thither immediately.	195.695660869244
The superior met her; Milady showed her the cardinal’s order. The	194.91493086249744
abbess assigned her a chamber, and had breakfast served.	324.9546207276007
All the past was effaced from the eyes of this woman; and her looks,	293.808915952911
fixed on the future, beheld nothing but the high fortunes reserved for	359.7908802349711
her by the cardinal, whom she had so successfully served without his	341.9083405857911
name being in any way mixed up with the sanguinary affair. The ever-new	228.16528928096008
passions which consumed her gave to her life the appearance of those	356.0816206023221
clouds which float in the heavens, reflecting sometimes azure,	189.1498989233847
sometimes fire, sometimes the opaque blackness of the tempest, and	169.04913381874678
which leave no traces upon the earth behind them but devastation and	203.73670585919734
death.	214.60029073180357
After breakfast, the abbess came to pay her a visit. There is very	188.48476135761956
little amusement in the cloister, and the good superior was eager to	182.06272071343037
make the acquaintance of her new boarder.	200.63891434492666
Milady wished to please the abbess. This was a very easy matter for a	357.2690768035463
woman so really superior as she was. She tried to be agreeable, and she	249.0737188794839
was charming, winning the good superior by her varied conversation and	304.44526695995216
by the graces of her whole personality.	187.81167260698507
The abbess, who was the daughter of a noble house, took particular	314.82133464157175
delight in stories of the court, which so seldom travel to the	257.8675386067362
extremities of the kingdom, and which, above all, have so much	346.3811294152897
difficulty in penetrating the walls of convents, at whose threshold the	325.3379055166754
noise of the world dies away.	337.7029992723164
Milady, on the contrary, was quite conversant with all aristocratic	352.95487744555635
intrigues, amid which she had constantly lived for five or six years.	277.7925566996049
She made it her business, therefore, to amuse the good abbess with the	166.20937308566934
worldly practices of the court of France, mixed with the eccentric	262.62683154360514
pursuits of the king; she made for her the scandalous chronicle of the	267.44123152862517
lords and ladies of the court, whom the abbess knew perfectly by name,	190.0506080341019
touched lightly on the amours of the queen and the Duke of Buckingham,	187.80450939148673
talking a great deal to induce her auditor to talk a little.	200.41307250835
But the abbess contented herself with listening and smiling without	290.9677397363942
replying a word. Milady, however, saw that this sort of narrative	195.34640212658778
amused her very much, and kept at it; only she now let her conversation	318.37700718948395
drift toward the cardinal.	242.83261201872634
But she was greatly embarrassed. She did not know whether the abbess	272.26551846854835
was a royalist or a cardinalist; she therefore confined herself to a	270.4292875933007
prudent middle course. But the abbess, on her part, maintained a	283.3520527586187
reserve still more prudent, contenting herself with making a profound	233.06070911942817
inclination of the head every time the fair traveler pronounced the	183.12453554283562
name of his Eminence.	179.25328303673567
Milady began to think she should soon grow weary of a convent life; she	290.68555113974287
resolved, then, to risk something in order that she might know how to	226.21376296205204
act afterward. Desirous of seeing how far the discretion of the good	246.27376759403415
abbess would go, she began to tell a story, obscure at first, but very	249.20466706623523
circumstantial afterward, about the cardinal, relating the amours of	282.3337823711753
the minister with Mme. d’Aiguillon, Marion de Lorme, and several other	233.84575584585878
gay women.	297.67405361356714
The abbess listened more attentively, grew animated by degrees, and	255.3362441812004
smiled.	336.08702163144596
“Good,” thought Milady; “she takes a pleasure in my conversation. If	353.3492586237712
she is a cardinalist, she has no fanaticism, at least.”	324.98797012342186
She then went on to describe the persecutions exercised by the cardinal	278.2694047104388
upon his enemies. The abbess only crossed herself, without approving or	343.1685226138154
disapproving.	358.5794105374912
This confirmed Milady in her opinion that the abbess was rather	340.7664531211786
royalist than cardinalist. Milady therefore continued, coloring her	317.839223748894
narrations more and more.	246.50714612480982
“I am very ignorant of these matters,” said the abbess, at length; “but	340.0982396311841
however distant from the court we may be, however remote from the	272.95000018283554
interests of the world we may be placed, we have very sad examples of	276.6134939284625
what you have related. And one of our boarders has suffered much from	248.37997872791846
the vengeance and persecution of the cardinal!”	194.41206397811564
“One of your boarders?” said Milady; “oh, my God! Poor woman! I pity	352.02519429365236
her, then.”	326.5264334322812
“And you have reason, for she is much to be pitied. Imprisonment,	197.28485232817738
menaces, ill treatment—she has suffered everything. But after all,”	209.41568874781825
resumed the abbess, “Monsieur Cardinal has perhaps plausible motives	331.14946843760686
for acting thus; and though she has the look of an angel, we must not	319.8535604703077
always judge people by the appearance.”	268.90124759804166
“Good!” said Milady to herself; “who knows! I am about, perhaps, to	309.7374443858927
discover something here; I am in the vein.”	258.7998570998989
She tried to give her countenance an appearance of perfect candor.	339.5596481638269
“Alas,” said Milady, “I know it is so. It is said that we must not	236.46184548570966
trust to the face; but in what, then, shall we place confidence, if not	271.36970752474804
in the most beautiful work of the Lord? As for me, I shall be deceived	186.68410548243958
all my life perhaps, but I shall always have faith in a person whose	200.9491694089073
countenance inspires me with sympathy.”	321.8793589986698
“You would, then, be tempted to believe,” said the abbess, “that this	320.2180334081353
young person is innocent?”	238.78392647023438
“The cardinal pursues not only crimes,” said she: “there are certain	168.13732165179883
virtues which he pursues more severely than certain offenses.”	230.6666850581907
“Permit me, madame, to express my surprise,” said the abbess.	262.3036756963338
“At what?” said Milady, with the utmost ingenuousness.	354.436968884424
“At the language you use.”	266.6250457161871
“What do you find so astonishing in that language?” said Milady,	271.71445797286106
smiling.	234.7180770974101
“You are the friend of the cardinal, for he sends you hither, and yet—”	206.1397796122747
“And yet I speak ill of him,” replied Milady, finishing the thought of	332.2452478175155
the superior.	204.74665707313116
“At least you don’t speak well of him.”	293.09273307881426
“That is because I am not his friend,” said she, sighing, “but his	176.17998224996074
victim!”	315.9006077676006
“But this letter in which he recommends you to me?”	265.07042977516875
“Is an order for me to confine myself to a sort of prison, from which	231.0122677160148
he will release me by one of his satellites.”	257.0432756581459
“But why have you not fled?”	298.81068948107105
“Whither should I go? Do you believe there is a spot on the earth which	243.72266406841285
the cardinal cannot reach if he takes the trouble to stretch forth his	194.35283027002475
hand? If I were a man, that would barely be possible; but what can a	304.80465520102064
woman do? This young boarder of yours, has she tried to fly?”	310.3197658578837
“No, that is true; but she—that is another thing; I believe she is	273.19962892793353
detained in France by some love affair.”	169.38247894375255
“Ah,” said Milady, with a sigh, “if she loves she is not altogether	299.00879073188855
wretched.”	286.49894554293877
“Then,” said the abbess, looking at Milady with increasing interest, “I	269.78247802624804
behold another poor victim?”	285.8256240529313
“Alas, yes,” said Milady.	227.03939713003354
The abbess looked at her for an instant with uneasiness, as if a fresh	173.8752560483935
thought suggested itself to her mind.	267.17727387461986
“You are not an enemy of our holy faith?” said she, hesitatingly.	365.84091647763876
“Who—I?” cried Milady; “I a Protestant? Oh, no! I call to witness the	267.5281614966574
God who hears us, that on the contrary I am a fervent Catholic!”	262.78364995186826
“Then, madame,” said the abbess, smiling, “be reassured; the house in	344.98168053628194
which you are shall not be a very hard prison, and we will do all in	292.5281200525973
our power to make you cherish your captivity. You will find here,	253.2008358680435
moreover, the young woman of whom I spoke, who is persecuted, no doubt,	185.21660129949817
in consequence of some court intrigue. She is amiable and	199.89462139901346
well-behaved.”	242.79913479255487
“What is her name?”	237.8145400030839
“She was sent to me by someone of high rank, under the name of Kitty. I	292.92075804847997
have not tried to discover her other name.”	195.49521948027535
“Kitty!” cried Milady. “What? Are you sure?”	326.6205225486223
“That she is called so? Yes, madame. Do you know her?”	195.17451793650517
Milady smiled to herself at the idea which had occurred to her that	286.9149764851635
this might be her old chambermaid. There was connected with the	274.7618163507323
remembrance of this girl a remembrance of anger; and a desire of	297.9107454064624
vengeance disordered the features of Milady, which, however,	307.79669298226656
immediately recovered the calm and benevolent expression which this	191.19380995180452
woman of a hundred faces had for a moment allowed them to lose.	361.82845152870505
“And when can I see this young lady, for whom I already feel so great a	258.90786210430167
sympathy?” asked Milady.	208.75219718760448
“Why, this evening,” said the abbess; “today even. But you have been	181.8693176399215
traveling these four days, as you told me yourself. This morning you	317.8204663659063
rose at five o’clock; you must stand in need of repose. Go to bed and	277.54490620740717
sleep; at dinnertime we will rouse you.”	221.13670429625296
Although Milady would very willingly have gone without sleep, sustained	255.27557713104778
as she was by all the excitements which a new adventure awakened in her	261.2101553053957
heart, ever thirsting for intrigues, she nevertheless accepted the	201.4996757298332
offer of the superior. During the last fifteen days she had experienced	271.1744309828225
so many and such various emotions that if her frame of iron was still	358.39824708060075
capable of supporting fatigue, her mind required repose.	269.1914510553692
She therefore took leave of the abbess, and went to bed, softly rocked	237.39650001901057
by the ideas of vengeance which the name of Kitty had naturally brought	222.56703809477744
to her thoughts. She remembered that almost unlimited promise which the	353.3106242494713
cardinal had given her if she succeeded in her enterprise. She had	267.59200558093767
succeeded; D’Artagnan was then in her power!	297.6988801891438
One thing alone frightened her; that was the remembrance of her	356.37076115256605
husband, the Comte de la Fère, whom she had believed dead, or at least	306.5419230824622
expatriated, and whom she found again in Athos—the best friend of	178.94872422541974
D’Artagnan.	219.7945413171707
But alas, if he was the friend of D’Artagnan, he must have lent him his	345.55525020522816
assistance in all the proceedings by whose aid the queen had defeated	199.38740053053098
the project of his Eminence; if he was the friend of D’Artagnan, he was	307.51013227717647
the enemy of the cardinal; and she doubtless would succeed in involving	240.77532407617707
him in the vengeance by which she hoped to destroy the young Musketeer.	274.15737803401976
All these hopes were so many sweet thoughts for Milady; so, rocked by	322.04688529094034
them, she soon fell asleep.	320.6102831699578
She was awakened by a soft voice which sounded at the foot of her bed.	173.2709173877974
She opened her eyes, and saw the abbess, accompanied by a young woman	326.4584550618864
with light hair and delicate complexion, who fixed upon her a look full	174.9440151900054
of benevolent curiosity.	181.32592438757115
The face of the young woman was entirely unknown to her. Each examined	357.89916163887654
the other with great attention, while exchanging the customary	317.30469260326714
compliments; both were very handsome, but of quite different styles of	271.13382796018055
beauty. Milady, however, smiled in observing that she excelled the	339.1671015729321
young woman by far in her high air and aristocratic bearing. It is true	326.0204673392012
that the habit of a novice, which the young woman wore, was not very	364.8862978697431
advantageous in a contest of this kind.	357.74017816472826
The abbess introduced them to each other. When this formality was	299.43206599472956
