ended, as her duties called her to chapel, she left the two young women	226.60926208837682
alone.	323.2598215929024
The novice, seeing Milady in bed, was about to follow the example of	247.77572938263864
the superior; but Milady stopped her.	242.80802980817867
“How, madame,” said she, “I have scarcely seen you, and you already	197.53155929284014
wish to deprive me of your company, upon which I had counted a little,	204.83944626214486
I must confess, for the time I have to pass here?”	320.24447497783433
“No, madame,” replied the novice, “only I thought I had chosen my time	339.6223116086201
ill; you were asleep, you are fatigued.”	313.34573967963547
“Well,” said Milady, “what can those who sleep wish for—a happy	335.026104015338
awakening? This awakening you have given me; allow me, then, to enjoy	188.9594742322827
it at my ease,” and taking her hand, she drew her toward the armchair	316.3935935537521
by the bedside.	324.89543881985514
The novice sat down.	270.85498588242586
“How unfortunate I am!” said she; “I have been here six months without	200.27705554697434
the shadow of recreation. You arrive, and your presence was likely to	268.48415552500387
afford me delightful company; yet I expect, in all probability, to quit	312.1997483793909
the convent at any moment.”	199.8768771914838
“How, you are going soon?” asked Milady.	188.0454986826102
“At least I hope so,” said the novice, with an expression of joy which	316.187417808913
she made no effort to disguise.	228.67583215908854
“I think I learned you had suffered persecutions from the cardinal,”	285.1188415144548
continued Milady; “that would have been another motive for sympathy	301.3619806679294
between us.”	339.1725824821592
“What I have heard, then, from our good mother is true; you have	318.83004122331624
likewise been a victim of that wicked priest.”	172.75663031290182
“Hush!” said Milady; “let us not, even here, speak thus of him. All my	351.44641035241307
misfortunes arise from my having said nearly what you have said before	364.67179163691503
a woman whom I thought my friend, and who betrayed me. Are you also the	222.97392471568278
victim of a treachery?”	173.63095255323645
“No,” said the novice, “but of my devotion—of a devotion to a woman I	191.7468872506033
loved, for whom I would have laid down my life, for whom I would give	209.73289646114046
it still.”	291.9615724836347
“And who has abandoned you—is that it?”	289.2779826650681
“I have been sufficiently unjust to believe so; but during the last two	351.7302382217356
or three days I have obtained proof to the contrary, for which I thank	277.44299086915765
God—for it would have cost me very dear to think she had forgotten me.	358.88066648507026
But you, madame, you appear to be free,” continued the novice; “and if	300.10507517445535
you were inclined to fly it only rests with yourself to do so.”	297.6729766304493
“Whither would you have me go, without friends, without money, in a	196.4219089400492
part of France with which I am unacquainted, and where I have never	283.58821526414636
been before?”	203.05138269260144
“Oh,” cried the novice, “as to friends, you would have them wherever	179.6186512014351
you want, you appear so good and are so beautiful!”	264.48717479872494
“That does not prevent,” replied Milady, softening her smile so as to	172.14369901716358
give it an angelic expression, “my being alone or being persecuted.”	317.5747777880615
“Hear me,” said the novice; “we must trust in heaven. There always	362.3431329673459
comes a moment when the good you have done pleads your cause before	321.55009830695906
God; and see, perhaps it is a happiness for you, humble and powerless	342.7293691803318
as I am, that you have met with me, for if I leave this place, well—I	175.47352491718084
have powerful friends, who, after having exerted themselves on my	179.06725682352533
account, may also exert themselves for you.”	297.885147685139
“Oh, when I said I was alone,” said Milady, hoping to make the novice	285.0745347456702
talk by talking of herself, “it is not for want of friends in high	260.78845653095624
places; but these friends themselves tremble before the cardinal. The	359.08435394861255
queen herself does not dare to oppose the terrible minister. I have	283.1522301705714
proof that her Majesty, notwithstanding her excellent heart, has more	245.39671003357103
than once been obliged to abandon to the anger of his Eminence persons	187.55580159112566
who had served her.”	326.21674534979076
“Trust me, madame; the queen may appear to have abandoned those	236.13307606846922
persons, but we must not put faith in appearances. The more they are	273.3018046769791
persecuted, the more she thinks of them; and often, when they least	352.90683233096485
expect it, they have proof of a kind remembrance.”	224.5447691756835
“Alas!” said Milady, “I believe so; the queen is so good!”	166.20502439736833
“Oh, you know her, then, that lovely and noble queen, that you speak of	178.68231434777894
her thus!” cried the novice, with enthusiasm.	270.66706886060183
“That is to say,” replied Milady, driven into her entrenchment, “that I	279.90600206797575
have not the honor of knowing her personally; but I know a great number	334.600750070354
of her most intimate friends. I am acquainted with Monsieur de Putange;	233.17284762927412
I met Monsieur Dujart in England; I know Monsieur de Tréville.”	241.93575377619493
“Monsieur de Tréville!” exclaimed the novice, “do you know Monsieur de	245.23121275769716
Tréville?”	350.44128019983054
“Yes, perfectly well—intimately even.”	315.55216313363644
“The captain of the king’s Musketeers?”	185.6088870021758
“The captain of the king’s Musketeers.”	262.34112747469885
“Why, then, only see!” cried the novice; “we shall soon be well	169.91492073497065
acquainted, almost friends. If you know Monsieur de Tréville, you must	247.87169024806167
have visited him?”	272.69744855354736
“Often!” said Milady, who, having entered this track, and perceiving	323.4989938543507
that falsehood succeeded, was determined to follow it to the end.	281.9939262290709
“With him, then, you must have seen some of his Musketeers?”	247.82881552765951
“All those he is in the habit of receiving!” replied Milady, for whom	174.09124832610104
this conversation began to have a real interest.	178.53872550018755
“Name a few of those whom you know, and you will see if they are my	240.22442483571447
friends.”	348.1927374764563
“Well!” said Milady, embarrassed, “I know Monsieur de Louvigny,	180.7955848809222
Monsieur de Courtivron, Monsieur de Ferussac.”	339.0522433287706
The novice let her speak, then seeing that she paused, she said, “Don’t	272.5911355469173
you know a gentleman named Athos?”	332.62545881566393
Milady became as pale as the sheets in which she was lying, and	200.52872246688733
mistress as she was of herself, could not help uttering a cry, seizing	315.69736557634656
the hand of the novice, and devouring her with looks.	304.7782528192172
“What is the matter? Good God!” asked the poor woman, “have I said	249.55862617237398
anything that has wounded you?”	170.6977643498062
“No; but the name struck me, because I also have known that gentleman,	242.36992936522927
and it appeared strange to me to meet with a person who appears to know	256.03520152155033
him well.”	311.9330971658131
“Oh, yes, very well; not only him, but some of his friends, Messieurs	306.7873883709998
Porthos and Aramis!”	348.9347241420668
“Indeed! you know them likewise? I know them,” cried Milady, who began	269.231337888694
to feel a chill penetrate her heart.	166.840573322725
“Well, if you know them, you know that they are good and free	286.1945069228212
companions. Why do you not apply to them, if you stand in need of	285.8879824620613
help?”	182.75458836229592
“That is to say,” stammered Milady, “I am not really very intimate with	168.6872796331308
any of them. I know them from having heard one of their friends,	226.4481940905896
Monsieur d’Artagnan, say a great deal about them.”	306.0567863116871
“You know Monsieur d’Artagnan!” cried the novice, in her turn seizing	182.64888465908555
the hands of Milady and devouring her with her eyes.	216.20477696187316
Then remarking the strange expression of Milady’s countenance, she	183.80761335874746
said, “Pardon me, madame; you know him by what title?”	327.7104943265532
“Why,” replied Milady, embarrassed, “why, by the title of friend.”	239.8149101596932
“You deceive me, madame,” said the novice; “you have been his	240.90089730112655
mistress!”	267.15842656017566
“It is you who have been his mistress, madame!” cried Milady, in her	360.5468591826385
turn.	283.01734730480905
“I?” said the novice.	300.0374369588835
“Yes, you! I know you now. You are Madame Bonacieux!”	262.7354484900957
The young woman drew back, filled with surprise and terror.	356.81386465473486
“Oh, do not deny it! Answer!” continued Milady.	335.78878202509713
“Well, yes, madame,” said the novice, “Are we rivals?”	334.805984287348
The countenance of Milady was illumined by so savage a joy that under	254.73340236185695
any other circumstances Mme. Bonacieux would have fled in terror; but	362.363048297407
she was absorbed by jealousy.	170.513481290478
“Speak, madame!” resumed Mme. Bonacieux, with an energy of which she	225.6996217938486
might not have been believed capable. “Have you been, or are you, his	285.76129643899435
mistress?”	317.21114905296326
“Oh, no!” cried Milady, with an accent that admitted no doubt of her	185.92517770073343
truth. “Never, never!”	214.88691049009185
“I believe you,” said Mme. Bonacieux; “but why, then, did you cry out	260.48102901422
so?”	299.3626301472123
“Do you not understand?” said Milady, who had already overcome her	182.28134390280428
agitation and recovered all her presence of mind.	260.0376661610346
“How can I understand? I know nothing.”	235.72692425041717
“Can you not understand that Monsieur d’Artagnan, being my friend,	361.9656548776113
might take me into his confidence?”	184.12196091532834
“Truly?”	219.87820790156215
“Do you not perceive that I know all—your abduction from the little	353.0711115938691
house at St. Germain, his despair, that of his friends, and their	252.2888436992969
useless inquiries up to this moment? How could I help being astonished	353.70025496262997
when, without having the least expectation of such a thing, I meet you	169.21707206114303
face to face—you, of whom we have so often spoken together, you whom he	272.1976569099238
loves with all his soul, you whom he had taught me to love before I had	241.62000233657153
seen you! Ah, dear Constance, I have found you, then; I see you at	226.58776211242883
last!”	168.0958346226841
And Milady stretched out her arms to Mme. Bonacieux, who, convinced by	297.8270933079085
what she had just said, saw nothing in this woman whom an instant	271.7406650870007
before she had believed her rival but a sincere and devoted friend.	235.94213415632674
“Oh, pardon me, pardon me!” cried she, sinking upon the shoulders of	233.74765670877343
Milady. “Pardon me, I love him so much!”	280.48837005611495
These two women held each other for an instant in a close embrace.	265.1434435296998
Certainly, if Milady’s strength had been equal to her hatred, Mme.	255.34144800482247
Bonacieux would never have left that embrace alive. But not being able	358.3358306427899
to stifle her, she smiled upon her.	203.07322693896083
“Oh, you beautiful, good little creature!” said Milady. “How delighted	208.41049471994205
I am to have found you! Let me look at you!” and while saying these	269.3004709177001
words, she absolutely devoured her by her looks. “Oh, yes it is you	305.07925165846177
indeed! From what he has told me, I know you now. I recognize you	319.2620254586849
perfectly.”	318.1246746239751
The poor young woman could not possibly suspect what frightful cruelty	206.46942205749951
was behind the rampart of that pure brow, behind those brilliant eyes	171.66441443041197
in which she read nothing but interest and compassion.	351.6152222930652
“Then you know what I have suffered,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “since he	212.04979150623325
has told you what he has suffered; but to suffer for him is happiness.”	333.4032713935173
Milady replied mechanically, “Yes, that is happiness.” She was thinking	271.08367778814886
of something else.	277.6842142427173
“And then,” continued Mme. Bonacieux, “my punishment is drawing to a	226.96185889808868
close. Tomorrow, this evening, perhaps, I shall see him again; and then	343.17825821863573
the past will no longer exist.”	206.922840679493
“This evening?” asked Milady, roused from her reverie by these words.	300.1001312641501
“What do you mean? Do you expect news from him?”	276.964701158828
“I expect himself.”	324.68346972799833
“Himself? D’Artagnan here?”	169.7038319884615
“Himself!”	289.3865027752284
“But that’s impossible! He is at the siege of La Rochelle with the	222.57670648529916
cardinal. He will not return till after the taking of the city.”	287.7517576159646
“Ah, you fancy so! But is there anything impossible for my D’Artagnan,	240.3560182985881
the noble and loyal gentleman?”	238.3901515775444
“Oh, I cannot believe you!”	268.47125118479573
“Well, read, then!” said the unhappy young woman, in the excess of her	312.8684298840094
pride and joy, presenting a letter to Milady.	227.08664022408936
“The writing of Madame de Chevreuse!” said Milady to herself. “Ah, I	316.8460754281921
always thought there was some secret understanding in that quarter!”	191.9635284320275
And she greedily read the following few lines:	265.377738811919
MY DEAR CHILD, Hold yourself ready. _Our friend_ will see you soon, and	189.08017394490338
he will only see you to release you from that imprisonment in which	296.0464660682718
your safety required you should be concealed. Prepare, then, for your	171.7974731900721
departure, and never despair of us.	170.16616378069253
    Our charming Gascon has just proved himself as brave and faithful	253.86838724853277
    as ever. Tell him that certain parties are grateful for the warning	350.1303907925743
    he has given.	266.7874435351652
“Yes, yes,” said Milady; “the letter is precise. Do you know what that	179.1554968364452
warning was?”	316.52897728239503
“No, I only suspect he has warned the queen against some fresh	364.7765000092355
machinations of the cardinal.”	321.4018060491714
“Yes, that’s it, no doubt!” said Milady, returning the letter to Mme.	289.633075797026
Bonacieux, and letting her head sink pensively upon her bosom.	280.918221226939
At that moment they heard the gallop of a horse.	208.77392193364946
“Oh!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, darting to the window, “can it be he?”	200.59310757619372
Milady remained still in bed, petrified by surprise; so many unexpected	258.6104229167751
things happened to her all at once that for the first time she was at a	285.1117234462266
loss.	194.38321637954516
“He, he!” murmured she; “can it be he?” And she remained in bed with	178.9993360437788
her eyes fixed.	213.33720561995295
“Alas, no!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “it is a man I don’t know, although he	230.08264341387348
seems to be coming here. Yes, he checks his pace; he stops at the gate;	224.46510126184114
he rings.”	181.28284292701903
Milady sprang out of bed.	327.3573042226825
“You are sure it is not he?” said she.	217.38707667656212
“Yes, yes, very sure!”	211.18338465767187
“Perhaps you did not see well.”	173.48473346883742
“Oh, if I were to see the plume of his hat, the end of his cloak, I	312.1027103398328
should know _him!_”	172.6160381790669
Milady was dressing herself all the time.	356.96875938144365
“Yes, he has entered.”	285.41044141761176
“It is for you or me!”	360.76534088316396
“My God, how agitated you seem!”	350.7095823010261
“Yes, I admit it. I have not your confidence; I fear the cardinal.”	309.6251161494107
“Hush!” said Mme. Bonacieux; “somebody is coming.”	197.04029160048245
Immediately the door opened, and the superior entered.	333.92207561653197
“Did you come from Boulogne?” demanded she of Milady.	316.0756022456261
“Yes,” replied she, trying to recover her self-possession. “Who wants	362.07578507465075
me?”	222.22752824474105
“A man who will not tell his name, but who comes from the cardinal.”	345.27751939100006
“And who wishes to speak with me?”	207.4021368505974
“Who wishes to speak to a lady recently come from Boulogne.”	187.8912322247399
“Then let him come in, if you please.”	245.37137139979484
“Oh, my God, my God!” cried Mme. Bonacieux. “Can it be bad news?”	293.79093085540717
“I fear it.”	289.73636722744425
“I will leave you with this stranger; but as soon as he is gone, if you	258.56135342278174
will permit me, I will return.”	210.3264655298554
“_Permit_ you? I _beseech_ you.”	222.8914802173443
The superior and Mme. Bonacieux retired.	221.81380803808204
Milady remained alone, with her eyes fixed upon the door. An instant	250.22820278688832
later, the jingling of spurs was heard upon the stairs, steps drew	360.4281016253981
near, the door opened, and a man appeared.	336.8103210560173
Milady uttered a cry of joy; this man was the Comte de Rochefort—the	293.26565549172204
demoniacal tool of his Eminence.	247.16472017643576
Chapter LXII.	214.83245845212153
TWO VARIETIES OF DEMONS	331.24232935277405
Ah,” cried Milady and Rochefort together, “it is you!”	344.8899424903343
“Yes, it is I.”	299.57091463964525
“And you come?” asked Milady.	340.7156219835723
“From La Rochelle; and you?”	173.33048479669606
“From England.”	280.13229313336103
“Buckingham?”	306.7607083672715
“Dead or desperately wounded, as I left without having been able to	187.7026473368286
hear anything of him. A fanatic has just assassinated him.”	183.27080974109205
“Ah,” said Rochefort, with a smile; “this is a fortunate chance—one	207.74472746807396
that will delight his Eminence! Have you informed him of it?”	344.8329349857004
“I wrote to him from Boulogne. But what brings you here?”	345.7667226095572
“His Eminence was uneasy, and sent me to find you.”	277.16913673094535
“I only arrived yesterday.”	270.3809167653144
“And what have you been doing since yesterday?”	316.43433857226046
“I have not lost my time.”	254.0282639088748
“Oh, I don’t doubt that.”	207.93462889394817
“Do you know whom I have encountered here?”	178.44827633554397
“No.”	213.4730395135618
“Guess.”	193.86648559220532
“How can I?”	277.743247553504
“That young woman whom the queen took out of prison.”	219.17716569132506
“The mistress of that fellow D’Artagnan?”	333.1620602970725
“Yes; Madame Bonacieux, with whose retreat the cardinal was	195.48657659900212
unacquainted.”	228.42105731605537
“Well, well,” said Rochefort, “here is a chance which may pair off with	206.7567657087979
the other! Monsieur Cardinal is indeed a privileged man!”	267.88600084308155
“Imagine my astonishment,” continued Milady, “when I found myself face	365.2312199669788
to face with this woman!”	209.41161784855558
“Does she know you?”	258.75483806463586
“No.”	302.3203612666864
“Then she looks upon you as a stranger?”	240.85126067642784
Milady smiled. “I am her best friend.”	250.9750864287796
“Upon my honor,” said Rochefort, “it takes you, my dear countess, to	268.8032949512443
perform such miracles!”	209.1665910584219
“And it is well I can, Chevalier,” said Milady, “for do you know what	175.76970195923744
is going on here?”	255.42503216000352
“No.”	315.28523707065233
“They will come for her tomorrow or the day after, with an order from	206.2093983254418
the queen.”	316.89307487900675
“Indeed! And who?”	243.59964196529495
“D’Artagnan and his friends.”	190.48816294780784
“Indeed, they will go so far that we shall be obliged to send them to	217.80223240957466
the Bastille.”	176.00769414718724
“Why is it not done already?”	189.6134068044202
“What would you? The cardinal has a weakness for these men which I	360.5490829679312
cannot comprehend.”	222.35068533609098
“Indeed!”	290.6624502279193
“Yes.”	310.38234596942175
“Well, then, tell him this, Rochefort. Tell him that our conversation	301.91381518178315
at the inn of the Red Dovecot was overheard by these four men; tell him	274.5223439602892
that after his departure one of them came up to me and took from me by	272.03878293106675
violence the safe-conduct which he had given me; tell him they warned	349.1697263871928
Lord de Winter of my journey to England; that this time they nearly	330.73869784494855
foiled my mission as they foiled the affair of the studs; tell him that	329.3768153392549
among these four men two only are to be feared—D’Artagnan and Athos;	311.9193182093853
tell him that the third, Aramis, is the lover of Madame de Chevreuse—he	300.2199982012793
may be left alone, we know his secret, and it may be useful; as to the	347.1427556149847
fourth, Porthos, he is a fool, a simpleton, a blustering booby, not	331.4752111194582
worth troubling himself about.”	166.2406169870558
“But these four men must be now at the siege of La Rochelle?”	330.30256436881587
“I thought so, too; but a letter which Madame Bonacieux has received	251.2801497363327
from Madame the Constable, and which she has had the imprudence to show	224.94621633353592
me, leads me to believe that these four men, on the contrary, are on	335.02675377240246
the road hither to take her away.”	363.68333818457745
“The devil! What’s to be done?”	242.46416317755575
“What did the cardinal say about me?”	243.0738635428632
“I was to take your dispatches, written or verbal, and return by post;	237.44926340053064
and when he shall know what you have done, he will advise what you have	275.7548381708557
to do.”	291.8908869424501
“I must, then, remain here?”	269.0740361532461
“Here, or in the neighborhood.”	214.8039527779681
“You cannot take me with you?”	310.3799358883655
“No, the order is imperative. Near the camp you might be recognized;	286.7230573792815
and your presence, you must be aware, would compromise the cardinal.”	283.48730530919573
“Then I must wait here, or in the neighborhood?”	188.88074291822068
“Only tell me beforehand where you will wait for intelligence from the	315.3029283067618
cardinal; let me know always where to find you.”	307.51063163369423
“Observe, it is probable that I may not be able to remain here.”	192.11167931512566
“Why?”	284.0294971713374
“You forget that my enemies may arrive at any minute.”	356.68435636683375
“That’s true; but is this little woman, then, to escape his Eminence?”	208.90875971621963
“Bah!” said Milady, with a smile that belonged only to herself; “you	175.95242211875816
forget that I am her best friend.”	357.5725470766406
“Ah, that’s true! I may then tell the cardinal, with respect to this	321.1969920342279
little woman—”	247.81001480796766
“That he may be at ease.”	291.7501256283049
“Is that all?”	230.19993731263526
“He will know what that means.”	297.9234860836907
“He will guess, at least. Now, then, what had I better do?”	185.2131698144995
“Return instantly. It appears to me that the news you bear is worth the	268.52767115223094
trouble of a little diligence.”	202.95754528847013
“My chaise broke down coming into Lilliers.”	222.75317639081152
“Capital!”	337.9432264279077
“What, _capital?_”	329.4122513312915
“Yes, I want your chaise.”	289.25603459988486
“And how shall I travel, then?”	301.2524552282265
“On horseback.”	309.6390310682062
“You talk very comfortably,—a hundred and eighty leagues!”	329.28692359137256
“What’s that?”	275.3683464094278
“One can do it! Afterward?”	234.90639551842025
“Afterward? Why, in passing through Lilliers you will send me your	216.1595766336125
chaise, with an order to your servant to place himself at my disposal.”	281.382691428658
“Well.”	259.6934980867063
“You have, no doubt, some order from the cardinal about you?”	198.80596248711004
“I have my _full power_.”	328.15416032756605
“Show it to the abbess, and tell her that someone will come and fetch	318.59506641941636
me, either today or tomorrow, and that I am to follow the person who	353.3068579545343
presents himself in your name.”	177.40653453636168
“Very well.”	188.73974935943704
“Don’t forget to treat me harshly in speaking of me to the abbess.”	197.0882910715135
“To what purpose?”	283.3977646130194
“I am a victim of the cardinal. It is necessary to inspire confidence	280.0168114501065
in that poor little Madame Bonacieux.”	312.5780696016534
“That’s true. Now, will you make me a report of all that has happened?”	345.39056923745335
“Why, I have related the events to you. You have a good memory; repeat	240.4626638935094
what I have told you. A paper may be lost.”	306.87707236346944
“You are right; only let me know where to find you that I may not run	232.12172229605596
needlessly about the neighborhood.”	302.21732831128077
“That’s correct; wait!”	203.99789795618386
“Do you want a map?”	321.37230822154083
“Oh, I know this country marvelously!”	264.3568481717386
“You? When were you here?”	327.4864640092682
“I was brought up here.”	224.75833684263364
“Truly?”	206.67480436093456
“It is worth something, you see, to have been brought up somewhere.”	304.9059003262661
“You will wait for me, then?”	330.7217405822106
“Let me reflect a little! Ay, that will do—at Armentières.”	301.2352407366502
“Where is that Armentières?”	304.5602541728516
“A little town on the Lys; I shall only have to cross the river, and I	321.78627878696864
shall be in a foreign country.”	277.069484737193
“Capital! but it is understood you will only cross the river in case of	246.90133795695806
danger.”	189.18431586241744
“That is well understood.”	292.81291598724204
“And in that case, how shall I know where you are?”	334.4246568427027
“You do not want your lackey?”	236.5728581333441
“Is he a sure man?”	318.0527417420292
“To the proof.”	257.2640680997183
“Give him to me. Nobody knows him. I will leave him at the place I	225.85203330008864
quit, and he will conduct you to me.”	319.4713805212943
“And you say you will wait for me at Armentières?”	288.0880638357354
“At Armentières.”	222.24909895612743
“Write that name on a bit of paper, lest I should forget it. There is	341.7369378706744
nothing compromising in the name of a town. Is it not so?”	190.55067897200394
“Eh, who knows? Never mind,” said Milady, writing the name on half a	353.40333673439716
sheet of paper; “I will compromise myself.”	299.31203853286286
“Well,” said Rochefort, taking the paper from Milady, folding it, and	216.37476085361703
placing it in the lining of his hat, “you may be easy. I will do as	203.00893392219155
children do, for fear of losing the paper—repeat the name along the	356.4354650705233
route. Now, is that all?”	320.8129691315938
“I believe so.”	227.26064905847977
“Let us see: Buckingham dead or grievously wounded; your conversation	273.1439178413236
with the cardinal overheard by the four Musketeers; Lord de Winter	316.4371778455085
warned of your arrival at Portsmouth; D’Artagnan and Athos to the	270.37205372505065
Bastille; Aramis the lover of Madame de Chevreuse; Porthos an ass;	242.14845340929412
Madame Bonacieux found again; to send you the chaise as soon as	198.12532326879617
possible; to place my lackey at your disposal; to make you out a victim	199.21732401825406
of the cardinal in order that the abbess may entertain no suspicion;	251.9664165579267
Armentières, on the banks of the Lys. Is that all, then?”	354.09000191528287
“In truth, my dear Chevalier, you are a miracle of memory. _A propos_,	211.1965355768433
add one thing—”	231.1067591882602
“What?”	280.2402637956785
“I saw some very pretty woods which almost touch the convent garden.	291.50324643064874
Say that I am permitted to walk in those woods. Who knows? Perhaps I	320.2754598451052
shall stand in need of a back door for retreat.”	287.04497569702505
“You think of everything.”	195.30518751742585
“And you forget one thing.”	200.60648863701556
“What?”	296.7095181095075
“To ask me if I want money.”	252.1073909897865
“That’s true. How much do you want?”	221.4357903736226
“All you have in gold.”	249.545561770985
“I have five hundred pistoles, or thereabouts.”	174.10619649832444
“I have as much. With a thousand pistoles one may face everything.	178.3378773925309
Empty your pockets.”	298.36284312520104
“There.”	186.7093364609779
“Right. And you go—”	169.78639752593483
“In an hour—time to eat a morsel, during which I shall send for a post	281.4072512143175
horse.”	206.6358966068758
“Capital! Adieu, Chevalier.”	299.22850511083124
“Adieu, Countess.”	191.0849204289919
“Commend me to the cardinal.”	360.5990943697227
“Commend me to Satan.”	248.43166089827614
Milady and Rochefort exchanged a smile and separated. An hour afterward	296.3098263956051
Rochefort set out at a grand gallop; five hours after that he passed	299.77599743581936
through Arras.	229.92632338938074
Our readers already know how he was recognized by D’Artagnan, and how	349.70215196589317
that recognition by inspiring fear in the four Musketeers had given	351.037623789808
fresh activity to their journey.	278.0634631146402
Chapter LXIII.	336.5167742106979
THE DROP OF WATER	304.8537952133015
Rochefort had scarcely departed when Mme. Bonacieux re-entered. She	222.81468643354165
found Milady with a smiling countenance.	252.79614726431976
“Well,” said the young woman, “what you dreaded has happened. This	234.0909195105885
evening, or tomorrow, the cardinal will send someone to take you away.”	338.4125115409181
“Who told you that, my dear?” asked Milady.	190.01840157516796
“I heard it from the mouth of the messenger himself.”	221.58676623877304
“Come and sit down close to me,” said Milady.	274.2613340176637
“Here I am.”	335.8527953685243
“Wait till I assure myself that nobody hears us.”	356.0324039946091
“Why all these precautions?”	201.7360623803533
“You shall know.”	316.2608474125815
Milady arose, went to the door, opened it, looked in the corridor, and	257.2668084598598
then returned and seated herself close to Mme. Bonacieux.	227.23287497255166
“Then,” said she, “he has well played his part.”	348.13621969807093
“Who has?”	238.39174316471906
“He who just now presented himself to the abbess as a messenger from	224.98721599826624
the cardinal.”	260.80399410673283
“It was, then, a part he was playing?”	325.1915843883106
“Yes, my child.”	232.7891024343134
“That man, then, was not—”	278.9743253439008
“That man,” said Milady, lowering her voice, “is my brother.”	357.2771427009503
“Your brother!” cried Mme. Bonacieux.	350.96163099298485
“No one must know this secret, my dear, but yourself. If you reveal it	226.48108610580016
to anyone in the world, I shall be lost, and perhaps yourself	332.159162740664
likewise.”	251.54416055368893
“Oh, my God!”	309.3526098279619
“Listen. This is what has happened: My brother, who was coming to my	267.0138874548444
assistance to take me away by force if it were necessary, met with the	192.97084351053508
emissary of the cardinal, who was coming in search of me. He followed	189.4520812587131
him. At a solitary and retired part of the road he drew his sword, and	277.10493131674014
required the messenger to deliver up to him the papers of which he was	254.03596964440928
the bearer. The messenger resisted; my brother killed him.”	261.16310439463183
“Oh!” said Mme. Bonacieux, shuddering.	206.92875151676128
“Remember, that was the only means. Then my brother determined to	349.1010151610124
substitute cunning for force. He took the papers, and presented himself	299.7116896275348
here as the emissary of the cardinal, and in an hour or two a carriage	343.56893696375244
will come to take me away by the orders of his Eminence.”	359.71265438295313
“I understand. It is your brother who sends this carriage.”	231.69950931668444
“Exactly; but that is not all. That letter you have received, and which	196.90225740709573
you believe to be from Madame de Chevreuse—”	303.7486019749458
“Well?”	348.4176947993691
“It is a forgery.”	267.7470823954159
“How can that be?”	345.4195712648559
“Yes, a forgery; it is a snare to prevent your making any resistance	325.87319736831375
when they come to fetch you.”	290.50476968812507
“But it is D’Artagnan that will come.”	347.14634078545095
“Do not deceive yourself. D’Artagnan and his friends are detained at	362.08579630175973
the siege of La Rochelle.”	206.1857014209688
“How do you know that?”	248.92636023853308
“My brother met some emissaries of the cardinal in the uniform of	168.40852082079766
Musketeers. You would have been summoned to the gate; you would have	323.3795621601102
believed yourself about to meet friends; you would have been abducted,	182.41588382091524
and conducted back to Paris.”	300.8472787286853
“Oh, my God! My senses fail me amid such a chaos of iniquities. I feel,	212.26924932862238
if this continues,” said Mme. Bonacieux, raising her hands to her	280.26384901314555
forehead, “I shall go mad!”	186.716040645566
“Stop—”	212.52499434383503
“What?”	212.0991802266526
“I hear a horse’s steps; it is my brother setting off again. I should	361.18518864452824
like to offer him a last salute. Come!”	357.95166215113994
Milady opened the window, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to join	296.45822714191576
her. The young woman complied.	218.20876276306853
Rochefort passed at a gallop.	182.31367560045632
“Adieu, brother!” cried Milady.	279.1900525795562
The chevalier raised his head, saw the two young women, and without	259.7379460514579
stopping, waved his hand in a friendly way to Milady.	299.5032194469753
“The good George!” said she, closing the window with an expression of	302.46994725139757
countenance full of affection and melancholy. And she resumed her seat,	174.9900669982349
as if plunged in reflections entirely personal.	263.2548371139171
“Dear lady,” said Mme. Bonacieux, “pardon me for interrupting you; but	183.63519444706486
what do you advise me to do? Good heaven! You have more experience than	280.64287692454883
I have. Speak; I will listen.”	321.1653058729067
“In the first place,” said Milady, “it is possible I may be deceived,	272.5920043169487
and that D’Artagnan and his friends may really come to your	279.92125991225794
assistance.”	338.97939554141954
“Oh, that would be too much!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “so much happiness	312.22032273228257
is not in store for me!”	233.3301797160818
“Then you comprehend it would be only a question of time, a sort of	176.74139136405685
race, which should arrive first. If your friends are the more speedy,	230.2387408203224
you are to be saved; if the satellites of the cardinal, you are lost.”	355.77417899420766
“Oh, yes, yes; lost beyond redemption! What, then, to do? What to do?”	166.0747184221023
“There would be a very simple means, very natural—”	293.4060378481592
“Tell me what!”	207.49411374365073
“To wait, concealed in the neighborhood, and assure yourself who are	258.45444434136243
the men who come to ask for you.”	327.2154624574418
“But where can I wait?”	168.4775908446172
“Oh, there is no difficulty in that. I shall stop and conceal myself a	323.3606110877125
few leagues hence until my brother can rejoin me. Well, I take you with	190.37524114240762
me; we conceal ourselves, and wait together.”	194.18274474669195
“But I shall not be allowed to go; I am almost a prisoner.”	263.4622182428849
“As they believe that I go in consequence of an order from the	351.4068050662928
cardinal, no one will believe you anxious to follow me.”	313.3741494219911
“Well?”	351.76799940868324
“Well! The carriage is at the door; you bid me adieu; you mount the	291.84015460615615
step to embrace me a last time; my brother’s servant, who comes to	174.88019607854278
fetch me, is told how to proceed; he makes a sign to the postillion,	166.83891464002784
and we set off at a gallop.”	296.20095320816506
“But D’Artagnan! D’Artagnan! if he comes?”	317.40992643213315
“Shall we not know it?”	210.737725164461
“How?”	308.71215210240183
“Nothing easier. We will send my brother’s servant back to Béthune,	293.6869706818472
whom, as I told you, we can trust. He shall assume a disguise, and	307.6553288030947
place himself in front of the convent. If the emissaries of the	334.6207084278923
cardinal arrive, he will take no notice; if it is Monsieur d’Artagnan	177.49269702256808
and his friends, he will bring them to us.”	317.8794222852914
“He knows them, then?”	229.97239960650157
“Doubtless. Has he not seen Monsieur d’Artagnan at my house?”	355.84021904335555
“Oh, yes, yes; you are right. Thus all may go well—all may be for the	229.54970694015373
best; but we do not go far from this place?”	219.7563755190912
“Seven or eight leagues at the most. We will keep on the frontiers, for	279.6666004625054
instance; and at the first alarm we can leave France.”	260.45062103172063
“And what can we do there?”	284.71917081145244
“Wait.”	240.44555891009912
“But if they come?”	169.28983084776704
“My brother’s carriage will be here first.”	219.79008677105168
“If I should happen to be any distance from you when the carriage comes	354.10443647494736
for you—at dinner or supper, for instance?”	192.4048287242402
“Do one thing.”	247.5006008910773
“What is that?”	258.8202847023037
“Tell your good superior that in order that we may be as much together	309.3472943804527
as possible, you ask her permission to share my repast.”	342.18011625731833
“Will she permit it?”	214.77105452551388
“What inconvenience can it be?”	199.31427860814372
“Oh, delightful! In this way we shall not be separated for an instant.”	355.2761054078833
“Well, go down to her, then, to make your request. I feel my head a	249.0474107292341
little confused; I will take a turn in the garden.”	237.48389832412857
“Go; and where shall I find you?”	278.6416105849994
“Here, in an hour.”	358.3890314526533
“Here, in an hour. Oh, you are so kind, and I am so grateful!”	214.28711756115416
“How can I avoid interesting myself for one who is so beautiful and so	283.3790212755126
amiable? Are you not the beloved of one of my best friends?”	279.2883440321691
“Dear D’Artagnan! Oh, how he will thank you!”	260.0049908692271
“I hope so. Now, then, all is agreed; let us go down.”	191.57478592048892
“You are going into the garden?”	286.5784411677705
“Yes.”	356.2782109293229
“Go along this corridor, down a little staircase, and you are in it.”	229.20212805204164
“Excellent; thank you!”	227.94055964192893
And the two women parted, exchanging charming smiles.	211.4178603632194
Milady had told the truth—her head was confused, for her ill-arranged	211.06911710295003
plans clashed one another like chaos. She required to be alone that she	208.78727968103217
might put her thoughts a little into order. She saw vaguely the future;	236.01727258703954
but she stood in need of a little silence and quiet to give all her	266.57756349499033
ideas, as yet confused, a distinct form and a regular plan.	238.7207339389335
What was most pressing was to get Mme. Bonacieux away, and convey her	365.0640720532751
to a place of safety, and there, if matters required, make her a	200.45527756175431
hostage. Milady began to have doubts of the issue of this terrible	236.45368547413705
duel, in which her enemies showed as much perseverance as she did	222.49811582866528
animosity.	196.8484811125721
Besides, she felt as we feel when a storm is coming on—that this issue	304.5006679802399
was near, and could not fail to be terrible.	220.93212843646558
The principal thing for her, then, was, as we have said, to keep Mme.	256.88970834055755
Bonacieux in her power. Mme. Bonacieux was the very life of D’Artagnan.	277.2232093797263
This was more than his life, the life of the woman he loved; this was,	193.166827763597
in case of ill fortune, a means of temporizing and obtaining good	235.43097191897945
conditions.	184.4520270412216
Now, this point was settled; Mme. Bonacieux, without any suspicion,	297.8600896315004
accompanied her. Once concealed with her at Armentières, it would be	167.78732611941635
easy to make her believe that D’Artagnan had not come to Béthune. In	310.6824574766576
fifteen days at most, Rochefort would be back; besides, during that	181.012656101339
fifteen days she would have time to think how she could best avenge	250.74427259028744
herself on the four friends. She would not be weary, thank God! for she	243.23719357258358
should enjoy the sweetest pastime such events could accord a woman of	286.1107449445956
her character—perfecting a beautiful vengeance.	168.5366361279322
Revolving all this in her mind, she cast her eyes around her, and	320.5752034936785
arranged the topography of the garden in her head. Milady was like a	208.25803955448615
good general who contemplates at the same time victory and defeat, and	280.8944827146929
who is quite prepared, according to the chances of the battle, to march	339.2058991809015
forward or to beat a retreat.	278.6465352965062
At the end of an hour she heard a soft voice calling her; it was Mme.	272.95658446043296
Bonacieux’s. The good abbess had naturally consented to her request;	254.84031275452725
and as a commencement, they were to sup together.	251.73756373612065
On reaching the courtyard, they heard the noise of a carriage which	303.60767736918797
stopped at the gate.	239.28869242069007
Milady listened.	306.3479193741786
“Do you hear anything?” said she.	311.82478492239477
“Yes, the rolling of a carriage.”	352.9388278987981
“It is the one my brother sends for us.”	302.6129437446459
“Oh, my God!”	245.13054654113552
“Come, come! courage!”	334.41382324567155
The bell of the convent gate was sounded; Milady was not mistaken.	212.42195217734348
“Go to your chamber,” said she to Mme. Bonacieux; “you have perhaps	338.18139056684123
some jewels you would like to take.”	302.16632345258665
“I have his letters,” said she.	285.3535750711842
“Well, go and fetch them, and come to my apartment. We will snatch some	246.5315059143339
supper; we shall perhaps travel part of the night, and must keep our	269.1695701164
strength up.”	169.25896440985946
“Great God!” said Mme. Bonacieux, placing her hand upon her bosom, “my	327.1463952091403
heart beats so I cannot walk.”	345.9656505909301
“Courage, courage! remember that in a quarter of an hour you will be	301.94324612648745
safe; and think that what you are about to do is for _his_ sake.”	213.73330231314756
“Yes, yes, everything for him. You have restored my courage by a single	182.75243659308748
word; go, I will rejoin you.”	275.6412273582148
Milady ran up to her apartment quickly; she there found Rochefort’s	327.8588567242873
lackey, and gave him his instructions.	243.839473980219
He was to wait at the gate; if by chance the Musketeers should appear,	304.05238947997736
the carriage was to set off as fast as possible, pass around the	363.218220368204
convent, and go and wait for Milady at a little village which was	212.98210022026035
situated at the other side of the wood. In this case Milady would cross	195.4058050291378
the garden and gain the village on foot. As we have already said,	187.26481169049092
Milady was admirably acquainted with this part of France.	359.868313939425
If the Musketeers did not appear, things were to go on as had been	246.7364966970355
agreed; Mme. Bonacieux was to get into the carriage as if to bid her	206.55483235046037
adieu, and she was to take away Mme. Bonacieux.	345.5572365030342
Mme. Bonacieux came in; and to remove all suspicion, if she had any,	167.45140616879632
Milady repeated to the lackey, before her, the latter part of her	167.98459623311277
instructions.	200.08149072961655
Milady asked some questions about the carriage. It was a chaise drawn	274.7964579403865
by three horses, driven by a postillion; Rochefort’s lackey would	321.50884351552327
precede it, as courier.	211.68351005431896
Milady was wrong in fearing that Mme. Bonacieux would have any	272.22656889537427
suspicion. The poor young woman was too pure to suppose that any female	196.17794440431086
could be guilty of such perfidy; besides, the name of the Comtesse de	359.92184199472393
Winter, which she had heard the abbess pronounce, was wholly unknown to	216.55549995080926
her, and she was even ignorant that a woman had had so great and so	220.75855437600114
fatal a share in the misfortune of her life.	328.70405280848877
“You see,” said she, when the lackey had gone out, “everything is	340.3542686259054
ready. The abbess suspects nothing, and believes that I am taken by	275.3648072760871
order of the cardinal. This man goes to give his last orders; take the	341.5170855719763
least thing, drink a finger of wine, and let us be gone.”	347.259934895533
“Yes,” said Mme. Bonacieux, mechanically, “yes, let us be gone.”	220.29790085464464
Milady made her a sign to sit down opposite, poured her a small glass	278.688937796577
of Spanish wine, and helped her to the wing of a chicken.	201.52110895288388
“See,” said she, “if everything does not second us! Here is night	249.537708858316
coming on; by daybreak we shall have reached our retreat, and nobody	324.84880972163256
can guess where we are. Come, courage! take something.”	264.3608769872694
Mme. Bonacieux ate a few mouthfuls mechanically, and just touched the	345.20678886405
glass with her lips.	308.78813453452415
“Come, come!” said Milady, lifting hers to her mouth, “do as I do.”	266.6249706269354
But at the moment the glass touched her lips, her hand remained	282.26784033075916
suspended; she heard something on the road which sounded like the	303.5245253600209
rattling of a distant gallop. Then it grew nearer, and it seemed to	325.00554012548804
her, almost at the same time, that she heard the neighing of horses.	200.41768835271742
This noise acted upon her joy like the storm which awakens the sleeper	178.1310416628637
in the midst of a happy dream; she grew pale and ran to the window,	336.0293208174266
while Mme. Bonacieux, rising all in a tremble, supported herself upon	225.29161227467324
her chair to avoid falling. Nothing was yet to be seen, only they heard	355.47336300177517
the galloping draw nearer.	195.4411561473096
“Oh, my God!” said Mme. Bonacieux, “what is that noise?”	303.19597998493487
“That of either our friends or our enemies,” said Milady, with her	319.8803022025651
terrible coolness. “Stay where you are, I will tell you.”	231.7914937524882
Mme. Bonacieux remained standing, mute, motionless, and pale as a	188.0244579566119
statue.	245.15637371589418
The noise became louder; the horses could not be more than a hundred	309.4828793262216
and fifty paces distant. If they were not yet to be seen, it was	296.0055773624717
because the road made an elbow. The noise became so distinct that the	217.54389956973552
horses might be counted by the rattle of their hoofs.	269.2489650493645
Milady gazed with all the power of her attention; it was just light	342.821009004385
enough for her to see who was coming.	286.9744901009091
All at once, at the turning of the road she saw the glitter of laced	216.8247331003626
hats and the waving of feathers; she counted two, then five, then eight	259.25457281535705
horsemen. One of them preceded the rest by double the length of his	228.7535913398372
horse.	297.8006362881838
Milady uttered a stifled groan. In the first horseman she recognized	200.02268636591452
D’Artagnan.	342.80026876981265
“Oh, my God, my God,” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “what is it?”	170.82834638629905
“It is the uniform of the cardinal’s Guards. Not an instant to be lost!	195.10580465504546
Fly, fly!”	350.91711810072275
“Yes, yes, let us fly!” repeated Mme. Bonacieux, but without being able	327.4938014596926
to make a step, glued as she was to the spot by terror.	172.37654391278818
They heard the horsemen pass under the windows.	314.79200582104437
“Come, then, come, then!” cried Milady, trying to drag the young woman	186.10887664132366
along by the arm. “Thanks to the garden, we yet can flee; I have the	261.3227446155302
key, but make haste! in five minutes it will be too late!”	227.2907049083273
Mme. Bonacieux tried to walk, made two steps, and sank upon her knees.	277.50633116196263
Milady tried to raise and carry her, but could not do it.	259.067070427845
At this moment they heard the rolling of the carriage, which at the	192.9094283971508
approach of the Musketeers set off at a gallop. Then three or four	221.4819253468386
shots were fired.	194.92017114839825
“For the last time, will you come?” cried Milady.	363.02517186537665
“Oh, my God, my God! you see my strength fails me; you see plainly I	228.62184833359797
cannot walk. Flee alone!”	278.7291549307761
“Flee alone, and leave you here? No, no, never!” cried Milady.	359.6639439033487
All at once she paused, a livid flash darted from her eyes; she ran to	305.8338665823993
the table, emptied into Mme. Bonacieux’s glass the contents of a ring	331.23841176242564
which she opened with singular quickness. It was a grain of a reddish	245.73001523707507
color, which dissolved immediately.	291.38602301562014
Then, taking the glass with a firm hand, she said, “Drink. This wine	316.2691610003068
will give you strength, drink!” And she put the glass to the lips of	180.5970170926198
the young woman, who drank mechanically.	178.66640091643646
“This is not the way that I wished to avenge myself,” said Milady,	260.30299891058485
replacing the glass upon the table, with an infernal smile, “but, my	214.20069993504143
faith! we do what we can!” And she rushed out of the room.	364.5887494361228
Mme. Bonacieux saw her go without being able to follow her; she was	229.07790404665468
like people who dream they are pursued, and who in vain try to walk.	305.55500017335504
A few moments passed; a great noise was heard at the gate. Every	294.2304253985135
instant Mme. Bonacieux expected to see Milady, but she did not return.	225.68554310051948
Several times, with terror, no doubt, the cold sweat burst from her	244.82698538888548
burning brow.	253.14114709022684
At length she heard the grating of the hinges of the opening gates; the	273.20022078715596
noise of boots and spurs resounded on the stairs. There was a great	172.5698760651971
murmur of voices which continued to draw near, amid which she seemed to	292.15513049979927
hear her own name pronounced.	333.57945886002517
All at once she uttered a loud cry of joy, and darted toward the door;	327.38703402673696
she had recognized the voice of D’Artagnan.	229.56864174919568
“D’Artagnan! D’Artagnan!” cried she, “is it you? This way! this way!”	356.19215167212997
“Constance? Constance?” replied the young man, “where are you? where	269.3647170056703
are you? My God!”	247.12752083169943
At the same moment the door of the cell yielded to a shock, rather than	191.3633922663228
opened; several men rushed into the chamber. Mme. Bonacieux had sunk	264.6574954909959
into an armchair, without the power of moving.	329.3070073522969
D’Artagnan threw down a yet-smoking pistol which he held in his hand,	262.3713697002834
and fell on his knees before his mistress. Athos replaced his in his	334.2520691207082
belt; Porthos and Aramis, who held their drawn swords in their hands,	290.9258500883961
returned them to their scabbards.	316.63093694894087
“Oh, D’Artagnan, my beloved D’Artagnan! You have come, then, at last!	273.47252590981225
You have not deceived me! It is indeed thee!”	298.26858047816154
“Yes, yes, Constance. Reunited!”	337.3405369354832
“Oh, it was in vain she told me you would not come! I hoped in silence.	297.11339646101874
I was not willing to fly. Oh, I have done well! How happy I am!”	355.8845861283581
At this word _she_, Athos, who had seated himself quietly, started up.	277.46524216292016
“_She!_ What she?” asked D’Artagnan.	348.2853541815539
“Why, my companion. She who out of friendship for me wished to take me	312.04042853725036
from my persecutors. She who, mistaking you for the cardinal’s Guards,	225.67835033066433
has just fled away.”	316.26314223191673
“Your companion!” cried D’Artagnan, becoming more pale than the white	232.62602171754915
veil of his mistress. “Of what companion are you speaking, dear	245.33008221019315
Constance?”	340.1914669864801
“Of her whose carriage was at the gate; of a woman who calls herself	202.47948132727112
your friend; of a woman to whom you have told everything.”	218.01636495164402
“Her name, her name!” cried D’Artagnan. “My God, can you not remember	261.3460967041737
her name?”	314.3465286083558
“Yes, it was pronounced in my hearing once. Stop—but—it is very	284.4758483434135
strange—oh, my God, my head swims! I cannot see!”	228.4928742672895
“Help, help, my friends! her hands are icy cold,” cried D’Artagnan.	239.9369559415814
“She is ill! Great God, she is losing her senses!”	353.67877813177245
While Porthos was calling for help with all the power of his strong	258.35303746603137
voice, Aramis ran to the table to get a glass of water; but he stopped	284.6140785492199
at seeing the horrible alteration that had taken place in the	263.48182624684534
countenance of Athos, who, standing before the table, his hair rising	282.7018076851315
from his head, his eyes fixed in stupor, was looking at one of the	322.4680137141698
glasses, and appeared a prey to the most horrible doubt.	192.79069910181278
“Oh!” said Athos, “oh, no, it is impossible! God would not permit such	333.07308789563416
a crime!”	277.34734486820116
“Water, water!” cried D’Artagnan. “Water!”	364.8959838549398
“Oh, poor woman, poor woman!” murmured Athos, in a broken voice.	319.40285755429625
Mme. Bonacieux opened her eyes under the kisses of D’Artagnan.	261.4903179156996
“She revives!” cried the young man. “Oh, my God, my God, I thank thee!”	183.3850829359496
“Madame!” said Athos, “madame, in the name of heaven, whose empty glass	200.70320369978185
is this?”	353.23461706946205
“Mine, monsieur,” said the young woman, in a dying voice.	245.73578383607057
“But who poured the wine for you that was in this glass?”	227.55812335258975
“She.”	238.2787928926137
“But who is _she?_”	179.2312708874699
“Oh, I remember!” said Mme. Bonacieux, “the Comtesse de Winter.”	169.91147835415103
The four friends uttered one and the same cry, but that of Athos	245.1610890705599
dominated all the rest.	349.2312266255508
At that moment the countenance of Mme. Bonacieux became livid; a	248.41288806345796
fearful agony pervaded her frame, and she sank panting into the arms of	194.29610011560123
Porthos and Aramis.	247.15955842399637
D’Artagnan seized the hands of Athos with an anguish difficult to be	267.3459266572607
described.	338.88043842056675
“And what do you believe?” His voice was stifled by sobs.	198.16410836415918
“I believe everything,” said Athos, biting his lips till the blood	321.88277443260324
sprang to avoid sighing.	196.82740541191566
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan!” cried Mme. Bonacieux, “where art thou? Do not	220.03650983629635
leave me! You see I am dying!”	275.25536930593614
D’Artagnan released the hands of Athos which he still held clasped in	315.5100602303712
both his own, and hastened to her. Her beautiful face was distorted	236.77498576148804
with agony; her glassy eyes had no longer their sight; a convulsive	235.61130379955688
shuddering shook her whole body; the sweat rolled from her brow.	344.02438253967694
“In the name of heaven, run, call! Aramis! Porthos! Call for help!”	202.31254080646357
“Useless!” said Athos, “useless! For the poison which _she_ pours there	358.6589240524878
is no antidote.”	363.59634302486904
“Yes, yes! Help, help!” murmured Mme. Bonacieux; “help!”	283.42857354162305
Then, collecting all her strength, she took the head of the young man	184.61479384161166
between her hands, looked at him for an instant as if her whole soul	287.090088414933
passed into that look, and with a sobbing cry pressed her lips to his.	321.40180338838246
“Constance, Constance!” cried D’Artagnan.	222.91471213999716
A sigh escaped from the mouth of Mme. Bonacieux, and dwelt for an	265.73185728395197
instant on the lips of D’Artagnan. That sigh was the soul, so chaste	240.98049009499385
and so loving, which reascended to heaven.	255.79606043291082
D’Artagnan pressed nothing but a corpse in his arms. The young man	199.75587856018623
uttered a cry, and fell by the side of his mistress as pale and as icy	191.26827710894398
as herself.	234.64740237879113
Porthos wept; Aramis pointed toward heaven; Athos made the sign of the	350.8006711624522
cross.	291.92521902604415
At that moment a man appeared in the doorway, almost as pale as those	332.2169459514463
in the chamber. He looked around him and saw Mme. Bonacieux dead, and	235.71729789758095
D’Artagnan in a swoon. He appeared just at that moment of stupor which	259.26952393859983
follows great catastrophes.	209.05560395226507
“I was not deceived,” said he; “here is Monsieur d’Artagnan; and you	355.2797056833417
are his friends, Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.”	212.88039472642825
The persons whose names were thus pronounced looked at the stranger	246.28777890509303
with astonishment. It seemed to all three that they knew him.	260.9609720885182
“Gentlemen,” resumed the newcomer, “you are, as I am, in search of a	317.0180947958229
woman who,” added he, with a terrible smile, “must have passed this	234.34543140369203
way, for I see a corpse.”	302.20220751210127
The three friends remained mute—for although the voice as well as the	220.69085418096614
countenance reminded them of someone they had seen, they could not	206.04457944875742
remember under what circumstances.	174.3243361346372
“Gentlemen,” continued the stranger, “since you do not recognize a man	245.18403794505767
who probably owes his life to you twice, I must name myself. I am Lord	334.67587036287716
de Winter, brother-in-law of that _woman_.”	220.60944475076695
The three friends uttered a cry of surprise.	351.0858372308818
Athos rose, and offering him his hand, “Be welcome, my Lord,” said he,	231.67799061654995
“you are one of us.”	342.68206173507633
“I set out five hours after her from Portsmouth,” said Lord de Winter.	190.80574422636894
“I arrived three hours after her at Boulogne. I missed her by twenty	355.34650880574475
minutes at St. Omer. Finally, at Lilliers I lost all trace of her. I	240.19850749162322
was going about at random, inquiring of everybody, when I saw you	258.84308062195475
gallop past. I recognized Monsieur d’Artagnan. I called to you, but you	360.22922233590344
did not answer me; I wished to follow you, but my horse was too much	175.37734575001957
fatigued to go at the same pace with yours. And yet it appears, in	323.26695404701024
spite of all your diligence, you have arrived too late.”	217.34761396499061
“You see!” said Athos, pointing to Mme. Bonacieux dead, and to	251.33663674935977
D’Artagnan, whom Porthos and Aramis were trying to recall to life.	267.9866577510694
“Are they both dead?” asked Lord de Winter, sternly.	292.34206475593294
“No,” replied Athos, “fortunately Monsieur d’Artagnan has only	272.05569206616366
fainted.”	249.24690970455703
“Ah, indeed, so much the better!” said Lord de Winter.	334.2683484952171
At that moment D’Artagnan opened his eyes. He tore himself from the	209.8986789128391
arms of Porthos and Aramis, and threw himself like a madman on the	205.52096572767405
corpse of his mistress.	236.13920320237042
Athos rose, walked toward his friend with a slow and solemn step,	212.49193551239514
embraced him tenderly, and as he burst into violent sobs, he said to	196.84106008912295
him with his noble and persuasive voice, “Friend, be a man! Women weep	182.0317606514096
for the dead; men avenge them!”	333.80216161892224
“Oh, yes!” cried D’Artagnan, “yes! If it be to avenge her, I am ready	271.6127882380335
to follow you.”	351.6636401477255
Athos profited by this moment of strength which the hope of vengeance	266.3676237579319
restored to his unfortunate friend to make a sign to Porthos and Aramis	297.9764049304542
to go and fetch the superior.	300.75307736585853
The two friends met her in the corridor, greatly troubled and much	326.23643016791976
upset by such strange events; she called some of the nuns, who against	234.08897181804667
all monastic custom found themselves in the presence of five men.	214.07611223055594
“Madame,” said Athos, passing his arm under that of D’Artagnan, “we	317.6615107022005
abandon to your pious care the body of that unfortunate woman. She was	285.63443775347434
an angel on earth before being an angel in heaven. Treat her as one of	194.56303303752546
your sisters. We will return someday to pray over her grave.”	221.65374603080863
D’Artagnan concealed his face in the bosom of Athos, and sobbed aloud.	254.13752149646325
“Weep,” said Athos, “weep, heart full of love, youth, and life! Alas,	252.59474442874617
would I could weep like you!”	344.37493318326244
And he drew away his friend, as affectionate as a father, as consoling	332.0666153036086
as a priest, noble as a man who has suffered much.	246.1620344152072
All five, followed by their lackeys leading their horses, took their	241.66737918785074
way to the town of Béthune, whose outskirts they perceived, and stopped	281.40613945390686
before the first inn they came to.	340.15591057813947
“But,” said D’Artagnan, “shall we not pursue that woman?”	257.5412013110163
“Later,” said Athos. “I have measures to take.”	202.38951768102444
“She will escape us,” replied the young man; “she will escape us, and	271.6647216596765
it will be your fault, Athos.”	286.3469528082129
“I will be accountable for her,” said Athos.	193.57857467041984
D’Artagnan had so much confidence in the word of his friend that he	289.1271645379532
lowered his head, and entered the inn without reply.	206.19381994225654
Porthos and Aramis regarded each other, not understanding this	199.1502202905561
assurance of Athos.	287.6978724083632
Lord de Winter believed he spoke in this manner to soothe the grief of	183.11396738583625
D’Artagnan.	360.54624178827225
“Now, gentlemen,” said Athos, when he had ascertained there were five	343.9043313188349
chambers free in the hôtel, “let everyone retire to his own apartment.	345.60699612884235
D’Artagnan needs to be alone, to weep and to sleep. I take charge of	343.0548763997321
everything; be easy.”	189.97769382997262
“It appears, however,” said Lord de Winter, “if there are any measures	329.6410656787986
to take against the countess, it concerns me; she is my sister-in-law.”	292.59314359059454
“And me,” said Athos, “—she is my wife!”	340.1847795359155
D’Artagnan smiled—for he understood that Athos was sure of his	171.42675287867885
vengeance when he revealed such a secret. Porthos and Aramis looked at	306.91129042744376
each other, and grew pale. Lord de Winter thought Athos was mad.	186.93614402930277
“Now, retire to your chambers,” said Athos, “and leave me to act. You	241.92744387871505
must perceive that in my quality of a husband this concerns me. Only,	364.8287858717329
D’Artagnan, if you have not lost it, give me the paper which fell from	266.0404045673731
that man’s hat, upon which is written the name of the village of—”	351.60031347869676
“Ah,” said D’Artagnan, “I comprehend! that name written in her hand.”	355.212234999698
“You see, then,” said Athos, “there is a god in heaven still!”	277.8581300465011
Chapter LXIV.	282.90893232662023
THE MAN IN THE RED CLOAK	329.5096666950632
The despair of Athos had given place to a concentrated grief which only	230.04176941574593
rendered more lucid the brilliant mental faculties of that	274.9245609306348
extraordinary man.	293.63608667401263
Possessed by one single thought—that of the promise he had made, and of	351.5845714179843
the responsibility he had taken—he retired last to his chamber, begged	330.5236600278017
the host to procure him a map of the province, bent over it, examined	350.8455030489944
every line traced upon it, perceived that there were four different	180.45563770879676
roads from Béthune to Armentières, and summoned the lackeys.	358.02350085557913
Planchet, Grimaud, Bazin, and Mousqueton presented themselves, and	201.3099289309539
received clear, positive, and serious orders from Athos.	220.60358594016145
They must set out the next morning at daybreak, and go to	321.3439621492089
Armentières—each by a different route. Planchet, the most intelligent	171.84918616347318
of the four, was to follow that by which the carriage had gone upon	192.07336292358443
which the four friends had fired, and which was accompanied, as may be	183.66796005167475
remembered, by Rochefort’s servant.	198.875268945487
Athos set the lackeys to work first because, since these men had been	236.6122793454724
in the service of himself and his friends he had discovered in each of	274.817320767253
them different and essential qualities. Then, lackeys who ask questions	277.48617795319996
inspire less mistrust than masters, and meet with more sympathy among	205.0719727451703
those to whom they address themselves. Besides, Milady knew the	299.84711669481146
masters, and did not know the lackeys; on the contrary, the lackeys	252.42315407213215
knew Milady perfectly.	268.67068936124565
All four were to meet the next day at eleven o’clock. If they had	281.5740839924562
discovered Milady’s retreat, three were to remain on guard; the fourth	308.4638797506276
was to return to Béthune in order to inform Athos and serve as a guide	288.27433024230345
to the four friends. These arrangements made, the lackeys retired.	278.0094202091974
Athos then arose from his chair, girded on his sword, enveloped himself	345.5483474238568
in his cloak, and left the hôtel. It was nearly ten o’clock. At ten	238.92296179895436
o’clock in the evening, it is well known, the streets in provincial	349.9066400941608
towns are very little frequented. Athos nevertheless was visibly	213.22021827511776
anxious to find someone of whom he could ask a question. At length he	214.81855502771998
met a belated passenger, went up to him, and spoke a few words to him.	279.9440290456985
The man he addressed recoiled with terror, and only answered the few	250.88042710449164
words of the Musketeer by pointing. Athos offered the man half a	218.0602921479578
pistole to accompany him, but the man refused.	324.96939479949424
Athos then plunged into the street the man had indicated with his	179.786056443978
finger; but arriving at four crossroads, he stopped again, visibly	351.3282681153007
embarrassed. Nevertheless, as the crossroads offered him a better	246.25681851577775
chance than any other place of meeting somebody, he stood still. In a	177.33237306708793
few minutes a night watch passed. Athos repeated to him the same	329.38930549846566
question he had asked the first person he met. The night watch evinced	306.54173550269
the same terror, refused, in his turn, to accompany Athos, and only	335.029253596311
pointed with his hand to the road he was to take.	180.4890045728543
Athos walked in the direction indicated, and reached the suburb	319.6302502982389
situated at the opposite extremity of the city from that by which he	352.07075728538166
and his friends had entered it. There he again appeared uneasy and	290.0397696355091
embarrassed, and stopped for the third time.	169.97479176856828
Fortunately, a mendicant passed, who, coming up to Athos to ask	319.9624255590542
charity, Athos offered him half a crown to accompany him where he was	262.240907991296
going. The mendicant hesitated at first, but at the sight of the piece	229.78601706124425
of silver which shone in the darkness he consented, and walked on	234.8019239260367
before Athos.	321.7143807800418
Arrived at the angle of a street, he pointed to a small house,	319.6647054723372
isolated, solitary, and dismal. Athos went toward the house, while the	285.3625518145373
mendicant, who had received his reward, left as fast as his legs could	314.15303906253155
carry him.	201.02707752813677
Athos went round the house before he could distinguish the door, amid	321.0147165901643
the red color in which the house was painted. No light appeared through	184.4480414365619
the chinks of the shutters; no noise gave reason to believe that it was	218.87559475670753
inhabited. It was dark and silent as the tomb.	217.93453789452073
Three times Athos knocked without receiving an answer. At the third	219.34108771632657
knock, however, steps were heard inside. The door at length was opened,	277.3020095268604
and a man appeared, of high stature, pale complexion, and black hair	332.21013838346244
and beard.	305.8644609930974
Athos and he exchanged some words in a low voice, then the tall man	332.94436723890885
made a sign to the Musketeer that he might come in. Athos immediately	304.49692512367426
profited by the permission, and the door was closed behind him.	333.0608360353982
The man whom Athos had come so far to seek, and whom he had found with	320.42081311175684
so much trouble, introduced him into his laboratory, where he was	332.1001759824892
engaged in fastening together with iron wire the dry bones of a	345.05220630997087
skeleton. All the frame was adjusted except the head, which lay on the	330.392027150242
table.	229.07099760073714
All the rest of the furniture indicated that the dweller in this house	262.99272248971835
occupied himself with the study of natural science. There were large	171.65019355534153
bottles filled with serpents, ticketed according to their species;	206.73688070502507
dried lizards shone like emeralds set in great squares of black wood,	218.54513624933045
and bunches of wild odoriferous herbs, doubtless possessed of virtues	257.11684414982267
unknown to common men, were fastened to the ceiling and hung down in	264.5481070019888
the corners of the apartment. There was no family, no servant; the tall	232.41276940233598
man alone inhabited this house.	322.8688786357087
Athos cast a cold and indifferent glance upon the objects we have	339.41236245936943
described, and at the invitation of him whom he came to seek sat down	207.1460595776399
near him.	256.1389569857854
Then he explained to him the cause of his visit, and the service he	292.83239611387586
required of him. But scarcely had he expressed his request when the	365.04001941106833
unknown, who remained standing before the Musketeer, drew back with	190.31064778594475
signs of terror, and refused. Then Athos took from his pocket a small	263.7294168126479
paper, on which two lines were written, accompanied by a signature and	195.5433184418032
a seal, and presented them to him who had made too prematurely these	242.27077193057244
signs of repugnance. The tall man had scarcely read these lines, seen	218.5850258120967
the signature, and recognized the seal, when he bowed to denote that he	272.64451826438074
had no longer any objection to make, and that he was ready to obey.	194.8834919018045
Athos required no more. He arose, bowed, went out, returned by the same	287.74040380687336
way he came, re-entered the hôtel, and went to his apartment.	318.1236378252172
At daybreak D’Artagnan entered the chamber, and demanded what was to be	251.88227434425636
done.	181.66054596914768
“To wait,” replied Athos.	244.8383842230692
Some minutes after, the superior of the convent sent to inform the	357.43706907803914
Musketeers that the burial would take place at midday. As to the	234.2821220259142
poisoner, they had heard no tidings of her whatever, only that she must	197.12702599937404
have made her escape through the garden, on the sand of which her	234.3489939711205
footsteps could be traced, and the door of which had been found shut.	182.95897869116254
As to the key, it had disappeared.	172.56609639486555
At the hour appointed, Lord de Winter and the four friends repaired to	183.58631168974622
the convent; the bells tolled, the chapel was open, the grating of the	191.26148838685484
choir was closed. In the middle of the choir the body of the victim,	276.9710595486214
clothed in her novitiate dress, was exposed. On each side of the choir	335.3652117100586
and behind the gratings opening into the convent was assembled the	248.7872878540913
whole community of the Carmelites, who listened to the divine service,	195.76372253466252
and mingled their chant with the chant of the priests, without seeing	233.43716531050615
the profane, or being seen by them.	320.73834894106886
At the door of the chapel D’Artagnan felt his courage fall anew, and	230.84705281370105
returned to look for Athos; but Athos had disappeared.	298.9766930459451
Faithful to his mission of vengeance, Athos had requested to be	171.3740942455141
conducted to the garden; and there upon the sand following the light	194.94915887341364
steps of this woman, who left sharp tracks wherever she went, he	257.46819328612673
advanced toward the gate which led into the wood, and causing it to be	197.801533733793
opened, he went out into the forest.	203.80567898123937
Then all his suspicions were confirmed; the road by which the carriage	296.3995749594232
had disappeared encircled the forest. Athos followed the road for some	273.10233409403526
time, his eyes fixed upon the ground; slight stains of blood, which	300.1839207617312
came from the wound inflicted upon the man who accompanied the carriage	297.57060368031443
as a courier, or from one of the horses, dotted the road. At the end of	340.2066099989816
three-quarters of a league, within fifty paces of Festubert, a larger	254.2004210335541
bloodstain appeared; the ground was trampled by horses. Between the	330.1349037635998
forest and this accursed spot, a little behind the trampled ground, was	265.77545543471257
the same track of small feet as in the garden; the carriage had stopped	306.7906582528618
here. At this spot Milady had come out of the wood, and entered the	235.38974569357217
carriage.	191.69915840708993
Satisfied with this discovery which confirmed all his suspicions, Athos	243.27227467748625
returned to the hôtel, and found Planchet impatiently waiting for him.	238.43319930381784
Everything was as Athos had foreseen.	177.64342078623972
Planchet had followed the road; like Athos, he had discovered the	321.5288953599804
stains of blood; like Athos, he had noted the spot where the horses had	199.95242436818648
halted. But he had gone farther than Athos—for at the village of	208.00780040244263
Festubert, while drinking at an inn, he had learned without needing to	323.09847582585314
ask a question that the evening before, at half-past eight, a wounded	260.6033101841199
man who accompanied a lady traveling in a post-chaise had been obliged	286.4190960286154
to stop, unable to go further. The accident was set down to the account	199.78597824180545
of robbers, who had stopped the chaise in the wood. The man remained in	337.1702803810282
the village; the woman had had a relay of horses, and continued her	311.77066045295885
journey.	317.6706458215481
Planchet went in search of the postillion who had driven her, and found	260.7652735683958
him. He had taken the lady as far as Fromelles; and from Fromelles she	328.54500104766396
had set out for Armentières. Planchet took the crossroad, and by seven	207.2459731795882
o’clock in the morning he was at Armentières.	238.4676630518661
There was but one tavern, the Post. Planchet went and presented himself	254.67656915051515
as a lackey out of a place, who was in search of a situation. He had	310.6569389238489
not chatted ten minutes with the people of the tavern before he learned	195.18176910173136
that a woman had come there alone about eleven o’clock the night	288.2766142942612
before, had engaged a chamber, had sent for the master of the hôtel,	311.98081689065873
and told him she desired to remain some time in the neighborhood.	197.22734846163954
Planchet had no need to learn more. He hastened to the rendezvous,	339.76344645371114
found the lackeys at their posts, placed them as sentinels at all the	184.98952604054332
outlets of the hôtel, and came to find Athos, who had just received	344.6735593866879
this information when his friends returned.	207.47870224176
All their countenances were melancholy and gloomy, even the mild	337.77992693947186
countenance of Aramis.	274.30603878970874
“What is to be done?” asked D’Artagnan.	290.66767867181113
“To wait!” replied Athos.	258.90707472699194
Each retired to his own apartment.	239.93302367772722
At eight o’clock in the evening Athos ordered the horses to be saddled,	297.8116271149054
and Lord de Winter and his friends notified that they must prepare for	325.58206038529215
the expedition.	320.95267953013604
In an instant all five were ready. Each examined his arms, and put them	273.82209544513387
in order. Athos came down last, and found D’Artagnan already on	214.54954857822787
horseback, and growing impatient.	317.5297549015018
“Patience!” cried Athos; “one of our party is still wanting.”	182.76843918895668
The four horsemen looked round them with astonishment, for they sought	171.1466553155598
vainly in their minds to know who this other person could be.	287.0216161978593
At this moment Planchet brought out Athos’s horse; the Musketeer leaped	219.0030684337886
lightly into the saddle.	233.80825116678534
“Wait for me,” cried he, “I will soon be back,” and he set off at a	251.25944040859883
gallop.	296.0234765384117
In a quarter of an hour he returned, accompanied by a tall man, masked,	202.3441956818637
and wrapped in a large red cloak.	358.1486913919393
Lord de Winter and the three Musketeers looked at one another	259.48832533496943
inquiringly. Neither could give the others any information, for all	323.644811924938
were ignorant who this man could be; nevertheless, they felt convinced	207.4955840165506
that all was as it should be, as it was done by the order of Athos.	305.15964883632114
At nine o’clock, guided by Planchet, the little cavalcade set out,	235.6375659804891
taking the route the carriage had taken.	272.3173804461116
It was a melancholy sight—that of these six men, traveling in silence,	318.9129252421839
each plunged in his own thoughts, sad as despair, gloomy as	282.1433024875977
chastisement.	251.5921539591783
Chapter LXV.	313.10865859733417
TRIAL	341.7089712366277
It was a stormy and dark night; vast clouds covered the heavens,	189.71084022272711
concealing the stars; the moon would not rise till midnight.	170.3847377848873
Occasionally, by the light of a flash of lightning which gleamed along	199.56139201451322
the horizon, the road stretched itself before them, white and solitary;	293.1619177791482
the flash extinct, all remained in darkness.	176.4847513498122
Every minute Athos was forced to restrain D’Artagnan, constantly in	233.48924942326883
advance of the little troop, and to beg him to keep in the line, which	257.315989268516
in an instant he again departed from. He had but one thought—to go	316.74704458984485
forward; and he went.	348.8651904683593
They passed in silence through the little village of Festubert, where	304.1951955642381
the wounded servant was, and then skirted the wood of Richebourg. At	252.49668283155614
Herlier, Planchet, who led the column, turned to the left.	261.2640628000245
Several times Lord de Winter, Porthos, or Aramis tried to talk with the	262.28919345627594
man in the red cloak; but to every interrogation which they put to him	300.7515994494072
he bowed, without response. The travelers then comprehended that there	227.07363231459843
must be some reason why the unknown preserved such a silence, and	238.501767079305
ceased to address themselves to him.	362.90632590259065
The storm increased, the flashes succeeded one another more rapidly,	354.6867126674671
the thunder began to growl, and the wind, the precursor of a hurricane,	334.1649991871193
whistled in the plumes and the hair of the horsemen.	339.76677932873145
The cavalcade trotted on more sharply.	241.78399652819937
A little before they came to Fromelles the storm burst. They spread	206.32830107534363
their cloaks. There remained three leagues to travel, and they did it	235.4974076793257
amid torrents of rain.	222.68884102784108
D’Artagnan took off his hat, and could not be persuaded to make use of	284.2827798468441
his cloak. He found pleasure in feeling the water trickle over his	282.8104865041261
burning brow and over his body, agitated by feverish shudders.	259.09013592704133
The moment the little troop passed Goskal and were approaching the	233.3340972225324
