Post, a man sheltered beneath a tree detached himself from the trunk	319.9919170251811
with which he had been confounded in the darkness, and advanced into	325.913405985069
the middle of the road, putting his finger on his lips.	237.14646372776133
Athos recognized Grimaud.	297.57381187206386
“What’s the manner?” cried Athos. “Has she left Armentières?”	318.76245526617834
Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative. D’Artagnan ground his teeth.	212.10075156554126
“Silence, D’Artagnan!” said Athos. “I have charged myself with this	284.32089525420224
affair. It is for me, then, to interrogate Grimaud.”	174.82078118350705
“Where is she?” asked Athos.	188.72157038300054
Grimaud extended his hands in the direction of the Lys. “Far from	204.83721295439875
here?” asked Athos.	311.63518460664693
Grimaud showed his master his forefinger bent.	315.4802970869523
“Alone?” asked Athos.	272.5478173573507
Grimaud made the sign yes.	203.64944542641348
“Gentlemen,” said Athos, “she is alone within half a league of us, in	295.1901828797596
the direction of the river.”	194.8897847735197
“That’s well,” said D’Artagnan. “Lead us, Grimaud.”	360.2615665034763
Grimaud took his course across the country, and acted as guide to the	233.26331420730207
cavalcade.	210.12149778947213
At the end of five hundred paces, more or less, they came to a rivulet,	350.1633488240114
which they forded.	218.581645149376
By the aid of the lightning they perceived the village of Erquinheim.	349.8058110727463
“Is she there, Grimaud?” asked Athos.	196.0344413608648
Grimaud shook his head negatively.	279.0962238116616
“Silence, then!” cried Athos.	343.4627144797297
And the troop continued their route.	279.4966790123301
Another flash illuminated all around them. Grimaud extended his arm,	211.59104475678316
and by the bluish splendor of the fiery serpent they distinguished a	183.2486124702071
little isolated house on the banks of the river, within a hundred paces	326.2909617437627
of a ferry.	359.9133674143584
One window was lighted.	345.54357608441444
“Here we are!” said Athos.	205.74211441331147
At this moment a man who had been crouching in a ditch jumped up and	178.56783942473055
came towards them. It was Mousqueton. He pointed his finger to the	219.51324587197644
lighted window.	279.45626319605594
“She is there,” said he.	305.0758092983175
“And Bazin?” asked Athos.	311.7203943013883
“While I watched the window, he guarded the door.”	209.67824883874226
“Good!” said Athos. “You are good and faithful servants.”	295.7917143458161
Athos sprang from his horse, gave the bridle to Grimaud, and advanced	240.1925168592379
toward the window, after having made a sign to the rest of the troop to	263.9371444610274
go toward the door.	235.65549894679293
The little house was surrounded by a low, quickset hedge, two or three	295.0739892755938
feet high. Athos sprang over the hedge and went up to the window, which	284.1847057782962
was without shutters, but had the half-curtains closely drawn.	352.84695415912995
He mounted the skirting stone that his eyes might look over the	230.00823476318521
curtain.	187.77506579412113
By the light of a lamp he saw a woman, wrapped in a dark mantle, seated	292.39852431236045
upon a stool near a dying fire. Her elbows were placed upon a mean	274.62167418455
table, and she leaned her head upon her two hands, which were white as	252.9216192987429
ivory.	241.37636793910508
He could not distinguish her countenance, but a sinister smile passed	264.129442360653
over the lips of Athos. He was not deceived; it was she whom he sought.	240.23670807786797
At this moment a horse neighed. Milady raised her head, saw close to	348.3965253183519
the panes the pale face of Athos, and screamed.	278.9957578974261
Athos, perceiving that she knew him, pushed the window with his knee	286.0136804698755
and hand. The window yielded. The squares were broken to shivers; and	197.05300481808857
Athos, like the spectre of vengeance, leaped into the room.	263.4430548239001
Milady rushed to the door and opened it. More pale and menacing than	209.19679947094681
Athos, D’Artagnan stood on the threshold.	350.92241945737373
Milady recoiled, uttering a cry. D’Artagnan, believing she might have	362.41965293784904
means of flight and fearing she should escape, drew a pistol from his	360.73518594119975
belt; but Athos raised his hand.	249.44107543765801
“Put back that weapon, D’Artagnan!” said he; “this woman must be tried,	356.64522017414504
not assassinated. Wait an instant, my friend, and you shall be	255.87941359400193
satisfied. Come in, gentlemen.”	338.3510970050653
D’Artagnan obeyed; for Athos had the solemn voice and the powerful	307.31771954103857
gesture of a judge sent by the Lord himself. Behind D’Artagnan entered	225.5452255384053
Porthos, Aramis, Lord de Winter, and the man in the red cloak.	359.38959882496044
The four lackeys guarded the door and the window.	321.8103470763084
Milady had sunk into a chair, with her hands extended, as if to conjure	341.6630328908749
this terrible apparition. Perceiving her brother-in-law, she uttered a	200.11445499492294
terrible cry.	252.5083336059448
“What do you want?” screamed Milady.	306.69003638814183
“We want,” said Athos, “Charlotte Backson, who first was called	314.31739601092954
Comtesse de la Fère, and afterwards Milady de Winter, Baroness of	217.28594754306604
Sheffield.”	261.77152221273445
“That is I! that is I!” murmured Milady, in extreme terror; “what do	250.36983138403488
you want?”	177.45141357994686
“We wish to judge you according to your crime,” said Athos; “you shall	175.7786220631507
be free to defend yourself. Justify yourself if you can. M. d’Artagnan,	350.1551865810906
it is for you to accuse her first.”	201.1738396900198
D’Artagnan advanced.	289.7072643050756
“Before God and before men,” said he, “I accuse this woman of having	311.8439091106692
poisoned Constance Bonacieux, who died yesterday evening.”	297.5794002251421
He turned towards Porthos and Aramis.	300.2691679879764
“We bear witness to this,” said the two Musketeers, with one voice.	197.87022576141516
D’Artagnan continued: “Before God and before men, I accuse this woman	325.74588517356597
of having attempted to poison me, in wine which she sent me from	271.02649314341534
Villeroy, with a forged letter, as if that wine came from my friends.	266.8074923147811
God preserved me, but a man named Brisemont died in my place.”	265.6126923564373
“We bear witness to this,” said Porthos and Aramis, in the same manner	289.06095095256813
as before.	236.3462879578731
“Before God and before men, I accuse this woman of having urged me to	194.43109678135062
the murder of the Baron de Wardes; but as no one else can attest the	364.0668990451726
truth of this accusation, I attest it myself. I have done.” And	303.84700838738706
D’Artagnan passed to the other side of the room with Porthos and	304.6282292744395
Aramis.	263.8941484171429
“Your turn, my Lord,” said Athos.	174.09891158701842
The baron came forward.	259.9147689129594
“Before God and before men,” said he, “I accuse this woman of having	210.03914255449737
caused the assassination of the Duke of Buckingham.”	349.02654324168196
“The Duke of Buckingham assassinated!” cried all present, with one	334.1062719257525
voice.	221.5304053114229
“Yes,” said the baron, “assassinated. On receiving the warning letter	354.28328999986604
you wrote to me, I had this woman arrested, and gave her in charge to a	267.2362251098227
loyal servant. She corrupted this man; she placed the poniard in his	229.87704649598513
hand; she made him kill the duke. And at this moment, perhaps, Felton	301.80449585431904
is paying with his head for the crime of this fury!”	330.27291402987566
A shudder crept through the judges at the revelation of these unknown	259.4796467914169
crimes.	328.3045742253764
“That is not all,” resumed Lord de Winter. “My brother, who made you	277.8843097120041
his heir, died in three hours of a strange disorder which left livid	182.02817258064155
traces all over the body. My sister, how did your husband die?”	224.68155676462985
“Horror!” cried Porthos and Aramis.	217.919723031137
“Assassin of Buckingham, assassin of Felton, assassin of my brother, I	229.84191334328327
demand justice upon you, and I swear that if it be not granted to me, I	312.87184233619763
will execute it myself.”	302.0341291812081
And Lord de Winter ranged himself by the side of D’Artagnan, leaving	249.00688941205885
the place free for another accuser.	334.97060709055654
Milady let her head sink between her two hands, and tried to recall her	188.99066257931824
ideas, whirling in a mortal vertigo.	353.40184556705066
“My turn,” said Athos, himself trembling as the lion trembles at the	307.57018891719895
sight of the serpent—“my turn. I married that woman when she was a	233.53593630150718
young girl; I married her in opposition to the wishes of all my family;	343.5717010251004
I gave her my wealth, I gave her my name; and one day I discovered that	353.9879869945676
this woman was branded—this woman was marked with a _fleur-de-lis_ on	358.7055388342196
her left shoulder.”	347.37305312320115
“Oh,” said Milady, raising herself, “I defy you to find any tribunal	312.2632984156693
which pronounced that infamous sentence against me. I defy you to find	281.09510830176845
him who executed it.”	219.205921658652
“Silence!” said a hollow voice. “It is for me to reply to that!” And	247.27335810647372
the man in the red cloak came forward in his turn.	332.4738039112649
“What man is that? What man is that?” cried Milady, suffocated by	314.16452931812887
terror, her hair loosening itself, and rising above her livid	254.21871734946097
countenance as if alive.	307.0108724718598
All eyes were turned towards this man—for to all except Athos he was	349.6470016333048
unknown.	199.42882802078955
Even Athos looked at him with as much stupefaction as the others, for	332.9242920309893
he knew not how he could in any way find himself mixed up with the	335.8462410057217
horrible drama then unfolded.	329.69442958097306
After approaching Milady with a slow and solemn step, so that the table	211.3489318779949
alone separated them, the unknown took off his mask.	335.8584247702783
Milady for some time examined with increasing terror that pale face,	324.8710886024359
framed with black hair and whiskers, the only expression of which was	288.1546176110736
icy impassibility. Then she suddenly cried, “Oh, no, no!” rising and	305.9790239315565
retreating to the very wall. “No, no! it is an infernal apparition! It	352.01740502260714
is not he! Help, help!” screamed she, turning towards the wall, as if	361.55638967507593
she would tear an opening with her hands.	294.4277747259896
“Who are you, then?” cried all the witnesses of this scene.	184.97619545142754
“Ask that woman,” said the man in the red cloak, “for you may plainly	270.09008647799874
see she knows me!”	193.94694074514877
“The executioner of Lille, the executioner of Lille!” cried Milady, a	345.16054801911594
prey to insensate terror, and clinging with her hands to the wall to	300.2244482919721
avoid falling.	233.36263076191753
Everyone drew back, and the man in the red cloak remained standing	337.5657521124771
alone in the middle of the room.	276.0478003758555
“Oh, grace, grace, pardon!” cried the wretch, falling on her knees.	276.2015756781717
The unknown waited for silence, and then resumed, “I told you well that	363.42444831753573
she would know me. Yes, I am the executioner of Lille, and this is my	229.98170603368953
history.”	178.8160962132103
All eyes were fixed upon this man, whose words were listened to with	275.9725493193399
anxious attention.	336.30885297467137
“That woman was once a young girl, as beautiful as she is today. She	282.4308618098694
was a nun in the convent of the Benedictines of Templemar. A young	300.6554284791061
priest, with a simple and trustful heart, performed the duties of the	337.52312076429945
church of that convent. She undertook his seduction, and succeeded; she	168.25759967139678
would have seduced a saint.	264.8789884447627
“Their vows were sacred and irrevocable. Their connection could not	307.32434675383183
last long without ruining both. She prevailed upon him to leave the	194.11110157891454
country; but to leave the country, to fly together, to reach another	327.3888165887481
part of France, where they might live at ease because unknown, money	327.5659364097104
was necessary. Neither had any. The priest stole the sacred vases, and	179.66645113042492
sold them; but as they were preparing to escape together, they were	228.4505597478835
both arrested.	241.35088446260073
“Eight days later she had seduced the son of the jailer, and escaped.	232.26921282920614
The young priest was condemned to ten years of imprisonment, and to be	300.1227204734489
branded. I was executioner of the city of Lille, as this woman has	298.22392415973366
said. I was obliged to brand the guilty one; and he, gentlemen, was my	338.23759837567843
brother!	218.34803277458153
“I then swore that this woman who had ruined him, who was more than his	331.3282901713027
accomplice, since she had urged him to the crime, should at least share	344.191074501059
his punishment. I suspected where she was concealed. I followed her, I	209.34168360062176
caught her, I bound her; and I imprinted the same disgraceful mark upon	261.056446308466
her that I had imprinted upon my poor brother.	351.3154002961103
“The day after my return to Lille, my brother in his turn succeeded in	336.54842962313444
making his escape; I was accused of complicity, and was condemned to	250.96456965471629
remain in his place till he should be again a prisoner. My poor brother	196.85209915865752
was ignorant of this sentence. He rejoined this woman; they fled	205.63620252045456
together into Berry, and there he obtained a little curacy. This woman	354.42975959360217
passed for his sister.	196.95100160686627
“The Lord of the estate on which the chapel of the curacy was situated	219.33717530407534
saw this pretend sister, and became enamoured of her—amorous to such a	300.1268662279318
degree that he proposed to marry her. Then she quitted him she had	220.77823412793563
ruined for him she was destined to ruin, and became the Comtesse de la	192.68397513547527
Fère—”	172.84544940575458
All eyes were turned towards Athos, whose real name that was, and who	215.6219167084397
made a sign with his head that all was true which the executioner had	203.10854841561292
said.	351.68093367278937
“Then,” resumed he, “mad, desperate, determined to get rid of an	287.8374102839291
existence from which she had stolen everything, honor and happiness, my	283.56335586907977
poor brother returned to Lille, and learning the sentence which had	325.76956073669845
condemned me in his place, surrendered himself, and hanged himself that	269.9211809282907
same night from the iron bar of the loophole of his prison.	274.48331266910014
“To do justice to them who had condemned me, they kept their word. As	273.8923048545347
soon as the identity of my brother was proved, I was set at liberty.	348.18616646604164
“That is the crime of which I accuse her; that is the cause for which	321.01584932985753
she was branded.”	254.15866979943272
“Monsieur d’Artagnan,” said Athos, “what is the penalty you demand	358.6791662456242
against this woman?”	320.28969299073117
“The punishment of death,” replied D’Artagnan.	270.490741439922
“My Lord de Winter,” continued Athos, “what is the penalty you demand	277.23755060704156
against this woman?”	281.2716094598959
“The punishment of death,” replied Lord de Winter.	351.14510770179083
“Messieurs Porthos and Aramis,” repeated Athos, “you who are her	191.21219495425734
judges, what is the sentence you pronounce upon this woman?”	171.62489050955105
“The punishment of death,” replied the Musketeers, in a hollow voice.	236.61011801854784
Milady uttered a frightful shriek, and dragged herself along several	222.642613554873
paces upon her knees toward her judges.	173.2381415083513
Athos stretched out his hand toward her.	324.3527993933695
“Charlotte Backson, Comtesse de la Fère, Milady de Winter,” said he,	309.04833283781375
“your crimes have wearied men on earth and God in heaven. If you know a	296.3537569025118
prayer, say it—for you are condemned, and you shall die.”	246.97697555574427
At these words, which left no hope, Milady raised herself in all her	192.35164890110926
pride, and wished to speak; but her strength failed her. She felt that	305.09737543413837
a powerful and implacable hand seized her by the hair, and dragged her	316.94362483185716
away as irrevocably as fatality drags humanity. She did not, therefore,	259.8191175207229
even attempt the least resistance, and went out of the cottage.	315.53579181335016
Lord de Winter, D’Artagnan, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, went out close	349.5341071825379
behind her. The lackeys followed their masters, and the chamber was	336.0675467358567
left solitary, with its broken window, its open door, and its smoky	181.5804165058707
lamp burning sadly on the table.	301.33437086875415
Chapter LXVI.	168.8640142820143
EXECUTION	323.45910769106973
It was near midnight; the moon, lessened by its decline, and reddened	228.14571418745217
by the last traces of the storm, arose behind the little town of	321.86813420951125
Armentières, which showed against its pale light the dark outline of	277.9884289148638
its houses, and the skeleton of its high belfry. In front of them the	167.36324764670647
Lys rolled its waters like a river of molten tin; while on the other	298.7456879504309
side was a black mass of trees, profiled on a stormy sky, invaded by	308.30690000538954
large coppery clouds which created a sort of twilight amid the night.	308.1900838425646
On the left was an old abandoned mill, with its motionless wings, from	210.27002271550438
the ruins of which an owl threw out its shrill, periodical, and	347.71320833425364
monotonous cry. On the right and on the left of the road, which the	209.8862567543913
dismal procession pursued, appeared a few low, stunted trees, which	186.02402309237925
looked like deformed dwarfs crouching down to watch men traveling at	350.63647319174834
this sinister hour.	264.3990166731955
From time to time a broad sheet of lightning opened the horizon in its	363.68593130118234
whole width, darted like a serpent over the black mass of trees, and	222.7839683170523
like a terrible scimitar divided the heavens and the waters into two	270.3014771467018
parts. Not a breath of wind now disturbed the heavy atmosphere. A	210.76892850201676
deathlike silence oppressed all nature. The soil was humid and	213.41515982682802
glittering with the rain which had recently fallen, and the refreshed	210.8645935358073
herbs sent forth their perfume with additional energy.	214.536322082644
Two lackeys dragged Milady, whom each held by one arm. The executioner	304.8531940516249
walked behind them, and Lord de Winter, D’Artagnan, Porthos, and Aramis	174.31619594894818
walked behind the executioner. Planchet and Bazin came last.	275.9306554184791
The two lackeys conducted Milady to the bank of the river. Her mouth	227.98364261455183
was mute; but her eyes spoke with their inexpressible eloquence,	358.8514265554145
supplicating by turns each of those on whom she looked.	197.73308312013572
Being a few paces in advance she whispered to the lackeys, “A thousand	347.84181707773416
pistoles to each of you, if you will assist my escape; but if you	310.4099685941957
deliver me up to your masters, I have near at hand avengers who will	311.03404587005525
make you pay dearly for my death.”	351.16744349332873
Grimaud hesitated. Mousqueton trembled in all his members.	325.5356008001491
Athos, who heard Milady’s voice, came sharply up. Lord de Winter did	321.28905627430913
the same.	168.2234895014448
“Change these lackeys,” said he; “she has spoken to them. They are no	336.4495806998134
longer sure.”	342.3443411526399
Planchet and Bazin were called, and took the places of Grimaud and	293.7545497412881
Mousqueton.	228.00266664489433
On the bank of the river the executioner approached Milady, and bound	232.59895677007762
her hands and feet.	315.0560674580677
Then she broke the silence to cry out, “You are cowards, miserable	279.7972396364931
assassins—ten men combined to murder one woman. Beware! If I am not	173.8757011645223
saved I shall be avenged.”	341.52091911919143
“You are not a woman,” said Athos, coldly and sternly. “You do not	270.6694609172237
belong to the human species; you are a demon escaped from hell, whither	327.7026965064937
we send you back again.”	346.4772575428741
“Ah, you virtuous men!” said Milady; “please to remember that he who	294.34898572194834
shall touch a hair of my head is himself an assassin.”	190.54331663158206
“The executioner may kill, without being on that account an assassin,”	262.3209949319201
said the man in the red cloak, rapping upon his immense sword. “This is	283.4861490900489
the last judge; that is all. _Nachrichter_, as say our neighbors, the	184.88787679442922
Germans.”	266.5942609199138
And as he bound her while saying these words, Milady uttered two or	266.41331489974186
three savage cries, which produced a strange and melancholy effect in	202.42861272851943
flying away into the night, and losing themselves in the depths of the	256.0398023721761
woods.	275.8291634393004
“If I am guilty, if I have committed the crimes you accuse me of,”	296.6800984636511
shrieked Milady, “take me before a tribunal. You are not judges! You	196.1469109013083
cannot condemn me!”	250.63402152253377
“I offered you Tyburn,” said Lord de Winter. “Why did you not accept	358.5799495981205
it?”	314.1630416092815
“Because I am not willing to die!” cried Milady, struggling. “Because I	251.41460308940083
am too young to die!”	311.2531552003379
“The woman you poisoned at Béthune was still younger than you, madame,	242.2000823205293
and yet she is dead,” said D’Artagnan.	331.52575783915995
“I will enter a cloister; I will become a nun,” said Milady.	315.9814890479736
“You were in a cloister,” said the executioner, “and you left it to	351.44622873843775
ruin my brother.”	277.1771563324546
Milady uttered a cry of terror and sank upon her knees. The executioner	204.8217624714199
took her up in his arms and was carrying her toward the boat.	219.7018223384516
“Oh, my God!” cried she, “my God! are you going to drown me?”	357.07439263874073
These cries had something so heartrending in them that M. d’Artagnan,	349.543802704883
who had been at first the most eager in pursuit of Milady, sat down on	221.9303718495957
the stump of a tree and hung his head, covering his ears with the palms	364.5559584969547
of his hands; and yet, notwithstanding, he could still hear her cry and	360.1957682063518
threaten.	285.1700756983038
D’Artagnan was the youngest of all these men. His heart failed him.	167.95832179284417
“Oh, I cannot behold this frightful spectacle!” said he. “I cannot	242.17340924545329
consent that this woman should die thus!”	285.4774286641051
Milady heard these few words and caught at a shadow of hope.	268.881673087856
“D’Artagnan, D’Artagnan!” cried she; “remember that I loved you!”	251.03035524720417
The young man rose and took a step toward her.	234.5090551643322
But Athos rose likewise, drew his sword, and placed himself in the way.	187.37904159062222
“If you take one step farther, D’Artagnan,” said he, “we shall cross	360.0577815339486
swords together.”	319.8236595518081
D’Artagnan sank on his knees and prayed.	231.8168432978568
“Come,” continued Athos, “executioner, do your duty.”	322.9809245844884
“Willingly, monseigneur,” said the executioner; “for as I am a good	229.5672329016029
Catholic, I firmly believe I am acting justly in performing my	300.5482878525688
functions on this woman.”	264.6139067294707
“That’s well.”	309.5664554101836
Athos made a step toward Milady.	341.7315840703798
“I pardon you,” said he, “the ill you have done me. I pardon you for my	183.6368691707499
blasted future, my lost honor, my defiled love, and my salvation	358.52663654966796
forever compromised by the despair into which you have cast me. Die in	315.99801995382415
peace!”	258.61440927547034
Lord de Winter advanced in his turn.	257.89745477135733
“I pardon you,” said he, “for the poisoning of my brother, and the	206.34683248058496
assassination of his Grace, Lord Buckingham. I pardon you for the death	271.4118342328608
of poor Felton; I pardon you for the attempts upon my own person. Die	254.80656134030403
in peace!”	181.26447533021718
“And I,” said M. d’Artagnan. “Pardon me, madame, for having by a trick	199.75733788727564
unworthy of a gentleman provoked your anger; and I, in exchange, pardon	287.20515561644675
you the murder of my poor love and your cruel vengeance against me. I	189.9827731035338
pardon you, and I weep for you. Die in peace!”	219.01905869602862
“I am lost!” murmured Milady in English. “I must die!”	340.08311470832024
Then she arose of herself, and cast around her one of those piercing	299.03491920985465
looks which seemed to dart from an eye of flame.	168.0862210358239
She saw nothing; she listened, and she heard nothing.	305.7700277775064
“Where am I to die?” said she.	270.7027733890872
“On the other bank,” replied the executioner.	232.9944678216862
Then he placed her in the boat, and as he was going to set foot in it	232.92609377077378
himself, Athos handed him a sum of silver.	335.5030062951562
“Here,” said he, “is the price of the execution, that it may be plain	184.07458823721092
we act as judges.”	360.05365153000366
“That is correct,” said the executioner; “and now in her turn, let this	351.00728341523586
woman see that I am not fulfilling my trade, but my debt.”	199.44439556208633
And he threw the money into the river.	292.7664461928691
The boat moved off toward the left-hand shore of the Lys, bearing the	345.6956799390254
guilty woman and the executioner; all the others remained on the	226.92298442379928
right-hand bank, where they fell on their knees.	230.72761592365663
The boat glided along the ferry rope under the shadow of a pale cloud	257.8768373227043
which hung over the water at that moment.	305.4298448915066
The troop of friends saw it gain the opposite bank; the figures were	241.80269094835546
defined like black shadows on the red-tinted horizon.	334.79560971303835
Milady, during the passage had contrived to untie the cord which	264.8651694191792
fastened her feet. On coming near the bank, she jumped lightly on shore	269.69848883620335
and took to flight. But the soil was moist; on reaching the top of the	204.10574042219616
bank, she slipped and fell upon her knees.	351.2134484406014
She was struck, no doubt, with a superstitious idea; she conceived that	172.61851562480814
heaven denied its aid, and she remained in the attitude in which she	290.7295282480824
had fallen, her head drooping and her hands clasped.	355.2105595689503
Then they saw from the other bank the executioner raise both his arms	302.80589195809176
slowly; a moonbeam fell upon the blade of the large sword. The two arms	324.09580636500834
fell with a sudden force; they heard the hissing of the scimitar and	228.47642695892628
the cry of the victim, then a truncated mass sank beneath the blow.	322.3512938289517
The executioner then took off his red cloak, spread it upon the ground,	223.79242334685512
laid the body in it, threw in the head, tied all up by the four	318.37140347098307
corners, lifted it on his back, and entered the boat again.	336.9039498618242
In the middle of the stream he stopped the boat, and suspending his	325.80091434484206
burden over the water cried in a loud voice, “Let the justice of God be	211.36098812555366
done!” and he let the corpse drop into the depths of the waters, which	173.23781455390687
closed over it.	336.42515331428484
Three days afterward the four Musketeers were in Paris; they had not	330.3565182639927
exceeded their leave of absence, and that same evening they went to pay	223.63474775747497
their customary visit to M. de Tréville.	214.33886382584433
“Well, gentlemen,” said the brave captain, “I hope you have been well	166.80031859730454
amused during your excursion.”	209.07568649398735
“Prodigiously,” replied Athos in the name of himself and his comrades.	184.44385901498842
Chapter LXVII.	333.0048962258168
CONCLUSION	221.55702051237435
On the sixth of the following month the king, in compliance with the	320.8447433612512
promise he had made the cardinal to return to La Rochelle, left his	365.5460327419612
capital still in amazement at the news which began to spread itself of	327.56487132038546
Buckingham’s assassination.	321.78327149732905
Although warned that the man she had loved so much was in great danger,	234.32824719138927
the queen, when his death was announced to her, would not believe the	226.98209856464976
fact, and even imprudently exclaimed, “it is false; he has just written	324.915686301275
to me!”	219.21860605581108
But the next day she was obliged to believe this fatal intelligence;	310.20852102354024
Laporte, detained in England, as everyone else had been, by the orders	238.33434474572422
of Charles I., arrived, and was the bearer of the duke’s dying gift to	180.55622734372682
the queen.	187.922517974852
The joy of the king was lively. He did not even give himself the	296.6508475914061
trouble to dissemble, and displayed it with affectation before the	188.02332650751427
queen. Louis XIII., like every weak mind, was wanting in generosity.	331.8494209671688
But the king soon again became dull and indisposed; his brow was not	233.75815172890754
one of those that long remain clear. He felt that in returning to camp	261.86100674482077
he should re-enter slavery; nevertheless, he did return.	322.066340984563
The cardinal was for him the fascinating serpent, and himself the bird	261.7252598198173
which flies from branch to branch without power to escape.	354.9129160769211
The return to La Rochelle, therefore, was profoundly dull. Our four	298.0792778767743
friends, in particular, astonished their comrades; they traveled	223.8087115631841
together, side by side, with sad eyes and heads lowered. Athos alone	331.3533787582488
from time to time raised his expansive brow; a flash kindled in his	181.02101272277224
eyes, and a bitter smile passed over his lips, then, like his comrades,	171.55749284512675
he sank again into reverie.	352.6669051920714
As soon as the escort arrived in a city, when they had conducted the	323.9707042013279
king to his quarters the four friends either retired to their own or to	272.7754992891394
some secluded cabaret, where they neither drank nor played; they only	238.38156090801576
conversed in a low voice, looking around attentively to see that no one	195.72469939844427
overheard them.	334.764503529277
One day, when the king had halted to fly the magpie, and the four	227.58035631008593
friends, according to their custom, instead of following the sport had	299.7615632196994
stopped at a cabaret on the high road, a man coming from la Rochelle on	338.68690684871467
horseback pulled up at the door to drink a glass of wine, and darted a	348.70620352323505
searching glance into the room where the four Musketeers were sitting.	245.76958699833617
“Holloa, Monsieur d’Artagnan!” said he, “is not that you whom I see	224.05694980798341
yonder?”	279.0004180220359
D’Artagnan raised his head and uttered a cry of joy. It was the man he	330.97606837311275
called his phantom; it was his stranger of Meung, of the Rue des	259.8698371680615
Fossoyeurs and of Arras.	172.71970203744726
D’Artagnan drew his sword, and sprang toward the door.	223.9481566057035
But this time, instead of avoiding him the stranger jumped from his	226.5737197942339
horse, and advanced to meet D’Artagnan.	243.1874214671929
“Ah, monsieur!” said the young man, “I meet you, then, at last! This	187.46373351246103
time you shall not escape me!”	221.49242276186322
“Neither is it my intention, monsieur, for this time I was seeking you;	201.8938892894606
in the name of the king, I arrest you.”	266.5837610958316
“How! what do you say?” cried D’Artagnan.	344.4413713168063
“I say that you must surrender your sword to me, monsieur, and that	271.79863174723545
without resistance. This concerns your head, I warn you.”	255.95289048506547
“Who are you, then?” demanded D’Artagnan, lowering the point of his	179.58626114645284
sword, but without yet surrendering it.	219.43823478853017
“I am the Chevalier de Rochefort,” answered the other, “the equerry of	312.5732012828764
Monsieur le Cardinal Richelieu, and I have orders to conduct you to his	233.88047097225092
Eminence.”	281.9437628206257
“We are returning to his Eminence, monsieur the Chevalier,” said Athos,	172.0290704489228
advancing; “and you will please to accept the word of Monsieur	274.5463247694607
d’Artagnan that he will go straight to La Rochelle.”	188.00988474993687
“I must place him in the hands of guards who will take him into camp.”	252.5357433577965
“We will be his guards, monsieur, upon our word as gentlemen; but	213.8316650723672
likewise, upon our word as gentlemen,” added Athos, knitting his brow,	326.1357870938671
“Monsieur d’Artagnan shall not leave us.”	341.2375949475428
The Chevalier de Rochefort cast a glance backward, and saw that Porthos	268.9794839099288
and Aramis had placed themselves between him and the gate; he	261.674437312708
understood that he was completely at the mercy of these four men.	216.311210888118
“Gentlemen,” said he, “if Monsieur d’Artagnan will surrender his sword	256.9922534730044
to me and join his word to yours, I shall be satisfied with your	188.85123403016416
promise to convey Monsieur d’Artagnan to the quarters of Monseigneur	197.60476240604854
the Cardinal.”	219.73146585505765
“You have my word, monsieur, and here is my sword.”	352.7253060170789
“This suits me the better,” said Rochefort, “as I wish to continue my	323.5544796947347
journey.”	337.36687634842605
“If it is for the purpose of rejoining Milady,” said Athos, coolly, “it	316.2533309638055
is useless; you will not find her.”	262.0547712804924
“What has become of her, then?” asked Rochefort, eagerly.	299.06214827597563
“Return to camp and you shall know.”	351.5821598796492
Rochefort remained for a moment in thought; then, as they were only a	247.3950205921646
day’s journey from Surgères, whither the cardinal was to come to meet	365.4366632215043
the king, he resolved to follow the advice of Athos and go with them.	244.8048011117064
Besides, this return offered him the advantage of watching his	306.036931098844
prisoner.	244.4744071694061
They resumed their route.	261.6585137728941
On the morrow, at three o’clock in the afternoon, they arrived at	285.32884526366996
Surgères. The cardinal there awaited Louis XIII. The minister and the	255.4197143605105
king exchanged numerous caresses, felicitating each other upon the	197.5253255210619
fortunate chance which had freed France from the inveterate enemy who	180.7378664474436
set all Europe against her. After which, the cardinal, who had been	310.88659412042546
informed that D’Artagnan was arrested and who was anxious to see him,	325.54344433802135
took leave of the king, inviting him to come the next day to view the	275.51915437358434
work already done upon the dyke.	252.42605790212346
On returning in the evening to his quarters at the bridge of La Pierre,	345.2632289427431
the cardinal found, standing before the house he occupied, D’Artagnan,	332.0315933545494
without his sword, and the three Musketeers armed.	286.20923681129193
This time, as he was well attended, he looked at them sternly, and made	350.3413259395808
a sign with his eye and hand for D’Artagnan to follow him.	259.1172709036566
D’Artagnan obeyed.	324.5484567403239
“We shall wait for you, D’Artagnan,” said Athos, loud enough for the	220.76021011702028
cardinal to hear him.	222.61358755054385
His Eminence bent his brow, stopped for an instant, and then kept on	324.689009414016
his way without uttering a single word.	287.69092879647786
D’Artagnan entered after the cardinal, and behind D’Artagnan the door	231.9322362849059
was guarded.	290.6830758722352
His Eminence entered the chamber which served him as a study, and made	287.91652090958655
a sign to Rochefort to bring in the young Musketeer.	240.28764972883832
Rochefort obeyed and retired.	246.121779721881
D’Artagnan remained alone in front of the cardinal; this was his second	310.38950602024806
interview with Richelieu, and he afterward confessed that he felt well	257.4797655132617
assured it would be his last.	327.3373618259237
Richelieu remained standing, leaning against the mantelpiece; a table	305.4180181557457
was between him and D’Artagnan.	244.27132524336568
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “you have been arrested by my orders.”	309.90539486074965
“So they tell me, monseigneur.”	231.6980882021077
“Do you know why?”	261.2067198200069
“No, monseigneur, for the only thing for which I could be arrested is	250.12002144867057
still unknown to your Eminence.”	211.37934858772113
Richelieu looked steadfastly at the young man.	219.95376191720268
“Holloa!” said he, “what does that mean?”	284.3728065299989
“If Monseigneur will have the goodness to tell me, in the first place,	298.34569921753973
what crimes are imputed to me, I will then tell him the deeds I have	242.9517390067508
really done.”	211.63815584993768
“Crimes are imputed to you which had brought down far loftier heads	290.334782109286
than yours, monsieur,” said the cardinal.	301.2242539772392
“What, monseigneur?” said D’Artagnan, with a calmness which astonished	190.5887200524455
the cardinal himself.	267.61665272623424
“You are charged with having corresponded with the enemies of the	354.90994280514803
kingdom; you are charged with having surprised state secrets; you are	237.97519349675918
charged with having tried to thwart the plans of your general.”	204.59831674703736
“And who charges me with this, monseigneur?” said D’Artagnan, who had	293.3341174324725
no doubt the accusation came from Milady, “a woman branded by the	227.94400034590365
justice of the country; a woman who has espoused one man in France and	349.0902060905905
another in England; a woman who poisoned her second husband and who	259.25571509283833
attempted both to poison and assassinate me!”	267.1298108845456
“What do you say, monsieur?” cried the cardinal, astonished; “and of	291.16363915211895
what woman are you speaking thus?”	233.01999021557765
“Of Milady de Winter,” replied D’Artagnan, “yes, of Milady de Winter,	244.63675790564378
of whose crimes your Eminence is doubtless ignorant, since you have	179.32812308021016
honored her with your confidence.”	316.33870853373037
“Monsieur,” said the cardinal, “if Milady de Winter has committed the	179.32698735319173
crimes you lay to her charge, she shall be punished.”	353.6925864145844
“She has been punished, monseigneur.”	241.40957594212267
“And who has punished her?”	295.56597305130504
“We.”	303.035419148193
“She is in prison?”	296.81767233051914
“She is dead.”	314.62354993886146
“Dead!” repeated the cardinal, who could not believe what he heard,	360.6188255440289
“dead! Did you not say she was dead?”	213.10279208682292
“Three times she attempted to kill me, and I pardoned her; but she	263.53861465898717
murdered the woman I loved. Then my friends and I took her, tried her,	279.9299902709764
and condemned her.”	309.3940695615849
D’Artagnan then related the poisoning of Mme. Bonacieux in the convent	338.09490951435123
of the Carmelites at Béthune, the trial in the isolated house, and the	238.67724093526996
execution on the banks of the Lys.	174.23569663521582
A shudder crept through the body of the cardinal, who did not shudder	264.3471594667012
readily.	306.1359219106007
But all at once, as if undergoing the influence of an unspoken thought,	176.3696946660876
the countenance of the cardinal, till then gloomy, cleared up by	363.0655001774195
degrees, and recovered perfect serenity.	251.0248224983794
“So,” said the cardinal, in a tone that contrasted strongly with the	270.8652799576967
severity of his words, “you have constituted yourselves judges, without	238.28622330104048
remembering that they who punish without license to punish are	340.4159571956748
assassins?”	197.49075870853943
“Monseigneur, I swear to you that I never for an instant had the	326.6132259494005
intention of defending my head against you. I willingly submit to any	174.02914118519996
punishment your Eminence may please to inflict upon me. I do not hold	197.38403389455408
life dear enough to be afraid of death.”	215.08466401572747
“Yes, I know you are a man of a stout heart, monsieur,” said the	340.55435043108525
cardinal, with a voice almost affectionate; “I can therefore tell you	351.42712508704483
beforehand you shall be tried, and even condemned.”	285.7947129205326
“Another might reply to your Eminence that he had his pardon in his	330.48497285847
pocket. I content myself with saying: Command, monseigneur; I am	216.2504839056867
ready.”	195.2813988815708
“Your pardon?” said Richelieu, surprised.	311.2151519696331
“Yes, monseigneur,” said D’Artagnan.	213.94367978611132
“And signed by whom—by the king?” And the cardinal pronounced these	357.7899942343327
words with a singular expression of contempt.	330.8138613314753
“No, by your Eminence.”	286.4042116380336
“By me? You are insane, monsieur.”	255.39061371060725
“Monseigneur will doubtless recognize his own handwriting.”	229.00913301900965
And D’Artagnan presented to the cardinal the precious piece of paper	351.1638460937197
which Athos had forced from Milady, and which he had given to	167.83234823293552
D’Artagnan to serve him as a safeguard.	286.68001640726527
His Eminence took the paper, and read in a slow voice, dwelling upon	356.69966678727485
every syllable:	282.97464401501907
“Dec. 3, 1627	178.46078432276047
“It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of	356.5175925196537
this has done what he has done.	242.510985189395
“RICHELIEU”	357.50854935704876
The cardinal, after having read these two lines, sank into a profound	317.39520462932774
reverie; but he did not return the paper to D’Artagnan.	294.6885806439068
“He is meditating by what sort of punishment he shall cause me to die,”	338.6684848497418
said the Gascon to himself. “Well, my faith! he shall see how a	257.0939760838922
gentleman can die.”	301.37735428594385
The young Musketeer was in excellent disposition to die heroically.	335.2353934873228
Richelieu still continued thinking, rolling and unrolling the paper in	259.92804790485053
his hands.	168.1786630354127
At length he raised his head, fixed his eagle look upon that loyal,	234.55723906171013
open, and intelligent countenance, read upon that face, furrowed with	279.0974338745134
tears, all the sufferings its possessor had endured in the course of a	207.81724817477334
month, and reflected for the third or fourth time how much there was in	348.61937269676116
that youth of twenty-one years before him, and what resources his	270.73323052069094
activity, his courage, and his shrewdness might offer to a good master.	195.26094180632458
On the other side, the crimes, the power, and the infernal genius of	310.395075327429
Milady had more than once terrified him. He felt something like a	308.6563713433894
secret joy at being forever relieved of this dangerous accomplice.	278.8960381554016
Richelieu slowly tore the paper which D’Artagnan had generously	233.29067646808147
relinquished.	310.0833151609859
“I am lost!” said D’Artagnan to himself. And he bowed profoundly before	335.62966588677097
the cardinal, like a man who says, “Lord, Thy will be done!”	317.0464559412926
The cardinal approached the table, and without sitting down, wrote a	261.52642392078724
few lines upon a parchment of which two-thirds were already filled, and	313.85982889268763
affixed his seal.	346.17513097557526
“That is my condemnation,” thought D’Artagnan; “he will spare me the	270.3324191711062
_ennui_ of the Bastille, or the tediousness of a trial. That’s very	336.23018125864337
kind of him.”	352.0291744273289
“Here, monsieur,” said the cardinal to the young man. “I have taken	229.16844134156588
from you one _carte blanche_ to give you another. The name is wanting	335.7598734746001
in this commission; you can write it yourself.”	168.64127883468845
D’Artagnan took the paper hesitatingly and cast his eyes over it; it	283.5317049906093
was a lieutenant’s commission in the Musketeers.	292.43305193840183
D’Artagnan fell at the feet of the cardinal.	318.64299562225943
“Monseigneur,” said he, “my life is yours; henceforth dispose of it.	228.03068452231952
But this favor which you bestow upon me I do not merit. I have three	255.21960142971852
friends who are more meritorious and more worthy—”	166.65109032826717
“You are a brave youth, D’Artagnan,” interrupted the cardinal, tapping	348.48915793979734
him familiarly on the shoulder, charmed at having vanquished this	248.20949820038524
rebellious nature. “Do with this commission what you will; only	347.5529229116873
remember, though the name be blank, it is to you I give it.”	329.9137811637302
“I shall never forget it,” replied D’Artagnan. “Your Eminence may be	206.93774821094638
certain of that.”	264.06343529546757
The cardinal turned and said in a loud voice, “Rochefort!” The	234.09103217344295
chevalier, who no doubt was near the door, entered immediately.	167.10686700855172
“Rochefort,” said the cardinal, “you see Monsieur d’Artagnan. I receive	343.1493988396023
him among the number of my friends. Greet each other, then; and be wise	196.0635747043092
if you wish to preserve your heads.”	289.66386709251714
Rochefort and D’Artagnan coolly greeted each other with their lips; but	249.8858366628611
the cardinal was there, observing them with his vigilant eye.	217.47581029367288
They left the chamber at the same time.	307.66596246068565
“We shall meet again, shall we not, monsieur?”	343.98589271061695
“When you please,” said D’Artagnan.	214.56730056351668
“An opportunity will come,” replied Rochefort.	236.886368906925
“Hey?” said the cardinal, opening the door.	248.96582778325148
The two men smiled at each other, shook hands, and saluted his	361.38974364676983
Eminence.	257.52813745414517
“We were beginning to grow impatient,” said Athos.	277.0451332464787
“Here I am, my friends,” replied D’Artagnan; “not only free, but in	181.50483404509515
favor.”	267.31667577790375
“Tell us about it.”	300.7823797535166
“This evening; but for the moment, let us separate.”	356.88415617467695
Accordingly, that same evening D’Artagnan repaired to the quarters of	194.49879665603075
Athos, whom he found in a fair way to empty a bottle of Spanish wine—an	265.69696929915983
occupation which he religiously accomplished every night.	203.66926153427247
D’Artagnan related what had taken place between the cardinal and	354.02481253307343
himself, and drawing the commission from his pocket, said, “Here, my	210.76541042956612
dear Athos, this naturally belongs to you.”	225.4350010937298
Athos smiled with one of his sweet and expressive smiles.	359.5774124578267
“Friend,” said he, “for Athos this is too much; for the Comte de la	344.916762073643
Fère it is too little. Keep the commission; it is yours. Alas! you have	288.3258731573619
purchased it dearly enough.”	181.97245330606262
D’Artagnan left Athos’s chamber and went to that of Porthos. He found	253.708729934901
him clothed in a magnificent dress covered with splendid embroidery,	354.8031651948101
admiring himself before a glass.	219.50339106311546
“Ah, ah! is that you, dear friend?” exclaimed Porthos. “How do you	280.1159832221009
think these garments fit me?”	192.4388602774907
“Wonderfully,” said D’Artagnan; “but I come to offer you a dress which	359.8081480430644
will become you still better.”	261.91867657545123
“What?” asked Porthos.	360.34874133431555
“That of a lieutenant of Musketeers.”	282.8114472543165
D’Artagnan related to Porthos the substance of his interview with the	343.06962600087337
cardinal, and said, taking the commission from his pocket, “Here, my	221.19765785031217
friend, write your name upon it and become my chief.”	300.67056848952456
Porthos cast his eyes over the commission and returned it to	249.74399595554036
D’Artagnan, to the great astonishment of the young man.	305.6511524071642
“Yes,” said he, “yes, that would flatter me very much; but I should not	290.7887404083582
have time enough to enjoy the distinction. During our expedition to	295.607000649322
Béthune the husband of my duchess died; so, my dear, the coffer of the	249.5042133346638
defunct holding out its arms to me, I shall marry the widow. Look here!	216.15174259236156
I was trying on my wedding suit. Keep the lieutenancy, my dear, keep	270.7423945688796
it.”	199.16409101892538
The young man then entered the apartment of Aramis. He found him	323.84012342978997
kneeling before a _priedieu_, with his head leaning on an open prayer	352.202829124968
book.	208.1742011556193
He described to him his interview with the cardinal, and said, for the	258.7833243715041
third time drawing his commission from his pocket, “You, our friend,	308.2147435521878
our intelligence, our invisible protector, accept this commission. You	194.34504189969783
have merited it more than any of us by your wisdom and your counsels,	212.70378126295446
always followed by such happy results.”	175.4262056288063
“Alas, dear friend!” said Aramis, “our late adventures have disgusted	180.5619853941995
me with military life. This time my determination is irrevocably taken.	245.6765896612875
After the siege I shall enter the house of the Lazarists. Keep the	351.66853746765094
commission, D’Artagnan; the profession of arms suits you. You will be a	216.7932103899757
brave and adventurous captain.”	215.75931524917854
D’Artagnan, his eye moist with gratitude though beaming with joy, went	342.62121660641606
back to Athos, whom he found still at table contemplating the charms of	249.4283056536286
his last glass of Malaga by the light of his lamp.	310.59944306173014
“Well,” said he, “they likewise have refused me.”	313.37181581444065
“That, dear friend, is because nobody is more worthy than yourself.”	316.54042569510557
He took a quill, wrote the name of D’Artagnan in the commission, and	363.5418268870736
returned it to him.	222.15932076691254
“I shall then have no more friends,” said the young man. “Alas! nothing	194.00646034892424
but bitter recollections.”	358.80372680316304
And he let his head sink upon his hands, while two large tears rolled	331.38466947756046
down his cheeks.	283.5404123097709
“You are young,” replied Athos; “and your bitter recollections have	332.3535085827965
time to change themselves into sweet remembrances.”	214.46815356790486
EPILOGUE	205.87344508035028
La Rochelle, deprived of the assistance of the English fleet and of the	306.5977884927437
diversion promised by Buckingham, surrendered after a siege of a year.	214.00280770153455
On the twenty-eighth of October, 1628, the capitulation was signed.	191.15642925904504
The king made his entrance into Paris on the twenty-third of December	201.27509493659358
of the same year. He was received in triumph, as if he came from	193.1995320560827
conquering an enemy and not Frenchmen. He entered by the Faubourg St.	228.6971166752355
Jacques, under verdant arches.	179.14906807111643
D’Artagnan took possession of his command. Porthos left the service,	250.15041636372314
and in the course of the following year married Mme. Coquenard; the	309.36846789097694
coffer so much coveted contained eight hundred thousand livres.	282.7662945318658
Mousqueton had a magnificent livery, and enjoyed the satisfaction of	167.2964371651138
which he had been ambitious all his life—that of standing behind a	289.86394712028107
gilded carriage.	184.96165631083178
Aramis, after a journey into Lorraine, disappeared all at once, and	301.6805746838808
ceased to write to his friends; they learned at a later period through	177.91984268314212
Mme. de Chevreuse, who told it to two or three of her intimates, that,	329.78705924226404
yielding to his vocation, he had retired into a convent—only into	239.0022756870829
which, nobody knew.	218.59298344243442
Bazin became a lay brother.	337.74577991010943
Athos remained a Musketeer under the command of D’Artagnan till the	191.65604312803194
year 1633, at which period, after a journey he made to Touraine, he	356.47189961187473
also quit the service, under the pretext of having inherited a small	284.887126371763
property in Roussillon.	232.73308841620891
Grimaud followed Athos.	283.3628110250154
D’Artagnan fought three times with Rochefort, and wounded him three	285.67688979640377
times.	340.862659106978
“I shall probably kill you the fourth,” said he to him, holding out his	346.53739377389513
hand to assist him to rise.	332.56855941292883
“It is much better both for you and for me to stop where we are,”	281.43130893227504
answered the wounded man. “_Corbleu!_ I am more your friend than you	207.71481985300608
think—for after our very first encounter, I could by saying a word to	315.86889515077064
the cardinal have had your throat cut!”	351.3481916294256
They this time embraced heartily, and without retaining any malice.	355.7974527288267
Planchet obtained from Rochefort the rank of sergeant in the Piedmont	356.7431529096976
regiment.	284.2295167313179
M. Bonacieux lived on very quietly, wholly ignorant of what had become	268.8892817846095
of his wife, and caring very little about it. One day he had the	208.0926692392019
imprudence to recall himself to the memory of the cardinal. The	243.7013009890233
cardinal had him informed that he would provide for him so that he	189.97774456250465
should never want for anything in future. In fact, M. Bonacieux, having	173.83916290519346
left his house at seven o’clock in the evening to go to the Louvre,	179.1883647517558
never appeared again in the Rue des Fossoyeurs; the opinion of those	255.32665137644102
who seemed to be best informed was that he was fed and lodged in some	186.7569216153058
royal castle, at the expense of his generous Eminence.	190.18062031903025
        	271.4034736743575
